    51	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTRANSCRIBER'S NOTES ON THE E-TEXT:
    52	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
    53	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis E-text was prepared from the Pelican Classics edition of Leviathan,
    54	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich in turn was prepared from the first edition. I have tried to
    55	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollow as closely as possible the original, and to give the flavour of
    56	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe text that Hobbes himself proof-read, but the following differences
    57	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere unavoidable.
    58	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
    59	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHobbes used capitals and italics very extensively, for emphasis, for
    60	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproper names, for quotations, and sometimes, it seems, just because.
    61	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
    62	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe original has very extensive margin notes, which are used to show
    63	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere he introduces the definitions of words and concepts, to give in
    64	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshort the subject that a paragraph or section is dealing with, and to
    65	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive references to his quotations, largely but not exclusively biblical.
    66	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo some degree, these margin notes seem to have been intended to serve
    67	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin place of an index, the original having none. They are all in italics.
    68	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
    69	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHe also used italics for words in other languages than English, and
    70	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere are a number of Greek words, in the Greek alphabet, in the text.
    71	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
    72	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo deal with these within the limits of plain vanilla ASCII, I have done
    73	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe following in this E-text.
    74	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
    75	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI have restricted my use of full capitalization to those places where
    76	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHobbes used it, except in the chapter headings, which I have fully
    77	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcapitalized, where Hobbes used a mixture of full capitalization and
    78	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\titalics.
    79	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
    80	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhere it is clear that the italics are to indicate the text is quoting,
    81	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI have introduced quotation marks. Within quotation marks I have
    82	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tretained the capitalization that Hobbes used.
    83	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
    84	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhere italics seem to be used for emphasis, or for proper names, or just
    85	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause, I have capitalized the initial letter of the words. This has
    86	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe disadvantage that they are not then distinguished from those that
    87	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHobbes capitalized in plain text, but the extent of his italics would
    88	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake the text very ugly if I was to use an underscore or slash.
    89	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
    90	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhere the margin notes are either to introduce the paragraph subject,
    91	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor to show where he introduces word definitions, I have included them as
    92	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theaders to the paragraph, again with all words having initial capitals,
    93	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand on a shortened line.
    94	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
    95	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor margin references to quotes, I have included them in the text,
    96	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin brackets immediately next to the quotation. Where Hobbes included
    97	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treferences in the main text, I have left them as he put them, except to
    98	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchange his square brackets to round.
    99	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the Greek alphabet, I have simply substituted the nearest ordinary
   101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tletters that I can, and I have used initial capitals for foreign
   102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlanguage words.
   103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeither Thomas Hobbes nor his typesetters seem to have had many
   105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinhibitions about spelling and punctuation. I have tried to reproduce
   106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth exactly, with the exception of the introduction of quotation marks.
   107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn preparing the text, I have found that it has much more meaning if
   109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI read it with sub-vocalization, or aloud, rather than trying to read
   110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsilently. Hobbes' use of emphasis and his eccentric punctuation and
   111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstruction seem then to work.
   112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTO MY MOST HONOR'D FRIEND Mr. FRANCIS GODOLPHIN of GODOLPHIN
   116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHONOR'D SIR.
   119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tYour most worthy Brother Mr SIDNEY GODOLPHIN, when he lived, was pleas'd
   121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto think my studies something, and otherwise to oblige me, as you know,
   122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith reall testimonies of his good opinion, great in themselves, and the
   123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreater for the worthinesse of his person. For there is not any vertue
   124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat disposeth a man, either to the service of God, or to the service
   125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his Country, to Civill Society, or private Friendship, that did not
   126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifestly appear in his conversation, not as acquired by necessity,
   127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor affected upon occasion, but inhaerent, and shining in a generous
   128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstitution of his nature. Therefore in honour and gratitude to him,
   129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand with devotion to your selfe, I humbly Dedicate unto you this my
   130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscourse of Common-wealth. I know not how the world will receive it,
   131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor how it may reflect on those that shall seem to favour it. For in a
   132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tway beset with those that contend on one side for too great Liberty, and
   133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton the other side for too much Authority, 'tis hard to passe between the
   134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpoints of both unwounded. But yet, me thinks, the endeavour to advance
   135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Civill Power, should not be by the Civill Power condemned; nor
   136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate men, by reprehending it, declare they think that Power too
   137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat. Besides, I speak not of the men, but (in the Abstract) of the
   138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeat of Power, (like to those simple and unpartiall creatures in the
   139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRoman Capitol, that with their noyse defended those within it, not
   140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause they were they, but there) offending none, I think, but those
   141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout, or such within (if there be any such) as favour them. That
   142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich perhaps may most offend, are certain Texts of Holy Scripture,
   143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talledged by me to other purpose than ordinarily they use to be by
   144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tothers. But I have done it with due submission, and also (in order to
   145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmy Subject) necessarily; for they are the Outworks of the Enemy, from
   146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhence they impugne the Civill Power. If notwithstanding this, you find
   147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmy labour generally decryed, you may be pleased to excuse your selfe,
   148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand say that I am a man that love my own opinions, and think all true I
   149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, that I honoured your Brother, and honour you, and have presum'd on
   150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat, to assume the Title (without your knowledge) of being, as I am,
   151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSir,
   153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tYour most humble, and most obedient servant, Thomas Hobbes.
   155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tParis APRILL 15/25 1651.

   306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTHE INTRODUCTION
   307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature (the art whereby God hath made and governes the world) is by the
   310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tart of man, as in many other things, so in this also imitated, that it
   311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan make an Artificial Animal. For seeing life is but a motion of Limbs,
   312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe begining whereof is in some principall part within; why may we not
   313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, that all Automata (Engines that move themselves by springs and
   314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twheeles as doth a watch) have an artificiall life? For what is the
   315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeart, but a Spring; and the Nerves, but so many Strings; and the
   316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJoynts, but so many Wheeles, giving motion to the whole Body, such as
   317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas intended by the Artificer? Art goes yet further, imitating that
   318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRationall and most excellent worke of Nature, Man. For by Art is created
   319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat great LEVIATHAN called a COMMON-WEALTH, or STATE, (in latine
   320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCIVITAS) which is but an Artificiall Man; though of greater stature
   321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand strength than the Naturall, for whose protection and defence it
   322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas intended; and in which, the Soveraignty is an Artificiall Soul, as
   323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiving life and motion to the whole body; The Magistrates, and other
   324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOfficers of Judicature and Execution, artificiall Joynts; Reward and
   325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishment (by which fastned to the seat of the Soveraignty, every joynt
   326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand member is moved to performe his duty) are the Nerves, that do the
   327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame in the Body Naturall; The Wealth and Riches of all the particular
   328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmembers, are the Strength; Salus Populi (the Peoples Safety) its
   329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBusinesse; Counsellors, by whom all things needfull for it to know,
   330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare suggested unto it, are the Memory; Equity and Lawes, an artificiall
   331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason and Will; Concord, Health; Sedition, Sicknesse; and Civill War,
   332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeath. Lastly, the Pacts and Covenants, by which the parts of this Body
   333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPolitique were at first made, set together, and united, resemble that
   334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFiat, or the Let Us Make Man, pronounced by God in the Creation.
   335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo describe the Nature of this Artificiall man, I will consider
   337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFirst the Matter thereof, and the Artificer; both which is Man.
   339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, How, and by what Covenants it is made; what are the Rights and
   341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjust Power or Authority of a Soveraigne; and what it is that Preserveth
   342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Dissolveth it.
   343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, what is a Christian Common-Wealth.
   345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, what is the Kingdome of Darkness.
   347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConcerning the first, there is a saying much usurped of late, That
   349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWisedome is acquired, not by reading of Books, but of Men. Consequently
   350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereunto, those persons, that for the most part can give no other proof
   351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof being wise, take great delight to shew what they think they have read
   352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin men, by uncharitable censures of one another behind their backs.
   353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut there is another saying not of late understood, by which they might
   354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlearn truly to read one another, if they would take the pains; and that
   355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, Nosce Teipsum, Read Thy Self: which was not meant, as it is now
   356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tused, to countenance, either the barbarous state of men in power,
   357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttowards their inferiors; or to encourage men of low degree, to a
   358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsawcie behaviour towards their betters; But to teach us, that for the
   359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsimilitude of the thoughts, and Passions of one man, to the thoughts,
   360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Passions of another, whosoever looketh into himselfe, and
   361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsidereth what he doth, when he does Think, Opine, Reason, Hope,
   362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFeare, &c, and upon what grounds; he shall thereby read and know,
   363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat are the thoughts, and Passions of all other men, upon the like
   364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toccasions. I say the similitude of Passions, which are the same in all
   365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, Desire, Feare, Hope, &c; not the similitude or The Objects of the
   366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions, which are the things Desired, Feared, Hoped, &c: for these the
   367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstitution individuall, and particular education do so vary, and they
   368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare so easie to be kept from our knowledge, that the characters of mans
   369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theart, blotted and confounded as they are, with dissembling, lying,
   370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcounterfeiting, and erroneous doctrines, are legible onely to him that
   371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsearcheth hearts. And though by mens actions wee do discover their
   372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesignee sometimes; yet to do it without comparing them with our own,
   373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand distinguishing all circumstances, by which the case may come to
   374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe altered, is to decypher without a key, and be for the most part
   375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeceived, by too much trust, or by too much diffidence; as he that
   376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treads, is himselfe a good or evill man.
   377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut let one man read another by his actions never so perfectly, it
   379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tserves him onely with his acquaintance, which are but few. He that is
   380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto govern a whole Nation, must read in himselfe, not this, or that
   381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular man; but Man-kind; which though it be hard to do, harder than
   382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto learn any Language, or Science; yet, when I shall have set down my
   383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town reading orderly, and perspicuously, the pains left another, will be
   384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely to consider, if he also find not the same in himselfe. For this
   385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkind of Doctrine, admitteth no other Demonstration.
   386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPART 1 OF MAN
   391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER I. OF SENSE
   396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConcerning the Thoughts of man, I will consider them first Singly, and
   399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafterwards in Trayne, or dependance upon one another. Singly, they
   400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare every one a Representation or Apparence, of some quality, or other
   401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAccident of a body without us; which is commonly called an Object. Which
   402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tObject worketh on the Eyes, Eares, and other parts of mans body; and by
   403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiversity of working, produceth diversity of Apparences.
   404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Originall of them all, is that which we call Sense; (For there is
   406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno conception in a mans mind, which hath not at first, totally, or by
   407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparts, been begotten upon the organs of Sense.) The rest are derived
   408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom that originall.
   409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo know the naturall cause of Sense, is not very necessary to the
   411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbusiness now in hand; and I have els-where written of the same at large.
   412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNevertheless, to fill each part of my present method, I will briefly
   413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeliver the same in this place.
   414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe cause of Sense, is the Externall Body, or Object, which presseth the
   416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\torgan proper to each Sense, either immediatly, as in the Tast and Touch;
   417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor mediately, as in Seeing, Hearing, and Smelling: which pressure, by
   418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe mediation of Nerves, and other strings, and membranes of the body,
   419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontinued inwards to the Brain, and Heart, causeth there a resistance,
   420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor counter-pressure, or endeavour of the heart, to deliver it self:
   421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich endeavour because Outward, seemeth to be some matter without. And
   422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Seeming, or Fancy, is that which men call sense; and consisteth, as
   423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Eye, in a Light, or Colour Figured; To the Eare, in a Sound; To
   424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Nostrill, in an Odour; To the Tongue and Palat, in a Savour; and
   425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the rest of the body, in Heat, Cold, Hardnesse, Softnesse, and such
   426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother qualities, as we discern by Feeling. All which qualities called
   427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSensible, are in the object that causeth them, but so many several
   428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmotions of the matter, by which it presseth our organs diversly. Neither
   429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin us that are pressed, are they anything els, but divers motions; (for
   430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmotion, produceth nothing but motion.) But their apparence to us is
   431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFancy, the same waking, that dreaming. And as pressing, rubbing,
   432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor striking the Eye, makes us fancy a light; and pressing the Eare,
   433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproduceth a dinne; so do the bodies also we see, or hear, produce the
   434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame by their strong, though unobserved action, For if those Colours,
   435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Sounds, were in the Bodies, or Objects that cause them, they could
   436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot bee severed from them, as by glasses, and in Ecchoes by reflection,
   437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twee see they are; where we know the thing we see, is in one place; the
   438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapparence, in another. And though at some certain distance, the reall,
   439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand very object seem invested with the fancy it begets in us; Yet still
   440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe object is one thing, the image or fancy is another. So that Sense in
   441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall cases, is nothing els but originall fancy, caused (as I have said)
   442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the pressure, that is, by the motion, of externall things upon our
   443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEyes, Eares, and other organs thereunto ordained.
   444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the Philosophy-schooles, through all the Universities of
   446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristendome, grounded upon certain Texts of Aristotle, teach another
   447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoctrine; and say, For the cause of Vision, that the thing seen, sendeth
   448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforth on every side a Visible Species(in English) a Visible Shew,
   449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApparition, or Aspect, or a Being Seen; the receiving whereof into the
   450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEye, is Seeing. And for the cause of Hearing, that the thing heard,
   451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsendeth forth an Audible Species, that is, an Audible Aspect, or Audible
   452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBeing Seen; which entring at the Eare, maketh Hearing. Nay for the
   453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcause of Understanding also, they say the thing Understood sendeth forth
   454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIntelligible Species, that is, an Intelligible Being Seen; which
   455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomming into the Understanding, makes us Understand. I say not this,
   456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas disapproving the use of Universities: but because I am to speak
   457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thereafter of their office in a Common-wealth, I must let you see on
   458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall occasions by the way, what things would be amended in them; amongst
   459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the frequency of insignificant Speech is one.
   460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER II. OF IMAGINATION
   464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat when a thing lies still, unlesse somewhat els stirre it, it will
   467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlye still for ever, is a truth that no man doubts of. But that when a
   468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing is in motion, it will eternally be in motion, unless somewhat els
   469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstay it, though the reason be the same, (namely, that nothing can change
   470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit selfe,) is not so easily assented to. For men measure, not onely
   471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother men, but all other things, by themselves: and because they find
   472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves subject after motion to pain, and lassitude, think every
   473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing els growes weary of motion, and seeks repose of its own accord;
   474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlittle considering, whether it be not some other motion, wherein that
   475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesire of rest they find in themselves, consisteth. From hence it is,
   476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat the Schooles say, Heavy bodies fall downwards, out of an appetite
   477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto rest, and to conserve their nature in that place which is most proper
   478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor them; ascribing appetite, and Knowledge of what is good for their
   479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconservation, (which is more than man has) to things inanimate absurdly.
   480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen a Body is once in motion, it moveth (unless something els hinder
   482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit) eternally; and whatsoever hindreth it, cannot in an instant, but in
   483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, and by degrees quite extinguish it: And as wee see in the water,
   484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough the wind cease, the waves give not over rowling for a long
   485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime after; so also it happeneth in that motion, which is made in the
   486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinternall parts of a man, then, when he Sees, Dreams, &c. For after the
   487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobject is removed, or the eye shut, wee still retain an image of the
   488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing seen, though more obscure than when we see it. And this is it,
   489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Latines call Imagination, from the image made in seeing; and apply
   490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same, though improperly, to all the other senses. But the Greeks
   491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcall it Fancy; which signifies Apparence, and is as proper to one sense,
   492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas to another. Imagination therefore is nothing but Decaying Sense; and
   493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis found in men, and many other living Creatures, as well sleeping, as
   494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twaking.
   495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMemory
   500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe decay of Sense in men waking, is not the decay of the motion made in
   502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense; but an obscuring of it, in such manner, as the light of the Sun
   503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobscureth the light of the Starres; which starrs do no less exercise
   504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir vertue by which they are visible, in the day, than in the night.
   505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut because amongst many stroaks, which our eyes, eares, and other
   506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\torgans receive from externall bodies, the predominant onely is sensible;
   507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore the light of the Sun being predominant, we are not affected
   508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the action of the starrs. And any object being removed from our
   509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teyes, though the impression it made in us remain; yet other objects more
   510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent succeeding, and working on us, the Imagination of the past is
   511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobscured, and made weak; as the voyce of a man is in the noyse of the
   512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tday. From whence it followeth, that the longer the time is, after the
   513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsight, or Sense of any object, the weaker is the Imagination. For the
   514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontinuall change of mans body, destroyes in time the parts which in
   515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense were moved: So that the distance of time, and of place, hath one
   516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the same effect in us. For as at a distance of place, that which wee
   517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlook at, appears dimme, and without distinction of the smaller parts;
   518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand as Voyces grow weak, and inarticulate: so also after great distance
   519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof time, our imagination of the Past is weak; and wee lose( for example)
   520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Cities wee have seen, many particular Streets; and of Actions, many
   521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular Circumstances. This Decaying Sense, when wee would express
   522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe thing it self, (I mean Fancy it selfe,) wee call Imagination, as I
   523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid before; But when we would express the Decay, and signifie that the
   524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSense is fading, old, and past, it is called Memory. So that Imagination
   525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Memory, are but one thing, which for divers considerations hath
   526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivers names.
   527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMuch memory, or memory of many things, is called Experience. Againe,
   529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImagination being only of those things which have been formerly
   530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperceived by Sense, either all at once, or by parts at severall
   531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimes; The former, (which is the imagining the whole object, as it was
   532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresented to the sense) is Simple Imagination; as when one imagineth a
   533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, or horse, which he hath seen before. The other is Compounded; as
   534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen from the sight of a man at one time, and of a horse at another, we
   535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconceive in our mind a Centaure. So when a man compoundeth the image of
   536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own person, with the image of the actions of an other man; as when a
   537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman imagins himselfe a Hercules, or an Alexander, (which happeneth often
   538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto them that are much taken with reading of Romants) it is a compound
   539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timagination, and properly but a Fiction of the mind. There be also other
   540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImaginations that rise in men, (though waking) from the great impression
   541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade in sense; As from gazing upon the Sun, the impression leaves an
   542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timage of the Sun before our eyes a long time after; and from being long
   543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand vehemently attent upon Geometricall Figures, a man shall in the
   544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdark, (though awake) have the Images of Lines, and Angles before his
   545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teyes: which kind of Fancy hath no particular name; as being a thing that
   546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoth not commonly fall into mens discourse.
   547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDreams
   552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe imaginations of them that sleep, are those we call Dreams. And these
   554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso (as all other Imaginations) have been before, either totally, or
   555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby parcells in the Sense. And because in sense, the Brain, and Nerves,
   556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich are the necessary Organs of sense, are so benummed in sleep, as
   557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot easily to be moved by the action of Externall Objects, there can
   558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thappen in sleep, no Imagination; and therefore no Dreame, but what
   559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceeds from the agitation of the inward parts of mans body; which
   560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinward parts, for the connexion they have with the Brayn, and other
   561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOrgans, when they be distempered, do keep the same in motion; whereby
   562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Imaginations there formerly made, appeare as if a man were waking;
   563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaving that the Organs of Sense being now benummed, so as there is
   564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno new object, which can master and obscure them with a more vigorous
   565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpression, a Dreame must needs be more cleare, in this silence of
   566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense, than are our waking thoughts. And hence it cometh to pass, that
   567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is a hard matter, and by many thought impossible to distinguish
   568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texactly between Sense and Dreaming. For my part, when I consider, that
   569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Dreames, I do not often, nor constantly think of the same Persons,
   570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPlaces, Objects, and Actions that I do waking; nor remember so long a
   571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrayne of coherent thoughts, Dreaming, as at other times; And because
   572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twaking I often observe the absurdity of Dreames, but never dream of
   573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe absurdities of my waking Thoughts; I am well satisfied, that being
   574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tawake, I know I dreame not; though when I dreame, I think my selfe
   575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tawake.
   576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd seeing dreames are caused by the distemper of some of the inward
   578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparts of the Body; divers distempers must needs cause different Dreams.
   579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd hence it is, that lying cold breedeth Dreams of Feare, and raiseth
   580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe thought and Image of some fearfull object (the motion from the
   581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbrain to the inner parts, and from the inner parts to the Brain being
   582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treciprocall:) and that as Anger causeth heat in some parts of the Body,
   583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen we are awake; so when we sleep, the over heating of the same parts
   584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcauseth Anger, and raiseth up in the brain the Imagination of an Enemy.
   585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the same manner; as naturall kindness, when we are awake causeth
   586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesire; and desire makes heat in certain other parts of the body; so
   587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso, too much heat in those parts, while wee sleep, raiseth in the
   588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbrain an imagination of some kindness shewn. In summe, our Dreams are
   589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe reverse of our waking Imaginations; The motion when we are awake,
   590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeginning at one end; and when we Dream, at another.
   591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApparitions Or Visions
   596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe most difficult discerning of a mans Dream, from his waking thoughts,
   598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis then, when by some accident we observe not that we have slept:
   599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is easie to happen to a man full of fearfull thoughts; and
   600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose conscience is much troubled; and that sleepeth, without the
   601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcircumstances, of going to bed, or putting off his clothes, as one that
   602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnoddeth in a chayre. For he that taketh pains, and industriously layes
   603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe to sleep, in case any uncouth and exorbitant fancy come unto
   604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, cannot easily think it other than a Dream. We read of Marcus
   605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBrutes, (one that had his life given him by Julius Caesar, and was also
   606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this favorite, and notwithstanding murthered him,) how at Phillipi,
   607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe night before he gave battell to Augustus Caesar, he saw a fearfull
   608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapparition, which is commonly related by Historians as a Vision: but
   609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsidering the circumstances, one may easily judge to have been but
   610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta short Dream. For sitting in his tent, pensive and troubled with the
   611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thorrour of his rash act, it was not hard for him, slumbering in the
   612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcold, to dream of that which most affrighted him; which feare, as by
   613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdegrees it made him wake; so also it must needs make the Apparition by
   614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdegrees to vanish: And having no assurance that he slept, he could have
   615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno cause to think it a Dream, or any thing but a Vision. And this is no
   616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery rare Accident: for even they that be perfectly awake, if they be
   617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimorous, and supperstitious, possessed with fearfull tales, and alone
   618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the dark, are subject to the like fancies, and believe they see
   619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspirits and dead mens Ghosts walking in Churchyards; whereas it is
   620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither their Fancy onely, or els the knavery of such persons, as make
   621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuse of such superstitious feare, to pass disguised in the night, to
   622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaces they would not be known to haunt.
   623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom this ignorance of how to distinguish Dreams, and other strong
   625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFancies, from vision and Sense, did arise the greatest part of the
   626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion of the Gentiles in time past, that worshipped Satyres, Fawnes,
   627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnymphs, and the like; and now adayes the opinion than rude people have
   628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Fayries, Ghosts, and Goblins; and of the power of Witches. For as for
   629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitches, I think not that their witch craft is any reall power; but yet
   630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat they are justly punished, for the false beliefe they have, that
   631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey can do such mischiefe, joyned with their purpose to do it if they
   632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan; their trade being neerer to a new Religion, than to a Craft or
   633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScience. And for Fayries, and walking Ghosts, the opinion of them has I
   634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthink been on purpose, either taught, or not confuted, to keep in
   635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcredit the use of Exorcisme, of Crosses, of holy Water, and other such
   636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinventions of Ghostly men. Neverthelesse, there is no doubt, but God can
   637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake unnaturall Apparitions. But that he does it so often, as men need
   638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto feare such things, more than they feare the stay, or change, of the
   639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcourse of Nature, which he also can stay, and change, is no point of
   640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian faith. But evill men under pretext that God can do any thing,
   641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare so bold as to say any thing when it serves their turn, though
   642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey think it untrue; It is the part of a wise man, to believe them no
   643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfurther, than right reason makes that which they say, appear credible.
   644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf this superstitious fear of Spirits were taken away, and with it,
   645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrognostiques from Dreams, false Prophecies, and many other things
   646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdepending thereon, by which, crafty ambitious persons abuse the
   647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsimple people, men would be much more fitted than they are for civill
   648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tObedience.
   649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd this ought to be the work of the Schooles; but they rather nourish
   651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch doctrine. For (not knowing what Imagination, or the Senses are),
   652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat they receive, they teach: some saying, that Imaginations rise of
   653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, and have no cause: Others that they rise most commonly from
   654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Will; and that Good thoughts are blown (inspired) into a man, by
   655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod; and evill thoughts by the Divell: or that Good thoughts are powred
   656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(infused) into a man, by God; and evill ones by the Divell. Some say
   657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Senses receive the Species of things, and deliver them to the
   658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-sense; and the Common Sense delivers them over to the Fancy, and
   659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Fancy to the Memory, and the Memory to the Judgement, like
   660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thanding of things from one to another, with many words making nothing
   661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood.
   662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUnderstanding
   667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Imagination that is raysed in man (or any other creature indued with
   669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe faculty of imagining) by words, or other voluntary signes, is that
   670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe generally call Understanding; and is common to Man and Beast. For a
   671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdogge by custome will understand the call, or the rating of his Master;
   672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand so will many other Beasts. That Understanding which is peculiar to
   673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, is the Understanding not onely his will; but his conceptions and
   674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthoughts, by the sequell and contexture of the names of things into
   675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAffirmations, Negations, and other formes of Speech: And of this kinde
   676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Understanding I shall speak hereafter.
   677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER III. OF THE CONSEQUENCE OR TRAYNE OF IMAGINATIONS
   681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Consequence, or Trayne of Thoughts, I understand that succession
   684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof one Thought to another, which is called (to distinguish it from
   685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDiscourse in words) Mentall Discourse.
   686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen a man thinketh on any thing whatsoever, His next Thought after, is
   688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot altogether so casuall as it seems to be. Not every Thought to every
   689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThought succeeds indifferently. But as wee have no Imagination, whereof
   690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe have not formerly had Sense, in whole, or in parts; so we have no
   691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTransition from one Imagination to another, whereof we never had the
   692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike before in our Senses. The reason whereof is this. All Fancies
   693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Motions within us, reliques of those made in the Sense: And those
   694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmotions that immediately succeeded one another in the sense, continue
   695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso together after Sense: In so much as the former comming again to
   696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake place, and be praedominant, the later followeth, by coherence of
   697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe matter moved, is such manner, as water upon a plain Table is drawn
   698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich way any one part of it is guided by the finger. But because
   699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin sense, to one and the same thing perceived, sometimes one thing,
   700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes another succeedeth, it comes to passe in time, that in the
   701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImagining of any thing, there is no certainty what we shall Imagine
   702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnext; Onely this is certain, it shall be something that succeeded the
   703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame before, at one time or another.
   704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTrayne Of Thoughts Unguided
   709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis Trayne of Thoughts, or Mentall Discourse, is of two sorts. The
   711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst is Unguided, Without Designee, and inconstant; Wherein there is no
   712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassionate Thought, to govern and direct those that follow, to it self,
   713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas the end and scope of some desire, or other passion: In which case the
   714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthoughts are said to wander, and seem impertinent one to another, as
   715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin a Dream. Such are Commonly the thoughts of men, that are not onely
   716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout company, but also without care of any thing; though even then
   717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Thoughts are as busie as at other times, but without harmony; as
   718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe sound which a Lute out of tune would yeeld to any man; or in tune,
   719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto one that could not play. And yet in this wild ranging of the mind,
   720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man may oft-times perceive the way of it, and the dependance of one
   721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought upon another. For in a Discourse of our present civill warre,
   722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat could seem more impertinent, than to ask (as one did) what was the
   723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvalue of a Roman Penny? Yet the Cohaerence to me was manifest enough.
   724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the Thought of the warre, introduced the Thought of the delivering
   725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tup the King to his Enemies; The Thought of that, brought in the Thought
   726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the delivering up of Christ; and that again the Thought of the 30
   727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpence, which was the price of that treason: and thence easily followed
   728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat malicious question; and all this in a moment of time; for Thought
   729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis quick.
   730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTrayne Of Thoughts Regulated
   735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe second is more constant; as being Regulated by some desire, and
   737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesignee. For the impression made by such things as wee desire, or
   738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfeare, is strong, and permanent, or, (if it cease for a time,) of quick
   739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treturn: so strong it is sometimes, as to hinder and break our sleep.
   740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom Desire, ariseth the Thought of some means we have seen produce the
   741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike of that which we ayme at; and from the thought of that, the
   742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought of means to that mean; and so continually, till we come to some
   743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeginning within our own power. And because the End, by the greatnesse
   744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the impression, comes often to mind, in case our thoughts begin to
   745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twander, they are quickly again reduced into the way: which observed by
   746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone of the seven wise men, made him give men this praecept, which is
   747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnow worne out, Respice Finem; that is to say, in all your actions,
   748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlook often upon what you would have, as the thing that directs all your
   749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthoughts in the way to attain it.
   750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRemembrance
   755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Trayn of regulated Thoughts is of two kinds; One, when of an effect
   757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timagined, wee seek the causes, or means that produce it: and this
   758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis common to Man and Beast. The other is, when imagining any thing
   759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever, wee seek all the possible effects, that can by it be
   760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproduced; that is to say, we imagine what we can do with it, when wee
   761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave it. Of which I have not at any time seen any signe, but in man
   762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely; for this is a curiosity hardly incident to the nature of any
   763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tliving creature that has no other Passion but sensuall, such as are
   764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thunger, thirst, lust, and anger. In summe, the Discourse of the Mind,
   765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen it is governed by designee, is nothing but Seeking, or the faculty
   766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Invention, which the Latines call Sagacitas, and Solertia; a hunting
   767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of the causes, of some effect, present or past; or of the effects,
   768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof some present or past cause, sometimes a man seeks what he hath lost;
   769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand from that place, and time, wherein hee misses it, his mind runs
   770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tback, from place to place, and time to time, to find where, and when
   771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the had it; that is to say, to find some certain, and limited time and
   772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace, in which to begin a method of seeking. Again, from thence, his
   773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthoughts run over the same places and times, to find what action, or
   774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother occasion might make him lose it. This we call Remembrance,
   775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Calling to mind: the Latines call it Reminiscentia, as it were a
   776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRe-Conning of our former actions.
   777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSometimes a man knows a place determinate, within the compasse whereof
   779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this is to seek; and then his thoughts run over all the parts thereof,
   780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the same manner, as one would sweep a room, to find a jewell; or as
   781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Spaniel ranges the field, till he find a sent; or as a man should run
   782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover the alphabet, to start a rime.
   783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrudence
   788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSometime a man desires to know the event of an action; and then he
   790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthinketh of some like action past, and the events thereof one after
   791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother; supposing like events will follow like actions. As he that
   792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforesees what wil become of a Criminal, re-cons what he has seen follow
   793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton the like Crime before; having this order of thoughts, The Crime,
   794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Officer, the Prison, the Judge, and the Gallowes. Which kind
   795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof thoughts, is called Foresight, and Prudence, or Providence; and
   796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes Wisdome; though such conjecture, through the difficulty of
   797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserving all circumstances, be very fallacious. But this is certain; by
   798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thow much one man has more experience of things past, than another; by
   799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso much also he is more Prudent, and his expectations the seldomer faile
   800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim. The Present onely has a being in Nature; things Past have a being
   801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Memory onely, but things To Come have no being at all; the Future
   802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing but a fiction of the mind, applying the sequels of actions Past,
   803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the actions that are Present; which with most certainty is done by
   804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim that has most Experience; but not with certainty enough. And though
   805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit be called Prudence, when the Event answereth our Expectation; yet in
   806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tits own nature, it is but Presumption. For the foresight of things to
   807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome, which is Providence, belongs onely to him by whose will they are
   808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto come. From him onely, and supernaturally, proceeds Prophecy. The best
   809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphet naturally is the best guesser; and the best guesser, he that is
   810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost versed and studied in the matters he guesses at: for he hath most
   811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignes to guesse by.
   812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignes
   817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Signe, is the Event Antecedent, of the Consequent; and contrarily,
   819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Consequent of the Antecedent, when the like Consequences have been
   820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserved, before: And the oftner they have been observed, the lesse
   821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuncertain is the Signe. And therefore he that has most experience in
   822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany kind of businesse, has most Signes, whereby to guesse at the Future
   823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, and consequently is the most prudent: And so much more prudent
   824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan he that is new in that kind of business, as not to be equalled by
   825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany advantage of naturall and extemporary wit: though perhaps many young
   826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen think the contrary.
   827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse it is not Prudence that distinguisheth man from beast.
   829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere be beasts, that at a year old observe more, and pursue that which
   830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis for their good, more prudently, than a child can do at ten.
   831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConjecture Of The Time Past
   836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs Prudence is a Praesumtion of the Future, contracted from the
   838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExperience of time Past; So there is a Praesumtion of things Past taken
   839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom other things (not future but) past also. For he that hath seen
   840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby what courses and degrees, a flourishing State hath first come into
   841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcivill warre, and then to ruine; upon the sights of the ruines of any
   842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother State, will guesse, the like warre, and the like courses have been
   843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere also. But his conjecture, has the same incertainty almost with the
   844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconjecture of the Future; both being grounded onely upon Experience.
   845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere is no other act of mans mind, that I can remember, naturally
   847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplanted in him, so, as to need no other thing, to the exercise of it,
   848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut to be born a man, and live with the use of his five Senses. Those
   849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Faculties, of which I shall speak by and by, and which seem proper
   850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto man onely, are acquired, and encreased by study and industry; and of
   851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost men learned by instruction, and discipline; and proceed all from
   852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe invention of Words, and Speech. For besides Sense, and Thoughts, and
   853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Trayne of thoughts, the mind of man has no other motion; though by
   854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe help of Speech, and Method, the same Facultyes may be improved to
   855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch a height, as to distinguish men from all other living Creatures.
   856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhatsoever we imagine, is Finite. Therefore there is no Idea, or
   858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconception of anything we call Infinite. No man can have in his mind an
   859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImage of infinite magnitude; nor conceive the ends, and bounds of
   860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe thing named; having no Conception of the thing, but of our own
   861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinability. And therefore the Name of GOD is used, not to make us
   862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconceive him; (for he is Incomprehensible; and his greatnesse, and power
   863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare unconceivable;) but that we may honour him. Also because whatsoever
   864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as I said before,) we conceive, has been perceived first by sense,
   865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither all at once, or by parts; a man can have no thought, representing
   866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany thing, not subject to sense. No man therefore can conceive any
   867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing, but he must conceive it in some place; and indued with some
   868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeterminate magnitude; and which may be divided into parts; nor that any
   869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing is all in this place, and all in another place at the same time;
   870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor that two, or more things can be in one, and the same place at once:
   871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor none of these things ever have, or can be incident to Sense; but are
   872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsurd speeches, taken upon credit (without any signification at all,)
   873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom deceived Philosophers, and deceived, or deceiving Schoolemen.
   874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER IV. OF SPEECH
   878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOriginall Of Speech
   883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Invention of Printing, though ingenious, compared with the invention
   885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Letters, is no great matter. But who was the first that found the use
   886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Letters, is not known. He that first brought them into Greece, men
   887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay was Cadmus, the sonne of Agenor, King of Phaenicia. A profitable
   888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInvention for continuing the memory of time past, and the conjunction of
   889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmankind, dispersed into so many, and distant regions of the Earth; and
   890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith all difficult, as proceeding from a watchfull observation of the
   891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivers motions of the Tongue, Palat, Lips, and other organs of Speech;
   892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereby to make as many differences of characters, to remember them.
   893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the most noble and profitable invention of all other, was that of
   894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpeech, consisting of Names or Apellations, and their Connexion; whereby
   895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen register their Thoughts; recall them when they are past; and also
   896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeclare them one to another for mutuall utility and conversation;
   897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout which, there had been amongst men, neither Common-wealth, nor
   898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSociety, nor Contract, nor Peace, no more than amongst Lyons, Bears,
   899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Wolves. The first author of Speech was GOD himselfe, that instructed
   900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdam how to name such creatures as he presented to his sight; For the
   901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture goeth no further in this matter. But this was sufficient
   902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto direct him to adde more names, as the experience and use of the
   903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcreatures should give him occasion; and to joyn them in such manner by
   904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdegrees, as to make himselfe understood; and so by succession of time,
   905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso much language might be gotten, as he had found use for; though not so
   906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcopious, as an Orator or Philosopher has need of. For I do not find any
   907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing in the Scripture, out of which, directly or by consequence can
   908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe gathered, that Adam was taught the names of all Figures, Numbers,
   909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMeasures, Colours, Sounds, Fancies, Relations; much less the names
   910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Words and Speech, as Generall, Speciall, Affirmative, Negative,
   911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterrogative, Optative, Infinitive, all which are usefull; and least of
   912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall, of Entity, Intentionality, Quiddity, and other significant words of
   913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe School.
   914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut all this language gotten, and augmented by Adam and his posterity,
   916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas again lost at the tower of Babel, when by the hand of God, every man
   917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas stricken for his rebellion, with an oblivion of his former language.
   918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd being hereby forced to disperse themselves into severall parts of
   919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe world, it must needs be, that the diversity of Tongues that now is,
   920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceeded by degrees from them, in such manner, as need (the mother of
   921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall inventions) taught them; and in tract of time grew every where more
   922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcopious.
   923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Use Of Speech
   928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe generall use of Speech, is to transferre our Mentall Discourse, into
   930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVerbal; or the Trayne of our Thoughts, into a Trayne of Words; and that
   931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor two commodities; whereof one is, the Registring of the Consequences
   932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof our Thoughts; which being apt to slip out of our memory, and put
   933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tus to a new labour, may again be recalled, by such words as they were
   934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmarked by. So that the first use of names, is to serve for Markes,
   935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Notes of remembrance. Another is, when many use the same words,
   936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto signifie (by their connexion and order,) one to another, what they
   937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconceive, or think of each matter; and also what they desire, feare,
   938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor have any other passion for, and for this use they are called
   939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignes. Speciall uses of Speech are these; First, to Register, what by
   940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcogitation, wee find to be the cause of any thing, present or past; and
   941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat we find things present or past may produce, or effect: which in
   942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsumme, is acquiring of Arts. Secondly, to shew to others that knowledge
   943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich we have attained; which is, to Counsell, and Teach one another.
   944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, to make known to others our wills, and purposes, that we may
   945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave the mutuall help of one another. Fourthly, to please and delight
   946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour selves, and others, by playing with our words, for pleasure or
   947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tornament, innocently.
   948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbuses Of Speech
   953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo these Uses, there are also foure correspondent Abuses. First,
   955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen men register their thoughts wrong, by the inconstancy of the
   956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignification of their words; by which they register for their
   957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconceptions, that which they never conceived; and so deceive themselves.
   958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, when they use words metaphorically; that is, in other sense
   959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan that they are ordained for; and thereby deceive others. Thirdly,
   960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen by words they declare that to be their will, which is not.
   961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, when they use them to grieve one another: for seeing nature
   962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath armed living creatures, some with teeth, some with horns, and some
   963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith hands, to grieve an enemy, it is but an abuse of Speech, to grieve
   964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim with the tongue, unlesse it be one whom wee are obliged to govern;
   965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand then it is not to grieve, but to correct and amend.
   966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe manner how Speech serveth to the remembrance of the consequence
   968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof causes and effects, consisteth in the imposing of Names, and the
   969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConnexion of them.
   970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNames Proper & Common Universall
   975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Names, some are Proper, and singular to one onely thing; as Peter,
   977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJohn, This Man, This Tree: and some are Common to many things; as Man,
   978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHorse, Tree; every of which though but one Name, is nevertheless the
   979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of divers particular things; in respect of all which together, it
   980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis called an Universall; there being nothing in the world Universall
   981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut Names; for the things named, are every one of them Individual and
   982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSingular.
   983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOne Universall name is imposed on many things, for their similitude in
   985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome quality, or other accident: And whereas a Proper Name bringeth to
   986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmind one thing onely; Universals recall any one of those many.
   987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd of Names Universall, some are of more, and some of lesse extent; the
   989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlarger comprehending the lesse large: and some again of equall extent,
   990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomprehending each other reciprocally. As for example, the Name Body is
   991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof larger signification than the word Man, and conprehendeth it; and the
   992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnames Man and Rationall, are of equall extent, comprehending mutually
   993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone another. But here wee must take notice, that by a Name is not
   994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talwayes understood, as in Grammar, one onely word; but sometimes by
   995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcircumlocution many words together. For all these words, Hee That In
   996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHis Actions Observeth The Lawes Of His Country, make but one Name,
   997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequivalent to this one word, Just.
   998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
   999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy this imposition of Names, some of larger, some of stricter
  1000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignification, we turn the reckoning of the consequences of things
  1001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timagined in the mind, into a reckoning of the consequences of
  1002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAppellations. For example, a man that hath no use of Speech at all,
  1003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(such, as is born and remains perfectly deafe and dumb,) if he set
  1004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore his eyes a triangle, and by it two right angles, (such as are the
  1005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcorners of a square figure,) he may by meditation compare and find, that
  1006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe three angles of that triangle, are equall to those two right angles
  1007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat stand by it. But if another triangle be shewn him different in
  1008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshape from the former, he cannot know without a new labour, whether the
  1009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthree angles of that also be equall to the same. But he that hath the
  1010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuse of words, when he observes, that such equality was consequent, not
  1011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the length of the sides, nor to any other particular thing in his
  1012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttriangle; but onely to this, that the sides were straight, and the
  1013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tangles three; and that that was all, for which he named it a Triangle;
  1014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill boldly conclude Universally, that such equality of angles is in
  1015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall triangles whatsoever; and register his invention in these generall
  1016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttermes, Every Triangle Hath Its Three Angles Equall To Two Right Angles.
  1017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd thus the consequence found in one particular, comes to be registred
  1018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand remembred, as a Universall rule; and discharges our mentall
  1019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treckoning, of time and place; and delivers us from all labour of the
  1020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmind, saving the first; and makes that which was found true Here, and
  1021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNow, to be true in All Times and Places.
  1022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the use of words in registring our thoughts, is in nothing so
  1024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevident as in Numbering. A naturall foole that could never learn by
  1025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theart the order of numerall words, as One, Two, and Three, may observe
  1026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery stroak of the Clock, and nod to it, or say one, one, one; but can
  1027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnever know what houre it strikes. And it seems, there was a time when
  1028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose names of number were not in use; and men were fayn to apply their
  1029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfingers of one or both hands, to those things they desired to keep
  1030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccount of; and that thence it proceeded, that now our numerall words
  1031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare but ten, in any Nation, and in some but five, and then they begin
  1032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain. And he that can tell ten, if he recite them out of order, will
  1033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlose himselfe, and not know when he has done: Much lesse will he be
  1034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\table to add, and substract, and performe all other operations of
  1035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArithmetique. So that without words, there is no possibility of
  1036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treckoning of Numbers; much lesse of Magnitudes, of Swiftnesse, of Force,
  1037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand other things, the reckonings whereof are necessary to the being, or
  1038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twell-being of man-kind.
  1039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen two Names are joyned together into a Consequence, or Affirmation;
  1041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas thus, A Man Is A Living Creature; or thus, If He Be A Man, He Is A
  1042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiving Creature, If the later name Living Creature, signifie all that
  1043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe former name Man signifieth, then the affirmation, or consequence is
  1044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTrue; otherwise False. For True and False are attributes of Speech, not
  1045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof things. And where Speech in not, there is neither Truth nor Falshood.
  1046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tErrour there may be, as when wee expect that which shall not be; or
  1047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuspect what has not been: but in neither case can a man be charged with
  1048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUntruth.
  1049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing then that Truth consisteth in the right ordering of names in our
  1051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taffirmations, a man that seeketh precise Truth, had need to remember
  1052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat every name he uses stands for; and to place it accordingly; or els
  1053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the will find himselfe entangled in words, as a bird in lime-twiggs; the
  1054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore he struggles, the more belimed. And therefore in Geometry, (which
  1055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the onely Science that it hath pleased God hitherto to bestow on
  1056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmankind,) men begin at settling the significations of their words; which
  1057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsettling of significations, they call Definitions; and place them in the
  1058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeginning of their reckoning.
  1059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy this it appears how necessary it is for any man that aspires to true
  1061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKnowledge, to examine the Definitions of former Authors; and either
  1062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto correct them, where they are negligently set down; or to make them
  1063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe. For the errours of Definitions multiply themselves, according
  1064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas the reckoning proceeds; and lead men into absurdities, which at last
  1065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey see, but cannot avoyd, without reckoning anew from the beginning;
  1066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin which lyes the foundation of their errours. From whence it happens,
  1067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat they which trust to books, do as they that cast up many little
  1068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsumms into a greater, without considering whether those little summes
  1069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere rightly cast up or not; and at last finding the errour visible,
  1070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand not mistrusting their first grounds, know not which way to cleere
  1071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves; but spend time in fluttering over their bookes; as birds
