  1072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat entring by the chimney, and finding themselves inclosed in a
  1073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchamber, flitter at the false light of a glasse window, for want of wit
  1074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto consider which way they came in. So that in the right Definition
  1075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Names, lyes the first use of Speech; which is the Acquisition of
  1076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScience: And in wrong, or no Definitions' lyes the first abuse; from
  1077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich proceed all false and senslesse Tenets; which make those men that
  1078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake their instruction from the authority of books, and not from their
  1079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town meditation, to be as much below the condition of ignorant men, as
  1080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen endued with true Science are above it. For between true Science,
  1081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand erroneous Doctrines, Ignorance is in the middle. Naturall sense and
  1082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timagination, are not subject to absurdity. Nature it selfe cannot erre:
  1083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand as men abound in copiousnesse of language; so they become more wise,
  1084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor more mad than ordinary. Nor is it possible without Letters for any
  1085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman to become either excellently wise, or (unless his memory be hurt by
  1086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisease, or ill constitution of organs) excellently foolish. For words
  1087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare wise mens counters, they do but reckon by them: but they are the
  1088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmony of fooles, that value them by the authority of an Aristotle, a
  1089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCicero, or a Thomas, or any other Doctor whatsoever, if but a man.
  1090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubject To Names
  1095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubject To Names, is whatsoever can enter into, or be considered in an
  1097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccount; and be added one to another to make a summe; or substracted one
  1098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom another, and leave a remainder. The Latines called Accounts of mony
  1099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRationes, and accounting, Ratiocinatio: and that which we in bills or
  1100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbooks of account call Items, they called Nomina; that is, Names: and
  1101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthence it seems to proceed, that they extended the word Ratio, to the
  1102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaculty of Reckoning in all other things. The Greeks have but one word
  1103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLogos, for both Speech and Reason; not that they thought there was no
  1104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpeech without Reason; but no Reasoning without Speech: And the act of
  1105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasoning they called syllogisme; which signifieth summing up of the
  1106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequences of one saying to another. And because the same things may
  1107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenter into account for divers accidents; their names are (to shew that
  1108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiversity) diversly wrested, and diversified. This diversity of names
  1109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay be reduced to foure generall heads.
  1110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFirst, a thing may enter into account for Matter, or Body; as Living,
  1112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSensible, Rationall, Hot, Cold, Moved, Quiet; with all which names the
  1113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tword Matter, or Body is understood; all such, being names of Matter.
  1114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, it may enter into account, or be considered, for some accident
  1116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor quality, which we conceive to be in it; as for Being Moved, for Being
  1117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo Long, for Being Hot, &c; and then, of the name of the thing it selfe,
  1118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby a little change or wresting, wee make a name for that accident, which
  1119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe consider; and for Living put into account Life; for Moved, Motion;
  1120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Hot, Heat; for Long, Length, and the like. And all such Names, are
  1121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe names of the accidents and properties, by which one Matter, and Body
  1122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis distinguished from another. These are called Names Abstract; Because
  1123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSevered (not from Matter, but) from the account of Matter.
  1124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, we bring into account, the Properties of our own bodies,
  1126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereby we make such distinction: as when any thing is Seen by us, we
  1127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treckon not the thing it selfe; but the Sight, the Colour, the Idea of
  1128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit in the fancy: and when any thing is Heard, wee reckon it not; but the
  1129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHearing, or Sound onely, which is our fancy or conception of it by the
  1130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEare: and such are names of fancies.
  1131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, we bring into account, consider, and give names, to Names
  1133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, and to Speeches: For, Generall, Universall, Speciall,
  1134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOequivocall, are names of Names. And Affirmation, Interrogation,
  1135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandement, Narration, Syllogisme, Sermon, Oration, and many other
  1136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch, are names of Speeches.
  1137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUse Of Names Positive
  1142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd this is all the variety of Names Positive; which are put to mark
  1144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsomewhat which is in Nature, or may be feigned by the mind of man, as
  1145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBodies that are, or may be conceived to be; or of bodies, the Properties
  1146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat are, or may be feigned to be; or Words and Speech.
  1147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNegative Names With Their Uses
  1152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere be also other Names, called Negative; which are notes to signifie
  1154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat a word is not the name of the thing in question; as these words
  1155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNothing, No Man, Infinite, Indocible, Three Want Foure, and the
  1156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike; which are nevertheless of use in reckoning, or in correcting of
  1157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treckoning; and call to mind our past cogitations, though they be not
  1158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnames of any thing; because they make us refuse to admit of Names not
  1159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trightly used.
  1160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWords Insignificant
  1165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll other names, are but insignificant sounds; and those of two
  1167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsorts. One, when they are new, and yet their meaning not explained by
  1168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDefinition; whereof there have been aboundance coyned by Schoole-men,
  1169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand pusled Philosophers.
  1170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother, when men make a name of two Names, whose significations are
  1172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontradictory and inconsistent; as this name, an Incorporeall Body, or
  1173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which is all one) an Incorporeall Substance, and a great number more.
  1174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor whensoever any affirmation is false, the two names of which it
  1175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis composed, put together and made one, signifie nothing at all. For
  1176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texample if it be a false affirmation to say A Quadrangle Is Round,
  1177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe word Round Quadrangle signifies nothing; but is a meere sound. So
  1178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlikewise if it be false, to say that vertue can be powred, or blown up
  1179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand down; the words In-powred Vertue, In-blown Vertue, are as absurd
  1180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand insignificant, as a Round Quadrangle. And therefore you shall hardly
  1181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeet with a senselesse and insignificant word, that is not made up of
  1182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome Latin or Greek names. A Frenchman seldome hears our Saviour called
  1183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the name of Parole, but by the name of Verbe often; yet Verbe and
  1184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tParole differ no more, but that one is Latin, the other French.
  1185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUnderstanding
  1190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen a man upon the hearing of any Speech, hath those thoughts which the
  1192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords of that Speech, and their connexion, were ordained and constituted
  1193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto signifie; Then he is said to understand it; Understanding being
  1194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnothing els, but conception caused by Speech. And therefore if Speech
  1195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe peculiar to man (as for ought I know it is,) then is Understanding
  1196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeculiar to him also. And therefore of absurd and false affirmations,
  1197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin case they be universall, there can be no Understanding; though many
  1198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthink they understand, then, when they do but repeat the words softly,
  1199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor con them in their mind.
  1200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat kinds of Speeches signifie the Appetites, Aversions, and Passions
  1202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof mans mind; and of their use and abuse, I shall speak when I have
  1203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspoken of the Passions.
  1204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInconstant Names
  1209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe names of such things as affect us, that is, which please, and
  1211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisplease us, because all men be not alike affected with the same thing,
  1212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor the same man at all times, are in the common discourses of men, of
  1213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInconstant signification. For seeing all names are imposed to signifie
  1214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour conceptions; and all our affections are but conceptions; when we
  1215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconceive the same things differently, we can hardly avoyd different
  1216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaming of them. For though the nature of that we conceive, be the
  1217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame; yet the diversity of our reception of it, in respect of different
  1218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstitutions of body, and prejudices of opinion, gives everything a
  1219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttincture of our different passions. And therefore in reasoning, a man
  1220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbust take heed of words; which besides the signification of what we
  1221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timagine of their nature, disposition, and interest of the speaker; such
  1222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas are the names of Vertues, and Vices; For one man calleth Wisdome,
  1223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat another calleth Feare; and one Cruelty, what another Justice;
  1224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone Prodigality, what another Magnanimity; one Gravity, what another
  1225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tStupidity, &c. And therefore such names can never be true grounds of any
  1226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tratiocination. No more can Metaphors, and Tropes of speech: but these
  1227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare less dangerous, because they profess their inconstancy; which the
  1228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother do not.
  1229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER V. OF REASON, AND SCIENCE.
  1233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason What It Is
  1238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen a man Reasoneth, hee does nothing els but conceive a summe totall,
  1240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom Addition of parcels; or conceive a Remainder, from Substraction of
  1241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone summe from another: which (if it be done by Words,) is conceiving of
  1242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe consequence of the names of all the parts, to the name of the whole;
  1243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor from the names of the whole and one part, to the name of the other
  1244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart. And though in some things, (as in numbers,) besides Adding and
  1245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubstracting, men name other operations, as Multiplying and Dividing;
  1246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet they are the same; for Multiplication, is but Addition together of
  1247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings equall; and Division, but Substracting of one thing, as often as
  1248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe can. These operations are not incident to Numbers onely, but to
  1249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall manner of things that can be added together, and taken one out of
  1250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother. For as Arithmeticians teach to adde and substract in Numbers;
  1251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso the Geometricians teach the same in Lines, Figures (solid and
  1252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuperficiall,) Angles, Proportions, Times, degrees of Swiftnesse, Force,
  1253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower, and the like; The Logicians teach the same in Consequences
  1254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Words; adding together Two Names, to make an Affirmation; and Two
  1255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAffirmations, to make a syllogisme; and Many syllogismes to make a
  1256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDemonstration; and from the Summe, or Conclusion of a syllogisme, they
  1257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubstract one Proposition, to finde the other. Writers of Politiques,
  1258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadde together Pactions, to find mens Duties; and Lawyers, Lawes and
  1259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFacts, to find what is Right and Wrong in the actions of private men.
  1260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn summe, in what matter soever there is place for Addition and
  1261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubstraction, there also is place for Reason; and where these have no
  1262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace, there Reason has nothing at all to do.
  1263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason Defined
  1268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOut of all which we may define, (that is to say determine,) what that
  1270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, which is meant by this word Reason, when wee reckon it amongst
  1271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Faculties of the mind. For Reason, in this sense, is nothing but
  1272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReckoning (that is, Adding and Substracting) of the Consequences of
  1273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgenerall names agreed upon, for the Marking and Signifying of our
  1274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthoughts; I say Marking them, when we reckon by our selves; and
  1275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignifying, when we demonstrate, or approve our reckonings to other men.
  1276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight Reason Where
  1281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as in Arithmetique, unpractised men must, and Professors themselves
  1283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay often erre, and cast up false; so also in any other subject of
  1284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReasoning, the ablest, most attentive, and most practised men, may
  1285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeceive themselves, and inferre false Conclusions; Not but that Reason
  1286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit selfe is always Right Reason, as well as Arithmetique is a certain
  1287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand infallible art: But no one mans Reason, nor the Reason of any
  1288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone number of men, makes the certaintie; no more than an account is
  1289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore well cast up, because a great many men have unanimously
  1290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapproved it. And therfore, as when there is a controversy in an account,
  1291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe parties must by their own accord, set up for right Reason, the
  1292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason of some Arbitrator, or Judge, to whose sentence they will
  1293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth stand, or their controversie must either come to blowes, or be
  1294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tundecided, for want of a right Reason constituted by Nature; so is
  1295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit also in all debates of what kind soever: And when men that think
  1296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves wiser than all others, clamor and demand right Reason for
  1297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudge; yet seek no more, but that things should be determined, by no
  1298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother mens reason but their own, it is as intolerable in the society of
  1299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, as it is in play after trump is turned, to use for trump on every
  1300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toccasion, that suite whereof they have most in their hand. For they do
  1301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnothing els, that will have every of their passions, as it comes to
  1302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbear sway in them, to be taken for right Reason, and that in their own
  1303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontroversies: bewraying their want of right Reason, by the claym they
  1304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlay to it.
  1305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Use Of Reason
  1310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Use and End of Reason, is not the finding of the summe, and truth
  1312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof one, or a few consequences, remote from the first definitions, and
  1313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsettled significations of names; but to begin at these; and proceed from
  1314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone consequence to another. For there can be no certainty of the last
  1315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConclusion, without a certainty of all those Affirmations and Negations,
  1316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton which it was grounded, and inferred. As when a master of a family,
  1317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin taking an account, casteth up the summs of all the bills of expence,
  1318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto one sum; and not regarding how each bill is summed up, by those
  1319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat give them in account; nor what it is he payes for; he advantages
  1320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe no more, than if he allowed the account in grosse, trusting to
  1321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery of the accountants skill and honesty; so also in Reasoning of all
  1322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother things, he that takes up conclusions on the trust of Authors, and
  1323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoth not fetch them from the first Items in every Reckoning, (which are
  1324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe significations of names settled by definitions), loses his labour;
  1325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand does not know any thing; but onely beleeveth.
  1326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Error And Absurdity
  1331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen a man reckons without the use of words, which may be done in
  1333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular things, (as when upon the sight of any one thing, wee
  1334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconjecture what was likely to have preceded, or is likely to follow upon
  1335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit;) if that which he thought likely to follow, followes not; or that
  1336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich he thought likely to have preceded it, hath not preceded it, this
  1337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis called ERROR; to which even the most prudent men are subject. But
  1338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen we Reason in Words of generall signification, and fall upon a
  1339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgenerall inference which is false; though it be commonly called Error,
  1340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is indeed an ABSURDITY, or senseless Speech. For Error is but a
  1341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeception, in presuming that somewhat is past, or to come; of which,
  1342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough it were not past, or not to come; yet there was no impossibility
  1343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscoverable. But when we make a generall assertion, unlesse it be a
  1344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrue one, the possibility of it is unconceivable. And words whereby we
  1345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconceive nothing but the sound, are those we call Absurd, insignificant,
  1346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Non-sense. And therefore if a man should talk to me of a Round
  1347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tQuadrangle; or Accidents Of Bread In Cheese; or Immaterial Substances;
  1348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor of A Free Subject; A Free Will; or any Free, but free from being
  1349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thindred by opposition, I should not say he were in an Errour; but that
  1350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this words were without meaning; that is to say, Absurd.
  1351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI have said before, (in the second chapter,) that a Man did excell
  1353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall other Animals in this faculty, that when he conceived any thing
  1354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever, he was apt to enquire the consequences of it, and what
  1355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teffects he could do with it. And now I adde this other degree of the
  1356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame excellence, that he can by words reduce the consequences he findes
  1357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto generall Rules, called Theoremes, or Aphorismes; that is, he can
  1358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason, or reckon, not onely in number; but in all other things, whereof
  1359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone may be added unto, or substracted from another.
  1360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut this priviledge, is allayed by another; and that is, by the
  1362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpriviledge of Absurdity; to which no living creature is subject, but man
  1363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely. And of men, those are of all most subject to it, that professe
  1364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophy. For it is most true that Cicero sayth of them somewhere;
  1365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat there can be nothing so absurd, but may be found in the books of
  1366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophers. And the reason is manifest. For there is not one of them
  1367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat begins his ratiocination from the Definitions, or Explications of
  1368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe names they are to use; which is a method that hath been used onely
  1369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Geometry; whose Conclusions have thereby been made indisputable.
  1370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCauses Of Absurditie
  1375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe first cause of Absurd conclusions I ascribe to the want of Method;
  1377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin that they begin not their Ratiocination from Definitions; that
  1378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, from settled significations of their words: as if they could cast
  1379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccount, without knowing the value of the numerall words, One, Two, and
  1380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThree.
  1381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whereas all bodies enter into account upon divers considerations,
  1383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which I have mentioned in the precedent chapter;) these considerations
  1384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing diversly named, divers absurdities proceed from the confusion, and
  1385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunfit connexion of their names into assertions. And therefore
  1386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe second cause of Absurd assertions, I ascribe to the giving of names
  1388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Bodies, to Accidents; or of Accidents, to Bodies; As they do, that
  1389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, Faith Is Infused, or Inspired; when nothing can be Powred, or
  1390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBreathed into any thing, but body; and that, Extension is Body; that
  1391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhantasmes are Spirits, &c.
  1392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe third I ascribe to the giving of the names of the Accidents of
  1394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBodies Without Us, to the Accidents of our Own Bodies; as they do that
  1395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, the Colour Is In The Body; The Sound Is In The Ayre, &c.
  1396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fourth, to the giving of the names of Bodies, to Names, or Speeches;
  1398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they do that say, that There Be Things Universall; that A Living
  1399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCreature Is Genus, or A Generall Thing, &c.
  1400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fifth, to the giving of the names of Accidents, to Names and
  1402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpeeches; as they do that say, The Nature Of A Thing Is In Its
  1403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDefinition; A Mans Command Is His Will; and the like.
  1404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe sixth, to the use of Metaphors, Tropes, and other Rhetoricall
  1406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfigures, in stead of words proper. For though it be lawfull to say, (for
  1407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texample) in common speech, The Way Goeth, Or Leadeth Hither, Or Thither,
  1408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Proverb Sayes This Or That (whereas wayes cannot go, nor Proverbs
  1409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeak;) yet in reckoning, and seeking of truth, such speeches are not to
  1410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe admitted.
  1411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe seventh, to names that signifie nothing; but are taken up, and
  1413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlearned by rote from the Schooles, as Hypostatical, Transubstantiate,
  1414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsubstantiate, Eternal-now, and the like canting of Schoole-men.
  1415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo him that can avoyd these things, it is not easie to fall into any
  1417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsurdity, unlesse it be by the length of an account; wherein he may
  1418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperhaps forget what went before. For all men by nature reason alike, and
  1419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twell, when they have good principles. For who is so stupid, as both to
  1420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmistake in Geometry, and also to persist in it, when another detects his
  1421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\terror to him?
  1422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScience
  1427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy this it appears that Reason is not as Sense, and Memory, borne with
  1429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tus; nor gotten by Experience onely; as Prudence is; but attayned by
  1430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIndustry; first in apt imposing of Names; and secondly by getting a good
  1431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand orderly Method in proceeding from the Elements, which are Names,
  1432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Assertions made by Connexion of one of them to another; and so to
  1433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsyllogismes, which are the Connexions of one Assertion to another, till
  1434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe come to a knowledge of all the Consequences of names appertaining to
  1435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe subject in hand; and that is it, men call SCIENCE. And whereas
  1436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSense and Memory are but knowledge of Fact, which is a thing past, and
  1437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tirrevocable; Science is the knowledge of Consequences, and dependance
  1438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof one fact upon another: by which, out of that we can presently do, we
  1439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow how to do something els when we will, or the like, another time;
  1440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBecause when we see how any thing comes about, upon what causes, and by
  1441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat manner; when the like causes come into our power, wee see how to
  1442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake it produce the like effects.
  1443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChildren therefore are not endued with Reason at all, till they have
  1445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tattained the use of Speech: but are called Reasonable Creatures, for the
  1446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossibility apparent of having the use of Reason in time to come. And
  1447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe most part of men, though they have the use of Reasoning a little
  1448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tway, as in numbring to some degree; yet it serves them to little use in
  1449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommon life; in which they govern themselves, some better, some worse,
  1450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccording to their differences of experience, quicknesse of memory, and
  1451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinclinations to severall ends; but specially according to good or evill
  1452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfortune, and the errors of one another. For as for Science, or certain
  1453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trules of their actions, they are so farre from it, that they know
  1454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot what it is. Geometry they have thought Conjuring: but for other
  1455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSciences, they who have not been taught the beginnings, and some
  1456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprogresse in them, that they may see how they be acquired and generated,
  1457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare in this point like children, that having no thought of generation,
  1458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare made believe by the women, that their brothers and sisters are not
  1459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tborn, but found in the garden.
  1460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut yet they that have no Science, are in better, and nobler condition
  1462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith their naturall Prudence; than men, that by mis-reasoning, or by
  1463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrusting them that reason wrong, fall upon false and absurd generall
  1464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trules. For ignorance of causes, and of rules, does not set men so farre
  1465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of their way, as relying on false rules, and taking for causes of
  1466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat they aspire to, those that are not so, but rather causes of the
  1467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary.
  1468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo conclude, The Light of humane minds is Perspicuous Words, but by
  1470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texact definitions first snuffed, and purged from ambiguity; Reason is
  1471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Pace; Encrease of Science, the Way; and the Benefit of man-kind, the
  1472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnd. And on the contrary, Metaphors, and senslesse and ambiguous words,
  1473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare like Ignes Fatui; and reasoning upon them, is wandering amongst
  1474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinnumerable absurdities; and their end, contention, and sedition, or
  1475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontempt.
  1476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrudence & Sapience, With Their Difference
  1481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs, much Experience, is Prudence; so, is much Science, Sapience. For
  1483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough wee usually have one name of Wisedome for them both; yet
  1484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Latines did always distinguish between Prudentia and Sapientia,
  1485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tascribing the former to Experience, the later to Science. But to make
  1486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir difference appeare more cleerly, let us suppose one man endued
  1487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith an excellent naturall use, and dexterity in handling his armes; and
  1488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother to have added to that dexterity, an acquired Science, of where
  1489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the can offend, or be offended by his adversarie, in every possible
  1490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tposture, or guard: The ability of the former, would be to the ability
  1491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the later, as Prudence to Sapience; both usefull; but the later
  1492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinfallible. But they that trusting onely to the authority of books,
  1493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollow the blind blindly, are like him that trusting to the false rules
  1494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the master of fence, ventures praesumptuously upon an adversary, that
  1495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither kills, or disgraces him.
  1496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignes Of Science
  1501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe signes of Science, are some, certain and infallible; some,
  1503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuncertain. Certain, when he that pretendeth the Science of any thing,
  1504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan teach the same; that is to say, demonstrate the truth thereof
  1505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperspicuously to another: Uncertain, when onely some particular events
  1506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanswer to his pretence, and upon many occasions prove so as he sayes
  1507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey must. Signes of prudence are all uncertain; because to observe by
  1508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texperience, and remember all circumstances that may alter the successe,
  1509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis impossible. But in any businesse, whereof a man has not infallible
  1510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScience to proceed by; to forsake his own natural judgement, and be
  1511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tguided by generall sentences read in Authors, and subject to many
  1512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texceptions, is a signe of folly, and generally scorned by the name of
  1513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPedantry. And even of those men themselves, that in Councells of the
  1514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, love to shew their reading of Politiques and History,
  1515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery few do it in their domestique affaires, where their particular
  1516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterest is concerned; having Prudence enough for their private
  1517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taffaires: but in publique they study more the reputation of their owne
  1518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twit, than the successe of anothers businesse.
  1519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER VI. OF THE INTERIOUR BEGINNINGS OF VOLUNTARY MOTIONS
  1523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCOMMONLY CALLED THE PASSIONS. AND THE SPEECHES BY WHICH THEY ARE
  1525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEXPRESSED.
  1526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMotion Vitall And Animal
  1531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere be in Animals, two sorts of Motions peculiar to them: One called
  1533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVitall; begun in generation, and continued without interruption through
  1534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir whole life; such as are the Course of the Bloud, the Pulse, the
  1535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBreathing, the Concoctions, Nutrition, Excretion, &c; to which Motions
  1536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere needs no help of Imagination: The other in Animal Motion,
  1537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\totherwise called Voluntary Motion; as to Go, to Speak, to Move any of
  1538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour limbes, in such manner as is first fancied in our minds. That Sense,
  1539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Motion in the organs and interiour parts of mans body, caused by
  1540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe action of the things we See, Heare, &c.; And that Fancy is but the
  1541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReliques of the same Motion, remaining after Sense, has been already
  1542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsayd in the first and second Chapters. And because Going, Speaking, and
  1543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe like Voluntary motions, depend alwayes upon a precedent thought of
  1544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhither, Which Way, and What; it is evident, that the Imagination is
  1545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe first internall beginning of all Voluntary Motion. And although
  1546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunstudied men, doe not conceive any motion at all to be there, where
  1547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe thing moved is invisible; or the space it is moved in, is (for the
  1548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshortnesse of it) insensible; yet that doth not hinder, but that such
  1549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMotions are. For let a space be never so little, that which is moved
  1550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover a greater space, whereof that little one is part, must first be
  1551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmoved over that. These small beginnings of Motion, within the body
  1552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Man, before they appear in walking, speaking, striking, and other
  1553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvisible actions, are commonly called ENDEAVOUR.
  1554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEndeavour; Appetite; Desire; Hunger; Thirst; Aversion
  1559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis Endeavour, when it is toward something which causes it, is called
  1561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAPPETITE, or DESIRE; the later, being the generall name; and the other,
  1562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toftentimes restrayned to signifie the Desire of Food, namely Hunger and
  1563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirst. And when the Endeavour is fromward something, it is generally
  1564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled AVERSION. These words Appetite, and Aversion we have from the
  1565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLatines; and they both of them signifie the motions, one of approaching,
  1566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe other of retiring. So also do the Greek words for the same, which
  1567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare orme and aphorme. For nature it selfe does often presse upon men
  1568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose truths, which afterwards, when they look for somewhat beyond
  1569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature, they stumble at. For the Schooles find in meere Appetite to go,
  1570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor move, no actuall Motion at all: but because some Motion they must
  1571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledge, they call it Metaphoricall Motion; which is but an absurd
  1572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeech; for though Words may be called metaphoricall; Bodies, and
  1573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMotions cannot.
  1574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat which men Desire, they are also sayd to LOVE; and to HATE those
  1576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings, for which they have Aversion. So that Desire, and Love, are the
  1577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame thing; save that by Desire, we alwayes signifie the Absence of
  1578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe object; by Love, most commonly the Presence of the same. So also
  1579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Aversion, we signifie the Absence; and by Hate, the Presence of the
  1580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tObject.
  1581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Appetites, and Aversions, some are born with men; as Appetite of
  1583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfood, Appetite of excretion, and exoneration, (which may also and more
  1584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproperly be called Aversions, from somewhat they feele in their Bodies;)
  1585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand some other Appetites, not many. The rest, which are Appetites of
  1586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular things, proceed from Experience, and triall of their effects
  1587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon themselves, or other men. For of things wee know not at all, or
  1588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbelieve not to be, we can have no further Desire, than to tast and try.
  1589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut Aversion wee have for things, not onely which we know have hurt us;
  1590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut also that we do not know whether they will hurt us, or not.
  1591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContempt
  1596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThose things which we neither Desire, nor Hate, we are said to Contemne:
  1598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCONTEMPT being nothing els but an immobility, or contumacy of the Heart,
  1599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin resisting the action of certain things; and proceeding from that the
  1600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeart is already moved otherwise, by either more potent objects; or from
  1601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twant of experience of them.
  1602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because the constitution of a mans Body, is in continuall mutation;
  1604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is impossible that all the same things should alwayes cause in him
  1605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same Appetites, and aversions: much lesse can all men consent, in
  1606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Desire of almost any one and the same Object.
  1607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood Evill
  1612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut whatsoever is the object of any mans Appetite or Desire; that is
  1614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, which he for his part calleth Good: And the object of his Hate,
  1615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Aversion, evill; And of his contempt, Vile, and Inconsiderable.
  1616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor these words of Good, evill, and Contemptible, are ever used with
  1617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trelation to the person that useth them: There being nothing simply and
  1618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsolutely so; nor any common Rule of Good and evill, to be taken from
  1619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe nature of the objects themselves; but from the Person of the man
  1620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(where there is no Common-wealth;) or, (in a Common-wealth,) From the
  1621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson that representeth it; or from an Arbitrator or Judge, whom men
  1622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisagreeing shall by consent set up, and make his sentence the Rule
  1623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof.
  1624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPulchrum Turpe; Delightfull Profitable; Unpleasant Unprofitable
  1629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Latine Tongue has two words, whose significations approach to
  1631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose of Good and Evill; but are not precisely the same; And those are
  1632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPulchrum and Turpe. Whereof the former signifies that, which by some
  1633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapparent signes promiseth Good; and the later, that, which promiseth
  1634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevill. But in our Tongue we have not so generall names to expresse them
  1635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby. But for Pulchrum, we say in some things, Fayre; in other Beautifull,
  1636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Handsome, or Gallant, or Honourable, or Comely, or Amiable; and
  1637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Turpe, Foule, Deformed, Ugly, Base, Nauseous, and the like, as the
  1638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject shall require; All which words, in their proper places signifie
  1639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnothing els, but the Mine, or Countenance, that promiseth Good and
  1640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevill. So that of Good there be three kinds; Good in the Promise,
  1641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is Pulchrum; Good in Effect, as the end desired, which is called
  1642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJucundum, Delightfull; and Good as the Means, which is called Utile,
  1643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProfitable; and as many of evill: For evill, in Promise, is that
  1644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey call Turpe; evill in Effect, and End, is Molestum, Unpleasant,
  1645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTroublesome; and evill in the Means, Inutile, Unprofitable, Hurtfull.
  1646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDelight Displeasure
  1651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs, in Sense, that which is really within us, is (As I have sayd
  1653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore) onely Motion, caused by the action of externall objects, but in
  1654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapparence; to the Sight, Light and Colour; to the Eare, Sound; to the
  1655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNostrill, Odour, &c: so, when the action of the same object is continued
  1656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Eyes, Eares, and other organs to the Heart; the real effect
  1657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is nothing but Motion, or Endeavour; which consisteth in Appetite,
  1658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Aversion, to, or from the object moving. But the apparence, or sense
  1659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof that motion, is that wee either call DELIGHT, or TROUBLE OF MIND.
  1660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

  1664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPleasure Offence
  1665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis Motion, which is called Appetite, and for the apparence of it
  1667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDelight, and Pleasure, seemeth to be, a corroboration of Vitall motion,
  1668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand a help thereunto; and therefore such things as caused Delight, were
  1669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot improperly called Jucunda, (A Juvando,) from helping or fortifying;
  1670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the contrary, Molesta, Offensive, from hindering, and troubling the
  1671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmotion vitall.
  1672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPleasure therefore, (or Delight,) is the apparence, or sense of Good;
  1674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Molestation or Displeasure, the apparence, or sense of evill. And
  1675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently all Appetite, Desire, and Love, is accompanied with some
  1676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDelight more or lesse; and all Hatred, and Aversion, with more or lesse
  1677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDispleasure and Offence.
  1678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPleasures Of Sense; Pleasures Of The Mind; Joy Paine Griefe
  1683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Pleasures, or Delights, some arise from the sense of an object
  1685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresent; And those may be called Pleasures Of Sense, (The word Sensuall,
  1686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas it is used by those onely that condemn them, having no place till
  1687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere be Lawes.) Of this kind are all Onerations and Exonerations of the
  1688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbody; as also all that is pleasant, in the Sight, Hearing, Smell,
  1689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTast, Or Touch; Others arise from the Expectation, that proceeds from
  1690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforesight of the End, or Consequence of things; whether those things in
  1691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Sense Please or Displease: And these are Pleasures Of The Mind of
  1692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim that draweth those consequences; and are generally called JOY. In
  1693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe like manner, Displeasures, are some in the Sense, and called PAYNE;
  1694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tothers, in the Expectation of consequences, and are called GRIEFE.
  1695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese simple Passions called Appetite, Desire, Love, Aversion, Hate,
  1697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJoy, and griefe, have their names for divers considerations diversified.
  1698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs first, when they one succeed another, they are diversly called from
  1699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe opinion men have of the likelihood of attaining what they
  1700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesire. Secondly, from the object loved or hated. Thirdly, from the
  1701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsideration of many of them together. Fourthly, from the Alteration or
  1702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuccession it selfe.
  1703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHope-- For Appetite with an opinion of attaining, is called HOPE.
  1706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDespaire-- The same, without such opinion, DESPAIRE.
  1708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFeare-- Aversion, with opinion of Hurt from the object, FEARE.
  1710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCourage-- The same, with hope of avoyding that Hurt by resistance,
  1712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCOURAGE.
  1713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnger-- Sudden Courage, ANGER.
  1715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConfidence-- Constant Hope, CONFIDENCE of our selves.
  1717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDiffidence-- Constant Despayre, DIFFIDENCE of our selves.
  1719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIndignation-- Anger for great hurt done to another, when we conceive the
  1721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame to be done by Injury, INDIGNATION.
  1722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBenevolence-- Desire of good to another, BENEVOLENCE, GOOD WILL,
  1724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHARITY. If to man generally, GOOD NATURE.
  1725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovetousnesse-- Desire of Riches, COVETOUSNESSE: a name used alwayes in
  1727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignification of blame; because men contending for them, are displeased
  1728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith one anothers attaining them; though the desire in it selfe, be to
  1729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe blamed, or allowed, according to the means by which those Riches are
  1730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsought.
  1731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAmbition-- Desire of Office, or precedence, AMBITION: a name used also
  1733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the worse sense, for the reason before mentioned.
  1734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPusillanimity-- Desire of things that conduce but a little to our ends;
  1736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd fear of things that are but of little hindrance, PUSILLANIMITY.
  1737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMagnanimity-- Contempt of little helps, and hindrances, MAGNANIMITY.
  1739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tValour-- Magnanimity, in danger of Death, or Wounds, VALOUR, FORTITUDE.
  1741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberality-- Magnanimity in the use of Riches, LIBERALITY
  1743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiserablenesse-- Pusillanimity, in the same WRETCHEDNESSE,
  1745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMISERABLENESSE; or PARSIMONY; as it is liked or disliked.
  1746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKindnesse-- Love of Persons for society, KINDNESSE.
  1748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall Lust-- Love of Persons for Pleasing the sense onely, NATURAL
  1750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLUST.
  1751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLuxury-- Love of the same, acquired from Rumination, that is Imagination
  1753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Pleasure past, LUXURY.
  1754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Passion Of Love; Jealousie-- Love of one singularly, with desire to
  1756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe singularly beloved, THE PASSION OF LOVE. The same, with fear that the
  1757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlove is not mutuall, JEALOUSIE.
  1758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRevengefulnesse-- Desire, by doing hurt to another, to make him condemn
  1760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome fact of his own, REVENGEFULNESSE.
  1761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCuriosity-- Desire, to know why, and how, CURIOSITY; such as is in no
  1763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tliving creature but Man; so that Man is distinguished, not onely by his
  1764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason; but also by this singular Passion from other Animals; in whom
  1765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe appetite of food, and other pleasures of Sense, by praedominance,
  1766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake away the care of knowing causes; which is a Lust of the mind,
  1767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat by a perseverance of delight in the continuall and indefatigable
  1768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgeneration of Knowledge, exceedeth the short vehemence of any carnall
  1769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPleasure.
  1770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion Superstition; True Religion-- Feare of power invisible, feigned
  1772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the mind, or imagined from tales publiquely allowed, RELIGION; not
  1773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallowed, superstition. And when the power imagined is truly such as we
  1774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timagine, TRUE RELIGION.
  1775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPanique Terrour-- Feare, without the apprehension of why, or what,
  1777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPANIQUE TERROR; called so from the fables that make Pan the author of
  1778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem; whereas in truth there is always in him that so feareth, first,
  1779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome apprehension of the cause, though the rest run away by example;
  1780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one supposing his fellow to know why. And therefore this Passion
  1781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thappens to none but in a throng, or multitude of people.
  1782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdmiration-- Joy, from apprehension of novelty, ADMIRATION; proper to
  1784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, because it excites the appetite of knowing the cause.
  1785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGlory Vaine-glory-- Joy, arising from imagination of a man's own power
  1787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand ability, is that exultation of the mind which is called GLORYING:
  1788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich, if grounded upon the experience of his own former actions, is
  1789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same with Confidence: but if grounded on the flattery of others, or
  1790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely supposed by himselfe, for delight in the consequences of it,
  1791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis called VAINE-GLORY: which name is properly given; because a
  1792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twell-grounded Confidence begetteth attempt; whereas the supposing of
  1793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower does not, and is therefore rightly called Vaine.
  1794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDejection-- Griefe, from opinion of want of power, is called dejection
  1796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof mind.
  1797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Vaine-glory which consisteth in the feigning or supposing of
  1799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabilities in ourselves, which we know are not, is most incident to young
  1800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, and nourished by the Histories or Fictions of Gallant Persons; and
  1801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis corrected often times by Age, and Employment.
  1802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSudden Glory Laughter-- Sudden glory, is the passion which maketh those
  1804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGrimaces called LAUGHTER; and is caused either by some sudden act of
  1805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own, that pleaseth them; or by the apprehension of some
  1806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeformed thing in another, by comparison whereof they suddenly applaud
  1807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves. And it is incident most to them, that are conscious of the
  1808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfewest abilities in themselves; who are forced to keep themselves in
  1809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own favour, by observing the imperfections of other men.
  1810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore much Laughter at the defects of others is a signe of
  1811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPusillanimity. For of great minds, one of the proper workes is, to help
  1812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand free others from scorn; and compare themselves onely with the most
  1813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\table.
  1814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSudden Dejection Weeping-- On the contrary, Sudden Dejection is the
  1816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpassion that causeth WEEPING; and is caused by such accidents, as
  1817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuddenly take away some vehement hope, or some prop of their power: and
  1818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are most subject to it, that rely principally on helps externall,
  1819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as are Women, and Children. Therefore, some Weep for the loss of
  1820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFriends; Others for their unkindnesse; others for the sudden stop made
  1821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto their thoughts of revenge, by Reconciliation. But in all cases, both
  1822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaughter and Weeping, are sudden motions; Custome taking them both away.
  1823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor no man Laughs at old jests; or Weeps for an old calamity.
  1824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tShame Blushing-- Griefe, for the discovery of some defect of ability
  1826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis SHAME, or the passion that discovereth itself in BLUSHING; and
  1827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsisteth in the apprehension of some thing dishonourable; and in young
  1828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, is a signe of the love of good reputation; and commendable: in
  1829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\told men it is a signe of the same; but because it comes too late, not
  1830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommendable.
  1831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImpudence-- The Contempt of good reputation is called IMPUDENCE.
  1833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPitty-- Griefe, for the calamity of another is PITTY; and ariseth
  1835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the imagination that the like calamity may befall himselfe; and
  1836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore is called also COMPASSION, and in the phrase of this present
  1837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime a FELLOW-FEELING: and therefore for Calamity arriving from
  1838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat wickedness, the best men have the least Pitty; and for the same
  1839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCalamity, those have least Pitty, that think themselves least obnoxious
  1840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the same.
  1841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCruelty-- Contempt, or little sense of the calamity of others, is that
  1843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich men call CRUELTY; proceeding from Security of their own fortune.
  1844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor, that any man should take pleasure in other mens' great harmes,
  1845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout other end of his own, I do not conceive it possible.
  1846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEmulation Envy-- Griefe, for the success of a Competitor in wealth,
  1848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thonour, or other good, if it be joyned with Endeavour to enforce our own
  1849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabilities to equal or exceed him, is called EMULATION: but joyned with
  1850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEndeavour to supplant or hinder a Competitor, ENVIE.
  1851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeliberation-- When in the mind of man, Appetites and Aversions, Hopes
  1853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Feares, concerning one and the same thing, arise alternately; and
  1854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivers good and evill consequences of the doing, or omitting the thing
  1855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpropounded, come successively into our thoughts; so that sometimes we
  1856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave an Appetite to it, sometimes an Aversion from it; sometimes Hope to
  1857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe able to do it; sometimes Despaire, or Feare to attempt it; the whole
  1858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsum of Desires, Aversions, Hopes and Feares, continued till the thing be
  1859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither done, or thought impossible, is that we call DELIBERATION.
  1860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore of things past, there is no Deliberation; because manifestly
  1862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpossible to be changed: nor of things known to be impossible, or
  1863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought so; because men know, or think such Deliberation vaine. But
  1864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof things impossible, which we think possible, we may Deliberate; not
  1865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknowing it is in vain. And it is called DELIBERATION; because it is a
  1866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tputting an end to the Liberty we had of doing, or omitting, according to
  1867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour own Appetite, or Aversion.
  1868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis alternate succession of Appetites, Aversions, Hopes and Feares is
  1870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno less in other living Creatures than in Man; and therefore Beasts also
  1871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeliberate.
  1872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvery Deliberation is then sayd to End when that whereof they
  1874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeliberate, is either done, or thought impossible; because till then wee
  1875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tretain the liberty of doing, or omitting, according to our Appetite, or
  1876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAversion.
  1877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Will
  1882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Deliberation, the last Appetite, or Aversion, immediately adhaering
  1884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the action, or to the omission thereof, is that wee call the
  1885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWILL; the Act, (not the faculty,) of Willing. And Beasts that have
  1886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeliberation must necessarily also have Will. The Definition of the
  1887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWill, given commonly by the Schooles, that it is a Rationall Appetite,
  1888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not good. For if it were, then could there be no Voluntary Act
  1889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst Reason. For a Voluntary Act is that, which proceedeth from the
  1890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWill, and no other. But if in stead of a Rationall Appetite, we shall
  1891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay an Appetite resulting from a precedent Deliberation, then the
  1892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDefinition is the same that I have given here. Will, therefore, Is The
  1893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLast Appetite In Deliberating. And though we say in common Discourse, a
  1894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman had a Will once to do a thing, that neverthelesse he forbore to
  1895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo; yet that is properly but an Inclination, which makes no Action
  1896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVoluntary; because the action depends not of it, but of the last
  1897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInclination, or Appetite. For if the intervenient Appetites make any
  1898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taction Voluntary, then by the same reason all intervenient Aversions
  1899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould make the same action Involuntary; and so one and the same action
  1900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould be both Voluntary & Involuntary.
  1901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy this it is manifest, that not onely actions that have their beginning
  1903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom Covetousness, Ambition, Lust, or other Appetites to the thing
  1904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpropounded; but also those that have their beginning from Aversion,
  1905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Feare of those consequences that follow the omission, are Voluntary
  1906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActions.
  1907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFormes Of Speech, In Passion
  1912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe formes of Speech by which the Passions are expressed, are partly the
  1914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame, and partly different from those, by which we express our Thoughts.
  1915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first generally all Passions may be expressed Indicatively; as, I
  1916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLove, I Feare, I Joy, I Deliberate, I Will, I Command: but some of them
  1917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave particular expressions by themselves, which nevertheless are not
  1918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taffirmations, unless it be when they serve to make other inferences,
  1919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbesides that of the Passion they proceed from. Deliberation is expressed
  1920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjunctively; which is a speech proper to signifie suppositions, with
  1921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir consequences; as, If This Be Done, Then This Will Follow; and
  1922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiffers not from the language of Reasoning, save that Reasoning is in
  1923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgenerall words, but Deliberation for the most part is of Particulars.
  1924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe language of Desire, and Aversion, is Imperative; as, Do This,
  1925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tForbear That; which when the party is obliged to do, or forbear, is
  1926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommand; otherwise Prayer; or els Counsell. The language of Vaine-Glory,
  1927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Indignation, Pitty and Revengefulness, Optative: but of the Desire to
  1928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow, there is a peculiar expression called Interrogative; as, What Is
  1929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt, When Shall It, How Is It Done, and Why So? Other language of the
  1930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions I find none: for Cursing, Swearing, Reviling, and the like, do
  1931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot signifie as Speech; but as the actions of a tongue accustomed.
  1932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese forms of Speech, I say, are expressions, or voluntary
  1934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifications of our Passions: but certain signes they be not; because
  1935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey may be used arbitrarily, whether they that use them, have such
  1936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions or not. The best signes of Passions present, are either in the
  1937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcountenance, motions of the body, actions, and ends, or aims, which we
  1938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\totherwise know the man to have.
  1939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood And Evill Apparent
  1944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because in Deliberation the Appetites and Aversions are raised by
  1946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforesight of the good and evill consequences, and sequels of the action
  1947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof we Deliberate; the good or evill effect thereof dependeth on the
  1948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforesight of a long chain of consequences, of which very seldome any man
  1949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis able to see to the end. But for so far as a man seeth, if the Good
  1950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin those consequences be greater than the evill, the whole chain is that
  1951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich Writers call Apparent or Seeming Good. And contrarily, when the
  1952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevill exceedeth the good, the whole is Apparent or Seeming Evill: so
  1953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat he who hath by Experience, or Reason, the greatest and surest
  1954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprospect of Consequences, Deliberates best himself; and is able, when he
  1955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill, to give the best counsel unto others.
  1956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFelicity
  1961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContinual Successe in obtaining those things which a man from time to
  1963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime desireth, that is to say, continual prospering, is that men call
  1964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFELICITY; I mean the Felicity of this life. For there is no such thing
  1965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas perpetual Tranquillity of mind, while we live here; because Life
  1966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\titself is but Motion, and can never be without Desire, nor without
  1967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFeare, no more than without Sense. What kind of Felicity God hath
  1968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordained to them that devoutly honour him, a man shall no sooner know,
  1969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan enjoy; being joys, that now are as incomprehensible, as the word of
  1970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSchool-men, Beatifical Vision, is unintelligible.
  1971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPraise Magnification
  1976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe form of speech whereby men signifie their opinion of the Goodnesse
  1978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof anything is PRAISE. That whereby they signifie the power and
  1979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreatness of anything is MAGNIFYING. And that whereby they signifie
  1980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe opinion they have of a man's felicity is by the Greeks called
  1981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMakarismos, for which we have no name in our tongue. And thus much is
  1982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsufficient for the present purpose to have been said of the passions.
  1983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER VII. OF THE ENDS OR RESOLUTIONS OF DISCOURSE
  1987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf all Discourse, governed by desire of Knowledge, there is at last
  1990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan End, either by attaining, or by giving over. And in the chain of
  1991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDiscourse, wheresoever it be interrupted, there is an End for that time.
  1992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgement, or Sentence Final; Doubt
  1997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  1998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf the Discourse be meerly Mentall, it consisteth of thoughts that the
  1999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing will be, and will not be; or that it has been, and has not been,
  2000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talternately. So that wheresoever you break off the chayn of a mans
  2001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDiscourse, you leave him in a Praesumption of It Will Be, or, It Will
  2002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNot Be; or it Has Been, or, Has Not Been. All which is Opinion. And that
  2003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is alternate Appetite, in Deliberating concerning Good and Evil,
