  2004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same is alternate Opinion in the Enquiry of the truth of Past, and
  2005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFuture. And as the last Appetite in Deliberation is called the Will, so
  2006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe last Opinion in search of the truth of Past, and Future, is called
  2007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe JUDGEMENT, or Resolute and Final Sentence of him that Discourseth.
  2008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as the whole chain of Appetites alternate, in the question of Good
  2009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Bad is called Deliberation; so the whole chain of Opinions alternate,
  2010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the question of True, or False is called DOUBT.
  2011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNo Discourse whatsoever, can End in absolute knowledge of Fact, past, or
  2013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto come. For, as for the knowledge of Fact, it is originally, Sense; and
  2014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tever after, Memory. And for the knowledge of consequence, which I have
  2015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid before is called Science, it is not Absolute, but Conditionall. No
  2016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman can know by Discourse, that this, or that, is, has been, or will
  2017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe; which is to know absolutely: but onely, that if This be, That is; if
  2018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis has been, That has been; if This shall be, That shall be: which
  2019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to know conditionally; and that not the consequence of one thing to
  2020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother; but of one name of a thing, to another name of the same thing.
  2021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScience Opinion Conscience
  2026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore, when the Discourse is put into Speech, and begins with
  2028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Definitions of Words, and proceeds by Connexion of the same into
  2029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgeneral Affirmations, and of these again into Syllogismes, the end or
  2030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlast sum is called the Conclusion; and the thought of the mind by it
  2031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignified is that conditional Knowledge, or Knowledge of the consequence
  2032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof words, which is commonly called Science. But if the first ground of
  2033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch Discourse be not Definitions, or if the Definitions be not rightly
  2034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjoyned together into Syllogismes, then the End or Conclusion is again
  2035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOPINION, namely of the truth of somewhat said, though sometimes in
  2036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsurd and senslesse words, without possibility of being understood.
  2037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen two, or more men, know of one and the same fact, they are said
  2038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be CONSCIOUS of it one to another; which is as much as to know it
  2039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttogether. And because such are fittest witnesses of the facts of one
  2040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, or of a third, it was, and ever will be reputed a very Evill
  2041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tact, for any man to speak against his Conscience; or to corrupt or force
  2042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother so to do: Insomuch that the plea of Conscience, has been always
  2043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thearkened unto very diligently in all times. Afterwards, men made use
  2044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the same word metaphorically, for the knowledge of their own secret
  2045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfacts, and secret thoughts; and therefore it is Rhetorically said that
  2046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Conscience is a thousand witnesses. And last of all, men, vehemently
  2047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin love with their own new opinions, (though never so absurd,) and
  2048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobstinately bent to maintain them, gave those their opinions also that
  2049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treverenced name of Conscience, as if they would have it seem unlawful,
  2050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto change or speak against them; and so pretend to know they are true,
  2051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen they know at most but that they think so.
  2052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBeliefe Faith
  2057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen a mans Discourse beginneth not at Definitions, it beginneth either
  2059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat some other contemplation of his own, and then it is still called
  2060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOpinion; Or it beginneth at some saying of another, of whose ability to
  2061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow the truth, and of whose honesty in not deceiving, he doubteth
  2062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot; and then the Discourse is not so much concerning the Thing, as the
  2063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson; And the Resolution is called BELEEFE, and FAITH: Faith, In the
  2064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman; Beleefe, both Of the man, and Of the truth of what he sayes. So
  2065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen in Beleefe are two opinions; one of the saying of the man; the
  2066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother of his vertue. To Have Faith In, or Trust To, or Beleeve A Man,
  2067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifie the same thing; namely, an opinion of the veracity of the man:
  2068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut to Beleeve What Is Said, signifieth onely an opinion of the truth
  2069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the saying. But wee are to observe that this Phrase, I Beleeve In;
  2070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas also the Latine, Credo In; and the Greek, Pisteno Eis, are never used
  2071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut in the writings of Divines. In stead of them, in other writings are
  2072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tput, I Beleeve Him; I Have Faith In Him; I Rely On Him: and in Latin,
  2073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCredo Illi; Fido Illi: and in Greek, Pisteno Anto: and that this
  2074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsingularity of the Ecclesiastical use of the word hath raised many
  2075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisputes about the right object of the Christian Faith.
  2076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut by Beleeving In, as it is in the Creed, is meant, not trust in the
  2078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson; but Confession and acknowledgement of the Doctrine. For not
  2079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely Christians, but all manner of men do so believe in God, as to hold
  2080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall for truth they heare him say, whether they understand it, or not;
  2081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is all the Faith and trust can possibly be had in any person
  2082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever: But they do not all believe the Doctrine of the Creed.
  2083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom whence we may inferre, that when wee believe any saying whatsoever
  2085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit be, to be true, from arguments taken, not from the thing it selfe, or
  2086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the principles of naturall Reason, but from the Authority, and
  2087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood opinion wee have, of him that hath sayd it; then is the speaker, or
  2088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperson we believe in, or trust in, and whose word we take, the object of
  2089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Faith; and the Honour done in Believing, is done to him onely. And
  2090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently, when wee Believe that the Scriptures are the word of God,
  2091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thaving no immediate revelation from God himselfe, our Beleefe, Faith,
  2092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Trust is in the Church; whose word we take, and acquiesce therein.
  2093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd they that believe that which a Prophet relates unto them in the
  2094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of God, take the word of the Prophet, do honour to him, and in him
  2095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrust, and believe, touching the truth of what he relateth, whether he
  2096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe a true, or a false Prophet. And so it is also with all other History.
  2097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor if I should not believe all that is written By Historians, of the
  2098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tglorious acts of Alexander, or Caesar; I do not think the Ghost of
  2099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlexander, or Caesar, had any just cause to be offended; or any body
  2100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\telse, but the Historian. If Livy say the Gods made once a Cow speak, and
  2101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe believe it not; wee distrust not God therein, but Livy. So that it is
  2102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevident, that whatsoever we believe, upon no other reason, than what is
  2103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdrawn from authority of men onely, and their writings; whether they be
  2104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsent from God or not, is Faith in men onely.
  2105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER VIII. OF THE VERTUES COMMONLY CALLED INTELLECTUAL;
  2109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAND THEIR CONTRARY DEFECTS
  2111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIntellectuall Vertue Defined
  2116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVertue generally, in all sorts of subjects, is somewhat that is valued
  2118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor eminence; and consisteth in comparison. For if all things
  2119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere equally in all men, nothing would be prized. And by Vertues
  2120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tINTELLECTUALL, are always understood such abilityes of the mind, as men
  2121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpraise, value, and desire should be in themselves; and go commonly under
  2122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe name of a Good Witte; though the same word Witte, be used also, to
  2123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdistinguish one certain ability from the rest.
  2124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWit, Naturall, Or Acquired
  2129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese Vertues are of two sorts; Naturall, and Acquired. By Naturall, I
  2131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmean not, that which a man hath from his Birth: for that is nothing else
  2132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut Sense; wherein men differ so little one from another, and from brute
  2133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBeasts, as it is not to be reckoned amongst Vertues. But I mean, that
  2134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitte, which is gotten by Use onely, and Experience; without Method,
  2135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCulture, or Instruction. This NATURALL WITTE, consisteth principally
  2136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin two things; Celerity Of Imagining, (that is, swift succession of one
  2137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought to another;) and Steddy Direction to some approved end. On the
  2138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContrary a slow Imagination, maketh that Defect, or fault of the mind,
  2139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is commonly called DULNESSE, Stupidity, and sometimes by other
  2140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnames that signifie slownesse of motion, or difficulty to be moved.
  2141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood Wit, Or Fancy; Good Judgement; Discretion
  2146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd this difference of quicknesse, is caused by the difference of mens
  2148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpassions; that love and dislike, some one thing, some another: and
  2149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore some mens thoughts run one way, some another: and are held to,
  2150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand observe differently the things that passe through their imagination.
  2151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whereas in his succession of mens thoughts, there is nothing to
  2152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserve in the things they think on, but either in what they be Like One
  2153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother, or in what they be Unlike, or What They Serve For, or How They
  2154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tServe To Such A Purpose; Those that observe their similitudes, in case
  2155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey be such as are but rarely observed by others, are sayd to have a
  2156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood Wit; by which, in this occasion, is meant a Good Fancy. But they
  2157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat observe their differences, and dissimilitudes; which is called
  2158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDistinguishing, and Discerning, and Judging between thing and thing; in
  2159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcase, such discerning be not easie, are said to have a Good Judgement:
  2160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand particularly in matter of conversation and businesse; wherein,
  2161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimes, places, and persons are to be discerned, this Vertue is called
  2162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDISCRETION. The former, that is, Fancy, without the help of Judgement,
  2163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not commended as a Vertue: but the later which is Judgement, and
  2164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDiscretion, is commended for it selfe, without the help of Fancy.
  2165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBesides the Discretion of times, places, and persons, necessary to a
  2166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood Fancy, there is required also an often application of his thoughts
  2167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto their End; that is to say, to some use to be made of them. This done;
  2168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the that hath this Vertue, will be easily fitted with similitudes, that
  2169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill please, not onely by illustration of his discourse, and adorning it
  2170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith new and apt metaphors; but also, by the rarity or their invention.
  2171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut without Steddinesse, and Direction to some End, a great Fancy is one
  2172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkind of Madnesse; such as they have, that entring into any discourse,
  2173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare snatched from their purpose, by every thing that comes in their
  2174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought, into so many, and so long digressions, and parentheses, that
  2175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey utterly lose themselves: Which kind of folly, I know no particular
  2176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname for: but the cause of it is, sometimes want of experience; whereby
  2177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat seemeth to a man new and rare, which doth not so to others:
  2178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes Pusillanimity; by which that seems great to him, which other
  2179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen think a trifle: and whatsoever is new, or great, and therefore
  2180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought fit to be told, withdrawes a man by degrees from the intended
  2181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tway of his discourse.
  2182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn a good Poem, whether it be Epique, or Dramatique; as also in Sonnets,
  2184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEpigrams, and other Pieces, both Judgement and Fancy are required:
  2185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the Fancy must be more eminent; because they please for the
  2186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExtravagancy; but ought not to displease by Indiscretion.
  2187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn a good History, the Judgement must be eminent; because the goodnesse
  2189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsisteth, in the Method, in the Truth, and in the Choyse of the
  2190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions that are most profitable to be known. Fancy has no place, but
  2191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely in adorning the stile.
  2192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Orations of Prayse, and in Invectives, the Fancy is praedominant;
  2194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause the designe is not truth, but to Honour or Dishonour; which is
  2195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdone by noble, or by vile comparisons. The Judgement does but suggest
  2196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat circumstances make an action laudable, or culpable.
  2197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Hortatives, and Pleadings, as Truth, or Disguise serveth best to the
  2199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDesigne in hand; so is the Judgement, or the Fancy most required.
  2200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Demonstration, in Councell, and all rigourous search of Truth,
  2202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgement does all; except sometimes the understanding have need to be
  2203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topened by some apt similitude; and then there is so much use of Fancy.
  2204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut for Metaphors, they are in this case utterly excluded. For seeing
  2205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey openly professe deceipt; to admit them into Councell, or Reasoning,
  2206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere manifest folly.
  2207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd in any Discourse whatsoever, if the defect of Discretion be
  2209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapparent, how extravagant soever the Fancy be, the whole discourse
  2210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill be taken for a signe of want of wit; and so will it never when the
  2211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDiscretion is manifest, though the Fancy be never so ordinary.
  2212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe secret thoughts of a man run over all things, holy, prophane,
  2214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tclean, obscene, grave, and light, without shame, or blame; which verball
  2215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscourse cannot do, farther than the Judgement shall approve of the
  2216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTime, Place, and Persons. An Anatomist, or a Physitian may speak, or
  2217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twrite his judgement of unclean things; because it is not to please,
  2218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut profit: but for another man to write his extravagant, and pleasant
  2219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfancies of the same, is as if a man, from being tumbled into the dirt,
  2220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould come and present himselfe before good company. And 'tis the want
  2221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Discretion that makes the difference. Again, in profest remissnesse
  2222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof mind, and familiar company, a man may play with the sounds, and
  2223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taequivocal significations of words; and that many times with encounters
  2224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof extraordinary Fancy: but in a Sermon, or in publique, or before
  2225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpersons unknown, or whom we ought to reverence, there is no Gingling of
  2226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords that will not be accounted folly: and the difference is onely in
  2227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe want of Discretion. So that where Wit is wanting, it is not Fancy
  2228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is wanting, but Discretion. Judgement therefore without Fancy is
  2229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWit, but Fancy without Judgement not.
  2230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrudence
  2235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen the thoughts of a man, that has a designe in hand, running over a
  2237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmultitude of things, observes how they conduce to that designe; or what
  2238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesigne they may conduce into; if his observations be such as are not
  2239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teasie, or usuall, This wit of his is called PRUDENCE; and dependeth on
  2240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmuch Experience, and Memory of the like things, and their consequences
  2241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theretofore. In which there is not so much difference of Men, as there is
  2242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin their Fancies and Judgements; Because the Experience of men equall
  2243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin age, is not much unequall, as to the quantity; but lyes in different
  2244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toccasions; every one having his private designes. To govern well a
  2245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfamily, and a kingdome, are not different degrees of Prudence; but
  2246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifferent sorts of businesse; no more then to draw a picture in little,
  2247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor as great, or greater then the life, are different degrees of Art. A
  2248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplain husband-man is more Prudent in affaires of his own house, then a
  2249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivy Counseller in the affaires of another man.
  2250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCraft
  2255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Prudence, if you adde the use of unjust, or dishonest means, such
  2257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas usually are prompted to men by Feare, or Want; you have that Crooked
  2258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWisdome, which is called CRAFT; which is a signe of Pusillanimity. For
  2259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMagnanimity is contempt of unjust, or dishonest helps. And that which
  2260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Latines Call Versutia, (translated into English, Shifting,) and is
  2261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta putting off of a present danger or incommodity, by engaging into
  2262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta greater, as when a man robbs one to pay another, is but a shorter
  2263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsighted Craft, called Versutia, from Versura, which signifies taking
  2264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmony at usurie, for the present payment of interest.
  2265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAcquired Wit
  2270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for Acquired Wit, (I mean acquired by method and instruction,) there
  2272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis none but Reason; which is grounded on the right use of Speech; and
  2273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproduceth the Sciences. But of Reason and Science, I have already spoken
  2274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the fifth and sixth Chapters.
  2275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe causes of this difference of Witts, are in the Passions: and
  2277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe difference of Passions, proceedeth partly from the different
  2278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConstitution of the body, and partly from different Education. For if
  2279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe difference proceeded from the temper of the brain, and the organs of
  2280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSense, either exterior or interior, there would be no lesse difference
  2281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men in their Sight, Hearing, or other Senses, than in their Fancies,
  2282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Discretions. It proceeds therefore from the Passions; which are
  2283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifferent, not onely from the difference of mens complexions; but also
  2284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom their difference of customes, and education.
  2285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Passions that most of all cause the differences of Wit, are
  2287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprincipally, the more or lesse Desire of Power, of Riches, of Knowledge,
  2288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand of Honour. All which may be reduced to the first, that is Desire of
  2289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower. For Riches, Knowledge and Honour are but severall sorts of Power.
  2290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGiddinesse Madnesse
  2295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore, a man who has no great Passion for any of these things;
  2297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut is as men terme it indifferent; though he may be so farre a good
  2298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, as to be free from giving offence; yet he cannot possibly have
  2299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither a great Fancy, or much Judgement. For the Thoughts, are to the
  2300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDesires, as Scouts, and Spies, to range abroad, and find the way to the
  2301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings Desired: All Stedinesse of the minds motion, and all quicknesse
  2302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the same, proceeding from thence. For as to have no Desire, is to
  2303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Dead: so to have weak Passions, is Dulnesse; and to have Passions
  2304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tindifferently for every thing, GIDDINESSE, and Distraction; and to have
  2305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstronger, and more vehement Passions for any thing, than is ordinarily
  2306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseen in others, is that which men call MADNESSE.
  2307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhereof there be almost as many kinds, as of the Passions themselves.
  2309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSometimes the extraordinary and extravagant Passion, proceedeth from the
  2310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevill constitution of the organs of the Body, or harme done them; and
  2311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes the hurt, and indisposition of the Organs, is caused by the
  2312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvehemence, or long continuance of the Passion. But in both cases the
  2313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMadnesse is of one and the same nature.
  2314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Passion, whose violence, or continuance maketh Madnesse, is either
  2316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat Vaine-Glory; which is commonly called Pride, and Selfe-Conceipt;
  2317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor great Dejection of mind.
  2318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRage
  2323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPride, subjecteth a man to Anger, the excesse whereof, is the Madnesse
  2325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled RAGE, and FURY. And thus it comes to passe that excessive desire
  2326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Revenge, when it becomes habituall, hurteth the organs, and becomes
  2327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRage: That excessive love, with jealousie, becomes also Rage: Excessive
  2328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion of a mans own selfe, for divine inspiration, for wisdome,
  2329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlearning, forme, and the like, becomes Distraction, and Giddinesse:
  2330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same, joyned with Envy, Rage: Vehement opinion of the truth of any
  2331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing, contradicted by others, Rage.
  2332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMelancholy
  2337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDejection, subjects a man to causelesse fears; which is a Madnesse
  2339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommonly called MELANCHOLY, apparent also in divers manners; as in
  2340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thaunting of solitudes, and graves; in superstitious behaviour; and in
  2341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfearing some one, some another particular thing. In summe, all Passions
  2342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat produce strange and unusuall behaviour, are called by the generall
  2343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of Madnesse. But of the severall kinds of Madnesse, he that
  2344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould take the paines, might enrowle a legion. And if the Excesses be
  2345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmadnesse, there is no doubt but the Passions themselves, when they tend
  2346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Evill, are degrees of the same.
  2347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(For example,) Though the effect of folly, in them that are possessed of
  2349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan opinion of being inspired, be not visible alwayes in one man, by any
  2350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery extravagant action, that proceedeth from such Passion; yet when
  2351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany of them conspire together, the Rage of the whole multitude is
  2352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvisible enough. For what argument of Madnesse can there be greater, than
  2353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto clamour, strike, and throw stones at our best friends? Yet this is
  2354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsomewhat lesse than such a multitude will do. For they will clamour,
  2355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfight against, and destroy those, by whom all their lifetime before,
  2356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey have been protected, and secured from injury. And if this be
  2357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMadnesse in the multitude, it is the same in every particular man. For
  2358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas in the middest of the sea, though a man perceive no sound of
  2359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat part of the water next him; yet he is well assured, that part
  2360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontributes as much, to the Roaring of the Sea, as any other part, of
  2361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same quantity: so also, thought wee perceive no great unquietnesse,
  2362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin one, or two men; yet we may be well assured, that their singular
  2363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions, are parts of the Seditious roaring of a troubled Nation. And
  2364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif there were nothing else that bewrayed their madnesse; yet that very
  2365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tarrogating such inspiration to themselves, is argument enough. If some
  2366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman in Bedlam should entertaine you with sober discourse; and you desire
  2367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin taking leave, to know what he were, that you might another time
  2368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequite his civility; and he should tell you, he were God the Father;
  2369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI think you need expect no extravagant action for argument of his
  2370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMadnesse.
  2371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis opinion of Inspiration, called commonly, Private Spirit, begins
  2373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery often, from some lucky finding of an Errour generally held by
  2374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tothers; and not knowing, or not remembring, by what conduct of reason,
  2375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey came to so singular a truth, (as they think it, though it be many
  2376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimes an untruth they light on,) they presently admire themselves; as
  2377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing in the speciall grace of God Almighty, who hath revealed the same
  2378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto them supernaturally, by his Spirit.
  2379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, that Madnesse is nothing else, but too much appearing Passion,
  2381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay be gathered out of the effects of Wine, which are the same with
  2382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose of the evill disposition of the organs. For the variety of
  2383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbehaviour in men that have drunk too much, is the same with that of
  2384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMad-men: some of them Raging, others Loving, others laughing, all
  2385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textravagantly, but according to their severall domineering Passions:
  2386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the effect of the wine, does but remove Dissimulation; and take from
  2387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem the sight of the deformity of their Passions. For, (I believe) the
  2388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost sober men, when they walk alone without care and employment of the
  2389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmind, would be unwilling the vanity and Extravagance of their thoughts
  2390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat that time should be publiquely seen: which is a confession, that
  2391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions unguided, are for the most part meere Madnesse.
  2392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe opinions of the world, both in antient and later ages, concerning
  2394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe cause of madnesse, have been two. Some, deriving them from the
  2395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions; some, from Daemons, or Spirits, either good, or bad, which
  2396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey thought might enter into a man, possesse him, and move his organs
  2397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis such strange, and uncouth manner, as mad-men use to do. The former
  2398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsort therefore, called such men, Mad-men: but the Later, called them
  2399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes Daemoniacks, (that is, possessed with spirits;) sometimes
  2400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnergumeni, (that is agitated, or moved with spirits;) and now in
  2401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tItaly they are called not onely Pazzi, Mad-men; but also Spiritati, men
  2402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossest.
  2403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere was once a great conflux of people in Abdera, a City of the
  2405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGreeks, at the acting of the Tragedy of Andromeda, upon an extream hot
  2406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tday: whereupon, a great many of the spectators falling into Fevers, had
  2407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis accident from the heat, and from The Tragedy together, that they
  2408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdid nothing but pronounce Iambiques, with the names of Perseus and
  2409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAndromeda; which together with the Fever, was cured, by the comming on
  2410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Winter: And this madnesse was thought to proceed from the Passion
  2411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timprinted by the Tragedy. Likewise there raigned a fit of madnesse in
  2412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother Graecian city, which seized onely the young Maidens; and caused
  2413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany of them to hang themselves. This was by most then thought an act of
  2414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Divel. But one that suspected, that contempt of life in them,
  2415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmight proceed from some Passion of the mind, and supposing they did not
  2416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontemne also their honour, gave counsell to the Magistrates, to strip
  2417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as so hang'd themselves, and let them hang out naked. This the
  2418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstory sayes cured that madnesse. But on the other side, the same
  2419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGraecians, did often ascribe madnesse, to the operation of the
  2420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEumenides, or Furyes; and sometimes of Ceres, Phoebus, and other Gods:
  2421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso much did men attribute to Phantasmes, as to think them aereal living
  2422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbodies; and generally to call them Spirits. And as the Romans in this,
  2423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theld the same opinion with the Greeks: so also did the Jewes; For they
  2424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalle mad-men Prophets, or (according as they thought the spirits
  2425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood or bad) Daemoniacks; and some of them called both Prophets, and
  2426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDaemoniacks, mad-men; and some called the same man both Daemoniack, and
  2427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmad-man. But for the Gentiles, 'tis no wonder; because Diseases, and
  2428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHealth; Vices, and Vertues; and many naturall accidents, were with them
  2429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttermed, and worshipped as Daemons. So that a man was to understand by
  2430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDaemon, as well (sometimes) an Ague, as a Divell. But for the Jewes to
  2431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave such opinion, is somewhat strange. For neither Moses, nor Abraham
  2432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretended to Prophecy by possession of a Spirit; but from the voyce of
  2433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod; or by a Vision or Dream: Nor is there any thing in his Law,
  2434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMorall, or Ceremoniall, by which they were taught, there was any such
  2435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnthusiasme; or any Possession. When God is sayd, (Numb. 11. 25.) to
  2436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake from the Spirit that was in Moses, and give it to the 70. Elders,
  2437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Spirit of God (taking it for the substance of God) is not divided.
  2438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Scriptures by the Spirit of God in man, mean a mans spirit, enclined
  2439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Godlinesse. And where it is said (Exod. 28. 3.) "Whom I have filled
  2440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the Spirit of wisdome to make garments for Aaron," is not meant a
  2441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspirit put into them, that can make garments; but the wisdome of their
  2442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town spirits in that kind of work. In the like sense, the spirit of
  2443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, when it produceth unclean actions, is ordinarily called an unclean
  2444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspirit; and so other spirits, though not alwayes, yet as often as the
  2445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvertue or vice so stiled, is extraordinary, and Eminent. Neither did the
  2446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Prophets of the old Testament pretend Enthusiasme; or, that God
  2447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspake in them; but to them by Voyce, Vision, or Dream; and the Burthen
  2448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Lord was not Possession, but Command. How then could the Jewes
  2449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfall into this opinion of possession? I can imagine no reason, but that
  2450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is common to all men; namely, the want of curiosity to search
  2451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturall causes; and their placing Felicity, in the acquisition of the
  2452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrosse pleasures of the Senses, and the things that most immediately
  2453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconduce thereto. For they that see any strange, and unusuall ability, or
  2454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdefect in a mans mind; unlesse they see withall, from what cause it may
  2455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprobably proceed, can hardly think it naturall; and if not naturall,
  2456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey must needs thinke it supernaturall; and then what can it be, but
  2457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat either God, or the Divell is in him? And hence it came to passe,
  2458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen our Saviour (Mark 3.21.) was compassed about with the multitude,
  2459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose of the house doubted he was mad, and went out to hold him: but
  2460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Scribes said he had Belzebub, and that was it, by which he cast out
  2461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivels; as if the greater mad-man had awed the lesser. And that (John
  2462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t10. 20.) some said, "He hath a Divell, and is mad;" whereas others
  2463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tholding him for a Prophet, sayd, "These are not the words of one that
  2464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath a Divell." So in the old Testament he that came to anoynt Jehu, (2
  2465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings 9.11.) was a Prophet; but some of the company asked Jehu, "What
  2466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcame that mad-man for?" So that in summe, it is manifest, that whosoever
  2467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbehaved himselfe in extraordinary manner, was thought by the Jewes to be
  2468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossessed either with a good, or evill spirit; except by the Sadduces,
  2469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho erred so farre on the other hand, as not to believe there were at
  2470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall any spirits, (which is very neere to direct Atheisme;) and thereby
  2471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperhaps the more provoked others, to terme such men Daemoniacks, rather
  2472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan mad-men.
  2473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut why then does our Saviour proceed in the curing of them, as if they
  2475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere possest; and not as if they were mad. To which I can give no other
  2476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkind of answer, but that which is given to those that urge the Scripture
  2477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin like manner against the opinion of the motion of the Earth. The
  2478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture was written to shew unto men the kingdome of God; and to
  2479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprepare their mindes to become his obedient subjects; leaving the
  2480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld, and the Philosophy thereof, to the disputation of men, for the
  2481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texercising of their naturall Reason. Whether the Earths, or Suns motion
  2482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake the day, and night; or whether the Exorbitant actions of men,
  2483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceed from Passion, or from the Divell, (so we worship him not) it is
  2484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall one, as to our obedience, and subjection to God Almighty; which is
  2485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe thing for which the Scripture was written. As for that our Saviour
  2486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeaketh to the disease, as to a person; it is the usuall phrase of all
  2487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat cure by words onely, as Christ did, (and Inchanters pretend to
  2488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo, whether they speak to a Divel or not.) For is not Christ also said
  2489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Math. 8.26.) to have rebuked the winds? Is not he said also (Luk. 4.
  2490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t39.) to rebuke a Fever? Yet this does not argue that a Fever is a Divel.
  2491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whereas many of these Divels are said to confesse Christ; it is not
  2492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessary to interpret those places otherwise, than that those mad-men
  2493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconfessed him. And whereas our Saviour (Math. 12. 43.) speaketh of an
  2494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunclean Spirit, that having gone out of a man, wandreth through dry
  2495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaces, seeking rest, and finding none; and returning into the same
  2496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, with seven other spirits worse than himselfe; It is manifestly a
  2497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tParable, alluding to a man, that after a little endeavour to quit his
  2498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlusts, is vanquished by the strength of them; and becomes seven times
  2499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworse than he was. So that I see nothing at all in the Scripture, that
  2500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequireth a beliefe, that Daemoniacks were any other thing but Mad-men.
  2501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInsignificant Speech
  2506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere is yet another fault in the Discourses of some men; which may also
  2508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe numbred amongst the sorts of Madnesse; namely, that abuse of words,
  2509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof I have spoken before in the fifth chapter, by the Name of
  2510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbsurdity. And that is, when men speak such words, as put together, have
  2511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin them no signification at all; but are fallen upon by some, through
  2512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmisunderstanding of the words they have received, and repeat by rote; by
  2513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tothers, from intention to deceive by obscurity. And this is incident to
  2514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone but those, that converse in questions of matters incomprehensible,
  2515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas the Schoole-men; or in questions of abstruse Philosophy. The common
  2516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsort of men seldome speak Insignificantly, and are therefore, by those
  2517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Egregious persons counted Idiots. But to be assured their words
  2518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare without any thing correspondent to them in the mind, there would
  2519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneed some Examples; which if any man require, let him take a Schoole-man
  2520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto his hands, and see if he can translate any one chapter concerning
  2521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany difficult point; as the Trinity; the Deity; the nature of Christ;
  2522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTransubstantiation; Free-will. &c. into any of the moderne tongues, so
  2523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas to make the same intelligible; or into any tolerable Latine, such
  2524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they were acquainted withall, that lived when the Latine tongue was
  2525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVulgar. What is the meaning of these words. "The first cause does not
  2526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessarily inflow any thing into the second, by force of the Essential
  2527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubordination of the second causes, by which it may help it to worke?"
  2528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThey are the Translation of the Title of the sixth chapter of Suarez
  2529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst Booke, Of The Concourse, Motion, And Help Of God. When men write
  2530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhole volumes of such stuffe, are they not Mad, or intend to make others
  2531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso? And particularly, in the question of Transubstantiation; where
  2532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter certain words spoken, they that say, the White-nesse, Round-nesse,
  2533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMagni-tude, Quali-ty, Corruptibili-ty, all which are incorporeall, &c.
  2534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgo out of the Wafer, into the Body of our blessed Saviour, do they not
  2535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake those Nesses, Tudes and Ties, to be so many spirits possessing his
  2536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbody? For by Spirits, they mean alwayes things, that being incorporeall,
  2537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare neverthelesse moveable from one place to another. So that this kind
  2538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Absurdity, may rightly be numbred amongst the many sorts of Madnesse;
  2539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand all the time that guided by clear Thoughts of their worldly lust,
  2540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey forbear disputing, or writing thus, but Lucide Intervals. And thus
  2541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmuch of the Vertues and Defects Intellectuall.
  2542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER IX. OF THE SEVERALL SUBJECTS OF KNOWLEDGE
  2546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere are of KNOWLEDGE two kinds; whereof one is Knowledge Of Fact: the
  2549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Knowledge Of The Consequence Of One Affirmation To Another. The
  2550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformer is nothing else, but Sense and Memory, and is Absolute Knowledge;
  2551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas when we see a Fact doing, or remember it done: And this is the
  2552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKnowledge required in a Witnesse. The later is called Science; and is
  2553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConditionall; as when we know, that, If The Figure Showne Be A Circle,
  2554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThen Any Straight Line Through The Centre Shall Divide It Into Two
  2555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEquall Parts. And this is the Knowledge required in a Philosopher; that
  2556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, of him that pretends to Reasoning.
  2557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Register of Knowledge Of Fact is called History. Whereof there be
  2559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttwo sorts: one called Naturall History; which is the History of such
  2560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFacts, or Effects of Nature, as have no Dependance on Mans Will; Such as
  2561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare the Histories of Metals, Plants, Animals, Regions, and the like. The
  2562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother, is Civill History; which is the History of the Voluntary Actions
  2563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men in Common-wealths.
  2564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Registers of Science, are such Books as contain the Demonstrations
  2566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Consequences of one Affirmation, to another; and are commonly called
  2567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBooks of Philosophy; whereof the sorts are many, according to the
  2568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiversity of the Matter; And may be divided in such manner as I have
  2569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivided them in the following Table.
  2570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
