  2693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t     B.  Consequences from the Accidents of Politique Bodies; which is
  2695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t        called POLITIQUES, and CIVILL PHILOSOPHY
  2696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t        1.  Of Consequences from the Institution of COMMON-WEALTHS, to
  2698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t           the Rights, and Duties of the Body Politique, or Soveraign.
  2699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t        2.  Of Consequences from the same, to the Duty and Right of
  2701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t           the Subjects.
  2702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER X. OF POWER, WORTH, DIGNITY, HONOUR AND WORTHINESS
  2706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower
  2711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe POWER of a Man, (to take it Universally,) is his present means,
  2713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obtain some future apparent Good. And is either Originall, or
  2714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstrumentall.
  2715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall Power, is the eminence of the Faculties of Body, or Mind: as
  2717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textraordinary Strength, Forme, Prudence, Arts, Eloquence, Liberality,
  2718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNobility. Instrumentall are those Powers, which acquired by these, or
  2719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby fortune, are means and Instruments to acquire more: as Riches,
  2720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReputation, Friends, and the Secret working of God, which men call
  2721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood Luck. For the nature of Power, is in this point, like to Fame,
  2722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tincreasing as it proceeds; or like the motion of heavy bodies, which the
  2723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfurther they go, make still the more hast.
  2724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Greatest of humane Powers, is that which is compounded of the Powers
  2726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof most men, united by consent, in one person, Naturall, or civill, that
  2727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thas the use of all their Powers depending on his will; such as is the
  2728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower of a Common-wealth: or depending on the wills of each particular;
  2729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as is the Power of a Faction, or of divers factions leagued.
  2730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore to have servants, is Power; To have Friends, is Power: for
  2731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are strengths united.
  2732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso Riches joyned with liberality, is Power; because it procureth
  2734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfriends, and servants: Without liberality, not so; because in this case
  2735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey defend not; but expose men to Envy, as a Prey.
  2736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReputation of power, is Power; because it draweth with it the adhaerance
  2738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof those that need protection.
  2739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo is Reputation of love of a mans Country, (called Popularity,) for the
  2741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame Reason.
  2742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso, what quality soever maketh a man beloved, or feared of many; or
  2744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe reputation of such quality, is Power; because it is a means to have
  2745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe assistance, and service of many.
  2746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood successe is Power; because it maketh reputation of Wisdome, or good
  2748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfortune; which makes men either feare him, or rely on him.
  2749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAffability of men already in power, is encrease of Power; because it
  2751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgaineth love.
  2752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReputation of Prudence in the conduct of Peace or War, is Power; because
  2754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto prudent men, we commit the government of our selves, more willingly
  2755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan to others.
  2756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNobility is Power, not in all places, but onely in those Common-wealths,
  2758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere it has Priviledges: for in such priviledges consisteth their
  2759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower.
  2760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEloquence is Power; because it is seeming Prudence.
  2762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tForme is Power; because being a promise of Good, it recommendeth men to
  2764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe favour of women and strangers.
  2765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Sciences, are small Power; because not eminent; and therefore, not
  2767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledged in any man; nor are at all, but in a few; and in them, but
  2768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a few things. For Science is of that nature, as none can understand
  2769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit to be, but such as in a good measure have attayned it.
  2770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArts of publique use, as Fortification, making of Engines, and other
  2772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstruments of War; because they conferre to Defence, and Victory,
  2773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Power; And though the true Mother of them, be Science, namely the
  2774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMathematiques; yet, because they are brought into the Light, by the hand
  2775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Artificer, they be esteemed (the Midwife passing with the vulgar
  2776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the Mother,) as his issue.
  2777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorth
  2782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Value, or WORTH of a man, is as of all other things, his Price;
  2784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, so much as would be given for the use of his Power:
  2785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore is not absolute; but a thing dependant on the need and
  2786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudgement of another. An able conductor of Souldiers, is of great Price
  2787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin time of War present, or imminent; but in Peace not so. A learned and
  2788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuncorrupt Judge, is much Worth in time of Peace; but not so much in
  2789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWar. And as in other things, so in men, not the seller, but the buyer
  2790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdetermines the Price. For let a man (as most men do,) rate themselves as
  2791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe highest Value they can; yet their true Value is no more than it is
  2792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\testeemed by others.
  2793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe manifestation of the Value we set on one another, is that which is
  2795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommonly called Honouring, and Dishonouring. To Value a man at a high
  2796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trate, is to Honour him; at a low rate, is to Dishonour him. But high,
  2797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand low, in this case, is to be understood by comparison to the rate
  2798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat each man setteth on himselfe.
  2799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDignity
  2804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe publique worth of a man, which is the Value set on him by the
  2806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, is that which men commonly call DIGNITY. And this Value
  2807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof him by the Common-wealth, is understood, by offices of Command,
  2808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudicature, publike Employment; or by Names and Titles, introduced for
  2809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdistinction of such Value.
  2810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Honour and Dishonour
  2815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo pray to another, for ayde of any kind, is to HONOUR; because a signe
  2817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe have an opinion he has power to help; and the more difficult the ayde
  2818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, the more is the Honour.
  2819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo obey, is to Honour; because no man obeyes them, whom they think
  2821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave no power to help, or hurt them. And consequently to disobey, is to
  2822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDishonour.
  2823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo give great gifts to a man, is to Honour him; because 'tis buying
  2825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Protection, and acknowledging of Power. To give little gifts, is to
  2826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDishonour; because it is but Almes, and signifies an opinion of the
  2827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneed of small helps. To be sedulous in promoting anothers good; also
  2828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto flatter, is to Honour; as a signe we seek his protection or ayde. To
  2829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneglect, is to Dishonour.
  2830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo give way, or place to another, in any Commodity, is to Honour; being
  2832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta confession of greater power. To arrogate, is to Dishonour.
  2833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo shew any signe of love, or feare of another, is to Honour; for both
  2835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto love, and to feare, is to value. To contemne, or lesse to love or
  2836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfeare then he expects, is to Dishonour; for 'tis undervaluing.
  2837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo praise, magnifie, or call happy, is to Honour; because nothing but
  2839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgoodnesse, power, and felicity is valued. To revile, mock, or pitty, is
  2840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Dishonour.
  2841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo speak to another with consideration, to appear before him with
  2843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdecency, and humility, is to Honour him; as signes of fear to offend.
  2844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo speak to him rashly, to do anything before him obscenely, slovenly,
  2845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpudently, is to Dishonour.
  2846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo believe, to trust, to rely on another, is to Honour him; signe of
  2848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion of his vertue and power. To distrust, or not believe, is to
  2849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDishonour.
  2850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo hearken to a mans counsell, or discourse of what kind soever, is to
  2852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonour; as a signe we think him wise, or eloquent, or witty. To sleep,
  2853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor go forth, or talk the while, is to Dishonour.
  2854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo do those things to another, which he takes for signes of Honour, or
  2856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Law or Custome makes so, is to Honour; because in approving
  2857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Honour done by others, he acknowledgeth the power which others
  2858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledge. To refuse to do them, is to Dishonour.
  2859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo agree with in opinion, is to Honour; as being a signe of approving
  2861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this judgement, and wisdome. To dissent, is Dishonour; and an upbraiding
  2862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof errour; and (if the dissent be in many things) of folly.
  2863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo imitate, is to Honour; for it is vehemently to approve. To imitate
  2865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tones Enemy, is to Dishonour.
  2866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo honour those another honours, is to Honour him; as a signe of
  2868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapprobation of his judgement. To honour his Enemies, is to Dishonour
  2869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim.
  2870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo employ in counsell, or in actions of difficulty, is to Honour; as a
  2872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsigne of opinion of his wisdome, or other power. To deny employment in
  2873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same cases, to those that seek it, is to Dishonour.
  2874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll these wayes of Honouring, are naturall; and as well within, as
  2876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout Common-wealths. But in Common-wealths, where he, or they that
  2877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave the supreme Authority, can make whatsoever they please, to stand
  2878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor signes of Honour, there be other Honours.
  2879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Soveraigne doth Honour a Subject, with whatsoever Title, or Office, or
  2881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEmployment, or Action, that he himselfe will have taken for a signe of
  2882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this will to Honour him.
  2883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe King of Persia, Honoured Mordecay, when he appointed he should be
  2885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconducted through the streets in the Kings Garment, upon one of the
  2886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings Horses, with a Crown on his head, and a Prince before him,
  2887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproclayming, "Thus shall it be done to him that the King will honour."
  2888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd yet another King of Persia, or the same another time, to one that
  2889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdemanded for some great service, to weare one of the Kings robes, gave
  2890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim leave so to do; but with his addition, that he should weare it as
  2891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Kings foole; and then it was Dishonour. So that of Civill Honour;
  2892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as are Magistracy, Offices, Titles; and in some places Coats, and
  2893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScutchions painted: and men Honour such as have them, as having so many
  2894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignes of favour in the Common-wealth; which favour is Power.
  2895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonourable is whatsoever possession, action, or quality, is an argument
  2897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand signe of Power.
  2898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore To be Honoured, loved, or feared of many, is Honourable;
  2900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas arguments of Power. To be Honoured of few or none, Dishonourable.
  2901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood fortune (if lasting,) Honourable; as a signe of the favour of God.
  2903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIll fortune, and losses, Dishonourable. Riches, are Honourable; for
  2904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are Power. Poverty, Dishonourable. Magnanimity, Liberality,
  2905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHope, Courage, Confidence, are Honourable; for they proceed from the
  2906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconscience of Power. Pusillanimity, Parsimony, Fear, Diffidence, are
  2907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDishonourable.
  2908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTimely Resolution, or determination of what a man is to do, is
  2910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonourable; as being the contempt of small difficulties, and dangers.
  2911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Irresolution, Dishonourable; as a signe of too much valuing of
  2912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlittle impediments, and little advantages: For when a man has weighed
  2913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings as long as the time permits, and resolves not, the difference
  2914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof weight is but little; and therefore if he resolve not, he overvalues
  2915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlittle things, which is Pusillanimity.
  2916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll Actions, and Speeches, that proceed, or seem to proceed from much
  2918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExperience, Science, Discretion, or Wit, are Honourable; For all these
  2919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Powers. Actions, or Words that proceed from Errour, Ignorance, or
  2920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFolly, Dishonourable.
  2921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGravity, as farre forth as it seems to proceed from a mind employed on
  2923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome thing else, is Honourable; because employment is a signe of
  2924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower. But if it seem to proceed from a purpose to appear grave, it is
  2925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDishonourable. For the gravity of the Former, is like the steddinesse of
  2926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Ship laden with Merchandise; but of the later, like the steddinesse of
  2927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Ship ballasted with Sand, and other trash.
  2928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo be Conspicuous, that is to say, to be known, for Wealth, Office,
  2930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat Actions, or any eminent Good, is Honourable; as a signe of the
  2931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower for which he is conspicuous. On the contrary, Obscurity, is
  2932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDishonourable.
  2933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo be descended from conspicuous Parents, is Honourable; because they
  2935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe more easily attain the aydes, and friends of their Ancestors. On the
  2936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary, to be descended from obscure Parentage, is Dishonourable.
  2937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActions proceeding from Equity, joyned with losse, are Honourable;
  2939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas signes of Magnanimity: for Magnanimity is a signe of Power. On the
  2940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary, Craft, Shifting, neglect of Equity, is Dishonourable.
  2941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor does it alter the case of Honour, whether an action (so it be great
  2943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand difficult, and consequently a signe of much power,) be just or
  2944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunjust: for Honour consisteth onely in the opinion of Power. Therefore
  2945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe ancient Heathen did not thinke they Dishonoured, but greatly
  2946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonoured the Gods, when they introduced them in their Poems, committing
  2947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRapes, Thefts, and other great, but unjust, or unclean acts: In so much
  2948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas nothing is so much celebrated in Jupiter, as his Adulteries; nor
  2949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Mercury, as his Frauds, and Thefts: of whose praises, in a hymne
  2950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Homer, the greatest is this, that being born in the morning, he had
  2951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinvented Musique at noon, and before night, stolen away the Cattell of
  2952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAppollo, from his Herdsmen.
  2953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso amongst men, till there were constituted great Common-wealths,
  2955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit was thought no dishonour to be a Pyrate, or a High-way Theefe; but
  2956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trather a lawfull Trade, not onely amongst the Greeks, but also amongst
  2957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall other Nations; as is manifest by the Histories of antient time. And
  2958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat this day, in this part of the world, private Duels are, and alwayes
  2959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill be Honourable, though unlawfull, till such time as there shall be
  2960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonour ordained for them that refuse, and Ignominy for them that make
  2961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Challenge. For Duels also are many times effects of Courage; and the
  2962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tground of Courage is alwayes Strength or Skill, which are Power; though
  2963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the most part they be effects of rash speaking, and of the fear of
  2964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDishonour, in one, or both the Combatants; who engaged by rashnesse, are
  2965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdriven into the Lists to avoyd disgrace.
  2966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScutchions, and coats of Armes haereditary, where they have any eminent
  2968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriviledges, are Honourable; otherwise not: for their Power consisteth
  2969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither in such Priviledges, or in Riches, or some such thing as is
  2970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequally honoured in other men. This kind of Honour, commonly called
  2971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGentry, has been derived from the Antient Germans. For there never was
  2972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany such thing known, where the German Customes were unknown. Nor is it
  2973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnow any where in use, where the Germans have not inhabited. The antient
  2974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGreek Commanders, when they went to war, had their Shields painted with
  2975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch Devises as they pleased; insomuch as an unpainted Buckler was a
  2976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsigne of Poverty, and of a common Souldier: but they transmitted not the
  2977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInheritance of them. The Romans transmitted the Marks of their Families:
  2978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut they were the Images, not the Devises of their Ancestors. Amongst
  2979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people of Asia, Afrique, and America, there is not, nor was ever,
  2980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany such thing. The Germans onely had that custome; from whom it has
  2981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen derived into England, France, Spain, and Italy, when in great
  2982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnumbers they either ayded the Romans, or made their own Conquests in
  2983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese Westerne parts of the world.
  2984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  2985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor Germany, being antiently, as all other Countries, in their
  2986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeginnings, divided amongst an infinite number of little Lords, or
  2987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMasters of Families, that continually had wars one with another; those
  2988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMasters, or Lords, principally to the end they might, when they were
  2989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovered with Arms, be known by their followers; and partly for ornament,
  2990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth painted their Armor, or their Scutchion, or Coat, with the picture
  2991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof some Beast, or other thing; and also put some eminent and visible
  2992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmark upon the Crest of their Helmets. And his ornament both of the
  2993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArmes, and Crest, descended by inheritance to their Children; to the
  2994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teldest pure, and to the rest with some note of diversity, such as the
  2995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOld master, that is to say in Dutch, the Here-alt thought fit. But when
  2996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany such Families, joyned together, made a greater Monarchy, this duty
  2997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Herealt, to distinguish Scutchions, was made a private Office
  2998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta part. And the issue of these Lords, is the great and antient Gentry;
  2999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich for the most part bear living creatures, noted for courage, and
  3000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trapine; or Castles, Battlements, Belts, Weapons, Bars, Palisadoes, and
  3001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother notes of War; nothing being then in honour, but vertue military.
  3002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfterwards, not onely Kings, but popular Common-wealths, gave divers
  3003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanners of Scutchions, to such as went forth to the War, or returned
  3004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom it, for encouragement, or recompence to their service. All which,
  3005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby an observing Reader, may be found in such ancient Histories, Greek
  3006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Latine, as make mention of the German Nation, and Manners, in their
  3007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimes.
  3008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTitles of Honour
  3013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTitles of Honour, such as are Duke, Count, Marquis, and Baron, are
  3015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonourable; as signifying the value set upon them by the Soveraigne
  3016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower of the Common-wealth: Which Titles, were in old time titles
  3017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Office, and Command, derived some from the Romans, some from the
  3018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGermans, and French. Dukes, in Latine Duces, being Generalls in War:
  3019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounts, Comites, such as bare the Generall company out of friendship;
  3020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand were left to govern and defend places conquered, and pacified:
  3021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMarquises, Marchiones, were Counts that governed the Marches, or bounds
  3022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Empire. Which titles of Duke, Count, and Marquis, came into the
  3023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEmpire, about the time of Constantine the Great, from the customes of
  3024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe German Militia. But Baron, seems to have been a Title of the Gaules,
  3025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand signifies a Great man; such as were the Kings, or Princes men, whom
  3026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey employed in war about their persons; and seems to be derived from
  3027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVir, to Ber, and Bar, that signified the same in the Language of the
  3028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGaules, that Vir in Latine; and thence to Bero, and Baro: so that such
  3029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen were called Berones, and after Barones; and (in Spanish) Varones.
  3030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut he that would know more particularly the originall of Titles of
  3031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonour, may find it, as I have done this, in Mr. Seldens most excellent
  3032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTreatise of that subject. In processe of time these offices of Honour,
  3033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby occasion of trouble, and for reasons of good and peacable government,
  3034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere turned into meer Titles; serving for the most part, to distinguish
  3035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe precedence, place, and order of subjects in the Common-wealth: and
  3036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen were made Dukes, Counts, Marquises, and Barons of Places, wherein
  3037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey had neither possession, nor command: and other Titles also, were
  3038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdevised to the same end.
  3039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorthinesse Fitnesse
  3044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWORTHINESSE, is a thing different from the worth, or value of a man; and
  3046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso from his merit, or desert; and consisteth in a particular power,
  3047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor ability for that, whereof he is said to be worthy: which particular
  3048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tability, is usually named FITNESSE, or Aptitude.
  3049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor he is Worthiest to be a Commander, to be a Judge, or to have any
  3051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother charge, that is best fitted, with the qualities required to the
  3052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twell discharging of it; and Worthiest of Riches, that has the qualities
  3053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost requisite for the well using of them: any of which qualities being
  3054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsent, one may neverthelesse be a Worthy man, and valuable for
  3055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome thing else. Again, a man may be Worthy of Riches, Office, and
  3056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEmployment, that neverthelesse, can plead no right to have it before
  3057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother; and therefore cannot be said to merit or deserve it. For Merit,
  3058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpraesupposeth a right, and that the thing deserved is due by promise: Of
  3059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich I shall say more hereafter, when I shall speak of Contracts.
  3060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

  3064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XI. OF THE DIFFERENCE OF MANNERS
  3065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat Is Here Meant By Manners
  3070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy MANNERS, I mean not here, Decency of behaviour; as how one man should
  3072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsalute another, or how a man should wash his mouth, or pick his teeth
  3073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore company, and such other points of the Small Morals; But those
  3074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tqualities of man-kind, that concern their living together in Peace, and
  3075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUnity. To which end we are to consider, that the Felicity of this life,
  3076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsisteth not in the repose of a mind satisfied. For there is no such
  3077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFinis Ultimus, (utmost ayme,) nor Summum Bonum, (greatest good,) as is
  3078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspoken of in the Books of the old Morall Philosophers. Nor can a man
  3079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany more live, whose Desires are at an end, than he, whose Senses and
  3080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImaginations are at a stand. Felicity is a continuall progresse of the
  3081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesire, from one object to another; the attaining of the former, being
  3082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstill but the way to the later. The cause whereof is, That the object
  3083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof mans desire, is not to enjoy once onely, and for one instant of time;
  3084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut to assure for ever, the way of his future desire. And therefore the
  3085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvoluntary actions, and inclinations of all men, tend, not only to the
  3086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprocuring, but also to the assuring of a contented life; and differ
  3087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely in the way: which ariseth partly from the diversity of passions,
  3088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin divers men; and partly from the difference of the knowledge, or
  3089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion each one has of the causes, which produce the effect desired.
  3090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Restlesse Desire Of Power, In All Men
  3095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo that in the first place, I put for a generall inclination of all
  3097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmankind, a perpetuall and restlesse desire of Power after power, that
  3098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tceaseth onely in Death. And the cause of this, is not alwayes that a man
  3099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thopes for a more intensive delight, than he has already attained to; or
  3100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat he cannot be content with a moderate power: but because he cannot
  3101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassure the power and means to live well, which he hath present, without
  3102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe acquisition of more. And from hence it is, that Kings, whose power
  3103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis greatest, turn their endeavours to the assuring it a home by Lawes,
  3104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor abroad by Wars: and when that is done, there succeedeth a new desire;
  3105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin some, of Fame from new Conquest; in others, of ease and sensuall
  3106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpleasure; in others, of admiration, or being flattered for excellence in
  3107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome art, or other ability of the mind.
  3108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLove Of Contention From Competition
  3113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCompetition of Riches, Honour, command, or other power, enclineth to
  3115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContention, Enmity, and War: because the way of one Competitor, to the
  3116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tattaining of his desire, is to kill, subdue, supplant, or repell the
  3117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother. Particularly, competition of praise, enclineth to a reverence of
  3118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAntiquity. For men contend with the living, not with the dead; to these
  3119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tascribing more than due, that they may obscure the glory of the other.
  3120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivil Obedience From Love Of Ease
  3125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDesire of Ease, and sensuall Delight, disposeth men to obey a common
  3127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower: because by such Desires, a man doth abandon the protection might
  3128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe hoped for from his own Industry, and labour.

  3133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom Feare Of Death Or Wounds
  3134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFear of Death, and Wounds, disposeth to the same; and for the same
  3136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treason. On the contrary, needy men, and hardy, not contented with their
  3137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent condition; as also, all men that are ambitious of Military
  3138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommand, are enclined to continue the causes of warre; and to stirre up
  3139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrouble and sedition: for there is no honour Military but by warre; nor
  3140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany such hope to mend an ill game, as by causing a new shuffle.

  3147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDesire of Knowledge, and Arts of Peace, enclineth men to obey a common
  3148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower: For such Desire, containeth a desire of leasure; and consequently

  3154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLove Of Vertue, From Love Of Praise
  3155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDesire of Praise, disposeth to laudable actions, such as please them
  3157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose judgement they value; for of these men whom we contemn, we contemn
  3158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso the Praises. Desire of Fame after death does the same. And though
  3159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter death, there be no sense of the praise given us on Earth, as being
  3160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjoyes, that are either swallowed up in the unspeakable joyes of Heaven,
  3161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor extinguished in the extreme torments of Hell: yet is not such Fame
  3162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvain; because men have a present delight therein, from the foresight
  3163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof it, and of the benefit that may rebound thereby to their posterity:
  3164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich though they now see not, yet they imagine; and any thing that is
  3165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpleasure in the sense, the same also is pleasure in the imagination.

  3170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHate, From Difficulty Of Requiting Great Benefits
  3171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo have received from one, to whom we think our selves equall, greater
  3173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbenefits than there is hope to Requite, disposeth to counterfiet love;
  3174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut really secret hatred; and puts a man into the estate of a desperate
  3175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdebtor, that in declining the sight of his creditor, tacitely wishes
  3176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim there, where he might never see him more. For benefits oblige; and
  3177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobligation is thraldome; which is to ones equall, hateful. But to have
  3178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceived benefits from one, whom we acknowledge our superiour, enclines
  3179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto love; because the obligation is no new depession: and cheerfull
  3180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacceptation, (which men call Gratitude,) is such an honour done to
  3181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe obliger, as is taken generally for retribution. Also to receive
  3182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbenefits, though from an equall, or inferiour, as long as there is hope
  3183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof requitall, disposeth to love: for in the intention of the receiver,
  3184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe obligation is of ayd, and service mutuall; from whence proceedeth
  3185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Emulation of who shall exceed in benefiting; the most noble and
  3186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprofitable contention possible; wherein the victor is pleased with his
  3187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvictory, and the other revenged by confessing it.

  3194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo have done more hurt to a man, than he can, or is willing to expiate,
  3195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenclineth the doer to hate the sufferer. For he must expect revenge, or
  3196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforgivenesse; both which are hatefull.

  3210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd From Distrust Of Their Own Wit
  3211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMen that distrust their own subtilty, are in tumult, and sedition,
  3213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetter disposed for victory, than they that suppose themselves wise,
  3214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor crafty. For these love to consult, the other (fearing to be
  3215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcircumvented,) to strike first. And in sedition, men being alwayes in
  3216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe procincts of Battell, to hold together, and use all advantages of
  3217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforce, is a better stratagem, than any that can proceed from subtilty of
  3218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWit.
  3219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVain Undertaking From Vain-glory
  3224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVain-glorious men, such as without being conscious to themselves of
  3226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat sufficiency, delight in supposing themselves gallant men, are
  3227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenclined onely to ostentation; but not to attempt: Because when
  3228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdanger or difficulty appears, they look for nothing but to have their
  3229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinsufficiency discovered.
  3230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVain-glorious men, such as estimate their sufficiency by the flattery
  3232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof other men, or the fortune of some precedent action, without assured
  3233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tground of hope from the true knowledge of themselves, are enclined to
  3234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trash engaging; and in the approach of danger, or difficulty, to retire
  3235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif they can: because not seeing the way of safety, they will rather
  3236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thazard their honour, which may be salved with an excuse; than their
  3237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlives, for which no salve is sufficient.
  3238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

  3242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAmbition, From Opinion Of Sufficiency
  3243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMen that have a strong opinion of their own wisdome in matter of
  3245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgovernment, are disposed to Ambition. Because without publique
  3246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEmployment in counsell or magistracy, the honour of their wisdome is
  3247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlost. And therefore Eloquent speakers are enclined to Ambition; for
  3248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEloquence seemeth wisdome, both to themselves and others
  3249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIrresolution, From Too Great Valuing Of Small Matters
  3254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPusillanimity disposeth men to Irresolution, and consequently to lose
  3256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe occasions, and fittest opportunities of action. For after men have
  3257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen in deliberation till the time of action approach, if it be not
  3258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen manifest what is best to be done, tis a signe, the difference of
  3259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMotives, the one way and the other, are not great: Therefore not to
  3260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tresolve then, is to lose the occasion by weighing of trifles; which is
  3261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpusillanimity.
  3262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrugality,(though in poor men a Vertue,) maketh a man unapt to atchieve
  3264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch actions, as require the strength of many men at once: For it
  3265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tweakeneth their Endeavour, which is to be nourished and kept in vigor by
  3266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReward.
  3267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConfidence In Others From Ignorance Of The Marks Of Wisdome and
  3269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKindnesse Eloquence, with flattery, disposeth men to confide in them
  3270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat have it; because the former is seeming Wisdome, the later seeming
  3271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKindnesse. Adde to them Military reputation, and it disposeth men to
  3272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadhaere, and subject themselves to those men that have them. The two
  3273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformer, having given them caution against danger from him; the later
  3274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgives them caution against danger from others.
  3275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

  3277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd From The Ignorance Of Naturall Causes
  3280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWant of Science, that is, Ignorance of causes, disposeth, or rather
  3282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstraineth a man to rely on the advise, and authority of others. For
  3283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall men whom the truth concernes, if they rely not on their own,
  3284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmust rely on the opinion of some other, whom they think wiser than
  3285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, and see not why he should deceive them.

  3289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd From Want Of Understanding
  3291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance of the signification of words; which is, want of
  3293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstanding, disposeth men to take on trust, not onely the truth they
  3294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow not; but also the errors; and which is more, the non-sense of them
  3295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey trust: For neither Error, nor non-sense, can without a perfect
  3296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstanding of words, be detected.
  3297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom the same it proceedeth, that men give different names, to one and
  3299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same thing, from the difference of their own passions: As they that
  3300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapprove a private opinion, call it Opinion; but they that mislike it,
  3301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHaeresie: and yet haeresie signifies no more than private opinion; but
  3302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thas onely a greater tincture of choler.
  3303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom the same also it proceedeth, that men cannot distinguish, without
  3305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstudy and great understanding, between one action of many men, and many
  3306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions of one multitude; as for example, between the one action of
  3307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall the Senators of Rome in killing Catiline, and the many actions of a
  3308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnumber of Senators in killing Caesar; and therefore are disposed to take
  3309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the action of the people, that which is a multitude of actions done
  3310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby a multitude of men, led perhaps by the perswasion of one.
  3311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdhaerence To Custome, From Ignorance Of The Nature Of Right And Wrong
  3313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance of the causes, and originall constitution of Right, Equity,
  3314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, and Justice, disposeth a man to make Custome and Example the rule
  3315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his actions; in such manner, as to think that Unjust which it
  3316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath been the custome to punish; and that Just, of the impunity and
  3317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapprobation whereof they can produce an Example, or (as the Lawyers
  3318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich onely use the false measure of Justice barbarously call it) a
  3319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrecedent; like little children, that have no other rule of good and
  3320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevill manners, but the correction they receive from their Parents, and
  3321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMasters; save that children are constant to their rule, whereas men are
  3322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot so; because grown strong, and stubborn, they appeale from custome
  3323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto reason, and from reason to custome, as it serves their turn; receding
  3324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom custome when their interest requires it, and setting themselves
  3325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst reason, as oft as reason is against them: Which is the cause,
  3326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat the doctrine of Right and Wrong, is perpetually disputed, both by
  3327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Pen and the Sword: whereas the doctrine of Lines, and Figures, is
  3328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot so; because men care not, in that subject what be truth, as a thing
  3329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat crosses no mans ambition, profit, or lust. For I doubt not, but if
  3330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit had been a thing contrary to any mans right of dominion, or to the
  3331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterest of men that have dominion, That The Three Angles Of A Triangle
  3332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tShould Be Equall To Two Angles Of A Square; that doctrine should have
  3333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen, if not disputed, yet by the burning of all books of Geometry,
  3334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuppressed, as farre as he whom it concerned was able.
  3335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdhaerence To Private Men, From Ignorance Of The Causes Of Peace
  3337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance of remote causes, disposeth men to attribute all events, to
  3338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe causes immediate, and Instrumentall: For these are all the causes
  3339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey perceive. And hence it comes to passe, that in all places, men that
  3340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare grieved with payments to the Publique, discharge their anger upon
  3341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Publicans, that is to say, Farmers, Collectors, and other Officers
  3342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the publique Revenue; and adhaere to such as find fault with the
  3343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublike Government; and thereby, when they have engaged themselves
  3344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeyond hope of justification, fall also upon the Supreme Authority, for
  3345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfeare of punishment, or shame of receiving pardon.
  3346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCredulity From Ignorance Of Nature
  3351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance of naturall causes disposeth a man to Credulity, so as
  3353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto believe many times impossibilities: for such know nothing to
  3354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe contrary, but that they may be true; being unable to detect the
  3355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImpossibility. And Credulity, because men love to be hearkened unto in
  3356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcompany, disposeth them to lying: so that Ignorance it selfe without
  3357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMalice, is able to make a man bothe to believe lyes, and tell them; and
  3358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes also to invent them.
  3359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCuriosity To Know, From Care Of Future Time
  3364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnxiety for the future time, disposeth men to enquire into the causes
  3366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof things: because the knowledge of them, maketh men the better able to
  3367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\torder the present to their best advantage.
  3368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall Religion, From The Same
  3373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCuriosity, or love of the knowledge of causes, draws a man from
  3375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsideration of the effect, to seek the cause; and again, the cause of
  3376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat cause; till of necessity he must come to this thought at last, that
  3377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is some cause, whereof there is no former cause, but is eternall;
  3378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is it men call God. So that it is impossible to make any profound
  3379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenquiry into naturall causes, without being enclined thereby to believe
  3380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is one God Eternall; though they cannot have any Idea of him in
  3381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir mind, answerable to his nature. For as a man that is born blind,
  3382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thearing men talk of warming themselves by the fire, and being brought
  3383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto warm himself by the same, may easily conceive, and assure himselfe,
  3384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is somewhat there, which men call Fire, and is the cause of the
  3385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theat he feeles; but cannot imagine what it is like; nor have an Idea of
  3386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit in his mind, such as they have that see it: so also, by the visible
  3387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings of this world, and their admirable order, a man may conceive
  3388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is a cause of them, which men call God; and yet not have an Idea,
  3389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Image of him in his mind.
  3390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd they that make little, or no enquiry into the naturall causes of
  3392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings, yet from the feare that proceeds from the ignorance it selfe,
  3393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof what it is that hath the power to do them much good or harm, are
  3394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenclined to suppose, and feign unto themselves, severall kinds of Powers
  3395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInvisible; and to stand in awe of their own imaginations; and in time
  3396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof distresse to invoke them; as also in the time of an expected good
  3397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuccesse, to give them thanks; making the creatures of their own
  3398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfancy, their Gods. By which means it hath come to passe, that from the
  3399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinnumerable variety of Fancy, men have created in the world innumerable
  3400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsorts of Gods. And this Feare of things invisible, is the naturall Seed
  3401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof that, which every one in himself calleth Religion; and in them that
  3402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworship, or feare that Power otherwise than they do, Superstition.
  3403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd this seed of Religion, having been observed by many; some of those
  3405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat have observed it, have been enclined thereby to nourish, dresse,
  3406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand forme it into Lawes; and to adde to it of their own invention,
  3407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany opinion of the causes of future events, by which they thought they
  3408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould best be able to govern others, and make unto themselves the
  3409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreatest use of their Powers.
  3410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XII. OF RELIGION
  3414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion, In Man Onely
  3419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing there are no signes, nor fruit of Religion, but in Man onely;
  3421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is no cause to doubt, but that the seed of Religion, is also onely
  3422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Man; and consisteth in some peculiar quality, or at least in some
  3423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teminent degree thereof, not to be found in other Living creatures.
  3424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFirst, From His Desire Of Knowing Causes
  3429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first, it is peculiar to the nature of Man, to be inquisitive into
  3431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Causes of the Events they see, some more, some lesse; but all men so
  3432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmuch, as to be curious in the search of the causes of their own good and
  3433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevill fortune.
  3434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom The Consideration Of The Beginning Of Things
  3439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, upon the sight of any thing that hath a Beginning, to think
  3441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso it had a cause, which determined the same to begin, then when it
  3442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdid, rather than sooner or later.
  3443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom His Observation Of The Sequell Of Things
  3448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, whereas there is no other Felicity of Beasts, but the enjoying
  3450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their quotidian Food, Ease, and Lusts; as having little, or no
  3451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforesight of the time to come, for want of observation, and memory
  3452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the order, consequence, and dependance of the things they see; Man
  3453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserveth how one Event hath been produced by another; and remembreth in
  3454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem Antecedence and Consequence; And when he cannot assure himselfe of
  3455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe true causes of things, (for the causes of good and evill fortune for
  3456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe most part are invisible,) he supposes causes of them, either such
  3457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas his own fancy suggesteth; or trusteth to the Authority of other men,
  3458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as he thinks to be his friends, and wiser than himselfe.
  3459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Naturall Cause Of Religion, The Anxiety Of The Time To Come The
  3461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttwo first, make Anxiety. For being assured that there be causes of all
  3462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings that have arrived hitherto, or shall arrive hereafter; it is
  3463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpossible for a man, who continually endeavoureth to secure himselfe
  3464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the evill he feares, and procure the good he desireth, not to
  3465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe in a perpetuall solicitude of the time to come; So that every man,
  3466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tespecially those that are over provident, are in an estate like to that
  3467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Prometheus. For as Prometheus, (which interpreted, is, The Prudent
  3468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMan,) was bound to the hill Caucasus, a place of large prospect, where,
  3469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Eagle feeding on his liver, devoured in the day, as much as was
  3470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepayred in the night: So that man, which looks too far before him, in
  3471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe care of future time, hath his heart all the day long, gnawed on by
  3472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfeare of death, poverty, or other calamity; and has no repose, nor pause
  3473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his anxiety, but in sleep.
  3474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhich Makes Them Fear The Power Of Invisible Things
  3479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis perpetuall feare, alwayes accompanying mankind in the ignorance of
  3481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcauses, as it were in the Dark, must needs have for object something.
  3482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore when there is nothing to be seen, there is nothing to
  3483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccuse, either of their good, or evill fortune, but some Power, or Agent
  3484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInvisible: In which sense perhaps it was, that some of the old Poets
  3485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid, that the Gods were at first created by humane Feare: which spoken
  3486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Gods, (that is to say, of the many Gods of the Gentiles) is
  3487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery true. But the acknowledging of one God Eternall, Infinite, and
  3488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOmnipotent, may more easily be derived, from the desire men have to
  3489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow the causes of naturall bodies, and their severall vertues, and
  3490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toperations; than from the feare of what was to befall them in time to
  3491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome. For he that from any effect hee seeth come to passe, should reason
  3492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the next and immediate cause thereof, and from thence to the cause
  3493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof that cause, and plonge himselfe profoundly in the pursuit of causes;
  3494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall at last come to this, that there must be (as even the Heathen
  3495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophers confessed) one First Mover; that is, a First, and an
  3496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternall cause of all things; which is that which men mean by the name
  3497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God: And all this without thought of their fortune; the solicitude
  3498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof, both enclines to fear, and hinders them from the search of the
  3499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcauses of other things; and thereby gives occasion of feigning of as
  3500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany Gods, as there be men that feigne them.
  3501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Suppose Them Incorporeall
  3506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd for the matter, or substance of the Invisible Agents, so fancyed;
  3508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey could not by naturall cogitation, fall upon any other conceipt, but
  3509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat it was the same with that of the Soule of man; and that the Soule
  3510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof man, was of the same substance, with that which appeareth in a Dream,
  3511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto one that sleepeth; or in a Looking-glasse, to one that is awake;
  3512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich, men not knowing that such apparitions are nothing else but
  3513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcreatures of the Fancy, think to be reall, and externall Substances;
  3514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore call them Ghosts; as the Latines called them Imagines,
  3515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Umbrae; and thought them Spirits, that is, thin aereall bodies; and
  3516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Invisible Agents, which they feared, to bee like them; save that
  3517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey appear, and vanish when they please. But the opinion that such
  3518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirits were Incorporeall, or Immateriall, could never enter into the
  3519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmind of any man by nature; because, though men may put together words of
  3520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontradictory signification, as Spirit, and Incorporeall; yet they
  3521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan never have the imagination of any thing answering to them:
  3522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore, men that by their own meditation, arrive to the
  3523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledgement of one Infinite, Omnipotent, and Eternall God,
  3524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchoose rather to confesse he is Incomprehensible, and above their
  3525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstanding; than to define his Nature By Spirit Incorporeall, and
  3526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen Confesse their definition to be unintelligible: or if they give him
  3527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch a title, it is not Dogmatically, with intention to make the Divine
  3528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature understood; but Piously, to honour him with attributes, of
  3529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifications, as remote as they can from the grossenesse of Bodies
  3530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVisible.
  3531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut Know Not The Way How They Effect Anything
  3536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThen, for the way by which they think these Invisible Agents wrought
  3538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir effects; that is to say, what immediate causes they used, in
  3539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbringing things to passe, men that know not what it is that we call
  3540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCausing, (that is, almost all men) have no other rule to guesse by, but
  3541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby observing, and remembring what they have seen to precede the like
  3542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teffect at some other time, or times before, without seeing between the
  3543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tantecedent and subsequent Event, any dependance or connexion at all:
  3544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore from the like things past, they expect the like things to
  3545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome; and hope for good or evill luck, superstitiously, from things that
  3546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave no part at all in the causing of it: As the Athenians did for their
  3547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twar at Lepanto, demand another Phormio; the Pompeian faction for their
  3548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twarre in Afrique, another Scipio; and others have done in divers other
  3549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toccasions since. In like manner they attribute their fortune to a
  3550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstander by, to a lucky or unlucky place, to words spoken, especially
  3551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif the name of God be amongst them; as Charming, and Conjuring (the
  3552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLeiturgy of Witches;) insomuch as to believe, they have power to turn a
  3553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstone into bread, bread into a man, or any thing, into any thing.
  3554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut Honour Them As They Honour Men
  3559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, for the worship which naturally men exhibite to Powers
  3561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinvisible, it can be no other, but such expressions of their reverence,
  3562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they would use towards men; Gifts, Petitions, Thanks, Submission
  3563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Body, Considerate Addresses, sober Behaviour, premeditated Words,
  3564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSwearing (that is, assuring one another of their promises,) by invoking
  3565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem. Beyond that reason suggesteth nothing; but leaves them either to
  3566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trest there; or for further ceremonies, to rely on those they believe to
  3567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe wiser than themselves.
  3568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Attribute To Them All Extraordinary Events
  3573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, concerning how these Invisible Powers declare to men the things
  3575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich shall hereafter come to passe, especially concerning their good
  3576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor evill fortune in generall, or good or ill successe in any particular
  3577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tundertaking, men are naturally at a stand; save that using to conjecture
  3578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the time to come, by the time past, they are very apt, not onely to
  3579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake casuall things, after one or two encounters, for Prognostiques
  3580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the like encounter ever after, but also to believe the like
  3581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrognostiques from other men, of whom they have once conceived a good
  3582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion.
  3583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

  3587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFoure Things, Naturall Seeds Of Religion
  3588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd in these foure things, Opinion of Ghosts, Ignorance of second
  3590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcauses, Devotion towards what men fear, and Taking of things Casuall for
  3591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrognostiques, consisteth the Naturall seed of Religion; which by reason
  3592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the different Fancies, Judgements, and Passions of severall men, hath
  3593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrown up into ceremonies so different, that those which are used by one
  3594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, are for the most part ridiculous to another.
  3595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMade Different By Culture
  3600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor these seeds have received culture from two sorts of men. One sort
  3602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave been they, that have nourished, and ordered them, according to
  3603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own invention. The other, have done it, by Gods commandement, and
  3604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdirection: but both sorts have done it, with a purpose to make those men
  3605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat relyed on them, the more apt to Obedience, Lawes, Peace, Charity,
  3606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand civill Society. So that the Religion of the former sort, is a part
  3607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof humane Politiques; and teacheth part of the duty which Earthly Kings
  3608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequire of their Subjects. And the Religion of the later sort is
  3609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivine Politiques; and containeth Precepts to those that have yeelded
  3610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves subjects in the Kingdome of God. Of the former sort, were all
  3611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Founders of Common-wealths, and the Law-givers of the Gentiles: Of
  3612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe later sort, were Abraham, Moses, and our Blessed Saviour; by whom
  3613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave been derived unto us the Lawes of the Kingdome of God.
  3614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Absurd Opinion Of Gentilisme
  3619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd for that part of Religion, which consisteth in opinions concerning
  3621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe nature of Powers Invisible, there is almost nothing that has a
  3622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname, that has not been esteemed amongst the Gentiles, in one place or
  3623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, a God, or Divell; or by their Poets feigned to be inanimated,
  3624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinhabited, or possessed by some Spirit or other.
  3625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe unformed matter of the World, was a God, by the name of Chaos.
  3627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Heaven, the Ocean, the Planets, the Fire, the Earth, the Winds, were
  3629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso many Gods.
  3630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMen, Women, a Bird, a Crocodile, a Calf, a Dogge, a Snake, an Onion,
  3632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Leeke, Deified. Besides, that they filled almost all places, with
  3633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspirits called Daemons; the plains, with Pan, and Panises, or Satyres;
  3634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Woods, with Fawnes, and Nymphs; the Sea, with Tritons, and other
  3635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNymphs; every River, and Fountayn, with a Ghost of his name, and with
  3636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNymphs; every house, with it Lares, or Familiars; every man, with his
  3637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGenius; Hell, with Ghosts, and spirituall Officers, as Charon, Cerberus,
  3638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Furies; and in the night time, all places with Larvae, Lemures,
  3639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGhosts of men deceased, and a whole kingdome of Fayries, and Bugbears.
  3640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThey have also ascribed Divinity, and built Temples to meer Accidents,
  3641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Qualities; such as are Time, Night, Day, Peace, Concord, Love,
  3642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContention, Vertue, Honour, Health, Rust, Fever, and the like; which
  3643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen they prayed for, or against, they prayed to, as if there were
  3644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGhosts of those names hanging over their heads, and letting fall, or
  3645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithholding that Good, or Evill, for, or against which they prayed. They
  3646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinvoked also their own Wit, by the name of Muses; their own Ignorance,
  3647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the name of Fortune; their own Lust, by the name of Cupid; their
  3648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town Rage, by the name Furies; their own privy members by the name of
  3649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriapus; and attributed their pollutions, to Incubi, and Succubae:
  3650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinsomuch as there was nothing, which a Poet could introduce as a person
  3651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his Poem, which they did not make either a God, or a Divel.
  3652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe same authors of the Religion of the Gentiles, observing the second
  3654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tground for Religion, which is mens Ignorance of causes; and thereby
  3655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir aptnesse to attribute their fortune to causes, on which there
  3656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas no dependence at all apparent, took occasion to obtrude on their
  3657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tignorance, in stead of second causes, a kind of second and ministeriall
  3658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods; ascribing the cause of Foecundity, to Venus; the cause of Arts, to
  3659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApollo; of Subtilty and Craft, to Mercury; of Tempests and stormes,
  3660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Aeolus; and of other effects, to other Gods: insomuch as there was
  3661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst the Heathen almost as great variety of Gods, as of businesse.
  3662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd to the Worship, which naturally men conceived fit to bee used
  3664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttowards their Gods, namely Oblations, Prayers, Thanks, and the rest
  3665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformerly named; the same Legislators of the Gentiles have added their
  3666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImages, both in Picture, and Sculpture; that the more ignorant sort,
  3667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(that is to say, the most part, or generality of the people,) thinking
  3668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Gods for whose representation they were made, were really included,
