  3669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand as it were housed within them, might so much the more stand in feare
  3670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them: And endowed them with lands, and houses, and officers, and
  3671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trevenues, set apart from all other humane uses; that is, consecrated,
  3672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand made holy to those their Idols; as Caverns, Groves, Woods,
  3673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMountains, and whole Ilands; and have attributed to them, not onely
  3674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe shapes, some of Men, some of Beasts, some of Monsters; but also the
  3675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaculties, and Passions of men and beasts; as Sense, Speech, Sex, Lust,
  3676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGeneration, (and this not onely by mixing one with another, to propagate
  3677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe kind of Gods; but also by mixing with men, and women, to beget
  3678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmongrill Gods, and but inmates of Heaven, as Bacchus, Hercules,
  3679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand others;) besides, Anger, Revenge, and other passions of living
  3680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcreatures, and the actions proceeding from them, as Fraud, Theft,
  3681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdultery, Sodomie, and any vice that may be taken for an effect of
  3682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower, or a cause of Pleasure; and all such Vices, as amongst men are
  3683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaken to be against Law, rather than against Honour.
  3684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, to the Prognostiques of time to come; which are naturally, but
  3686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConjectures upon the Experience of time past; and supernaturall, divine
  3687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRevelation; the same authors of the Religion of the Gentiles, partly
  3688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon pretended Experience, partly upon pretended Revelation, have
  3689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadded innumerable other superstitious wayes of Divination; and made men
  3690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbelieve they should find their fortunes, sometimes in the ambiguous
  3691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor senslesse answers of the priests at Delphi, Delos, Ammon, and other
  3692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfamous Oracles; which answers, were made ambiguous by designe, to own
  3693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe event both wayes; or absurd by the intoxicating vapour of the place,
  3694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is very frequent in sulphurous Cavernes: Sometimes in the leaves
  3695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Sibills; of whose Prophecyes (like those perhaps of Nostradamus;
  3696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the fragments now extant seem to be the invention of later times)
  3697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere were some books in reputation in the time of the Roman Republique:
  3698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSometimes in the insignificant Speeches of Mad-men, supposed to
  3699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe possessed with a divine Spirit; which Possession they called
  3700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnthusiasme; and these kinds of foretelling events, were accounted
  3701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTheomancy, or Prophecy; Sometimes in the aspect of the Starres at their
  3702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNativity; which was called Horoscopy, and esteemed a part of judiciary
  3703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAstrology: Sometimes in their own hopes and feares, called Thumomancy,
  3704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Presage: Sometimes in the Prediction of Witches, that pretended
  3705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconference with the dead; which is called Necromancy, Conjuring, and
  3706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitchcraft; and is but juggling and confederate knavery: Sometimes in
  3707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Casuall flight, or feeding of birds; called Augury: Sometimes in
  3708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Entrayles of a sacrificed beast; which was Aruspicina: Sometimes
  3709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Dreams: Sometimes in Croaking of Ravens, or chattering of Birds:
  3710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSometimes in the Lineaments of the face; which was called Metoposcopy;
  3711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor by Palmistry in the lines of the hand; in casuall words, called
  3712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOmina: Sometimes in Monsters, or unusuall accidents; as Ecclipses,
  3713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tComets, rare Meteors, Earthquakes, Inundations, uncouth Births, and the
  3714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike, which they called Portenta and Ostenta, because they thought them
  3715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto portend, or foreshew some great Calamity to come; Sometimes, in meer
  3716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLottery, as Crosse and Pile; counting holes in a sive; dipping of Verses
  3717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Homer, and Virgil; and innumerable other such vaine conceipts. So
  3718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teasie are men to be drawn to believe any thing, from such men as have
  3719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgotten credit with them; and can with gentlenesse, and dexterity, take
  3720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thold of their fear, and ignorance.
  3721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Designes Of The Authors Of The Religion Of The Heathen And therefore
  3723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe first Founders, and Legislators of Common-wealths amongst the
  3724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGentiles, whose ends were only to keep the people in obedience, and
  3725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeace, have in all places taken care; First, to imprint in their minds a
  3726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeliefe, that those precepts which they gave concerning Religion, might
  3727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot be thought to proceed from their own device, but from the dictates
  3728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof some God, or other Spirit; or else that they themselves were of a
  3729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thigher nature than mere mortalls, that their Lawes might the more easily
  3730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe received: So Numa Pompilius pretended to receive the Ceremonies he
  3731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinstituted amongst the Romans, from the Nymph Egeria: and the first King
  3732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand founder of the Kingdome of Peru, pretended himselfe and his wife to
  3733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe the children of the Sunne: and Mahomet, to set up his new Religion,
  3734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretended to have conferences with the Holy Ghost, in forme of a Dove.
  3735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, they have had a care, to make it believed, that the same
  3736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings were displeasing to the Gods, which were forbidden by the
  3737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes. Thirdly, to prescribe Ceremonies, Supplications, Sacrifices, and
  3738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFestivalls, by which they were to believe, the anger of the Gods might
  3739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe appeased; and that ill success in War, great contagions of Sicknesse,
  3740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarthquakes, and each mans private Misery, came from the Anger of
  3741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Gods; and their Anger from the Neglect of their Worship, or the
  3742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforgetting, or mistaking some point of the Ceremonies required. And
  3743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough amongst the antient Romans, men were not forbidden to deny, that
  3744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich in the Poets is written of the paines, and pleasures after this
  3745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife; which divers of great authority, and gravity in that state have
  3746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin their Harangues openly derided; yet that beliefe was alwaies more
  3747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcherished, than the contrary.
  3748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd by these, and such other Institutions, they obtayned in order to
  3750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir end, (which was the peace of the Commonwealth,) that the common
  3751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople in their misfortunes, laying the fault on neglect, or errour in
  3752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Ceremonies, or on their own disobedience to the lawes, were the
  3753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlesse apt to mutiny against their Governors. And being entertained with
  3754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe pomp, and pastime of Festivalls, and publike Gomes, made in
  3755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thonour of the Gods, needed nothing else but bread, to keep them from
  3756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscontent, murmuring, and commotion against the State. And therefore
  3757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Romans, that had conquered the greatest part of the then known
  3758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorld, made no scruple of tollerating any Religion whatsoever in the
  3759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCity of Rome it selfe; unlesse it had somthing in it, that could not
  3760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsist with their Civill Government; nor do we read, that any Religion
  3761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas there forbidden, but that of the Jewes; who (being the peculiar
  3762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God) thought it unlawfull to acknowledge subjection to any
  3763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmortall King or State whatsoever. And thus you see how the Religion of
  3764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Gentiles was a part of their Policy.
  3765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe True Religion, And The Lawes Of Gods Kingdome The Same But where God
  3767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe, by supernaturall Revelation, planted Religion; there he
  3768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso made to himselfe a peculiar Kingdome; and gave Lawes, not only of
  3769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbehaviour towards himselfe; but also towards one another; and thereby
  3770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Kingdome of God, the Policy, and lawes Civill, are a part of
  3771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion; and therefore the distinction of Temporall, and Spirituall
  3772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDomination, hath there no place. It is true, that God is King of all the
  3773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarth: Yet may he be King of a peculiar, and chosen Nation. For there is
  3774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno more incongruity therein, than that he that hath the generall command
  3775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the whole Army, should have withall a peculiar Regiment, or Company
  3776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his own. God is King of all the Earth by his Power: but of his
  3777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchosen people, he is King by Covenant. But to speake more largly of the
  3778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God, both by Nature, and Covenant, I have in the following
  3779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscourse assigned an other place.
  3780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Causes Of Change In Religion
  3785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom the propagation of Religion, it is not hard to understand
  3787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe causes of the resolution of the same into its first seeds, or
  3788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprinciples; which are only an opinion of a Deity, and Powers invisible,
  3789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand supernaturall; that can never be so abolished out of humane nature,
  3790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut that new Religions may againe be made to spring out of them, by the
  3791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tculture of such men, as for such purpose are in reputation.
  3792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor seeing all formed Religion, is founded at first, upon the faith
  3794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich a multitude hath in some one person, whom they believe not only to
  3795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe a wise man, and to labour to procure their happiness, but also to
  3796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe a holy man, to whom God himselfe vouchsafeth to declare his will
  3797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturally; It followeth necessarily, when they that have the
  3798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGoverment of Religion, shall come to have either the wisedome of those
  3799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, their sincerity, or their love suspected; or that they shall
  3800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe unable to shew any probable token of divine Revelation; that the
  3801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion which they desire to uphold, must be suspected likewise; and
  3802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(without the feare of the Civill Sword) contradicted and rejected.
  3803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInjoyning Beleefe Of Impossibilities
  3808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat which taketh away the reputation of Wisedome, in him that formeth
  3810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Religion, or addeth to it when it is allready formed, is the enjoyning
  3811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a beliefe of contradictories: For both parts of a contradiction
  3812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot possibly be true: and therefore to enjoyne the beliefe of them,
  3813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis an argument of ignorance; which detects the Author in that; and
  3814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscredits him in all things else he shall propound as from revelation
  3815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall: which revelation a man may indeed have of many things
  3816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabove, but of nothing against naturall reason.
  3817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoing Contrary To The Religion They Establish
  3822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat which taketh away the reputation of Sincerity, is the doing, or
  3824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaying of such things, as appeare to be signes, that what they require
  3825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother men to believe, is not believed by themselves; all which doings,
  3826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor sayings are therefore called Scandalous, because they be stumbling
  3827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tblocks, that make men to fall in the way of Religion: as Injustice,
  3828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCruelty, Prophanesse, Avarice, and Luxury. For who can believe, that he
  3829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat doth ordinarily such actions, as proceed from any of these
  3830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trootes, believeth there is any such Invisible Power to be feared, as he
  3831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taffrighteth other men withall, for lesser faults?
  3832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat which taketh away the reputation of Love, is the being detected of
  3834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate ends: as when the beliefe they require of others, conduceth or
  3835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseemeth to conduce to the acquiring of Dominion, Riches, Dignity, or
  3836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsecure Pleasure, to themselves onely, or specially. For that which men
  3837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treap benefit by to themselves, they are thought to do for their own
  3838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsakes, and not for love of others
  3839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWant Of The Testimony Of Miracles
  3844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, the testimony that men can render of divine Calling, can be no
  3846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother, than the operation of Miracles; or true Prophecy, (which also is
  3847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Miracle;) or extraordinary Felicity. And therefore, to those points
  3848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Religion, which have been received from them that did such Miracles;
  3849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that are added by such, as approve not their Calling by some
  3850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracle, obtain no greater beliefe, than what the Custome, and Lawes of
  3851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe places, in which they be educated, have wrought into them. For as
  3852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin naturall things, men of judgement require naturall signes,
  3853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand arguments; so in supernaturall things, they require signes
  3854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall, (which are Miracles,) before they consent inwardly, and
  3855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom their hearts.
  3856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll which causes of the weakening of mens faith, do manifestly appear
  3858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Examples following. First, we have the Example of the children
  3859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Israel; who when Moses, that had approved his Calling to them by
  3860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles, and by the happy conduct of them out of Egypt, was absent but
  3861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t40 dayes, revolted from the worship of the true God, recommended to
  3862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem by him; and setting up (Exod.32 1,2) a Golden Calfe for their God,
  3863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trelapsed into the Idolatry of the Egyptians; from whom they had been
  3864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso lately delivered. And again, after Moses, Aaron, Joshua, and that
  3865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgeneration which had seen the great works of God in Israel, (Judges
  3866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2 11) were dead; another generation arose, and served Baal. So that
  3867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles fayling, Faith also failed.
  3868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, when the sons of Samuel, (1 Sam.8.3) being constituted by their
  3870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfather Judges in Bersabee, received bribes, and judged unjustly, the
  3871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople of Israel refused any more to have God to be their King, in other
  3872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner than he was King of other people; and therefore cryed out to
  3873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSamuel, to choose them a King after the manner of the Nations. So that
  3874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice Fayling, Faith also fayled: Insomuch, as they deposed their God,
  3875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom reigning over them.
  3876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whereas in the planting of Christian Religion, the Oracles ceased
  3878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin all parts of the Roman Empire, and the number of Christians encreased
  3879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twonderfully every day, and in every place, by the preaching of the
  3880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles, and Evangelists; a great part of that successe, may reasonably
  3881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe attributed, to the contempt, into which the Priests of the Gentiles
  3882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof that time, had brought themselves, by their uncleannesse, avarice,
  3883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand jugling between Princes. Also the Religion of the Church of Rome,
  3884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas partly, for the same cause abolished in England, and many other
  3885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparts of Christendome; insomuch, as the fayling of Vertue in the
  3886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors, maketh Faith faile in the People: and partly from bringing
  3887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Philosophy, and doctrine of Aristotle into Religion, by the
  3888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSchoole-men; from whence there arose so many contradictions, and
  3889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsurdities, as brought the Clergy into a reputation both of Ignorance,
  3890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand of Fraudulent intention; and enclined people to revolt from them,
  3891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither against the will of their own Princes, as in France, and Holland;
  3892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor with their will, as in England.
  3893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, amongst the points by the Church of Rome declared necessary for
  3895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation, there be so many, manifestly to the advantage of the Pope,
  3896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand of his spirituall subjects, residing in the territories of other
  3897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Princes, that were it not for the mutuall emulation of those
  3898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrinces, they might without warre, or trouble, exclude all forraign
  3899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority, as easily as it has been excluded in England. For who is
  3900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere that does not see, to whose benefit it conduceth, to have it
  3901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbelieved, that a King hath not his Authority from Christ, unlesse a
  3902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBishop crown him? That a King, if he be a Priest, cannot Marry? That
  3903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhether a Prince be born in lawfull Marriage, or not, must be judged by
  3904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority from Rome? That Subjects may be freed from their Alleageance,
  3905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif by the Court of Rome, the King be judged an Heretique? That a King
  3906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as Chilperique of France) may be deposed by a Pope (as Pope Zachary,)
  3907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor no cause; and his Kingdome given to one of his Subjects? That the
  3908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tClergy, and Regulars, in what Country soever, shall be exempt from the
  3909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJurisdiction of their King, in cases criminall? Or who does not see, to
  3910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose profit redound the Fees of private Masses, and Vales of Purgatory;
  3911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith other signes of private interest, enough to mortifie the most
  3912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlively Faith, if (as I sayd) the civill Magistrate, and Custome did not
  3913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore sustain it, than any opinion they have of the Sanctity, Wisdome,
  3914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Probity of their Teachers? So that I may attribute all the changes
  3915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Religion in the world, to one and the some cause; and that is,
  3916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunpleasing Priests; and those not onely amongst Catholiques, but even in
  3917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Church that hath presumed most of Reformation.
  3918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XIII. OF THE NATURALL CONDITION OF MANKIND,
  3922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAS CONCERNING THEIR FELICITY, AND MISERY
  3924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature hath made men so equall, in the faculties of body, and mind; as
  3927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat though there bee found one man sometimes manifestly stronger
  3928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin body, or of quicker mind then another; yet when all is reckoned
  3929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttogether, the difference between man, and man, is not so considerable,
  3930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas that one man can thereupon claim to himselfe any benefit, to which
  3931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother may not pretend, as well as he. For as to the strength of body,
  3932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe weakest has strength enough to kill the strongest, either by secret
  3933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmachination, or by confederacy with others, that are in the same danger
  3934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith himselfe.
  3935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as to the faculties of the mind, (setting aside the arts grounded
  3937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon words, and especially that skill of proceeding upon generall, and
  3938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinfallible rules, called Science; which very few have, and but in few
  3939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings; as being not a native faculty, born with us; nor attained,
  3940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as Prudence,) while we look after somewhat els,) I find yet a greater
  3941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequality amongst men, than that of strength. For Prudence, is but
  3942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExperience; which equall time, equally bestowes on all men, in those
  3943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings they equally apply themselves unto. That which may perhaps make
  3944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch equality incredible, is but a vain conceipt of ones owne wisdome,
  3945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich almost all men think they have in a greater degree, than the
  3946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVulgar; that is, than all men but themselves, and a few others, whom by
  3947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFame, or for concurring with themselves, they approve. For such is the
  3948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnature of men, that howsoever they may acknowledge many others to be
  3949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore witty, or more eloquent, or more learned; Yet they will hardly
  3950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbelieve there be many so wise as themselves: For they see their own wit
  3951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat hand, and other mens at a distance. But this proveth rather that men
  3952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare in that point equall, than unequall. For there is not ordinarily a
  3953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreater signe of the equall distribution of any thing, than that every
  3954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman is contented with his share.
  3955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom Equality Proceeds Diffidence
  3960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom this equality of ability, ariseth equality of hope in the attaining
  3962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof our Ends. And therefore if any two men desire the same thing, which
  3963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse they cannot both enjoy, they become enemies; and in the
  3964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tway to their End, (which is principally their owne conservation, and
  3965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes their delectation only,) endeavour to destroy, or subdue one
  3966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan other. And from hence it comes to passe, that where an Invader hath
  3967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno more to feare, than an other mans single power; if one plant, sow,
  3968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbuild, or possesse a convenient Seat, others may probably be expected to
  3969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome prepared with forces united, to dispossesse, and deprive him, not
  3970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonly of the fruit of his labour, but also of his life, or liberty. And
  3971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Invader again is in the like danger of another.
  3972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom Diffidence Warre
  3977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd from this diffidence of one another, there is no way for any man to
  3979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsecure himselfe, so reasonable, as Anticipation; that is, by force, or
  3980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twiles, to master the persons of all men he can, so long, till he see no
  3981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother power great enough to endanger him: And this is no more than his
  3982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town conservation requireth, and is generally allowed. Also because there
  3983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe some, that taking pleasure in contemplating their own power in
  3984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe acts of conquest, which they pursue farther than their security
  3985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequires; if others, that otherwise would be glad to be at ease within
  3986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmodest bounds, should not by invasion increase their power, they would
  3987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot be able, long time, by standing only on their defence, to subsist.
  3988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd by consequence, such augmentation of dominion over men, being
  3989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessary to a mans conservation, it ought to be allowed him.
  3990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  3991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgaine, men have no pleasure, (but on the contrary a great deale of
  3992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgriefe) in keeping company, where there is no power able to over-awe
  3993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem all. For every man looketh that his companion should value him, at
  3994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same rate he sets upon himselfe: And upon all signes of contempt,
  3995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor undervaluing, naturally endeavours, as far as he dares (which amongst
  3996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem that have no common power, to keep them in quiet, is far enough
  3997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto make them destroy each other,) to extort a greater value from his
  3998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontemners, by dommage; and from others, by the example.
  3999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo that in the nature of man, we find three principall causes of
  4001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquarrel. First, Competition; Secondly, Diffidence; Thirdly, Glory.
  4002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe first, maketh men invade for Gain; the second, for Safety; and
  4004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe third, for Reputation. The first use Violence, to make themselves
  4005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMasters of other mens persons, wives, children, and cattell; the second,
  4006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto defend them; the third, for trifles, as a word, a smile, a different
  4007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion, and any other signe of undervalue, either direct in their
  4008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPersons, or by reflexion in their Kindred, their Friends, their Nation,
  4009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Profession, or their Name.
  4010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOut Of Civil States,
  4015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere Is Alwayes Warre Of Every One Against Every One Hereby it is
  4017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest, that during the time men live without a common Power to keep
  4018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem all in awe, they are in that condition which is called Warre;
  4019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand such a warre, as is of every man, against every man. For WARRE,
  4020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsisteth not in Battell onely, or the act of fighting; but in a tract
  4021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof time, wherein the Will to contend by Battell is sufficiently known:
  4022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore the notion of Time, is to be considered in the nature of
  4023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWarre; as it is in the nature of Weather. For as the nature of Foule
  4024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tweather, lyeth not in a showre or two of rain; but in an inclination
  4025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereto of many dayes together: So the nature of War, consisteth not in
  4026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactuall fighting; but in the known disposition thereto, during all the
  4027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime there is no assurance to the contrary. All other time is PEACE.
  4028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Incommodites Of Such A War
  4033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhatsoever therefore is consequent to a time of Warre, where every man
  4035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Enemy to every man; the same is consequent to the time, wherein men
  4036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlive without other security, than what their own strength, and their
  4037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town invention shall furnish them withall. In such condition, there is
  4038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno place for Industry; because the fruit thereof is uncertain; and
  4039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently no Culture of the Earth; no Navigation, nor use of the
  4040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommodities that may be imported by Sea; no commodious Building; no
  4041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstruments of moving, and removing such things as require much force;
  4042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno Knowledge of the face of the Earth; no account of Time; no Arts; no
  4043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLetters; no Society; and which is worst of all, continuall feare, and
  4044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdanger of violent death; And the life of man, solitary, poore, nasty,
  4045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbrutish, and short.
  4046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt may seem strange to some man, that has not well weighed these things;
  4048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Nature should thus dissociate, and render men apt to invade,
  4049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand destroy one another: and he may therefore, not trusting to this
  4050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInference, made from the Passions, desire perhaps to have the same
  4051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconfirmed by Experience. Let him therefore consider with himselfe, when
  4052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaking a journey, he armes himselfe, and seeks to go well accompanied;
  4053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen going to sleep, he locks his dores; when even in his house he
  4054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlocks his chests; and this when he knows there bee Lawes, and publike
  4055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOfficers, armed, to revenge all injuries shall bee done him; what
  4056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion he has of his fellow subjects, when he rides armed; of his
  4057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfellow Citizens, when he locks his dores; and of his children, and
  4058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tservants, when he locks his chests. Does he not there as much accuse
  4059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmankind by his actions, as I do by my words? But neither of us accuse
  4060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmans nature in it. The Desires, and other Passions of man, are in
  4061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves no Sin. No more are the Actions, that proceed from those
  4062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions, till they know a Law that forbids them; which till Lawes be
  4063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade they cannot know: nor can any Law be made, till they have agreed
  4064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon the Person that shall make it.
  4065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt may peradventure be thought, there was never such a time, nor
  4067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition of warre as this; and I believe it was never generally so,
  4068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover all the world: but there are many places, where they live so now.
  4069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the savage people in many places of America, except the government
  4070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof small Families, the concord whereof dependeth on naturall lust, have
  4071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno government at all; and live at this day in that brutish manner, as
  4072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI said before. Howsoever, it may be perceived what manner of life there
  4073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould be, where there were no common Power to feare; by the manner of
  4074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife, which men that have formerly lived under a peacefull government,
  4075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuse to degenerate into, in a civill Warre.
  4076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut though there had never been any time, wherein particular men were in
  4078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta condition of warre one against another; yet in all times, Kings, and
  4079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpersons of Soveraigne authority, because of their Independency, are
  4080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin continuall jealousies, and in the state and posture of Gladiators;
  4081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thaving their weapons pointing, and their eyes fixed on one another;
  4082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, their Forts, Garrisons, and Guns upon the Frontiers of their
  4083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdomes; and continuall Spyes upon their neighbours; which is a
  4084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tposture of War. But because they uphold thereby, the Industry of their
  4085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects; there does not follow from it, that misery, which accompanies
  4086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Liberty of particular men.
  4087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Such A Warre, Nothing Is Unjust
  4092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo this warre of every man against every man, this also is consequent;
  4094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat nothing can be Unjust. The notions of Right and Wrong, Justice and
  4095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInjustice have there no place. Where there is no common Power, there is
  4096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno Law: where no Law, no Injustice. Force, and Fraud, are in warre the
  4097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttwo Cardinall vertues. Justice, and Injustice are none of the Faculties
  4098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneither of the Body, nor Mind. If they were, they might be in a man that
  4099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere alone in the world, as well as his Senses, and Passions. They
  4100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Qualities, that relate to men in Society, not in Solitude. It is
  4101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequent also to the same condition, that there be no Propriety, no
  4102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominion, no Mine and Thine distinct; but onely that to be every mans
  4103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat he can get; and for so long, as he can keep it. And thus much
  4104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the ill condition, which man by meer Nature is actually placed in;
  4105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough with a possibility to come out of it, consisting partly in the
  4106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions, partly in his Reason.
  4107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Passions That Incline Men To Peace
  4112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Passions that encline men to Peace, are Feare of Death; Desire of
  4114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch things as are necessary to commodious living; and a Hope by their
  4115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIndustry to obtain them. And Reason suggesteth convenient Articles of
  4116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace, upon which men may be drawn to agreement. These Articles, are
  4117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey, which otherwise are called the Lawes of Nature: whereof I shall
  4118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeak more particularly, in the two following Chapters.
  4119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XIV. OF THE FIRST AND SECOND NATURALL LAWES, AND OF CONTRACTS
  4123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight Of Nature What
  4128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe RIGHT OF NATURE, which Writers commonly call Jus Naturale, is the
  4130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty each man hath, to use his own power, as he will himselfe, for
  4131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe preservation of his own Nature; that is to say, of his own Life;
  4132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand consequently, of doing any thing, which in his own Judgement, and
  4133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason, hee shall conceive to be the aptest means thereunto.
  4134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty What
  4139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy LIBERTY, is understood, according to the proper signification of the
  4141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tword, the absence of externall Impediments: which Impediments, may oft
  4142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake away part of a mans power to do what hee would; but cannot hinder
  4143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim from using the power left him, according as his judgement, and
  4144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treason shall dictate to him.
  4145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Law Of Nature What
  4150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA LAW OF NATURE, (Lex Naturalis,) is a Precept, or generall Rule,
  4152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfound out by Reason, by which a man is forbidden to do, that, which
  4153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis destructive of his life, or taketh away the means of preserving the
  4154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame; and to omit, that, by which he thinketh it may be best preserved.
  4155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor though they that speak of this subject, use to confound Jus, and
  4156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLex, Right and Law; yet they ought to be distinguished; because RIGHT,
  4157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsisteth in liberty to do, or to forbeare; Whereas LAW, determineth,
  4158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand bindeth to one of them: so that Law, and Right, differ as much,
  4159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas Obligation, and Liberty; which in one and the same matter are
  4160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinconsistent.
  4161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturally Every Man Has Right To Everything
  4166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because the condition of Man, (as hath been declared in the
  4168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprecedent Chapter) is a condition of Warre of every one against every
  4169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone; in which case every one is governed by his own Reason; and there
  4170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis nothing he can make use of, that may not be a help unto him, in
  4171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreserving his life against his enemyes; It followeth, that in such a
  4172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition, every man has a Right to every thing; even to one anothers
  4173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbody. And therefore, as long as this naturall Right of every man to
  4174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery thing endureth, there can be no security to any man, (how strong
  4175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor wise soever he be,) of living out the time, which Nature ordinarily
  4176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talloweth men to live.
  4177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Fundamental Law Of Nature
  4182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd consequently it is a precept, or generall rule of Reason, "That
  4184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery man, ought to endeavour Peace, as farre as he has hope of
  4185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobtaining it; and when he cannot obtain it, that he may seek, and use,
  4186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall helps, and advantages of Warre." The first branch, of which Rule,
  4187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontaineth the first, and Fundamentall Law of Nature; which is, "To seek
  4188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace, and follow it." The Second, the summe of the Right of Nature;
  4189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is, "By all means we can, to defend our selves."
  4190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Second Law Of Nature
  4195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom this Fundamentall Law of Nature, by which men are commanded to
  4197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tendeavour Peace, is derived this second Law; "That a man be willing,
  4198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen others are so too, as farre-forth, as for Peace, and defence of
  4199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe he shall think it necessary, to lay down this right to all
  4200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings; and be contented with so much liberty against other men, as
  4201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the would allow other men against himselfe." For as long as every man
  4202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tholdeth this Right, of doing any thing he liketh; so long are all men in
  4203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe condition of Warre. But if other men will not lay down their Right,
  4204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas well as he; then there is no Reason for any one, to devest himselfe
  4205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his: For that were to expose himselfe to Prey, (which no man is bound
  4206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto) rather than to dispose himselfe to Peace. This is that Law of the
  4207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGospell; "Whatsoever you require that others should do to you, that do
  4208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tye to them." And that Law of all men, "Quod tibi feiri non vis, alteri
  4209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tne feceris."
  4210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat it is to lay down a Right
  4215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Lay Downe a mans Right to any thing, is to Devest himselfe of the
  4217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty, of hindring another of the benefit of his own Right to the
  4218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame. For he that renounceth, or passeth away his Right, giveth not to
  4219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany other man a Right which he had not before; because there is nothing
  4220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto which every man had not Right by Nature: but onely standeth out of
  4221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this way, that he may enjoy his own originall Right, without hindrance
  4222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom him; not without hindrance from another. So that the effect which
  4223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tredoundeth to one man, by another mans defect of Right, is but so much
  4224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiminution of impediments to the use of his own Right originall.
  4225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRenouncing (or) Transferring Right What; Obligation Duty Justice
  4230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight is layd aside, either by simply Renouncing it; or by Transferring
  4232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit to another. By Simply RENOUNCING; when he cares not to whom the
  4233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbenefit thereof redoundeth. By TRANSFERRING; when he intendeth the
  4234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbenefit thereof to some certain person, or persons. And when a man hath
  4235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin either manner abandoned, or granted away his Right; then is he said
  4236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be OBLIGED, or BOUND, not to hinder those, to whom such Right is
  4237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgranted, or abandoned, from the benefit of it: and that he Ought, and it
  4238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this DUTY, not to make voyd that voluntary act of his own: and that such
  4239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thindrance is INJUSTICE, and INJURY, as being Sine Jure; the Right being
  4240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore renounced, or transferred. So that Injury, or Injustice, in
  4241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe controversies of the world, is somewhat like to that, which in the
  4242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisputations of Scholers is called Absurdity. For as it is there called
  4243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Absurdity, to contradict what one maintained in the Beginning: so in
  4244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe world, it is called Injustice, and Injury, voluntarily to undo that,
  4245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich from the beginning he had voluntarily done. The way by which a man
  4246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither simply Renounceth, or Transferreth his Right, is a Declaration,
  4247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Signification, by some voluntary and sufficient signe, or signes,
  4248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat he doth so Renounce, or Transferre; or hath so Renounced, or
  4249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTransferred the same, to him that accepteth it. And these Signes are
  4250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither Words onely, or Actions onely; or (as it happeneth most often)
  4251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth Words and Actions. And the same are the BONDS, by which men are
  4252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbound, and obliged: Bonds, that have their strength, not from their own
  4253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature, (for nothing is more easily broken then a mans word,) but from
  4254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFeare of some evill consequence upon the rupture.
  4255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNot All Rights Are Alienable
  4260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhensoever a man Transferreth his Right, or Renounceth it; it is either
  4262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin consideration of some Right reciprocally transferred to himselfe; or
  4263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor some other good he hopeth for thereby. For it is a voluntary act:
  4264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand of the voluntary acts of every man, the object is some Good To
  4265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHimselfe. And therefore there be some Rights, which no man can be
  4266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood by any words, or other signes, to have abandoned, or
  4267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransferred. As first a man cannot lay down the right of resisting them,
  4268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat assault him by force, to take away his life; because he cannot be
  4269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood to ayme thereby, at any Good to himselfe. The same may be
  4270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsayd of Wounds, and Chayns, and Imprisonment; both because there is
  4271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno benefit consequent to such patience; as there is to the patience of
  4272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuffering another to be wounded, or imprisoned: as also because a man
  4273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot tell, when he seeth men proceed against him by violence, whether
  4274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey intend his death or not. And lastly the motive, and end for which
  4275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis renouncing, and transferring or Right is introduced, is nothing
  4276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\telse but the security of a mans person, in his life, and in the means of
  4277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso preserving life, as not to be weary of it. And therefore if a man by
  4278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords, or other signes, seem to despoyle himselfe of the End, for which
  4279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose signes were intended; he is not to be understood as if he meant
  4280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, or that it was his will; but that he was ignorant of how such words
  4281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand actions were to be interpreted.
  4282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContract What
  4287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe mutuall transferring of Right, is that which men call CONTRACT.
  4289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere is difference, between transferring of Right to the Thing; and
  4291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransferring, or tradition, that is, delivery of the Thing it selfe. For
  4292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Thing may be delivered together with the Translation of the Right;
  4293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas in buying and selling with ready mony; or exchange of goods, or
  4294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlands: and it may be delivered some time after.
  4295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant What
  4300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, one of the Contractors, may deliver the Thing contracted for on
  4302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this part, and leave the other to perform his part at some determinate
  4303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime after, and in the mean time be trusted; and then the Contract on
  4304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this part, is called PACT, or COVENANT: Or both parts may contract now,
  4305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto performe hereafter: in which cases, he that is to performe in time
  4306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto come, being trusted, his performance is called Keeping Of Promise, or
  4307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith; and the fayling of performance (if it be voluntary) Violation Of
  4308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith.
  4309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFree-gift
  4314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen the transferring of Right, is not mutuall; but one of the parties
  4316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransferreth, in hope to gain thereby friendship, or service from
  4317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, or from his friends; or in hope to gain the reputation of
  4318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCharity, or Magnanimity; or to deliver his mind from the pain of
  4319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcompassion; or in hope of reward in heaven; This is not Contract, but
  4320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGIFT, FREEGIFT, GRACE: which words signifie one and the same thing.
  4321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignes Of Contract Expresse
  4326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignes of Contract, are either Expresse, or By Inference. Expresse, are
  4328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords spoken with understanding of what they signifie; And such words
  4329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare either of the time Present, or Past; as, I Give, I Grant, I Have
  4330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGiven, I Have Granted, I Will That This Be Yours: Or of the future;
  4331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas, I Will Give, I Will Grant; which words of the future, are called
  4332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPromise.
  4333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignes Of Contract By Inference
  4338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignes by Inference, are sometimes the consequence of Words; sometimes
  4340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe consequence of Silence; sometimes the consequence of Actions;
  4341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes the consequence of Forbearing an Action: and generally a signe
  4342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Inference, of any Contract, is whatsoever sufficiently argues the
  4343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill of the Contractor.
  4344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFree Gift Passeth By Words Of The Present Or Past
  4349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWords alone, if they be of the time to come, and contain a bare promise,
  4351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare an insufficient signe of a Free-gift and therefore not obligatory.
  4352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor if they be of the time to Come, as, To Morrow I Will Give, they
  4353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare a signe I have not given yet, and consequently that my right is not
  4354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransferred, but remaineth till I transferre it by some other Act. But
  4355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif the words be of the time Present, or Past, as, "I have given, or do
  4356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive to be delivered to morrow," then is my to morrows Right given away
  4357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto day; and that by the vertue of the words, though there were no
  4358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother argument of my will. And there is a great difference in the
  4359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignification of these words, Volos Hoc Tuum Esse Cras, and Cros Dabo;
  4360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is between "I will that this be thine to morrow," and, "I will
  4361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive it to thee to morrow:" For the word I Will, in the former manner
  4362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof speech, signifies an act of the will Present; but in the later, it
  4363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifies a promise of an act of the will to Come: and therefore the
  4364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformer words, being of the Present, transferre a future right; the
  4365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlater, that be of the Future, transferre nothing. But if there be other
  4366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignes of the Will to transferre a Right, besides Words; then, though
  4367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe gift be Free, yet may the Right be understood to passe by words of
  4368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe future: as if a man propound a Prize to him that comes first to the
  4369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tend of a race, The gift is Free; and though the words be of the
  4370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFuture, yet the Right passeth: for if he would not have his words so be
  4371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood, he should not have let them runne.
  4372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignes Of Contract Are Words Both Of The Past, Present, and Future In
  4374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContracts, the right passeth, not onely where the words are of the time
  4375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresent, or Past; but also where they are of the Future; because all
  4376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContract is mutuall translation, or change of Right; and therefore he
  4377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat promiseth onely, because he hath already received the benefit for
  4378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich he promiseth, is to be understood as if he intended the Right
  4379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould passe: for unlesse he had been content to have his words so
  4380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood, the other would not have performed his part first. And
  4381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor that cause, in buying, and selling, and other acts of Contract, A
  4382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPromise is equivalent to a Covenant; and therefore obligatory.
  4383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMerit What
  4388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHe that performeth first in the case of a Contract, is said to MERIT
  4390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which he is to receive by the performance of the other; and he hath
  4391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit as Due. Also when a Prize is propounded to many, which is to be given
  4392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto him onely that winneth; or mony is thrown amongst many, to be enjoyed
  4393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby them that catch it; though this be a Free Gift; yet so to Win, or
  4394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso to Catch, is to Merit, and to have it as DUE. For the Right is
  4395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransferred in the Propounding of the Prize, and in throwing down the
  4396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmony; though it be not determined to whom, but by the Event of the
  4397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontention. But there is between these two sorts of Merit, this
  4398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifference, that In Contract, I Merit by vertue of my own power, and the
  4399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContractors need; but in this case of Free Gift, I am enabled to
  4400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMerit onely by the benignity of the Giver; In Contract, I merit at The
  4401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContractors hand that hee should depart with his right; In this case of
  4402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgift, I Merit not that the giver should part with his right; but that
  4403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen he has parted with it, it should be mine, rather than anothers.
  4404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd this I think to be the meaning of that distinction of the Schooles,
  4405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetween Meritum Congrui, and Meritum Condigni. For God Almighty, having
  4406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpromised Paradise to those men (hoodwinkt with carnall desires,) that
  4407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan walk through this world according to the Precepts, and Limits
  4408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprescribed by him; they say, he that shall so walk, shall Merit Paradise
  4409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEx Congruo. But because no man can demand a right to it, by his own
  4410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRighteousnesse, or any other power in himselfe, but by the Free Grace of
  4411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod onely; they say, no man can Merit Paradise Ex Condigno. This I say,
  4412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI think is the meaning of that distinction; but because Disputers do not
  4413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagree upon the signification of their own termes of Art, longer than it
  4414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tserves their turn; I will not affirme any thing of their meaning:
  4415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely this I say; when a gift is given indefinitely, as a prize to be
  4416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontended for, he that winneth Meriteth, and may claime the Prize as
  4417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDue.
  4418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants Of Mutuall Trust, When Invalid
  4423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a Covenant be made, wherein neither of the parties performe
  4425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresently, but trust one another; in the condition of meer Nature,
  4426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which is a condition of Warre of every man against every man,) upon
  4427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany reasonable suspition, it is Voyd; But if there be a common Power set
  4428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover them bothe, with right and force sufficient to compell performance;
  4429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is not Voyd. For he that performeth first, has no assurance the other
  4430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill performe after; because the bonds of words are too weak to bridle
  4431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmens ambition, avarice, anger, and other Passions, without the feare of
  4432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome coerceive Power; which in the condition of meer Nature, where all
  4433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen are equall, and judges of the justnesse of their own fears cannot
  4434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossibly be supposed. And therefore he which performeth first, does
  4435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut betray himselfe to his enemy; contrary to the Right (he can never
  4436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabandon) of defending his life, and means of living.
  4437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut in a civill estate, where there is a Power set up to constrain
  4439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that would otherwise violate their faith, that feare is no more
  4440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasonable; and for that cause, he which by the Covenant is to perform
  4441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst, is obliged so to do.
  4442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe cause of Feare, which maketh such a Covenant invalid, must be
  4444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talwayes something arising after the Covenant made; as some new fact,
  4445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor other signe of the Will not to performe; else it cannot make the
  4446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant Voyd. For that which could not hinder a man from promising,
  4447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought not to be admitted as a hindrance of performing.
  4448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight To The End, Containeth Right To The Means
  4453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHe that transferreth any Right, transferreth the Means of enjoying it,
  4455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas farre as lyeth in his power. As he that selleth Land, is understood
  4456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto transferre the Herbage, and whatsoever growes upon it; Nor can he
  4457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat sells a Mill turn away the Stream that drives it. And they that
  4458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive to a man The Right of government in Soveraignty, are understood
  4459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto give him the right of levying mony to maintain Souldiers; and of
  4460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappointing Magistrates for the administration of Justice.
  4461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNo Covenant With Beasts
  4466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo make Covenant with bruit Beasts, is impossible; because not
  4468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstanding our speech, they understand not, nor accept of any
  4469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttranslation of Right; nor can translate any Right to another; and
  4470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout mutuall acceptation, there is no Covenant.
  4471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor With God Without Speciall Revelation
  4476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo make Covenant with God, is impossible, but by Mediation of such
  4478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas God speaketh to, either by Revelation supernaturall, or by his
  4479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLieutenants that govern under him, and in his Name; For otherwise we
  4480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow not whether our Covenants be accepted, or not. And therefore they
  4481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Vow any thing contrary to any law of Nature, Vow in vain; as being
  4482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta thing unjust to pay such Vow. And if it be a thing commanded by the
  4483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw of Nature, it is not the Vow, but the Law that binds them.
  4484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNo Covenant, But Of Possible And Future
  4489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe matter, or subject of a Covenant, is alwayes something that falleth
  4491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder deliberation; (For to Covenant, is an act of the Will; that is to
  4492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay an act, and the last act, of deliberation;) and is therefore alwayes
  4493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood to be something to come; and which is judged Possible for him
  4494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Covenanteth, to performe.
  4495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore, to promise that which is known to be Impossible, is no
  4497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant. But if that prove impossible afterwards, which before was
  4498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought possible, the Covenant is valid, and bindeth, (though not to the
  4499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing it selfe,) yet to the value; or, if that also be impossible, to
  4500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe unfeigned endeavour of performing as much as is possible; for to
  4501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore no man can be obliged.
  4502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

  4506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants How Made Voyd
  4507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMen are freed of their Covenants two wayes; by Performing; or by being
  4509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tForgiven. For Performance, is the naturall end of obligation; and
  4510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tForgivenesse, the restitution of liberty; as being a retransferring of
  4511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Right, in which the obligation consisted.
  4512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants Extorted By Feare Are Valide
  4517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants entred into by fear, in the condition of meer Nature, are
  4519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobligatory. For example, if I Covenant to pay a ransome, or service for
  4520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmy life, to an enemy; I am bound by it. For it is a Contract, wherein
  4521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone receiveth the benefit of life; the other is to receive mony,
  4522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor service for it; and consequently, where no other Law (as in the
  4523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition, of meer Nature) forbiddeth the performance, the Covenant
  4524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis valid. Therefore Prisoners of warre, if trusted with the payment of
  4525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Ransome, are obliged to pay it; And if a weaker Prince, make a
  4526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisadvantageous peace with a stronger, for feare; he is bound to keep
  4527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit; unlesse (as hath been sayd before) there ariseth some new, and just
  4528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcause of feare, to renew the war. And even in Common-wealths, if I be
  4529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforced to redeem my selfe from a Theefe by promising him mony, I am
  4530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbound to pay it, till the Civill Law discharge me. For whatsoever I may
  4531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfully do without Obligation, the same I may lawfully Covenant to do
  4532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthrough feare: and what I lawfully Covenant, I cannot lawfully break.
  4533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Former Covenant To One, Makes Voyd The Later To Another
  4538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA former Covenant, makes voyd a later. For a man that hath passed away
  4540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Right to one man to day, hath it not to passe to morrow to another:
  4541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore the later promise passeth no Right, but is null.
  4542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Mans Covenant Not To Defend Himselfe, Is Voyd
  4547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Covenant not to defend my selfe from force, by force, is alwayes voyd.
  4549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor (as I have shewed before) no man can transferre, or lay down his
  4550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight to save himselfe from Death, Wounds, and Imprisonment, (the
  4551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tavoyding whereof is the onely End of laying down any Right,)
  4552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore the promise of not resisting force, in no Covenant
  4553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransferreth any right; nor is obliging. For though a man may Covenant
  4554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthus, "Unlesse I do so, or so, kill me;" he cannot Covenant thus "Unless
  4555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI do so, or so, I will not resist you, when you come to kill me." For
  4556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman by nature chooseth the lesser evill, which is danger of death in
  4557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tresisting; rather than the greater, which is certain and present death
  4558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin not resisting. And this is granted to be true by all men, in
  4559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat they lead Criminals to Execution, and Prison, with armed men,
  4560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnotwithstanding that such Criminals have consented to the Law, by which
  4561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are condemned.
  4562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNo Man Obliged To Accuse Himselfe
  4567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Covenant to accuse ones Selfe, without assurance of pardon, is
  4569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlikewise invalide. For in the condition of Nature, where every man is
  4570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudge, there is no place for Accusation: and in the Civill State, the
  4571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAccusation is followed with Punishment; which being Force, a man is
  4572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot obliged not to resist. The same is also true, of the Accusation of
  4573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose, by whose Condemnation a man falls into misery; as of a Father,
  4574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWife, or Benefactor. For the Testimony of such an Accuser, if it be not
  4575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twillingly given, is praesumed to be corrupted by Nature; and therefore
  4576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot to be received: and where a mans Testimony is not to be credited,
  4577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this not bound to give it. Also Accusations upon Torture, are not to
  4578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe reputed as Testimonies. For Torture is to be used but as means of
  4579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconjecture, and light, in the further examination, and search of truth;
  4580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand what is in that case confessed, tendeth to the ease of him that is
  4581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTortured; not to the informing of the Torturers: and therefore ought
  4582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot to have the credit of a sufficient Testimony: for whether he deliver
