  4583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe by true, or false Accusation, he does it by the Right of
  4584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreserving his own life.
  4585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe End Of An Oath; The Forme Of As Oath
  4590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe force of Words, being (as I have formerly noted) too weak to hold
  4592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen to the performance of their Covenants; there are in mans nature, but
  4593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttwo imaginable helps to strengthen it. And those are either a Feare
  4594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the consequence of breaking their word; or a Glory, or Pride in
  4595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappearing not to need to breake it. This later is a Generosity too
  4596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trarely found to be presumed on, especially in the pursuers of Wealth,
  4597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommand, or sensuall Pleasure; which are the greatest part of Mankind.
  4598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Passion to be reckoned upon, is Fear; whereof there be two very
  4599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgenerall Objects: one, the Power of Spirits Invisible; the other, the
  4600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower of those men they shall therein Offend. Of these two, though the
  4601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformer be the greater Power, yet the feare of the later is commonly
  4602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe greater Feare. The Feare of the former is in every man, his own
  4603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion: which hath place in the nature of man before Civill Society.
  4604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe later hath not so; at least not place enough, to keep men to their
  4605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpromises; because in the condition of meer Nature, the inequality of
  4606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower is not discerned, but by the event of Battell. So that before the
  4607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime of Civill Society, or in the interruption thereof by Warre, there
  4608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis nothing can strengthen a Covenant of Peace agreed on, against the
  4609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttemptations of Avarice, Ambition, Lust, or other strong desire, but the
  4610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfeare of that Invisible Power, which they every one Worship as God; and
  4611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFeare as a Revenger of their perfidy. All therefore that can be done
  4612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetween two men not subject to Civill Power, is to put one another
  4613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto swear by the God he feareth: Which Swearing or OATH, is a Forme Of
  4614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpeech, Added To A Promise; By Which He That Promiseth, Signifieth, That
  4615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUnlesse He Performe, He Renounceth The Mercy Of His God, Or Calleth To
  4616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHim For Vengeance On Himselfe. Such was the Heathen Forme, "Let Jupiter
  4617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkill me else, as I kill this Beast." So is our Forme, "I shall do thus,
  4618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand thus, so help me God." And this, with the Rites and Ceremonies,
  4619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich every one useth in his own Religion, that the feare of breaking
  4620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaith might be the greater.
  4621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNo Oath, But By God
  4626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy this it appears, that an Oath taken according to any other Forme, or
  4628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRite, then his, that sweareth, is in vain; and no Oath: And there is no
  4629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSwearing by any thing which the Swearer thinks not God. For though men
  4630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave sometimes used to swear by their Kings, for feare, or flattery; yet
  4631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey would have it thereby understood, they attributed to them Divine
  4632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thonour. And that Swearing unnecessarily by God, is but prophaning of his
  4633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname: and Swearing by other things, as men do in common discourse, is
  4634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot Swearing, but an impious Custome, gotten by too much vehemence of
  4635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttalking.
  4636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAn Oath Addes Nothing To The Obligation
  4641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt appears also, that the Oath addes nothing to the Obligation. For a
  4643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant, if lawfull, binds in the sight of God, without the Oath,
  4644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas much as with it; if unlawfull, bindeth not at all; though it be
  4645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconfirmed with an Oath.
  4646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XV. OF OTHER LAWES OF NATURE
  4650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Third Law Of Nature, Justice
  4655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom that law of Nature, by which we are obliged to transferre to
  4657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, such Rights, as being retained, hinder the peace of Mankind,
  4658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere followeth a Third; which is this, That Men Performe Their
  4659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants Made: without which, Covenants are in vain, and but Empty
  4660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords; and the Right of all men to all things remaining, wee are still
  4661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the condition of Warre.
  4662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice And Injustice What
  4667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd in this law of Nature, consisteth the Fountain and Originall of
  4669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJUSTICE. For where no Covenant hath preceded, there hath no Right been
  4670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransferred, and every man has right to every thing; and consequently,
  4671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno action can be Unjust. But when a Covenant is made, then to break it
  4672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Unjust: And the definition of INJUSTICE, is no other than The Not
  4673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerformance Of Covenant. And whatsoever is not Unjust, is Just.
  4674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice And Propriety Begin With The Constitution of Common-wealth
  4676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut because Covenants of mutuall trust, where there is a feare of not
  4677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperformance on either part, (as hath been said in the former Chapter,)
  4678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare invalid; though the Originall of Justice be the making of Covenants;
  4679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet Injustice actually there can be none, till the cause of such feare
  4680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe taken away; which while men are in the naturall condition of Warre,
  4681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot be done. Therefore before the names of Just, and Unjust can have
  4682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace, there must be some coercive Power, to compell men equally to
  4683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe performance of their Covenants, by the terrour of some punishment,
  4684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreater than the benefit they expect by the breach of their Covenant;
  4685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to make good that Propriety, which by mutuall Contract men acquire,
  4686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin recompence of the universall Right they abandon: and such power there
  4687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis none before the erection of a Common-wealth. And this is also to be
  4688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgathered out of the ordinary definition of Justice in the Schooles: For
  4689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey say, that "Justice is the constant Will of giving to every man his
  4690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town." And therefore where there is no Own, that is, no Propriety, there
  4691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis no Injustice; and where there is no coerceive Power erected, that is,
  4692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere there is no Common-wealth, there is no Propriety; all men having
  4693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight to all things: Therefore where there is no Common-wealth, there
  4694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnothing is Unjust. So that the nature of Justice, consisteth in keeping
  4695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof valid Covenants: but the Validity of Covenants begins not but with
  4696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Constitution of a Civill Power, sufficient to compell men to keep
  4697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem: And then it is also that Propriety begins.
  4698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice Not Contrary To Reason
  4703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Foole hath sayd in his heart, there is no such thing as Justice;
  4705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand sometimes also with his tongue; seriously alleaging, that every mans
  4706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconservation, and contentment, being committed to his own care, there
  4707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcould be no reason, why every man might not do what he thought conduced
  4708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereunto; and therefore also to make, or not make; keep, or not keep
  4709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants, was not against Reason, when it conduced to ones benefit.
  4710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHe does not therein deny, that there be Covenants; and that they are
  4711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes broken, sometimes kept; and that such breach of them may
  4712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe called Injustice, and the observance of them Justice: but he
  4713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestioneth, whether Injustice, taking away the feare of God, (for the
  4714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame Foole hath said in his heart there is no God,) may not sometimes
  4715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstand with that Reason, which dictateth to every man his own good; and
  4716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticularly then, when it conduceth to such a benefit, as shall put a
  4717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman in a condition, to neglect not onely the dispraise, and revilings,
  4718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut also the power of other men. The Kingdome of God is gotten by
  4719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tviolence; but what if it could be gotten by unjust violence? were it
  4720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst Reason so to get it, when it is impossible to receive hurt by
  4721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit? and if it be not against Reason, it is not against Justice; or else
  4722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice is not to be approved for good. From such reasoning as this,
  4723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuccesfull wickednesse hath obtained the Name of Vertue; and some that
  4724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin all other things have disallowed the violation of Faith; yet have
  4725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallowed it, when it is for the getting of a Kingdome. And the Heathen
  4726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat believed, that Saturn was deposed by his son Jupiter, believed
  4727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse the same Jupiter to be the avenger of Injustice: Somewhat
  4728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike to a piece of Law in Cokes Commentaries on Litleton; where he
  4729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsayes, If the right Heire of the Crown be attainted of Treason; yet the
  4730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrown shall descend to him, and Eo Instante the Atteynder be voyd; From
  4731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich instances a man will be very prone to inferre; that when the Heire
  4732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapparent of a Kingdome, shall kill him that is in possession, though his
  4733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfather; you may call it Injustice, or by what other name you will; yet
  4734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit can never be against Reason, seeing all the voluntary actions of
  4735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen tend to the benefit of themselves; and those actions are most
  4736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReasonable, that conduce most to their ends. This specious reasoning is
  4737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnevertheless false.
  4738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the question is not of promises mutuall, where there is no security
  4740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof performance on either side; as when there is no Civill Power erected
  4741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover the parties promising; for such promises are no Covenants: But
  4742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither where one of the parties has performed already; or where there
  4743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a Power to make him performe; there is the question whether it be
  4744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst reason, that is, against the benefit of the other to performe,
  4745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor not. And I say it is not against reason. For the manifestation
  4746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof, we are to consider; First, that when a man doth a thing, which
  4747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnotwithstanding any thing can be foreseen, and reckoned on, tendeth to
  4748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own destruction, howsoever some accident which he could not expect,
  4749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tarriving may turne it to his benefit; yet such events do not make it
  4750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasonably or wisely done. Secondly, that in a condition of Warre,
  4751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twherein every man to every man, for want of a common Power to keep them
  4752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall in awe, is an Enemy, there is no man can hope by his own strength,
  4753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor wit, to defend himselfe from destruction, without the help
  4754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Confederates; where every one expects the same defence by the
  4755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConfederation, that any one else does: and therefore he which declares
  4756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the thinks it reason to deceive those that help him, can in reason expect
  4757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno other means of safety, than what can be had from his own single
  4758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower. He therefore that breaketh his Covenant, and consequently
  4759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeclareth that he thinks he may with reason do so, cannot be received
  4760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto any Society, that unite themselves for Peace and defence, but
  4761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the errour of them that receive him; nor when he is received, be
  4762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tretayned in it, without seeing the danger of their errour; which errours
  4763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man cannot reasonably reckon upon as the means of his security; and
  4764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore if he be left, or cast out of Society, he perisheth; and if he
  4765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlive in Society, it is by the errours of other men, which he could not
  4766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforesee, nor reckon upon; and consequently against the reason of his
  4767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreservation; and so, as all men that contribute not to his destruction,
  4768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforbear him onely out of ignorance of what is good for themselves.
  4769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for the Instance of gaining the secure and perpetuall felicity of
  4771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeaven, by any way; it is frivolous: there being but one way imaginable;
  4772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand that is not breaking, but keeping of Covenant.
  4773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd for the other Instance of attaining Soveraignty by Rebellion; it is
  4775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest, that though the event follow, yet because it cannot reasonably
  4776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe expected, but rather the contrary; and because by gaining it so,
  4777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tothers are taught to gain the same in like manner, the attempt thereof
  4778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis against reason. Justice therefore, that is to say, Keeping of
  4779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant, is a Rule of Reason, by which we are forbidden to do any thing
  4780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdestructive to our life; and consequently a Law of Nature.
  4781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere be some that proceed further; and will not have the Law of Nature,
  4783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be those Rules which conduce to the preservation of mans life on
  4784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tearth; but to the attaining of an eternall felicity after death; to
  4785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich they think the breach of Covenant may conduce; and consequently
  4786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe just and reasonable; (such are they that think it a work of merit
  4787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto kill, or depose, or rebell against, the Soveraigne Power constituted
  4788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover them by their own consent.) But because there is no naturall
  4789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknowledge of mans estate after death; much lesse of the reward that is
  4790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen to be given to breach of Faith; but onely a beliefe grounded upon
  4791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother mens saying, that they know it supernaturally, or that they know
  4792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose, that knew them, that knew others, that knew it supernaturally;
  4793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBreach of Faith cannot be called a Precept of Reason, or Nature.
  4794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants Not Discharged By The Vice Of The Person To Whom Made
  4799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOthers, that allow for a Law of Nature, the keeping of Faith, do
  4801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse make exception of certain persons; as Heretiques, and
  4802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as use not to performe their Covenant to others: And this also is
  4803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst reason. For if any fault of a man, be sufficient to discharge
  4804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Covenant made; the same ought in reason to have been sufficient to
  4805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave hindred the making of it.
  4806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice Of Men, And Justice Of Actions What
  4811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe names of Just, and Unjust, when they are attributed to Men, signifie
  4813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone thing; and when they are attributed to Actions, another. When they
  4814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare attributed to Men, they signifie Conformity, or Inconformity of
  4815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tManners, to Reason. But when they are attributed to Actions, they
  4816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifie the Conformity, or Inconformity to Reason, not of Manners, or
  4817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner of life, but of particular Actions. A Just man therefore, is he
  4818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat taketh all the care he can, that his Actions may be all Just: and
  4819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Unjust man, is he that neglecteth it. And such men are more often
  4820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin our Language stiled by the names of Righteous, and Unrighteous; then
  4821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJust, and Unjust; though the meaning be the same. Therefore a Righteous
  4822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, does not lose that Title, by one, or a few unjust Actions, that
  4823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceed from sudden Passion, or mistake of Things, or Persons: nor does
  4824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Unrighteous man, lose his character, for such Actions, as he does,
  4825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof forbeares to do, for feare: because his Will is not framed by the
  4826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice, but by the apparant benefit of what he is to do. That which
  4827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgives to humane Actions the relish of Justice, is a certain Noblenesse
  4828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Gallantnesse of courage, (rarely found,) by which a man scorns to
  4829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe beholding for the contentment of his life, to fraud, or breach of
  4830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpromise. This Justice of the Manners, is that which is meant, where
  4831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice is called a Vertue; and Injustice a Vice.
  4832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the Justice of Actions denominates men, not Just, but Guiltlesse;
  4834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Injustice of the same, (which is also called Injury,) gives them
  4835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the name of Guilty.
  4836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice Of Manners, And Justice Of Actions
  4841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, the Injustice of Manners, is the disposition, or aptitude to
  4843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo Injurie; and is Injustice before it proceed to Act; and without
  4844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupposing any individuall person injured. But the Injustice of an
  4845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAction, (that is to say Injury,) supposeth an individuall person
  4846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInjured; namely him, to whom the Covenant was made: And therefore many
  4847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimes the injury is received by one man, when the dammage redoundeth
  4848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto another. As when The Master commandeth his servant to give mony to a
  4849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstranger; if it be not done, the Injury is done to the Master, whom
  4850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the had before Covenanted to obey; but the dammage redoundeth to the
  4851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstranger, to whom he had no Obligation; and therefore could not Injure
  4852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim. And so also in Common-wealths, private men may remit to one another
  4853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir debts; but not robberies or other violences, whereby they are
  4854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tendammaged; because the detaining of Debt, is an Injury to themselves;
  4855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut Robbery and Violence, are Injuries to the Person of the
  4856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth.
  4857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNothing Done To A Man, By His Own Consent Can Be Injury
  4862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhatsoever is done to a man, conformable to his own Will signified to
  4864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe doer, is no Injury to him. For if he that doeth it, hath not passed
  4865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taway his originall right to do what he please, by some Antecedent
  4866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant, there is no breach of Covenant; and therefore no Injury done
  4867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim. And if he have; then his Will to have it done being signified, is a
  4868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trelease of that Covenant; and so again there is no Injury done him.
  4869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice Commutative, And Distributive
  4874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice of Actions, is by Writers divided into Commutative, and
  4876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDistributive; and the former they say consisteth in proportion
  4877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArithmeticall; the later in proportion Geometricall. Commutative
  4878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore, they place in the equality of value of the things contracted
  4879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor; And Distributive, in the distribution of equall benefit, to men of
  4880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequall merit. As if it were Injustice to sell dearer than we buy; or to
  4881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive more to a man than he merits. The value of all things contracted
  4882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor, is measured by the Appetite of the Contractors: and therefore the
  4883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjust value, is that which they be contented to give. And Merit (besides
  4884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which is by Covenant, where the performance on one part, meriteth
  4885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe performance of the other part, and falls under Justice Commutative,
  4886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot Distributive,) is not due by Justice; but is rewarded of Grace
  4887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely. And therefore this distinction, in the sense wherein it useth to
  4888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe expounded, is not right. To speak properly, Commutative Justice,
  4889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the Justice of a Contractor; that is, a Performance of Covenant,
  4890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Buying, and Selling; Hiring, and Letting to Hire; Lending, and
  4891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBorrowing; Exchanging, Bartering, and other acts of Contract.
  4892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Distributive Justice, the Justice of an Arbitrator; that is to say,
  4894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe act of defining what is Just. Wherein, (being trusted by them that
  4895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake him Arbitrator,) if he performe his Trust, he is said to distribute
  4896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto every man his own: and his is indeed Just Distribution, and may
  4897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe called (though improperly) Distributive Justice; but more properly
  4898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEquity; which also is a Law of Nature, as shall be shewn in due place.
  4899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Fourth Law Of Nature, Gratitude
  4904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs Justice dependeth on Antecedent Covenant; so does Gratitude depend
  4906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton Antecedent Grace; that is to say, Antecedent Free-gift: and is the
  4907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfourth Law of Nature; which may be conceived in this Forme, "That a man
  4908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich receiveth Benefit from another of meer Grace, Endeavour that he
  4909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich giveth it, have no reasonable cause to repent him of his good
  4910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill." For no man giveth, but with intention of Good to himselfe;
  4911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause Gift is Voluntary; and of all Voluntary Acts, the Object is to
  4912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery man his own Good; of which if men see they shall be frustrated,
  4913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere will be no beginning of benevolence, or trust; nor consequently of
  4914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmutuall help; nor of reconciliation of one man to another; and therefore
  4915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are to remain still in the condition of War; which is contrary to
  4916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe first and Fundamentall Law of Nature, which commandeth men to Seek
  4917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace. The breach of this Law, is called Ingratitude; and hath the same
  4918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trelation to Grace, that Injustice hath to Obligation by Covenant.
  4919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Fifth, Mutuall accommodation, or Compleasance
  4924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA fifth Law of Nature, is COMPLEASANCE; that is to say, "That every
  4926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman strive to accommodate himselfe to the rest." For the understanding
  4927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof, we may consider, that there is in mens aptnesse to Society;
  4928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta diversity of Nature, rising from their diversity of Affections; not
  4929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunlike to that we see in stones brought together for building of an
  4930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAedifice. For as that stone which by the asperity, and irregularity of
  4931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFigure, takes more room from others, than it selfe fills; and for
  4932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe hardnesse, cannot be easily made plain, and thereby hindereth the
  4933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbuilding, is by the builders cast away as unprofitable, and troublesome:
  4934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso also, a man that by asperity of Nature, will strive to retain those
  4935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings which to himselfe are superfluous, and to others necessary; and
  4936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the stubbornness of his Passions, cannot be corrected, is to be
  4937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleft, or cast out of Society, as combersome thereunto. For seeing every
  4938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, not onely by Right, but also by necessity of Nature, is supposed
  4939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto endeavour all he can, to obtain that which is necessary for his
  4940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconservation; He that shall oppose himselfe against it, for things
  4941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuperfluous, is guilty of the warre that thereupon is to follow; and
  4942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore doth that, which is contrary to the fundamentall Law of
  4943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature, which commandeth To Seek Peace. The observers of this Law,
  4944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay be called SOCIABLE, (the Latines call them Commodi;) The contrary,
  4945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tStubborn, Insociable, Froward, Intractable.
  4946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Sixth, Facility To Pardon
  4951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA sixth Law of Nature is this, "That upon caution of the Future time,
  4953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man ought to pardon the offences past of them that repenting, desire
  4954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit." For PARDON, is nothing but granting of Peace; which though granted
  4955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto them that persevere in their hostility, be not Peace, but Feare; yet
  4956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot granted to them that give caution of the Future time, is signe of an
  4957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taversion to Peace; and therefore contrary to the Law of Nature.
  4958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Seventh, That In Revenges, Men Respect Onely The Future Good
  4963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA seventh is, " That in Revenges, (that is, retribution of evil for
  4965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevil,) Men look not at the greatnesse of the evill past, but the
  4966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreatnesse of the good to follow." Whereby we are forbidden to inflict
  4967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunishment with any other designe, than for correction of the offender,
  4968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor direction of others. For this Law is consequent to the next before
  4969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, that commandeth Pardon, upon security of the Future Time. Besides,
  4970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRevenge without respect to the Example, and profit to come, is a
  4971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttriumph, or glorying in the hurt of another, tending to no end; (for the
  4972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnd is alwayes somewhat to Come;) and glorying to no end, is vain-glory,
  4973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand contrary to reason; and to hurt without reason, tendeth to the
  4974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tintroduction of Warre; which is against the Law of Nature; and is
  4975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommonly stiled by the name of Cruelty.
  4976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Eighth, Against Contumely
  4981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because all signes of hatred, or contempt, provoke to fight;
  4983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinsomuch as most men choose rather to hazard their life, than not to be
  4984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trevenged; we may in the eighth place, for a Law of Nature set down this
  4985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrecept, "That no man by deed, word, countenance, or gesture, declare
  4986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHatred, or Contempt of another." The breach of which Law, is commonly
  4987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Contumely.
  4988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Ninth, Against Pride
  4993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  4994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe question who is the better man, has no place in the condition of
  4995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeer Nature; where, (as has been shewn before,) all men are equall. The
  4996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinequallity that now is, has been introduced by the Lawes civill. I know
  4997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Aristotle in the first booke of his Politiques, for a foundation of
  4998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this doctrine, maketh men by Nature, some more worthy to Command, meaning
  4999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe wiser sort (such as he thought himselfe to be for his Philosophy;)
  5000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tothers to Serve, (meaning those that had strong bodies, but were not
  5001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophers as he;) as if Master and Servant were not introduced by
  5002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsent of men, but by difference of Wit; which is not only against
  5003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treason; but also against experience. For there are very few so foolish,
  5004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat had not rather governe themselves, than be governed by others:
  5005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor when the wise in their own conceit, contend by force, with them who
  5006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdistrust their owne wisdome, do they alwaies, or often, or almost at any
  5007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, get the Victory. If Nature therefore have made men equall, that
  5008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequalitie is to be acknowledged; or if Nature have made men unequall;
  5009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet because men that think themselves equall, will not enter into
  5010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconditions of Peace, but upon Equall termes, such equalitie must be
  5011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadmitted. And therefore for the ninth Law of Nature, I put this, "That
  5012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery man acknowledge other for his Equall by Nature." The breach of
  5013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Precept is Pride.
  5014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Tenth Against Arrogance
  5019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOn this law, dependeth another, "That at the entrance into conditions of
  5021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace, no man require to reserve to himselfe any Right, which he is not
  5022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontent should be reserved to every one of the rest." As it is necessary
  5023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor all men that seek peace, to lay down certaine Rights of Nature; that
  5024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, not to have libertie to do all they list: so is it necessarie
  5025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor mans life, to retaine some; as right to governe their owne bodies;
  5026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenjoy aire, water, motion, waies to go from place to place; and all
  5027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings else without which a man cannot live, or not live well. If in
  5028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis case, at the making of Peace, men require for themselves, that
  5029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich they would not have to be granted to others, they do contrary
  5030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the precedent law, that commandeth the acknowledgement of naturall
  5031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequalitie, and therefore also against the law of Nature. The observers
  5032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof this law, are those we call Modest, and the breakers Arrogant Men.
  5033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Greeks call the violation of this law pleonexia; that is, a desire
  5034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof more than their share.
  5035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Eleventh Equity
  5040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso "If a man be trusted to judge between man and man," it is a precept
  5042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Law of Nature, "that he deale Equally between them." For without
  5043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat, the Controversies of men cannot be determined but by Warre.
  5044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHe therefore that is partiall in judgment, doth what in him lies, to
  5045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeterre men from the use of Judges, and Arbitrators; and consequently,
  5046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(against the fundamentall Lawe of Nature) is the cause of Warre.
  5047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe observance of this law, from the equall distribution to each man, of
  5049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which in reason belongeth to him, is called EQUITY, and (as I have
  5050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsayd before) distributive justice: the violation, Acception Of Persons,
  5051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProsopolepsia.
  5052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Twelfth, Equall Use Of Things Common
  5057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd from this followeth another law, "That such things as cannot be
  5059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivided, be enjoyed in Common, if it can be; and if the quantity of the
  5060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing permit, without Stint; otherwise Proportionably to the number of
  5061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem that have Right." For otherwise the distribution is Unequall, and
  5062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary to Equitie.
  5063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Thirteenth, Of Lot
  5068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut some things there be, that can neither be divided, nor enjoyed in
  5070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommon. Then, The Law of Nature, which prescribeth Equity, requireth,
  5071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"That the Entire Right; or else, (making the use alternate,) the First
  5072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPossession, be determined by Lot." For equall distribution, is of
  5073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law of Nature; and other means of equall distribution cannot be
  5074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timagined.
  5075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Fourteenth, Of Primogeniture, And First Seising
  5080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Lots there be two sorts, Arbitrary, and Naturall. Arbitrary, is
  5082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which is agreed on by the Competitors; Naturall, is either
  5083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrimogeniture, (which the Greek calls Kleronomia, which signifies, Given
  5084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Lot;) or First Seisure.
  5085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore those things which cannot be enjoyed in common, nor
  5087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivided, ought to be adjudged to the First Possessor; and is some cases
  5088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the First-Borne, as acquired by Lot.
  5089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Fifteenth, Of Mediators
  5094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is also a Law of Nature, "That all men that mediate Peace, be allowed
  5096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsafe Conduct." For the Law that commandeth Peace, as the End, commandeth
  5097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIntercession, as the Means; and to Intercession the Means is safe
  5098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConduct.
  5099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Sixteenth, Of Submission To Arbitrement
  5104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because, though men be never so willing to observe these Lawes,
  5106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere may neverthelesse arise questions concerning a mans action; First,
  5107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhether it were done, or not done; Secondly (if done) whether against
  5108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law, or not against the Law; the former whereof, is called a
  5109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestion Of Fact; the later a question Of Right; therefore unlesse the
  5110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparties to the question, Covenant mutually to stand to the sentence
  5111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof another, they are as farre from Peace as ever. This other, to whose
  5112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSentence they submit, is called an ARBITRATOR. And therefore it is of
  5113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law of Nature, "That they that are at controversie, submit their
  5114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight to the judgement of an Arbitrator."
  5115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Seventeenth, No Man Is His Own Judge
  5120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd seeing every man is presumed to do all things in order to his own
  5122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbenefit, no man is a fit Arbitrator in his own cause: and if he were
  5123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnever so fit; yet Equity allowing to each party equall benefit, if one
  5124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe admitted to be Judge, the other is to be admitted also; & so the
  5125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontroversie, that is, the cause of War, remains, against the Law of
  5126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature.
  5127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Eighteenth, No Man To Be Judge, That Has In Him Cause Of Partiality
  5132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the same reason no man in any Cause ought to be received for
  5134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArbitrator, to whom greater profit, or honour, or pleasure apparently
  5135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tariseth out of the victory of one party, than of the other: for he hath
  5136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaken (though an unavoydable bribe, yet) a bribe; and no man can be
  5137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobliged to trust him. And thus also the controversie, and the condition
  5138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof War remaineth, contrary to the Law of Nature.
  5139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Nineteenth, Of Witnesse
  5144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd in a controversie of Fact, the Judge being to give no more credit
  5146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto one, than to the other, (if there be no other Arguments) must give
  5147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcredit to a third; or to a third and fourth; or more: For else the
  5148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestion is undecided, and left to force, contrary to the Law of Nature.
  5149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese are the Lawes of Nature, dictating Peace, for a means of the
  5151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconservation of men in multitudes; and which onely concern the doctrine
  5152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Civill Society. There be other things tending to the destruction of
  5153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular men; as Drunkenness, and all other parts of Intemperance;
  5154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich may therefore also be reckoned amongst those things which the Law
  5155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Nature hath forbidden; but are not necessary to be mentioned, nor are
  5156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpertinent enough to this place.
  5157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Rule, By Which The Laws Of Nature May Easily Be Examined
  5162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd though this may seem too subtile a deduction of the Lawes of Nature,
  5164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be taken notice of by all men; whereof the most part are too busie in
  5165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgetting food, and the rest too negligent to understand; yet to leave
  5166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall men unexcusable, they have been contracted into one easie sum,
  5167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tintelligible even to the meanest capacity; and that is, "Do not that to
  5168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, which thou wouldest not have done to thy selfe;" which sheweth
  5169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, that he has no more to do in learning the Lawes of Nature, but,
  5170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen weighing the actions of other men with his own, they seem too
  5171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theavy, to put them into the other part of the ballance, and his own into
  5172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir place, that his own passions, and selfe-love, may adde nothing to
  5173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe weight; and then there is none of these Lawes of Nature that will
  5174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot appear unto him very reasonable.
  5175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Lawes Of Nature Oblige In Conscience Alwayes,
  5180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut In Effect Then Onely When There Is Security The Lawes of Nature
  5182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toblige In Foro Interno; that is to say, they bind to a desire they
  5183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould take place: but In Foro Externo; that is, to the putting them
  5184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin act, not alwayes. For he that should be modest, and tractable, and
  5185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperforme all he promises, in such time, and place, where no man els
  5186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould do so, should but make himselfe a prey to others, and procure his
  5187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town certain ruine, contrary to the ground of all Lawes of Nature, which
  5188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttend to Natures preservation. And again, he that shall observe the same
  5189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes towards him, observes them not himselfe, seeketh not Peace, but
  5190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWar; & consequently the destruction of his Nature by Violence.
  5191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whatsoever Lawes bind In Foro Interno, may be broken, not onely by
  5193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta fact contrary to the Law but also by a fact according to it, in case a
  5194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman think it contrary. For though his Action in this case, be according
  5195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Law; which where the Obligation is In Foro Interno, is a breach.
  5196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Laws Of Nature Are Eternal;
  5201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Lawes of Nature are Immutable and Eternall, For Injustice,
  5203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIngratitude, Arrogance, Pride, Iniquity, Acception of persons, and the
  5204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trest, can never be made lawfull. For it can never be that Warre shall
  5205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreserve life, and Peace destroy it.
  5206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Yet Easie
  5211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe same Lawes, because they oblige onely to a desire, and endeavour, I
  5213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmean an unfeigned and constant endeavour, are easie to be observed. For
  5214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin that they require nothing but endeavour; he that endeavoureth their
  5215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperformance, fulfilleth them; and he that fulfilleth the Law, is Just.
  5216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Science Of These Lawes, Is The True Morall Philosophy
  5221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd the Science of them, is the true and onely Moral Philosophy. For
  5223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMorall Philosophy is nothing else but the Science of what is Good, and
  5224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvill, in the conversation, and Society of mankind. Good, and Evill,
  5225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare names that signifie our Appetites, and Aversions; which in different
  5226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttempers, customes, and doctrines of men, are different: And divers men,
  5227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiffer not onely in their Judgement, on the senses of what is pleasant,
  5228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand unpleasant to the tast, smell, hearing, touch, and sight; but also
  5229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof what is conformable, or disagreeable to Reason, in the actions of
  5230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommon life. Nay, the same man, in divers times, differs from himselfe;
  5231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand one time praiseth, that is, calleth Good, what another time
  5232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the dispraiseth, and calleth Evil: From whence arise Disputes,
  5233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tControversies, and at last War. And therefore so long as man is in the
  5234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition of meer Nature, (which is a condition of War,) as private
  5235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAppetite is the measure of Good, and Evill: and consequently all men
  5236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagree on this, that Peace is Good, and therefore also the way, or
  5237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeans of Peace, which (as I have shewed before) are Justice, Gratitude,
  5238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tModesty, Equity, Mercy, & the rest of the Laws of Nature, are good; that
  5239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, Morall Vertues; and their contrarie Vices, Evill. Now the
  5240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tscience of Vertue and Vice, is Morall Philosophie; and therfore the true
  5241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine of the Lawes of Nature, is the true Morall Philosophie. But the
  5242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWriters of Morall Philosophie, though they acknowledge the same Vertues
  5243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Vices; Yet not seeing wherein consisted their Goodnesse; nor that
  5244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey come to be praised, as the meanes of peaceable, sociable, and
  5245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomfortable living; place them in a mediocrity of passions: as if not
  5246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Cause, but the Degree of daring, made Fortitude; or not the Cause,
  5247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the Quantity of a gift, made Liberality.
  5248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese dictates of Reason, men use to call by the name of Lawes; but
  5250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timproperly: for they are but Conclusions, or Theoremes concerning what
  5251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconduceth to the conservation and defence of themselves; whereas Law,
  5252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproperly is the word of him, that by right hath command over others. But
  5253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet if we consider the same Theoremes, as delivered in the word of
  5254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, that by right commandeth all things; then are they properly called
  5255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes.
  5256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XVI. OF PERSONS, AUTHORS, AND THINGS PERSONATED
  5260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Person What
  5264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA PERSON, is he "whose words or actions are considered, either as his
  5266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town, or as representing the words or actions of an other man, or of any
  5267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother thing to whom they are attributed, whether Truly or by Fiction."
  5268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson Naturall, And Artificiall
  5273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen they are considered as his owne, then is he called a Naturall
  5275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson: And when they are considered as representing the words and
  5276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions of an other, then is he a Feigned or Artificiall person.
  5277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Word Person, Whence
  5282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe word Person is latine: instead whereof the Greeks have Prosopon,
  5284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich signifies the Face, as Persona in latine signifies the Disguise,
  5285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Outward Appearance of a man, counterfeited on the Stage; and somtimes
  5286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore particularly that part of it, which disguiseth the face, as a Mask
  5287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Visard: And from the Stage, hath been translated to any Representer
  5288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof speech and action, as well in Tribunalls, as Theaters. So that a
  5289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson, is the same that an Actor is, both on the Stage and in common
  5290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConversation; and to Personate, is to Act, or Represent himselfe, or an
  5291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother; and he that acteth another, is said to beare his Person, or
  5292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tact in his name; (in which sence Cicero useth it where he saies, "Unus
  5293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSustineo Tres Personas; Mei, Adversarii, & Judicis, I beare three
  5294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPersons; my own, my Adversaries, and the Judges;") and is called in
  5295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiverse occasions, diversly; as a Representer, or Representative, a
  5296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLieutenant, a Vicar, an Attorney, a Deputy, a Procurator, an Actor, and
  5297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe like.
  5298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActor, Author; Authority
  5303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Persons Artificiall, some have their words and actions Owned by
  5305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose whom they represent. And then the Person is the Actor; and he that
  5306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\towneth his words and actions, is the AUTHOR: In which case the
  5307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActor acteth by Authority. For that which in speaking of goods and
  5308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossessions, is called an Owner, and in latine Dominus, in Greeke
  5309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKurios; speaking of Actions, is called Author. And as the Right of
  5310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossession, is called Dominion; so the Right of doing any Action, is
  5311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled AUTHORITY. So that by Authority, is alwayes understood a Right
  5312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof doing any act: and Done By Authority, done by Commission, or Licence
  5313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom him whose right it is.
  5314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants By Authority, Bind The Author
  5319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom hence it followeth, that when the Actor maketh a Covenant by
  5321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority, he bindeth thereby the Author, no lesse than if he had made
  5322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit himselfe; and no lesse subjecteth him to all the consequences of the
  5323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame. And therfore all that hath been said formerly, (Chap. 14) of the
  5324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnature of Covenants between man and man in their naturall capacity,
  5325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis true also when they are made by their Actors, Representers, or
  5326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProcurators, that have authority from them, so far-forth as is in their
  5327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommission, but no farther.
  5328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore he that maketh a Covenant with the Actor, or Representer,
  5330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot knowing the Authority he hath, doth it at his own perill. For no man
  5331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis obliged by a Covenant, whereof he is not Author; nor consequently by
  5332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Covenant made against, or beside the Authority he gave.
  5333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut Not The Actor
  5338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen the Actor doth any thing against the Law of Nature by command of
  5340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Author, if he be obliged by former Covenant to obey him, not he, but
  5341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Author breaketh the Law of Nature: for though the Action be against
  5342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law of Nature; yet it is not his: but contrarily; to refuse to do
  5343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, is against the Law of Nature, that forbiddeth breach of Covenant.
  5344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Authority Is To Be Shewne
  5349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd he that maketh a Covenant with the Author, by mediation of the
  5351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActor, not knowing what Authority he hath, but onely takes his word;
  5352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin case such Authority be not made manifest unto him upon demand, is
  5353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno longer obliged: For the Covenant made with the Author, is not valid,
  5354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout his Counter-assurance. But if he that so Covenanteth, knew
  5355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore hand he was to expect no other assurance, than the Actors word;
  5356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen is the Covenant valid; because the Actor in this case maketh
  5357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe the Author. And therefore, as when the Authority is evident,
  5358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Covenant obligeth the Author, not the Actor; so when the Authority
  5359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis feigned, it obligeth the Actor onely; there being no Author but
  5360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe.
  5361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThings Personated, Inanimate
  5366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere are few things, that are uncapable of being represented by
  5368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFiction. Inanimate things, as a Church, an Hospital, a Bridge, may
  5369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Personated by a Rector, Master, or Overseer. But things Inanimate,
  5370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot be Authors, nor therefore give Authority to their Actors: Yet the
  5371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActors may have Authority to procure their maintenance, given them by
  5372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that are Owners, or Governours of those things. And therefore,
  5373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch things cannot be Personated, before there be some state of Civill
  5374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment.
  5375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIrrational
  5380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLikewise Children, Fooles, and Mad-men that have no use of Reason, may
  5382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Personated by Guardians, or Curators; but can be no Authors (during
  5383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat time) of any action done by them, longer then (when they shall
  5384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trecover the use of Reason) they shall judge the same reasonable.
  5385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tYet during the Folly, he that hath right of governing them, may give
  5386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority to the Guardian. But this again has no place but in a State
  5387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill, because before such estate, there is no Dominion of Persons.
  5388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFalse Gods
  5393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAn Idol, or meer Figment of the brain, my be Personated; as were the
  5395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods of the Heathen; which by such Officers as the State appointed, were
  5396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPersonated, and held Possessions, and other Goods, and Rights, which men
  5397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom time to time dedicated, and consecrated unto them. But idols cannot
  5398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Authors: for a Idol is nothing. The Authority proceeded from the
  5399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tState: and therefore before introduction of Civill Government, the Gods
  5400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Heathen could not be Personated.
  5401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe True God
  5406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe true God may be Personated. As he was; first, by Moses; who governed
  5408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Israelites, (that were not his, but Gods people,) not in his own
  5409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname, with Hoc Dicit Moses; but in Gods Name, with Hoc Dicit Dominus.
  5410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, by the son of man, his own Son our Blessed Saviour Jesus
  5411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, that came to reduce the Jewes, and induce all Nations into the
  5412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of his Father; not as of himselfe, but as sent from his Father.
  5413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd thirdly, by the Holy Ghost, or Comforter, speaking, and working
  5414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Apostles: which Holy Ghost, was a Comforter that came not of
  5415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe; but was sent, and proceeded from them both.
  5416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Multitude Of Men, How One Person
  5421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Multitude of men, are made One Person, when they are by one man, or
  5423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone Person, Represented; so that it be done with the consent of
  5424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one of that Multitude in particular. For it is the Unity of the
  5425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresenter, not the Unity of the Represented, that maketh the Person
  5426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOne. And it is the Representer that beareth the Person, and but one
  5427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson: And Unity, cannot otherwise be understood in Multitude.
  5428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvery One Is Author
  5433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because the Multitude naturally is not One, but Many; they cannot
  5435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe understood for one; but many Authors, of every thing their
  5436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative faith, or doth in their name; Every man giving their
  5437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommon Representer, Authority from himselfe in particular; and owning
  5438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall the actions the Representer doth, in case they give him Authority
  5439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout stint: Otherwise, when they limit him in what, and how farre
  5440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the shall represent them, none of them owneth more, than they gave him
  5441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommission to Act.
  5442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAn Actor May Be Many Men Made One By Plurality Of Voyces
  5447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd if the Representative consist of many men, the voyce of the greater
  5449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnumber, must be considered as the voyce of them all. For if the lesser
  5450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnumber pronounce (for example) in the Affirmative, and the greater in
  5451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Negative, there will be Negatives more than enough to destroy
  5452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Affirmatives; and thereby the excesse of Negatives, standing
  5453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuncontradicted, are the onely voyce the Representative hath.
  5454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentatives, When The Number Is Even, Unprofitable
  5459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd a Representative of even number, especially when the number is
  5461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot great, whereby the contradictory voyces are oftentimes equall, is
  5462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore oftentimes mute, and uncapable of Action. Yet in some cases
  5463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontradictory voyces equall in number, may determine a question; as in
  5464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondemning, or absolving, equality of votes, even in that they condemne
  5465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot, do absolve; but not on the contrary condemne, in that they absolve
  5466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot. For when a Cause is heard; not to condemne, is to absolve; but on
  5467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe contrary, to say that not absolving, is condemning, is not true. The
  5468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike it is in a deliberation of executing presently, or deferring
  5469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttill another time; For when the voyces are equall, the not decreeing
  5470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExecution, is a decree of Dilation.
  5471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNegative Voyce
  5476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOr if the number be odde, as three, or more, (men, or assemblies;)
  5478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof every one has by a Negative Voice, authority to take away the
  5479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teffect of all the Affirmative Voices of the rest, This number is no
  5480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative; because by the diversity of Opinions, and Interests of
  5481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, it becomes oftentimes, and in cases of the greatest consequence, a
  5482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmute Person, and unapt, as for may things else, so for the government of
  5483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Multitude, especially in time of Warre.
  5484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Authors there be two sorts. The first simply so called; which I have
  5486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore defined to be him, that owneth the Action of another simply.
  5487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe second is he, that owneth an Action, or Covenant of another
  5488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconditionally; that is to say, he undertaketh to do it, if the
  5489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother doth it not, at, or before a certain time. And these Authors
  5490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconditionall, are generally called SURETYES, in Latine Fidejussores, and
  5491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSponsores; and particularly for Debt, Praedes; and for Appearance before
  5492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Judge, or Magistrate, Vades.
  5493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPART II. OF COMMON-WEALTH
  5499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XVII. OF THE CAUSES, GENERATION, AND DEFINITION OF A
  5503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCOMMON-WEALTH
  5504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe End Of Common-wealth, Particular Security
  5509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe finall Cause, End, or Designe of men, (who naturally love Liberty,
  5511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Dominion over others,) in the introduction of that restraint upon
  5512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, (in which wee see them live in Common-wealths,) is the
  5513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforesight of their own preservation, and of a more contented life
  5514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereby; that is to say, of getting themselves out from that miserable
  5515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition of Warre, which is necessarily consequent (as hath been shewn)
  5516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the naturall Passions of men, when there is no visible Power to keep
  5517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem in awe, and tye them by feare of punishment to the performance of
  5518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Covenants, and observation of these Lawes of Nature set down in
  5519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe fourteenth and fifteenth Chapters.
  5520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhich Is Not To Be Had From The Law Of Nature:
  5525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the Lawes of Nature (as Justice, Equity, Modesty, Mercy, and (in
  5527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsumme) Doing To Others, As Wee Would Be Done To,) if themselves, without
  5528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe terrour of some Power, to cause them to be observed, are contrary to
  5529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour naturall Passions, that carry us to Partiality, Pride, Revenge, and
  5530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe like. And Covenants, without the Sword, are but Words, and of no
  5531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstrength to secure a man at all. Therefore notwithstanding the Lawes of
  5532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature, (which every one hath then kept, when he has the will to keep
  5533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, when he can do it safely,) if there be no Power erected, or not
  5534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat enough for our security; every man will and may lawfully rely on
  5535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own strength and art, for caution against all other men. And in all
  5536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaces, where men have lived by small Families, to robbe and spoyle one
  5537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, has been a Trade, and so farre from being reputed against the
  5538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw of Nature, that the greater spoyles they gained, the greater was
  5539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir honour; and men observed no other Lawes therein, but the Lawes of
  5540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonour; that is, to abstain from cruelty, leaving to men their lives,
  5541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand instruments of husbandry. And as small Familyes did then; so now
  5542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo Cities and Kingdomes which are but greater Families (for their own
  5543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsecurity) enlarge their Dominions, upon all pretences of danger, and
