  5544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfear of Invasion, or assistance that may be given to Invaders, endeavour
  5545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas much as they can, to subdue, or weaken their neighbours, by open
  5546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforce, and secret arts, for want of other Caution, justly; and are
  5547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trememdbred for it in after ages with honour.
  5548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor From The Conjunction Of A Few Men Or Familyes
  5553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor is it the joyning together of a small number of men, that gives them
  5555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis security; because in small numbers, small additions on the one side
  5556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor the other, make the advantage of strength so great, as is sufficient
  5557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto carry the Victory; and therefore gives encouragement to an Invasion.
  5558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Multitude sufficient to confide in for our Security, is not
  5559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdetermined by any certain number, but by comparison with the Enemy we
  5560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfeare; and is then sufficient, when the odds of the Enemy is not of so
  5561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvisible and conspicuous moment, to determine the event of warre, as to
  5562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmove him to attempt.
  5563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor From A Great Multitude, Unlesse Directed By One Judgement
  5568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd be there never so great a Multitude; yet if their actions be
  5570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdirected according to their particular judgements, and particular
  5571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappetites, they can expect thereby no defence, nor protection, neither
  5572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst a Common enemy, nor against the injuries of one another. For
  5573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing distracted in opinions concerning the best use and application
  5574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their strength, they do not help, but hinder one another; and reduce
  5575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir strength by mutuall opposition to nothing: whereby they are
  5576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teasily, not onely subdued by a very few that agree together; but also
  5577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen there is no common enemy, they make warre upon each other, for
  5578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir particular interests. For if we could suppose a great Multitude of
  5579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen to consent in the observation of Justice, and other Lawes of Nature,
  5580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout a common Power to keep them all in awe; we might as well suppose
  5581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall Man-kind to do the same; and then there neither would be nor need to
  5582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe any Civill Government, or Common-wealth at all; because there would
  5583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Peace without subjection.
  5584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd That Continually
  5589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor is it enough for the security, which men desire should last all
  5591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe time of their life, that they be governed, and directed by one
  5592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudgement, for a limited time; as in one Battell, or one Warre. For
  5593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough they obtain a Victory by their unanimous endeavour against a
  5594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforraign enemy; yet afterwards, when either they have no common enemy,
  5595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor he that by one part is held for an enemy, is by another part held for
  5596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta friend, they must needs by the difference of their interests dissolve,
  5597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand fall again into a Warre amongst themselves.
  5598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhy Certain Creatures Without Reason, Or Speech,
  5603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDo Neverthelesse Live In Society, Without Any Coercive Power
  5608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is true, that certain living creatures, as Bees, and Ants, live
  5610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsociably one with another, (which are therefore by Aristotle numbred
  5611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst Politicall creatures;) and yet have no other direction, than
  5612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir particular judgements and appetites; nor speech, whereby one of
  5613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem can signifie to another, what he thinks expedient for the common
  5614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbenefit: and therefore some man may perhaps desire to know, why Man-kind
  5615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot do the same. To which I answer,
  5616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFirst, that men are continually in competition for Honour and Dignity,
  5618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich these creatures are not; and consequently amongst men there
  5619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tariseth on that ground, Envy and Hatred, and finally Warre; but amongst
  5620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese not so.
  5621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, that amongst these creatures, the Common good differeth not
  5623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Private; and being by nature enclined to their private, they
  5624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprocure thereby the common benefit. But man, whose Joy consisteth
  5625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin comparing himselfe with other men, can relish nothing but what is
  5626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teminent.
  5627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, that these creatures, having not (as man) the use of reason,
  5629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo not see, nor think they see any fault, in the administration of their
  5630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommon businesse: whereas amongst men, there are very many, that thinke
  5631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves wiser, and abler to govern the Publique, better than the
  5632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trest; and these strive to reforme and innovate, one this way, another
  5633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat way; and thereby bring it into Distraction and Civill warre.
  5634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, that these creatures, though they have some use of voice, in
  5636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmaking knowne to one another their desires, and other affections; yet
  5637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey want that art of words, by which some men can represent to others,
  5638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which is Good, in the likenesse of Evill; and Evill, in the
  5639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlikenesse of Good; and augment, or diminish the apparent greatnesse of
  5640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood and Evill; discontenting men, and troubling their Peace at their
  5641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpleasure.
  5642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFiftly, irrationall creatures cannot distinguish betweene Injury, and
  5644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDammage; and therefore as long as they be at ease, they are not offended
  5645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith their fellowes: whereas Man is then most troublesome, when he is
  5646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost at ease: for then it is that he loves to shew his Wisdome, and
  5647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontroule the Actions of them that governe the Common-wealth.
  5648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, the agreement of these creatures is Naturall; that of men, is
  5650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Covenant only, which is Artificiall: and therefore it is no wonder
  5651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif there be somewhat else required (besides Covenant) to make their
  5652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgreement constant and lasting; which is a Common Power, to keep them in
  5653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tawe, and to direct their actions to the Common Benefit.
  5654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Generation Of A Common-wealth
  5659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe only way to erect such a Common Power, as may be able to defend them
  5661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the invasion of Forraigners, and the injuries of one another, and
  5662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereby to secure them in such sort, as that by their owne industrie,
  5663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand by the fruites of the Earth, they may nourish themselves and live
  5664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontentedly; is, to conferre all their power and strength upon one
  5665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMan, or upon one Assembly of men, that may reduce all their Wills,
  5666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby plurality of voices, unto one Will: which is as much as to say, to
  5667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappoint one man, or Assembly of men, to beare their Person; and every
  5668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone to owne, and acknowledge himselfe to be Author of whatsoever he
  5669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat so beareth their Person, shall Act, or cause to be Acted, in those
  5670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings which concerne the Common Peace and Safetie; and therein to
  5671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubmit their Wills, every one to his Will, and their Judgements, to his
  5672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgment. This is more than Consent, or Concord; it is a reall Unitie of
  5673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem all, in one and the same Person, made by Covenant of every man with
  5674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery man, in such manner, as if every man should say to every man, "I
  5675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthorise and give up my Right of Governing my selfe, to this Man, or to
  5676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Assembly of men, on this condition, that thou give up thy Right
  5677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto him, and Authorise all his Actions in like manner." This done, the
  5678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMultitude so united in one Person, is called a COMMON-WEALTH, in latine
  5679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCIVITAS. This is the Generation of that great LEVIATHAN, or rather (to
  5680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeake more reverently) of that Mortall God, to which wee owe under the
  5681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImmortall God, our peace and defence. For by this Authoritie, given him
  5682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby every particular man in the Common-Wealth, he hath the use of so
  5683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmuch Power and Strength conferred on him, that by terror thereof, he is
  5684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinabled to forme the wills of them all, to Peace at home, and mutuall
  5685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tayd against their enemies abroad.
  5686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Definition Of A Common-wealth
  5691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd in him consisteth the Essence of the Common-wealth; which (to
  5693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdefine it,) is "One Person, of whose Acts a great Multitude, by mutuall
  5694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants one with another, have made themselves every one the Author,
  5695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the end he may use the strength and means of them all, as he shall
  5696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthink expedient, for their Peace and Common Defence."
  5697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne, And Subject, What
  5702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd he that carryeth this Person, as called SOVERAIGNE, and said to have
  5704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne Power; and every one besides, his SUBJECT.
  5705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe attaining to this Soveraigne Power, is by two wayes. One, by
  5707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall force; as when a man maketh his children, to submit themselves,
  5708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand their children to his government, as being able to destroy them if
  5709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey refuse, or by Warre subdueth his enemies to his will, giving them
  5710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir lives on that condition. The other, is when men agree amongst
  5711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, to submit to some Man, or Assembly of men, voluntarily, on
  5712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconfidence to be protected by him against all others. This later, may be
  5713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled a Politicall Common-wealth, or Common-wealth by Institution; and
  5714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe former, a Common-wealth by Acquisition. And first, I shall speak of
  5715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Common-wealth by Institution.
  5716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XVIII. OF THE RIGHTS OF SOVERAIGNES BY INSTITUTION
  5720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Act Of Instituting A Common-wealth, What
  5725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Common-wealth is said to be Instituted, when a Multitude of men do
  5727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgree, and Covenant, Every One With Every One, that to whatsoever Man,
  5728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Assembly Of Men, shall be given by the major part, the Right
  5729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Present the Person of them all, (that is to say, to be their
  5730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative;) every one, as well he that Voted For It, as he that
  5731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVoted Against It, shall Authorise all the Actions and Judgements, of
  5732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Man, or Assembly of men, in the same manner, as if they were his
  5733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town, to the end, to live peaceably amongst themselves, and be protected
  5734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst other men.
  5735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Consequences To Such Institution, Are
  5740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI. The Subjects Cannot Change The Forme Of Government
  5745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom this Institution of a Common-wealth are derived all the Rights, and
  5750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFacultyes of him, or them, on whom the Soveraigne Power is conferred by
  5751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe consent of the People assembled.
  5752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFirst, because they Covenant, it is to be understood, they are not
  5754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobliged by former Covenant to any thing repugnant hereunto. And
  5755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsequently they that have already Instituted a Common-wealth, being
  5756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereby bound by Covenant, to own the Actions, and Judgements of one,
  5757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot lawfully make a new Covenant, amongst themselves, to be obedient
  5758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto any other, in any thing whatsoever, without his permission. And
  5759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore, they that are subjects to a Monarch, cannot without his leave
  5760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcast off Monarchy, and return to the confusion of a disunited Multitude;
  5761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor transferre their Person from him that beareth it, to another Man,
  5762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor other Assembly of men: for they are bound, every man to every man,
  5763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Own, and be reputed Author of all, that he that already is their
  5764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne, shall do, and judge fit to be done: so that any one man
  5765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdissenting, all the rest should break their Covenant made to that man,
  5766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is injustice: and they have also every man given the Soveraignty
  5767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto him that beareth their Person; and therefore if they depose him,
  5768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey take from him that which is his own, and so again it is injustice.
  5769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBesides, if he that attempteth to depose his Soveraign, be killed, or
  5770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunished by him for such attempt, he is author of his own punishment,
  5771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas being by the Institution, Author of all his Soveraign shall do: And
  5772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause it is injustice for a man to do any thing, for which he may be
  5773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunished by his own authority, he is also upon that title, unjust.
  5774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whereas some men have pretended for their disobedience to their
  5775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, a new Covenant, made, not with men, but with God; this also
  5776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis unjust: for there is no Covenant with God, but by mediation of some
  5777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbody that representeth Gods Person; which none doth but Gods Lieutenant,
  5778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho hath the Soveraignty under God. But this pretence of Covenant with
  5779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, is so evident a lye, even in the pretenders own consciences, that
  5780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is not onely an act of an unjust, but also of a vile, and unmanly
  5781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisposition.
  5782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2. Soveraigne Power Cannot Be Forfeited
  5787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, Because the Right of bearing the Person of them all, is given
  5789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto him they make Soveraigne, by Covenant onely of one to another, and
  5790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot of him to any of them; there can happen no breach of Covenant on the
  5791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart of the Soveraigne; and consequently none of his Subjects, by any
  5792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretence of forfeiture, can be freed from his Subjection. That he which
  5793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis made Soveraigne maketh no Covenant with his Subjects beforehand, is
  5794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest; because either he must make it with the whole multitude, as
  5795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone party to the Covenant; or he must make a severall Covenant with
  5796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery man. With the whole, as one party, it is impossible; because as
  5797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet they are not one Person: and if he make so many severall Covenants
  5798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas there be men, those Covenants after he hath the Soveraignty are voyd,
  5799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause what act soever can be pretended by any one of them for breach
  5800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof, is the act both of himselfe, and of all the rest, because done
  5801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Person, and by the Right of every one of them in particular.
  5802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBesides, if any one, or more of them, pretend a breach of the Covenant
  5803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade by the Soveraigne at his Institution; and others, or one other of
  5804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Subjects, or himselfe alone, pretend there was no such breach,
  5805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is in this case, no Judge to decide the controversie: it returns
  5806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore to the Sword again; and every man recovereth the right of
  5807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProtecting himselfe by his own strength, contrary to the designe they
  5808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad in the Institution. It is therefore in vain to grant Soveraignty by
  5809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tway of precedent Covenant. The opinion that any Monarch receiveth his
  5810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower by Covenant, that is to say on Condition, proceedeth from want
  5811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof understanding this easie truth, that Covenants being but words, and
  5812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbreath, have no force to oblige, contain, constrain, or protect any man,
  5813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut what it has from the publique Sword; that is, from the untyed hands
  5814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof that Man, or Assembly of men that hath the Soveraignty, and whose
  5815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions are avouched by them all, and performed by the strength of them
  5816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall, in him united. But when an Assembly of men is made Soveraigne; then
  5817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno man imagineth any such Covenant to have past in the Institution; for
  5818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno man is so dull as to say, for example, the People of Rome, made
  5819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Covenant with the Romans, to hold the Soveraignty on such or such
  5820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconditions; which not performed, the Romans might lawfully depose the
  5821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRoman People. That men see not the reason to be alike in a Monarchy, and
  5822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin a Popular Government, proceedeth from the ambition of some, that
  5823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare kinder to the government of an Assembly, whereof they may hope to
  5824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticipate, than of Monarchy, which they despair to enjoy.
  5825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t3. No Man Can Without Injustice Protest Against The
  5830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstitution Of The Soveraigne Declared By The Major Part. Thirdly,
  5832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause the major part hath by consenting voices declared a Soveraigne;
  5833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the that dissented must now consent with the rest; that is, be contented
  5834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto avow all the actions he shall do, or else justly be destroyed by the
  5835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trest. For if he voluntarily entered into the Congregation of them that
  5836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere assembled, he sufficiently declared thereby his will (and therefore
  5837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttacitely covenanted) to stand to what the major part should ordayne: and
  5838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore if he refuse to stand thereto, or make Protestation against
  5839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany of their Decrees, he does contrary to his Covenant, and therfore
  5840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunjustly. And whether he be of the Congregation, or not; and whether his
  5841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsent be asked, or not, he must either submit to their decrees, or
  5842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe left in the condition of warre he was in before; wherein he might
  5843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout injustice be destroyed by any man whatsoever.
  5844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t4. The Soveraigns Actions Cannot Be Justly Accused By The Subject
  5849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, because every Subject is by this Institution Author of all the
  5851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActions, and Judgements of the Soveraigne Instituted; it followes, that
  5852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever he doth, it can be no injury to any of his Subjects; nor
  5853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought he to be by any of them accused of Injustice. For he that doth any
  5854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing by authority from another, doth therein no injury to him by whose
  5855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority he acteth: But by this Institution of a Common-wealth, every
  5856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular man is Author of all the Soveraigne doth; and consequently
  5857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the that complaineth of injury from his Soveraigne, complaineth of that
  5858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof he himselfe is Author; and therefore ought not to accuse any man
  5859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut himselfe; no nor himselfe of injury; because to do injury to ones
  5860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tselfe, is impossible. It is true that they that have Soveraigne
  5861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower, may commit Iniquity; but not Injustice, or Injury in the proper
  5862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignification.
  5863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t5. What Soever The Soveraigne Doth, Is Unpunishable By The Subject
  5868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFiftly, and consequently to that which was sayd last, no man that hath
  5870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne power can justly be put to death, or otherwise in any manner
  5871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby his Subjects punished. For seeing every Subject is author of the
  5872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions of his Soveraigne; he punisheth another, for the actions
  5873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommitted by himselfe.
  5874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t6. The Soveraigne Is Judge Of What Is Necessary For The Peace
  5879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Defence Of His Subjects
  5881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because the End of this Institution, is the Peace and Defence of
  5883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem all; and whosoever has right to the End, has right to the Means;
  5884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit belongeth of Right, to whatsoever Man, or Assembly that hath the
  5885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty, to be Judge both of the meanes of Peace and Defence;
  5886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand also of the hindrances, and disturbances of the same; and to do
  5887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever he shall think necessary to be done, both beforehand, for the
  5888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreserving of Peace and Security, by prevention of discord at home and
  5889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHostility from abroad; and, when Peace and Security are lost, for the
  5890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trecovery of the same. And therefore,
  5891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Judge Of What Doctrines Are Fit To Be Taught Them
  5896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSixtly, it is annexed to the Soveraignty, to be Judge of what Opinions
  5898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Doctrines are averse, and what conducing to Peace; and consequently,
  5899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton what occasions, how farre, and what, men are to be trusted withall,
  5900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin speaking to Multitudes of people; and who shall examine the Doctrines
  5901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof all bookes before they be published. For the Actions of men proceed
  5902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom their Opinions; and in the wel governing of Opinions, consisteth
  5903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe well governing of mens Actions, in order to their Peace, and
  5904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConcord. And though in matter of Doctrine, nothing ought to be regarded
  5905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the Truth; yet this is not repugnant to regulating of the same by
  5906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace. For Doctrine Repugnant to Peace, can no more be True, than Peace
  5907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Concord can be against the Law of Nature. It is true, that in
  5908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Common-wealth, where by the negligence, or unskilfullnesse of
  5909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernours, and Teachers, false Doctrines are by time generally
  5910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceived; the contrary Truths may be generally offensive; Yet the most
  5911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsudden, and rough busling in of a new Truth, that can be, does never
  5912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbreake the Peace, but onely somtimes awake the Warre. For those men that
  5913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare so remissely governed, that they dare take up Armes, to defend, or
  5914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tintroduce an Opinion, are still in Warre; and their condition not Peace,
  5915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut only a Cessation of Armes for feare of one another; and they live
  5916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas it were, in the procincts of battaile continually. It belongeth
  5917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore to him that hath the Soveraign Power, to be Judge, or
  5918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstitute all Judges of Opinions and Doctrines, as a thing necessary to
  5919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace, thereby to prevent Discord and Civill Warre.
  5920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t7. The Right Of Making Rules, Whereby The Subject May
  5925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvery Man Know What Is So His Owne, As No Other Subject
  5927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCan Without Injustice Take It From Him
  5929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeventhly, is annexed to the Soveraigntie, the whole power of
  5931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprescribing the Rules, whereby every man may know, what Goods he may
  5932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenjoy and what Actions he may doe, without being molested by any of
  5933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this fellow Subjects: And this is it men Call Propriety. For before
  5934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstitution of Soveraign Power (as hath already been shewn) all men had
  5935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tright to all things; which necessarily causeth Warre: and therefore this
  5936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProprietie, being necessary to Peace, and depending on Soveraign Power,
  5937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the Act of the Power, in order to the publique peace. These Rules of
  5938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPropriety (or Meum and Tuum) and of Good, Evill, Lawfull and Unlawfull
  5939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the actions of subjects, are the Civill Lawes, that is to say, the
  5940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawes of each Commonwealth in particular; though the name of Civill Law
  5941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe now restrained to the antient Civill Lawes of the City of Rome; which
  5942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing the head of a great part of the World, her Lawes at that time were
  5943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin these parts the Civill Law.
  5944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t8. To Him Also Belongeth The Right Of All Judicature
  5949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Decision Of Controversies:
  5951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEightly, is annexed to the Soveraigntie, the Right of Judicature; that
  5953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, of hearing and deciding all Controversies, which may arise
  5954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning Law, either Civill, or naturall, or concerning Fact. For
  5955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout the decision of Controversies, there is no protection of one
  5956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubject, against the injuries of another; the Lawes concerning Meum and
  5957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTuum are in vaine; and to every man remaineth, from the naturall and
  5958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessary appetite of his own conservation, the right of protecting
  5959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe by his private strength, which is the condition of Warre; and
  5960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary to the end for which every Common-wealth is instituted.
  5961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t9. And Of Making War, And Peace, As He Shall Think Best:
  5966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNinthly, is annexed to the Soveraignty, the Right of making Warre, and
  5968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace with other Nations, and Common-wealths; that is to say, of
  5969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudging when it is for the publique good, and how great forces are to
  5970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe assembled, armed, and payd for that end; and to levy mony upon the
  5971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects, to defray the expenses thereof. For the Power by which the
  5972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople are to be defended, consisteth in their Armies; and the strength
  5973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof an Army, in the union of their strength under one Command; which
  5974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommand the Soveraign Instituted, therefore hath; because the command
  5975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Militia, without other Institution, maketh him that hath it
  5976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign. And therefore whosoever is made Generall of an Army, he that
  5977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath the Soveraign Power is alwayes Generallissimo.
  5978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t10. And Of Choosing All Counsellours, And Ministers,
  5983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBoth Of Peace, And Warre:
  5985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTenthly, is annexed to the Soveraignty, the choosing of all
  5987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCouncellours, Ministers, Magistrates, and Officers, both in peace, and
  5988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWar. For seeing the Soveraign is charged with the End, which is the
  5989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommon Peace and Defence; he is understood to have Power to use such
  5990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMeans, as he shall think most fit for his discharge.
  5991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t11. And Of Rewarding, And Punishing, And That (Where No
  5996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFormer Law hath Determined The Measure Of It) Arbitrary:
  5998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  5999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEleventhly, to the Soveraign is committed the Power of Rewarding
  6000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith riches, or honour; and of Punishing with corporall, or pecuniary
  6001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunishment, or with ignominy every Subject according to the Lawe he hath
  6002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformerly made; or if there be no Law made, according as he shall judge
  6003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost to conduce to the encouraging of men to serve the Common-wealth, or
  6004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeterring of them from doing dis-service to the same.
  6005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t12. And Of Honour And Order
  6010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, considering what values men are naturally apt to set upon
  6012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves; what respect they look for from others; and how little they
  6013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvalue other men; from whence continually arise amongst them, Emulation,
  6014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tQuarrells, Factions, and at last Warre, to the destroying of one
  6015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, and diminution of their strength against a Common Enemy; It
  6016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis necessary that there be Lawes of Honour, and a publique rate of the
  6017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworth of such men as have deserved, or are able to deserve well of the
  6018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; and that there be force in the hands of some or other, to
  6019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tput those Lawes in execution. But it hath already been shown, that not
  6020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely the whole Militia, or forces of the Common-wealth; but also the
  6021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudicature of all Controversies, is annexed to the Soveraignty. To the
  6022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign therefore it belongeth also to give titles of Honour; and to
  6023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappoint what Order of place, and dignity, each man shall hold; and what
  6024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignes of respect, in publique or private meetings, they shall give to
  6025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone another.
  6026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese Rights Are Indivisible
  6031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese are the Rights, which make the Essence of Soveraignty; and which
  6033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare the markes, whereby a man may discern in what Man, or Assembly
  6034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men, the Soveraign Power is placed, and resideth. For these are
  6035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tincommunicable, and inseparable. The Power to coyn Mony; to dispose of
  6036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe estate and persons of Infant heires; to have praeemption in
  6037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMarkets; and all other Statute Praerogatives, may be transferred by the
  6038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign; and yet the Power to protect his Subject be retained. But if
  6039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the transferre the Militia, he retains the Judicature in vain, for want
  6040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof execution of the Lawes; Or if he grant away the Power of raising
  6041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMony; the Militia is in vain: or if he give away the government of
  6042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoctrines, men will be frighted into rebellion with the feare of
  6043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirits. And so if we consider any one of the said Rights, we shall
  6044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresently see, that the holding of all the rest, will produce no
  6045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teffect, in the conservation of Peace and Justice, the end for which all
  6046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths are Instituted. And this division is it, whereof it is
  6047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid, "A kingdome divided in it selfe cannot stand:" For unlesse this
  6048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivision precede, division into opposite Armies can never happen. If
  6049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere had not first been an opinion received of the greatest part of
  6050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEngland, that these Powers were divided between the King, and the Lords,
  6051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the House of Commons, the people had never been divided, and
  6052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfallen into this Civill Warre; first between those that disagreed
  6053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Politiques; and after between the Dissenters about the liberty of
  6054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion; which have so instructed men in this point of Soveraign Right,
  6055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat there be few now (in England,) that do not see, that these Rights
  6056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare inseparable, and will be so generally acknowledged, at the next
  6057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treturn of Peace; and so continue, till their miseries are forgotten; and
  6058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno longer, except the vulgar be better taught than they have hetherto
  6059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen.
  6060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Can By No Grant Passe Away Without Direct
  6065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRenouncing Of The Soveraign Power
  6067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because they are essentiall and inseparable Rights, it follows
  6069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessarily, that in whatsoever, words any of them seem to be granted
  6070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taway, yet if the Soveraign Power it selfe be not in direct termes
  6071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trenounced, and the name of Soveraign no more given by the Grantees to
  6072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim that Grants them, the Grant is voyd: for when he has granted all he
  6073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan, if we grant back the Soveraignty, all is restored, as inseparably
  6074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tannexed thereunto.
  6075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Power And Honour Of Subjects Vanisheth In The Presence
  6080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Power Soveraign
  6082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis great Authority being indivisible, and inseparably annexed to the
  6084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty, there is little ground for the opinion of them, that say of
  6085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Kings, though they be Singulis Majores, of greater Power than
  6086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one of their Subjects, yet they be Universis Minores, of lesse
  6087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower than them all together. For if by All Together, they mean not
  6088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe collective body as one person, then All Together, and Every One,
  6089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifie the same; and the speech is absurd. But if by All Together,
  6090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey understand them as one Person (which person the Soveraign bears,)
  6091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen the power of all together, is the same with the Soveraigns power;
  6092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand so again the speech is absurd; which absurdity they see well enough,
  6093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen the Soveraignty is in an Assembly of the people; but in a Monarch
  6094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey see it not; and yet the power of Soveraignty is the same in
  6095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhomsoever it be placed.
  6096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as the Power, so also the Honour of the Soveraign, ought to be
  6098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreater, than that of any, or all the Subjects. For in the Soveraignty
  6099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the fountain of Honour. The dignities of Lord, Earle, Duke, and
  6100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrince are his Creatures. As in the presence of the Master, the Servants
  6101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare equall, and without any honour at all; So are the Subjects, in the
  6102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresence of the Soveraign. And though they shine some more, some lesse,
  6103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen they are out of his sight; yet in his presence, they shine no more
  6104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan the Starres in presence of the Sun.
  6105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne Power Not Hurtfull As The Want Of It,
  6110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd The Hurt Proceeds For The Greatest Part From Not
  6112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubmitting Readily, To A Lesse
  6114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut a man may here object, that the Condition of Subjects is very
  6116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmiserable; as being obnoxious to the lusts, and other irregular passions
  6117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof him, or them that have so unlimited a Power in their hands. And
  6118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommonly they that live under a Monarch, think it the fault of Monarchy;
  6119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand they that live under the government of Democracy, or other
  6120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Assembly, attribute all the inconvenience to that forme of
  6121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; whereas the Power in all formes, if they be perfect
  6122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenough to protect them, is the same; not considering that the estate
  6123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Man can never be without some incommodity or other; and that the
  6124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreatest, that in any forme of Government can possibly happen to the
  6125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople in generall, is scarce sensible, in respect of the miseries, and
  6126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thorrible calamities, that accompany a Civill Warre; or that dissolute
  6127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition of masterlesse men, without subjection to Lawes, and a
  6128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcoercive Power to tye their hands from rapine, and revenge: nor
  6129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsidering that the greatest pressure of Soveraign Governours,
  6130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceedeth not from any delight, or profit they can expect in the
  6131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdammage, or weakening of their subjects, in whose vigor, consisteth
  6132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own selves, that unwillingly contributing to their own defence,
  6133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake it necessary for their Governours to draw from them what they can
  6134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin time of Peace, that they may have means on any emergent occasion, or
  6135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsudden need, to resist, or take advantage on their Enemies. For all men
  6136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare by nature provided of notable multiplying glasses, (that is their
  6137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions and Self-love,) through which, every little payment appeareth a
  6138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat grievance; but are destitute of those prospective glasses, (namely
  6139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMorall and Civill Science,) to see a farre off the miseries that hang
  6140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover them, and cannot without such payments be avoyded.
  6141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XIX. OF THE SEVERALL KINDS OF COMMON-WEALTH BY INSTITUTION,
  6145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAND OF SUCCESSION TO THE SOVERAIGNE POWER
  6147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Different Formes Of Common-wealths But Three
  6152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe difference of Common-wealths, consisteth in the difference of the
  6154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, or the Person representative of all and every one of the
  6155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMultitude. And because the Soveraignty is either in one Man, or in an
  6156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly of more than one; and into that Assembly either Every man hath
  6157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tright to enter, or not every one, but Certain men distinguished from the
  6158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trest; it is manifest, there can be but Three kinds of Common-wealth. For
  6159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Representative must needs be One man, or More: and if more, then it
  6160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the Assembly of All, or but of a Part. When the Representative is One
  6161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, then is the Common-wealth a MONARCHY: when an Assembly of All that
  6162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill come together, then it is a DEMOCRACY, or Popular Common-wealth:
  6163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen an Assembly of a Part onely, then it is called an ARISTOCRACY.
  6164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOther kind of Common-wealth there can be none: for either One, or
  6165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMore, or All must have the Soveraign Power (which I have shewn to be
  6166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tindivisible) entire.
  6167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTyranny And Oligarchy, But Different Names Of Monarchy, And Aristocracy
  6172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere be other names of Government, in the Histories, and books of
  6174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPolicy; as Tyranny, and Oligarchy: But they are not the names of other
  6175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFormes of Government, but of the same Formes misliked. For they that
  6176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare discontented under Monarchy, call it Tyranny; and they that are
  6177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdispleased with Aristocracy, called it Oligarchy: so also, they which
  6178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfind themselves grieved under a Democracy, call it Anarchy, (which
  6179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifies want of Government;) and yet I think no man believes, that
  6180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twant of Government, is any new kind of Government: nor by the same
  6181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treason ought they to believe, that the Government is of one kind, when
  6182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey like it, and another, when they mislike it, or are oppressed by the
  6183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernours.
  6184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubordinate Representatives Dangerous
  6189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is manifest, that men who are in absolute liberty, may, if they
  6191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplease, give Authority to One Man, to represent them every one; as
  6192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twell as give such Authority to any Assembly of men whatsoever; and
  6193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently may subject themselves, if they think good, to a Monarch,
  6194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas absolutely, as to any other Representative. Therefore, where there is
  6195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready erected a Soveraign Power, there can be no other Representative
  6196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the same people, but onely to certain particular ends, by the
  6197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign limited. For that were to erect two Soveraigns; and every
  6198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman to have his person represented by two Actors, that by opposing one
  6199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, must needs divide that Power, which (if men will live in Peace)
  6200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis indivisible, and thereby reduce the Multitude into the condition of
  6201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWarre, contrary to the end for which all Soveraignty is instituted. And
  6202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore as it is absurd, to think that a Soveraign Assembly, inviting
  6203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe People of their Dominion, to send up their Deputies, with power
  6204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto make known their Advise, or Desires, should therefore hold such
  6205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeputies, rather than themselves, for the absolute Representative of
  6206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people: so it is absurd also, to think the same in a Monarchy. And
  6207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI know not how this so manifest a truth, should of late be so little
  6208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserved; that in a Monarchy, he that had the Soveraignty from a descent
  6209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof 600 years, was alone called Soveraign, had the title of Majesty from
  6210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one of his Subjects, and was unquestionably taken by them
  6211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor their King; was notwithstanding never considered as their
  6212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative; that name without contradiction passing for the title
  6213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof those men, which at his command were sent up by the people to carry
  6214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Petitions, and give him (if he permitted it) their advise. Which
  6215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay serve as an admonition, for those that are the true, and absolute
  6216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative of a People, to instruct men in the nature of that
  6217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOffice, and to take heed how they admit of any other generall
  6218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentation upon any occasion whatsoever, if they mean to discharge
  6219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe truth committed to them.
  6220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tComparison Of Monarchy, With Soveraign Assemblyes
  6225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe difference between these three kindes of Common-wealth, consisteth
  6227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot in the difference of Power; but in the difference of Convenience, or
  6228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAptitude to produce the Peace, and Security of the people; for which end
  6229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were instituted. And to compare Monarchy with the other two, we may
  6230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserve; First, that whosoever beareth the Person of the people, or
  6231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis one of that Assembly that bears it, beareth also his own naturall
  6232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson. And though he be carefull in his politique Person to procure
  6233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe common interest; yet he is more, or no lesse carefull to procure the
  6234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate good of himselfe, his family, kindred and friends; and for the
  6235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost part, if the publique interest chance to crosse the private, he
  6236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreferrs the private: for the Passions of men, are commonly more potent
  6237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan their Reason. From whence it follows, that where the publique and
  6238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate interest are most closely united, there is the publique most
  6239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadvanced. Now in Monarchy, the private interest is the same with the
  6240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublique. The riches, power, and honour of a Monarch arise onely from
  6241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe riches, strength and reputation of his Subjects. For no King can
  6242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe rich, nor glorious, nor secure; whose Subjects are either poore, or
  6243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontemptible, or too weak through want, or dissention, to maintain a
  6244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twar against their enemies: Whereas in a Democracy, or Aristocracy, the
  6245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublique prosperity conferres not so much to the private fortune of one
  6246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is corrupt, or ambitious, as doth many times a perfidious advice, a
  6247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttreacherous action, or a Civill warre.
  6248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, that a Monarch receiveth counsell of whom, when, and where he
  6250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpleaseth; and consequently may heare the opinion of men versed in the
  6251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmatter about which he deliberates, of what rank or quality soever, and
  6252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas long before the time of action, and with as much secrecy, as he will.
  6253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut when a Soveraigne Assembly has need of Counsell, none are admitted
  6254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut such as have a Right thereto from the beginning; which for the
  6255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost part are of those who have beene versed more in the acquisition
  6256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Wealth than of Knowledge; and are to give their advice in long
  6257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscourses, which may, and do commonly excite men to action, but
  6258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot governe them in it. For the Understanding is by the flame of the
  6259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions, never enlightned, but dazled: Nor is there any place, or time,
  6260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twherein an Assemblie can receive Counsell with secrecie, because of
  6261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir owne Multitude.
  6262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, that the Resolutions of a Monarch, are subject to no other
  6264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInconstancy, than that of Humane Nature; but in Assemblies, besides that
  6265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Nature, there ariseth an Inconstancy from the Number. For the absence
  6266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a few, that would have the Resolution once taken, continue firme,
  6267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which may happen by security, negligence, or private impediments,) or
  6268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe diligent appearance of a few of the contrary opinion, undoes to day,
  6269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall that was concluded yesterday.
  6270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, that a Monarch cannot disagree with himselfe, out of envy, or
  6272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterest; but an Assembly may; and that to such a height, as may produce
  6273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Civill Warre.
  6274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFifthly, that in Monarchy there is this inconvenience; that any Subject,
  6276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the power of one man, for the enriching of a favourite or flatterer,
  6277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay be deprived of all he possesseth; which I confesse is a great and
  6278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinevitable inconvenience. But the same may as well happen, where the
  6279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne Power is in an Assembly: for their power is the same; and
  6280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are as subject to evill Counsell, and to be seduced by Orators, as
  6281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Monarch by Flatterers; and becoming one an others Flatterers, serve
  6282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone anothers Covetousnesse and Ambition by turnes. And whereas the
  6283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFavorites of an Assembly, are many; and the Kindred much more numerous,
  6284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan of any Monarch. Besides, there is no Favourite of a Monarch, which
  6285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot as well succour his friends, as hurt his enemies: But Orators,
  6286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, Favourites of Soveraigne Assemblies, though they have
  6287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat power to hurt, have little to save. For to accuse, requires lesse
  6288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEloquence (such is mans Nature) than to excuse; and condemnation, than
  6289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsolution more resembles Justice.
  6290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSixtly, that it is an inconvenience in Monarchie, that the Soveraigntie
  6292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay descend upon an Infant, or one that cannot discerne between Good and
  6293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvill: and consisteth in this, that the use of his Power, must be in the
  6294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thand of another Man, or of some Assembly of men, which are to governe by
  6295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this right, and in his name; as Curators, and Protectors of his Person,
  6296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Authority. But to say there is inconvenience, in putting the use of
  6297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign Power, into the hand of a Man, or an Assembly of men; is
  6298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say that all Government is more Inconvenient, than Confusion, and
  6299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Warre. And therefore all the danger that can be pretended, must
  6300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tarise from the Contention of those, that for an office of so great
  6301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thonour, and profit, may become Competitors. To make it appear, that
  6302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis inconvenience, proceedeth not from that forme of Government we call
  6303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarchy, we are to consider, that the precedent Monarch, hath appointed
  6304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho shall have the Tuition of his Infant Successor, either expressely
  6305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Testament, or tacitly, by not controlling the Custome in that
  6306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcase received: And then such inconvenience (if it happen) is to be
  6307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tattributed, not to the Monarchy, but to the Ambition, and Injustice of
  6308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Subjects; which in all kinds of Government, where the people are
  6309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot well instructed in their Duty, and the Rights of Soveraignty, is
  6310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same. Or else the precedent Monarch, hath not at all taken order for
  6311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch Tuition; And then the Law of Nature hath provided this sufficient
  6312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trule, That the Tuition shall be in him, that hath by Nature most
  6313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterest in the preservation of the Authority of the Infant, and to whom
  6314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleast benefit can accrue by his death, or diminution. For seeing every
  6315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman by nature seeketh his own benefit, and promotion; to put an Infant
  6316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto the power of those, that can promote themselves by his destruction,
  6317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor dammage, is not Tuition, but Trechery. So that sufficient provision
  6318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing taken, against all just quarrell, about the Government under a
  6319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChild, if any contention arise to the disturbance of the publique Peace,
  6320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is not to be attributed to the forme of Monarchy, but to the ambition
  6321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Subjects, and ignorance of their Duty. On the other side, there is
  6322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno great Common-wealth, the Soveraignty whereof is in a great Assembly,
  6323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is not, as to consultations of Peace, and Warre, and making of
  6324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes, in the same condition, as if the Government were in a Child. For
  6325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas a Child wants the judgement to dissent from counsell given him, and
  6326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis thereby necessitated to take the advise of them, or him, to whom he
  6327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis committed: So an Assembly wanteth the liberty, to dissent from the
  6328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcounsell of the major part, be it good, or bad. And as a Child has need
  6329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Tutor, or Protector, to preserve his Person, and Authority: So also
  6330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(in great Common-wealths,) the Soveraign Assembly, in all great dangers
  6331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand troubles, have need of Custodes Libertatis; that is of Dictators, or
  6332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProtectors of their Authoritie; which are as much as Temporary Monarchs;
  6333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto whom for a time, they may commit the entire exercise of their Power;
  6334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand have (at the end of that time) been oftner deprived thereof, than
  6335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInfant Kings, by their Protectors, Regents, or any other Tutors.
  6336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThough the Kinds of Soveraigntie be, as I have now shewn, but three;
  6338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, Monarchie, where one Man has it; or Democracie, where
  6339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe generall Assembly of Subjects hath it; or Aristocracie, where it is
  6340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin an Assembly of certain persons nominated, or otherwise distinguished
  6341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the rest: Yet he that shall consider the particular Common-wealthes
  6342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat have been, and are in the world, will not perhaps easily reduce
  6343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem to three, and may thereby be inclined to think there be other
  6344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFormes, arising from these mingled together. As for example, Elective
  6345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdomes; where Kings have the Soveraigne Power put into their hands
  6346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor a time; of Kingdomes, wherein the King hath a power limited: which
  6347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernments, are nevertheless by most Writers called Monarchie. Likewise
  6348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif a Popular, or Aristocraticall Common-wealth, subdue an Enemies
  6349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCountrie, and govern the same, by a President, Procurator, or
  6350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Magistrate; this may seeme perhaps at first sight, to be a
  6351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDemocraticall, or Aristocraticall Government. But it is not so. For
  6352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tElective Kings, are not Soveraignes, but Ministers of the Soveraigne;
  6353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor limited Kings Soveraignes, but Ministers of them that have the
  6354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne Power: nor are those Provinces which are in subjection to a
  6355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDemocracie, or Aristocracie of another Common-wealth, Democratically, or
  6356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAristocratically governed, but Monarchically.
  6357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first, concerning an Elective King, whose power is limited to
  6359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this life, as it is in many places of Christendome at this day; or to
  6360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcertaine Yeares or Moneths, as the Dictators power amongst the Romans;
  6361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf he have Right to appoint his Successor, he is no more Elective but
  6362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHereditary. But if he have no Power to elect his Successor, then there
  6363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis some other Man, or Assembly known, which after his decease may elect
  6364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta new, or else the Common-wealth dieth, and dissolveth with him, and
  6365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treturneth to the condition of Warre. If it be known who have the power
  6366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto give the Soveraigntie after his death, it is known also that the
  6367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigntie was in them before: For none have right to give that which
  6368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey have not right to possesse, and keep to themselves, if they think
  6369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood. But if there be none that can give the Soveraigntie, after the
  6370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdecease of him that was first elected; then has he power, nay he is
  6371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobliged by the Law of Nature, to provide, by establishing his Successor,
  6372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto keep those that had trusted him with the Government, from relapsing
  6373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto the miserable condition of Civill warre. And consequently he was,
  6374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen elected, a Soveraign absolute.
  6375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, that King whose power is limited, is not superiour to him, or
  6377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem that have the power to limit it; and he that is not superiour, is
  6378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot supreme; that is to say not Soveraign. The Soveraignty therefore
  6379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas alwaies in that Assembly which had the Right to Limit him; and
  6380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby consequence the government not Monarchy, but either Democracy, or
  6381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAristocracy; as of old time in Sparta; where the Kings had a priviledge
  6382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto lead their Armies; but the Soveraignty was in the Ephori.
  6383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, whereas heretofore the Roman People, governed the land of Judea
  6385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(for example) by a President; yet was not Judea therefore a Democracy;
  6386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause they were not governed by any Assembly, into which, any of
  6387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, had right to enter; nor by an Aristocracy; because they were
  6388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot governed by any Assembly, into which, any man could enter by their
  6389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tElection: but they were governed by one Person, which though as to the
  6390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople of Rome was an Assembly of the people, or Democracy; yet as to
  6391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people of Judea, which had no right at all of participating in the
  6392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgovernment, was a Monarch. For though where the people are governed
  6393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby an Assembly, chosen by themselves out of their own number, the
  6394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgovernment is called a Democracy, or Aristocracy; yet when they are
  6395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgoverned by an Assembly, not of their own choosing, 'tis a Monarchy; not
  6396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof One man, over another man; but of one people, over another people.
  6397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Right Of Succession
  6402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf all these Formes of Government, the matter being mortall, so that not
  6404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely Monarchs, but also whole Assemblies dy, it is necessary for the
  6405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconservation of the peace of men, that as there was order taken for
  6406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Artificiall Man, so there be order also taken, for an Artificiall
  6407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternity of life; without which, men that are governed by an Assembly,
  6408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould return into the condition of Warre in every age; and they
  6409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat are governed by One man, as soon as their Governour dyeth. This
  6410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArtificiall Eternity, is that which men call the Right of Succession.
  6411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere is no perfect forme of Government, where the disposing of the
  6413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuccession is not in the present Soveraign. For if it be in any other
  6414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular Man, or private Assembly, it is in a person subject, and may
  6415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe assumed by the Soveraign at his pleasure; and consequently the Right
  6416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis in himselfe. And if it be in no particular man, but left to a new
  6417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchoyce; then is the Common-wealth dissolved; and the Right is in him
  6418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat can get it; contrary to the intention of them that did institute
  6419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Common-wealth, for their perpetuall, and not temporary security.
  6420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn a Democracy, the whole Assembly cannot faile, unlesse the Multitude
  6422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat are to be governed faile. And therefore questions of the right of
  6423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuccession, have in that forme of Government no place at all.
  6424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn an Aristocracy, when any of the Assembly dyeth, the election of
  6426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother into his room belongeth to the Assembly, as the Soveraign, to
  6427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom belongeth the choosing of all Counsellours, and Officers. For that
  6428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Representative doth, as Actor, every one of the Subjects doth,
  6429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas Author. And though the Soveraign assembly, may give Power to others,
  6430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto elect new men, for supply of their Court; yet it is still by their
  6431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority, that the Election is made; and by the same it may (when the
  6432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublique shall require it) be recalled.
  6433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Present Monarch Hath Right To Dispose Of The Succession The greatest
  6435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifficultie about the right of Succession, is in Monarchy: And the
  6436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifficulty ariseth from this, that at first sight, it is not manifest
  6437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho is to appoint the Successor; nor many times, who it is whom he
  6438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath appointed. For in both these cases, there is required a more exact
  6439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tratiocination, than every man is accustomed to use. As to the question,
  6440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho shall appoint the Successor, of a Monarch that hath the Soveraign
  6441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority; that is to say, (for Elective Kings and Princes have not the
  6442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power in propriety, but in use only,) we are to consider, that
  6443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither he that is in possession, has right to dispose of the Succession,
  6444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor else that right is again in the dissolved Multitude. For the death
