  6445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof him that hath the Soveraign power in propriety, leaves the Multitude
  6446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout any Soveraign at all; that is, without any Representative in
  6447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom they should be united, and be capable of doing any one action at
  6448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall: And therefore they are incapable of Election of any new Monarch;
  6449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery man having equall right to submit himselfe to such as he thinks
  6450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbest able to protect him, or if he can, protect himselfe by his owne
  6451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsword; which is a returne to Confusion, and to the condition of a War of
  6452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery man against every man, contrary to the end for which Monarchy had
  6453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tits first Institution. Therfore it is manifest, that by the Institution
  6454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Monarchy, the disposing of the Successor, is alwaies left to the
  6455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgment and Will of the present Possessor.
  6456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd for the question (which may arise sometimes) who it is that the
  6458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarch in possession, hath designed to the succession and inheritance
  6459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his power; it is determined by his expresse Words, and Testament; or
  6460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby other tacite signes sufficient.
  6461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuccession Passeth By Expresse Words;
  6466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy expresse Words, or Testament, when it is declared by him in his life
  6468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, viva voce, or by Writing; as the first Emperours of Rome declared
  6469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho should be their Heires. For the word Heire does not of it selfe
  6470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timply the Children, or nearest Kindred of a man; but whomsoever a man
  6471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall any way declare, he would have to succeed him in his Estate.
  6472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf therefore a Monarch declare expresly, that such a man shall be his
  6473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeire, either by Word or Writing, then is that man immediately after the
  6474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdecease of his Predecessor, Invested in the right of being Monarch.
  6475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOr, By Not Controlling A Custome;
  6480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut where Testament, and expresse Words are wanting, other naturall
  6482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignes of the Will are to be followed: whereof the one is Custome. And
  6483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore where the Custome is, that the next of Kindred absolutely
  6484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsucceedeth, there also the next of Kindred hath right to the Succession;
  6485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor that, if the will of him that was in posession had been otherwise,
  6486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the might easily have declared the same in his life time. And likewise
  6487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere the Custome is, that the next of the Male Kindred succeedeth,
  6488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere also the right of Succession is in the next of the Kindred Male,
  6489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the same reason. And so it is if the Custome were to advance the
  6490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFemale. For whatsoever Custome a man may by a word controule, and does
  6491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot, it is a naturall signe he would have that Custome stand.
  6492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOr, By Presumption Of Naturall Affection
  6497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut where neither Custome, nor Testament hath preceded, there it is
  6499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be understood, First, that a Monarchs will is, that the government
  6500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tremain Monarchicall; because he hath approved that government in
  6501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe. Secondly, that a Child of his own, Male, or Female, be
  6502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreferred before any other; because men are presumed to be more enclined
  6503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby nature, to advance their own children, than the children of other
  6504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen; and of their own, rather a Male than a Female; because men, are
  6505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturally fitter than women, for actions of labour and danger. Thirdly,
  6506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere his own Issue faileth, rather a Brother than a stranger; and so
  6507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstill the neerer in bloud, rather than the more remote, because it is
  6508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talwayes presumed that the neerer of kin, is the neerer in affection; and
  6509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t'tis evident that a man receives alwayes, by reflexion, the most honour
  6510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the greatnesse of his neerest kindred.
  6511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Dispose Of The Succession, Though To A King Of Another Nation,
  6516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNot Unlawfull
  6518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut if it be lawfull for a Monarch to dispose of the Succession by words
  6520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Contract, or Testament, men may perhaps object a great inconvenience:
  6521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor he may sell, or give his Right of governing to a stranger; which,
  6522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause strangers (that is, men not used to live under the same
  6523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgovernment, not speaking the same language) do commonly undervalue one
  6524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, may turn to the oppression of his Subjects; which is indeed
  6525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta great inconvenience; but it proceedeth not necessarily from the
  6526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubjection to a strangers government, but from the unskilfulnesse of the
  6527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernours, ignorant of the true rules of Politiques. And therefore
  6528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Romans when they had subdued many Nations, to make their Government
  6529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdigestible, were wont to take away that grievance, as much as they
  6530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought necessary, by giving sometimes to whole Nations, and sometimes
  6531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Principall men of every Nation they conquered, not onely the
  6532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivileges, but also the Name of Romans; and took many of them into the
  6533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSenate, and Offices of charge, even in the Roman City. And this was it
  6534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour most wise King, King James, aymed at, in endeavouring the Union of
  6535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this two Realms of England and Scotland. Which if he could have obtained,
  6536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad in all likelihood prevented the Civill warres, which make both those
  6537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdomes at this present, miserable. It is not therefore any injury to
  6538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people, for a Monarch to dispose of the Succession by Will; though
  6539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the fault of many Princes, it hath been sometimes found inconvenient.
  6540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf the lawfulnesse of it, this also is an argument, that whatsoever
  6541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinconvenience can arrive by giving a Kingdome to a stranger, may arrive
  6542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso by so marrying with strangers, as the Right of Succession may
  6543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdescend upon them: yet this by all men is accounted lawfull.
  6544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XX. OF DOMINION PATERNALL AND DESPOTICALL
  6548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Common-wealth by Acquisition, is that, where the Soveraign Power is
  6551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacquired by Force; And it is acquired by force, when men singly, or
  6552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany together by plurality of voyces, for fear of death, or bonds, do
  6553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthorise all the actions of that Man, or Assembly, that hath their
  6554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlives and liberty in his Power.
  6555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWherein Different From A Common-wealth By Institution
  6560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd this kind of Dominion, or Soveraignty, differeth from Soveraignty by
  6562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstitution, onely in this, That men who choose their Soveraign, do it
  6563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor fear of one another, and not of him whom they Institute: But in this
  6564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcase, they subject themselves, to him they are afraid of. In both cases
  6565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey do it for fear: which is to be noted by them, that hold all such
  6566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants, as proceed from fear of death, or violence, voyd: which if
  6567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit were true, no man, in any kind of Common-wealth, could be obliged
  6568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Obedience. It is true, that in a Common-wealth once Instituted, or
  6569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacquired, Promises proceeding from fear of death, or violence, are no
  6570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenants, nor obliging, when the thing promised is contrary to the
  6571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes; But the reason is not, because it was made upon fear, but because
  6572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the that promiseth, hath no right in the thing promised. Also, when he
  6573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay lawfully performe, and doth not, it is not the Invalidity of
  6574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Covenant, that absolveth him, but the Sentence of the Soveraign.
  6575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOtherwise, whensoever a man lawfully promiseth, he unlawfully breaketh:
  6576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut when the Soveraign, who is the Actor, acquitteth him, then he is
  6577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacquitted by him that exorted the promise, as by the Author of such
  6578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsolution.
  6579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Rights Of Soveraignty The Same In Both
  6584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the Rights, and Consequences of Soveraignty, are the same in both.
  6586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHis Power cannot, without his consent, be Transferred to another: He
  6587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot Forfeit it: He cannot be Accused by any of his Subjects, of
  6588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInjury: He cannot be Punished by them: He is Judge of what is necessary
  6589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Peace; and Judge of Doctrines: He is Sole Legislator; and Supreme
  6590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudge of Controversies; and of the Times, and Occasions of Warre,
  6591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Peace: to him it belongeth to choose Magistrates, Counsellours,
  6592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommanders, and all other Officers, and Ministers; and to determine of
  6593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRewards, and punishments, Honour, and Order. The reasons whereof, are
  6594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same which are alledged in the precedent Chapter, for the same
  6595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRights, and Consequences of Soveraignty by Institution.
  6596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominion Paternall How Attained Not By Generation, But By Contract
  6601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominion is acquired two wayes; By Generation, and by Conquest. The
  6603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tright of Dominion by Generation, is that, which the Parent hath over
  6604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Children; and is called PATERNALL. And is not so derived from the
  6605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGeneration, as if therefore the Parent had Dominion over his Child
  6606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause he begat him; but from the Childs Consent, either expresse, or
  6607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby other sufficient arguments declared. For as to the Generation, God
  6608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath ordained to man a helper; and there be alwayes two that are equally
  6609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tParents: the Dominion therefore over the Child, should belong equally to
  6610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth; and he be equally subject to both, which is impossible; for no man
  6611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan obey two Masters. And whereas some have attributed the Dominion to
  6612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Man onely, as being of the more excellent Sex; they misreckon in it.
  6613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor there is not always that difference of strength or prudence between
  6614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe man and the woman, as that the right can be determined without War.
  6615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Common-wealths, this controversie is decided by the Civill Law: and
  6616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the most part, (but not alwayes) the sentence is in favour of the
  6617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFather; because for the most part Common-wealths have been erected by
  6618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Fathers, not by the Mothers of families. But the question lyeth
  6619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnow in the state of meer Nature; where there are supposed no lawes
  6620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Matrimony; no lawes for the Education of Children; but the Law of
  6621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature, and the naturall inclination of the Sexes, one to another, and
  6622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto their children. In this condition of meer Nature, either the Parents
  6623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetween themselves dispose of the dominion over the Child by Contract;
  6624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor do not dispose thereof at all. If they dispose thereof, the right
  6625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpasseth according to the Contract. We find in History that the Amazons
  6626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContracted with the Men of the neighbouring Countries, to whom they had
  6627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trecourse for issue, that the issue Male should be sent back, but the
  6628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFemale remain with themselves: so that the dominion of the Females was
  6629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Mother.
  6630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOr Education;
  6635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf there be no Contract, the Dominion is in the Mother. For in the
  6637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition of Meer Nature, where there are no Matrimoniall lawes, it
  6638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot be known who is the Father, unlesse it be declared by the Mother:
  6639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore the right of Dominion over the Child dependeth on her
  6640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill, and is consequently hers. Again, seeing the Infant is first in the
  6641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower of the Mother; so as she may either nourish, or expose it, if she
  6642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnourish it, it oweth its life to the Mother; and is therefore obliged to
  6643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobey her, rather than any other; and by consequence the Dominion over
  6644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is hers. But if she expose it, and another find, and nourish it, the
  6645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominion is in him that nourisheth it. For it ought to obey him by whom
  6646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is preserved; because preservation of life being the end, for which
  6647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone man becomes subject to another, every man is supposed to promise
  6648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobedience, to him, in whose power it is to save, or destroy him.
  6649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOr Precedent Subjection Of One Of The Parents To The Other
  6654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf the Mother be the Fathers subject, the Child, is in the Fathers
  6656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower: and if the Father be the Mothers subject, (as when a Soveraign
  6657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tQueen marrieth one of her subjects,) the Child is subject to the Mother;
  6658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause the Father also is her subject.
  6659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a man and a woman, Monarches of two severall Kingdomes, have a Child,
  6661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand contract concerning who shall have the Dominion of him, the Right of
  6662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Dominion passeth by the Contract. If they contract not, the Dominion
  6663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfolloweth the Dominion of the place of his residence. For the Soveraign
  6664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof each Country hath Dominion over all that reside therein.
  6665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHe that hath the Dominion over the Child, hath Dominion also over their
  6667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChildrens Children. For he that hath Dominion over the person of a man,
  6668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath Dominion over all that is his; without which, Dominion were but a
  6669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTitle, without the effect.
  6670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Right Of Succession Followeth The Rules Of The Rights Of Possession
  6675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Right of Succession to Paternall dominion, proceedeth in the same
  6677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner, as doth the Right of Succession to Monarchy; of which I have
  6678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready sufficiently spoken in the precedent chapter.
  6679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

  6681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDespoticall Dominion, How Attained
  6684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominion acquired by Conquest, or Victory in war, is that which some
  6686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWriters call DESPOTICALL, from Despotes, which signifieth a Lord, or
  6687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMaster; and is the Dominion of the Master over his Servant. And this
  6688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominion is then acquired to the Victor, when the Vanquished, to avoyd
  6689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe present stroke of death, covenanteth either in expresse words, or by
  6690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother sufficient signes of the Will, that so long as his life, and
  6691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe liberty of his body is allowed him, the Victor shall have the use
  6692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof, at his pleasure. And after such Covenant made, the Vanquished
  6693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a SERVANT, and not before: for by the word Servant (whether it be
  6694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tderived from Servire, to Serve, or from Servare, to Save, which I leave
  6695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Grammarians to dispute) is not meant a Captive, which is kept in
  6696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprison, or bonds, till the owner of him that took him, or bought him
  6697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof one that did, shall consider what to do with him: (for such men,
  6698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(commonly called Slaves,) have no obligation at all; but may break their
  6699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbonds, or the prison; and kill, or carry away captive their Master,
  6700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjustly:) but one, that being taken, hath corporall liberty allowed him;
  6701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand upon promise not to run away, nor to do violence to his Master, is
  6702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrusted by him.
  6703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNot By The Victory, But By The Consent Of The Vanquished
  6708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is not therefore the Victory, that giveth the right of Dominion over
  6710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Vanquished, but his own Covenant. Nor is he obliged because he is
  6711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConquered; that is to say, beaten, and taken, or put to flight; but
  6712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause he commeth in, and submitteth to the Victor; Nor is the Victor
  6713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobliged by an enemies rendring himselfe, (without promise of life,) to
  6714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspare him for this his yeelding to discretion; which obliges not the
  6715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVictor longer, than in his own discretion hee shall think fit.
  6716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd that men do, when they demand (as it is now called) Quarter, (which
  6718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Greeks called Zogria, taking alive,) is to evade the present fury of
  6719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Victor, by Submission, and to compound for their life, with Ransome,
  6720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Service: and therefore he that hath Quarter, hath not his life given,
  6721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut deferred till farther deliberation; For it is not an yeelding on
  6722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition of life, but to discretion. And then onely is his life in
  6723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsecurity, and his service due, when the Victor hath trusted him with his
  6724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcorporall liberty. For Slaves that work in Prisons, or Fetters, do it
  6725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot of duty, but to avoyd the cruelty of their task-masters.
  6726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Master of the Servant, is Master also of all he hath; and may exact
  6728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe use thereof; that is to say, of his goods, of his labour, of his
  6729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tservants, and of his children, as often as he shall think fit. For he
  6730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tholdeth his life of his Master, by the covenant of obedience; that is,
  6731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof owning, and authorising whatsoever the Master shall do. And in case
  6732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Master, if he refuse, kill him, or cast him into bonds, or otherwise
  6733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunish him for his disobedience, he is himselfe the author of the same;
  6734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand cannot accuse him of injury.
  6735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn summe the Rights and Consequences of both Paternall and Despoticall
  6737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominion, are the very same with those of a Soveraign by Institution;
  6738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand for the same reasons: which reasons are set down in the precedent
  6739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchapter. So that for a man that is Monarch of divers Nations, whereof he
  6740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath, in one the Soveraignty by Institution of the people assembled, and
  6741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin another by Conquest, that is by the Submission of each particular,
  6742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto avoyd death or bonds; to demand of one Nation more than of the other,
  6743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the title of Conquest, as being a Conquered Nation, is an act of
  6744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tignorance of the Rights of Soveraignty. For the Soveraign is absolute
  6745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover both alike; or else there is no Soveraignty at all; and so every
  6746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman may Lawfully protect himselfe, if he can, with his own sword, which
  6747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the condition of war.
  6748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDifference Between A Family And A Kingdom
  6753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy this it appears, that a great Family if it be not part of some
  6755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, is of it self, as to the Rights of Soveraignty, a little
  6756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarchy; whether that Family consist of a man and his children; or of
  6757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man and his servants; or of a man, and his children, and servants
  6758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttogether: wherein the Father of Master is the Soveraign. But yet a
  6759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFamily is not properly a Common-wealth; unlesse it be of that power by
  6760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tits own number, or by other opportunities, as not to be subdued without
  6761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe hazard of war. For where a number of men are manifestly too weak to
  6762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdefend themselves united, every one may use his own reason in time of
  6763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdanger, to save his own life, either by flight, or by submission to
  6764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe enemy, as hee shall think best; in the same manner as a very small
  6765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcompany of souldiers, surprised by an army, may cast down their armes,
  6766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand demand quarter, or run away, rather than be put to the sword. And
  6767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthus much shall suffice; concerning what I find by speculation, and
  6768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeduction, of Soveraign Rights, from the nature, need, and designes
  6769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men, in erecting of Commonwealths, and putting themselves under
  6770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarchs, or Assemblies, entrusted with power enough for their
  6771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprotection.
  6772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Right Of Monarchy From Scripture
  6777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLet us now consider what the Scripture teacheth in the same point. To
  6779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses, the children of Israel say thus. (Exod. 20. 19) "Speak thou to
  6780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tus, and we will heare thee; but let not God speak to us, lest we dye."
  6781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis is absolute obedience to Moses. Concerning the Right of Kings, God
  6782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself by the mouth of Samuel, saith, (1 Sam. 8. 11, 12, &c.) "This
  6783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be the Right of the King you will have to reigne over you. He
  6784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall take your sons, and set them to drive his Chariots, and to be his
  6785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thorsemen, and to run before his chariots; and gather in his harvest; and
  6786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto make his engines of War, and Instruments of his chariots; and shall
  6787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake your daughters to make perfumes, to be his Cookes, and Bakers. He
  6788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall take your fields, your vine-yards, and your olive-yards, and give
  6789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem to his servants. He shall take the tyth of your corne and wine, and
  6790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive it to the men of his chamber, and to his other servants. He shall
  6791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake your man-servants, and your maid-servants, and the choice of your
  6792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyouth, and employ them in his businesse. He shall take the tyth of your
  6793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tflocks; and you shall be his servants." This is absolute power, and
  6794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsummed up in the last words, "you shall be his servants." Againe, when
  6795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people heard what power their King was to have, yet they consented
  6796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereto, and say thus, (Verse. 19 &c.) "We will be as all other nations,
  6797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand our King shall judge our causes, and goe before us, to conduct our
  6798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twars." Here is confirmed the Right that Soveraigns have, both to the
  6799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMilitia, and to all Judicature; in which is conteined as absolute power,
  6800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas one man can possibly transferre to another. Again, the prayer of
  6801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing Salomon to God, was this. (1 Kings 3. 9) "Give to thy servant
  6802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstanding, to judge thy people, and to discerne between Good and
  6803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvill." It belongeth therefore to the Soveraigne to bee Judge, and
  6804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto praescribe the Rules of Discerning Good and Evill; which Rules are
  6805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes; and therefore in him is the Legislative Power. Saul sought
  6806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe life of David; yet when it was in his power to slay Saul, and his
  6807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tServants would have done it, David forbad them, saying (1 Sam. 24. 9)
  6808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"God forbid I should do such an act against my Lord, the anoynted of
  6809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod." For obedience of servants St. Paul saith, (Coll. 3. 20) "Servants
  6810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobey your masters in All things," and, (Verse. 22) "Children obey your
  6811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tParents in All things." There is simple obedience in those that are
  6812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject to Paternall, or Despoticall Dominion. Again, (Math. 23. 2,3)
  6813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"The Scribes and Pharisees sit in Moses chayre and therefore All that
  6814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey shall bid you observe, that observe and do." There again is simple
  6815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobedience. And St. Paul, (Tit. 3. 2) "Warn them that they subject
  6816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves to Princes, and to those that are in Authority, & obey
  6817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem." This obedience is also simple. Lastly, our Saviour himselfe
  6818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledges, that men ought to pay such taxes as are by Kings imposed,
  6819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere he sayes, "Give to Caesar that which is Caesars;" and payed such
  6820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaxes himselfe. And that the Kings word, is sufficient to take any thing
  6821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom any subject, when there is need; and that the King is Judge of that
  6822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneed: For he himselfe, as King of the Jewes, commanded his Disciples to
  6823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake the Asse, and Asses Colt to carry him into Jerusalem, saying, (Mat.
  6824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t21. 2,3) "Go into the Village over against you, and you shall find a
  6825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshee Asse tyed, and her Colt with her, unty them, and bring them to me.
  6826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd if any man ask you, what you mean by it, Say the Lord hath need
  6827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them: And they will let them go." They will not ask whether his
  6828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessity be a sufficient title; nor whether he be judge of that
  6829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessity; but acquiesce in the will of the Lord.
  6830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo these places may be added also that of Genesis, (Gen. 3. 5) "You
  6832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be as Gods, knowing Good and Evill." and verse 11. "Who told thee
  6833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat thou wast naked? hast thou eaten of the tree, of which I commanded
  6834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthee thou shouldest not eat?" For the Cognisance of Judicature of Good
  6835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Evill, being forbidden by the name of the fruit of the tree of
  6836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKnowledge, as a triall of Adams obedience; The Divell to enflame the
  6837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAmbition of the woman, to whom that fruit already seemed beautifull,
  6838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttold her that by tasting it, they should be as Gods, knowing Good and
  6839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvill. Whereupon having both eaten, they did indeed take upon them
  6840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods office, which is Judicature of Good and Evill; but acquired no new
  6841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tability to distinguish between them aright. And whereas it is sayd, that
  6842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thaving eaten, they saw they were naked; no man hath so interpreted that
  6843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace, as if they had formerly blind, as saw not their own skins: the
  6844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeaning is plain, that it was then they first judged their nakednesse
  6845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(wherein it was Gods will to create them) to be uncomely; and by being
  6846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tashamed, did tacitely censure God himselfe. And thereupon God saith,
  6847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Hast thou eaten, &c." as if he should say, doest thou that owest me
  6848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobedience, take upon thee to judge of my Commandements? Whereby it is
  6849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcleerly, (though Allegorically,) signified, that the Commands of
  6850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem that have the right to command, are not by their Subjects to be
  6851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcensured, nor disputed.
  6852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power Ought In All Common-wealths To Be Absolute
  6857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo it appeareth plainly, to my understanding, both from Reason, and
  6859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture, that the Soveraign Power, whether placed in One Man, as in
  6860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarchy, or in one Assembly of men, as in Popular, and Aristocraticall
  6861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths, is as great, as possibly men can be imagined to make
  6862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit. And though of so unlimited a Power, men may fancy many evill
  6863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequences, yet the consequences of the want of it, which is
  6864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperpetuall warre of every man against his neighbour, are much worse. The
  6865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition of man in this life shall never be without Inconveniences; but
  6866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere happeneth in no Common-wealth any great Inconvenience, but what
  6867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceeds from the Subjects disobedience, and breach of those Covenants,
  6868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom which the Common-wealth had its being. And whosoever thinking
  6869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power too great, will seek to make it lesse; must subject
  6870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe, to the Power, that can limit it; that is to say, to a greater.
  6871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe greatest objection is, that of the Practise; when men ask, where,
  6873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand when, such Power has by Subjects been acknowledged. But one may
  6874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\task them again, when, or where has there been a Kingdome long free from
  6875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSedition and Civill Warre. In those Nations, whose Common-wealths have
  6876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen long-lived, and not been destroyed, but by forraign warre, the
  6877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects never did dispute of the Soveraign Power. But howsoever, an
  6878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\targument for the Practise of men, that have not sifted to the bottom,
  6879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand with exact reason weighed the causes, and nature of Common-wealths,
  6880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand suffer daily those miseries, that proceed from the ignorance
  6881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof, is invalid. For though in all places of the world, men should
  6882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlay the foundation of their houses on the sand, it could not thence be
  6883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinferred, that so it ought to be. The skill of making, and maintaining
  6884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths, consisteth in certain Rules, as doth Arithmetique and
  6885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGeometry; not (as Tennis-play) on Practise onely: which Rules, neither
  6886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpoor men have the leisure, nor men that have had the leisure, have
  6887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thitherto had the curiosity, or the method to find out.
  6888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXI. OF THE LIBERTY OF SUBJECTS
  6892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty What
  6897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty, or FREEDOME, signifieth (properly) the absence of Opposition;
  6899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(by Opposition, I mean externall Impediments of motion;) and may
  6900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe applyed no lesse to Irrational, and Inanimate creatures, than to
  6901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRationall. For whatsoever is so tyed, or environed, as it cannot move,
  6902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut within a certain space, which space is determined by the opposition
  6903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof some externall body, we say it hath not Liberty to go further. And
  6904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso of all living creatures, whilest they are imprisoned, or restrained,
  6905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith walls, or chayns; and of the water whilest it is kept in by banks,
  6906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor vessels, that otherwise would spread it selfe into a larger space, we
  6907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuse to say, they are not at Liberty, to move in such manner, as without
  6908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose externall impediments they would. But when the impediment of
  6909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmotion, is in the constitution of the thing it selfe, we use not to
  6910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, it wants the Liberty; but the Power to move; as when a stone lyeth
  6911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstill, or a man is fastned to his bed by sicknesse.
  6912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat It Is To Be Free
  6917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd according to this proper, and generally received meaning of the
  6919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tword, A FREE-MAN, is "he, that in those things, which by his strength
  6920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand wit he is able to do, is not hindred to doe what he has a will
  6921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto." But when the words Free, and Liberty, are applyed to any thing but
  6922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBodies, they are abused; for that which is not subject to Motion, is not
  6923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject to Impediment: And therefore, when 'tis said (for example) The
  6924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tway is free, no liberty of the way is signified, but of those that walk
  6925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin it without stop. And when we say a Guift is free, there is not meant
  6926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany liberty of the Guift, but of the Giver, that was not bound by any
  6927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlaw, or Covenant to give it. So when we Speak Freely, it is not the
  6928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tliberty of voice, or pronunciation, but of the man, whom no law hath
  6929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobliged to speak otherwise then he did. Lastly, from the use of the
  6930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tword Freewill, no liberty can be inferred to the will, desire, or
  6931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinclination, but the liberty of the man; which consisteth in this, that
  6932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the finds no stop, in doing what he has the will, desire, or inclination
  6933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto doe.
  6934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFeare And Liberty Consistent
  6939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFeare and Liberty are consistent; as when a man throweth his goods into
  6941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Sea for Feare the ship should sink, he doth it neverthelesse very
  6942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twillingly, and may refuse to doe it if he will: It is therefore the
  6943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taction, of one that was Free; so a man sometimes pays his debt, only for
  6944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFeare of Imprisonment, which because no body hindred him from detaining,
  6945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas the action of a man at Liberty. And generally all actions which men
  6946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoe in Common-wealths, for Feare of the law, or actions, which the doers
  6947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad Liberty to omit.
  6948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty And Necessity Consistent
  6953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty and Necessity are Consistent: As in the water, that hath not
  6955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonly Liberty, but a Necessity of descending by the Channel: so likewise
  6956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Actions which men voluntarily doe; which (because they proceed
  6957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom their will) proceed from Liberty; and yet because every act of
  6958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmans will, and every desire, and inclination proceedeth from some cause,
  6959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich causes in a continuall chaine (whose first link in the hand of
  6960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod the first of all causes) proceed from Necessity. So that to him
  6961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat could see the connexion of those causes, the Necessity of all
  6962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmens voluntary actions, would appeare manifest. And therefore God, that
  6963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseeth, and disposeth all things, seeth also that the Liberty of man
  6964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin doing what he will, is accompanied with the Necessity of doing that
  6965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich God will, & no more, nor lesse. For though men may do many things,
  6966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich God does not command, nor is therefore Author of them; yet they
  6967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan have no passion, nor appetite to any thing, of which appetite Gods
  6968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill is not the cause. And did not his will assure the Necessity of mans
  6969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill, and consequently of all that on mans will dependeth, the Liberty
  6970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men would be a contradiction, and impediment to the omnipotence and
  6971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty of God. And this shall suffice, (as to the matter in hand) of
  6972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat naturall Liberty, which only is properly called Liberty.
  6973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArtificiall Bonds, Or Covenants
  6978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut as men, for the atteyning of peace, and conservation of themselves
  6980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereby, have made an Artificiall Man, which we call a Common-wealth; so
  6981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso have they made Artificiall Chains, called Civill Lawes, which they
  6982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, by mutuall covenants, have fastned at one end, to the lips
  6983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof that Man, or Assembly, to whom they have given the Soveraigne Power;
  6984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand at the other end to their own Ears. These Bonds in their own nature
  6985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut weak, may neverthelesse be made to hold, by the danger, though not
  6986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the difficulty of breaking them.
  6987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty Of Subjects Consisteth In Liberty From Covenants
  6992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  6993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn relation to these Bonds only it is, that I am to speak now, of the
  6994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty of Subjects. For seeing there is no Common-wealth in the world,
  6995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the regulating of all the actions, and words of men, (as being
  6996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta thing impossible:) it followeth necessarily, that in all kinds of
  6997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions, by the laws praetermitted, men have the Liberty, of doing what
  6998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own reasons shall suggest, for the most profitable to themselves.
  6999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor if wee take Liberty in the proper sense, for corporall Liberty; that
  7000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, freedome from chains, and prison, it were very absurd for men
  7001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto clamor as they doe, for the Liberty they so manifestly enjoy. Againe,
  7002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif we take Liberty, for an exemption from Lawes, it is no lesse absurd,
  7003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor men to demand as they doe, that Liberty, by which all other men may
  7004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe masters of their lives. And yet as absurd as it is, this is it they
  7005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdemand; not knowing that the Lawes are of no power to protect them,
  7006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout a Sword in the hands of a man, or men, to cause those laws to
  7007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe put in execution. The Liberty of a Subject, lyeth therefore only
  7008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin those things, which in regulating their actions, the Soveraign hath
  7009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpraetermitted; such as is the Liberty to buy, and sell, and otherwise
  7010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontract with one another; to choose their own aboad, their own diet,
  7011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own trade of life, and institute their children as they themselves
  7012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthink fit; & the like.
  7013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty Of The Subject Consistent With Unlimited Power Of The Soveraign
  7018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse we are not to understand, that by such Liberty, the
  7020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power of life, and death, is either abolished, or limited. For
  7021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit has been already shewn, that nothing the Soveraign Representative
  7022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan doe to a Subject, on what pretence soever, can properly be called
  7023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInjustice, or Injury; because every Subject is Author of every act the
  7024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign doth; so that he never wanteth Right to any thing, otherwise,
  7025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan as he himself is the Subject of God, and bound thereby to observe
  7026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe laws of Nature. And therefore it may, and doth often happen in
  7027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths, that a Subject may be put to death, by the command of
  7028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign Power; and yet neither doe the other wrong: as when Jeptha
  7029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcaused his daughter to be sacrificed: In which, and the like cases,
  7030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the that so dieth, had Liberty to doe the action, for which he is
  7031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse, without Injury put to death. And the same holdeth also
  7032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin a Soveraign Prince, that putteth to death an Innocent Subject. For
  7033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough the action be against the law of Nature, as being contrary to
  7034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEquitie, (as was the killing of Uriah, by David;) yet it was not an
  7035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInjurie to Uriah; but to God. Not to Uriah, because the right to doe
  7036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat he pleased, was given him by Uriah himself; And yet to God, because
  7037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDavid was Gods Subject; and prohibited all Iniquitie by the law of
  7038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature. Which distinction, David himself, when he repented the fact,
  7039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevidently confirmed, saying, "To thee only have I sinned." In the same
  7040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner, the people of Athens, when they banished the most potent of
  7041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Common-wealth for ten years, thought they committed no Injustice;
  7042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand yet they never questioned what crime he had done; but what hurt he
  7043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould doe: Nay they commanded the banishment of they knew not whom; and
  7044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery Citizen bringing his Oystershell into the market place, written
  7045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the name of him he desired should be banished, without actuall
  7046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccusing him, sometimes banished an Aristides, for his reputation of
  7047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice; And sometimes a scurrilous Jester, as Hyperbolus, to make a
  7048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJest of it. And yet a man cannot say, the Soveraign People of Athens
  7049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twanted right to banish them; or an Athenian the Libertie to Jest, or to
  7050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Just.
  7051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Liberty Which Writers Praise, Is The Liberty Of Soveraigns;
  7056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNot Of Private Men
  7058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Libertie, whereof there is so frequent, and honourable mention, in
  7060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Histories, and Philosophy of the Antient Greeks, and Romans, and in
  7061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe writings, and discourse of those that from them have received all
  7062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir learning in the Politiques, is not the Libertie of Particular
  7063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen; but the Libertie of the Common-wealth: which is the same with
  7064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat, which every man then should have, if there were no Civil Laws,
  7065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor Common-wealth at all. And the effects of it also be the same. For as
  7066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst masterlesse men, there is perpetuall war, of every man against
  7067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this neighbour; no inheritance, to transmit to the Son, nor to expect
  7068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Father; no propriety of Goods, or Lands; no security; but a
  7069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfull and absolute Libertie in every Particular man: So in States, and
  7070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths not dependent on one another, every Common-wealth, (not
  7071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery man) has an absolute Libertie, to doe what it shall judge (that is
  7072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, what that Man, or Assemblie that representeth it, shall judge)
  7073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost conducing to their benefit. But withall, they live in the condition
  7074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a perpetuall war, and upon the confines of battel, with their
  7075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrontiers armed, and canons planted against their neighbours
  7076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tround about. The Athenians, and Romanes, were free; that is, free
  7077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths: not that any particular men had the Libertie to resist
  7078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own Representative; but that their Representative had the Libertie
  7079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto resist, or invade other people. There is written on the Turrets of
  7080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe city of Luca in great characters at this day, the word LIBERTAS; yet
  7081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno man can thence inferre, that a particular man has more Libertie,
  7082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Immunitie from the service of the Commonwealth there, than in
  7083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConstantinople. Whether a Common-wealth be Monarchicall, or Popular, the
  7084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFreedome is still the same.
  7085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut it is an easy thing, for men to be deceived, by the specious name
  7087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Libertie; and for want of Judgement to distinguish, mistake that for
  7088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Private Inheritance, and Birth right, which is the right of the
  7089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique only. And when the same errour is confirmed by the authority of
  7090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen in reputation for their writings in this subject, it is no wonder if
  7091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit produce sedition, and change of Government. In these westerne
  7092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparts of the world, we are made to receive our opinions concerning the
  7093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstitution, and Rights of Common-wealths, from Aristotle, Cicero, and
  7094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother men, Greeks and Romanes, that living under Popular States, derived
  7095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Rights, not from the Principles of Nature, but transcribed them
  7096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto their books, out of the Practice of their own Common-wealths, which
  7097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere Popular; as the Grammarians describe the Rules of Language, out of
  7098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Practise of the time; or the Rules of Poetry, out of the Poems of
  7099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHomer and Virgil. And because the Athenians were taught, (to keep them
  7100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom desire of changing their Government,) that they were Freemen, and
  7101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall that lived under Monarchy were slaves; therefore Aristotle puts it
  7102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdown in his Politiques,(lib.6.cap.2) "In democracy, Liberty is to be
  7103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupposed: for 'tis commonly held, that no man is Free in any other
  7104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment." And as Aristotle; so Cicero, and other Writers have
  7105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrounded their Civill doctrine, on the opinions of the Romans, who were
  7106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaught to hate Monarchy, at first, by them that having deposed their
  7107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, shared amongst them the Soveraignty of Rome; and afterwards
  7108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby their Successors. And by reading of these Greek, and Latine Authors,
  7109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen from their childhood have gotten a habit (under a false shew of
  7110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty,) of favouring tumults, and of licentious controlling the
  7111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions of their Soveraigns; and again of controlling those controllers,
  7112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the effusion of so much blood; as I think I may truly say, there
  7113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas never any thing so deerly bought, as these Western parts have bought
  7114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe learning of the Greek and Latine tongues.
  7115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty Of The Subject How To Be Measured
  7120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo come now to the particulars of the true Liberty of a Subject; that is
  7122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, what are the things, which though commanded by the Soveraign, he
  7123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay neverthelesse, without Injustice, refuse to do; we are to consider,
  7124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat Rights we passe away, when we make a Common-wealth; or (which is
  7125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall one,) what Liberty we deny our selves, by owning all the Actions
  7126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(without exception) of the Man, or Assembly we make our Soveraign. For
  7127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the act of our Submission, consisteth both our Obligation, and
  7128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Liberty; which must therefore be inferred by arguments taken from
  7129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthence; there being no Obligation on any man, which ariseth not from
  7130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome Act of his own; for all men equally, are by Nature Free. And
  7131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause such arguments, must either be drawn from the expresse words, "I
  7132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthorise all his Actions," or from the Intention of him that submitteth
  7133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe to his Power, (which Intention is to be understood by the End
  7134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor which he so submitteth;) The Obligation, and Liberty of the Subject,
  7135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to be derived, either from those Words, (or others equivalent;) or
  7136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\telse from the End of the Institution of Soveraignty; namely, the Peace
  7137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Subjects within themselves, and their Defence against a common
  7138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnemy.
  7139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects Have Liberty To Defend Their Own Bodies,
  7144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEven Against Them That Lawfully Invade Them
  7146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFirst therefore, seeing Soveraignty by Institution, is by Covenant of
  7148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one to every one; and Soveraignty by Acquisition, by Covenants of
  7149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Vanquished to the Victor, or Child to the Parent; It is manifest,
  7150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat every Subject has Liberty in all those things, the right whereof
  7151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot by Covenant be transferred. I have shewn before in the 14.
  7152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChapter, that Covenants, not to defend a mans own body, are voyd.
  7153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore,
  7154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAre Not Bound To Hurt Themselves;
  7159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf the Soveraign command a man (though justly condemned,) to kill,
  7161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twound, or mayme himselfe; or not to resist those that assault him; or
  7162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto abstain from the use of food, ayre, medicine, or any other thing,
  7163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout which he cannot live; yet hath that man the Liberty to disobey.
  7164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a man be interrogated by the Soveraign, or his Authority, concerning
  7166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta crime done by himselfe, he is not bound (without assurance of Pardon)
  7167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto confesse it; because no man (as I have shewn in the same Chapter) can
  7168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe obliged by Covenant to accuse himselfe.
  7169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, the Consent of a Subject to Soveraign Power, is contained in
  7171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese words, "I Authorise, or take upon me, all his actions;" in which
  7172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is no restriction at all, of his own former naturall Liberty:
  7173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor by allowing him to Kill Me, I am not bound to Kill my selfe when
  7174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the commands me. "'Tis one thing to say 'Kill me, or my fellow, if you
  7175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplease;' another thing to say, 'I will kill my selfe, or my fellow.'" It
  7176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfolloweth therefore, that
  7177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNo man is bound by the words themselves, either to kill himselfe, or
  7179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany other man; And consequently, that the Obligation a man may sometimes
  7180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave, upon the Command of the Soveraign to execute any dangerous, or
  7181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdishonourable Office, dependeth not on the Words of our Submission; but
  7182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton the Intention; which is to be understood by the End thereof. When
  7183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore our refusall to obey, frustrates the End for which the
  7184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty was ordained; then there is no Liberty to refuse: otherwise
  7185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is.
  7186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor To Warfare, Unless They Voluntarily Undertake It
  7191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUpon this ground, a man that is commanded as a Souldier to fight against
  7193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe enemy, though his Soveraign have Right enough to punish his refusall
  7194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith death, may neverthelesse in many cases refuse, without Injustice;
  7195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas when he substituteth a sufficient Souldier in his place: for in this
  7196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcase he deserteth not the service of the Common-wealth. And there is
  7197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallowance to be made for naturall timorousnesse, not onely to women, (of
  7198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom no such dangerous duty is expected,) but also to men of feminine
  7199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcourage. When Armies fight, there is on one side, or both, a running
  7200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taway; yet when they do it not out of trechery, but fear, they are not
  7201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\testeemed to do it unjustly, but dishonourably. For the same reason, to
  7202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tavoyd battell, is not Injustice, but Cowardise. But he that inrowleth
  7203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe a Souldier, or taketh imprest mony, taketh away the excuse of
  7204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta timorous nature; and is obliged, not onely to go to the battell,
  7205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut also not to run from it, without his Captaines leave. And when the
  7206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDefence of the Common-wealth, requireth at once the help of all that
  7207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare able to bear Arms, every one is obliged; because otherwise the
  7208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstitution of the Common-wealth, which they have not the purpose, or
  7209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcourage to preserve, was in vain.
  7210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo resist the Sword of the Common-wealth, in defence of another man,
  7212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tguilty, or innocent, no man hath Liberty; because such Liberty, takes
  7213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taway from the Soveraign, the means of Protecting us; and is therefore
  7214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdestructive of the very essence of Government. But in case a great many
  7215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen together, have already resisted the Soveraign Power Unjustly, or
  7216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommitted some Capitall crime, for which every one of them expecteth
  7217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeath, whether have they not the Liberty then to joyn together, and
  7218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassist, and defend one another? Certainly they have: For they but defend
  7219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir lives, which the guilty man may as well do, as the Innocent. There
  7220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas indeed injustice in the first breach of their duty; Their bearing of
  7221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArms subsequent to it, though it be to maintain what they have done, is
  7222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno new unjust act. And if it be onely to defend their persons, it is not
  7223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunjust at all. But the offer of Pardon taketh from them, to whom it
  7224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis offered, the plea of self-defence, and maketh their perseverance in
  7225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassisting, or defending the rest, unlawfull.
  7226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Greatest Liberty Of Subjects, Dependeth On The Silence Of The Law
  7231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for other Lyberties, they depend on the silence of the Law. In cases
  7234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere the Soveraign has prescribed no rule, there the Subject hath
  7235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe liberty to do, or forbeare, according to his own discretion. And
  7236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore such Liberty is in some places more, and in some lesse; and in
  7237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome times more, in other times lesse, according as they that have the
  7238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty shall think most convenient. As for Example, there was
  7239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta time, when in England a man might enter in to his own Land,
  7240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(and dispossesse such as wrongfully possessed it) by force. But in
  7241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter-times, that Liberty of Forcible entry, was taken away by a Statute
  7242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade (by the King) in Parliament. And is some places of the world, men
  7243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave the Liberty of many wives: in other places, such Liberty is not
  7244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallowed.
  7245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a Subject have a controversie with his Soveraigne, of Debt, or
  7247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof right of possession of lands or goods, or concerning any service
  7248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequired at his hands, or concerning any penalty corporall, or
  7249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpecuniary, grounded on a precedent Law; He hath the same Liberty to sue
  7250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor his right, as if it were against a Subject; and before such Judges,
  7251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas are appointed by the Soveraign. For seeing the Soveraign demandeth
  7252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby force of a former Law, and not by vertue of his Power; he declareth
  7253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereby, that he requireth no more, than shall appear to be due by that
  7254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw. The sute therefore is not contrary to the will of the Soveraign;
  7255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand consequently the Subject hath the Liberty to demand the hearing of
  7256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Cause; and sentence, according to that Law. But if he demand, or
  7257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake any thing by pretence of his Power; there lyeth, in that case, no
  7258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taction of Law: for all that is done by him in Vertue of his Power, is
  7259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdone by the Authority of every subject, and consequently, he that brings
  7260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan action against the Soveraign, brings it against himselfe.
  7261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a Monarch, or Soveraign Assembly, grant a Liberty to all, or any of
  7263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Subjects; which Grant standing, he is disabled to provide for their
  7264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsafety, the Grant is voyd; unlesse he directly renounce, or transferre
  7265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraignty to another. For in that he might openly, (if it had been
  7266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this will,) and in plain termes, have renounced, or transferred it, and
  7267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdid not; it is to be understood it was not his will; but that the Grant
  7268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceeded from ignorance of the repugnancy between such a Liberty and
  7269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign Power; and therefore the Soveraignty is still retayned;
  7270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand consequently all those Powers, which are necessary to the exercising
  7271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof; such as are the Power of Warre, and Peace, of Judicature, of
  7272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappointing Officers, and Councellours, of levying Mony, and the rest
  7273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnamed in the 18th Chapter.
  7274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn What Cases Subjects Absolved Of Their Obedience To Their Soveraign
  7279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Obligation of Subjects to the Soveraign is understood to last as
  7281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlong, and no longer, than the power lasteth, by which he is able to
  7282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprotect them. For the right men have by Nature to protect themselves,
  7283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen none else can protect them, can by no Covenant be relinquished. The
  7284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty is the Soule of the Common-wealth; which once departed from
  7285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Body, the members doe no more receive their motion from it. The end
  7286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Obedience is Protection; which, wheresoever a man seeth it, either in
  7287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own, or in anothers sword, Nature applyeth his obedience to it, and
  7288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this endeavour to maintaine it. And though Soveraignty, in the intention
  7289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them that make it, be immortall; yet is it in its own nature, not
  7290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonly subject to violent death, by forreign war; but also through
  7291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe ignorance, and passions of men, it hath in it, from the very
  7292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinstitution, many seeds of a naturall mortality, by Intestine Discord.
  7293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Case Of Captivity
  7298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a Subject be taken prisoner in war; or his person, or his means of
  7300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife be within the Guards of the enemy, and hath his life and corporall
  7301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLibertie given him, on condition to be Subject to the Victor, he hath
  7302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLibertie to accept the condition; and having accepted it, is the subject
  7303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof him that took him; because he had no other way to preserve himselfe.
  7304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe case is the same, if he be deteined on the same termes, in a
  7305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforreign country. But if a man be held in prison, or bonds, or is not
  7306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrusted with the libertie of his bodie; he cannot be understood to be
  7307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbound by Covenant to subjection; and therefore may, if he can, make his
  7308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tescape by any means whatsoever.
  7309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Case The Soveraign Cast Off The Government From Himself And Heyrs
  7314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a Monarch shall relinquish the Soveraignty, both for himself, and
  7316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this heires; His Subjects returne to the absolute Libertie of Nature;
  7317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause, though Nature may declare who are his Sons, and who are the
  7318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnerest of his Kin; yet it dependeth on his own will, (as hath been said
  7319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the precedent chapter,) who shall be his Heyr. If therefore he will
  7320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave no Heyre, there is no Soveraignty, nor Subjection. The case is the
  7321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame, if he dye without known Kindred, and without declaration of
  7322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Heyre. For then there can no Heire be known, and consequently no
  7323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjection be due.
  7324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Case Of Banishment
  7329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf the Soveraign Banish his Subject; during the Banishment, he is not
  7331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubject. But he that is sent on a message, or hath leave to travell, is
  7332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstill Subject; but it is, by Contract between Soveraigns, not by vertue
  7333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the covenant of Subjection. For whosoever entreth into anothers
  7334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdominion, is Subject to all the Lawes thereof; unless he have a
