  7335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivilege by the amity of the Soveraigns, or by speciall licence.
  7336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Case The Soveraign Render Himself Subject To Another
  7341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a Monarch subdued by war, render himself Subject to the Victor; his
  7343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects are delivered from their former obligation, and become obliged
  7344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Victor. But if he be held prisoner, or have not the liberty
  7345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his own Body; he is not understood to have given away the Right of
  7346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigntie; and therefore his Subjects are obliged to yield obedience
  7347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Magistrates formerly placed, governing not in their own name,
  7348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut in his. For, his Right remaining, the question is only of the
  7349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdministration; that is to say, of the Magistrates and Officers; which,
  7350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif he have not means to name, he is supposed to approve those, which he
  7351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself had formerly appointed.
  7352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXII. OF SYSTEMES SUBJECT, POLITICALL, AND PRIVATE
  7356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Divers Sorts Of Systemes Of People
  7361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHaving spoken of the Generation, Forme, and Power of a Common-wealth, I
  7363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tam in order to speak next of the parts thereof. And first of Systemes,
  7364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich resemble the similar parts, or Muscles of a Body naturall. By
  7365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSYSTEMES; I understand any numbers of men joyned in one Interest, or one
  7366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBusinesse. Of which, some are Regular, and some Irregular. Regular are
  7367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose, where one Man, or Assembly of men, is constituted Representative
  7368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the whole number. All other are Irregular.
  7369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Regular, some are Absolute, and Independent, subject to none but
  7371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own Representative: such are only Common-wealths; Of which I have
  7372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspoken already in the 5. last preceding chapters. Others are Dependent;
  7373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, Subordinate to some Soveraign Power, to which every one,
  7374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas also their Representative is Subject.
  7375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Systemes subordinate, some are Politicall, and some Private.
  7377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPoliticall (otherwise Called Bodies Politique, and Persons In Law,)
  7378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare those, which are made by authority from the Soveraign Power of the
  7379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth. Private, are those, which are constituted by Subjects
  7380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst themselves, or by authoritie from a stranger. For no authority
  7381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tderived from forraign power, within the Dominion of another, is Publique
  7382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere, but Private.
  7383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd of Private Systemes, some are Lawfull; some Unlawfull: Lawfull, are
  7385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose which are allowed by the Common-wealth: all other are Unlawfull.
  7386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIrregular Systemes, are those which having no Representative,
  7387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsist only in concourse of People; which if not forbidden by the
  7388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, nor made on evill designe, (such as are conflux of People
  7389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto markets, or shews, or any other harmelesse end,) are Lawfull. But
  7390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen the Intention is evill, or (if the number be considerable) unknown,
  7391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are Unlawfull.
  7392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn All Bodies Politique The Power Of The Representative Is Limited
  7397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Bodies Politique, the power of the Representative is alwaies Limited:
  7399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd that which prescribeth the limits thereof, is the Power Soveraign.
  7400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor Power Unlimited, is absolute Soveraignty. And the Soveraign, in
  7401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery Commonwealth, is the absolute Representative of all the Subjects;
  7402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore no other, can be Representative of any part of them,
  7403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut so far forth, as he shall give leave; And to give leave to a Body
  7404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPolitique of Subjects, to have an absolute Representative to all
  7405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tintents and purposes, were to abandon the Government of so much of the
  7406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommonwealth, and to divide the Dominion, contrary to their Peace and
  7407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDefence, which the Soveraign cannot be understood to doe, by any Grant,
  7408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat does not plainly, and directly discharge them of their subjection.
  7409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor consequences of words, are not the signes of his will, when other
  7410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequences are signes of the contrary; but rather signes of errour,
  7411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand misreckoning; to which all mankind is too prone.
  7412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe bounds of that Power, which is given to the Representative of a
  7414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBodie Politique, are to be taken notice of, from two things. One is
  7415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Writt, or Letters from the Soveraign: the other is the Law of the
  7416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth.
  7417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Letters Patents
  7422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor though in the Institution or Acquisition of a Common-wealth,
  7424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is independent, there needs no Writing, because the Power of the
  7425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative has there no other bounds, but such as are set out by
  7426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe unwritten Law of Nature; yet in subordinate bodies, there are such
  7427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiversities of Limitation necessary, concerning their businesses, times,
  7428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand places, as can neither be remembred without Letters, nor taken
  7429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnotice of, unlesse such Letters be Patent, that they may be read to
  7430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, and withall sealed, or testified, with the Seales, or other
  7431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpermanent signes of the Authority Soveraign.
  7432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd The Lawes
  7437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because such Limitation is not alwaies easie, or perhaps possible
  7439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be described in writing; the ordinary Lawes, common to all Subjects,
  7440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmust determine, that the Representative may lawfully do, in all Cases,
  7441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere the Letters themselves are silent. And therefore
  7442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen The Representative Is One Man, His Unwarranted Acts His Own Onely
  7447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn a Body Politique, if the Representative be one man, whatsoever he
  7449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoes in the Person of the Body, which is not warranted in his Letters,
  7450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor by the Lawes, is his own act, and not the act of the Body, nor of
  7451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany other Member thereof besides himselfe: Because further than his
  7452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLetters, or the Lawes limit, he representeth no mans person, but his
  7453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town. But what he does according to these, is the act of every one: For
  7454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Act of the Soveraign every one is Author, because he is their
  7455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative unlimited; and the act of him that recedes not from the
  7456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLetters of the Soveraign, is the act of the Soveraign, and therefore
  7457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery member of the Body is Author of it.
  7458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen It Is An Assembly, It Is The Act Of Them That Assented Onely
  7463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut if the Representative be an Assembly, whatsoever that Assembly shall
  7465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDecree, not warranted by their Letters, or the Lawes, is the act of the
  7466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly, or Body Politique, and the act of every one by whose Vote the
  7467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDecree was made; but not the act of any man that being present Voted to
  7468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe contrary; nor of any man absent, unlesse he Voted it by procuration.
  7469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is the act of the Assembly, because Voted by the major part; and if
  7470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit be a crime, the Assembly may be punished, as farre-forth as it is
  7471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcapable, as by dissolution, or forfeiture of their Letters (which is to
  7472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch artificiall, and fictitious Bodies, capitall,) or (if the
  7473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly have a Common stock, wherein none of the Innocent Members have
  7474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpropriety,) by pecuniary Mulct. For from corporall penalties Nature hath
  7475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texempted all Bodies Politique. But they that gave not their Vote, are
  7476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore Innocent, because the Assembly cannot Represent any man in
  7477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings unwarranted by their Letters, and consequently are not involved
  7478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin their Votes.
  7479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen The Representative Is One Man, If He Borrow Mony, Or Owe It, By
  7481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContract; He Is Lyable Onely, The Members Not If the person of the Body
  7482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPolitique being in one man, borrow mony of a stranger, that is, of one
  7483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is not of the same Body, (for no Letters need limit borrowing,
  7484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseeing it is left to mens own inclinations to limit lending) the debt is
  7485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Representatives. For if he should have Authority from his Letters,
  7486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto make the members pay what he borroweth, he should have by consequence
  7487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraignty of them; and therefore the grant were either voyd,
  7488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas proceeding from Errour, commonly incident to humane Nature, and an
  7489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunsufficient signe of the will of the Granter; or if it be avowed
  7490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby him, then is the Representer Soveraign, and falleth not under the
  7491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent question, which is onely of Bodies subordinate. No member
  7492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore is obliged to pay the debt so borrowed, but the Representative
  7493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe: because he that lendeth it, being a stranger to the Letters,
  7494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to the qualification of the Body, understandeth those onely for
  7495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this debtors, that are engaged; and seeing the Representer can ingage
  7496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe, and none else, has him onely for Debtor; who must therefore
  7497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpay him, out of the common stock (if there be any), or (if there be
  7498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone) out of his own estate.
  7499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf he come into debt by Contract, or Mulct, the case is the same.
  7501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen It Is An Assembly, They Onely Are Liable That Have Assented
  7506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut when the Representative is an Assembly, and the debt to a stranger;
  7508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall they, and onely they are responsible for the debt, that gave their
  7509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvotes to the borrowing of it, or to the Contract that made it due, or to
  7510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe fact for which the Mulct was imposed; because every one of those in
  7511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvoting did engage himselfe for the payment: For he that is author of
  7512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe borrowing, is obliged to the payment, even of the whole debt, though
  7513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen payd by any one, he be discharged.
  7514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf The Debt Be To One Of The Assembly, The Body Onely Is Obliged
  7519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut if the debt be to one of the Assembly, the Assembly onely is obliged
  7521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the payment, out of their common stock (if they have any:) For having
  7522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tliberty of Vote, if he Vote the Mony, shall be borrowed, he Votes it
  7523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be payd; If he Vote it shall not be borrowed, or be absent, yet
  7524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause in lending, he voteth the borrowing, he contradicteth his former
  7525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVote, and is obliged by the later, and becomes both borrower and lender,
  7526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand consequently cannot demand payment from any particular man, but
  7527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the common Treasure onely; which fayling he hath no remedy, nor
  7528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomplaint, but against himselfe, that being privy to the acts of
  7529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Assembly, and their means to pay, and not being enforced, did
  7530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse through his own folly lend his mony.
  7531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProtestation Against The Decrees Of Bodies Politique
  7536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSometimes Lawful; But Against Soveraign Power Never It is manifest by
  7538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis, that in Bodies Politique subordinate, and subject to a Soveraign
  7539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower, it is sometimes not onely lawfull, but expedient, for a
  7540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular man to make open protestation against the decrees of the
  7541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative Assembly, and cause their dissent to be Registred, or to
  7542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake witnesse of it; because otherwise they may be obliged to pay debts
  7543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontracted, and be responsible for crimes committed by other men: But in
  7544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Soveraign Assembly, that liberty is taken away, both because he that
  7545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprotesteth there, denies their Soveraignty; and also because whatsoever
  7546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis commanded by the Soveraign Power, is as to the Subject (though not
  7547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso alwayes in the sight of God) justified by the Command; for of such
  7548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommand every Subject is the Author.
  7549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBodies Politique For Government Of A Province, Colony, Or Town
  7554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe variety of Bodies Politique, is almost infinite; for they are
  7556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot onely distinguished by the severall affaires, for which they are
  7557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstituted, wherein there is an unspeakable diversitie; but also by the
  7558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimes, places, and numbers, subject to many limitations. And as to their
  7559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taffaires, some are ordained for Government; As first, the Government
  7560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Province may be committed to an Assembly of men, wherein all
  7561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tresolutions shall depend on the Votes of the major part; and then this
  7562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly is a Body Politique, and their power limited by Commission.
  7563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis word Province signifies a charge, or care of businesse, which he
  7564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose businesse it is, committeth to another man, to be administred for,
  7565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand under him; and therefore when in one Common-wealth there be divers
  7566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCountries, that have their Lawes distinct one from another, or are farre
  7567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdistant in place, the Administration of the Government being committed
  7568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto divers persons, those Countries where the Soveraign is not resident,
  7569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut governs by Commission, are called Provinces. But of the government
  7570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Province, by an Assembly residing in the Province it selfe, there
  7571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe few examples. The Romans who had the Soveraignty of many Provinces;
  7572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet governed them alwaies by Presidents, and Praetors; and not by
  7573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssemblies, as they governed the City of Rome, and Territories adjacent.
  7574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn like manner, when there were Colonies sent from England, to Plant
  7575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVirginia, and Sommer-Ilands; though the government of them here, were
  7576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommitted to Assemblies in London, yet did those Assemblies never
  7577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommit the Government under them to any Assembly there; but did to each
  7578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPlantation send one Governour; For though every man, where he can be
  7579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent by Nature, desires to participate of government; yet where
  7580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey cannot be present, they are by Nature also enclined, to commit the
  7581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment of their common Interest rather to a Monarchicall, then a
  7582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPopular form of Government: which is also evident in those men that have
  7583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat private estates; who when they are unwilling to take the paines of
  7584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadministring the businesse that belongs to them, choose rather to trust
  7585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone Servant, than a Assembly either of their friends or servants.
  7586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut howsoever it be in fact, yet we may suppose the Government of a
  7587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProvince, or Colony committed to an Assembly: and when it is, that which
  7588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this place I have to say, is this; that whatsoever debt is by that
  7589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly contracted; or whatsoever unlawfull Act is decreed, is the Act
  7590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely of those that assented, and not of any that dissented, or were
  7591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsent, for the reasons before alledged. Also that an Assembly residing
  7592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of the bounds of that Colony whereof they have the government,
  7593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot execute any power over the persons, or goods of any of the
  7594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tColonie, to seize on them for debt, or other duty, in any place
  7595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout the Colony it selfe, as having no Jurisdiction, nor Authoritie
  7596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\telsewhere, but are left to the remedie, which the Law of the place
  7597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talloweth them. And though the Assembly have right, to impose a Mulct
  7598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon any of their members, that shall break the Lawes they make; yet
  7599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of the Colonie it selfe, they have no right to execute the same.
  7600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd that which is said here, of the Rights of an Assembly, for the
  7601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgovernment of a Province, or a Colony, is appliable also to an Assembly
  7602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the Government of a Town, or University, or a College, or a Church,
  7603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor for any other Government over the persons of men.
  7604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd generally, in all Bodies Politique, if any particular member
  7606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconceive himself Injured by the Body it self, the Cognisance of his
  7607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcause belongeth to the Soveraign, and those the Soveraign hath ordained
  7608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Judges in such causes, or shall ordaine for that particular cause;
  7609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand not to the Body it self. For the whole Body is in this case his
  7610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfellow subject, which in a Soveraign Assembly, is otherwise: for there,
  7611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif the Soveraign be not Judge, though in his own cause, there can be no
  7612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudge at all.
  7613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBodies Politique For Ordering Of Trade
  7618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn a Bodie Politique, for the well ordering of forraigne Traffique, the
  7620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost commodious Representative is an Assembly of all the members; that
  7621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, such a one, as every one that adventureth his mony, may be
  7622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent at all the Deliberations, and Resolutions of the Body, if they
  7623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill themselves. For proof whereof, we are to consider the end, for
  7624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich men that are Merchants, and may buy and sell, export, and import
  7625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Merchandise, according to their own discretions, doe neverthelesse
  7626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbind themselves up in one Corporation. It is true, there be few
  7627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMerchants, that with the Merchandise they buy at home, can fraight a
  7628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tShip, to export it; or with that they buy abroad, to bring it home; and
  7629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave therefore need to joyn together in one Society; where every man
  7630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay either participate of the gaine, according to the proportion of his
  7631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadventure; or take his own; and sell what he transports, or imports, at
  7632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch prices as he thinks fit. But this is no Body Politique, there being
  7633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno Common Representative to oblige them to any other Law, than that
  7634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is common to all other subjects. The End of their Incorporating,
  7635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to make their gaine the greater; which is done two wayes; by sole
  7636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbuying, and sole selling, both at home, and abroad. So that to grant
  7637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto a Company of Merchants to be a Corporation, or Body Politique, is to
  7638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrant them a double Monopoly, whereof one is to be sole buyers; another
  7639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be sole sellers. For when there is a Company incorporate for any
  7640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular forraign Country, they only export the Commodities vendible
  7641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin that Country; which is sole buying at home, and sole selling abroad.
  7642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor at home there is but one buyer, and abroad but one that selleth:
  7643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth which is gainfull to the Merchant, because thereby they buy at home
  7644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat lower, and sell abroad at higher rates: And abroad there is but one
  7645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbuyer of forraign Merchandise, and but one that sels them at home; both
  7646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich againe are gainfull to the adventurers.
  7647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf this double Monopoly one part is disadvantageous to the people at
  7649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thome, the other to forraigners. For at home by their sole exportation
  7650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey set what price they please on the husbandry and handy-works of
  7651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people; and by the sole importation, what price they please on all
  7652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforraign commodities the people have need of; both which are ill for the
  7653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople. On the contrary, by the sole selling of the native commodities
  7654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabroad, and sole buying the forraign commodities upon the place,
  7655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey raise the price of those, and abate the price of these, to
  7656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe disadvantage of the forraigner: For where but one selleth, the
  7657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMerchandise is the dearer; and where but one buyeth the cheaper: Such
  7658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCorporations therefore are no other then Monopolies; though they would
  7659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe very profitable for a Common-wealth, if being bound up into one body
  7660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin forraigne Markets they were at liberty at home, every man to buy, and
  7661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsell at what price he could.
  7662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe end then of these Bodies of Merchants, being not a Common benefit
  7664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the whole Body, (which have in this case no common stock, but what
  7665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis deducted out of the particular adventures, for building, buying,
  7666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvictualling and manning of Ships,) but the particular gaine of
  7667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery adventurer, it is reason that every one be acquainted with the
  7668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\temployment of his own; that is, that every one be of the Assembly, that
  7669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall have the power to order the same; and be acquainted with their
  7670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccounts. And therefore the Representative of such a Body must be
  7671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Assembly, where every member of the Body may be present at the
  7672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsultations, if he will.
  7673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a Body Politique of Merchants, contract a debt to a stranger by the
  7675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tact of their Representative Assembly, every Member is lyable by himself
  7676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the whole. For a stranger can take no notice of their private Lawes,
  7677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut considereth them as so many particular men, obliged every one to the
  7678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhole payment, till payment made by one dischargeth all the rest: But if
  7679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe debt be to one of the Company, the creditor is debter for the whole
  7680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto himself, and cannot therefore demand his debt, but only from the
  7681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommon stock, if there be any.
  7682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf the Common-wealth impose a Tax upon the Body, it is understood to be
  7684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlayd upon every member proportionably to his particular adventure in the
  7685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCompany. For there is in this case no other common stock, but what is
  7686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade of their particular adventures.
  7687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a Mulct be layd upon the Body for some unlawfull act, they only are
  7689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlyable by whose votes the act was decreed, or by whose assistance it was
  7690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texecuted; for in none of the rest is there any other crime but being
  7691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Body; which if a crime, (because the Body was ordeyned by the
  7692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority of the Common-wealth,) is not his.
  7693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf one of the Members be indebted to the Body, he may be sued by the
  7695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBody; but his goods cannot be taken, nor his person imprisoned by the
  7696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority of the Body; but only by Authority of the Common-wealth:
  7697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor if they can doe it by their own Authority, they can by their own
  7698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority give judgement that the debt is due, which is as much as to be
  7699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudge in their own Cause.
  7700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Bodie Politique For Counsel To Be Give To The Soveraign
  7705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese Bodies made for the government of Men, or of Traffique, be either
  7707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperpetuall, or for a time prescribed by writing. But there be Bodies
  7708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso whose times are limited, and that only by the nature of their
  7709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbusinesse. For example, if a Soveraign Monarch, or a Soveraign Assembly,
  7710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall think fit to give command to the towns, and other severall parts
  7711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their territory, to send to him their Deputies, to enforme him of the
  7712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition, and necessities of the Subjects, or to advise with him for
  7713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe making of good Lawes, or for any other cause, as with one Person
  7714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepresenting the whole Country, such Deputies, having a place and time
  7715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof meeting assigned them, are there, and at that time, a Body Politique,
  7716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepresenting every Subject of that Dominion; but it is onely for such
  7717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmatters as shall be propounded unto them by that Man, or Assembly, that
  7718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Soveraign Authority sent for them; and when it shall be declared
  7719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat nothing more shall be propounded, nor debated by them, the Body is
  7720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdissolved. For if they were the absolute Representative of the people,
  7721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen were it the Soveraign Assembly; and so there would be two Soveraign
  7722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssemblies, or two Soveraigns, over the same people; which cannot
  7723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsist with their Peace. And therefore where there is once a
  7724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty, there can be no absolute Representation of the people, but
  7725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby it. And for the limits of how farre such a Body shall represent the
  7726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhole People, they are set forth in the Writing by which they were sent
  7727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor. For the People cannot choose their Deputies to other intent, than
  7728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis in the Writing directed to them from their Soveraign expressed.
  7729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Regular Private Body, Lawfull, As A Family
  7734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivate Bodies Regular, and Lawfull, are those that are constituted
  7736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout Letters, or other written Authority, saving the Lawes common
  7737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto all other Subjects. And because they be united in one Person
  7738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative, they are held for Regular; such as are all Families, in
  7739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Father, or Master ordereth the whole Family. For he obligeth
  7740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Children, and Servants, as farre as the Law permitteth, though not
  7741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfurther, because none of them are bound to obedience in those actions,
  7742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Law hath forbidden to be done. In all other actions, during
  7743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe time they are under domestique government, they are subject to their
  7744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFathers, and Masters, as to their immediate Soveraigns. For the Father,
  7745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Master being before the Institution of Common-wealth, absolute
  7746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns in their own Families, they lose afterward no more of their
  7747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority, than the Law of the Common-wealth taketh from them.
  7748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivate Bodies Regular, But Unlawfull
  7753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivate Bodies Regular, but Unlawfull, are those that unite themselves
  7755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto one person Representative, without any publique Authority at all;
  7756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as are the Corporations of Beggars, Theeves and Gipsies, the better
  7757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto order their trade of begging, and stealing; and the Corporations of
  7758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, that by Authority from any forraign Person, unite themselves in
  7759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanothers Dominion, for easier propagation of Doctrines, and for making a
  7760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparty, against the Power of the Common-wealth.
  7761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSystemes Irregular, Such As Are Private Leagues
  7766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIrregular Systemes, in their nature, but Leagues, or sometimes meer
  7768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcourse of people, without union to any particular designe, not by
  7769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobligation of one to another, but proceeding onely from a similitude of
  7770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twills and inclinations, become Lawfull, or Unlawfull, according to the
  7771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfulnesse, or unlawfulnesse of every particular mans design therein:
  7772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd his designe is to be understood by the occasion.
  7773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Leagues of Subjects, (because Leagues are commonly made for mutuall
  7775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdefence,) are in a Common-wealth (which is no more than a League of
  7776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall the Subjects together) for the most part unnecessary, and savour of
  7777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunlawfull designe; and are for that cause Unlawfull, and go commonly by
  7778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe name of factions, or Conspiracies. For a League being a connexion of
  7779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen by Covenants, if there be no power given to any one Man or Assembly,
  7780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as in the condition of meer Nature) to compell them to performance,
  7781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis so long onely valid, as there ariseth no just cause of distrust: and
  7782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore Leagues between Common-wealths, over whom there is no humane
  7783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower established, to keep them all in awe, are not onely lawfull, but
  7784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso profitable for the time they last. But Leagues of the Subjects of
  7785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone and the same Common-wealth, where every one may obtain his right
  7786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby means of the Soveraign Power, are unnecessary to the maintaining of
  7787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace and Justice, and (in case the designe of them be evill, or Unknown
  7788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Common-wealth) unlawfull. For all uniting of strength by private
  7789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, is, if for evill intent, unjust; if for intent unknown, dangerous
  7790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Publique, and unjustly concealed.
  7791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecret Cabals
  7796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf the Soveraign Power be in a great Assembly, and a number of men,
  7798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart of the Assembly, without authority, consult a part, to contrive
  7799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe guidance of the rest; This is a Faction, or Conspiracy unlawfull,
  7800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas being a fraudulent seducing of the Assembly for their particular
  7801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterest. But if he, whose private interest is to be debated, and
  7802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudged in the Assembly, make as many friends as he can; in him it is
  7803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno Injustice; because in this case he is no part of the Assembly. And
  7804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough he hire such friends with mony, (unlesse there be an expresse Law
  7805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst it,) yet it is not Injustice. For sometimes, (as mens manners
  7806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare,) Justice cannot be had without mony; and every man may think his
  7807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town cause just, till it be heard, and judged.
  7808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFeuds Of Private Families
  7813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn all Common-wealths, if a private man entertain more servants, than
  7815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe government of his estate, and lawfull employment he has for them
  7816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequires, it is Faction, and unlawfull. For having the protection of the
  7817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, he needeth not the defence of private force. And whereas
  7818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Nations not throughly civilized, severall numerous Families have
  7819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlived in continuall hostility, and invaded one another with private
  7820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforce; yet it is evident enough, that they have done unjustly; or else
  7821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat they had no Common-wealth.
  7822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFactions For Government
  7827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as Factions for Kindred, so also Factions for Government of
  7829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion, as of Papists, Protestants, &c. or of State, as Patricians,
  7830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Plebeians of old time in Rome, and of Aristocraticalls and
  7831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDemocraticalls of old time in Greece, are unjust, as being contrary to
  7832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe peace and safety of the people, and a taking of the Sword out of the
  7833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thand of the Soveraign.
  7834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConcourse of people, is an Irregular Systeme, the lawfulnesse, or
  7836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunlawfulnesse, whereof dependeth on the occasion, and on the number of
  7837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem that are assembled. If the occasion be lawfull, and manifest, the
  7838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConcourse is lawfull; as the usuall meeting of men at Church, or at a
  7839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublique Shew, in usuall numbers: for if the numbers be extraordinarily
  7840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat, the occasion is not evident; and consequently he that cannot
  7841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trender a particular and good account of his being amongst them, is to
  7842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe judged conscious of an unlawfull, and tumultuous designe. It may be
  7843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfull for a thousand men, to joyn in a Petition to be delivered to a
  7844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudge, or Magistrate; yet if a thousand men come to present it, it is
  7845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta tumultuous Assembly; because there needs but one or two for that
  7846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpurpose. But in such cases as these, it is not a set number that makes
  7847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Assembly Unlawfull, but such a number, as the present Officers are
  7848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot able to suppresse, and bring to Justice.
  7849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen an unusuall number of men, assemble against a man whom they accuse;
  7851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Assembly is an Unlawfull tumult; because they may deliver their
  7852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccusation to the Magistrate by a few, or by one man. Such was the case
  7853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof St. Paul at Ephesus; where Demetrius, and a great number of other
  7854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, brought two of Pauls companions before the Magistrate, saying with
  7855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone Voyce, "Great is Diana of the Ephesians;" which was their way of
  7856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdemanding Justice against them for teaching the people such doctrine,
  7857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas was against their Religion, and Trade. The occasion here, considering
  7858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Lawes of that People, was just; yet was their Assembly Judged
  7859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUnlawfull, and the Magistrate reprehended them for it, in these
  7860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords,(Acts 19. 40) "If Demetrius and the other work-men can accuse any
  7861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, of any thing, there be Pleas, and Deputies, let them accuse one
  7862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother. And if you have any other thing to demand, your case may
  7863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe judged in an Assembly Lawfully called. For we are in danger to be
  7864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccused for this dayes sedition, because, there is no cause by which any
  7865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman can render any reason of this Concourse of People." Where he calleth
  7866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Assembly, whereof men can give no just account, a Sedition, and such
  7867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they could not answer for. And this is all I shall say concerning
  7868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSystemes, and Assemblyes of People, which may be compared (as I said,)
  7869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Similar parts of mans Body; such as be Lawfull, to the Muscles;
  7870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as are Unlawfull, to Wens, Biles, and Apostemes, engendred by the
  7871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunnaturall conflux of evill humours.
  7872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXIII. OF THE PUBLIQUE MINISTERS OF SOVERAIGN POWER
  7876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the last Chapter I have spoken of the Similar parts of a
  7879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; In this I shall speak of the parts Organicall, which are
  7880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Ministers.
  7881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Minister Who
  7886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA PUBLIQUE MINISTER, is he, that by the Soveraign, (whether a Monarch,
  7888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor an Assembly,) is employed in any affaires, with Authority to
  7889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepresent in that employment, the Person of the Common-wealth. And
  7890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereas every man, or assembly that hath Soveraignty, representeth
  7891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttwo Persons, or (as the more common phrase is) has two Capacities, one
  7892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall, and another Politique, (as a Monarch, hath the person not
  7893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely of the Common-wealth, but also of a man; and a Soveraign Assembly
  7894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath the Person not onely of the Common-wealth, but also of the
  7895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly); they that be servants to them in their naturall Capacity,
  7896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not Publique Ministers; but those onely that serve them in the
  7897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdministration of the Publique businesse. And therefore neither Ushers,
  7898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor Sergeants, nor other Officers that waite on the Assembly, for
  7899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno other purpose, but for the commodity of the men assembled, in an
  7900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAristocracy, or Democracy; nor Stewards, Chamberlains, Cofferers, or any
  7901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Officers of the houshold of a Monarch, are Publique Ministers in a
  7902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarchy.
  7903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters For The Generall Administration
  7908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Publique Ministers, some have charge committed to them of a general
  7910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdministration, either of the whole Dominion, or of a part thereof.
  7911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf the whole, as to a Protector, or Regent, may bee committed by
  7912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Predecessor of an Infant King, during his minority, the whole
  7913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdministration of his Kingdome. In which case, every Subject is so far
  7914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobliged to obedience, as the Ordinances he shall make, and the commands
  7915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the shall give be in the Kings name, and not inconsistent with his
  7916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne Power. Of a Part, or Province; as when either a Monarch, or
  7917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Soveraign Assembly, shall give the generall charge thereof to a
  7918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernour, Lieutenant, Praefect, or Vice-Roy: And in this case also,
  7919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one of that Province, is obliged to all he shall doe in the name
  7920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Soveraign, and that not incompatible with the Soveraigns Right.
  7921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor such Protectors, Vice-Roys, and Governours, have no other right, but
  7922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat depends on the Soveraigns Will; and no Commission that can be given
  7923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, can be interpreted for a Declaration of the will to transferre the
  7924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty, without expresse and perspicuous words to that purpose. And
  7925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis kind of Publique Ministers resembleth the Nerves, and Tendons that
  7926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmove the severall limbs of a body naturall.
  7927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor Speciall Administration, As For Oeconomy
  7932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOthers have speciall Administration; that is to say, charges of some
  7934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeciall businesse, either at home, or abroad: As at home, First, for
  7935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Oeconomy of a Common-wealth, They that have Authority concerning the
  7936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTreasure, as Tributes, Impositions, Rents, Fines, or whatsoever publique
  7937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trevenue, to collect, receive, issue, or take the Accounts thereof,
  7938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Publique Ministers: Ministers, because they serve the Person
  7939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative, and can doe nothing against his Command, nor without his
  7940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority: Publique, because they serve him in his Politicall Capacity.
  7941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, they that have Authority concerning the Militia; to have the
  7943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcustody of Armes, Forts, Ports; to Levy, Pay, or Conduct Souldiers; or
  7944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto provide for any necessary thing for the use of war, either by Land or
  7945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSea, are publique Ministers. But a Souldier without Command, though he
  7946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfight for the Common-wealth, does not therefore represent the Person of
  7947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit; because there is none to represent it to. For every one that hath
  7948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommand, represents it to them only whom he commandeth.
  7949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor Instruction Of The People
  7954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThey also that have authority to teach, or to enable others to teach
  7956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people their duty to the Soveraign Power, and instruct them in the
  7957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknowledge of what is just, and unjust, thereby to render them more apt
  7958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto live in godlinesse, and in peace among themselves, and resist the
  7959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublique enemy, are Publique Ministers: Ministers, in that they doe it
  7960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot by their own Authority, but by anothers; and Publique, because they
  7961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoe it (or should doe it) by no Authority, but that of the Soveraign.
  7962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Monarch, or the Soveraign Assembly only hath immediate Authority
  7963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom God, to teach and instruct the people; and no man but the
  7964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, receiveth his power Dei Gratia simply; that is to say, from
  7965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe favour of none but God: All other, receive theirs from the favour
  7966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand providence of God, and their Soveraigns; as in a Monarchy Dei Gratia
  7967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t& Regis; or Dei Providentia & Voluntate Regis.
  7968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor Judicature
  7973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThey also to whom Jurisdiction is given, are Publique Ministers. For in
  7975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Seats of Justice they represent the person of the Soveraign; and
  7976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Sentence, is his Sentence; For (as hath been before declared) all
  7977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudicature is essentially annexed to the Soveraignty; and therefore all
  7978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Judges are but Ministers of him, or them that have the Soveraign
  7979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower. And as Controversies are of two sorts, namely of Fact, and of
  7980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw; so are judgements, some of Fact, some of Law: And consequently in
  7981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same controversie, there may be two Judges, one of Fact, another of
  7982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw.
  7983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  7984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd in both these controversies, there may arise a controversie between
  7985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe party Judged, and the Judge; which because they be both Subjects to
  7986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign, ought in Equity to be Judged by men agreed on by consent
  7987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof both; for no man can be Judge in his own cause. But the Soveraign
  7988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis already agreed on for Judge by them both, and is therefore either to
  7989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theare the Cause, and determine it himself, or appoint for Judge such as
  7990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey shall both agree on. And this agreement is then understood to be
  7991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade between them divers wayes; as first, if the Defendant be allowed
  7992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto except against such of his Judges, whose interest maketh him suspect
  7993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, (for as to the Complaynant he hath already chosen his own Judge,)
  7994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose which he excepteth not against, are Judges he himself agrees on.
  7995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, if he appeale to any other Judge, he can appeale no further;
  7996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor his appeale is his choice. Thirdly, if he appeale to the Soveraign
  7997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself, and he by himself, or by Delegates which the parties shall
  7998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagree on, give Sentence; that Sentence is finall: for the Defendant is
  7999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudged by his own Judges, that is to say, by himself.
  8000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese properties of just and rationall Judicature considered, I cannot
  8002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforbeare to observe the excellent constitution of the Courts of Justice,
  8003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\testablished both for Common, and also for Publique Pleas in England. By
  8004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon Pleas, I meane those, where both the Complaynant and Defendant
  8005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Subjects: and by Publique, (which are also called Pleas of the
  8006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrown) those, where the Complaynant is the Soveraign. For whereas there
  8007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere two orders of men, whereof one was Lords, the other Commons; The
  8008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLords had this Priviledge, to have for Judges in all Capitall crimes,
  8009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone but Lords; and of them, as many as would be present; which being
  8010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tever acknowledged as a Priviledge of favour, their Judges were none but
  8011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as they had themselves desired. And in all controversies, every
  8012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubject (as also in civill controversies the Lords) had for Judges, men
  8013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Country where the matter in controversie lay; against which he
  8014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmight make his exceptions, till at last Twelve men without exception
  8015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing agreed on, they were Judged by those twelve. So that having
  8016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own Judges, there could be nothing alledged by the party, why the
  8017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsentence should not be finall, These publique persons, with Authority
  8018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Soveraign Power, either to Instruct, or Judge the people,
  8019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare such members of the Common-wealth, as may fitly be compared to the
  8020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\torgans of Voice in a Body naturall.
  8021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor Execution
  8026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Ministers are also all those, that have Authority from the
  8028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, to procure the Execution of Judgements given; to publish the
  8029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns Commands; to suppresse Tumults; to apprehend, and imprison
  8030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMalefactors; and other acts tending to the conservation of the
  8031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace. For every act they doe by such Authority, is the act of the
  8032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; and their service, answerable to that of the Hands, in a
  8033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBodie naturall.
  8034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Ministers abroad, are those that represent the Person of their
  8036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town Soveraign, to forraign States. Such are Ambassadors, Messengers,
  8037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgents, and Heralds, sent by publique Authoritie, and on publique
  8038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBusinesse.
  8039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut such as are sent by Authoritie only of some private partie of a
  8041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttroubled State, though they be received, are neither Publique, nor
  8042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivate Ministers of the Common-wealth; because none of their actions
  8043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave the Common-wealth for Author. Likewise, an Ambassador sent from a
  8044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrince, to congratulate, condole, or to assist at a solemnity, though
  8045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority be Publique; yet because the businesse is Private, and
  8046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbelonging to him in his naturall capacity; is a Private person. Also if
  8047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man be sent into another Country, secretly to explore their counsels,
  8048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand strength; though both the Authority, and the Businesse be Publique;
  8049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet because there is none to take notice of any Person in him, but
  8050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own; he is but a Private Minister; but yet a Minister of the
  8051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; and may be compared to an Eye in the Body naturall. And
  8052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that are appointed to receive the Petitions or other informations
  8053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the People, and are as it were the publique Eare, are Publique
  8054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters, and represent their Soveraign in that office.
  8055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsellers Without Other Employment Then To Advise
  8060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAre Not Publique Ministers
  8062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeither a Counsellor, nor a Councell of State, if we consider it with
  8064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno Authority of Judicature or Command, but only of giving Advice to
  8065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign when it is required, or of offering it when it is not
  8066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequired, is a Publique Person. For the Advice is addressed to the
  8067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign only, whose person cannot in his own presence, be represented
  8068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto him, by another. But a Body of Counsellors, are never without some
  8069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Authority, either of Judicature, or of immediate Administration:
  8070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs in a Monarchy, they represent the Monarch, in delivering his Commands
  8071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Publique Ministers: In a Democracy, the Councell, or Senate
  8072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpropounds the Result of their deliberations to the people, as a
  8073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCouncell; but when they appoint Judges, or heare Causes, or give
  8074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAudience to Ambassadors, it is in the quality of a Minister of the
  8075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeople: And in an Aristocracy the Councell of State is the Soveraign
  8076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly it self; and gives counsell to none but themselves.
  8077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXIV. OF THE NUTRITION, AND PROCREATION OF A COMMON-WEALTH
  8081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Nourishment Of A Common-wealth Consisteth In The Commodities
  8085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Sea And Land
  8087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe NUTRITION of a Common-wealth consisteth, in the Plenty, and
  8089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDistribution of Materials conducing to Life: In Concoction, or
  8090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPreparation; and (when concocted) in the Conveyance of it, by convenient
  8091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconduits, to the Publique use.
  8092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for the Plenty of Matter, it is a thing limited by Nature, to those
  8094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommodities, which from (the two breasts of our common Mother) Land,
  8095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Sea, God usually either freely giveth, or for labour selleth to
  8096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman-kind.
  8097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the Matter of this Nutriment, consisting in Animals, Vegetals, and
  8099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinerals, God hath freely layd them before us, in or neer to the face of
  8100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Earth; so as there needeth no more but the labour, and industry
  8101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof receiving them. Insomuch as Plenty dependeth (next to Gods favour)
  8102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeerly on the labour and industry of men.
  8103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis Matter, commonly called Commodities, is partly Native, and partly
  8105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tForraign: Native, that which is to be had within the Territory of
  8106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Common-wealth; Forraign, that which is imported from without. And
  8107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause there is no Territory under the Dominion of one Common-wealth,
  8108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(except it be of very vast extent,) that produceth all things needfull
  8109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the maintenance, and motion of the whole Body; and few that produce
  8110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot something more than necessary; the superfluous commodities to be had
  8111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithin, become no more superfluous, but supply these wants at home, by
  8112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timportation of that which may be had abroad, either by Exchange, or
  8113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby just Warre, or by Labour: for a mans Labour also, is a commodity
  8114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texchangeable for benefit, as well as any other thing: And there have
  8115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen Common-wealths that having no more Territory, than hath served
  8116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem for habitation, have neverthelesse, not onely maintained, but also
  8117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tencreased their Power, partly by the labour of trading from one place to
  8118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, and partly by selling the Manifactures, whereof the Materials
  8119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere brought in from other places.
  8120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd The Right Of Distribution Of Them
  8125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Distribution of the Materials of this Nourishment, is the
  8127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstitution of Mine, and Thine, and His, that is to say, in one word
  8128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPropriety; and belongeth in all kinds of Common-wealth to the Soveraign
  8129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower. For where there is no Common-wealth, there is, (as hath been
  8130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready shewn) a perpetuall warre of every man against his neighbour;
  8131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore every thing is his that getteth it, and keepeth it by
  8132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforce; which is neither Propriety nor Community; but Uncertainty. Which
  8133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis so evident, that even Cicero, (a passionate defender of Liberty,) in
  8134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta publique pleading, attributeth all Propriety to the Law Civil, "Let
  8135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Civill Law," saith he, "be once abandoned, or but negligently
  8136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tguarded, (not to say oppressed,) and there is nothing, that any man can
  8137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe sure to receive from his Ancestor, or leave to his Children." And
  8138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain; "Take away the Civill Law, and no man knows what is his own, and
  8139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat another mans." Seeing therefore the Introduction of Propriety is
  8140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan effect of Common-wealth; which can do nothing but by the Person that
  8141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresents it, it is the act onely of the Soveraign; and consisteth in
  8142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Lawes, which none can make that have not the Soveraign Power. And
  8143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis they well knew of old, who called that Nomos, (that is to say,
  8144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDistribution,) which we call Law; and defined Justice, by distributing
  8145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto every man his own.
  8146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll Private Estates Of Land Proceed Originally
  8151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom The Arbitrary Distribution Of The Soveraign
  8153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn this Distribution, the First Law, is for Division of the Land it
  8155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tselfe: wherein the Soveraign assigneth to every man a portion, according
  8156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas he, and not according as any Subject, or any number of them, shall
  8157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudge agreeable to Equity, and the Common Good. The Children of Israel,
  8158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere a Common-wealth in the Wildernesse; but wanted the commodities
  8159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Earth, till they were masters of the Land of Promise; which
  8160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafterward was divided amongst them, not by their own discretion, but
  8161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the discretion of Eleazar the Priest, and Joshua their Generall: who
  8162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen there were twelve Tribes, making them thirteen by subdivision of
  8163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Tribe of Joseph; made neverthelesse but twelve portions of the Land;
  8164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand ordained for the Tribe of Levi no land; but assigned them the Tenth
  8165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart of the whole fruits; which division was therefore Arbitrary. And
  8166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough a People comming into possession of a land by warre, do not
  8167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talwaies exterminate the antient Inhabitants, (as did the Jewes,) but
  8168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleave to many, or most, or all of them their Estates; yet it is manifest
  8169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey hold them afterwards, as of the Victors distribution; as the people
  8170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof England held all theirs of William the Conquerour.
  8171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPropriety Of A Subject Excludes Not The Dominion Of The Soveraign,
  8176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut Onely Of Another Subject
  8178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom whence we may collect, that the Propriety which a subject hath in
  8180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this lands, consisteth in a right to exclude all other subjects from the
  8181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuse of them; and not to exclude their Soveraign, be it an Assembly, or
  8182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Monarch. For seeing the Soveraign, that is to say, the Common-wealth
  8183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(whose Person he representeth,) is understood to do nothing but in order
  8184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the common Peace and Security, this Distribution of lands, is to be
  8185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood as done in order to the same: And consequently, whatsoever
  8186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDistribution he shall make in prejudice thereof, is contrary to the
  8187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill of every subject, that committed his Peace, and safety to his
  8188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscretion, and conscience; and therefore by the will of every one of
  8189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, is to be reputed voyd. It is true, that a Soveraign Monarch, or
  8190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe greater part of a Soveraign Assembly, may ordain the doing of many
  8191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings in pursuit of their Passions, contrary to their own consciences,
  8192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is a breach of trust, and of the Law of Nature; but this is not
  8193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenough to authorise any subject, either to make warre upon, or so much
  8194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas to accuse of Injustice, or any way to speak evill of their Soveraign;
  8195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause they have authorised all his actions, and in bestowing the
  8196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power, made them their own. But in what cases the Commands
  8197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Soveraigns are contrary to Equity, and the Law of Nature, is to be
  8198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsidered hereafter in another place.
  8199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Publique Is Not To Be Dieted
  8204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the Distribution of land, the Common-wealth it selfe, may be
  8206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconceived to have a portion, and possesse, and improve the same by
  8207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Representative; and that such portion may be made sufficient, to
  8208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsusteine the whole expence to the common Peace, and defence necessarily
  8209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequired: Which were very true, if there could be any Representative
  8210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconceived free from humane passions, and infirmities. But the nature
  8211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men being as it is, the setting forth of Publique Land, or of any
  8212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcertaine Revenue for the Common-wealth, is in vaine; and tendeth to the
  8213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdissolution of Government, and to the condition of meere Nature, and
  8214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWar, assoon as ever the Soveraign Power falleth into the hands of a
  8215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarch, or of an Assembly, that are either too negligent of mony, or
  8216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttoo hazardous in engaging the publique stock, into a long, or costly
  8217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twar. Common-wealths can endure no Diet: For seeing their expence is
  8218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot limited by their own appetite, but by externall Accidents, and the
  8219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappetites of their neighbours, the Publique Riches cannot be limited by
  8220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother limits, than those which the emergent occasions shall require. And
  8221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereas in England, there were by the Conquerour, divers Lands
  8222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treserved to his own use, (besides Forrests, and Chases, either for his
  8223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trecreation, or for preservation of Woods,) and divers services reserved
  8224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton the Land he gave his Subjects; yet it seems they were not reserved
  8225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor his Maintenance in his Publique, but in his Naturall capacity: For
  8226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the, and his Successors did for all that, lay Arbitrary Taxes on all
  8227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects land, when they judged it necessary. Or if those publique
  8228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLands, and Services, were ordained as a sufficient maintenance of the
  8229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, it was contrary to the scope of the Institution; being
  8230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as it appeared by those ensuing Taxes) insufficient, and (as it
  8231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappeares by the late Revenue of the Crown) Subject to Alienation,
  8232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Diminution. It is therefore in vaine, to assign a portion to the
