  8233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; which may sell, or give it away; and does sell, and give
  8234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit away when tis done by their Representative.
  8235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Places And Matter Of Traffique Depend, As Their Distribution,
  8240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOn The Soveraign
  8242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs the Distribution of Lands at home; so also to assigne in what places,
  8244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand for what commodities, the Subject shall traffique abroad, belongeth
  8245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Soveraign. For if it did belong to private persons to use their
  8246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town discretion therein, some of them would bee drawn for gaine, both
  8247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto furnish the enemy with means to hurt the Common-wealth, and hurt it
  8248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, by importing such things, as pleasing mens appetites, be
  8249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse noxious, or at least unprofitable to them. And therefore
  8250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit belongeth to the Common-wealth, (that is, to the Soveraign only,)
  8251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto approve, or disapprove both of the places, and matter of forraign
  8252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTraffique.
  8253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Laws Of Transferring Property Belong Also To The Soveraign
  8258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFurther, seeing it is not enough to the Sustentation of a Common-wealth,
  8260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat every man have a propriety in a portion of Land, or in some few
  8261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommodities, or a naturall property in some usefull art, and there is no
  8262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tart in the world, but is necessary either for the being, or well being
  8263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talmost of every particular man; it is necessary, that men distribute
  8264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which they can spare, and transferre their propriety therein,
  8265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmutually one to another, by exchange, and mutuall contract. And
  8266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore it belongeth to the Common-wealth, (that is to say, to the
  8267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign,) to appoint in what manner, all kinds of contract between
  8268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects, (as buying, selling, exchanging, borrowing, lending, letting,
  8269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand taking to hire,) are to bee made; and by what words, and signes they
  8270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be understood for valid. And for the Matter, and Distribution of
  8271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Nourishment, to the severall Members of the Common-wealth, thus much
  8272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(considering the modell of the whole worke) is sufficient.
  8273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMony The Bloud Of A Common-wealth
  8278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Concoction, I understand the reducing of all commodities, which are
  8280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot presently consumed, but reserved for Nourishment in time to come, to
  8281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome thing of equal value, and withall so portably, as not to hinder
  8282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe motion of men from place to place; to the end a man may have in
  8283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat place soever, such Nourishment as the place affordeth. And this is
  8284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnothing else but Gold, and Silver, and Mony. For Gold and Silver, being
  8285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as it happens) almost in all Countries of the world highly valued, is a
  8286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommodious measure for the value of all things else between Nations; and
  8287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMony (of what matter soever coyned by the Soveraign of a Common-wealth,)
  8288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a sufficient measure of the value of all things else, between the
  8289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects of that Common-wealth. By the means of which measures, all
  8290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommodities, Moveable, and Immoveable, are made to accompany a man, to
  8291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall places of his resort, within and without the place of his
  8292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordinary residence; and the same passeth from Man to Man, within the
  8293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; and goes round about, Nourishing (as it passeth)
  8294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery part thereof; In so much as this Concoction, is as it were the
  8295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSanguification of the Common-wealth: For naturall Bloud is in like
  8296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner made of the fruits of the Earth; and circulating, nourisheth by
  8297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe way, every Member of the Body of Man.
  8298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because Silver and Gold, have their value from the matter it self;
  8300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey have first this priviledge, that the value of them cannot be
  8301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taltered by the power of one, nor of a few Common-wealths; as being a
  8302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommon measure of the commodities of all places. But base Mony, may
  8303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teasily be enhanced, or abased. Secondly, they have the priviledge to
  8304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake Common-wealths, move, and stretch out their armes, when need is,
  8305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto forraign Countries; and supply, not only private Subjects that
  8306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttravell, but also whole Armies with provision. But that Coyne, which is
  8307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot considerable for the Matter, but for the Stamp of the place, being
  8308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunable to endure change of ayr, hath its effect at home only; where
  8309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso it is subject to the change of Laws, and thereby to have the value
  8310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiminished, to the prejudice many times of those that have it.
  8311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Conduits And Way Of Mony To The Publique Use
  8316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Conduits, and Wayes by which it is conveyed to the Publique use, are
  8318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof two sorts; One, that Conveyeth it to the Publique Coffers; The other,
  8319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Issueth the same out againe for publique payments. Of the first
  8320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsort, are Collectors, Receivers, and Treasurers; of the second are the
  8321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTreasurers againe, and the Officers appointed for payment of severall
  8322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublique or private Ministers. And in this also, the Artificiall Man
  8323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmaintains his resemblance with the Naturall; whose Veins receiving the
  8324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBloud from the severall Parts of the Body, carry it to the Heart; where
  8325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing made Vitall, the Heart by the Arteries sends it out again, to
  8326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenliven, and enable for motion all the Members of the same.
  8327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Children Of A Common-wealth Colonies
  8332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Procreation, or Children of a Common-wealth, are those we call
  8334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPlantations, or Colonies; which are numbers of men sent out from the
  8335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, under a Conductor, or Governour, to inhabit a Forraign
  8336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCountry, either formerly voyd of Inhabitants, or made voyd then, by
  8337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twarre. And when a Colony is setled, they are either a Common-wealth of
  8338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, discharged of their subjection to their Soveraign that sent
  8339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, (as hath been done by many Common-wealths of antient time,) in
  8340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich case the Common-wealth from which they went was called their
  8341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMetropolis, or Mother, and requires no more of them, then Fathers
  8342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequire of the Children, whom they emancipate, and make free from their
  8343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdomestique government, which is Honour, and Friendship; or else they
  8344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tremain united to their Metropolis, as were the Colonies of the people of
  8345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRome; and then they are no Common-wealths themselves, but Provinces, and
  8346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparts of the Common-wealth that sent them. So that the Right of Colonies
  8347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(saving Honour, and League with their Metropolis,) dependeth wholly on
  8348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Licence, or Letters, by which their Soveraign authorised them to
  8349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPlant.
  8350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXV. OF COUNSELL
  8354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell What
  8359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHow fallacious it is to judge of the nature of things, by the ordinary
  8361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand inconstant use of words, appeareth in nothing more, than in the
  8362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconfusion of Counsels, and Commands, arising from the Imperative manner
  8363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof speaking in them both, and in may other occasions besides. For the
  8364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords "Doe this," are the words not onely of him that Commandeth; but
  8365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso of him that giveth Counsell; and of him that Exhorteth; and yet
  8366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere are but few, that see not, that these are very different things;
  8367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor that cannot distinguish between them, when they perceive who it
  8368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis that speaketh, and to whom the Speech is directed, and upon what
  8369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toccasion. But finding those phrases in mens writings, and being not
  8370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\table, or not willing to enter into a consideration of the circumstances,
  8371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey mistake sometimes the Precepts of Counsellours, for the Precepts
  8372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them that command; and sometimes the contrary; according as it best
  8373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagreeth with the conclusions they would inferre, or the actions
  8374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey approve. To avoyd which mistakes, and render to those termes
  8375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Commanding, Counselling, and Exhorting, their proper and distinct
  8376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifications, I define them thus.
  8377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDifferences Between Command And Counsell
  8382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCOMMAND is, where a man saith, "Doe this," or "Doe this not," without
  8384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpecting other reason than the Will of him that sayes it. From this it
  8385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfolloweth manifestly, that he that Commandeth, pretendeth thereby his
  8386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town Benefit: For the reason of his Command is his own Will onely, and
  8387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe proper object of every mans Will, is some Good to himselfe.
  8388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCOUNSELL, is where a man saith, "Doe" or "Doe not this," and deduceth
  8390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own reasons from the benefit that arriveth by it to him to whom he
  8391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaith it. And from this it is evident, that he that giveth Counsell,
  8392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretendeth onely (whatsoever he intendeth) the good of him, to whom he
  8393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiveth it.
  8394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore between Counsell and Command, one great difference is, that
  8396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommand is directed to a mans own benefit; and Counsell to the benefit
  8397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof another man. And from this ariseth another difference, that a man
  8398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay be obliged to do what he is Commanded; as when he hath covenanted
  8399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey: But he cannot be obliged to do as he is Counselled, because the
  8400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thurt of not following it, is his own; or if he should covenant to follow
  8401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, then is the Counsell turned into the nature of a Command. A third
  8402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifference between them is, that no man can pretend a right to be of
  8403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother mans Counsell; because he is not to pretend benefit by it to
  8404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe; but to demand right to Counsell another, argues a will to know
  8405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this designes, or to gain some other Good to himselfe; which (as I said
  8406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore) is of every mans will the proper object.
  8407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis also is incident to the nature of Counsell; that whatsoever it be,
  8409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the that asketh it, cannot in equity accuse, or punish it: For to ask
  8410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell of another, is to permit him to give such Counsell as he shall
  8411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthink best; And consequently, he that giveth counsell to his Soveraign,
  8412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(whether a Monarch, or an Assembly) when he asketh it, cannot in equity
  8413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe punished for it, whether the same be conformable to the opinion of
  8414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe most, or not, so it be to the Proposition in debate. For if the
  8415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense of the Assembly can be taken notice of, before the Debate be
  8416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tended, they should neither ask, nor take any further Counsell; For the
  8417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSense of the Assembly, is the Resolution of the Debate, and End of all
  8418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeliberation. And generally he that demandeth Counsell, is Author of it;
  8419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore cannot punish it; and what the Soveraign cannot, no man
  8420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\telse can. But if one Subject giveth Counsell to another, to do any
  8421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing contrary to the Lawes, whether that Counsell proceed from
  8422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevill intention, or from ignorance onely, it is punishable by the
  8423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; because ignorance of the Law, is no good excuse, where
  8424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery man is bound to take notice of the Lawes to which he is subject.
  8425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExhortation And Dehortation What
  8430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEXHORTATION, and DEHORTATION, is Counsell, accompanied with signes in
  8432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim that giveth it, of vehement desire to have it followed; or to say it
  8433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore briefly, Counsell Vehemently Pressed. For he that Exhorteth, doth
  8434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot deduce the consequences of what he adviseth to be done, and tye
  8435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe therein to the rigour of true reasoning; but encourages him he
  8436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounselleth, to Action: As he that Dehorteth, deterreth him from it. And
  8437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore they have in their speeches, a regard to the common Passions,
  8438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand opinions of men, in deducing their reasons; and make use of
  8439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSimilitudes, Metaphors, Examples, and other tooles of Oratory, to
  8440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperswade their Hearers of the Utility, Honour, or Justice of following
  8441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir advise.
  8442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom whence may be inferred, First, that Exhortation and Dehortation,
  8444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis directed to the Good of him that giveth the Counsell, not of him that
  8445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tasketh it, which is contrary to the duty of a Counsellour; who (by the
  8446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdefinition of Counsell) ought to regard, not his own benefits, but his
  8447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom he adviseth. And that he directeth his Counsell to his own
  8448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbenefit, is manifest enough, by the long and vehement urging, or by
  8449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe artificial giving thereof; which being not required of him, and
  8450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently proceeding from his own occasions, is directed principally
  8451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto his own benefit, and but accidentarily to the good of him that is
  8452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounselled, or not at all.
  8453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, that the use of Exhortation and Dehortation lyeth onely, where
  8455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man is to speak to a Multitude; because when the Speech is addressed
  8456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto one, he may interrupt him, and examine his reasons more rigorously,
  8457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan can be done in a Multitude; which are too many to enter into
  8458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDispute, and Dialogue with him that speaketh indifferently to them
  8459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall at once. Thirdly, that they that Exhort and Dehort, where they are
  8460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequired to give Counsell, are corrupt Counsellours, and as it were
  8461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbribed by their own interest. For though the Counsell they give be never
  8462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso good; yet he that gives it, is no more a good Counsellour, than he
  8463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat giveth a Just Sentence for a reward, is a just Judge. But where a
  8464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman may lawfully Command, as a Father in his Family, or a Leader in an
  8465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArmy, his Exhortations and Dehortations, are not onely lawfull, but
  8466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso necessary, and laudable: But then they are no more Counsells, but
  8467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommands; which when they are for Execution of soure labour; sometimes
  8468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessity, and alwayes humanity requireth to be sweetned in the
  8469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdelivery, by encouragement, and in the tune and phrase of Counsell,
  8470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trather then in harsher language of Command.
  8471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExamples of the difference between Command and Counsell, we may take
  8473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the formes of Speech that expresse them in Holy Scripture. "Have no
  8474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Gods but me; Make to thy selfe no graven Image; Take not Gods name
  8475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin vain; Sanctifie the Sabbath; Honour thy Parents; Kill not; Steale
  8476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot," &c. are Commands; because the reason for which we are to obey
  8477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, is drawn from the will of God our King, whom we are obliged to
  8478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobey. But these words, "Sell all thou hast; give it to the poore; and
  8479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollow me," are Counsell; because the reason for which we are to do
  8480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso, is drawn from our own benefit; which is this, that we shall have
  8481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Treasure in Heaven." These words, "Go into the village over against
  8482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyou, and you shall find an Asse tyed, and her Colt; loose her, and bring
  8483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ther to me," are a Command: for the reason of their fact is drawn from
  8484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe will of their Master: but these words, "Repent, and be Baptized in
  8485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Name of Jesus," are Counsell; because the reason why we should so
  8486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo, tendeth not to any benefit of God Almighty, who shall still be King
  8487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin what manner soever we rebell; but of our selves, who have no other
  8488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeans of avoyding the punishment hanging over us for our sins.
  8489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDifferences Of Fit And Unfit Counsellours
  8494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs the difference of Counsell from Command, hath been now deduced from
  8496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe nature of Counsell, consisting in a deducing of the benefit, or
  8497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thurt that may arise to him that is to be Counselled, by the necessary
  8498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor probable consequences of the action he propoundeth; so may also the
  8499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifferences between apt, and inept counsellours be derived from the
  8500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame. For Experience, being but Memory of the consequences of like
  8501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions formerly observed, and Counsell but the Speech whereby that
  8502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texperience is made known to another; the Vertues, and Defects of
  8503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell, are the same with the Vertues, and Defects Intellectuall:
  8504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd to the Person of a Common-wealth, his Counsellours serve him in the
  8505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace of Memory, and Mentall Discourse. But with this resemblance of the
  8506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, to a naturall man, there is one dissimilitude joyned,
  8507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof great importance; which is, that a naturall man receiveth his
  8508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texperience, from the naturall objects of sense, which work upon him
  8509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout passion, or interest of their own; whereas they that give
  8510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell to the Representative person of a Common-wealth, may have,
  8511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand have often their particular ends, and passions, that render their
  8512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsells alwayes suspected, and many times unfaithfull. And therefore
  8513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe may set down for the first condition of a good Counsellour, That His
  8514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnds, And Interest, Be Not Inconsistent With The Ends And Interest Of
  8515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHim He Counselleth.
  8516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, Because the office of a Counsellour, when an action comes
  8518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto deliberation, is to make manifest the consequences of it, in such
  8519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner, as he that is Counselled may be truly and evidently informed; he
  8520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought to propound his advise, in such forme of speech, as may make
  8521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe truth most evidently appear; that is to say, with as firme
  8522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tratiocination, as significant and proper language, and as briefly, as
  8523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe evidence will permit. And therefore Rash, And Unevident Inferences;
  8524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(such as are fetched onely from Examples, or authority of Books, and are
  8525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot arguments of what is good, or evill, but witnesses of fact, or
  8526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof opinion,) Obscure, Confused, And Ambiguous Expressions, Also All
  8527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMetaphoricall Speeches, Tending To The Stirring Up Of Passion, (because
  8528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch reasoning, and such expressions, are usefull onely to deceive, or
  8529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto lead him we Counsell towards other ends than his own) Are Repugnant
  8530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo The Office Of A Counsellour.
  8531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, Because the Ability of Counselling proceedeth from Experience,
  8533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand long study; and no man is presumed to have experience in all those
  8534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings that to the Administration of a great Common-wealth are necessary
  8535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be known, No Man Is Presumed To Be A Good Counsellour, But In Such
  8536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBusinesse, As He Hath Not Onely Been Much Versed In, But Hath Also
  8537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMuch Meditated On, And Considered. For seeing the businesse of a
  8538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth is this, to preserve the people at home, and defend them
  8539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst forraign Invasion, we shall find, it requires great knowledge
  8540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the disposition of Man-kind, of the Rights of Government, and of the
  8541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnature of Equity, Law, Justice, and Honour, not to be attained without
  8542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstudy; And of the Strength, Commodities, Places, both of their own
  8543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCountry, and their Neighbours; as also of the inclinations, and designes
  8544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof all Nations that may any way annoy them. And this is not attained to,
  8545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout much experience. Of which things, not onely the whole summe, but
  8546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one of the particulars requires the age, and observation of a man
  8547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin years, and of more than ordinary study. The wit required for Counsel,
  8548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas I have said before is Judgement. And the differences of men in that
  8549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpoint come from different education, of some to one kind of study, or
  8550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbusinesse, and of others to another. When for the doing of any thing,
  8551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere be Infallible rules, (as in Engines, and Edifices, the rules of
  8552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGeometry,) all the experience of the world cannot equall his Counsell,
  8553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat has learnt, or found out the Rule. And when there is no such Rule,
  8554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the that hath most experience in that particular kind of businesse, has
  8555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherein the best Judgement, and is the best Counsellour.
  8556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, to be able to give Counsell to a Common-wealth, in a businesse
  8558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat hath reference to another Common-wealth, It Is Necessary To Be
  8559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAcquainted With The Intelligences, And Letters That Come From Thence,
  8560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd With All The Records Of Treaties, And Other Transactions Of State
  8561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBetween Them; which none can doe, but such as the Representative
  8562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall think fit. By which we may see, that they who are not called to
  8563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell, can have no good Counsell in such cases to obtrude.
  8564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFifthly, Supposing the number of Counsellors equall, a man is better
  8566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounselled by hearing them apart, then in an Assembly; and that for many
  8567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcauses. First, in hearing them apart, you have the advice of every man;
  8568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut in an Assembly may of them deliver their advise with I, or No, or
  8569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith their hands, or feet, not moved by their own sense, but by the
  8570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teloquence of another, or for feare of displeasing some that have spoken,
  8571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor the whole Assembly, by contradiction; or for feare of appearing
  8572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tduller in apprehension, than those that have applauded the contrary
  8573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion. Secondly, in an Assembly of many, there cannot choose but be
  8574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome whose interests are contrary to that of the Publique; and these
  8575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Interests make passionate, and Passion eloquent, and Eloquence
  8576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdrawes others into the same advice. For the Passions of men, which
  8577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tasunder are moderate, as the heat of one brand; in Assembly are like
  8578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany brands, that enflame one another, (especially when they blow one
  8579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother with Orations) to the setting of the Common-wealth on fire,
  8580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder pretence of Counselling it. Thirdly, in hearing every man apart,
  8581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone may examine (when there is need) the truth, or probability of
  8582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this reasons, and of the grounds of the advise he gives, by frequent
  8583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterruptions, and objections; which cannot be done in an Assembly,
  8584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere (in every difficult question) a man is rather astonied, and dazled
  8585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the variety of discourse upon it, than informed of the course he
  8586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought to take. Besides, there cannot be an Assembly of many, called
  8587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttogether for advice, wherein there be not some, that have the ambition
  8588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be thought eloquent, and also learned in the Politiques; and give not
  8589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir advice with care of the businesse propounded, but of the applause
  8590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their motly orations, made of the divers colored threds, or shreds of
  8591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthors; which is an Impertinence at least, that takes away the time
  8592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof serious Consultation, and in the secret way of Counselling apart, is
  8593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teasily avoided. Fourthly, in Deliberations that ought to be kept secret,
  8594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(whereof there be many occasions in Publique Businesse,) the Counsells
  8595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof many, and especially in Assemblies, are dangerous; And therefore
  8596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat Assemblies are necessitated to commit such affaires to lesser
  8597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnumbers, and of such persons as are most versed, and in whose fidelity
  8598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey have most confidence.
  8599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo conclude, who is there that so far approves the taking of Counsell
  8601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom a great Assembly of Counsellours, that wisheth for, or would accept
  8602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their pains, when there is a question of marrying his Children,
  8603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisposing of his Lands, governing his Household, or managing his
  8604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate Estate, especially if there be amongst them such as wish not
  8605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this prosperity? A man that doth his businesse by the help of many and
  8606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprudent Counsellours, with every one consulting apart in his proper
  8607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\telement, does it best, as he that useth able Seconds at Tennis play,
  8608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaced in their proper stations. He does next best, that useth his own
  8609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgement only; as he that has no Second at all. But he that is carried
  8610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tup and down to his businesse in a framed Counsell, which cannot move
  8611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut by the plurality of consenting opinions, the execution whereof is
  8612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommonly (out of envy, or interest) retarded by the part dissenting,
  8613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoes it worst of all, and like one that is carried to the ball, though
  8614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby good Players, yet in a Wheele-barrough, or other frame, heavy of it
  8615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tself, and retarded also by the inconcurrent judgements, and endeavours
  8616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them that drive it; and so much the more, as they be more that set
  8617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir hands to it; and most of all, when there is one, or more amongst
  8618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, that desire to have him lose. And though it be true, that many eys
  8619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsee more then one; yet it is not to be understood of many Counsellours;
  8620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut then only, when the finall Resolution is in one man. Otherwise,
  8621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause many eyes see the same thing in divers lines, and are apt to
  8622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlook asquint towards their private benefit; they that desire not to
  8623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmisse their marke, though they look about with two eyes, yet they never
  8624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tayme but with one; And therefore no great Popular Common-wealth was
  8625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tever kept up; but either by a forraign Enemy that united them; or by
  8626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe reputation of some one eminent Man amongst them; or by the secret
  8627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell of a few; or by the mutuall feare of equall factions; and
  8628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot by the open Consultations of the Assembly. And as for very little
  8629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths, be they Popular, or Monarchicall, there is no humane
  8630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twisdome can uphold them, longer then the Jealousy lasteth of their
  8631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpotent Neighbours.
  8632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXVI. OF CIVILL LAWES
  8636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Law what
  8641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy CIVILL LAWES, I understand the Lawes, that men are therefore bound to
  8643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserve, because they are Members, not of this, or that Common-wealth
  8644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin particular, but of a Common-wealth. For the knowledge of particular
  8645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes belongeth to them, that professe the study of the Lawes of their
  8646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseverall Countries; but the knowledge of Civill Law in generall, to any
  8647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman. The antient Law of Rome was called their Civil Law, from the word
  8648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivitas, which signifies a Common-wealth; And those Countries, which
  8649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thaving been under the Roman Empire, and governed by that Law, retaine
  8650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstill such part thereof as they think fit, call that part the Civill
  8651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, to distinguish it from the rest of their own Civill Lawes. But that
  8652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not it I intend to speak of here; my designe being not to shew what
  8653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Law here, and there; but what is Law; as Plato, Aristotle, Cicero,
  8654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand divers others have done, without taking upon them the profession of
  8655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe study of the Law.
  8656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first it manifest, that Law in generall, is not Counsell, but
  8658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommand; nor a Command of any man to any man; but only of him, whose
  8659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommand is addressed to one formerly obliged to obey him. And as for
  8660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Law, it addeth only the name of the person Commanding, which is
  8661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPersona Civitatis, the Person of the Common-wealth.
  8662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhich considered, I define Civill Law in this Manner. "CIVILL LAW, Is to
  8664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery Subject, those Rules, which the Common-wealth hath Commanded him,
  8665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Word, Writing, or other sufficient Sign of the Will, to make use
  8666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof, for the Distinction of Right, and Wrong; that is to say, of what is
  8667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary, and what is not contrary to the Rule."
  8668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn which definition, there is nothing that is not at first sight
  8670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevident. For every man seeth, that some Lawes are addressed to all the
  8671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects in generall; some to particular Provinces; some to particular
  8672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVocations; and some to particular Men; and are therefore Lawes, to every
  8673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof those to whom the Command is directed; and to none else. As also,
  8674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Lawes are the Rules of Just, and Unjust; nothing being reputed
  8675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUnjust, that is not contrary to some Law. Likewise, that none can
  8676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake Lawes but the Common-wealth; because our Subjection is to the
  8677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth only: and that Commands, are to be signified by sufficient
  8678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSigns; because a man knows not otherwise how to obey them. And
  8679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore, whatsoever can from this definition by necessary consequence
  8680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe deduced, ought to be acknowledged for truth. Now I deduce from it
  8681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis that followeth.
  8682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Soveraign Is Legislator
  8687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t1. The Legislator in all Common-wealths, is only the Soveraign, be he
  8689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone Man, as in a Monarchy, or one Assembly of men, as in a Democracy,
  8690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Aristocracy. For the Legislator, is he that maketh the Law. And the
  8691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth only, praescribes, and commandeth the observation of those
  8692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trules, which we call Law: Therefore the Common-wealth is the Legislator.
  8693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the Common-wealth is no Person, nor has capacity to doe any thing,
  8694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut by the Representative, (that is, the Soveraign;) and therefore the
  8695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign is the sole Legislator. For the same reason, none can abrogate
  8696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Law made, but the Soveraign; because a Law is not abrogated, but by
  8697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother Law, that forbiddeth it to be put in execution.
  8698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Not Subject To Civill Law
  8703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2. The Soveraign of a Common-wealth, be it an Assembly, or one Man, is
  8705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot subject to the Civill Lawes. For having power to make, and repeale
  8706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes, he may when he pleaseth, free himselfe from that subjection,
  8707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby repealing those Lawes that trouble him, and making of new; and
  8708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently he was free before. For he is free, that can be free when
  8709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the will: Nor is it possible for any person to be bound to himselfe;
  8710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause he that can bind, can release; and therefore he that is bound to
  8711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe onely, is not bound.
  8712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUse, A Law Not By Vertue Of Time, But Of The Soveraigns Consent
  8717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t3. When long Use obtaineth the authority of a Law, it is not the
  8719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLength of Time that maketh the Authority, but the Will of the Soveraign
  8720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignified by his silence, (for Silence is sometimes an argument of
  8721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsent;) and it is no longer Law, then the Soveraign shall be silent
  8722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherein. And therefore if the Soveraign shall have a question of Right
  8723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrounded, not upon his present Will, but upon the Lawes formerly
  8724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade; the Length of Time shal bring no prejudice to his Right; but the
  8725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestion shal be judged by Equity. For many unjust Actions, and unjust
  8726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSentences, go uncontrolled a longer time, than any man can remember.
  8727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd our Lawyers account no Customes Law, but such as are reasonable, and
  8728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat evill Customes are to be abolished; But the Judgement of what is
  8729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasonable, and of what is to be abolished, belongeth to him that maketh
  8730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law, which is the Soveraign Assembly, or Monarch.
  8731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Law Of Nature, And The Civill Law Contain Each Other
  8736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t4. The Law of Nature, and the Civill Law, contain each other, and are
  8738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof equall extent. For the Lawes of Nature, which consist in Equity,
  8739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice, Gratitude, and other morall Vertues on these depending, in the
  8740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondition of meer Nature (as I have said before in the end of the 15th
  8741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChapter,) are not properly Lawes, but qualities that dispose men to
  8742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeace, and to obedience. When a Common-wealth is once settled, then are
  8743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey actually Lawes, and not before; as being then the commands of the
  8744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; and therefore also Civill Lawes: for it is the Soveraign
  8745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower that obliges men to obey them. For in the differences of private
  8746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, to declare, what is Equity, what is Justice, and what is morall
  8747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVertue, and to make them binding, there is need of the Ordinances of
  8748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power, and Punishments to be ordained for such as shall break
  8749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem; which Ordinances are therefore part of the Civill Law. The Law of
  8750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature therefore is a part of the Civill Law in all Common-wealths of
  8751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe world. Reciprocally also, the Civill Law is a part of the Dictates
  8752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Nature. For Justice, that is to say, Performance of Covenant, and
  8753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiving to every man his own, is a Dictate of the Law of Nature. But
  8754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery subject in a Common-wealth, hath covenanted to obey the Civill
  8755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, (either one with another, as when they assemble to make a common
  8756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative, or with the Representative it selfe one by one, when
  8757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubdued by the Sword they promise obedience, that they may receive
  8758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife;) And therefore Obedience to the Civill Law is part also of the
  8759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw of Nature. Civill, and Naturall Law are not different kinds, but
  8760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifferent parts of Law; whereof one part being written, is called
  8761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill, the other unwritten, Naturall. But the Right of Nature, that
  8762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, the naturall Liberty of man, may by the Civill Law be abridged,
  8763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand restrained: nay, the end of making Lawes, is no other, but such
  8764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRestraint; without the which there cannot possibly be any Peace. And Law
  8765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas brought into the world for nothing else, but to limit the naturall
  8766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tliberty of particular men, in such manner, as they might not hurt, but
  8767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassist one another, and joyn together against a common Enemy.
  8768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProvinciall Lawes Are Not Made By Custome, But By The Soveraign Power
  8773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t5. If the Soveraign of one Common-wealth, subdue a people that have
  8775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlived under other written Lawes, and afterwards govern them by the
  8776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame Lawes, by which they were governed before; yet those Lawes are the
  8777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Lawes of the Victor, and not of the Vanquished Common-wealth, For
  8778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Legislator is he, not by whose authority the Lawes were first made,
  8779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut by whose authority they now continue to be Lawes. And therefore
  8780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere there be divers Provinces, within the Dominion of a Common-wealth,
  8781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand in those Provinces diversity of Lawes, which commonly are called the
  8782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCustomes of each severall Province, we are not to understand that such
  8783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCustomes have their Force, onely from Length of Time; but that they were
  8784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tantiently Lawes written, or otherwise made known, for the Constitutions,
  8785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Statutes of their Soveraigns; and are now Lawes, not by vertue of
  8786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Praescription of time, but by the Constitutions of their present
  8787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns. But if an unwritten Law, in all the Provinces of a Dominion,
  8788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be generally observed, and no iniquity appear in the use thereof;
  8789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat law can be no other but a Law of Nature, equally obliging all
  8790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman-kind.
  8791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSome Foolish Opinions Of Lawyers Concerning The Making Of Lawes
  8796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t6. Seeing then all Lawes, written, and unwritten, have their Authority,
  8798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand force, from the Will of the Common-wealth; that is to say, from the
  8799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWill of the Representative; which in a Monarchy is the Monarch, and
  8800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin other Common-wealths the Soveraign Assembly; a man may wonder from
  8801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhence proceed such opinions, as are found in the Books of Lawyers of
  8802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teminence in severall Common-wealths, directly, or by consequence making
  8803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Legislative Power depend on private men, or subordinate Judges.
  8804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for example, "That the Common Law, hath no Controuler but the
  8805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tParlament;" which is true onely where a Parlament has the Soveraign
  8806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower, and cannot be assembled, nor dissolved, but by their own
  8807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscretion. For if there be a right in any else to dissolve them, there
  8808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a right also to controule them, and consequently to controule their
  8809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontroulings. And if there be no such right, then the Controuler of
  8810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes is not Parlamentum, but Rex In Parlamento. And where a Parlament
  8811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Soveraign, if it should assemble never so many, or so wise men, from
  8812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Countries subject to them, for whatsoever cause; yet there is no man
  8813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill believe, that such an Assembly hath thereby acquired to themselves
  8814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Legislative Power. Item, that the two arms of a Common-wealth,
  8815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Force, and Justice; The First Whereof Is In The King; The Other
  8816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeposited In The Hands Of The Parlament. As if a Common-wealth could
  8817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsist, where the Force were in any hand, which Justice had not the
  8818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority to command and govern.
  8819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t7. That Law can never be against Reason, our Lawyers are agreed; and
  8821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat not the Letter,(that is, every construction of it,) but that which
  8822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis according to the Intention of the Legislator, is the Law. And it is
  8823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrue: but the doubt is, of whose Reason it is, that shall be received
  8824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Law. It is not meant of any private Reason; for then there would be
  8825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas much contradiction in the Lawes, as there is in the Schooles; nor yet
  8826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as Sr. Ed, Coke makes it (Sir Edward Coke, upon Littleton Lib.2. Ch.6
  8827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfol 97.b),) an Artificiall Perfection of Reason, Gotten By Long Study,
  8828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tObservation, And Experience, (as his was.) For it is possible long study
  8829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay encrease, and confirm erroneous Sentences: and where men build on
  8830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfalse grounds, the more they build, the greater is the ruine; and of
  8831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that study, and observe with equall time, and diligence, the
  8832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasons and resolutions are, and must remain discordant: and therefore
  8833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is not that Juris Prudentia, or wisedome of subordinate Judges;
  8834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the Reason of this our Artificiall Man the Common-wealth, and
  8835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Command, that maketh Law: And the Common-wealth being in
  8836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Representative but one Person, there cannot easily arise any
  8837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontradiction in the Lawes; and when there doth, the same Reason is
  8838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\table, by interpretation, or alteration, to take it away. In all Courts
  8839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Justice, the Soveraign (which is the Person of the Common-wealth,)
  8840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis he that Judgeth: The subordinate Judge, ought to have regard to the
  8841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treason, which moved his Soveraign to make such Law, that his Sentence
  8842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay be according thereunto; which then is his Soveraigns Sentence;
  8843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\totherwise it is his own, and an unjust one.
  8844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw Made, If Not Also Made Known, Is No Law
  8849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t8. From this, that the Law is a Command, and a Command consisteth in
  8851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeclaration, or manifestation of the will of him that commandeth, by
  8852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvoyce, writing, or some other sufficient argument of the same, we may
  8853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstand, that the Command of the Common-wealth, is Law onely to
  8854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose, that have means to take notice of it. Over naturall fooles,
  8855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchildren, or mad-men there is no Law, no more than over brute beasts;
  8856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor are they capable of the title of just, or unjust; because they had
  8857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnever power to make any covenant, or to understand the consequences
  8858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof; and consequently never took upon them to authorise the
  8859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions of any Soveraign, as they must do that make to themselves a
  8860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth. And as those from whom Nature, or Accident hath taken
  8861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taway the notice of all Lawes in generall; so also every man, from whom
  8862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany accident, not proceeding from his own default, hath taken away the
  8863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeans to take notice of any particular Law, is excused, if he observe it
  8864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot; And to speak properly, that Law is no Law to him. It is therefore
  8865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessary, to consider in this place, what arguments, and signes be
  8866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsufficient for the knowledge of what is the Law; that is to say, what is
  8867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe will of the Soveraign, as well in Monarchies, as in other formes of
  8868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgovernment.
  8869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUnwritten Lawes Are All Of Them Lawes Of Nature
  8874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first, if it be a Law that obliges all the Subjects without
  8876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texception, and is not written, nor otherwise published in such places as
  8877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey may take notice thereof, it is a Law of Nature. For whatsoever men
  8878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare to take knowledge of for Law, not upon other mens words, but every
  8879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone from his own reason, must be such as is agreeable to the reason of
  8880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall men; which no Law can be, but the Law of Nature. The Lawes of Nature
  8881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore need not any publishing, nor Proclamation; as being contained
  8882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this one Sentence, approved by all the world, "Do not that to
  8883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, which thou thinkest unreasonable to be done by another to thy
  8884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tselfe."
  8885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, if it be a Law that obliges only some condition of men, or one
  8887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular man and be not written, nor published by word, then also it
  8888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a Law of Nature; and known by the same arguments, and signs,
  8889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat distinguish those in such a condition, from other Subjects. For
  8890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever Law is not written, or some way published by him that makes
  8891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit Law, can be known no way, but by the reason of him that is to obey
  8892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit; and is therefore also a Law not only Civill, but Naturall. For
  8893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texample, if the Soveraign employ a Publique Minister, without written
  8894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstructions what to doe; he is obliged to take for Instructions the
  8895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDictates of Reason; As if he make a Judge, The Judge is to take notice,
  8896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat his Sentence ought to be according to the reason of his Soveraign,
  8897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich being alwaies understood to be Equity, he is bound to it by the
  8898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw of Nature: Or if an Ambassador, he is (in al things not conteined
  8899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his written Instructions) to take for Instruction that which Reason
  8900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdictates to be most conducing to his Soveraigns interest; and so of
  8901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall other Ministers of the Soveraignty, publique and private. All which
  8902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstructions of naturall Reason may be comprehended under one name of
  8903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFidelity; which is a branch of naturall Justice.
  8904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Law of Nature excepted, it belongeth to the essence of all other
  8906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes, to be made known, to every man that shall be obliged to obey
  8907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, either by word, or writing, or some other act, known to proceed
  8908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Soveraign Authority. For the will of another, cannot be
  8909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood, but by his own word, or act, or by conjecture taken from his
  8910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tscope and purpose; which in the person of the Common-wealth, is to be
  8911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupposed alwaies consonant to Equity and Reason. And in antient time,
  8912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore letters were in common use, the Lawes were many times put into
  8913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tverse; that the rude people taking pleasure in singing, or reciting
  8914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, might the more easily reteine them in memory. And for the same
  8915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treason Solomon adviseth a man, to bind the ten Commandements (Prov. 7.
  8916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t3) upon his ten fingers. And for the Law which Moses gave to the people
  8917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Israel at the renewing of the Covenant, (Deut. 11. 19) he biddeth
  8918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem to teach it their Children, by discoursing of it both at home, and
  8919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon the way; at going to bed, and at rising from bed; and to write
  8920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit upon the posts, and dores of their houses; and (Deut. 31. 12) to
  8921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassemble the people, man, woman, and child, to heare it read.
  8922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNothing Is Law Where The Legislator Cannot Be Known
  8927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor is it enough the Law be written, and published; but also that there
  8929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe manifest signs, that it proceedeth from the will of the Soveraign.
  8930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor private men, when they have, or think they have force enough to
  8931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsecure their unjust designes, and convoy them safely to their ambitious
  8932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tends, may publish for Lawes what they please, without, or against
  8933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Legislative Authority. There is therefore requisite, not only a
  8934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeclaration of the Law, but also sufficient signes of the Author, and
  8935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority. The Author, or Legislator is supposed in every Common-wealth
  8936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be evident, because he is the Soveraign, who having been Constituted
  8937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the consent of every one, is supposed by every one to be sufficiently
  8938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknown. And though the ignorance, and security of men be such, for the
  8939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost part, as that when the memory of the first Constitution of their
  8940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth is worn out, they doe not consider, by whose power they
  8941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuse to be defended against their enemies, and to have their industry
  8942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprotected, and to be righted when injury is done them; yet because no
  8943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman that considers, can make question of it, no excuse can be derived
  8944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the ignorance of where the Soveraignty is placed. And it is a
  8945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDictate of Naturall Reason, and consequently an evident Law of Nature,
  8946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat no man ought to weaken that power, the protection whereof he hath
  8947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself demanded, or wittingly received against others. Therefore of
  8948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho is Soveraign, no man, but by his own fault, (whatsoever evill men
  8949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuggest,) can make any doubt. The difficulty consisteth in the evidence
  8950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Authority derived from him; The removing whereof, dependeth on
  8951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe knowledge of the publique Registers, publique Counsels, publique
  8952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters, and publique Seales; by which all Lawes are sufficiently
  8953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tverified.
  8954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDifference Between Verifying And Authorising
  8959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVerifyed, I say, not Authorised: for the Verification, is but the
  8961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestimony and Record; not the Authority of the law; which consisteth in
  8962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Command of the Soveraign only.
  8963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Law Verifyed By The Subordinate Judge
  8968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf therefore a man have a question of Injury, depending on the Law of
  8970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature; that is to say, on common Equity; the Sentence of the Judge,
  8971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat by Commission hath Authority to take cognisance of such causes, is
  8972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta sufficient Verification of the Law of Nature in that individuall case.
  8973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor though the advice of one that professeth the study of the Law, be
  8974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tusefull for the avoyding of contention; yet it is but advice; tis the
  8975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudge must tell men what is Law, upon the hearing of the Controversy.
  8976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy The Publique Registers
  8981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut when the question is of injury, or crime, upon a written Law; every
  8983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman by recourse to the Registers, by himself, or others, may (if he
  8984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill) be sufficiently enformed, before he doe such injury, or commit the
  8985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcrime, whither it be an injury, or not: Nay he ought to doe so: for when
  8986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man doubts whether the act he goeth about, be just, or injust; and may
  8987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinforme himself, if he will; the doing is unlawfull. In like manner, he
  8988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat supposeth himself injured, in a case determined by the written Law,
  8989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich he may by himself, or others see and consider; if he complaine
  8990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore he consults with the Law, he does unjustly, and bewrayeth a
  8991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisposition rather to vex other men, than to demand his own right.
  8992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Letters Patent, And Publique Seale
  8997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  8998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf the question be of Obedience to a publique Officer; To have seen his
  8999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommission, with the Publique Seale, and heard it read; or to have
  9000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad the means to be informed of it, if a man would, is a sufficient
  9001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVerification of his Authority. For every man is obliged to doe his best
  9002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tendeavour, to informe himself of all written Lawes, that may concerne
  9003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own future actions.
  9004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Interpretation Of The Law Dependeth On The Soveraign Power
  9009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Legislator known; and the Lawes, either by writing, or by the
  9011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlight of Nature, sufficiently published; there wanteth yet another
  9012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery materiall circumstance to make them obligatory. For it is not the
  9013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLetter, but the Intendment, or Meaning; that is to say, the authentique
  9014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpretation of the Law (which is the sense of the Legislator,) in
  9015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the nature of the Law consisteth; And therefore the Interpretation
  9016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof all Lawes dependeth on the Authority Soveraign; and the Interpreters
  9017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan be none but those, which the Soveraign, (to whom only the
  9018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubject oweth obedience) shall appoint. For else, by the craft of an
  9019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpreter, the Law my be made to beare a sense, contrary to that of
  9020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign; by which means the Interpreter becomes the Legislator.
  9021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll Lawes Need Interpretation
  9026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll Laws, written, and unwritten, have need of Interpretation.
  9028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe unwritten Law of Nature, though it be easy to such, as without
  9029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpartiality, and passion, make use of their naturall reason, and
  9030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore leaves the violators thereof without excuse; yet considering
  9031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere be very few, perhaps none, that in some cases are not blinded by
  9032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tself love, or some other passion, it is now become of all Laws the most
  9033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobscure; and has consequently the greatest need of able Interpreters.
  9034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe written Laws, if they be short, are easily mis-interpreted, from the
  9035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivers significations of a word, or two; if long, they be more obscure
  9036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the diverse significations of many words: in so much as no written
  9037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, delivered in few, or many words, can be well understood, without a
  9038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperfect understanding of the finall causes, for which the Law was
  9039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade; the knowledge of which finall causes is in the Legislator. To him
  9040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore there can not be any knot in the Law, insoluble; either by
  9041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfinding out the ends, to undoe it by; or else by making what ends he
  9042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill, (as Alexander did with his sword in the Gordian knot,) by the
  9043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLegislative power; which no other Interpreter can doe.
  9044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Authenticall Interpretation Of Law Is Not That Of Writers
  9049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Interpretation of the Lawes of Nature, in a Common-wealth, dependeth
  9051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot on the books of Morall Philosophy. The Authority of writers, without
  9052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Authority of the Common-wealth, maketh not their opinions Law,
  9053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe they never so true. That which I have written in this Treatise,
  9054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning the Morall Vertues, and of their necessity, for the
  9055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprocuring, and maintaining peace, though it bee evident Truth, is not
  9056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore presently Law; but because in all Common-wealths in the world,
  9057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is part of the Civill Law: For though it be naturally reasonable; yet
  9058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is by the Soveraigne Power that it is Law: Otherwise, it were a great
  9059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\terrour, to call the Lawes of Nature unwritten Law; whereof wee see
  9060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso many volumes published, and in them so many contradictions of one
  9061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, and of themselves.
  9062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Interpreter Of The Law Is The Judge Giving Sentence Viva Voce
  9067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Every Particular Case
  9069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Interpretation of the Law of Nature, is the Sentence of the Judge
  9071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstituted by the Soveraign Authority, to heare and determine such
  9072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontroversies, as depend thereon; and consisteth in the application of
  9073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law to the present case. For in the act of Judicature, the Judge
  9074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoth no more but consider, whither the demand of the party, be consonant
  9075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto naturall reason, and Equity; and the Sentence he giveth, is therefore
  9076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Interpretation of the Law of Nature; which Interpretation is
  9077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthentique; not because it is his private Sentence; but because
  9078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the giveth it by Authority of the Soveraign, whereby it becomes the
  9079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns Sentence; which is Law for that time, to the parties
  9080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpleading.
  9081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Sentence Of A Judge, Does Not Bind Him, Or Another Judge
  9086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Give Like Sentence In Like Cases Ever After
  9088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut because there is no Judge Subordinate, nor Soveraign, but may erre
  9090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin a Judgement of Equity; if afterward in another like case he find it
  9091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore consonant to Equity to give a contrary Sentence, he is obliged to
  9092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoe it. No mans error becomes his own Law; nor obliges him to persist
  9093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin it. Neither (for the same reason) becomes it a Law to other Judges,
  9094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough sworn to follow it. For though a wrong Sentence given by
  9095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority of the Soveraign, if he know and allow it, in such Lawes as
  9096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare mutable, be a constitution of a new Law, in cases, in which every
  9097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlittle circumstance is the same; yet in Lawes immutable, such as are the
  9098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes of Nature, they are no Lawes to the same, or other Judges, in the
  9099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike cases for ever after. Princes succeed one another; and one Judge
  9100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpasseth, another commeth; nay, Heaven and Earth shall passe; but not one
  9101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttitle of the Law of Nature shall passe; for it is the Eternall Law of
  9102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod. Therefore all the Sentences of precedent Judges that have ever
  9103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen, cannot all together make a Law contrary to naturall Equity: Nor
  9104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany Examples of former Judges, can warrant an unreasonable Sentence, or
  9105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdischarge the present Judge of the trouble of studying what is Equity
  9106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(in the case he is to Judge,) from the principles of his own naturall
  9107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treason. For example sake, 'Tis against the Law of Nature, To Punish The
  9108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInnocent; and Innocent is he that acquitteth himselfe Judicially, and is
  9109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledged for Innocent by the Judge. Put the case now, that a man is
