  9110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccused of a capitall crime, and seeing the powers and malice of some
  9111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenemy, and the frequent corruption and partiality of Judges, runneth
  9112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taway for feare of the event, and afterwards is taken, and brought to a
  9113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlegall triall, and maketh it sufficiently appear, he was not guilty of
  9114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe crime, and being thereof acquitted, is neverthelesse condemned to
  9115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlose his goods; this is a manifest condemnation of the Innocent. I say
  9116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore, that there is no place in the world, where this can be an
  9117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterpretation of a Law of Nature, or be made a Law by the Sentences of
  9118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprecedent Judges, that had done the same. For he that judged it first,
  9119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudged unjustly; and no Injustice can be a pattern of Judgement to
  9120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsucceeding Judges. A written Law may forbid innocent men to fly, and
  9121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey may be punished for flying: But that flying for feare of injury,
  9122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould be taken for presumption of guilt, after a man is already
  9123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsolved of the crime Judicially, is contrary to the nature of a
  9124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresumption, which hath no place after Judgement given. Yet this is set
  9125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdown by a great Lawyer for the common Law of England. "If a man," saith
  9126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the, "that is Innocent, be accused of Felony, and for feare flyeth for
  9127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same; albeit he judicially acquitteth himselfe of the Felony; yet
  9128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif it be found that he fled for the Felony, he shall notwithstanding his
  9129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInnocency, Forfeit all his goods, chattels, debts, and duties. For as
  9130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Forfeiture of them, the Law will admit no proofe against the
  9131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresumption in Law, grounded upon his flight." Here you see, An Innocent
  9132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMan, Judicially Acquitted, Notwithstanding His Innocency, (when no
  9133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten Law forbad him to fly) after his acquitall, Upon A Presumption
  9134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Law, condemned to lose all the goods he hath. If the Law ground upon
  9135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this flight a Presumption of the fact, (which was Capitall,) the Sentence
  9136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought to have been Capitall: if the presumption were not of the Fact,
  9137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor what then ought he to lose his goods? This therefore is no Law of
  9138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEngland; nor is the condemnation grounded upon a Presumption of Law, but
  9139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon the Presumption of the Judges. It is also against Law, to say
  9140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat no Proofe shall be admitted against a Presumption of Law. For
  9141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall Judges, Soveraign and subordinate, if they refuse to heare Proofe,
  9142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trefuse to do Justice: for though the Sentence be Just, yet the Judges
  9143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat condemn without hearing the Proofes offered, are Unjust Judges; and
  9144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Presumption is but Prejudice; which no man ought to bring with him
  9145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Seat of Justice, whatsoever precedent judgements, or examples he
  9146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall pretend to follow. There be other things of this nature, wherein
  9147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmens Judgements have been perverted, by trusting to Precedents: but this
  9148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis enough to shew, that though the Sentence of the Judge, be a Law to
  9149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe party pleading, yet it is no Law to any Judge, that shall succeed
  9150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim in that Office.
  9151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn like manner, when question is of the Meaning of written Lawes, he is
  9153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot the Interpreter of them, that writeth a Commentary upon them. For
  9154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommentaries are commonly more subject to cavill, than the Text; and
  9155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore need other Commentaries; and so there will be no end of such
  9156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpretation. And therefore unlesse there be an Interpreter authorised
  9157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Soveraign, from which the subordinate Judges are not to recede,
  9158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Interpreter can be no other than the ordinary Judges, in the some
  9159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner, as they are in cases of the unwritten Law; and their Sentences
  9160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare to be taken by them that plead, for Lawes in that particular case;
  9161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut not to bind other Judges, in like cases to give like judgements.
  9162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor a Judge may erre in the Interpretation even of written Lawes; but no
  9163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\terrour of a subordinate Judge, can change the Law, which is the generall
  9164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSentence of the Soveraigne.
  9165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Difference Between The Letter And Sentence Of The Law
  9170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn written Lawes, men use to make a difference between the Letter, and
  9172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Sentence of the Law: And when by the Letter, is meant whatsoever
  9173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan be gathered from the bare words, 'tis well distinguished. For the
  9174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifications of almost all words, are either in themselves, or in the
  9175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmetaphoricall use of them, ambiguous; and may be drawn in argument, to
  9176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake many senses; but there is onely one sense of the Law. But if by the
  9177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLetter, be meant the Literall sense, then the Letter, and the Sentence
  9178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor intention of the Law, is all one. For the literall sense is that,
  9179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Legislator is alwayes supposed to be Equity: For it were a
  9180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat contumely for a Judge to think otherwise of the Soveraigne.
  9181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHe ought therefore, if the Word of the Law doe not fully authorise a
  9182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasonable Sentence, to supply it with the Law of Nature; or if the
  9183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcase be difficult, to respit Judgement till he have received more ample
  9184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority. For Example, a written Law ordaineth, that he which is thrust
  9185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of his house by force, shall be restored by force: It happens that
  9186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man by negligence leaves his house empty, and returning is kept out by
  9187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforce, in which case there is no speciall Law ordained. It is evident,
  9188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat this case is contained in the same Law: for else there is no remedy
  9189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor him at all; which is to be supposed against the Intention of the
  9190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLegislator. Again, the word of the Law, commandeth to Judge according
  9191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Evidence: A man is accused falsly of a fact, which the Judge saw
  9192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself done by another; and not by him that is accused. In this case
  9193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneither shall the Letter of the Law be followed to the condemnation of
  9194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Innocent, nor shall the Judge give Sentence against the evidence
  9195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Witnesses; because the Letter of the Law is to the contrary:
  9196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut procure of the Soveraign that another be made Judge, and himselfe
  9197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitnesse. So that the incommodity that follows the bare words of a
  9198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten Law, may lead him to the Intention of the Law, whereby to
  9199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterpret the same the better; though no Incommodity can warrant a
  9200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSentence against the Law. For every Judge of Right, and Wrong, is not
  9201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudge of what is Commodious, or Incommodious to the Common-wealth.
  9202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Abilities Required In A Judge
  9207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe abilities required in a good Interpreter of the Law, that is to say,
  9209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin a good Judge, are not the same with those of an Advocate; namely the
  9210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstudy of the Lawes. For a Judge, as he ought to take notice of the Fact,
  9211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom none but the Witnesses; so also he ought to take notice of the
  9212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, from nothing but the Statutes, and Constitutions of the Soveraign,
  9213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talledged in the pleading, or declared to him by some that have authority
  9214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Soveraign Power to declare them; and need not take care
  9215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore-hand, what hee shall Judge; for it shall bee given him what hee
  9216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall say concerning the Fact, by Witnesses; and what hee shall say in
  9217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpoint of Law, from those that shall in their pleadings shew it, and by
  9218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority interpret it upon the place. The Lords of Parlament in England
  9219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere Judges, and most difficult causes have been heard and determined
  9220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby them; yet few of them were much versed in the study of the Lawes,
  9221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand fewer had made profession of them: and though they consulted with
  9222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawyers, that were appointed to be present there for that purpose; yet
  9223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey alone had the authority of giving Sentence. In like manner, in
  9224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe ordinary trialls of Right, Twelve men of the common People, are the
  9225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudges, and give Sentence, not onely of the Fact, but of the Right; and
  9226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpronounce simply for the Complaynant, or for the Defendant; that is to
  9227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, are Judges not onely of the Fact, but also of the Right: and in a
  9228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestion of crime, not onely determine whether done, or not done; but
  9229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso whether it be Murder, Homicide, Felony, Assault, and the like,
  9230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich are determinations of Law: but because they are not supposed to
  9231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow the Law of themselves, there is one that hath Authority to enforme
  9232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem of it, in the particular case they are to Judge of. But yet if they
  9233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudge not according to that he tells them, they are not subject thereby
  9234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto any penalty; unlesse it be made appear, they did it against their
  9235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsciences, or had been corrupted by reward. The things that make
  9236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta good Judge, or good Interpreter of the Lawes, are, first A Right
  9237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUnderstanding of that principall Law of Nature called Equity; which
  9238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdepending not on the reading of other mens Writings, but on the
  9239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgoodnesse of a mans own naturall Reason, and Meditation, is presumed
  9240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be in those most, that have had most leisure, and had the most
  9241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinclination to meditate thereon. Secondly, Contempt Of Unnecessary
  9242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRiches, and Preferments. Thirdly, To Be Able In Judgement To Devest
  9243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHimselfe Of All Feare, Anger, Hatred, Love, And Compassion. Fourthly,
  9244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand lastly, Patience To Heare; Diligent Attention In Hearing; And Memory
  9245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Retain, Digest And Apply What He Hath Heard.
  9246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivisions Of Law
  9251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe difference and division of the Lawes, has been made in divers
  9253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanners, according to the different methods, of those men that have
  9254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten of them. For it is a thing that dependeth not on Nature, but on
  9255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe scope of the Writer; and is subservient to every mans proper method.
  9256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the Institutions of Justinian, we find seven sorts of Civill Lawes.
  9257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t1. The Edicts, Constitutions, and Epistles Of The Prince, that is, of
  9259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Emperour; because the whole power of the people was in him. Like
  9260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese, are the Proclamations of the Kings of England.
  9261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2. The Decrees Of The Whole People Of Rome (comprehending the Senate,)
  9263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen they were put to the Question by the Senate. These were Lawes, at
  9264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst, by the vertue of the Soveraign Power residing in the people; and
  9265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch of them as by the Emperours were not abrogated, remained Lawes by
  9266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Authority Imperiall. For all Lawes that bind, are understood to be
  9267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes by his authority that has power to repeale them. Somewhat like to
  9268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese Lawes, are the Acts of Parliament in England.
  9269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t3. The Decrees Of The Common People (excluding the Senate,) when they
  9271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere put to the question by the Tribune of the people. For such of them
  9272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas were not abrogated by the Emperours, remained Lawes by the Authority
  9273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImperiall. Like to these, were the Orders of the House of Commons in
  9274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEngland.
  9275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t4. Senatus Consulta, the Orders Of The Senate; because when the people
  9277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Rome grew so numerous, as it was inconvenient to assemble them; it
  9278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas thought fit by the Emperour, that men should Consult the Senate in
  9279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstead of the people: And these have some resemblance with the Acts of
  9280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell.
  9281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t5. The Edicts Of Praetors, and (in some Cases) of the Aediles: such as
  9283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare the Chiefe Justices in the Courts of England.
  9284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t6. Responsa Prudentum; which were the Sentences, and Opinions of those
  9286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawyers, to whom the Emperour gave Authority to interpret the Law, and
  9287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto give answer to such as in matter of Law demanded their advice;
  9288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich Answers, the Judges in giving Judgement were obliged by the
  9289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConstitutions of the Emperour to observe; And should be like the Reports
  9290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Cases Judged, if other Judges be by the Law of England bound to
  9291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserve them. For the Judges of the Common Law of England, are not
  9292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproperly Judges, but Juris Consulti; of whom the Judges, who are either
  9293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Lords, or Twelve men of the Country, are in point of Law to ask
  9294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadvice.
  9295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t7. Also, Unwritten Customes, (which in their own nature are an imitation
  9297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Law,) by the tacite consent of the Emperour, in case they be not
  9298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary to the Law of Nature, are very Lawes.
  9299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother division of Lawes, is into Naturall and Positive. Naturall are
  9301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose which have been Lawes from all Eternity; and are called not onely
  9302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall, but also Morall Lawes; consisting in the Morall Vertues, as
  9303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice, Equity, and all habits of the mind that conduce to Peace, and
  9304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCharity; of which I have already spoken in the fourteenth and fifteenth
  9305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChapters.
  9306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPositive, are those which have not been for Eternity; but have been
  9308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade Lawes by the Will of those that have had the Soveraign Power over
  9309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tothers; and are either written, or made known to men, by some other
  9310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\targument of the Will of their Legislator.
  9311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother Division Of Law
  9316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, of Positive Lawes some are Humane, some Divine; And of Humane
  9318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpositive lawes, some are Distributive, some Penal. Distributive are
  9319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that determine the Rights of the Subjects, declaring to every man
  9320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat it is, by which he acquireth and holdeth a propriety in lands,
  9321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor goods, and a right or liberty of action; and these speak to all
  9322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Subjects. Penal are those, which declare, what Penalty shall be
  9323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinflicted on those that violate the Law; and speak to the Ministers
  9324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Officers ordained for execution. For though every one ought to be
  9325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinformed of the Punishments ordained beforehand for their transgression;
  9326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse the Command is not addressed to the Delinquent, (who
  9327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot be supposed will faithfully punish himselfe,) but to publique
  9328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters appointed to see the Penalty executed. And these Penal Lawes
  9329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare for the most part written together with the Lawes Distributive; and
  9330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare sometimes called Judgements. For all Lawes are generall judgements,
  9331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Sentences of the Legislator; as also every particular Judgement, is a
  9332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw to him, whose case is Judged.
  9333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivine Positive Law How Made Known To Be Law
  9338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivine Positive Lawes (for Naturall Lawes being Eternall, and
  9340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUniversall, are all Divine,) are those, which being the Commandements of
  9341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, (not from all Eternity, nor universally addressed to all men, but
  9342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely to a certain people, or to certain persons,) are declared for
  9343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch, by those whom God hath authorised to declare them. But this
  9344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority of man to declare what be these Positive Lawes of God, how can
  9345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit be known? God may command a man by a supernaturall way, to deliver
  9346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes to other men. But because it is of the essence of Law, that he who
  9347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to be obliged, be assured of the Authority of him that declareth
  9348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, which we cannot naturally take notice to be from God, How Can A Man
  9349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWithout Supernaturall Revelation Be Assured Of The Revelation Received
  9350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy The Declarer? and How Can He Be Bound To Obey Them? For the first
  9351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestion, how a man can be assured of the Revelation of another, without
  9352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Revelation particularly to himselfe, it is evidently impossible:
  9353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor though a man may be induced to believe such Revelation, from the
  9354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles they see him doe, or from seeing the Extraordinary sanctity of
  9355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this life, or from seeing the Extraordinary wisedome, or Extraordinary
  9356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfelicity of his Actions, all which are marks of Gods extraordinary
  9357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfavour; yet they are not assured evidence of speciall Revelation.
  9358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles are Marvellous workes: but that which is marvellous to one,
  9359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay not be so to another. Sanctity may be feigned; and the visible
  9360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfelicities of this world, are most often the work of God by Naturall,
  9361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand ordinary causes. And therefore no man can infallibly know by
  9362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturall reason, that another has had a supernaturall revelation of Gods
  9363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill; but only a beliefe; every one (as the signs thereof shall appear
  9364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreater, or lesser) a firmer, or a weaker belief.
  9365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut for the second, how he can be bound to obey them; it is not so hard.
  9367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor if the Law declared, be not against the Law of Nature (which is
  9368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tundoubtedly Gods Law) and he undertake to obey it, he is bound by his
  9369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town act; bound I say to obey it, but not bound to believe it: for mens
  9370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeliefe, and interiour cogitations, are not subject to the commands,
  9371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut only to the operation of God, ordinary, or extraordinary. Faith of
  9372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSupernaturall Law, is not a fulfilling, but only an assenting to the
  9373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame; and not a duty that we exhibite to God, but a gift which God
  9374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfreely giveth to whom he pleaseth; as also Unbelief is not a breach
  9375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof any of his Lawes; but a rejection of them all, except the Lawes
  9376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall. But this that I say, will be made yet cleerer, by the
  9377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExamples, and Testimonies concerning this point in holy Scripture. The
  9378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant God made with Abraham (in a Supernaturall Manner) was thus,
  9379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Gen. 17. 10) "This is the Covenant which thou shalt observe between
  9380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMe and Thee and thy Seed after thee." Abrahams Seed had not this
  9381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trevelation, nor were yet in being; yet they are a party to the Covenant,
  9382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand bound to obey what Abraham should declare to them for Gods Law;
  9383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich they could not be, but in vertue of the obedience they owed to
  9384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Parents; who (if they be Subject to no other earthly power, as
  9385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\there in the case of Abraham) have Soveraign power over their children,
  9386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand servants. Againe, where God saith to Abraham, "In thee shall all
  9387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNations of the earth be blessed: For I know thou wilt command thy
  9388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchildren, and thy house after thee to keep the way of the Lord, and to
  9389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserve Righteousnesse and Judgement," it is manifest, the obedience of
  9390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Family, who had no Revelation, depended on their former obligation
  9391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey their Soveraign. At Mount Sinai Moses only went up to God; the
  9392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople were forbidden to approach on paine of death; yet were they bound
  9393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey all that Moses declared to them for Gods Law. Upon what ground,
  9394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut on this submission of their own, "Speak thou to us, and we will
  9395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theare thee; but let not God speak to us, lest we dye?" By which two
  9396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaces it sufficiently appeareth, that in a Common-wealth, a subject
  9397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat has no certain and assured Revelation particularly to himself
  9398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning the Will of God, is to obey for such, the Command of
  9399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Common-wealth: for if men were at liberty, to take for Gods
  9400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandements, their own dreams, and fancies, or the dreams and
  9401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfancies of private men; scarce two men would agree upon what is Gods
  9402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandement; and yet in respect of them, every man would despise the
  9403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandements of the Common-wealth. I conclude therefore, that in all
  9404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings not contrary to the Morall Law, (that is to say, to the Law of
  9405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature,) all Subjects are bound to obey that for divine Law, which is
  9406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeclared to be so, by the Lawes of the Common-wealth. Which also is
  9407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevident to any mans reason; for whatsoever is not against the Law of
  9408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature, may be made Law in the name of them that have the Soveraign
  9409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower; and there is no reason men should be the lesse obliged by it,
  9410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen tis propounded in the name of God. Besides, there is no place in
  9411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe world where men are permitted to pretend other Commandements of God,
  9412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan are declared for such by the Common-wealth. Christian States punish
  9413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that revolt from Christian Religion, and all other States, those
  9414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat set up any Religion by them forbidden. For in whatsoever is not
  9415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tregulated by the Common-wealth, tis Equity (which is the Law of Nature,
  9416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore an eternall Law of God) that every man equally enjoy his
  9417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tliberty.
  9418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother Division Of Lawes
  9423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere is also another distinction of Laws, into Fundamentall, and Not
  9425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFundamentall: but I could never see in any Author, what a Fundamentall
  9426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw signifieth. Neverthelesse one may very reasonably distinguish Laws
  9427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin that manner.
  9428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Fundamentall Law What
  9433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor a Fundamentall Law in every Common-wealth is that, which being taken
  9435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taway, the Common-wealth faileth, and is utterly dissolved; as a building
  9436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose Foundation is destroyed. And therefore a Fundamentall Law is that,
  9437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby which Subjects are bound to uphold whatsoever power is given to the
  9438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, whether a Monarch, or a Soveraign Assembly, without which the
  9439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth cannot stand, such as is the power of War and Peace, of
  9440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudicature, of Election of Officers, and of doing whatsoever he shall
  9441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthink necessary for the Publique good. Not Fundamentall is that
  9442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe abrogating whereof, draweth not with it the dissolution of the
  9443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-Wealth; such as are the Lawes Concerning Controversies between
  9444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject and subject. Thus much of the Division of Lawes.
  9445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDifference Between Law And Right
  9450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI find the words Lex Civilis, and Jus Civile, that is to say, Law and
  9452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight Civil, promiscuously used for the same thing, even in the most
  9453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlearned Authors; which neverthelesse ought not to be so. For Right is
  9454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty, namely that Liberty which the Civil Law leaves us: But Civill
  9455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw is an Obligation; and takes from us the Liberty which the Law of
  9456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature gave us. Nature gave a Right to every man to secure himselfe
  9457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby his own strength, and to invade a suspected neighbour, by way of
  9458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprevention; but the Civill Law takes away that Liberty, in all cases
  9459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere the protection of the Lawe may be safely stayd for. Insomuch as
  9460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLex and Jus, are as different as Obligation and Liberty.
  9461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Between A Law And A Charter
  9466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLikewise Lawes and Charters are taken promiscuously for the same
  9468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing. Yet Charters are Donations of the Soveraign; and not Lawes, but
  9469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texemptions from Law. The phrase of a Law is Jubeo, Injungo, I Command,
  9470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Enjoyn: the phrase of a Charter is Dedi, Concessi, I Have Given, I
  9471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHave Granted: but what is given or granted, to a man, is not forced
  9472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon him, by a Law. A Law may be made to bind All the Subjects of a
  9473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth: a Liberty, or Charter is only to One man, or some One
  9474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart of the people. For to say all the people of a Common-wealth, have
  9475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty in any case whatsoever; is to say, that in such case, there hath
  9476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen no Law made; or else having been made, is now abrogated.
  9477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXVII. OF CRIMES, EXCUSES, AND EXTENUATIONS
  9481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSinne What
  9485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Sinne, is not onely a Transgression of a Law, but also any Contempt of
  9487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Legislator. For such Contempt, is a breach of all his Lawes at once.
  9488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore may consist, not onely in the Commission of a Fact, or in
  9489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Speaking of Words by the Lawes forbidden, or in the Omission of
  9490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat the Law commandeth, but also in the Intention, or purpose to
  9491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransgresse. For the purpose to breake the Law, is some degree of
  9492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContempt of him, to whom it belongeth to see it executed. To be
  9493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdelighted in the Imagination onely, of being possessed of another mans
  9494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgoods, servants, or wife, without any intention to take them from him
  9495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby force, or fraud, is no breach of the Law, that sayth, "Thou shalt not
  9496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcovet:" nor is the pleasure a man my have in imagining, or dreaming of
  9497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe death of him, from whose life he expecteth nothing but dammage, and
  9498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdispleasure, a Sinne; but the resolving to put some Act in execution,
  9499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat tendeth thereto. For to be pleased in the fiction of that, which
  9500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould please a man if it were reall, is a Passion so adhaerent to the
  9501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature both of a man, and every other living creature, as to make it a
  9502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSinne, were to make Sinne of being a man. The consideration of this,
  9503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thas made me think them too severe, both to themselves, and others, that
  9504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmaintain, that the First motions of the mind, (though checked with the
  9505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfear of God) be Sinnes. But I confesse it is safer to erre on that hand,
  9506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan on the other.
  9507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Crime What
  9512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Crime, is a sinne, consisting in the Committing (by Deed, or Word)
  9514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof that which the Law forbiddeth, or the Omission of what it hath
  9515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommanded. So that every Crime is a sinne; but not every sinne a Crime.
  9516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo intend to steale, or kill, is a sinne, though it never appeare in
  9517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWord, or Fact: for God that seeth the thoughts of man, can lay it to
  9518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this charge: but till it appear by some thing done, or said, by which
  9519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe intention may be Crime; which distinction the Greeks observed in
  9520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe word amartema, and egklema, or aitia; wherof the former, (which is
  9521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttranslated Sinne,) signifieth any swarving from the Law whatsoever; but
  9522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe two later, (which are translated Crime,) signifie that sinne onely,
  9523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof one man may accuse another. But of Intentions, which never
  9524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappear by any outward act, there is no place for humane accusation. In
  9525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike manner the Latines by Peccatum, which is Sinne, signifie all manner
  9526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof deviation from the Law; but by crimen, (which word they derive from
  9527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCerno, which signifies to perceive,) they mean onely such sinnes, as my
  9528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe made appear before a Judge; and therfore are not meer Intentions.
  9529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhere No Civill Law Is, There Is No Crime
  9534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom this relation of Sinne to the Law, and of Crime to the Civill
  9536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, may be inferred, First, that where Law ceaseth, Sinne ceaseth.
  9537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut because the Law of Nature is eternall, Violation of Covenants,
  9538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIngratitude, Arrogance, and all Facts contrary to any Morall vertue, can
  9539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnever cease to be Sinne. Secondly, that the Civill Law ceasing, Crimes
  9540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcease: for there being no other Law remaining, but that of Nature, there
  9541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis no place for Accusation; every man being his own Judge, and accused
  9542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely by his own Conscience, and cleared by the Uprightnesse of his own
  9543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIntention. When therefore his Intention is Right, his fact is no Sinne:
  9544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif otherwise, his fact is Sinne; but not Crime. Thirdly, That when the
  9545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power ceaseth, Crime also ceaseth: for where there is no such
  9546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower, there is no protection to be had from the Law; and therefore
  9547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one may protect himself by his own power: for no man in the
  9548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstitution of Soveraign Power can be supposed to give away the Right
  9549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof preserving his own body; for the safety whereof all Soveraignty was
  9550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordained. But this is to be understood onely of those, that have not
  9551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves contributed to the taking away of the Power that protected
  9552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem: for that was a Crime from the beginning.
  9553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance Of The Law Of Nature Excuseth No Man
  9558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe source of every Crime, is some defect of the Understanding; or some
  9560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\terrour in Reasoning, or some sudden force of the Passions. Defect in
  9561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Understanding, is Ignorance; in Reasoning, Erroneous Opinion. Again,
  9562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tignorance is of three sort; of the Law, and of the Soveraign, and of the
  9563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPenalty. Ignorance of the Law of Nature Excuseth no man; because every
  9564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman that hath attained to the use of Reason, is supposed to know, he
  9565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought not to do to another, what he would not have done to himselfe.
  9566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore into what place soever a man shall come, if he do any thing
  9567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary to that Law, it is a Crime. If a man come from the Indies
  9568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thither, and perswade men here to receive a new Religion, or teach them
  9569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany thing that tendeth to disobedience of the Lawes of this Country,
  9570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough he be never so well perswaded of the truth of what he teacheth,
  9571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the commits a Crime, and may be justly punished for the same, not onely
  9572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause his doctrine is false, but also because he does that which he
  9573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould not approve in another, namely, that comming from hence, he should
  9574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tendeavour to alter the Religion there. But ignorance of the Civill Law,
  9575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall Excuse a man in a strange Country, till it be declared to him;
  9576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause, till then no Civill Law is binding.
  9577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance Of The Civill Law Excuseth Sometimes
  9582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the like manner, if the Civill Law of a mans own Country, be not
  9584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso sufficiently declared, as he may know it if he will; nor the Action
  9585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the Law of Nature; the Ignorance is a good Excuse: In other
  9586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcases ignorance of the Civill Law, Excuseth not.
  9587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance Of The Soveraign Excuseth Not
  9592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance of the Soveraign Power, in the place of a mans ordinary
  9594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tresidence, Excuseth him not; because he ought to take notice of the
  9595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower, by which he hath been protected there.
  9596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance Of The Penalty Excuseth Not
  9601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance of the Penalty, where the Law is declared, Excuseth no man:
  9603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor in breaking the Law, which without a fear of penalty to follow, were
  9604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot a Law, but vain words, he undergoeth the penalty, though he know not
  9605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat it is; because, whosoever voluntarily doth any action, accepteth
  9606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall the known consequences of it; but Punishment is a known consequence
  9607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the violation of the Lawes, in every Common-wealth; which punishment,
  9608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif it be determined already by the Law, he is subject to that; if not,
  9609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen is he subject to Arbitrary punishment. For it is reason, that he
  9610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich does Injury, without other limitation than that of his own Will,
  9611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould suffer punishment without other limitation, than that of his Will
  9612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose Law is thereby violated.
  9613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishments Declared Before The Fact, Excuse From Greater Punishments
  9618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter It
  9620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut when a penalty, is either annexed to the Crime in the Law it selfe,
  9622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor hath been usually inflicted in the like cases; there the Delinquent
  9623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Excused from a greater penalty. For the punishment foreknown, if not
  9624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat enough to deterre men from the action, is an invitement to it:
  9625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause when men compare the benefit of their Injustice, with the harm
  9626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their punishment, by necessity of Nature they choose that which
  9627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappeareth best for themselves; and therefore when they are punished more
  9628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan the Law had formerly determined, or more than others were punished
  9629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the same Crime; it the Law that tempted, and deceiveth them.
  9630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNothing Can Be Made A Crime By A Law Made After The Fact
  9635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNo Law, made after a Fact done, can make it a Crime: because if the
  9637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFact be against the Law of Nature, the Law was before the Fact; and a
  9638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPositive Law cannot be taken notice of, before it be made; and therefore
  9639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot be Obligatory. But when the Law that forbiddeth a Fact, is made
  9640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore the Fact be done; yet he that doth the Fact, is lyable to the
  9641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPenalty ordained after, in case no lesser Penalty were made known
  9642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore, neither by Writing, nor by Example, for the reason immediatly
  9643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore alledged.
  9644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFalse Principles Of Right And Wrong Causes Of Crime
  9649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom defect in Reasoning, (that is to say, from Errour,) men are prone
  9651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto violate the Lawes, three wayes. First, by Presumption of false
  9652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrinciples; as when men from having observed how in all places, and
  9653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin all ages, unjust Actions have been authorised, by the force, and
  9654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvictories of those who have committed them; and that potent men,
  9655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbreaking through the Cob-web Lawes of their Country, the weaker sort,
  9656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand those that have failed in their Enterprises, have been esteemed the
  9657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely Criminals; have thereupon taken for Principles, and grounds of
  9658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Reasoning, "That Justice is but a vain word: That whatsoever a man
  9659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan get by his own Industry, and hazard, is his own: That the Practice
  9660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof all Nations cannot be unjust: That examples of former times are good
  9661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArguments of doing the like again;" and many more of that kind: Which
  9662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing granted, no Act in it selfe can be a Crime, but must be made so
  9663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(not by the Law, but) by the successe of them that commit it; and the
  9664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame Fact be vertuous, or vicious, as Fortune pleaseth; so that what
  9665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMarius makes a Crime, Sylla shall make meritorious, and Caesar (the same
  9666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes standing) turn again into a Crime, to the perpetuall disturbance
  9667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Peace of the Common-wealth.
  9668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFalse Teachers Mis-interpreting The Law Of Nature Secondly, by false
  9673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTeachers, that either mis-interpret the Law of Nature, making it thereby
  9674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepugnant to the Law Civill; or by teaching for Lawes, such Doctrines of
  9675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own, or Traditions of former times, as are inconsistent with the
  9676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tduty of a Subject.
  9677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd False Inferences From True Principles, By Teachers
  9682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, by Erroneous Inferences from True Principles; which happens
  9684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommonly to men that are hasty, and praecipitate in concluding, and
  9685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tresolving what to do; such as are they, that have both a great opinion
  9686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their own understanding, and believe that things of this nature
  9687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequire not time and study, but onely common experience, and a good
  9688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturall wit; whereof no man thinks himselfe unprovided: whereas the
  9689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknowledge, of Right and Wrong, which is no lesse difficult, there is no
  9690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman will pretend to, without great and long study. And of those defects
  9691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Reasoning, there is none that can Excuse (though some of them may
  9692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExtenuate) a Crime, in any man, that pretendeth to the administration of
  9693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own private businesse; much lesse in them that undertake a publique
  9694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcharge; because they pretend to the Reason, upon the want whereof they
  9695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould ground their Excuse.
  9696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Their Passions;
  9701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf the Passions that most frequently are the causes of Crime, one,
  9703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Vain-glory, or a foolish over-rating of their own worth; as if
  9704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifference of worth, were an effect of their wit, or riches, or bloud,
  9705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor some other naturall quality, not depending on the Will of those that
  9706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave the Soveraign Authority. From whence proceedeth a Presumption that
  9707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe punishments ordained by the Lawes, and extended generally to all
  9708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects, ought not to be inflicted on them, with the same rigour they
  9709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare inflicted on poore, obscure, and simple men, comprehended under the
  9710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of the Vulgar.
  9711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresumption Of Riches
  9716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore it happeneth commonly, that such as value themselves by the
  9718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreatnesse of their wealth, adventure on Crimes, upon hope of escaping
  9719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunishment, by corrupting publique Justice, or obtaining Pardon by Mony,
  9720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor other rewards.
  9721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Friends
  9726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd that such as have multitude of Potent Kindred; and popular men, that
  9728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave gained reputation amongst the Multitude, take courage to violate
  9729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Lawes, from a hope of oppressing the Power, to whom it belongeth to
  9730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tput them in execution.
  9731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWisedome
  9736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd that such as have a great, and false opinion of their own Wisedome,
  9738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake upon them to reprehend the actions, and call in question the
  9739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority of them that govern, and so to unsettle the Lawes with their
  9740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublique discourse, as that nothing shall be a Crime, but what their own
  9741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesignes require should be so. It happeneth also to the same men, to be
  9742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprone to all such Crimes, as consist in Craft, and in deceiving of their
  9743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeighbours; because they think their designes are too subtile to be
  9744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperceived. These I say are effects of a false presumption of their own
  9745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWisdome. For of them that are the first movers in the disturbance of
  9746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, (which can never happen without a Civill Warre,) very few
  9747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare left alive long enough, to see their new Designes established: so
  9748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat the benefit of their Crimes, redoundeth to Posterity, and such as
  9749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould least have wished it: which argues they were not as wise, as
  9750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey thought they were. And those that deceive upon hope of not being
  9751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserved, do commonly deceive themselves, (the darknesse in which they
  9752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbelieve they lye hidden, being nothing else but their own blindnesse;)
  9753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand are no wiser than Children, that think all hid, by hiding their own
  9754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teyes.
  9755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd generally all vain-glorious men, (unlesse they be withall timorous,)
  9757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare subject to Anger; as being more prone than others to interpret for
  9758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontempt, the ordinary liberty of conversation: And there are few Crimes
  9759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat may not be produced by Anger.
  9760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHatred, Lust, Ambition, Covetousnesse, Causes Of Crime
  9765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for the Passions, of Hate, Lust, Ambition, and Covetousnesse, what
  9767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrimes they are apt to produce, is so obvious to every mans experience
  9768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand understanding, as there needeth nothing to be said of them, saving
  9769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat they are infirmities, so annexed to the nature, both of man, and
  9770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall other living creatures, as that their effects cannot be hindred,
  9771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut by extraordinary use of Reason, or a constant severity in punishing
  9772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem. For in those things men hate, they find a continuall, and
  9773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunavoydable molestation; whereby either a mans patience must be
  9774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teverlasting, or he must be eased by removing the power of that which
  9775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmolesteth him; The former is difficult; the later is many times
  9776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpossible, without some violation of the Law. Ambition, and
  9777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovetousnesse are Passions also that are perpetually incumbent, and
  9778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpressing; whereas Reason is not perpetually present, to resist them:
  9779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore whensoever the hope of impunity appears, their effects
  9780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceed. And for Lust, what it wants in the lasting, it hath in the
  9781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvehemence, which sufficeth to weigh down the apprehension of all easie,
  9782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor uncertain punishments.
  9783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFear Sometimes Cause Of Crime, As When The Danger Is Neither Present,
  9788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor Corporeall
  9790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf all Passions, that which enclineth men least to break the Lawes, is
  9792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFear. Nay, (excepting some generous natures,) it is the onely thing,
  9793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(when there is apparence of profit, or pleasure by breaking the Lawes,)
  9794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat makes men keep them. And yet in many cases a Crime may be committed
  9795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthrough Feare.
  9796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor not every Fear justifies the Action it produceth, but the fear onely
  9798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof corporeall hurt, which we call Bodily Fear, and from which a man
  9799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot see how to be delivered, but by the action. A man is assaulted,
  9800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfears present death, from which he sees not how to escape, but by
  9801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twounding him that assaulteth him; If he wound him to death, this is no
  9802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrime; because no man is supposed at the making of a Common-wealth, to
  9803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave abandoned the defence of his life, or limbes, where the Law cannot
  9804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tarrive time enough to his assistance. But to kill a man, because from
  9805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this actions, or his threatnings, I may argue he will kill me when he
  9806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan, (seeing I have time, and means to demand protection, from the
  9807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power,) is a Crime. Again, a man receives words of disgrace,
  9808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor some little injuries (for which they that made the Lawes, had
  9809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassigned no punishment, nor thought it worthy of a man that hath the use
  9810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Reason, to take notice of,) and is afraid, unlesse he revenge it,
  9811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the shall fall into contempt, and consequently be obnoxious to the like
  9812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinjuries from others; and to avoyd this, breaks the Law, and protects
  9813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe for the future, by the terrour of his private revenge. This is
  9814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Crime; For the hurt is not Corporeall, but Phantasticall, and (though
  9815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this corner of the world, made sensible by a custome not many years
  9816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsince begun, amongst young and vain men,) so light, as a gallant man,
  9817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand one that is assured of his own courage, cannot take notice of. Also
  9818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man may stand in fear of Spirits, either through his own superstition,
  9819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor through too much credit given to other men, that tell him of strange
  9820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDreams and visions; and thereby be made believe they will hurt him, for
  9821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoing, or omitting divers things, which neverthelesse, to do, or omit,
  9822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis contrary to the Lawes; And that which is so done, or omitted, is not
  9823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be Excused by this fear; but is a Crime. For (as I have shewn before
  9824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the second Chapter) Dreams be naturally but the fancies remaining in
  9825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsleep, after the impressions our Senses had formerly received waking;
  9826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand when men are by any accident unassured they have slept, seem to be
  9827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treall Visions; and therefore he that presumes to break the Law upon his
  9828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town, or anothers Dream, or pretended Vision, or upon other Fancy of
  9829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe power of Invisible Spirits, than is permitted by the Common-wealth,
  9830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleaveth the Law of Nature, which is a certain offence, and followeth the
  9831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timagery of his own, or another private mans brain, which he can never
  9832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow whether it signifieth any thing, or nothing, nor whether he that
  9833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttells his Dream, say true, or lye; which if every private man should
  9834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave leave to do, (as they must by the Law of Nature, if any one have
  9835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit) there could no Law be made to hold, and so all Common-wealth would
  9836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe dissolved.
  9837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrimes Not Equall
  9842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom these different sources of Crimes, it appeares already, that all
  9844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrimes are not (as the Stoicks of old time maintained) of the same
  9845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallay. There is place, not only for EXCUSE, by which that which seemed
  9846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Crime, is proved to be none at all; but also for EXTENUATION, by which
  9847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Crime, that seemed great, is made lesse. For though all Crimes doe
  9848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequally deserve the name of Injustice, as all deviation from a strait
  9849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tline is equally crookednesse, which the Stoicks rightly observed; yet
  9850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit does not follow that all Crimes are equally unjust, no more than that
  9851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall crooked lines are equally crooked; which the Stoicks not observing,
  9852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theld it as great a Crime, to kill a Hen, against the Law, as to kill
  9853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tones Father.
  9854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTotall Excuses
  9859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat which totally Excuseth a Fact, and takes away from it the nature of
  9861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Crime, can be none but that, which at the same time, taketh away the
  9862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobligation of the Law. For the fact committed once against the Law,
  9863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif he that committed it be obliged to the Law, can be no other than a
  9864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrime.
  9865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe want of means to know the Law, totally Excuseth: For the Law whereof
  9867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man has no means to enforme himself, is not obligatory. But the want
  9868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof diligence to enquire, shall not be considered as a want of means; Nor
  9869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall any man, that pretendeth to reason enough for the Government of
  9870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own affairs, be supposed to want means to know the Lawes of Nature;
  9871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause they are known by the reason he pretends to: only Children, and
  9872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMadmen are Excused from offences against the Law Naturall.
  9873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhere a man is captive, or in the power of the enemy, (and he is then in
  9875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe power of the enemy, when his person, or his means of living, is
  9876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso,) if it be without his own fault, the Obligation of the Law ceaseth;
  9877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause he must obey the enemy, or dye; and consequently such obedience
  9878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis no Crime: for no man is obliged (when the protection of the Law
  9879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaileth,) not to protect himself, by the best means he can.
  9880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a man by the terrour of present death, be compelled to doe a fact
  9882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the Law, he is totally Excused; because no Law can oblige a
  9883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman to abandon his own preservation. And supposing such a Law were
  9884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobligatory; yet a man would reason thus, "If I doe it not, I die
  9885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresently; if I doe it, I die afterwards; therefore by doing it, there
  9886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis time of life gained;" Nature therefore compells him to the fact.
  9887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen a man is destitute of food, or other thing necessary for his life,
  9889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand cannot preserve himselfe any other way, but by some fact against
  9890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law; as if in a great famine he take the food by force, or stealth,
  9891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich he cannot obtaine for mony nor charity; or in defence of his life,
  9892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsnatch away another mans Sword, he is totally Excused, for the reason
  9893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnext before alledged.
  9894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcuses Against The Author
  9899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, Facts done against the Law, by the authority of another, are
  9901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby that authority Excused against the Author; because no man ought to
  9902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccuse his own fact in another, that is but his instrument: but it
  9903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not Excused against a third person thereby injured; because in the
  9904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tviolation of the law, bothe the Author, and Actor are Criminalls.
  9905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom hence it followeth that when that Man, or Assembly, that hath the
  9906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power, commandeth a man to do that which is contrary to a
  9907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformer Law, the doing of it is totally Excused: For he ought not to
  9908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondemn it himselfe, because he is the Author; and what cannot justly
  9909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe condemned by the Soveraign, cannot justly be punished by any other.
  9910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBesides, when the Soveraign commandeth any thing to be done against
  9911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own former Law, the Command, as to that particular fact, is an
  9912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabrogation of the Law.
  9913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf that Man, or Assembly, that hath the Soveraign Power, disclaime
  9915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany Right essentiall to the Soveraignty, whereby there accrueth to the
  9916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubject, any liberty inconsistent with the Soveraign Power, that is to
  9917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, with the very being of a Common-wealth, if the Subject shall refuse
  9918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey the Command in any thing, contrary to the liberty granted, this
  9919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis neverthelesse a Sinne, and contrary to the duty of the Subject: for
  9920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the ought to take notice of what is inconsistent with the Soveraignty,
  9921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause it was erected by his own consent, and for his own defence;
  9922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand that such liberty as is inconsistent with it, was granted through
  9923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tignorance of the evill consequence thereof. But if he not onely disobey,
  9924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut also resist a publique Minister in the execution of it, then it is
  9925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Crime; because he might have been righted, (without any breach of the
  9926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace,) upon complaint.
  9927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Degrees of Crime are taken on divers Scales, and measured, First, by
  9929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe malignity of the Source, or Cause: Secondly, by the contagion of the
  9930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExample: Thirdly, by the mischiefe of the Effect; and Fourthly, by the
  9931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcurrence of Times, Places, and Persons.
  9932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresumption Of Power, Aggravateth
  9937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe same Fact done against the Law, if it proceed from Presumption of
  9939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstrength, riches, or friends to resist those that are to execute the
  9940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, is a greater Crime, than if it proceed from hope of not being
  9941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscovered, or of escape by flight: For Presumption of impunity by
  9942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforce, is a Root, from whence springeth, at all times, and upon all
  9943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttemptations, a contempt of all Lawes; whereas in the later case, the
  9944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapprehension of danger, that makes a man fly, renders him more obedient
  9945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the future. A Crime which we know to be so, is greater than the same
  9946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrime proceeding from a false perswasion that it is lawfull: For he that
  9947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommitteth it against his own conscience, presumeth on his force, or
  9948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother power, which encourages him to commit the same again: but he that
  9949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoth it by errour, after the errour shewn him, is conformable to the
  9950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw.
  9951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvill Teachers, Extenuate
  9956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHee, whose errour proceeds from the authority of a Teacher, or an
  9958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpreter of the Law publiquely authorised, is not so faulty, as he
  9959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose errour proceedeth from a peremptory pursute of his own principles,
  9960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand reasoning: For what is taught by one that teacheth by publique
  9961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority, the Common-wealth teacheth, and hath a resemblance of Law,
  9962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttill the same Authority controuleth it; and in all Crimes that contain
  9963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot in them a denyall of the Soveraign Power, nor are against an evident
  9964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, Excuseth totally: whereas he that groundeth his actions, on his
  9965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate Judgement, ought according to the rectitude, or errour thereof,
  9966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto stand, or fall.
  9967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExamples Of Impunity, Extenuate
  9972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe same Fact, if it have been constantly punished in other men, as
  9974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta greater Crime, than if there have been may precedent Examples of
  9975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpunity. For those Examples, are so many hopes of Impunity given by
  9976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign himselfe: And because he which furnishes a man with such
  9977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta hope, and presumption of mercy, as encourageth him to offend, hath his
  9978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart in the offence; he cannot reasonably charge the offender with the
  9979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhole.
  9980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPraemeditation, Aggravateth
  9985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Crime arising from a sudden Passion, is not so great, as when the same
  9987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tariseth from long meditation: For in the former case there is a place
  9988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Extenuation, in the common infirmity of humane nature: but he that
  9989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoth it with praemeditation, has used circumspection, and cast his eye,
  9990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton the Law, on the punishment, and on the consequence thereof to humane
  9991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsociety; all which in committing the Crime, hee hath contemned, and
  9992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpostposed to his own appetite. But there is no suddennesse of Passion
  9993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsufficient for a totall Excuse: For all the time between the first
  9994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknowing of the Law, and the Commission of the Fact, shall be taken for
  9995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta time of deliberation; because he ought by meditation of the Law, to
  9996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trectifie the irregularity of his Passions.
  9997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
  9998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhere the Law is publiquely, and with assiduity, before all the people
  9999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tread, and interpreted; a fact done against it, is a greater Crime,
 10000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan where men are left without such instruction, to enquire of it with
 10001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifficulty, uncertainty, and interruption of their Callings, and
 10002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe informed by private men: for in this case, part of the fault is
 10003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdischarged upon common infirmity; but in the former there is apparent
 10004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnegligence, which is not without some contempt of the Soveraign Power.
 10005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTacite Approbation Of The Soveraign, Extenuates
 10010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThose facts which the Law expresly condemneth, but the Law-maker by
 10012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother manifest signes of his will tacitly approveth, are lesse Crimes,
 10013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan the same facts, condemned both by the Law, and Lawmaker. For
 10014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseeing the will of the Law-maker is a Law, there appear in this case two
