 10015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontradictory Lawes; which would totally Excuse, if men were bound to
 10016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake notice of the Soveraigns approbation, by other arguments, than are
 10017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpressed by his command. But because there are punishments consequent,
 10018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot onely to the transgression of his Law, but also to the observing
 10019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof it, he is in part a cause of the transgression, and therefore cannot
 10020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasonably impute the whole Crime to the Delinquent. For example, the
 10021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw condemneth Duells; the punishment is made capitall: On the contrary
 10022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart, he that refuseth Duell, is subject to contempt and scorne, without
 10023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tremedy; and sometimes by the Soveraign himselfe thought unworthy to
 10024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave any charge, or preferment in Warre: If thereupon he accept Duell,
 10025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsidering all men lawfully endeavour to obtain the good opinion
 10026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them that have the Soveraign Power, he ought not in reason to be
 10027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trigorously punished; seeing part of the fault may be discharged on the
 10028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunisher; which I say, not as wishing liberty of private revenges,
 10029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor any other kind of disobedience; but a care in Governours, not
 10030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto countenance any thing obliquely, which directly they forbid. The
 10031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texamples of Princes, to those that see them, are, and ever have been,
 10032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore potent to govern their actions, than the Lawes themselves. And
 10033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough it be our duty to do, not what they do, but what they say; yet
 10034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill that duty never be performed, till it please God to give men an
 10035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textraordinary, and supernaturall grace to follow that Precept.
 10036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tComparison Of Crimes From Their Effects
 10041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, if we compare Crimes by the mischiefe of their Effects, First,
 10043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same fact, when it redounds to the dammage of many, is greater, than
 10044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen it redounds to the hurt of few. And therefore, when a fact hurteth,
 10045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot onely in the present, but also, (by example) in the future, it is a
 10046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreater Crime, than if it hurt onely in the present: for the former,
 10047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a fertile Crime, and multiplyes to the hurt of many; the later is
 10048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbarren. To maintain doctrines contrary to the Religion established in
 10049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Common-wealth, is a greater fault, in an authorised Preacher, than
 10050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin a private person: So also is it, to live prophanely, incontinently,
 10051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor do any irreligious act whatsoever. Likewise in a Professor of the
 10052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, to maintain any point, on do any act, that tendeth to the weakning
 10053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Soveraign Power, as a greater Crime, than in another man: Also in
 10054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man that hath such reputation for wisedome, as that his counsells are
 10055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollowed, or his actions imitated by many, his fact against the Law, is
 10056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta greater Crime, than the same fact in another: For such men not onely
 10057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommit Crime, but teach it for Law to all other men. And generally all
 10058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrimes are the greater, by the scandall they give; that is to say, by
 10059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecoming stumbling-blocks to the weak, that look not so much upon the
 10060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tway they go in, as upon the light that other men carry before them.
 10061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaesae Majestas
 10066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso Facts of Hostility against the present state of the Common-wealth,
 10068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare greater Crimes, than the same acts done to private men; For
 10069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe dammage extends it selfe to all: Such are the betraying of the
 10070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstrengths, or revealing of the secrets of the Common-wealth to an Enemy;
 10071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso all attempts upon the Representative of the Common-wealth, be it a
 10072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmonarch, or an Assembly; and all endeavours by word, or deed to diminish
 10073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Authority of the same, either in the present time, or in succession:
 10074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich Crimes the Latines understand by Crimina Laesae Majestatis, and
 10075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsist in designe, or act, contrary to a Fundamentall Law.
 10076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBribery And False Testimony
 10081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLikewise those Crimes, which render Judgements of no effect, are greater
 10083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrimes, than Injuries done to one, or a few persons; as to receive
 10084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmony to give False judgement, or testimony, is a greater Crime, than
 10085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\totherwise to deceive a man of the like, or a greater summe; because not
 10086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely he has wrong, that falls by such judgements; but all Judgements
 10087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare rendered uselesse, and occasion ministred to force, and private
 10088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trevenges.
 10089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDepeculation
 10094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso Robbery, and Depeculation of the Publique treasure, or Revenues,
 10096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a greater Crime, than the robbing, or defrauding of a Private man;
 10097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause to robbe the publique, is to robbe many at once.
 10098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounterfeiting Authority
 10103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso the Counterfeit usurpation of publique Ministery, the
 10105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounterfeiting of publique Seales, or publique Coine, than
 10106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcounterfeiting of a private mans person, or his seale; because the fraud
 10107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof, extendeth to the dammage of many.
 10108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrimes Against Private Men Compared
 10113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf facts against the Law, done to private men, the greater Crime, is
 10115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat, where the dammage in the common opinion of men, is most sensible.
 10116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore
 10117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo kill against the Law, is a greater Crime, that any other injury, life
 10119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreserved.
 10120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd to kill with Torment, greater, than simply to kill.
 10122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Mutilation of a limbe, greater, than the spoyling a man of his
 10124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgoods.
 10125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd the spoyling a man of his goods, by Terrour of death, or wounds,
 10127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan by clandestine surreption.
 10128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd by clandestine Surreption, than by consent fraudulently obtained.
 10130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd the violation of chastity by Force, greater, than by flattery.
 10132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd of a woman Married, than of a woman not married.
 10134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor all these things are commonly so valued; though some men are more,
 10136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand some lesse sensible of the same offence. But the Law regardeth not
 10137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe particular, but the generall inclination of mankind.
 10138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore the offence men take, from contumely, in words, or
 10140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgesture, when they produce no other harme, than the present griefe of
 10141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim that is reproached, hath been neglected in the Lawes of the Greeks,
 10142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRomans, and other both antient, and moderne Common-wealths; supposing
 10143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe true cause of such griefe to consist, not in the contumely, (which
 10144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttakes no hold upon men conscious of their own Vertue,) but in the
 10145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPusillanimity of him that is offended by it.
 10146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso a Crime against a private man, is much aggravated by the person,
 10148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, and place. For to kill ones Parent, is a greater Crime, than to
 10149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkill another: for the Parent ought to have the honour of a Soveraign,
 10150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(though he have surrendred his Power to the Civill Law,) because he had
 10151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit originally by Nature. And to Robbe a poore man, is a greater Crime,
 10152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan to robbe a rich man; because 'tis to the poore a more sensible
 10153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdammage.
 10154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd a Crime committed in the Time, or Place appointed for Devotion, is
 10156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreater, than if committed at another time or place: for it proceeds
 10157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom a greater contempt of the Law.
 10158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMany other cases of Aggravation, and Extenuation might be added: but by
 10160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese I have set down, it is obvious to every man, to take the altitude
 10161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof any other Crime proposed.
 10162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Crimes What
 10167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, because in almost all Crimes there is an Injury done, not onely
 10169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto some Private man, but also to the Common-wealth; the same Crime, when
 10170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe accusation is in the name of the Common-wealth, is called Publique
 10171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrime; and when in the name of a Private man, a Private Crime; And the
 10172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPleas according thereunto called Publique, Judicia Publica, Pleas of the
 10173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrown; or Private Pleas. As in an Accusation of Murder, if the accuser
 10174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe a Private man, the plea is a Private plea; if the accuser be the
 10175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, the plea is a Publique plea.
 10176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXVIII. OF PUNISHMENTS, AND REWARDS
 10180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Definition Of Punishment
 10185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"A PUNISHMENT, is an Evill inflicted by publique Authority, on him that
 10187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath done, or omitted that which is Judged by the same Authority to be
 10188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Transgression of the Law; to the end that the will of men may thereby
 10189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe better be disposed to obedience."
 10190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight To Punish Whence Derived
 10195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBefore I inferre any thing from this definition, there is a question to
 10197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe answered, of much importance; which is, by what door the Right, or
 10198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority of Punishing in any case, came in. For by that which has
 10199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen said before, no man is supposed bound by Covenant, not to resist
 10200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tviolence; and consequently it cannot be intended, that he gave any right
 10201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto another to lay violent hands upon his person. In the making of a
 10202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, every man giveth away the right of defending another; but
 10203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot of defending himselfe. Also he obligeth himselfe, to assist him that
 10204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath the Soveraignty, in the Punishing of another; but of himselfe
 10205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot. But to covenant to assist the Soveraign, in doing hurt to another,
 10206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunlesse he that so covenanteth have a right to doe it himselfe, is not
 10207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto give him a Right to Punish. It is manifest therefore that the Right
 10208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Common-wealth (that is, he, or they that represent it) hath to
 10209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunish, is not grounded on any concession, or gift of the Subjects.
 10210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut I have also shewed formerly, that before the Institution of
 10211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, every man had a right to every thing, and to do
 10212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever he thought necessary to his own preservation; subduing,
 10213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thurting, or killing any man in order thereunto. And this is the
 10214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfoundation of that right of Punishing, which is exercised in every
 10215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth. For the Subjects did not give the Soveraign that right;
 10216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut onely in laying down theirs, strengthned him to use his own, as he
 10217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould think fit, for the preservation of them all: so that it was not
 10218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiven, but left to him, and to him onely; and (excepting the limits set
 10219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim by naturall Law) as entire, as in the condition of meer Nature, and
 10220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof warre of every one against his neighbour.
 10221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivate Injuries, And Revenges No Punishments
 10226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom the definition of Punishment, I inferre, First, that neither
 10228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate revenges, nor injuries of private men, can properly be stiled
 10229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishment; because they proceed not from publique Authority.
 10230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor Denyall Of Preferment
 10235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, that to be neglected, and unpreferred by the publique
 10237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfavour, is not a Punishment; because no new evill is thereby on any man
 10238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInflicted; he is onely left in the estate he was in before.
 10239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor Pain Inflicted Without Publique Hearing
 10244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, that the evill inflicted by publique Authority, without
 10246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprecedent publique condemnation, is not to be stiled by the name of
 10247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishment; but of an hostile act; because the fact for which a man
 10248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Punished, ought first to be Judged by publique Authority, to be a
 10249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransgression of the Law.
 10250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor Pain Inflicted By Usurped Power
 10255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, that the evill inflicted by usurped power, and Judges
 10257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout Authority from the Soveraign, is not Punishment; but an act of
 10258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thostility; because the acts of power usurped, have not for Author, the
 10259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperson condemned; and therefore are not acts of publique Authority.
 10260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor Pain Inflicted Without Respect To The Future Good
 10265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFifthly, that all evill which is inflicted without intention, or
 10267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossibility of disposing the Delinquent, or (by his example) other men,
 10268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey the Lawes, is not Punishment; but an act of hostility; because
 10269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout such an end, no hurt done is contained under that name.
 10270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall Evill Consequences, No Punishments
 10275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSixthly, whereas to certain actions, there be annexed by Nature, divers
 10277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thurtfull consequences; as when a man in assaulting another, is himselfe
 10278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tslain, or wounded; or when he falleth into sicknesse by the doing of
 10279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome unlawfull act; such hurt, though in respect of God, who is the
 10280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthor of Nature, it may be said to be inflicted, and therefore a
 10281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishment divine; yet it is not contaned in the name of Punishment in
 10282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trespect of men, because it is not inflicted by the Authority of man.
 10283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHurt Inflicted, If Lesse Than The Benefit Of Transgressing,
 10288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIs Not Punishment
 10290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeventhly, If the harm inflicted be lesse than the benefit, or
 10292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontentment that naturally followeth the crime committed, that harm is
 10293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot within the definition; and is rather the Price, or Redemption, than
 10294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Punishment of a Crime: Because it is of the nature of Punishment, to
 10295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave for end, the disposing of men to obey the Law; which end (if it
 10296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe lesse that the benefit of the transgression) it attaineth not, but
 10297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworketh a contrary effect.
 10298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhere The Punishment Is Annexed To The Law, A Greater Hurt Is Not
 10303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishment, But Hostility
 10305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEighthly, If a Punishment be determined and prescribed in the Law it
 10307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tselfe, and after the crime committed, there be a greater Punishment
 10308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinflicted, the excesse is not Punishment, but an act of hostility. For
 10309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseeing the aym of Punishment is not a revenge, but terrour; and the
 10310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tterrour of a great Punishment unknown, is taken away by the declaration
 10311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a lesse, the unexpected addition is no part of the Punishment.
 10312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut where there is no Punishment at all determined by the Law, there
 10313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever is inflicted, hath the nature of Punishment. For he that
 10314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgoes about the violation of a Law, wherein no penalty is determined,
 10315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpecteth an indeterminate, that is to say, an arbitrary Punishment.
 10316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHurt Inflicted For A Fact Done Before The Law, No Punishment
 10321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNinthly, Harme inflicted for a Fact done before there was a Law that
 10323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforbad it, is not Punishment, but an act of Hostility: For before the
 10324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, there is no transgression of the Law: But Punishment supposeth a
 10325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfact judged, to have been a transgression of the Law; Therefore
 10326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHarme inflicted before the Law made, is not Punishment, but an act of
 10327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHostility.
 10328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Representative Of The Common-wealth Unpunishable
 10333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTenthly, Hurt inflicted on the Representative of the Common-wealth, is
 10335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot Punishment, but an act of Hostility: Because it is of the nature
 10336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Punishment, to be inflicted by publique Authority, which is the
 10337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority only of the Representative it self.
 10338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHurt To Revolted Subjects Is Done By Right Of War, Not
 10343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Way Of Punishment
 10345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, Harme inflicted upon one that is a declared enemy, fals not
 10347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder the name of Punishment: Because seeing they were either never
 10348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject to the Law, and therefore cannot transgresse it; or having been
 10349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject to it, and professing to be no longer so, by consequence deny
 10350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey can transgresse it, all the Harmes that can be done them, must be
 10351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaken as acts of Hostility. But in declared Hostility, all infliction of
 10352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevill is lawfull. From whence it followeth, that if a subject shall
 10353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby fact, or word, wittingly, and deliberatly deny the authority of
 10354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Representative of the Common-wealth, (whatsoever penalty hath
 10355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen formerly ordained for Treason,) he may lawfully be made to suffer
 10356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever the Representative will: For in denying subjection, he denyes
 10357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch Punishment as by the Law hath been ordained; and therefore suffers
 10358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas an enemy of the Common-wealth; that is, according to the will of
 10359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Representative. For the Punishments set down in the Law, are to
 10360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects, not to Enemies; such as are they, that having been by their
 10361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town act Subjects, deliberately revolting, deny the Soveraign Power.
 10362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe first, and most generall distribution of Punishments, is into
 10364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivine, and Humane. Of the former I shall have occasion, to speak, in a
 10365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore convenient place hereafter.
 10366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHumane, are those Punishments that be inflicted by the Commandement
 10368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Man; and are either Corporall, or Pecuniary, or Ignominy, or
 10369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImprisonment, or Exile, or mixt of these.
 10370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishments Corporall
 10375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCorporall Punishment is that, which is inflicted on the body directly,
 10377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand according to the intention of him that inflicteth it: such as are
 10378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstripes, or wounds, or deprivation of such pleasures of the body, as
 10379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere before lawfully enjoyed.
 10380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCapitall
 10385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd of these, some be Capitall, some Lesse than Capitall. Capitall, is
 10387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Infliction of Death; and that either simply, or with torment. Lesse
 10388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan Capitall, are Stripes, Wounds, Chains, and any other corporall
 10389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPaine, not in its own nature mortall. For if upon the Infliction of
 10390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Punishment death follow not in the Intention of the Inflicter, the
 10391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishment is not be bee esteemed Capitall, though the harme prove
 10392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmortall by an accident not to be foreseen; in which case death is not
 10393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinflicted, but hastened.
 10394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPecuniary Punishment, is that which consisteth not only in the
 10396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeprivation of a Summe of Mony, but also of Lands, or any other goods
 10397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich are usually bought and sold for mony. And in case the Law, that
 10398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordaineth such a punishment, be made with design to gather mony, from
 10399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as shall transgresse the same, it is not properly a Punishment,
 10400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the Price of priviledge, and exemption from the Law, which doth not
 10401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsolutely forbid the fact, but only to those that are not able to pay
 10402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe mony: except where the Law is Naturall, or part of Religion; for in
 10403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat case it is not an exemption from the Law, but a transgression of
 10404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit. As where a Law exacteth a Pecuniary mulct, of them that take the
 10405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of God in vaine, the payment of the mulct, is not the price of a
 10406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdispensation to sweare, but the Punishment of the transgression of a Law
 10407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tundispensable. In like manner if the Law impose a Summe of Mony to be
 10408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpayd, to him that has been Injured; this is but a satisfaction for the
 10409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thurt done him; and extinguisheth the accusation of the party injured,
 10410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot the crime of the offender.
 10411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnominy
 10416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnominy, is the infliction of such Evill, as is made Dishonorable;
 10418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor the deprivation of such Good, as is made Honourable by the
 10419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth. For there be some things Honorable by Nature; as the
 10420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teffects of Courage, Magnanimity, Strength, Wisdome, and other abilities
 10421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof body and mind: Others made Honorable by the Common-wealth; as Badges,
 10422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTitles, Offices, or any other singular marke of the Soveraigns favour.
 10423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe former, (though they may faile by nature, or accident,) cannot be
 10424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaken away by a Law; and therefore the losse of them is not Punishment.
 10425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the later, may be taken away by the publique authority that made
 10426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem Honorable, and are properly Punishments: Such are degrading men
 10427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondemned, of their Badges, Titles, and Offices; or declaring them
 10428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuncapable of the like in time to come.
 10429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImprisonment
 10434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImprisonment, is when a man is by publique Authority deprived of
 10436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tliberty; and may happen from two divers ends; whereof one is the safe
 10437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcustody of a man accused; the other is the inflicting of paine on a man
 10438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondemned. The former is not Punishment; because no man is supposed
 10439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be Punisht, before he be Judicially heard, and declared guilty.
 10440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore whatsoever hurt a man is made to suffer by bonds, or
 10441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trestraint, before his cause be heard, over and above that which is
 10442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessary to assure his custody, is against the Law of Nature. But the
 10443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLater is Punishment, because Evill, and inflicted by publique Authority,
 10444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor somewhat that has by the same Authority been Judged a Transgression
 10445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Law. Under this word Imprisonment, I comprehend all restraint of
 10446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmotion, caused by an externall obstacle, be it a House, which is called
 10447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the generall name of a Prison; or an Iland, as when men are said to
 10448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe confined to it; or a place where men are set to worke, as in old time
 10449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen have been condemned to Quarries, and in these times to Gallies; or
 10450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe it a Chaine, or any other such impediment.
 10451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExile
 10456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExile, (Banishment) is when a man is for a crime, condemned to depart
 10458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of the dominion of the Common-wealth, or out of a certaine part
 10459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof; and during a prefixed time, or for ever, not to return into it:
 10460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand seemeth not in its own nature, without other circumstances, to be
 10461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Punishment; but rather an escape, or a publique commandement to
 10462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tavoid Punishment by flight. And Cicero sayes, there was never any such
 10463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishment ordained in the City of Rome; but cals it a refuge of men in
 10464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdanger. For if a man banished, be neverthelesse permitted to enjoy
 10465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Goods, and the Revenue of his Lands, the meer change of ayr is no
 10466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunishment; nor does it tend to that benefit of the Common-wealth, for
 10467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich all Punishments are ordained, (that is to say, to the forming of
 10468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmens wils to the observation of the Law;) but many times to the dammage
 10469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Common-wealth. For a Banished man, is a lawfull enemy of the
 10470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth that banished him; as being no more a Member of the
 10471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame. But if he be withall deprived of his Lands, or Goods, then
 10472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Punishment lyeth not in the Exile, but is to be reckoned amongst
 10473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishments Pecuniary.
 10474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Punishment Of Innocent Subjects Is Contrary To The Law Of Nature
 10479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll Punishments of Innocent subjects, be they great or little, are
 10481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the Law of Nature; For Punishment is only of Transgression of
 10482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law, and therefore there can be no Punishment of the Innocent. It
 10483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis therefore a violation, First, of that Law of Nature, which forbiddeth
 10484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall men, in their Revenges, to look at any thing but some future good:
 10485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor there can arrive no good to the Common-wealth, by Punishing the
 10486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInnocent. Secondly, of that, which forbiddeth Ingratitude: For seeing
 10487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall Soveraign Power, is originally given by the consent of every one of
 10488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Subjects, to the end they should as long as they are obedient, be
 10489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprotected thereby; the Punishment of the Innocent, is a rendring of
 10490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvill for Good. And thirdly, of the Law that commandeth Equity; that
 10491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, an equall distribution of Justice; which in Punishing the
 10492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInnocent is not observed.
 10493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut The Harme Done To Innocents In War, Not So
 10498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the Infliction of what evill soever, on an Innocent man, that is not
 10500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Subject, if it be for the benefit of the Common-wealth, and without
 10501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tviolation of any former Covenant, is no breach of the Law of Nature.
 10502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor all men that are not Subjects, are either Enemies, or else they have
 10503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tceased from being so, by some precedent covenants. But against Enemies,
 10504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom the Common-wealth judgeth capable to do them hurt, it is lawfull by
 10505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe originall Right of Nature to make warre; wherein the Sword Judgeth
 10506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot, nor doth the Victor make distinction of Nocent and Innocent, as to
 10507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe time past; nor has other respect of mercy, than as it conduceth to
 10508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe good of his own People. And upon this ground it is, that also
 10509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Subjects, who deliberatly deny the Authority of the Common-wealth
 10510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\testablished, the vengeance is lawfully extended, not onely to the
 10511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFathers, but also to the third and fourth generation not yet in being,
 10512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand consequently innocent of the fact, for which they are afflicted:
 10513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause the nature of this offence, consisteth in the renouncing of
 10514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubjection; which is a relapse into the condition of warre, commonly
 10515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Rebellion; and they that so offend, suffer not as Subjects, but
 10516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas Enemies. For Rebellion, is but warre renewed.
 10517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReward, Is Either Salary, Or Grace
 10522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tREWARD, is either of Gift, or by Contract. When by Contract, it is
 10524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Salary, and Wages; which is benefit due for service performed, or
 10525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpromised. When of Gift, it is benefit proceeding from the Grace of them
 10526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat bestow it, to encourage, or enable men to do them service. And
 10527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore when the Soveraign of a Common-wealth appointeth a Salary
 10528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto any publique Office, he that receiveth it, is bound in Justice
 10529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto performe his office; otherwise, he is bound onely in honour, to
 10530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledgement, and an endeavour of requitall. For though men have no
 10531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfull remedy, when they be commanded to quit their private businesse,
 10532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto serve the publique, without Reward, or Salary; yet they are not
 10533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbound thereto, by the Law of Nature, nor by the institution of the
 10534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, unlesse the service cannot otherwise be done; because it
 10535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis supposed the Soveraign may make use of all their means, insomuch as
 10536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe most common Souldier, may demand the wages of his warrefare, as a
 10537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdebt.
 10538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBenefits Bestowed For Fear, Are Not Rewards
 10543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe benefits which a Soveraign bestoweth on a Subject, for fear of some
 10545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower, and ability he hath to do hurt to the Common-wealth, are not
 10546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproperly Rewards; for they are not Salaryes; because there is in this
 10547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcase no contract supposed, every man being obliged already not to do the
 10548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth disservice: nor are they Graces; because they be extorted
 10549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby feare, which ought not to be incident to the Soveraign Power: but
 10550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare rather Sacrifices, which the Soveraign (considered in his naturall
 10551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperson, and not in the person of the Common-wealth) makes, for the
 10552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappeasing the discontent of him he thinks more potent than himselfe; and
 10553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tencourage not to obedience, but on the contrary, to the continuance, and
 10554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tincreasing of further extortion.
 10555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalaries Certain And Casuall
 10560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whereas some Salaries are certain, and proceed from the publique
 10562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTreasure; and others uncertain, and casuall, proceeding from the
 10563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texecution of the Office for which the Salary is ordained; the later
 10564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis in some cases hurtfull to the Common-wealth; as in the case of
 10565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudicature. For where the benefit of the Judges, and Ministers of a
 10566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCourt of Justice, ariseth for the multitude of Causes that are brought
 10567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto their cognisance, there must needs follow two Inconveniences: One,
 10568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the nourishing of sutes; for the more sutes, the greater benefit: and
 10569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother that depends on that, which is contention about Jurisdiction;
 10570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teach Court drawing to it selfe, as many Causes as it can. But in
 10571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toffices of Execution there are not those Inconveniences; because their
 10572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\temployment cannot be encreased by any endeavour of their own. And thus
 10573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmuch shall suffice for the nature of Punishment, and Reward; which are,
 10574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas it were, the Nerves and Tendons, that move the limbes and joynts of a
 10575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth.
 10576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHitherto I have set forth the nature of Man, (whose Pride and other
 10578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions have compelled him to submit himselfe to Government;) together
 10579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the great power of his Governour, whom I compared to Leviathan,
 10580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaking that comparison out of the two last verses of the one and
 10581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfortieth of Job; where God having set forth the great power of
 10582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLeviathan, called him King of the Proud. "There is nothing," saith he,
 10583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"on earth, to be compared with him. He is made so as not be afraid. Hee
 10584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseeth every high thing below him; and is King of all the children of
 10585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpride." But because he is mortall, and subject to decay, as all other
 10586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarthly creatures are; and because there is that in heaven, (though not
 10587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton earth) that he should stand in fear of, and whose Lawes he ought to
 10588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobey; I shall in the next following Chapters speak of his Diseases, and
 10589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe causes of his Mortality; and of what Lawes of Nature he is bound to
 10590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobey.
 10591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXIX. OF THOSE THINGS THAT WEAKEN, OR TEND TO THE DISSOLUTION OF
 10595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA COMMON-WEALTH
 10596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDissolution Of Common-wealths Proceedeth From Imperfect Institution
 10599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThough nothing can be immortall, which mortals make; yet, if men had the
 10601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuse of reason they pretend to, their Common-wealths might be secured, at
 10602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleast, from perishing by internall diseases. For by the nature of their
 10603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstitution, they are designed to live, as long as Man-kind, or as
 10604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Lawes of Nature, or as Justice it selfe, which gives them life.
 10605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore when they come to be dissolved, not by externall violence, but
 10606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tintestine disorder, the fault is not in men, as they are the Matter; but
 10607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they are the Makers, and orderers of them. For men, as they become
 10608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat last weary of irregular justling, and hewing one another, and desire
 10609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith all their hearts, to conforme themselves into one firme and lasting
 10610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tedifice; so for want, both of the art of making fit Laws, to square
 10611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir actions by, and also of humility, and patience, to suffer the rude
 10612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand combersome points of their present greatnesse to be taken off, they
 10613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot without the help of a very able Architect, be compiled, into any
 10614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother than a crasie building, such as hardly lasting out their own time,
 10615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmust assuredly fall upon the heads of their posterity.
 10616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAmongst the Infirmities therefore of a Common-wealth, I will reckon in
 10618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe first place, those that arise from an Imperfect Institution,
 10619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand resemble the diseases of a naturall body, which proceed from a
 10620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDefectuous Procreation.
 10621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWant Of Absolute Power
 10626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf which, this is one, "That a man to obtain a Kingdome, is sometimes
 10628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontent with lesse Power, than to the Peace, and defence of the
 10629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth is necessarily required." From whence it commeth to passe,
 10630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat when the exercise of the Power layd by, is for the publique safety
 10631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be resumed, it hath the resemblance of as unjust act; which disposeth
 10632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat numbers of men (when occasion is presented) to rebell; In the
 10633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame manner as the bodies of children, gotten by diseased parents, are
 10634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject either to untimely death, or to purge the ill quality, derived
 10635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom their vicious conception, by breaking out into biles and scabbs.
 10636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd when Kings deny themselves some such necessary Power, it is not
 10637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talwayes (though sometimes) out of ignorance of what is necessary to the
 10638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toffice they undertake; but many times out of a hope to recover the same
 10639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain at their pleasure: Wherein they reason not well; because such as
 10640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill hold them to their promises, shall be maintained against them by
 10641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforraign Common-wealths; who in order to the good of their own Subjects
 10642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlet slip few occasions to Weaken the estate of their Neighbours. So was
 10643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThomas Beckett Archbishop of Canterbury, supported against Henry
 10644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Second, by the Pope; the subjection of Ecclesiastiques to the
 10645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, having been dispensed with by William the Conqueror at
 10646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this reception, when he took an Oath, not to infringe the liberty of the
 10647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch. And so were the Barons, whose power was by William Rufus (to
 10648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave their help in transferring the Succession from his Elder brother,
 10649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto himselfe,) encreased to a degree, inconsistent with the Soveraign
 10650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower, maintained in their Rebellion against King John, by the French.
 10651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor does this happen in Monarchy onely. For whereas the stile of the
 10652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tantient Roman Common-wealth, was, The Senate, and People of Rome;
 10653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneither Senate, nor People pretended to the whole Power; which first
 10654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcaused the seditions, of Tiberius Gracchus, Caius Gracchus, Lucius
 10655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaturnius, and others; and afterwards the warres between the Senate and
 10656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe People, under Marius and Sylla; and again under Pompey and Caesar,
 10657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Extinction of their Democraty, and the setting up of Monarchy.
 10658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe people of Athens bound themselves but from one onely Action; which
 10660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas, that no man on pain of death should propound the renewing of the
 10661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twarre for the Island of Salamis; And yet thereby, if Solon had not
 10662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcaused to be given out he was mad, and afterwards in gesture and habit
 10663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a mad-man, and in verse, propounded it to the People that flocked
 10664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabout him, they had had an enemy perpetually in readinesse, even at the
 10665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgates of their Citie; such dammage, or shifts, are all Common-wealths
 10666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforced to, that have their Power never so little limited.
 10667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivate Judgement Of Good and Evill
 10672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the second place, I observe the Diseases of a Common-wealth, that
 10674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceed from the poyson of seditious doctrines; whereof one is, "That
 10675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery private man is Judge of Good and Evill actions." This is true in
 10676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe condition of meer Nature, where there are no Civill Lawes; and also
 10677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder Civill Government, in such cases as are not determined by the
 10678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw. But otherwise, it is manifest, that the measure of Good and Evill
 10679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions, is the Civill Law; and the Judge the Legislator, who is alwayes
 10680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative of the Common-wealth. From this false doctrine, men are
 10681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisposed to debate with themselves, and dispute the commands of the
 10682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; and afterwards to obey, or disobey them, as in their
 10683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate judgements they shall think fit. Whereby the Common-wealth is
 10684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdistracted and Weakened.
 10685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tErroneous Conscience
 10690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother doctrine repugnant to Civill Society, is, that "Whatsoever a
 10692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman does against his Conscience, is Sinne;" and it dependeth on the
 10693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresumption of making himself judge of Good and Evill. For a mans
 10694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConscience, and his Judgement is the same thing; and as the Judgement,
 10695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso also the Conscience may be erroneous. Therefore, though he that is
 10696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject to no Civill Law, sinneth in all he does against his Conscience,
 10697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause he has no other rule to follow but his own reason; yet it is
 10698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot so with him that lives in a Common-wealth; because the Law is the
 10699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublique Conscience, by which he hath already undertaken to be guided.
 10700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOtherwise in such diversity, as there is of private Consciences, which
 10701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare but private opinions, the Common-wealth must needs be distracted,
 10702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand no man dare to obey the Soveraign Power, farther than it shall seem
 10703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood in his own eyes.
 10704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPretence Of Inspiration
 10709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt hath been also commonly taught, "That Faith and Sanctity, are not to
 10711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe attained by Study and Reason, but by supernaturall Inspiration, or
 10712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInfusion," which granted, I see not why any man should render a reason
 10713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his Faith; or why every Christian should not be also a Prophet; or
 10714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhy any man should take the Law of his Country, rather than his own
 10715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInspiration, for the rule of his action. And thus wee fall again into
 10716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe fault of taking upon us to Judge of Good and Evill; or to make
 10717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudges of it, such private men as pretend to be supernaturally Inspired,
 10718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Dissolution of all Civill Government. Faith comes by hearing,
 10719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand hearing by those accidents, which guide us into the presence of them
 10720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat speak to us; which accidents are all contrived by God Almighty; and
 10721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet are not supernaturall, but onely, for the great number of them that
 10722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcurre to every effect, unobservable. Faith, and Sanctity, are indeed
 10723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot very frequent; but yet they are not Miracles, but brought to passe
 10724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby education, discipline, correction, and other naturall wayes, by which
 10725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod worketh them in his elect, as such time as he thinketh fit. And
 10726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese three opinions, pernicious to Peace and Government, have in this
 10727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart of the world, proceeded chiefly from the tongues, and pens of
 10728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunlearned Divines; who joyning the words of Holy Scripture together,
 10729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\totherwise than is agreeable to reason, do what they can, to make men
 10730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthink, that Sanctity and Naturall Reason, cannot stand together.
 10731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjecting The Soveraign Power To Civill Lawes
 10736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA fourth opinion, repugnant to the nature of a Common-wealth, is this,
 10738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"That he that hath the Soveraign Power, is subject to the Civill Lawes."
 10739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is true, that Soveraigns are all subjects to the Lawes of Nature;
 10740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause such lawes be Divine, and cannot by any man, or Common-wealth
 10741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe abrogated. But to those Lawes which the Soveraign himselfe, that is,
 10742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Common-wealth maketh, he is not subject. For to be subject to
 10743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes, is to be subject to the Common-wealth, that is to the Soveraign
 10744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative, that is to himselfe; which is not subjection, but
 10745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfreedome from the Lawes. Which errour, because it setteth the Lawes
 10746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabove the Soveraign, setteth also a Judge above him, and a Power to
 10747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunish him; which is to make a new Soveraign; and again for the same
 10748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treason a third, to punish the second; and so continually without end, to
 10749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Confusion, and Dissolution of the Common-wealth.
 10750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAttributing Of Absolute Propriety To The Subjects
 10755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Fifth doctrine, that tendeth to the Dissolution of a Common-wealth,
 10757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, "That every private man has an absolute Propriety in his Goods;
 10758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch, as excludeth the Right of the Soveraign." Every man has indeed a
 10759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPropriety that excludes the Right of every other Subject: And he has it
 10760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely from the Soveraign Power; without the protection whereof, every
 10761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother man should have equall Right to the same. But if the Right of the
 10762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign also be excluded, he cannot performe the office they have put
 10763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim into; which is, to defend them both from forraign enemies, and
 10764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the injuries of one another; and consequently there is no longer a
 10765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth.
 10766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd if the Propriety of Subjects, exclude not the Right of the
 10768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Representative to their Goods; much lesse to their offices
 10769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Judicature, or Execution, in which they Represent the Soveraign
 10770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe.
 10771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDividing Of The Soveraign Power
 10776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere is a Sixth doctrine, plainly, and directly against the essence
 10778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Common-wealth; and 'tis this, "That the Soveraign Power may be
 10779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivided." For what is it to divide the Power of a Common-wealth, but
 10780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Dissolve it; for Powers divided mutually destroy each other. And for
 10781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese doctrines, men are chiefly beholding to some of those, that making
 10782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprofession of the Lawes, endeavour to make them depend upon their own
 10783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlearning, and not upon the Legislative Power.
 10784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImitation Of Neighbour Nations
 10789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as False Doctrine, so also often-times the Example of different
 10791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment in a neighbouring Nation, disposeth men to alteration of
 10792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe forme already setled. So the people of the Jewes were stirred up to
 10793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treject God, and to call upon the Prophet Samuel, for a King after
 10794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe manner of the Nations; So also the lesser Cities of Greece, were
 10795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontinually disturbed, with seditions of the Aristocraticall, and
 10796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDemocraticall factions; one part of almost every Common-wealth, desiring
 10797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto imitate the Lacedaemonians; the other, the Athenians. And I doubt
 10798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot, but many men, have been contented to see the late troubles in
 10799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEngland, out of an imitation of the Low Countries; supposing there
 10800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneeded no more to grow rich, than to change, as they had done, the forme
 10801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their Government. For the constitution of mans nature, is of it selfe
 10802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject to desire novelty: When therefore they are provoked to the same,
 10803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the neighbourhood also of those that have been enriched by it, it is
 10804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talmost impossible for them, not to be content with those that solicite
 10805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem to change; and love the first beginnings, though they be grieved
 10806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the continuance of disorder; like hot blouds, that having gotten
 10807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe itch, tear themselves with their own nayles, till they can endure
 10808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe smart no longer.
 10809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImitation Of The Greeks, And Romans
 10814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as to Rebellion in particular against Monarchy; one of the most
 10816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrequent causes of it, is the Reading of the books of Policy, and
 10817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHistories of the antient Greeks, and Romans; from which, young men,
 10818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand all others that are unprovided of the Antidote of solid Reason,
 10819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceiving a strong, and delightfull impression, of the great exploits
 10820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof warre, atchieved by the Conductors of their Armies, receive withall
 10821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta pleasing Idea, of all they have done besides; and imagine their great
 10822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprosperity, not to have proceeded from the aemulation of particular men,
 10823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut from the vertue of their popular form of government: Not considering
 10824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe frequent Seditions, and Civill Warres, produced by the imperfection
 10825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their Policy. From the reading, I say, of such books, men have
 10826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tundertaken to kill their Kings, because the Greek and Latine writers,
 10827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin their books, and discourses of Policy, make it lawfull, and laudable,
 10828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor any man so to do; provided before he do it, he call him Tyrant. For
 10829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey say not Regicide, that is, killing of a King, but Tyrannicide, that
 10830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, killing of a Tyrant is lawfull. From the same books, they that live
 10831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder a Monarch conceive an opinion, that the Subjects in a Popular
 10832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth enjoy Liberty; but that in a Monarchy they are all Slaves.
 10833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI say, they that live under a Monarchy conceive such an opinion; not
 10834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey that live under a Popular Government; for they find no such matter.
 10835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn summe, I cannot imagine, how anything can be more prejudiciall to a
 10836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarchy, than the allowing of such books to be publikely read, without
 10837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent applying such correctives of discreet Masters, as are fit to
 10838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake away their Venime; Which Venime I will not doubt to compare to
 10839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe biting of a mad Dogge, which is a disease the Physicians call
 10840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHydrophobia, or Fear Of Water. For as he that is so bitten, has a
 10841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontinuall torment of thirst, and yet abhorreth water; and is in such
 10842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan estate, as if the poyson endeavoured to convert him into a Dogge:
 10843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo when a Monarchy is once bitten to the quick, by those Democraticall
 10844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twriters, that continually snarle at that estate; it wanteth nothing
 10845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore than a strong Monarch, which neverthelesse out of a certain
 10846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTyrannophobia, or feare of being strongly governed, when they have him,
 10847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey abhorre.
 10848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs here have been Doctors, that hold there be three Soules in a man;
 10850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso there be also that think there may be more Soules, (that is, more
 10851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns,) than one, in a Common-wealth; and set up a Supremacy
 10852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the Soveraignty; Canons against Lawes; and a Ghostly Authority
 10853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the Civill; working on mens minds, with words and distinctions,
 10854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat of themselves signifie nothing, but bewray (by their obscurity)
 10855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat there walketh (as some think invisibly) another Kingdome, as it
 10856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere a Kingdome of Fayries, in the dark. Now seeing it is manifest, that
 10857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Civill Power, and the Power of the Common-wealth is the same
 10858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing; and that Supremacy, and the Power of making Canons, and granting
 10859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaculties, implyeth a Common-wealth; it followeth, that where one is
 10860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, another Supreme; where one can make Lawes, and another
 10861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake Canons; there must needs be two Common-wealths, of one & the same
 10862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects; which is a Kingdome divided in it selfe, and cannot stand. For
 10863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnotwithstanding the insignificant distinction of Temporall, and Ghostly,
 10864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are still two Kingdomes, and every Subject is subject to two
 10865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMasters. For seeing the Ghostly Power challengeth the Right to declare
 10866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat is Sinne it challengeth by consequence to declare what is Law,
 10867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Sinne being nothing but the transgression of the Law;) and again, the
 10868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Power challenging to declare what is Law, every Subject must
 10869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobey two Masters, who bothe will have their Commands be observed as Law;
 10870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is impossible. Or, if it be but one Kingdome, either the Civill,
 10871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is the Power of the Common-wealth, must be subordinate to the
 10872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGhostly; or the Ghostly must be subordinate to the Temporall and then
 10873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is no Supremacy but the Temporall. When therefore these two Powers
 10874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toppose one another, the Common-wealth cannot but be in great danger
 10875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Civill warre, and Dissolution. For the Civill Authority being more
 10876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvisible, and standing in the cleerer light of naturall reason cannot
 10877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchoose but draw to it in all times a very considerable part of the
 10878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople: And the Spirituall, though it stand in the darknesse of Schoole
 10879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdistinctions, and hard words; yet because the fear of Darknesse, and
 10880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGhosts, is greater than other fears, cannot want a party sufficient to
 10881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTrouble, and sometimes to Destroy a Common-wealth. And this is a Disease
 10882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich not unfitly may be compared to the Epilepsie, or Falling-sicknesse
 10883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which the Jewes took to be one kind of possession by Spirits) in the
 10884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBody Naturall. For as in this Disease, there is an unnaturall spirit,
 10885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor wind in the head that obstructeth the roots of the Nerves, and moving
 10886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem violently, taketh away the motion which naturally they should have
 10887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the power of the Soule in the Brain, and thereby causeth violent,
 10888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand irregular motions (which men call Convulsions) in the parts;
 10889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinsomuch as he that is seized therewith, falleth down sometimes into the
 10890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twater, and sometimes into the fire, as a man deprived of his senses;
 10891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso also in the Body Politique, when the Spirituall power, moveth the
 10892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMembers of a Common-wealth, by the terrour of punishments, and hope of
 10893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trewards (which are the Nerves of it,) otherwise than by the Civill Power
 10894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which is the Soule of the Common-wealth) they ought to be moved; and by
 10895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstrange, and hard words suffocates the people, and either Overwhelm
 10896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Common-wealth with Oppression, or cast it into the Fire of a Civill
 10897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twarre.
 10898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMixt Government
 10903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSometimes also in the meerly Civill government, there be more than
 10905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone Soule: As when the Power of levying mony, (which is the Nutritive
 10906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaculty,) has depended on a generall Assembly; the Power of conduct and
 10907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommand, (which is the Motive Faculty,) on one man; and the Power of
 10908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmaking Lawes, (which is the Rationall faculty,) on the accidentall
 10909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsent, not onely of those two, but also of a third; This endangereth
 10910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Common-wealth, somtimes for want of consent to good Lawes; but most
 10911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toften for want of such Nourishment, as is necessary to Life, and Motion.
 10912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor although few perceive, that such government, is not government,
 10913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut division of the Common-wealth into three Factions, and call it
 10914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmixt Monarchy; yet the truth is, that it is not one independent
 10915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, but three independent Factions; nor one Representative
 10916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson, but three. In the Kingdome of God, there may be three Persons
 10917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tindependent, without breach of unity in God that Reigneth; but where men
 10918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReigne, that be subject to diversity of opinions, it cannot be so. And
 10919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore if the King bear the person of the People, and the generall
 10920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly bear also the person of the People, and another assembly bear
 10921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe person of a Part of the people, they are not one Person, nor one
 10922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, but three Persons, and three Soveraigns.
 10923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo what Disease in the Naturall Body of man, I may exactly compare this
 10925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tirregularity of a Common-wealth, I know not. But I have seen a man, that
 10926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad another man growing out of his side, with an head, armes, breast,
 10927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand stomach, of his own: If he had had another man growing out of his
 10928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother side, the comparison might then have been exact.
 10929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWant Of Mony
 10934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHitherto I have named such Diseases of a Common-wealth, as are of the
 10936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreatest, and most present danger. There be other, not so great; which
 10937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse are not unfit to be observed. As first, the difficulty of
 10938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\traising Mony, for the necessary uses of the Common-wealth; especially
 10939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the approach of warre. This difficulty ariseth from the opinion, that
 10940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery Subject hath of a Propriety in his lands and goods, exclusive of
 10941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraigns Right to the use of the same. From whence it commeth to
 10942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpasse, that the Soveraign Power, which foreseeth the necessities and
 10943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdangers of the Common-wealth, (finding the passage of mony to the
 10944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublique Treasure obstructed, by the tenacity of the people,) whereas
 10945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit ought to extend it selfe, to encounter, and prevent such dangers in
 10946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir beginnings, contracteth it selfe as long as it can, and when it
 10947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot longer, struggles with the people by strategems of Law, to obtain
 10948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlittle summes, which not sufficing, he is fain at last violently to
 10949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topen the way for present supply, or Perish; and being put often to these
