 10950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textremities, at last reduceth the people to their due temper; or else
 10951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Common-wealth must perish. Insomuch as we may compare this Distemper
 10952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery aptly to an Ague; wherein, the fleshy parts being congealed, or
 10953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby venomous matter obstructed; the Veins which by their naturall course
 10954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tempty themselves into the Heart, are not (as they ought to be) supplyed
 10955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Arteries, whereby there succeedeth at first a cold contraction,
 10956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand trembling of the limbes; and afterwards a hot, and strong endeavour
 10957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Heart, to force a passage for the Bloud; and before it can do
 10958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat, contenteth it selfe with the small refreshments of such things as
 10959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcoole of a time, till (if Nature be strong enough) it break at last
 10960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe contumacy of the parts obstructed, and dissipateth the venome into
 10961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsweat; or (if Nature be too weak) the Patient dyeth.
 10962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonopolies And Abuses Of Publicans
 10967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, there is sometimes in a Common-wealth, a Disease, which
 10969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tresembleth the Pleurisie; and that is, when the Treasure of the
 10970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, flowing out of its due course, is gathered together in
 10971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttoo much abundance, in one, or a few private men, by Monopolies, or by
 10972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFarmes of the Publique Revenues; in the same manner as the Blood in a
 10973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPleurisie, getting into the Membrane of the breast, breedeth there an
 10974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInflammation, accompanied with a Fever, and painfull stitches.
 10975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPopular Men
 10980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso, the Popularity of a potent Subject, (unlesse the Common-wealth
 10982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave very good caution of his fidelity,) is a dangerous Disease; because
 10983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people (which should receive their motion from the Authority of the
 10984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign,) by the flattery, and by the reputation of an ambitious man,
 10985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare drawn away from their obedience to the Lawes, to follow a man, of
 10986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose vertues, and designes they have no knowledge. And this is commonly
 10987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof more danger in a Popular Government, than in a Monarchy; as it may
 10988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teasily be made believe, they are the People. By this means it was, that
 10989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJulius Caesar, who was set up by the People against the Senate, having
 10990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twon to himselfe the affections of his Army, made himselfe Master, both
 10991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Senate and People. And this proceeding of popular, and ambitious men,
 10992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis plain Rebellion; and may be resembled to the effects of Witchcraft.
 10993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcessive Greatnesse Of A Town, Multitude Of Corporations
 10998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 10999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother infirmity of a Common-wealth, is the immoderate greatnesse of a
 11000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTown, when it is able to furnish out of its own Circuit, the number, and
 11001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpence of a great Army: As also the great number of Corporations; which
 11002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare as it were many lesser Common-wealths in the bowels of a greater,
 11003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike wormes in the entrayles of a naturall man.
 11004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty Of Disputing Against Soveraign Power
 11009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo which may be added, the Liberty of Disputing against absolute Power,
 11011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby pretenders to Politicall Prudence; which though bred for the most
 11012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart in the Lees of the people; yet animated by False Doctrines, are
 11013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperpetually medling with the Fundamentall Lawes, to the molestation
 11014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Common-wealth; like the little Wormes, which Physicians call
 11015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAscarides.
 11016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWe may further adde, the insatiable appetite, or Bulimia, of enlarging
 11018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominion; with the incurable Wounds thereby many times received from
 11019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe enemy; And the Wens, of ununited conquests, which are many times a
 11020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tburthen, and with lesse danger lost, than kept; As also the Lethargy of
 11021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEase, and Consumption of Riot and Vain Expence.
 11022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

 11025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDissolution Of The Common-wealth
 11027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, when in a warre (forraign, or intestine,) the enemies got a
 11029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfinal Victory; so as (the forces of the Common-wealth keeping the field
 11030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno longer) there is no farther protection of Subjects in their loyalty;
 11031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen is the Common-wealth DISSOLVED, and every man at liberty to protect
 11032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe by such courses as his own discretion shall suggest unto him.
 11033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the Soveraign, is the publique Soule, giving Life and Motion to the
 11034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; which expiring, the Members are governed by it no more,
 11035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan the Carcasse of a man, by his departed (though Immortal) Soule. For
 11036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough the Right of a Soveraign Monarch cannot be extinguished by the
 11037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tact of another; yet the Obligation of the members may. For he that
 11038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twants protection, may seek it anywhere; and when he hath it, is obliged
 11039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(without fraudulent pretence of having submitted himselfe out of fear,)
 11040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto protect his Protection as long as he is able. But when the Power of
 11041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Assembly is once suppressed, the Right of the same perisheth utterly;
 11042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause the Assembly it selfe is extinct; and consequently, there is no
 11043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossibility for the Soveraignty to re-enter.
 11044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXX. OF THE OFFICE OF THE SOVERAIGN REPRESENTATIVE
 11048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Procuration Of The Good Of The People
 11053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe OFFICE of the Soveraign, (be it a Monarch, or an Assembly,)
 11055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsisteth in the end, for which he was trusted with the Soveraign
 11056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower, namely the procuration of the Safety Of The People; to which he
 11057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis obliged by the Law of Nature, and to render an account thereof to
 11058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, the Author of that Law, and to none but him. But by Safety here, is
 11059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot meant a bare Preservation, but also all other Contentments of life,
 11060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich every man by lawfull Industry, without danger, or hurt to the
 11061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, shall acquire to himselfe.
 11062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Instruction & Lawes
 11067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd this is intended should be done, not by care applyed to
 11069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIndividualls, further than their protection from injuries, when they
 11070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall complain; but by a generall Providence, contained in publique
 11071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstruction, both of Doctrine, and Example; and in the making, and
 11072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texecuting of good Lawes, to which individuall persons may apply their
 11073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town cases.
 11074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgainst The Duty Of A Soveraign To Relinquish Any Essentiall Right
 11079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Soveraignty Or Not To See The People Taught The Grounds Of Them
 11081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because, if the essentiall Rights of Soveraignty (specified before
 11083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the eighteenth Chapter) be taken away, the Common-wealth is thereby
 11084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdissolved, and every man returneth into the condition, and calamity of a
 11085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twarre with every other man, (which is the greatest evill that can happen
 11086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this life;) it is the Office of the Soveraign, to maintain those
 11087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRights entire; and consequently against his duty, First, to transferre
 11088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto another, or to lay from himselfe any of them. For he that deserteth
 11089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Means, deserteth the Ends; and he deserteth the Means, that being
 11090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign, acknowledgeth himselfe subject to the Civill Lawes; and
 11091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trenounceth the Power of Supreme Judicature; or of making Warre, or
 11092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace by his own Authority; or of Judging of the Necessities of the
 11093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; or of levying Mony, and Souldiers, when, and as much as
 11094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his own conscience he shall judge necessary; or of making Officers,
 11095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Ministers both of Warre, and Peace; or of appointing Teachers, and
 11096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texamining what Doctrines are conformable, or contrary to the Defence,
 11097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeace, and Good of the people. Secondly, it is against his duty, to let
 11098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people be ignorant, or mis-in-formed of the grounds, and reasons
 11099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof those his essentiall Rights; because thereby men are easie to be
 11100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseduced, and drawn to resist him, when the Common-wealth shall require
 11101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir use and exercise.
 11102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd the grounds of these Rights, have the rather need to be diligently,
 11104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand truly taught; because they cannot be maintained by any Civill Law,
 11105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor terrour of legal punishment. For a Civill Law, that shall forbid
 11106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRebellion, (and such is all resistance to the essentiall Rights of
 11107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty,) is not (as a Civill Law) any obligation, but by vertue
 11108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely of the Law of Nature, that forbiddeth the violation of Faith;
 11109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich naturall obligation if men know not, they cannot know the Right of
 11110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany Law the Soveraign maketh. And for the Punishment, they take it
 11111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut for an act of Hostility; which when they think they have strength
 11112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenough, they will endeavour by acts of Hostility, to avoyd.
 11113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tObjection Of Those That Say There Are No Principles Of Reason For
 11118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbsolute Soveraignty
 11120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs I have heard some say, that Justice is but a word, without substance;
 11122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand that whatsoever a man can by force, or art, acquire to himselfe,
 11123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(not onely in the condition of warre, but also in a Common-wealth,) is
 11124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own, which I have already shewed to be false: So there be also
 11125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat maintain, that there are no grounds, nor Principles of Reason, to
 11126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsustain those essentiall Rights, which make Soveraignty absolute. For
 11127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif there were, they would have been found out in some place, or other;
 11128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereas we see, there has not hitherto been any Common-wealth, where
 11129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Rights have been acknowledged, or challenged. Wherein they argue
 11130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas ill, as if the Savage people of America, should deny there were any
 11131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrounds, or Principles of Reason, so to build a house, as to last as
 11132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlong as the materials, because they never yet saw any so well built.
 11133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTime, and Industry, produce every day new knowledge. And as the art
 11134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof well building, is derived from Principles of Reason, observed by
 11135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tindustrious men, that had long studied the nature of materials, and
 11136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe divers effects of figure, and proportion, long after mankind
 11137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbegan (though poorly) to build: So, long time after men have begun to
 11138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstitute Common-wealths, imperfect, and apt to relapse into disorder,
 11139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere may, Principles of Reason be found out, by industrious meditation,
 11140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto make use of them, or be neglected by them, or not, concerneth my
 11141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular interest, at this day, very little. But supposing that
 11142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese of mine are not such Principles of Reason; yet I am sure they are
 11143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrinciples from Authority of Scripture; as I shall make it appear, when
 11144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI shall come to speak of the Kingdome of God, (administred by Moses,)
 11145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover the Jewes, his peculiar people by Covenant.
 11146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tObjection From The Incapacity Of The Vulgar
 11151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut they say again, that though the Principles be right, yet Common
 11153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople are not of capacity enough to be made to understand them. I
 11154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould be glad, that the Rich, and Potent Subjects of a Kingdome, or
 11155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that are accounted the most Learned, were no lesse incapable than
 11156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey. But all men know, that the obstructions to this kind of doctrine,
 11157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceed not so much from the difficulty of the matter, as from the
 11158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterest of them that are to learn. Potent men, digest hardly any thing
 11159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat setteth up a Power to bridle their affections; and Learned men,
 11160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany thing that discovereth their errours, and thereby lesseneth their
 11161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority: whereas the Common-peoples minds, unlesse they be tainted
 11162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith dependance on the Potent, or scribbled over with the opinions
 11163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their Doctors, are like clean paper, fit to receive whatsoever by
 11164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Authority shall be imprinted in them. Shall whole Nations be
 11165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbrought to Acquiesce in the great Mysteries of Christian Religion, which
 11166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare above Reason; and millions of men be made believe, that the same
 11167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBody may be in innumerable places, at one and the same time, which
 11168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis against Reason; and shall not men be able, by their teaching, and
 11169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreaching, protected by the Law, to make that received, which is so
 11170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsonant to Reason, that any unprejudicated man, needs no more to learn
 11171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, than to hear it? I conclude therefore, that in the instruction
 11172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the people in the Essentiall Rights (which are the Naturall, and
 11173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFundamentall Lawes) of Soveraignty, there is no difficulty, (whilest a
 11174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign has his Power entire,) but what proceeds from his own fault,
 11175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor the fault of those whom he trusteth in the administration of the
 11176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; and consequently, it is his Duty, to cause them so to be
 11177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinstructed; and not onely his Duty, but his Benefit also, and Security,
 11178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the danger that may arrive to himselfe in his naturall Person,
 11179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom Rebellion.
 11180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects Are To Be Taught, Not To Affect Change Of Government
 11185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd (to descend to particulars) the People are to be taught, First, that
 11187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey ought not to be in love with any forme of Government they see
 11188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin their neighbour Nations, more than with their own, nor (whatsoever
 11189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent prosperity they behold in Nations that are otherwise governed
 11190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan they,) to desire change. For the prosperity of a People ruled by
 11191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Aristocraticall, or Democraticall assembly, commeth not from
 11192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAristocracy, nor from Democracy, but from the Obedience, and Concord of
 11193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Subjects; nor do the people flourish in a Monarchy, because one man
 11194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thas the right to rule them, but because they obey him. Take away in
 11195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany kind of State, the Obedience, (and consequently the Concord of the
 11196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeople,) and they shall not onely not flourish, but in short time be
 11197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdissolved. And they that go about by disobedience, to doe no more than
 11198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treforme the Common-wealth, shall find they do thereby destroy it; like
 11199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe foolish daughters of Peleus (in the fable;) which desiring to renew
 11200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe youth of their decrepit Father, did by the Counsell of Medea, cut
 11201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim in pieces, and boyle him, together with strange herbs, but made not
 11202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof him a new man. This desire of change, is like the breach of the first
 11203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Gods Commandements: For there God says, Non Habebis Deos Alienos;
 11204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThou shalt not have the Gods of other Nations; and in another place
 11205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning Kings, that they are Gods.
 11206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor Adhere (Against The Soveraign) To Popular Men
 11211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, they are to be taught, that they ought not to be led with
 11213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadmiration of the vertue of any of their fellow Subjects, how
 11214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thigh soever he stand, nor how conspicuously soever he shine in the
 11215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; nor of any Assembly, (except the Soveraign Assembly,)
 11216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso as to deferre to them any obedience, or honour, appropriate to the
 11217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign onely, whom (in their particular stations) they represent; nor
 11218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto receive any influence from them, but such as is conveighed by them
 11219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Soveraign Authority. For that Soveraign, cannot be imagined to
 11220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlove his People as he ought, that is not Jealous of them, but suffers
 11221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem by the flattery of Popular men, to be seduced from their loyalty,
 11222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they have often been, not onely secretly, but openly, so as to
 11223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproclaime Marriage with them In Facie Ecclesiae by Preachers; and by
 11224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublishing the same in the open streets: which may fitly be compared to
 11225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe violation of the second of the ten Commandements.
 11226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor To Dispute The Soveraign Power
 11230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, in consequence to this, they ought to be informed, how great
 11232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfault it is, to speak evill of the Soveraign Representative, (whether
 11233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOne man, or an Assembly of men;) or to argue and dispute his Power, or
 11234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany way to use his Name irreverently, whereby he may be brought into
 11235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContempt with his People, and their Obedience (in which the safety
 11236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Common-wealth consisteth) slackened. Which doctrine the third
 11237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandement by resemblance pointeth to.
 11238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd To Have Dayes Set Apart To Learn Their Duty
 11243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, seeing people cannot be taught this, nor when 'tis taught,
 11245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tremember it, nor after one generation past, so much as know in whom the
 11246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power is placed, without setting a part from their ordinary
 11247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlabour, some certain times, in which they may attend those that are
 11248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappointed to instruct them; It is necessary that some such times be
 11249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdetermined, wherein they may assemble together, and (after prayers and
 11250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpraises given to God, the Soveraign of Soveraigns) hear those their
 11251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDuties told them, and the Positive Lawes, such as generally concern them
 11252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall, read and expounded, and be put in mind of the Authority that maketh
 11253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem Lawes. To this end had the Jewes every seventh day, a Sabbath, in
 11254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Law was read and expounded; and in the solemnity whereof they
 11255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere put in mind, that their King was God; that having created the world
 11256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin six days, he rested the seventh day; and by their resting on it from
 11257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir labour, that that God was their King, which redeemed them from
 11258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir servile, and painfull labour in Egypt, and gave them a time, after
 11259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey had rejoyced in God, to take joy also in themselves, by lawfull
 11260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trecreation. So that the first Table of the Commandements, is spent all,
 11261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin setting down the summe of Gods absolute Power; not onely as God,
 11262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut as King by pact, (in peculiar) of the Jewes; and may therefore give
 11263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlight, to those that have the Soveraign Power conferred on them by the
 11264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsent of men, to see what doctrine they Ought to teach their Subjects.
 11265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd To Honour Their Parents
 11270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because the first instruction of Children, dependeth on the care
 11272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their Parents; it is necessary that they should be obedient to them,
 11273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhilest they are under their tuition; and not onely so, but that also
 11274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafterwards (as gratitude requireth,) they acknowledge the benefit of
 11275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir education, by externall signes of honour. To which end they are
 11276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be taught, that originally the Father of every man was also his
 11277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Lord, with power over him of life and death; and that the
 11278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFathers of families, when by instituting a Common-wealth, they resigned
 11279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat absolute Power, yet it was never intended, they should lose the
 11280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thonour due unto them for their education. For to relinquish such right,
 11281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas not necessary to the Institution of Soveraign Power; nor would there
 11282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe any reason, why any man should desire to have children, or take the
 11283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcare to nourish, and instruct them, if they were afterwards to have no
 11284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother benefit from them, than from other men. And this accordeth with
 11285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe fifth Commandement.
 11286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd To Avoyd Doing Of Injury:
 11291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, every Soveraign Ought to cause Justice to be taught, which
 11293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(consisting in taking from no man what is his) is as much as to say, to
 11294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcause men to be taught not to deprive their Neighbour, by violence,
 11295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor fraud, of any thing which by the Soveraign Authority is theirs. Of
 11296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings held in propriety, those that are dearest to a man are his own
 11297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife, & limbs; and in the next degree, (in most men,) those that
 11298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcern conjugall affection; and after them riches and means of living.
 11299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore the People are to be taught, to abstain from violence to
 11300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone anothers person, by private revenges; from violation of conjugall
 11301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thonour; and from forcibly rapine, and fraudulent surreption of one
 11302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanothers goods. For which purpose also it is necessary they be shewed
 11303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe evill consequences of false Judgement, by corruption either of
 11304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudges or Witnesses, whereby the distinction of propriety is taken away,
 11305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Justice becomes of no effect: all which things are intimated in the
 11306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsixth, seventh, eighth, and ninth Commandements.
 11307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd To Do All This Sincerely From The Heart
 11312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, they are to be taught, that not onely the unjust facts, but the
 11314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesignes and intentions to do them, (though by accident hindred,) are
 11315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInjustice; which consisteth in the pravity of the will, as well as in
 11316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe irregularity of the act. And this is the intention of the tenth
 11317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandement, and the summe of the Second Table; which is reduced all to
 11318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis one Commandement of mutuall Charity, "Thou shalt love thy neighbour
 11319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas thy selfe:" as the summe of the first Table is reduced to "the love
 11320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God;" whom they had then newly received as their King.
 11321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Use Of Universities
 11326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for the Means, and Conduits, by which the people may receive this
 11328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInstruction, wee are to search, by what means so may Opinions,
 11329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary to the peace of Man-kind, upon weak and false Principles, have
 11330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse been so deeply rooted in them. I mean those, which I have
 11331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the precedent Chapter specified: as That men shall Judge of what is
 11332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfull and unlawfull, not by the Law it selfe, but by their own
 11333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate Judgements; That Subjects sinne in obeying the Commands of the
 11334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, unlesse they themselves have first judged them to be
 11335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfull: That their Propriety in their riches is such, as to exclude the
 11336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominion, which the Common-wealth hath over the same: That it is lawfull
 11337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Subjects to kill such, as they call Tyrants: That the Soveraign
 11338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower may be divided, and the like; which come to be instilled into
 11339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe People by this means. They whom necessity, or covetousnesse keepeth
 11340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tattent on their trades, and labour; and they, on the other side, whom
 11341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuperfluity, or sloth carrieth after their sensuall pleasures, (which
 11342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttwo sorts of men take up the greatest part of Man-kind,) being diverted
 11343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the deep meditation, which the learning of truth, not onely in the
 11344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmatter of Naturall Justice, but also of all other Sciences necessarily
 11345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequireth, receive the Notions of their duty, chiefly from Divines
 11346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Pulpit, and partly from such of their Neighbours, or familiar
 11347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacquaintance, as having the Faculty of discoursing readily, and
 11348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplausibly, seem wiser and better learned in cases of Law, and
 11349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConscience, than themselves. And the Divines, and such others as make
 11350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshew of Learning, derive their knowledge from the Universities, and from
 11351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Schooles of Law, or from the Books, which by men eminent in
 11352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Schooles, and Universities have been published. It is therefore
 11353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest, that the Instruction of the people, dependeth wholly, on the
 11354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tright teaching of Youth in the Universities. But are not (may some men
 11355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay) the Universities of England learned enough already to do that? or
 11356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis it you will undertake to teach the Universities? Hard questions. Yet
 11357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the first, I doubt not to answer; that till towards the later end of
 11358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHenry the Eighth, the Power of the Pope, was alwayes upheld against the
 11359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower of the Common-wealth, principally by the Universities; and that
 11360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe doctrines maintained by so many Preachers, against the Soveraign
 11361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower of the King, and by so many Lawyers, and others, that had their
 11362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teducation there, is a sufficient argument, that though the Universities
 11363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere not authors of those false doctrines, yet they knew not how to
 11364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplant the true. For in such a contradiction of Opinions, it is most
 11365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcertain, that they have not been sufficiently instructed; and 'tis no
 11366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twonder, if they yet retain a relish of that subtile liquor, wherewith
 11367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were first seasoned, against the Civill Authority. But to the later
 11368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestion, it is not fit, nor needfull for me to say either I, or No: for
 11369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany man that sees what I am doing, may easily perceive what I think.
 11370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe safety of the People, requireth further, from him, or them that have
 11372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign Power, that Justice be equally administred to all degrees
 11373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof People; that is, that as well the rich, and mighty, as poor and
 11374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobscure persons, may be righted of the injuries done them; so as the
 11375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat, may have no greater hope of impunity, when they doe violence,
 11376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdishonour, or any Injury to the meaner sort, than when one of these,
 11377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoes the like to one of them: For in this consisteth Equity; to which,
 11378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas being a Precept of the Law of Nature, a Soveraign is as much subject,
 11379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas any of the meanest of his People. All breaches of the Law, are
 11380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toffences against the Common-wealth: but there be some, that are also
 11381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst private Persons. Those that concern the Common-wealth onely, may
 11382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout breach of Equity be pardoned; for every man may pardon what is
 11383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdone against himselfe, according to his own discretion. But an offence
 11384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst a private man, cannot in Equity be pardoned, without the consent
 11385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof him that is injured; or reasonable satisfaction.
 11386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Inequality of Subjects, proceedeth from the Acts of Soveraign Power;
 11388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore has no more place in the presence of the Soveraign; that
 11389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, in a Court of Justice, then the Inequality between Kings,
 11390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand their Subjects, in the presence of the King of Kings. The honour of
 11391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat Persons, is to be valued for their beneficence, and the aydes
 11392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey give to men of inferiour rank, or not at all. And the violences,
 11393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toppressions, and injuries they do, are not extenuated, but aggravated by
 11394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe greatnesse of their persons; because they have least need to commit
 11395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem. The consequences of this partiality towards the great, proceed in
 11396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis manner. Impunity maketh Insolence; Insolence Hatred; and Hatred,
 11397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Endeavour to pull down all oppressing and contumelious greatnesse,
 11398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough with the ruine of the Common-wealth.
 11399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEquall Taxes
 11404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Equall Justice, appertaineth also the Equall imposition of Taxes;
 11406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe equality whereof dependeth not on the Equality of riches, but on the
 11407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEquality of the debt, that every man oweth to the Common-wealth for his
 11408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdefence. It is not enough, for a man to labour for the maintenance
 11409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his life; but also to fight, (if need be,) for the securing of his
 11410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlabour. They must either do as the Jewes did after their return from
 11411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcaptivity, in re-edifying the Temple, build with one hand, and hold the
 11412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSword in the other; or else they must hire others to fight for them. For
 11413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Impositions that are layd on the People by the Soveraign Power, are
 11414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnothing else but the Wages, due to them that hold the publique Sword,
 11415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto defend private men in the exercise of severall Trades, and Callings.
 11416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing then the benefit that every one receiveth thereby, is the
 11417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenjoyment of life, which is equally dear to poor, and rich; the debt
 11418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich a poor man oweth them that defend his life, is the same which a
 11419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trich man oweth for the defence of his; saving that the rich, who have
 11420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe service of the poor, may be debtors not onely for their own persons,
 11421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut for many more. Which considered, the Equality of Imposition,
 11422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsisteth rather in the Equality of that which is consumed, than of the
 11423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\triches of the persons that consume the same. For what reason is there,
 11424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat he which laboureth much, and sparing the fruits of his labour,
 11425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsumeth little, should be more charged, then he that living idlely,
 11426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgetteth little, and spendeth all he gets; seeing the one hath no
 11427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore protection from the Common-wealth, then the other? But when the
 11428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImpositions, are layd upon those things which men consume, every man
 11429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpayeth Equally for what he useth: Nor is the Common-wealth defrauded, by
 11430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe luxurious waste of private men.
 11431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Charity
 11436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whereas many men, by accident unevitable, become unable to maintain
 11438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves by their labour; they ought not to be left to the Charity
 11439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof private persons; but to be provided for, (as far-forth as the
 11440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessities of Nature require,) by the Lawes of the Common-wealth. For
 11441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas it is Uncharitablenesse in any man, to neglect the impotent; so it
 11442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis in the Soveraign of a Common-wealth, to expose them to the hazard of
 11443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch uncertain Charity.
 11444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrevention Of Idlenesse
 11449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut for such as have strong bodies, the case is otherwise: they are to
 11451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe forced to work; and to avoyd the excuse of not finding employment,
 11452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere ought to be such Lawes, as may encourage all manner of Arts; as
 11453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNavigation, Agriculture, Fishing, and all manner of Manifacture that
 11454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequires labour. The multitude of poor, and yet strong people still
 11455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tencreasing, they are to be transplanted into Countries not sufficiently
 11456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinhabited: where neverthelesse, they are not to exterminate those they
 11457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfind there; but constrain them to inhabit closer together, and not range
 11458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta great deal of ground, to snatch what they find; but to court each
 11459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlittle Plot with art and labour, to give them their sustenance in due
 11460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseason. And when all the world is overchargd with Inhabitants, then the
 11461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlast remedy of all is Warre; which provideth for every man, by Victory,
 11462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Death.
 11463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood Lawes What
 11468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo the care of the Soveraign, belongeth the making of Good Lawes. But
 11470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat is a good Law? By a Good Law, I mean not a Just Law: for no Law can
 11471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Unjust. The Law is made by the Soveraign Power, and all that is done
 11472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby such Power, is warranted, and owned by every one of the people; and
 11473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which every man will have so, no man can say is unjust. It is in
 11474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Lawes of a Common-wealth, as in the Lawes of Gaming: whatsoever
 11475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Gamesters all agree on, is Injustice to none of them. A good Law
 11476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis that, which is Needfull, for the Good Of The People, and withall
 11477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerspicuous.
 11478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuch As Are Necessary
 11483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the use of Lawes, (which are but Rules Authorised) is not to bind
 11485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe People from all Voluntary actions; but to direct and keep them in
 11486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch a motion, as not to hurt themselves by their own impetuous desires,
 11487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trashnesse, or indiscretion, as Hedges are set, not to stop Travellers,
 11488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut to keep them in the way. And therefore a Law that is not Needfull,
 11489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thaving not the true End of a Law, is not Good. A Law may be conceived to
 11490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Good, when it is for the benefit of the Soveraign; though it be
 11491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot Necessary for the People; but it is not so. For the good of the
 11492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign and People, cannot be separated. It is a weak Soveraign, that
 11493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thas weak Subjects; and a weak People, whose Soveraign wanteth Power to
 11494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trule them at his will. Unnecessary Lawes are not good Lawes; but trapps
 11495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Mony: which where the right of Soveraign Power is acknowledged, are
 11496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuperfluous; and where it is not acknowledged, unsufficient to defend
 11497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe People.
 11498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuch As Are Perspicuous
 11503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Perspicuity, consisteth not so much in the words of the Law it
 11505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tselfe, as in a Declaration of the Causes, and Motives, for which it was
 11506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade. That is it, that shewes us the meaning of the Legislator, and the
 11507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeaning of the Legislator known, the Law is more easily understood
 11508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby few, than many words. For all words, are subject to ambiguity;
 11509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore multiplication of words in the body of the Law, is
 11510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmultiplication of ambiguity: Besides it seems to imply, (by too much
 11511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiligence,) that whosoever can evade the words, is without the compasse
 11512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Law. And this is a cause of many unnecessary Processes. For when
 11513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI consider how short were the Lawes of antient times; and how they
 11514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrew by degrees still longer; me thinks I see a contention between the
 11515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPenners, and Pleaders of the Law; the former seeking to circumscribe
 11516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe later; and the later to evade their circumscriptions; and that the
 11517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPleaders have got the Victory. It belongeth therefore to the Office of
 11518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Legislator, (such as is in all Common-wealths the Supreme
 11519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentative, be it one Man, or an Assembly,) to make the reason
 11520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerspicuous, why the Law was made; and the Body of the Law it selfe, as
 11521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshort, but in as proper, and significant termes, as may be.
 11522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishments
 11527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt belongeth also to the Office of the Soveraign, to make a right
 11529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapplication of Punishments, and Rewards. And seeing the end of punishing
 11530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not revenge, and discharge of choler; but correction, either of the
 11531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toffender, or of others by his example; the severest Punishments are to
 11532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe inflicted for those Crimes, that are of most Danger to the
 11533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique; such as are those which proceed from malice to the Government
 11534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\testablished; those that spring from contempt of Justice; those that
 11535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprovoke Indignation in the Multitude; and those, which unpunished, seem
 11536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthorised, as when they are committed by Sonnes, Servants, or Favorites
 11537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men in Authority: For Indignation carrieth men, not onely against the
 11538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActors, and Authors of Injustice; but against all Power that is likely
 11539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto protect them; as in the case of Tarquin; when for the Insolent act of
 11540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone of his Sonnes, he was driven out of Rome, and the Monarchy it selfe
 11541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdissolved. But Crimes of Infirmity; such as are those which proceed
 11542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom great provocation, from great fear, great need, or from ignorance
 11543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhether the Fact be a great Crime, or not, there is place many times for
 11544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLenity, without prejudice to the Common-wealth; and Lenity when there is
 11545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch place for it, is required by the Law of Nature. The Punishment of
 11546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Leaders, and teachers in a Commotion; not the poore seduced People,
 11547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen they are punished, can profit the Common-wealth by their example.
 11548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo be severe to the People, is to punish that ignorance, which may in
 11549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat part be imputed to the Soveraign, whose fault it was, they were no
 11550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetter instructed.
 11551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRewards
 11556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn like manner it belongeth to the Office, and Duty of the Soveraign,
 11558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto apply his Rewards alwayes so, as there may arise from them benefit
 11559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Common-wealth: wherein consisteth their Use, and End; and is then
 11560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdone, when they that have well served the Common-wealth, are with
 11561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas little expence of the Common Treasure, as is possible, so well
 11562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trecompenced, as others thereby may be encouraged, both to serve the same
 11563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas faithfully as they can, and to study the arts by which they may be
 11564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenabled to do it better. To buy with Mony, or Preferment, from a Popular
 11565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tambitious Subject, to be quiet, and desist from making ill impressions
 11566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the mindes of the People, has nothing of the nature of Reward; (which
 11567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis ordained not for disservice, but for service past;) nor a signe of
 11568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGratitude, but of Fear: nor does it tend to the Benefit, but to the
 11569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDammage of the Publique. It is a contention with Ambition, like that of
 11570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHercules with the Monster Hydra, which having many heads, for every one
 11571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat was vanquished, there grew up three. For in like manner, when the
 11572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstubbornnesse of one Popular man, is overcome with Reward, there arise
 11573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany more (by the Example) that do the same Mischiefe, in hope of like
 11574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBenefit: and as all sorts of Manifacture, so also Malice encreaseth by
 11575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing vendible. And though sometimes a Civill warre, may be differred,
 11576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby such wayes as that, yet the danger growes still the greater, and the
 11577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique ruine more assured. It is therefore against the Duty of the
 11578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, to whom the Publique Safety is committed, to Reward those
 11579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat aspire to greatnesse by disturbing the Peace of their Country, and
 11580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot rather to oppose the beginnings of such men, with a little danger,
 11581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan after a longer time with greater.
 11582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsellours
 11587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother Businesse of the Soveraign, is to choose good Counsellours;
 11589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI mean such, whose advice he is to take in the Government of the
 11590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth. For this word Counsell, Consilium, corrupted from
 11591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsidium, is a large signification, and comprehendeth all Assemblies
 11592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men that sit together, not onely to deliberate what is to be done
 11593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thereafter, but also to judge of Facts past, and of Law for the present.
 11594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI take it here in the first sense onely: And in this sense, there is no
 11595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchoyce of Counsell, neither in a Democracy, nor Aristocracy; because the
 11596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpersons Counselling are members of the person Counselled. The choyce
 11597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Counsellours therefore is to Monarchy; In which, the Soveraign that
 11598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tendeavoureth not to make choyce of those, that in every kind are the
 11599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost able, dischargeth not his Office as he ought to do. The most able
 11600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsellours, are they that have least hope of benefit by giving evill
 11601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell, and most knowledge of those things that conduce to the Peace,
 11602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Defence of the Common-wealth. It is a hard matter to know who
 11603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpecteth benefit from publique troubles; but the signes that guide to a
 11604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjust suspicion, is the soothing of the people in their unreasonable,
 11605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor irremediable grievances, by men whose estates are not sufficient to
 11606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdischarge their accustomed expences, and may easily be observed by any
 11607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone whom it concerns to know it. But to know, who has most knowledge of
 11608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Publique affaires, is yet harder; and they that know them, need them
 11609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta great deale the lesse. For to know, who knowes the Rules almost of any
 11610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArt, is a great degree of the knowledge of the same Art; because no
 11611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman can be assured of the truth of anothers Rules, but he that is first
 11612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaught to understand them. But the best signes of Knowledge of any
 11613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArt, are, much conversing in it, and constant good effects of it. Good
 11614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell comes not by Lot, nor by Inheritance; and therefore there is no
 11615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore reason to expect good Advice from the rich, or noble, in matter
 11616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof State, than in delineating the dimensions of a fortresse; unlesse we
 11617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall think there needs no method in the study of the Politiques, (as
 11618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere does in the study of Geometry,) but onely to be lookers on; which
 11619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not so. For the Politiques is the harder study of the two. Whereas
 11620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin these parts of Europe, it hath been taken for a Right of certain
 11621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpersons, to have place in the highest Councell of State by Inheritance;
 11622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is derived from the Conquests of the antient Germans; wherein many
 11623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsolute Lords joyning together to conquer other Nations, would not
 11624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenter in to the Confederacy, without such Priviledges, as might be
 11625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmarks of difference in time following, between their Posterity, and the
 11626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tposterity of their Subjects; which Priviledges being inconsistent with
 11627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign Power, by the favour of the Soveraign, they may seem to
 11628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkeep; but contending for them as their Right, they must needs by
 11629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdegrees let them go, and have at last no further honour, than adhaereth
 11630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturally to their abilities.
 11631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd how able soever be the Counsellours in any affaire, the benefit
 11633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their Counsell is greater, when they give every one his Advice, and
 11634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasons of it apart, than when they do it in an Assembly, by way of
 11635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOrations; and when they have praemeditated, than when they speak on the
 11636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsudden; both because they have more time, to survey the consequences
 11637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof action; and are lesse subject to be carried away to contradiction,
 11638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthrough Envy, Emulation, or other Passions arising from the difference
 11639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof opinion.
 11640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe best Counsell, in those things that concern not other Nations, but
 11642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely the ease, and benefit the Subjects may enjoy, by Lawes that
 11643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlook onely inward, is to be taken from the generall informations, and
 11644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomplaints of the people of each Province, who are best acquainted
 11645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith their own wants, and ought therefore, when they demand nothing in
 11646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tderogation of the essentiall Rights of Soveraignty, to be diligently
 11647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaken notice of. For without those Essentiall Rights, (as I have often
 11648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore said,) the Common-wealth cannot at all subsist.
 11649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommanders
 11654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Commander of an Army in chiefe, if he be not Popular, shall not be
 11656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeloved, nor feared as he ought to be by his Army; and consequently
 11657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot performe that office with good successe. He must therefore be
 11658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIndustrious, Valiant, Affable, Liberall and Fortunate, that he may gain
 11659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan opinion both of sufficiency, and of loving his Souldiers. This is
 11660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPopularity, and breeds in the Souldiers both desire, and courage, to
 11661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trecommend themselves to his favour; and protects the severity of
 11662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Generall, in punishing (when need is) the Mutinous, or negligent
 11663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSouldiers. But this love of Souldiers, (if caution be not given of
 11664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Commanders fidelity,) is a dangerous thing to Soveraign Power;
 11665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tespecially when it is in the hands of an Assembly not popular. It
 11666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbelongeth therefore to the safety of the People, both that they be good
 11667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConductors, and faithfull subjects, to whom the Soveraign Commits his
 11668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArmies.
 11669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut when the Soveraign himselfe is Popular, that is, reverenced and
 11671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeloved of his People, there is no danger at all from the Popularity of
 11672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Subject. For Souldiers are never so generally unjust, as to side with
 11673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Captain; though they love him, against their Soveraign, when they
 11674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlove not onely his Person, but also his Cause. And therefore those,
 11675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho by violence have at any time suppressed the Power of their Lawfull
 11676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, before they could settle themselves in his place, have been
 11677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talwayes put to the trouble of contriving their Titles, to save the
 11678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeople from the shame of receiving them. To have a known Right to
 11679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power, is so popular a quality, as he that has it needs no
 11680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore, for his own part, to turn the hearts of his Subjects to him, but
 11681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat they see him able absolutely to govern his own Family: Nor, on the
 11682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart of his enemies, but a disbanding of their Armies. For the greatest
 11683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand most active part of Mankind, has never hetherto been well contented
 11684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the present.
 11685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConcerning the Offices of one Soveraign to another, which are
 11687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomprehended in that Law, which is commonly called the Law of Nations,
 11688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI need not say any thing in this place; because the Law of Nations, and
 11689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law of Nature, is the same thing. And every Soveraign hath the same
 11690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight, in procuring the safety of his People, that any particular man
 11691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan have, in procuring the safety of his own Body. And the same Law,
 11692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat dictateth to men that have no Civil Government, what they ought to
 11693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo, and what to avoyd in regard of one another, dictateth the same to
 11694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths, that is, to the Consciences of Soveraign Princes, and
 11695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Assemblies; there being no Court of Naturall Justice, but
 11696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Conscience onely; where not Man, but God raigneth; whose Lawes,
 11697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(such of them as oblige all Mankind,) in respect of God, as he is the
 11698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthor of Nature, are Naturall; and in respect of the same God, as he is
 11699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing of Kings, are Lawes. But of the Kingdome of God, as King of Kings,
 11700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand as King also of a peculiar People, I shall speak in the rest of this
 11701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscourse.
 11702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXXI. OF THE KINGDOME OF GOD BY NATURE
 11706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Scope Of The Following Chapters
 11711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat the condition of meer Nature, that is to say, of absolute Liberty,
 11713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as is theirs, that neither are Soveraigns, nor Subjects, is
 11714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnarchy, and the condition of Warre: That the Praecepts, by which men
 11715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare guided to avoyd that condition, are the Lawes of Nature: That
 11716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Common-wealth, without Soveraign Power, is but a word, without
 11717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubstance, and cannot stand: That Subjects owe to Soveraigns, simple
 11718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tObedience, in all things, wherein their obedience is not repugnant
 11719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Lawes of God, I have sufficiently proved, in that which I have
 11720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready written. There wants onely, for the entire knowledge of Civill
 11721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tduty, to know what are those Lawes of God. For without that, a man knows
 11722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot, when he is commanded any thing by the Civill Power, whether it be
 11723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary to the Law of God, or not: and so, either by too much civill
 11724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobedience, offends the Divine Majesty, or through feare of offending
 11725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, transgresses the commandements of the Common-wealth. To avoyd both
 11726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese Rocks, it is necessary to know what are the Lawes Divine. And
 11727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseeing the knowledge of all Law, dependeth on the knowledge of the
 11728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power; I shall say something in that which followeth, of the
 11729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKINGDOME OF GOD.
 11730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWho Are Subjects In The Kingdome Of God
 11735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"God is King, let the Earth rejoice," saith the Psalmist. (Psal. 96. 1).
 11737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd again, "God is King though the Nations be angry; and he that sitteth
 11738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton the Cherubins, though the earth be moved." (Psal. 98. 1). Whether
 11739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen will or not, they must be subject alwayes to the Divine Power. By
 11740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdenying the Existence, or Providence of God, men may shake off their
 11741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEase, but not their Yoke. But to call this Power of God, which extendeth
 11742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit selfe not onely to Man, but also to Beasts, and Plants, and Bodies
 11743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinanimate, by the name of Kingdome, is but a metaphoricall use of
 11744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe word. For he onely is properly said to Raigne, that governs his
 11745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects, by his Word, and by promise of Rewards to those that obey
 11746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, and by threatning them with Punishment that obey it not. Subjects
 11747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore in the Kingdome of God, are not Bodies Inanimate, nor
 11748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcreatures Irrationall; because they understand no Precepts as his: Nor
 11749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAtheists; nor they that believe not that God has any care of the actions
 11750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof mankind; because they acknowledge no Word for his, nor have hope of
 11751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this rewards, or fear of his threatnings. They therefore that believe
 11752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is a God that governeth the world, and hath given Praecepts, and
 11753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpropounded Rewards, and Punishments to Mankind, are Gods Subjects; all
 11754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe rest, are to be understood as Enemies.
 11755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Threefold Word Of God, Reason, Revelation, Prophecy
 11760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo rule by Words, requires that such Words be manifestly made known;
 11762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor else they are no Lawes: For to the nature of Lawes belongeth a
 11763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsufficient, and clear Promulgation, such as may take away the excuse of
 11764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance; which in the Lawes of men is but of one onely kind, and that
 11765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, Proclamation, or Promulgation by the voyce of man. But God
 11766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeclareth his Lawes three wayes; by the Dictates of Naturall Reason, By
 11767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRevelation, and by the Voyce of some Man, to whom by the operation of
 11768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles, he procureth credit with the rest. From hence there ariseth
 11769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta triple Word of God, Rational, Sensible, and Prophetique: to which
 11770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCorrespondeth a triple Hearing; Right Reason, Sense Supernaturall, and
 11771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith. As for Sense Supernaturall, which consisteth in Revelation, or
 11772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInspiration, there have not been any Universall Lawes so given, because
 11773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod speaketh not in that manner, but to particular persons, and to
 11774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivers men divers things.
 11775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Twofold Kingdome Of God, Naturall And Prophetique From the difference
 11777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetween the other two kinds of Gods Word, Rationall, and Prophetique,
 11778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere may be attributed to God, a two-fold Kingdome, Naturall, and
 11779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphetique: Naturall, wherein he governeth as many of Mankind as
 11780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledge his Providence, by the naturall Dictates of Right Reason;
 11781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Prophetique, wherein having chosen out one peculiar Nation (the
 11782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJewes) for his Subjects, he governed them, and none but them, not onely
 11783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby naturall Reason, but by Positive Lawes, which he gave them by the
 11784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmouths of his holy Prophets. Of the Naturall Kingdome of God I intend to
 11785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeak in this Chapter.
 11786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Right Of Gods Soveraignty Is Derived From His Omnipotence The Right
 11788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Nature, whereby God reigneth over men, and punisheth those that
 11789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbreak his Lawes, is to be derived, not from his Creating them, as if
 11790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the required obedience, as of Gratitude for his benefits; but from his
 11791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIrresistible Power. I have formerly shewn, how the Soveraign Right
 11792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tariseth from Pact: To shew how the same Right may arise from Nature,
 11793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequires no more, but to shew in what case it is never taken away.
 11794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing all men by Nature had Right to All things, they had Right every
 11795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone to reigne over all the rest. But because this Right could not be
 11796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobtained by force, it concerned the safety of every one, laying by that
 11797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight, to set up men (with Soveraign Authority) by common consent,
 11798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto rule and defend them: whereas if there had been any man of Power
 11799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIrresistible; there had been no reason, why he should not by that Power
 11800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave ruled, and defended both himselfe, and them, according to his own
 11801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscretion. To those therefore whose Power is irresistible, the dominion
 11802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof all men adhaereth naturally by their excellence of Power; and
 11803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently it is from that Power, that the Kingdome over men, and
 11804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Right of afflicting men at his pleasure, belongeth Naturally to God
 11805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlmighty; not as Creator, and Gracious; but as Omnipotent. And though
 11806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishment be due for Sinne onely, because by that word is understood
 11807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAffliction for Sinne; yet the Right of Afflicting, is not alwayes
 11808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tderived from mens Sinne, but from Gods Power.
 11809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSinne Not The Cause Of All Affliction
 11814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis question, "Why Evill men often Prosper, and Good men suffer
 11816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdversity," has been much disputed by the Antient, and is the same
 11817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith this of ours, "By what Right God dispenseth the Prosperities and
 11818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdversities of this life;" and is of that difficulty, as it hath shaken
 11819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe faith, not onely of the Vulgar, but of Philosophers, and which is
 11820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore, of the Saints, concerning the Divine Providence. "How Good," saith
 11821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDavid, "is the God of Israel to those that are Upright in Heart; and yet
 11822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmy feet were almost gone, my treadings had well-nigh slipt; for I was
 11823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrieved at the Wicked, when I saw the Ungodly in such Prosperity."
 11824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Job, how earnestly does he expostulate with God, for the many
 11825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfflictions he suffered, notwithstanding his Righteousnesse? This
 11826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestion in the case of Job, is decided by God himselfe, not by
 11827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\targuments derived from Job's Sinne, but his own Power. For whereas the
 11828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfriends of Job drew their arguments from his Affliction to his Sinne,
 11829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand he defended himselfe by the conscience of his Innocence, God
 11830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe taketh up the matter, and having justified the Affliction by
 11831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\targuments drawn from his Power, such as this "Where was thou when I
 11832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlayd the foundations of the earth," and the like, both approved
 11833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJob's Innocence, and reproved the Erroneous doctrine of his friends.
 11834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConformable to this doctrine is the sentence of our Saviour, concerning
 11835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe man that was born Blind, in these words, "Neither hath this man
 11836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsinned, nor his fathers; but that the works of God might be made
