 11837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest in him." And though it be said "That Death entred into the
 11838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld by sinne," (by which is meant that if Adam had never sinned, he had
 11839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnever dyed, that is, never suffered any separation of his soule from his
 11840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbody,) it follows not thence, that God could not justly have Afflicted
 11841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, though he had not Sinned, as well as he afflicteth other living
 11842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcreatures, that cannot sinne.
 11843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivine Lawes
 11848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHaving spoken of the Right of Gods Soveraignty, as grounded onely on
 11850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature; we are to consider next, what are the Divine Lawes, or Dictates
 11851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Naturall Reason; which Lawes concern either the naturall Duties of
 11852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone man to another, or the Honour naturally due to our Divine Soveraign.
 11853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe first are the same Lawes of Nature, of which I have spoken already
 11854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the 14. and 15. Chapters of this Treatise; namely, Equity, Justice,
 11855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMercy, Humility, and the rest of the Morall Vertues. It remaineth
 11856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore that we consider, what Praecepts are dictated to men, by their
 11857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall Reason onely, without other word of God, touching the Honour
 11858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Worship of the Divine Majesty.
 11859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonour And Worship What
 11864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonour consisteth in the inward thought, and opinion of the Power, and
 11866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGoodnesse of another: and therefore to Honour God, is to think as Highly
 11867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his Power and Goodnesse, as is possible. And of that opinion, the
 11868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texternall signes appearing in the Words, and Actions of men, are called
 11869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship; which is one part of that which the Latines understand by the
 11870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tword Cultus: For Cultus signifieth properly, and constantly, that labour
 11871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich a man bestowes on any thing, with a purpose to make benefit by it.
 11872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNow those things whereof we make benefit, are either subject to us, and
 11873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe profit they yeeld, followeth the labour we bestow upon them, as a
 11874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturall effect; or they are not subject to us, but answer our labour,
 11875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccording to their own Wills. In the first sense the labour bestowed on
 11876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Earth, is called Culture; and the education of Children a Culture of
 11877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir mindes. In the second sense, where mens wills are to be wrought to
 11878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour purpose, not by Force, but by Compleasance, it signifieth as much as
 11879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCourting, that is, a winning of favour by good offices; as by praises,
 11880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby acknowledging their Power, and by whatsoever is pleasing to them from
 11881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom we look for any benefit. And this is properly Worship: in which
 11882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense Publicola, is understood for a Worshipper of the People, and
 11883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCultus Dei, for the Worship of God.
 11884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeverall Signes Of Honour
 11889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom internall Honour, consisting in the opinion of Power and Goodnesse,
 11891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tarise three Passions; Love, which hath reference to Goodnesse; and Hope,
 11892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Fear, that relate to Power: And three parts of externall worship;
 11893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPraise, Magnifying, and Blessing: The subject of Praise, being
 11894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGoodnesse; the subject of Magnifying, and Blessing, being Power, and the
 11895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teffect thereof Felicity. Praise, and Magnifying are significant both by
 11896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWords, and Actions: By Words, when we say a man is Good, or Great:
 11897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Actions, when we thank him for his Bounty, and obey his Power. The
 11898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion of the Happinesse of another, can onely be expressed by words.
 11899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship Naturall And Arbitrary
 11904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere be some signes of Honour, (both in Attributes and Actions,) that
 11906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Naturally so; as amongst Attributes, Good, Just, Liberall, and the
 11907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike; and amongst Actions, Prayers, Thanks, and Obedience. Others are
 11908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso by Institution, or Custome of men; and in some times and places are
 11909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonourable; in others Dishonourable; in others Indifferent: such as are
 11910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Gestures in Salutation, Prayer, and Thanksgiving, in different
 11911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimes and places, differently used. The former is Naturall; the later
 11912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArbitrary Worship.
 11913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship Commanded And Free
 11918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd of Arbitrary Worship, there bee two differences: For sometimes it is
 11920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Commanded, sometimes Voluntary Worship: Commanded, when it is such
 11921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas hee requireth, who is Worshipped: Free, when it is such as the
 11922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorshipper thinks fit. When it is Commanded, not the words, or gestures,
 11923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the obedience is the Worship. But when Free, the Worship consists
 11924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the opinion of the beholders: for if to them the words, or actions by
 11925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich we intend honour, seem ridiculous, and tending to contumely; they
 11926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not Worship; because a signe is not a signe to him that giveth it,
 11927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut to him to whom it is made; that is, to the spectator.
 11928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship Publique And Private
 11933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, there is a Publique, and a Private Worship. Publique, is the
 11935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship that a Common-wealth performeth, as one Person. Private, is that
 11936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich a Private person exhibiteth. Publique, in respect of the whole
 11937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, is Free; but in respect of Particular men it is not so.
 11938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivate, is in secret Free; but in the sight of the multitude, it is
 11939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnever without some Restraint, either from the Lawes, or from the Opinion
 11940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men; which is contrary to the nature of Liberty.
 11941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe End Of Worship
 11946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe End of Worship amongst men, is Power. For where a man seeth another
 11948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworshipped he supposeth him powerfull, and is the readier to obey him;
 11949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich makes his Power greater. But God has no Ends: the worship we do
 11950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, proceeds from our duty, and is directed according to our capacity,
 11951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby those rules of Honour, that Reason dictateth to be done by the weak
 11952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the more potent men, in hope of benefit, for fear of dammage, or in
 11953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthankfulnesse for good already received from them.
 11954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAttributes Of Divine Honour
 11959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat we may know what worship of God is taught us by the light of
 11961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature, I will begin with his Attributes. Where, First, it is manifest,
 11962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe ought to attribute to him Existence: For no man can have the will to
 11963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thonour that, which he thinks not to have any Beeing.
 11964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, that those Philosophers, who sayd the World, or the Soule of
 11966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe World was God, spake unworthily of him; and denyed his Existence:
 11967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor by God, is understood the cause of the World; and to say the World
 11968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis God, is to say there is no cause of it, that is, no God.
 11969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, to say the World was not Created, but Eternall, (seeing that
 11971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is Eternall has no cause,) is to deny there is a God.
 11972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, that they who attributing (as they think) Ease to God, take
 11974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom him the care of Mankind; take from him his Honour: for it takes
 11975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taway mens love, and fear of him; which is the root of Honour.
 11976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFifthly, in those things that signifie Greatnesse, and Power; to say he
 11978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Finite, is not to Honour him: For it is not a signe of the Will to
 11979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonour God, to attribute to him lesse than we can; and Finite, is lesse
 11980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan we can; because to Finite, it is easie to adde more.
 11981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore to attribute Figure to him, is not Honour; for all Figure is
 11983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFinite:
 11984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor to say we conceive, and imagine, or have an Idea of him, in our
 11986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmind: for whatsoever we conceive is Finite:
 11987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNot to attribute to him Parts, or Totality; which are the Attributes
 11989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely of things Finite:
 11990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor to say he is this, or that Place: for whatsoever is in Place, is
 11992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbounded, and Finite:
 11993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor that he is Moved, or Resteth: for both these Attributes ascribe to
 11995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim Place:
 11996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 11997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor that there be more Gods than one; because it implies them all
 11998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFinite: for there cannot be more than one Infinite: Nor to ascribe to
 11999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim (unlesse Metaphorically, meaning not the Passion, but the Effect)
 12000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions that partake of Griefe; as Repentance, Anger, Mercy: or of
 12001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWant; as Appetite, Hope, Desire; or of any Passive faculty: For Passion,
 12002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Power limited by somewhat else.
 12003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore when we ascribe to God a Will, it is not to be understood,
 12005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas that of Man, for a Rationall Appetite; but as the Power, by which he
 12006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teffecteth every thing.
 12007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLikewise when we attribute to him Sight, and other acts of Sense; as
 12009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso Knowledge, and Understanding; which in us is nothing else, but
 12010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta tumult of the mind, raised by externall things that presse the
 12011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\torganicall parts of mans body: For there is no such thing in God; and
 12012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing things that depend on naturall causes, cannot be attributed to
 12013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim.
 12014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHee that will attribute to God, nothing but what is warranted by
 12016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturall Reason, must either use such Negative Attributes, as Infinite,
 12017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternall, Incomprehensible; or Superlatives, as Most High, Most Great,
 12018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the like; or Indefinite, as Good, Just, Holy, Creator; and in such
 12019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense, as if he meant not to declare what he is, (for that were to
 12020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcircumscribe him within the limits of our Fancy,) but how much wee
 12021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadmire him, and how ready we would be to obey him; which is a signe of
 12022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHumility, and of a Will to honour him as much as we can: For there is
 12023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut one Name to signifie our Conception of his Nature, and that is, I
 12024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAM: and but one Name of his Relation to us, and that is God; in which is
 12025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontained Father, King, and Lord.
 12026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActions That Are Signes Of Divine Honour
 12031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConcerning the actions of Divine Worship, it is a most generall Precept
 12033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Reason, that they be signes of the Intention to Honour God; such as
 12034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare, First, Prayers: For not the Carvers, when they made Images, were
 12035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought to make them Gods; but the People that Prayed to them.
 12036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, Thanksgiving; which differeth from Prayer in Divine Worship,
 12038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno otherwise, than that Prayers precede, and Thanks succeed the benefit;
 12039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe end both of the one, and the other, being to acknowledge God, for
 12040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthor of all benefits, as well past, as future.
 12041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, Gifts; that is to say, Sacrifices, and Oblations, (if they be
 12043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the best,) are signes of Honour: for they are Thanksgivings.
 12044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, Not to swear by any but God, is naturally a signe of Honour:
 12046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor it is a confession that God onely knoweth the heart; and that no
 12047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmans wit, or strength can protect a man against Gods vengence on the
 12048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperjured.
 12049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFifthly, it is a part of Rationall Worship, to speak Considerately
 12051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God; for it argues a Fear of him, and Fear, is a confession of his
 12052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower. Hence followeth, That the name of God is not to be used rashly,
 12053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to no purpose; for that is as much, as in Vain: And it is to
 12054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno purpose; unlesse it be by way of Oath, and by order of the
 12055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, to make Judgements certain; or between Common-wealths,
 12056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto avoyd Warre. And that disputing of Gods nature is contrary to his
 12057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonour: For it is supposed, that in this naturall Kingdome of God, there
 12058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis no other way to know any thing, but by naturall Reason; that is, from
 12059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Principles of naturall Science; which are so farre from teaching us
 12060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany thing of Gods nature, as they cannot teach us our own nature, nor
 12061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe nature of the smallest creature living. And therefore, when men out
 12062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Principles of naturall Reason, dispute of the Attributes of God,
 12063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey but dishonour him: For in the Attributes which we give to God, we
 12064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not to consider the signification of Philosophicall Truth; but the
 12065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignification of Pious Intention, to do him the greatest Honour we are
 12066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\table. From the want of which consideration, have proceeded the volumes
 12067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof disputation about the Nature of God, that tend not to his Honour, but
 12068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the honour of our own wits, and learning; and are nothing else but
 12069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinconsiderate, and vain abuses of his Sacred Name.
 12070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSixthly, in Prayers, Thanksgivings, Offerings and Sacrifices, it is a
 12072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDictate of naturall Reason, that they be every one in his kind the
 12073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbest, and most significant of Honour. As for example, that Prayers, and
 12074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThanksgiving, be made in Words and Phrases, not sudden, nor light, nor
 12075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPlebeian; but beautifull and well composed; For else we do not God
 12076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas much honour as we can. And therefore the Heathens did absurdly, to
 12077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworship Images for Gods: But their doing it in Verse, and with Musick,
 12078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth of Voyce, and Instruments, was reasonable. Also that the Beasts
 12079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey offered in sacrifice, and the Gifts they offered, and their actions
 12080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Worshipping, were full of submission, and commemorative of benefits
 12081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceived, was according to reason, as proceeding from an intention to
 12082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thonour him.
 12083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeventhly, Reason directeth not onely to worship God in Secret; but
 12085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso, and especially, in Publique, and in the sight of men: For without
 12086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat, (that which in honour is most acceptable) the procuring others to
 12087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thonour him, is lost.
 12088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, Obedience to his Lawes (that is, in this case to the Lawes
 12090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Nature,) is the greatest worship of all. For as Obedience is
 12091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore acceptable to God than sacrifice; so also to set light by his
 12092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandements, is the greatest of all contumelies. And these are the
 12093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLawes of that Divine Worship, which naturall Reason dictateth to private
 12094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen.
 12095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Worship Consisteth In Uniformity
 12100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut seeing a Common-wealth is but one Person, it ought also to exhibite
 12102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto God but one Worship; which then it doth, when it commandeth it to be
 12103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texhibited by Private men, Publiquely. And this is Publique Worship; the
 12104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproperty whereof, is to be Uniforme: For those actions that are done
 12105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifferently, by different men, cannot be said to be a Publique Worship.
 12106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore, where many sorts of Worship be allowed, proceeding from
 12107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe different Religions of Private men, it cannot be said there is any
 12108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Worship, nor that the Common-wealth is of any Religion at all.
 12109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll Attributes Depend On The Lawes Civill
 12114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because words (and consequently the Attributes of God) have their
 12116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignification by agreement, and constitution of men; those Attributes
 12117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare to be held significative of Honour, that men intend shall so be; and
 12118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever may be done by the wills of particular men, where there is no
 12119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw but Reason, may be done by the will of the Common-wealth, by Lawes
 12120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill. And because a Common-wealth hath no Will, nor makes no Lawes,
 12121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut those that are made by the Will of him, or them that have the
 12122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Power; it followeth, that those Attributes which the Soveraign
 12123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordaineth, in the Worship of God, for signes of Honour, ought to be
 12124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaken and used for such, by private men in their publique Worship.
 12125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNot All Actions
 12130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut because not all Actions are signes by Constitution; but some are
 12132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturally signes of Honour, others of Contumely, these later (which are
 12133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that men are ashamed to do in the sight of them they reverence)
 12134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot be made by humane power a part of Divine worship; nor the former
 12135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(such as are decent, modest, humble Behaviour) ever be separated from
 12136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit. But whereas there be an infinite number of Actions, and Gestures, of
 12137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan indifferent nature; such of them as the Common-wealth shall ordain to
 12138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Publiquely and Universally in use, as signes of Honour, and part of
 12139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods Worship, are to be taken and used for such by the Subjects. And
 12140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which is said in the Scripture, "It is better to obey God than
 12141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen," hath place in the kingdome of God by Pact, and not by Nature.
 12142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall Punishments
 12147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHaving thus briefly spoken of the Naturall Kingdome of God, and his
 12149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaturall Lawes, I will adde onely to this Chapter a short declaration of
 12150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Naturall Punishments. There is no action of man in this life, that
 12151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not the beginning of so long a chayn of Consequences, as no humane
 12152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProvidence, is high enough, to give a man a prospect to the end. And
 12153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this Chayn, there are linked together both pleasing and unpleasing
 12154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevents; in such manner, as he that will do any thing for his pleasure,
 12155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmust engage himselfe to suffer all the pains annexed to it; and these
 12156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpains, are the Naturall Punishments of those actions, which are the
 12157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeginning of more Harme that Good. And hereby it comes to passe, that
 12158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIntemperance, is naturally punished with Diseases; Rashnesse, with
 12159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMischances; Injustice, with the Violence of Enemies; Pride, with Ruine;
 12160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCowardise, with Oppression; Negligent government of Princes, with
 12161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRebellion; and Rebellion, with Slaughter. For seeing Punishments
 12162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare consequent to the breach of Lawes; Naturall Punishments must be
 12163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturally consequent to the breach of the Lawes of Nature; and therfore
 12164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollow them as their naturall, not arbitrary effects.
 12165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Conclusion Of The Second Part
 12170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd thus farre concerning the Constitution, Nature, and Right of
 12172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns; and concerning the Duty of Subjects, derived from the
 12173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrinciples of Naturall Reason. And now, considering how different
 12174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Doctrine is, from the Practise of the greatest part of the world,
 12175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tespecially of these Western parts, that have received their Morall
 12176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlearning from Rome, and Athens; and how much depth of Morall Philosophy
 12177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis required, in them that have the Administration of the Soveraign
 12178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower; I am at the point of believing this my labour, as uselesse,
 12179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Common-wealth of Plato; For he also is of opinion that it is
 12180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpossible for the disorders of State, and change of Governments by
 12181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Warre, ever to be taken away, till Soveraigns be Philosophers.
 12182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut when I consider again, that the Science of Naturall Justice, is the
 12183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely Science necessary for Soveraigns, and their principall Ministers;
 12184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand that they need not be charged with the Sciences Mathematicall, (as
 12185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Plato they are,) further, than by good Lawes to encourage men to
 12186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe study of them; and that neither Plato, nor any other Philosopher
 12187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thitherto, hath put into order, and sufficiently, or probably proved all
 12188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Theoremes of Morall doctrine, that men may learn thereby, both how
 12189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto govern, and how to obey; I recover some hope, that one time or other,
 12190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis writing of mine, may fall into the hands of a Soveraign, who will
 12191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsider it himselfe, (for it is short, and I think clear,) without the
 12192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thelp of any interested, or envious Interpreter; and by the exercise of
 12193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tentire Soveraignty, in protecting the Publique teaching of it, convert
 12194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Truth of Speculation, into the Utility of Practice.
 12195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPART III. OF A CHRISTIAN COMMON-WEALTH
 12201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXXII. OF THE PRINCIPLES OF CHRISTIAN POLITIQUES
 12206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Word Of God Delivered By Prophets Is The Main Principle
 12209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Christian Politiques
 12211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI have derived the Rights of Soveraigne Power, and the duty of Subjects
 12213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thitherto, from the Principles of Nature onely; such as Experience has
 12214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfound true, or Consent (concerning the use of words) has made so; that
 12215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, from the nature of Men, known to us by Experience, and
 12216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom Definitions (of such words as are Essentiall to all Politicall
 12217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasoning) universally agreed on. But in that I am next to handle, which
 12218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the Nature and Rights of a CHRISTIAN COMMON-WEALTH, whereof there
 12219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdependeth much upon Supernaturall Revelations of the Will of God; the
 12220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tground of my Discourse must be, not only the Naturall Word of God, but
 12221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso the Propheticall.
 12222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse, we are not to renounce our Senses, and Experience; nor
 12224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(that which is the undoubted Word of God) our naturall Reason. For they
 12225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare the talents which he hath put into our hands to negotiate, till the
 12226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcoming again of our blessed Saviour; and therefore not to be folded up
 12227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Napkin of an Implicate Faith, but employed in the purchase of
 12228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice, Peace, and true Religion, For though there be many things in
 12229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods Word above Reason; that is to say, which cannot by naturall reason
 12230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe either demonstrated, or confuted; yet there is nothing contrary
 12231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto it; but when it seemeth so, the fault is either in our unskilfull
 12232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpretation, or erroneous Ratiocination.
 12233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore, when any thing therein written is too hard for our
 12235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texamination, wee are bidden to captivate our understanding to the Words;
 12236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand not to labour in sifting out a Philosophicall truth by Logick, of
 12237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch mysteries as are not comprehensible, nor fall under any rule of
 12238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturall science. For it is with the mysteries of our Religion, as with
 12239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twholsome pills for the sick, which swallowed whole, have the vertue to
 12240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcure; but chewed, are for the most part cast up again without effect.
 12241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat It Is To Captivate The Understanding
 12246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut by the Captivity of our Understanding, is not meant a Submission of
 12248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Intellectual faculty, to the Opinion of any other man; but of
 12249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Will to Obedience, where obedience is due. For Sense, Memory,
 12250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUnderstanding, Reason, and Opinion are not in our power to change; but
 12251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talwaies, and necessarily such, as the things we see, hear, and consider
 12252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuggest unto us; and therefore are not effects of our Will, but our Will
 12253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them. We then Captivate our Understanding and Reason, when we forbear
 12254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontradiction; when we so speak, as (by lawfull Authority) we are
 12255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommanded; and when we live accordingly; which in sum, is Trust, and
 12256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith reposed in him that speaketh, though the mind be incapable of any
 12257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNotion at all from the words spoken.
 12258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHow God Speaketh To Men
 12263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen God speaketh to man, it must be either immediately; or by mediation
 12265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof another man, to whom he had formerly spoken by himself immediately.
 12266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHow God speaketh to a man immediately, may be understood by those well
 12267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenough, to whom he hath so spoken; but how the same should be understood
 12268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby another, is hard, if not impossible to know. For if a man pretend to
 12269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tme, that God hath spoken to him supernaturally, and immediately, and I
 12270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake doubt of it, I cannot easily perceive what argument he can produce,
 12271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto oblige me to beleeve it. It is true, that if he be my Soveraign,
 12272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the may oblige me to obedience, so, as not by act or word to declare I
 12273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve him not; but not to think any otherwise then my reason perswades
 12274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tme. But if one that hath not such authority over me, shall pretend the
 12275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame, there is nothing that exacteth either beleefe, or obedience.
 12276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor to say that God hath spoken to him in the Holy Scripture, is not
 12278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say God hath spoken to him immediately, but by mediation of the
 12279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets, or of the Apostles, or of the Church, in such manner as he
 12280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeaks to all other Christian men. To say he hath spoken to him in a
 12281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDream, is no more than to say he dreamed that God spake to him; which is
 12282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot of force to win beleef from any man, that knows dreams are for
 12283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe most part naturall, and may proceed from former thoughts; and such
 12284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdreams as that, from selfe conceit, and foolish arrogance, and false
 12285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion of a mans own godlinesse, or other vertue, by which he thinks he
 12286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath merited the favour of extraordinary Revelation. To say he hath
 12287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseen a Vision, or heard a Voice, is to say, that he hath dreamed between
 12288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsleeping and waking: for in such manner a man doth many times naturally
 12289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake his dream for a vision, as not having well observed his own
 12290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tslumbering. To say he speaks by supernaturall Inspiration, is to say he
 12291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfinds an ardent desire to speak, or some strong opinion of himself, for
 12292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich he can alledge no naturall and sufficient reason. So that
 12293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough God Almighty can speak to a man, by Dreams, Visions, Voice, and
 12294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInspiration; yet he obliges no man to beleeve he hath so done to him
 12295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat pretends it; who (being a man), may erre, and (which is more) may
 12296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlie.
 12297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy What Marks Prophets Are Known
 12302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHow then can he, to whom God hath never revealed his Wil immediately
 12304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(saving by the way of natural reason) know when he is to obey, or not
 12305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey his Word, delivered by him, that sayes he is a Prophet? (1 Kings
 12306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t22) Of 400 Prophets, of whom the K. of Israel asked counsel, concerning
 12307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe warre he made against Ramoth Gilead, only Micaiah was a true one.(1
 12308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings 13) The Prophet that was sent to prophecy against the Altar set up
 12309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Jeroboam, though a true Prophet, and that by two miracles done in
 12310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this presence appears to be a Prophet sent from God, was yet deceived by
 12311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother old Prophet, that perswaded him as from the mouth of God, to eat
 12312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand drink with him. If one Prophet deceive another, what certainty is
 12313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere of knowing the will of God, by other way than that of Reason? To
 12314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich I answer out of the Holy Scripture, that there be two marks, by
 12315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich together, not asunder, a true Prophet is to be known. One is the
 12316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoing of miracles; the other is the not teaching any other Religion than
 12317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which is already established. Asunder (I say) neither of these is
 12318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsufficient. (Deut. 13 v. 1,2,3,4,5 ) "If a Prophet rise amongst you, or
 12319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Dreamer of dreams, and shall pretend the doing of a miracle, and the
 12320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmiracle come to passe; if he say, Let us follow strange Gods, which thou
 12321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thast not known, thou shalt not hearken to him, &c. But that Prophet and
 12322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDreamer of dreams shall be put to death, because he hath spoken to you
 12323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Revolt from the Lord your God." In which words two things are to
 12324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe observed, First, that God wil not have miracles alone serve for
 12325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\targuments, to approve the Prophets calling; but (as it is in the third
 12326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tverse) for an experiment of the constancy of our adherence to himself.
 12327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the works of the Egyptian Sorcerers, though not so great as those
 12328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Moses, yet were great miracles. Secondly, that how great soever the
 12329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmiracle be, yet if it tend to stir up revolt against the King, or him
 12330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat governeth by the Kings authority, he that doth such miracle, is
 12331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot to be considered otherwise than as sent to make triall of their
 12332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallegiance. For these words, "revolt from the Lord your God," are in
 12333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis place equivalent to "revolt from your King." For they had made God
 12334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir King by pact at the foot of Mount Sinai; who ruled them by Moses
 12335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonly; for he only spake with God, and from time to time declared Gods
 12336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandements to the people. In like manner, after our Saviour Christ
 12337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad made his Disciples acknowledge him for the Messiah, (that is to say,
 12338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Gods anointed, whom the nation of the Jews daily expected for their
 12339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing, but refused when he came,) he omitted not to advertise them of the
 12340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdanger of miracles. "There shall arise," (saith he) "false Christs, and
 12341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfalse Prophets, and shall doe great wonders and miracles, even to the
 12342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseducing (if it were possible) of the very Elect." (Mat. 24. 24) By
 12343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich it appears, that false Prophets may have the power of miracles;
 12344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet are wee not to take their doctrin for Gods Word. St. Paul says
 12345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfurther to the Galatians, that "if himself, or an Angell from heaven
 12346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreach another Gospel to them, than he had preached, let him be
 12347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccursed." (Gal. 1. 8) That Gospel was, that Christ was King; so that
 12348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall preaching against the power of the King received, in consequence
 12349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto these words, is by St. Paul accursed. For his speech is addressed to
 12350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose, who by his preaching had already received Jesus for the Christ,
 12351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, for King of the Jews.
 12352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Marks Of A Prophet In The Old Law, Miracles, And Doctrine
 12357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConformable To The Law
 12359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as Miracles, without preaching that Doctrine which God hath
 12361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\testablished; so preaching the true Doctrine, without the doing of
 12362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles, is an unsufficient argument of immediate Revelation. For if
 12363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man that teacheth not false Doctrine, should pretend to bee a Prophet
 12364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout shewing any Miracle, he is never the more to bee regarded for
 12365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this pretence, as is evident by Deut. 18. v. 21, 22. "If thou say in
 12366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthy heart, How shall we know that the Word (of the Prophet) is not that
 12367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Lord hath spoken. When the Prophet shall have spoken in the
 12368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of the Lord, that which shall not come to passe, that's the word
 12369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Lord hath not spoken, but the Prophet has spoken it out of
 12370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe pride of his own heart, fear him not." But a man may here again ask,
 12371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen the Prophet hath foretold a thing, how shal we know whether it will
 12372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome to passe or not? For he may foretel it as a thing to arrive after
 12373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta certain long time, longer then the time of mans life; or indefinitely,
 12374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat it will come to passe one time or other: in which case this mark
 12375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Prophet is unusefull; and therefore the miracles that oblige us to
 12376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve a Prophet, ought to be confirmed by an immediate, or a not
 12377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlong deferr'd event. So that it is manifest, that the teaching of
 12378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Religion which God hath established, and the showing of a present
 12379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracle, joined together, were the only marks whereby the Scripture
 12380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould have a true Prophet, that is to say immediate Revelation to be
 12381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledged; neither of them being singly sufficient to oblige any
 12382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother man to regard what he saith.
 12383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles Ceasing, Prophets Cease, The Scripture Supplies Their Place
 12388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing therefore Miracles now cease, we have no sign left, whereby to
 12390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledge the pretended Revelations, or Inspirations of any private
 12391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman; nor obligation to give ear to any Doctrine, farther than it is
 12392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconformable to the Holy Scriptures, which since the time of our Saviour,
 12393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupply the want of all other Prophecy; and from which, by wise and
 12394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcareful ratiocination, all rules and precepts necessary to the knowledge
 12395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof our duty both to God and man, without Enthusiasme, or supernaturall
 12396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInspiration, may easily be deduced. And this Scripture is it, out of
 12397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich I am to take the Principles of my Discourse, concerning the
 12398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRights of those that are the Supream Govenors on earth, of Christian
 12399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths; and of the duty of Christian Subjects towards their
 12400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns. And to that end, I shall speak in the next Chapter, or the
 12401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBooks, Writers, Scope and Authority of the Bible.
 12402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXXIII. OF THE NUMBER, ANTIQUITY, SCOPE, AUTHORITY,
 12406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAND INTERPRETERS OF THE BOOKS OF HOLY SCRIPTURES
 12408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Books Of Holy Scripture
 12413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy the Books of Holy SCRIPTURE, are understood those, which ought to be
 12415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Canon, that is to say, the Rules of Christian life. And because all
 12416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRules of life, which men are in conscience bound to observe, are Laws;
 12417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe question of the Scripture, is the question of what is Law throughout
 12418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall Christendome, both Naturall, and Civill. For though it be not
 12419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdetermined in Scripture, what Laws every Christian King shall constitute
 12420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his own Dominions; yet it is determined what laws he shall not
 12421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstitute. Seeing therefore I have already proved, that Soveraigns
 12422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin their own Dominions are the sole Legislators; those Books only are
 12423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCanonicall, that is, Law, in every nation, which are established for
 12424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch by the Soveraign Authority. It is true, that God is the Soveraign
 12425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof all Soveraigns; and therefore, when he speaks to any Subject, he
 12426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought to be obeyed, whatsoever any earthly Potentate command to the
 12427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary. But the question is not of obedience to God, but of When,
 12428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand What God hath said; which to Subjects that have no supernaturall
 12429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trevelation, cannot be known, but by that naturall reason, which guided
 12430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, for the obtaining of Peace and Justice, to obey the authority
 12431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their severall Common-wealths; that is to say, of their lawfull
 12432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns. According to this obligation, I can acknowledge no other
 12433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBooks of the Old Testament, to be Holy Scripture, but those which have
 12434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen commanded to be acknowledged for such, by the Authority of the
 12435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch of England. What Books these are, is sufficiently known, without
 12436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Catalogue of them here; and they are the same that are acknowledged
 12437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby St. Jerome, who holdeth the rest, namely, the Wisdome of Solomon,
 12438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticus, Judith, Tobias, the first and second of Maccabees,
 12439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(though he had seen the first in Hebrew) and the third and fourth of
 12440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEsdras, for Apocrypha. Of the Canonicall, Josephus a learned Jew, that
 12441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twrote in the time of the Emperor Domitian, reckoneth Twenty Two, making
 12442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe number agree with the Hebrew Alphabet. St. Jerome does the same,
 12443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough they reckon them in different manner. For Josephus numbers Five
 12444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBooks of Moses, Thirteen of Prophets, that writ the History of their own
 12445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimes (which how it agrees with the Prophets writings contained in the
 12446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBible wee shall see hereafter), and Four of Hymnes and Morall Precepts.
 12447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut St. Jerome reckons Five Books of Moses, Eight of Prophets, and Nine
 12448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof other Holy writ, which he calls of Hagiographa. The Septuagint, who
 12449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere 70. learned men of the Jews, sent for by Ptolemy King of Egypt, to
 12450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttranslate the Jewish Law, out of the Hebrew into the Greek, have left us
 12451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno other for holy Scripture in the Greek tongue, but the same that are
 12452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceived in the Church of England.
 12453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for the Books of the New Testament, they are equally acknowledged for
 12455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCanon by all Christian Churches, and by all sects of Christians, that
 12456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadmit any Books at all for Canonicall.
 12457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTheir Antiquity
 12462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWho were the originall writers of the severall Books of Holy Scripture,
 12464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thas not been made evident by any sufficient testimony of other History,
 12465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which is the only proof of matter of fact); nor can be by any arguments
 12466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof naturall Reason; for Reason serves only to convince the truth (not
 12467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof fact, but) of consequence. The light therefore that must guide us in
 12468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis question, must be that which is held out unto us from the Bookes
 12469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves: And this light, though it show us not the writer of every
 12470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbook, yet it is not unusefull to give us knowledge of the time, wherein
 12471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were written.
 12472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Pentateuch Not Written By Moses
 12477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first, for the Pentateuch, it is not argument enough that they were
 12479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten by Moses, because they are called the five Books of Moses; no
 12480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore than these titles, The Book of Joshua, the Book of Judges, The Book
 12481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Ruth, and the Books of the Kings, are arguments sufficient to prove,
 12482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat they were written by Joshua, by the Judges, by Ruth, and by the
 12483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings. For in titles of Books, the subject is marked, as often as the
 12484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twriter. The History Of Livy, denotes the Writer; but the History Of
 12485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScanderbeg, is denominated from the subject. We read in the last Chapter
 12486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Deuteronomie, Ver. 6. concerning the sepulcher of Moses, "that no man
 12487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknoweth of his sepulcher to this day," that is, to the day wherein those
 12488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords were written. It is therefore manifest, that those words were
 12489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten after his interrement. For it were a strange interpretation, to
 12490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay Moses spake of his own sepulcher (though by Prophecy), that it was
 12491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot found to that day, wherein he was yet living. But it may perhaps
 12492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe alledged, that the last Chapter only, not the whole Pentateuch, was
 12493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten by some other man, but the rest not: Let us therefore consider
 12494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which we find in the Book of Genesis, Chap. 12. Ver. 6 "And Abraham
 12495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpassed through the land to the place of Sichem, unto the plain of Moreh,
 12496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Canaanite was then in the land;" which must needs bee the
 12497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords of one that wrote when the Canaanite was not in the land; and
 12498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently, not of Moses, who dyed before he came into it. Likewise
 12499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNumbers 21. Ver. 14. the Writer citeth another more ancient Book,
 12500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEntituled, The Book of the Warres of the Lord, wherein were registred
 12501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Acts of Moses, at the Red-sea, and at the brook of Arnon. It is
 12502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore sufficiently evident, that the five Books of Moses were
 12503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten after his time, though how long after it be not so manifest.
 12504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut though Moses did not compile those Books entirely, and in the form
 12506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe have them; yet he wrote all that which hee is there said to have
 12507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten: as for example, the Volume of the Law, which is contained, as
 12508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit seemeth in the 11 of Deuteronomie, and the following Chapters to the
 12509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t27. which was also commanded to be written on stones, in their entry
 12510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto the land of Canaan. (Deut. 31. 9) And this did Moses himself
 12511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twrite, and deliver to the Priests and Elders of Israel, to be read
 12512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery seventh year to all Israel, at their assembling in the feast of
 12513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTabernacles. And this is that Law which God commanded, that their Kings
 12514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(when they should have established that form of Government) should take
 12515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta copy of from the Priests and Levites to lay in the side of the Arke;
 12516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Deut. 31. 26) and the same which having been lost, was long time after
 12517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfound again by Hilkiah, and sent to King Josias, who causing it to be
 12518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tread to the People, renewed the Covenant between God and them. (2 King.

 12524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Book of Joshua Written After His Time
 12525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat the Book of Joshua was also written long after the time of Joshua,
 12527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay be gathered out of many places of the Book it self. Joshua had
 12528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tset up twelve stones in the middest of Jordan, for a monument of their
 12529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpassage; (Josh 4. 9) of which the Writer saith thus, "They are there
 12530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunto this day;" (Josh 5. 9) for "unto this day", is a phrase that
 12531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifieth a time past, beyond the memory of man. In like manner, upon
 12532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe saying of the Lord, that he had rolled off from the people the
 12533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReproach of Egypt, the Writer saith, "The place is called Gilgal unto
 12534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis day;" which to have said in the time of Joshua had been improper.
 12535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo also the name of the Valley of Achor, from the trouble that Achan
 12536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\traised in the Camp, (Josh. 7. 26) the Writer saith, "remaineth unto
 12537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis day;" which must needs bee therefore long after the time of Joshua.
 12538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArguments of this kind there be many other; as Josh. 8. 29. 13. 13. 14.
 12539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t14. 15. 63.

 12544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Booke Of Judges And Ruth Written Long After The Captivity
 12545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe same is manifest by like arguments of the Book of Judges, chap. 1.
 12547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t21,26 6.24 10.4 15.19 17.6 and Ruth 1. 1. but especially Judg. 18. 30.

 12549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTribe of Dan, untill the day of the captivity of the land."

 12564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof that Book, must be long after the time of the fact; that is, long

 12578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime. For the Facts Registred are alwaies more ancient than such Books

 12606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJob
 12607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Book of Job hath no mark in it of the time wherein it was written:
 12609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand though it appear sufficiently (Exekiel 14.14, and James 5.11.)
 12610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat he was no fained person; yet the Book it self seemeth not to be
 12611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta History, but a Treatise concerning a question in ancient time much
 12612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisputed, "why wicked men have often prospered in this world, and good
 12613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen have been afflicted;" and it is the most probably, because from the
 12614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeginning, to the third verse of the third chapter, where the complaint
 12615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Job beginneth, the Hebrew is (as St. Jerome testifies) in prose; and
 12616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom thence to the sixt verse of the last chapter in Hexameter Verses;
 12617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the rest of that chapter again in prose. So that the dispute is all
 12618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin verse; and the prose is added, but as a Preface in the beginning, and
 12619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Epilogue in the end. But Verse is no usuall stile of such, as either
 12620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare themselves in great pain, as Job; or of such as come to comfort
 12621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, as his friends; but in Philosophy, especially morall Philosophy,
 12622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin ancient time frequent.

 12627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Psalter
 12628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Psalmes were written the most part by David, for the use of the
 12630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tQuire. To these are added some songs of Moses, and other holy men; and
 12631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome of them after the return from the Captivity; as the 137. and the
 12632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t126. whereby it is manifest that the Psalter was compiled, and put into
 12633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe form it now hath, after the return of the Jews from Babylon.

 12637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Proverbs
 12639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Proverbs, being a Collection of wise and godly Sayings, partly of
 12641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSolomon, partly of Agur the son of Jakeh; and partly of the Mother
 12642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof King Lemuel, cannot probably be thought to have been collected by
 12643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSolomon, rather then by Agur, or the Mother of Lemues; and that, though
 12644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe sentences be theirs, yet the collection or compiling them into this
 12645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone Book, was the work of some other godly man, that lived after them
 12646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall.

 12651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiastes And The Canticles
 12652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Books of Ecclesiastes and the Canticles have nothing that was not
 12654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSolomons, except it be the Titles, or Inscriptions. For "The Words of
 12655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Preacher, the Son of David, King in Jerusalem;" and, "the Song of
 12656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSongs, which is Solomon's," seem to have been made for distinctions
 12657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsake, then, when the Books of Scripture were gathered into one body of
 12658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law; to the end, that not the Doctrine only, but the Authors also
 12659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmight be extant.

 12664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Prophets
 12665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf the Prophets, the most ancient, are Sophoniah, Jonas, Amos, Hosea,
 12667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsaiah and Michaiah, who lived in the time of Amaziah, and Azariah,
 12668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\totherwise Ozias, Kings of Judah. But the Book of Jonas is not properly
 12669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Register of his Prophecy, (for that is contained in these few words,
 12670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Fourty dayes and Ninivy shall be destroyed,") but a History or Narration
 12671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his frowardenesse and disputing Gods commandements; so that there is
 12672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsmall probability he should be the Author, seeing he is the subject of
 12673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit. But the Book of Amos is his Prophecy.
 12674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJeremiah, Abdias, Nahum, and Habakkuk prophecyed in the time of Josiah.
 12676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEzekiel, Daniel, Aggeus, and Zacharias, in the Captivity.
 12678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen Joel and Malachi prophecyed, is not evident by their Writings. But
 12680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsidering the Inscriptions, or Titles of their Books, it is manifest
 12681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenough, that the whole Scripture of the Old Testament, was set forth in
 12682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe form we have it, after the return of the Jews from their Captivity
 12683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Babylon, and before the time of Ptolemaeus Philadelphus, that caused
 12684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit to bee translated into Greek by seventy men, which were sent him
 12685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of Judea for that purpose. And if the Books of Apocrypha (which
 12686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare recommended to us by the Church, though not for Canonicall, yet for
 12687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprofitable Books for our instruction) may in this point be credited, the
 12688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture was set forth in the form wee have it in, by Esdras; as may
 12689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappear by that which he himself saith, in the second book, chapt. 14.
 12690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tverse 21, 22, &c. where speaking to God, he saith thus, "Thy law is
 12691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tburnt; therefore no man knoweth the things which thou has done, or the
 12692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworks that are to begin. But if I have found Grace before thee, send
 12693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdown the holy Spirit into me, and I shall write all that hath been done
 12694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the world, since the beginning, which were written in thy Law, that
 12695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen may find thy path, and that they which will live in the later days,
 12696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay live." And verse 45. "And it came to passe when the forty dayes were
 12697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfulfilled, that the Highest spake, saying, 'The first that thou hast
 12698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten, publish openly, that the worthy and unworthy may read it; but
 12699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkeep the seventy last, that thou mayst deliver them onely to such as
 12700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe wise among the people.'" And thus much concerning the time of the
 12701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twriting of the Bookes of the Old Testament.
 12702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe New Testament
 12707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Writers of the New Testament lived all in lesse then an age after
 12709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrists Ascension, and had all of them seen our Saviour, or been his
 12710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDisciples, except St. Paul, and St. Luke; and consequently whatsoever
 12711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas written by them, is as ancient as the time of the Apostles. But
 12712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe time wherein the Books of the New Testament were received, and
 12713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledged by the Church to be of their writing, is not altogether so
 12714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tancient. For, as the Bookes of the Old Testament are derived to us, from
 12715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno higher time then that of Esdras, who by the direction of Gods Spirit
 12716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tretrived them, when they were lost: Those of the New Testament, of which
 12717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe copies were not many, nor could easily be all in any one private
 12718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmans hand, cannot bee derived from a higher time, that that wherein the
 12719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernours of the Church collected, approved, and recommended them to
 12720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tus, as the writings of those Apostles and Disciples; under whose names
 12721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey go. The first enumeration of all the Bookes, both of the Old,
 12722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand New Testament, is in the Canons of the Apostles, supposed to be
 12723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcollected by Clement the first (after St. Peter) Bishop of Rome. But
 12724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause that is but supposed, and by many questioned, the Councell of
 12725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaodicea is the first we know, that recommended the Bible to the then
 12726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Churches, for the Writings of the Prophets and Apostles: and
 12727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Councell was held in the 364. yeer after Christ. At which time,
 12728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough ambition had so far prevailed on the great Doctors of the Church,
 12729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas no more to esteem Emperours, though Christian, for the Shepherds of
 12730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people, but for Sheep; and Emperours not Christian, for Wolves; and
 12731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tendeavoured to passe their Doctrine, not for Counsell, and Information,
 12732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas Preachers; but for Laws, as absolute Governours; and thought such
 12733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrauds as tended to make the people the more obedient to Christian
 12734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine, to be pious; yet I am perswaded they did not therefore
 12735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfalsifie the Scriptures, though the copies of the Books of the New
 12736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestament, were in the hands only of the Ecclesiasticks; because if they
 12737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad had an intention so to doe, they would surely have made them more
 12738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfavorable to their power over Christian Princes, and Civill Soveraignty,
 12739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan they are. I see not therefore any reason to doubt, but that the
 12740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOld, and New Testament, as we have them now, are the true Registers of
 12741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose things, which were done and said by the Prophets, and Apostles.
 12742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd so perhaps are some of those Books which are called Apocrypha, if
 12743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleft out of the Canon, not for inconformity of Doctrine with the
 12744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trest, but only because they are not found in the Hebrew. For after the
 12745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconquest of Asia by Alexander the Great, there were few learned Jews,
 12746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat were not perfect in the Greek tongue. For the seventy Interpreters
 12747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat converted the Bible into Greek, were all of them Hebrews; and we
 12748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave extant the works of Philo and Josephus both Jews, written by them
 12749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teloquently in Greek. But it is not the Writer, but the authority of the
 12750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, that maketh a Book Canonicall.
 12751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTheir Scope
 12756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd although these Books were written by divers men, yet it is manifest
 12758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Writers were all indued with one and the same Spirit, in that they
 12759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconspire to one and the same end, which is the setting forth of the
 12760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRights of the Kingdome of God, the Father, Son, and Holy Ghost. For
 12761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Book of Genesis, deriveth the Genealogy of Gods people, from the
 12762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcreation of the World, to the going into Egypt: the other four Books of
 12763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses, contain the Election of God for their King, and the Laws which
 12764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee prescribed for their Government: The Books of Joshua, Judges, Ruth,
 12765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Samuel, to the time of Saul, describe the acts of Gods people,
 12766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttill the time they cast off Gods yoke, and called for a King, after the
 12767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner of their neighbour nations; The rest of the History of the
 12768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOld Testament, derives the succession of the line of David, to the
 12769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCaptivity, out of which line was to spring the restorer of the Kingdome
 12770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God, even our blessed Saviour God the Son, whose coming was foretold
 12771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Bookes of the Prophets, after whom the Evangelists writt his
 12772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife, and actions, and his claim to the Kingdome, whilst he lived one
 12773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tearth: and lastly, the Acts, and Epistles of the Apostles, declare the
 12774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcoming of God, the Holy Ghost, and the Authority he left with them, and
 12775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir successors, for the direction of the Jews, and for the invitation
 12776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Gentiles. In summe, the Histories and the Prophecies of the old
 12777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestament, and the Gospels, and Epistles of the New Testament, have had
 12778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone and the same scope, to convert men to the obedience of God; 1. in
 12779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses, and the Priests; 2. in the man Christ; and 3. in the Apostles and
 12780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe successors to Apostolicall power. For these three at several times
 12781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdid represent the person of God: Moses, and his successors the High
 12782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriests, and Kings of Judah, in the Old Testament: Christ himself, in
 12783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe time he lived on earth: and the Apostles, and their successors, from
 12784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe day of Pentecost (when the Holy Ghost descended on them) to this
 12785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tday.
 12786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Question Of The Authority Of The Scriptures Stated.
 12791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is a question much disputed between the divers sects of Christian
 12793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion, From Whence The Scriptures Derive Their Authority; which
 12794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestion is also propounded sometimes in other terms, as, How Wee Know
 12795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThem To Be The Word Of God, or, Why We Beleeve Them To Be So: and the
 12796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifficulty of resolving it, ariseth chiefly from the impropernesse of
 12797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe words wherein the question it self is couched. For it is beleeved
 12798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton all hands, that the first and originall Author of them is God; and
 12799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently the question disputed, is not that. Again, it is manifest,
 12800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat none can know they are Gods Word, (though all true Christians
 12801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve it,) but those to whom God himself hath revealed it
 12802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturally; and therefore the question is not rightly moved, of our
 12803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKnowledge of it. Lastly, when the question is propounded of our Beleefe;
 12804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause some are moved to beleeve for one, and others for other reasons,
 12805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere can be rendred no one generall answer for them all. The question
 12806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttruly stated is, By What Authority They Are Made Law.
 12807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
