 12810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTheir Authority And Interpretation
 12812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs far as they differ not from the Laws of Nature, there is no doubt,
 12814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut they are the Law of God, and carry their Authority with them,
 12815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlegible to all men that have the use of naturall reason: but this is
 12816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno other Authority, then that of all other Morall Doctrine consonant to
 12817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason; the Dictates whereof are Laws, not Made, but Eternall.
 12818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf they be made Law by God himselfe, they are of the nature of written
 12820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, which are Laws to them only to whom God hath so sufficiently
 12821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpublished them, as no man can excuse himself, by saying, he know not
 12822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were his.
 12823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHe therefore, to whom God hath not supernaturally revealed, that they
 12825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare his, nor that those that published them, were sent by him, is not
 12826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobliged to obey them, by any Authority, but his, whose Commands have
 12827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready the force of Laws; that is to say, by any other Authority, then
 12828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat of the Common-wealth, residing in the Soveraign, who only has the
 12829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLegislative power. Again, if it be not the Legislative Authority of
 12830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Common-wealth, that giveth them the force of Laws, it must bee
 12831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome other Authority derived from God, either private, or publique:
 12832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif private, it obliges onely him, to whom in particular God hath been
 12833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpleased to reveale it. For if every man should be obliged, to take for
 12834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods Law, what particular men, on pretence of private Inspiration, or
 12835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRevelation, should obtrude upon him, (in such a number of men, that out
 12836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof pride, and ignorance, take their own Dreams, and extravagant Fancies,
 12837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Madnesse, for testimonies of Gods Spirit; or out of ambition,
 12838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretend to such Divine testimonies, falsely, and contrary to their
 12839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town consciences,) it were impossible that any Divine Law should be
 12840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledged. If publique, it is the Authority of the Common-wealth, or
 12841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Church. But the Church, if it be one person, is the same thing
 12842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith a Common-wealth of Christians; called a Common-wealth, because it
 12843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsisteth of men united in one person, their Soveraign; and a Church,
 12844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause it consisteth in Christian men, united in one Christian
 12845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign. But if the Church be not one person, then it hath no
 12846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority at all; it can neither command, nor doe any action at all; nor
 12847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis capable of having any power, or right to any thing; nor has any Will,
 12848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason, nor Voice; for all these qualities are personall. Now if the
 12849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhole number of Christians be not contained in one Common-wealth, they
 12850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not one person; nor is there an Universall Church that hath any
 12851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority over them; and therefore the Scriptures are not made Laws,
 12852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Universall Church: or if it bee one Common-wealth, then all
 12853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Monarchs, and States are private persons, and subject to
 12854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee judged, deposed, and punished by an Universall Soveraigne of all
 12855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristendome. So that the question of the Authority of the Scriptures is
 12856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treduced to this, "Whether Christian Kings, and the Soveraigne Assemblies
 12857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Christian Common-wealths, be absolute in their own Territories,
 12858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timmediately under God; or subject to one Vicar of Christ, constituted
 12859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover the Universall Church; to bee judged, condemned, deposed, and put
 12860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto death, as hee shall think expedient, or necessary for the common
 12861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood."
 12862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhich question cannot bee resolved, without a more particular
 12864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsideration of the Kingdome of God; from whence also, wee are to judge
 12865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Authority of Interpreting the Scripture. For, whosoever hath a
 12866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfull power over any Writing, to make it Law, hath the power also to
 12867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapprove, or disapprove the interpretation of the same.
 12868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXXIV. OF THE SIGNIFICATION OF SPIRIT, ANGEL, AND INSPIRATION IN
 12872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTHE BOOKS OF HOLY SCRIPTURE
 12873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBody And Spirit How Taken In The Scripture
 12878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing the foundation of all true Ratiocination, is the constant
 12880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSignification of words; which in the Doctrine following, dependeth not
 12881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as in naturall science) on the Will of the Writer, nor (as in common
 12882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconversation) on vulgar use, but on the sense they carry in the
 12883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture; It is necessary, before I proceed any further, to determine,
 12884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of the Bible, the meaning of such words, as by their ambiguity, may
 12885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trender what I am to inferre upon them, obscure, or disputable. I will
 12886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbegin with the words BODY, and SPIRIT, which in the language of the
 12887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSchools are termed, Substances, Corporeall, and Incorporeall.
 12888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Word Body, in the most generall acceptation, signifieth that
 12890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich filleth, or occupyeth some certain room, or imagined place; and
 12891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdependeth not on the imagination, but is a reall part of that we call
 12892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Universe. For the Universe, being the Aggregate of all Bodies, there
 12893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis no reall part thereof that is not also Body; nor any thing properly
 12894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Body, that is not also part of (that Aggregate of all Bodies) the
 12895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUniverse. The same also, because Bodies are subject to change, that is
 12896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, to variety of apparence to the sense of living creatures, is
 12897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Substance, that is to say, Subject, to various accidents, as
 12898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes to be Moved, sometimes to stand Still; and to seem to our
 12899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsenses sometimes Hot, sometimes Cold, sometimes of one Colour, Smel,
 12900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTast, or Sound, somtimes of another. And this diversity of Seeming,
 12901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(produced by the diversity of the operation of bodies, on the organs
 12902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof our sense) we attribute to alterations of the Bodies that operate, &
 12903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcall them Accidents of those Bodies. And according to this acceptation
 12904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the word, Substance and Body, signifie the same thing; and therefore
 12905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubstance Incorporeall are words, which when they are joined together,
 12906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdestroy one another, as if a man should say, an Incorporeall Body.
 12907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut in the sense of common people, not all the Universe is called Body,
 12909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut only such parts thereof as they can discern by the sense of Feeling,
 12910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto resist their force, or by the sense of their Eyes, to hinder them
 12911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom a farther prospect. Therefore in the common language of men, Aire,
 12912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Aeriall Substances, use not to be taken for Bodies, but (as often
 12913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas men are sensible of their effects) are called Wind, or Breath, or
 12914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(because the some are called in the Latine Spiritus) Spirits; as when
 12915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey call that aeriall substance, which in the body of any living
 12916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcreature, gives it life and motion, Vitall and Animall Spirits. But for
 12917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Idols of the brain, which represent Bodies to us, where they
 12918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not, as in a Looking-glasse, in a Dream, or to a Distempered brain
 12919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twaking, they are (as the Apostle saith generally of all Idols) nothing;
 12920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNothing at all, I say, there where they seem to bee; and in the brain
 12921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit self, nothing but tumult, proceeding either from the action of the
 12922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobjects, or from the disorderly agitation of the Organs of our Sense.
 12923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd men, that are otherwise imployed, then to search into their causes,
 12924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow not of themselves, what to call them; and may therefore easily be
 12925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperswaded, by those whose knowledge they much reverence, some to
 12926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcall them Bodies, and think them made of aire compacted by a power
 12927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall, because the sight judges them corporeall; and some to
 12928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcall them Spirits, because the sense of Touch discerneth nothing in the
 12929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace where they appear, to resist their fingers: So that the proper
 12930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignification of Spirit in common speech, is either a subtile, fluid,
 12931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand invisible Body, or a Ghost, or other Idol or Phantasme of the
 12932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImagination. But for metaphoricall significations, there be many: for
 12933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes it is taken for Disposition or Inclination of the mind; as
 12934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen for the disposition to controwl the sayings of other men, we say,
 12935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Spirit Contradiction; For A Disposition to Uncleannesse, An Unclean
 12936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit; for Perversenesse, A Froward Spirit; for Sullennesse, A Dumb
 12937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit, and for Inclination To Godlinesse, And Gods Service, the Spirit
 12938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God: sometimes for any eminent ability, or extraordinary passion,
 12939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor disease of the mind, as when Great Wisdome is called the Spirit Of
 12940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWisdome; and Mad Men are said to be Possessed With A Spirit.
 12941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOther signification of Spirit I find no where any; and where none
 12943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof these can satisfie the sense of that word in Scripture, the place
 12944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfalleth not under humane Understanding; and our Faith therein consisteth
 12945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot in our Opinion, but in our Submission; as in all places where God
 12946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis said to be a Spirit; or where by the Spirit of God, is meant God
 12947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe. For the nature of God is incomprehensible; that is to say, we
 12948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstand nothing of What He Is, but only That He Is; and therefore the
 12949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAttributes we give him, are not to tell one another, What He Is, Nor
 12950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto signifie our opinion of his Nature, but our desire to honor him with
 12951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch names as we conceive most honorable amongst our selves.
 12952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit Of God Taken In The Scripture Sometimes For A Wind, Or Breath
 12957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGen. 1. 2. "The Spirit of God moved upon the face of the Waters." Here
 12959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif by the Spirit of God be meant God himself, then is Motion attributed
 12960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto God, and consequently Place, which are intelligible only of Bodies,
 12961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand not of substances incorporeall; and so the place is above our
 12962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstanding, that can conceive nothing moved that changes not place,
 12963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor that has not dimension; and whatsoever has dimension, is Body. But
 12964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe meaning of those words is best understood by the like place, Gen.
 12965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t8. 1. Where when the earth was covered with Waters, as in the beginning,
 12966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod intending to abate them, and again to discover the dry land, useth
 12967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike words, "I will bring my Spirit upon the Earth, and the waters shall
 12968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe diminished:" in which place by Spirit is understood a Wind, (that is
 12969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Aire or Spirit Moved,) which might be called (as in the former place)
 12970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Spirit of God, because it was Gods Work.
 12971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, For Extraordinary Gifts Of The Understanding
 12976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGen. 41. 38. Pharaoh calleth the Wisdome of Joseph, the Spirit of God.
 12978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor Joseph having advised him to look out a wise and discreet man, and
 12979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto set him over the land of Egypt, he saith thus, "Can we find such a
 12980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman as this is, in whom is the Spirit of God?" and Exod. 28.3. "Thou
 12981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshalt speak (saith God) to all that are wise hearted, whom I have filled
 12982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the Spirit of Wisdome, to make Aaron Garments, to consecrate him."
 12983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhere extraordinary Understanding, though but in making Garments, as
 12984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing the Gift of God, is called the Spirit of God. The same is found
 12985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain, Exod. 31.3,4,5,6. and 35.31. And Isaiah 11.2,3. where the Prophet
 12986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeaking of the Messiah, saith, "The Spirit of the Lord shall abide upon
 12987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, the Spirit of wisdome and understanding, the Spirit of counsell,
 12988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand fortitude; and the Spirit of the fear of the Lord." Where manifestly
 12989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis meant, not so many Ghosts, but so many eminent Graces that God would
 12990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive him.
 12991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, For Extraordinary Affections
 12996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 12997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the Book of Judges, an extraordinary Zeal, and Courage in the
 12998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdefence of Gods people, is called the Spirit of God; as when it excited
 12999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOthoniel, Gideon, Jeptha, and Samson to deliver them from servitude,
 13000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudg. 3.10. 6.34. 11.29. 13.25. 14.6,19. And of Saul, upon the newes of
 13001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe insolence of the Ammonites towards the men of Jabeth Gilead, it is
 13002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid (1 Sam.11.6.) that "The Spirit of God came upon Saul, and his Anger
 13003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(or, as it is in the Latine, His Fury) was kindled greatly." Where it is
 13004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot probable was meant a Ghost, but an extraordinary Zeal to punish the
 13005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcruelty of the Ammonites. In like manner by the Spirit of God, that came
 13006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon Saul, when hee was amongst the Prophets that praised God in Songs,
 13007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Musick (1 Sam.19.20.) is to be understood, not a Ghost, but an
 13008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunexpected and sudden Zeal to join with them in their devotions.
 13009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, For The Gift Of Prediction By Dreams And Visions
 13014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe false Prophet Zedekiah, saith to Micaiah (1 Kings 22.24.) "Which way
 13016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twent the Spirit of the Lord from me to speak to thee?" Which cannot be
 13017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood of a Ghost; for Micaiah declared before the Kings of Israel
 13018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Judah, the event of the battle, as from a Vision, and not as from a
 13019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit, speaking in him.
 13020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the same manner it appeareth, in the Books of the Prophets, that
 13022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough they spake by the Spirit of God, that is to say, by a speciall
 13023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrace of Prediction; yet their knowledge of the future, was not by a
 13024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGhost within them, but by some supernaturall Dream or Vision.
 13025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFiftly, For Life
 13030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGen. 2.7. It is said, "God made man of the dust of the Earth, and
 13032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbreathed into his nostrills (spiraculum vitae) the breath of life, and
 13033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman was made a living soul." There the Breath of Life inspired by God,
 13034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifies no more, but that God gave him life; And (Job 27.3.) "as long
 13035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas the Spirit of God is in my nostrils;" is no more then to say, "as
 13036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlong as I live." So in Ezek. 1.20. "the Spirit of life was in the
 13037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twheels," is equivalent to, "the wheels were alive." And (Ezek. 2.30.)
 13038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"the spirit entred into me, and set me on my feet," that is, "I
 13039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trecovered my vitall strength;" not that any Ghost, or incorporeal
 13040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubstance entred into, and possessed his body.
 13041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSixtly, For A Subordination To Authority
 13046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the 11 chap. of Numbers. verse 17. "I will take (saith God) of the
 13048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit, which is upon thee, and will put it upon them, and they shall
 13049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbear the burthen of the people with thee;" that is, upon the seventy
 13050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tElders: whereupon two of the seventy are said to prophecy in the campe;
 13051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof whom some complained, and Joshua desired Moses to forbid them; which
 13052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses would not doe. Whereby it appears; that Joshua knew not they had
 13053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceived authority so to do, and prophecyed according to the mind of
 13054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses, that is to say, by a Spirit, or Authority subordinate to his own.
 13055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the like sense we read (Deut. 34.9.) that "Joshua was full of the
 13057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit of wisdome," because Moses had laid his hands upon him: that is,
 13058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause he was Ordained by Moses, to prosecute the work hee had himselfe
 13059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbegun, (namely, the bringing of Gods people into the promised land), but
 13060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprevented by death, could not finish.
 13061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the like sense it is said, (Rom. 8.9.) "If any man have not the
 13063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit of Christ, he is none of his:" not meaning thereby the Ghost of
 13064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, but a Submission to his Doctrine. As also (1 John 4.2.) "Hereby
 13065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyou shall know the Spirit of God; Every Spirit that confesseth that
 13066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJesus Christ is come in the flesh, is of God;" by which is meant the
 13067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit of unfained Christianity, or Submission to that main Article of
 13068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian faith, that Jesus is the Christ; which cannot be interpreted
 13069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Ghost.
 13070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLikewise these words (Luke 4.1.) "And Jesus full of the Holy Ghost"
 13072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(that is, as it is exprest, Mat. 4.1. and Mar. 1.12. "of the Holy
 13073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit",) may be understood, for Zeal to doe the work for which hee was
 13074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsent by God the Father: but to interpret it of a Ghost, is to say, that
 13075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod himselfe (for so our Saviour was,) was filled with God; which is
 13076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery unproper, and unsignificant. How we came to translate Spirits, by
 13077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe word Ghosts, which signifieth nothing, neither in heaven, nor earth,
 13078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the Imaginary inhabitants of mans brain, I examine not: but this I
 13079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, the word Spirit in the text signifieth no such thing; but either
 13080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproperly a reall Substance, or Metaphorically, some extraordinary
 13081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbility of Affection of the Mind, or of the Body.
 13082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeventhly, For Aeriall Bodies
 13087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Disciples of Christ, seeing him walking upon the sea, (Mat. 14.26.
 13089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Marke 6.49.) supposed him to be a Spirit, meaning thereby an Aeriall
 13090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBody, and not a Phantasme: for it is said, they all saw him; which
 13091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot be understood of the delusions of the brain, (which are not
 13092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommon to many at once, as visible Bodies are; but singular, because of
 13093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe differences of Fancies), but of Bodies only. In like manner, where
 13094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the was taken for a Spirit, by the same Apostles (Luke 24.3,7.): So also
 13095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Acts 12.15) when St. Peter was delivered out of Prison, it would not
 13096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe beleeved; but when the Maid said he was at the dore, they said it
 13097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas his Angel; by which must be meant a corporeall substance, or we must
 13098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, the Disciples themselves did follow the common opinion of both Jews
 13099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Gentiles, that some such apparitions were not Imaginary, but Reall;
 13100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand such as needed not the fancy of man for their Existence: These the
 13101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJews called Spirits, and Angels, Good or Bad; as the Greeks called the
 13102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame by the name of Daemons. And some such apparitions may be reall, and
 13103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubstantiall; that is to say, subtile Bodies, which God can form by
 13104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same power, by which he formed all things, and make use of, as of
 13105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters, and Messengers (that is to say, Angels) to declare his
 13106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill, and execute the same when he pleaseth, in extraordinary and
 13107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall manner. But when hee hath so formed them they are
 13108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubstances, endued with dimensions, and take up roome, and can be moved
 13109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom place to place, which is peculiar to Bodies; and therefore are not
 13110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGhosts Incorporeall, that is to say, Ghosts that are in No Place;
 13111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, that are No Where; that is to say, that seeming to be
 13112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSomewhat, are Nothing. But if corporeall be taken in the most vulgar
 13113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner, for such Substances as are perceptible by our externall Senses;
 13114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen is Substance Incorporeall, a thing not Imaginary, but Reall;
 13115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnamely, a thin Substance Invisible, but that hath the same dimensions
 13116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat are in grosser Bodies.
 13117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAngel What
 13122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy the name of ANGEL, is signified generally, a Messenger; and most
 13124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toften, a Messenger of God: And by a Messenger of God, is signified, any
 13125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing that makes known his extraordinary Presence; that is to say, the
 13126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textraordinary manifestation of his power, especially by a Dream, or
 13127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVision.
 13128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConcerning the creation of Angels, there is nothing delivered in the
 13130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScriptures. That they are Spirits, is often repeated: but by the name of
 13131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit, is signified both in Scripture, and vulgarly, both amongst Jews,
 13132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Gentiles, sometimes thin Bodies; as the Aire, the Wind, the Spirits
 13133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVitall, and Animall, of living creatures; and sometimes the Images
 13134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat rise in the fancy in Dreams, and Visions; which are not reall
 13135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubstances, but accidents of the brain; yet when God raiseth them
 13136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturally, to signifie his Will, they are not unproperly termed
 13137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods Messengers, that is to say, his Angels.
 13138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as the Gentiles did vulgarly conceive the Imagery of the brain, for
 13140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings really subsistent without them, and not dependent on the fancy;
 13141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand out of them framed their opinions of Daemons, Good and Evill; which
 13142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause they seemed to subsist really, they called Substances; and
 13143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause they could not feel them with their hands, Incorporeall: so also
 13144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Jews upon the same ground, without any thing in the Old Testament
 13145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat constrained them thereunto, had generally an opinion, (except the
 13146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsect of the Sadduces,) that those apparitions (which it pleased God
 13147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes to produce in the fancie of men, for his own service, and
 13148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore called them his Angels) were substances, not dependent on the
 13149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfancy, but permanent creatures of God; whereof those which they thought
 13150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere good to them, they esteemed the Angels of God, and those they
 13151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought would hurt them, they called Evill Angels, or Evill Spirits;
 13152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as was the Spirit of Python, and the Spirits of Mad-men, of
 13153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLunatiques, and Epileptiques: For they esteemed such as were troubled
 13154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith such diseases, Daemoniaques.
 13155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut if we consider the places of the Old Testament where Angels are
 13157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmentioned, we shall find, that in most of them, there can nothing else
 13158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe understood by the word Angel, but some image raised (supernaturally)
 13159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the fancy, to signifie the presence of God in the execution of some
 13160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall work; and therefore in the rest, where their nature is not
 13161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texprest, it may be understood in the same manner.
 13162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor we read Gen. 16. that the same apparition is called, not onely an
 13164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAngel, but God; where that which (verse 7.) is called the Angel of
 13165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Lord, in the tenth verse, saith to Agar, "I will multiply thy seed
 13166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texceedingly;" that is, speaketh in the person of God. Neither was this
 13167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapparition a Fancy figured, but a Voice. By which it is manifest,
 13168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Angel signifieth there, nothing but God himself, that caused Agar
 13169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturally to apprehend a voice supernaturall, testifying Gods
 13170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeciall presence there. Why therefore may not the Angels that appeared
 13171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Lot, and are called Gen. 19.13. Men; and to whom, though they were
 13172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut two, Lot speaketh (ver. 18.) as but one, and that one, as God, (for
 13173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe words are, "Lot said unto them, Oh not so my Lord") be understood of
 13174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timages of men, supernaturally formed in the Fancy; as well as before by
 13175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAngel was understood a fancyed Voice? When the Angel called to Abraham
 13176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of heaven, to stay his hand (Gen. 22.11.) from slaying Isaac, there
 13177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas no Apparition, but a Voice; which neverthelesse was called properly
 13178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenough a Messenger, or Angel of God, because it declared Gods will
 13179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturally, and saves the labour of supposing any permanent Ghosts.
 13180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Angels which Jacob saw on the Ladder of Heaven (Gen. 28.12.) were
 13181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Vision of his sleep; therefore onely Fancy, and a Dream; yet being
 13182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall, and signs of Gods Speciall presence, those apparitions
 13183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not improperly called Angels. The same is to be understood
 13184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Gen.31.11.) where Jacob saith thus, "The Angel of the Lord appeared to
 13185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmee in my sleep." For an apparition made to a man in his sleep, is
 13186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which all men call a Dreame, whether such Dreame be naturall, or
 13187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall: and that which there Jacob calleth an Angel, was God
 13188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe; for the same Angel saith (verse 13.) "I am the God of Bethel."
 13189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso (Exod.14.9.) the Angel that went before the Army of Israel to the
 13191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRed Sea, and then came behind it, is (verse 19.) the Lord himself; and
 13192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the appeared not in the form of a beautifull man, but in form (by day)
 13193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Pillar Of Cloud and (by night) in form of a Pillar Of Fire; and yet
 13194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Pillar was all the apparition, and Angel promised to Moses (Exod.
 13195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t14.9.) for the Armies guide: For this cloudy pillar, is said, to have
 13196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdescended, and stood at the dore of the Tabernacle, and to have talked
 13197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith Moses.
 13198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere you see Motion, and Speech, which are commonly attributed to
 13200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAngels, attributed to a Cloud, because the Cloud served as a sign of
 13201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods presence; and was no lesse an Angel, then if it had had the form of
 13202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Man, or Child of never so great beauty; or Wings, as usually they are
 13203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpainted, for the false instruction of common people. For it is not the
 13204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshape; but their use, that makes them Angels. But their use is to be
 13205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifications of Gods presence in supernaturall operations; As when
 13206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses (Exod. 33.14.) had desired God to goe along with the Campe, (as
 13207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the had done alwaies before the making of the Golden Calfe,) God did not
 13208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanswer, "I will goe," nor "I will send an Angel in my stead;" but thus,
 13209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"my presence shall goe with thee."
 13210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo mention all the places of the Old Testament where the name of Angel
 13212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis found, would be too long. Therefore to comprehend them all at once,
 13213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI say, there is no text in that part of the Old Testament, which the
 13214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch of England holdeth for Canonicall, from which we can conclude,
 13215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is, or hath been created, any permanent thing (understood by the
 13216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of Spirit or Angel,) that hath not quantity; and that may not be,
 13217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the understanding divided; that is to say, considered by parts; so
 13218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas one part may bee in one place, and the next part in the next place
 13219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto it; and, in summe, which is not (taking Body for that, which is some
 13220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat, or some where) Corporeall; but in every place, the sense will bear
 13221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe interpretation of Angel, for Messenger; as John Baptist is called
 13222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Angel, and Christ the Angel of the Covenant; and as (according to the
 13223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame Analogy) the Dove, and the Fiery Tongues, in that they were signes
 13224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Gods speciall presence, might also be called Angels. Though we find
 13225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Daniel two names of Angels, Gabriel, and Michael; yet is cleer out of
 13226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe text it selfe, (Dan. 12.1) that by Michael is meant Christ, not as
 13227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Angel, but as a Prince: and that Gabriel (as the like apparitions
 13228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade to other holy men in their sleep) was nothing but a supernaturall
 13229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tphantasme, by which it seemed to Daniel, in his dream, that two Saints
 13230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing in talke, one of them said to the other, "Gabriel, let us make
 13231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis man understand his Vision:" For God needeth not, to distinguish
 13232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Celestiall servants by names, which are usefull onely to the short
 13233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmemories of Mortalls. Nor in the New Testament is there any place, out
 13234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof which it can be proved, that Angels (except when they are put for
 13235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch men, as God hath made the Messengers, and Ministers of his word,
 13236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor works) are things permanent, and withall incorporeall. That they
 13237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare permanent, may bee gathered from the words of our Saviour himselfe,
 13238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Mat. 25.41.) where he saith, it shall be said to the wicked in the last
 13239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tday, "Go ye cursed into everlasting fire prepared for the Devil and his
 13240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAngels:" which place is manifest for the permanence of Evill Angels,
 13241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(unlesse wee might think the name of Devill and his Angels may be
 13242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood of the Churches Adversaries and their Ministers;) but then
 13243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is repugnant to their Immateriality; because Everlasting fire is no
 13244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunishment to impatible substances, such as are all things Incorporeall.
 13245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAngels therefore are not thence proved to be Incorporeall. In like
 13246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner where St. Paul sayes (1 Cor. 6.3.) "Knew ye not that wee shall
 13247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudge the Angels?" And (2 Pet. 2.4.) "For if God spared not the Angels
 13248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat sinned, but cast them down into Hell." And (Jude 1,6.) "And the
 13249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAngels that kept not their first estate, but left their owne habitation,
 13250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee hath reserved in everlasting chaines under darknesse unto the
 13251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgement of the last day;" though it prove the Permanence of Angelicall
 13252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnature, it confirmeth also their Materiality. And (Mat. 22.30.) In the
 13253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tresurrection men doe neither marry, nor give in marriage, but are as
 13254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Angels of God in heaven:" but in the resurrection men shall be
 13255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPermanent, and not Incorporeall; so therefore also are the Angels.
 13256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere be divers other places out of which may be drawn the like
 13258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconclusion. To men that understand the signification of these words,
 13259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubstance, and Incorporeall; as Incorporeall is taken not for subtile
 13260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbody, but for Not Body, they imply a contradiction: insomuch as to say,
 13261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Angel, or Spirit is (in that sense) an Incorporeall Substance, is
 13262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say in effect, there is no Angel nor Spirit at all. Considering
 13263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore the signification of the word Angel in the Old Testament, and
 13264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe nature of Dreams and Visions that happen to men by the ordinary way
 13265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Nature; I was enclined to this opinion, that Angels were nothing
 13266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut supernaturall apparitions of the Fancy, raised by the speciall
 13267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand extraordinary operation of God, thereby to make his presence and
 13268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommandements known to mankind, and chiefly to his own people. But the
 13269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany places of the New Testament, and our Saviours own words, and in
 13270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch texts, wherein is no suspicion of corruption of the Scripture, have
 13271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textorted from my feeble Reason, an acknowledgement, and beleef, that
 13272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere be also Angels substantiall, and permanent. But to beleeve they be
 13273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin no place, that is to say, no where, that is to say, nothing, as they
 13274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(though indirectly) say, that will have them Incorporeall, cannot by
 13275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture bee evinced.
 13276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInspiration What
 13281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOn the signification of the word Spirit, dependeth that of the word
 13283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tINSPIRATION; which must either be taken properly; and then it is nothing
 13284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the blowing into a man some thin and subtile aire, or wind, in such
 13285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner as a man filleth a bladder with his breath; or if Spirits be not
 13286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcorporeal, but have their existence only in the fancy, it is nothing but
 13287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe blowing in of a Phantasme; which is improper to say, and impossible;
 13288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Phantasmes are not, but only seem to be somewhat. That word
 13289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore is used in the Scripture metaphorically onely: As (Gen. 2.7.)
 13290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere it is said, that God Inspired into man the breath of life, no more
 13291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis meant, then that God gave unto him vitall motion. For we are not to
 13292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthink that God made first a living breath, and then blew it into Adam
 13293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter he was made, whether that breath were reall, or seeming; but only
 13294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas it is (Acts 17.25.) "that he gave him life and breath;" that is,
 13295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade him a living creature. And where it is said (2 Tim. 3.16.) "all
 13296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture is given by Inspiration from God," speaking there of the
 13297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture of the Old Testament, it is an easie metaphor, to signifie,
 13298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat God enclined the spirit or mind of those Writers, to write that
 13299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich should be usefull, in teaching, reproving, correcting, and
 13300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinstructing men in the way of righteous living. But where St. Peter (2
 13301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPet. 1.21.) saith, that "Prophecy came not in old time by the will
 13302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof man, but the holy men of God spake as they were moved by the Holy
 13303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit," by the Holy Spirit, is meant the voice of God in a Dream, or
 13304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVision supernaturall, which is not Inspiration; Nor when our Saviour
 13305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbreathing on his Disciples, said, "Receive the Holy Spirit," was that
 13306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBreath the Spirit, but a sign of the spirituall graces he gave unto
 13307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem. And though it be said of many, and of our Saviour himself, that he
 13308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas full of the Holy Spirit; yet that Fulnesse is not to be understood
 13309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Infusion of the substance of God, but for accumulation of his gifts,
 13310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as are the gift of sanctity of life, of tongues, and the like,
 13311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhether attained supernaturally, or by study and industry; for in all
 13312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcases they are the gifts of God. So likewise where God sayes (Joel
 13313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2.28.) "I will powre out my Spirit upon all flesh, and your Sons and
 13314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyour Daughters shall prophecy, your Old men shall dream Dreams, and your
 13315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tYoung men shall see Visions," wee are not to understand it in the
 13316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproper sense, as if his Spirit were like water, subject to effusion, or
 13317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinfusion; but as if God had promised to give them Propheticall Dreams,
 13318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Visions. For the proper use of the word Infused, in speaking of
 13319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe graces of God, is an abuse of it; for those graces are Vertues, not
 13320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBodies to be carryed hither and thither, and to be powred into men, as
 13321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto barrels.
 13322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the same manner, to take Inspiration in the proper sense, or to
 13324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay that Good Spirits entred into men to make them prophecy, or Evill
 13325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirits into those that became Phrenetique, Lunatique, or Epileptique,
 13326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not to take the word in the sense of the Scripture; for the Spirit
 13327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is taken for the power of God, working by causes to us unknown. As
 13328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso (Acts 2.2.) the wind, that is there said to fill the house wherein
 13329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Apostles were assembled on the day of Pentecost, is not to be
 13330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood for the Holy Spirit, which is the Deity it self; but for an
 13331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExternall sign of Gods speciall working on their hearts, to effect in
 13332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem the internall graces, and holy vertues hee thought requisite for
 13333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe performance of their Apostleship.
 13334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXXV. OF THE SIGNIFICATION IN SCRIPTURE OF KINGDOME OF GOD, OF
 13338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHOLY, SACRED, AND SACRAMENT
 13339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdom Of God Taken By Divines Metaphorically But In The Scriptures
 13344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProperly
 13346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Kingdome of God in the Writings of Divines, and specially in
 13348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSermons, and Treatises of Devotion, is taken most commonly for Eternall
 13349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFelicity, after this life, in the Highest Heaven, which they also call
 13350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Kingdome of Glory; and sometimes for (the earnest of that felicity)
 13351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSanctification, which they terme the Kingdome of Grace, but never
 13352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the Monarchy, that is to say, the Soveraign Power of God over
 13353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany Subjects acquired by their own consent, which is the proper
 13354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignification of Kingdome.
 13355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo the contrary, I find the KINGDOME OF GOD, to signifie in most places
 13357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Scripture, a Kingdome Properly So Named, constituted by the Votes
 13358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the People of Israel in peculiar manner; wherein they chose God
 13359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor their King by Covenant made with him, upon Gods promising them the
 13360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossession of the land of Canaan; and but seldom metaphorically;
 13361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand then it is taken for Dominion Over Sinne; (and only in the New
 13362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestament;) because such a Dominion as that, every Subject shall have in
 13363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Kingdome of God, and without prejudice to the Soveraign.
 13364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom the very Creation, God not only reigned over all men Naturally by
 13366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this might; but also had Peculiar Subjects, whom he commanded by a Voice,
 13367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas one man speaketh to another. In which manner he Reigned over Adam,
 13368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand gave him commandement to abstaine from the tree of cognizance of
 13369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood and Evill; which when he obeyed not, but tasting thereof, took upon
 13370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim to be as God, judging between Good and Evill, not by his Creators
 13371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommandement, but by his own sense, his punishment was a privation of
 13372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe estate of Eternall life, wherein God had at first created him: And
 13373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafterwards God punished his posterity, for their vices, all but eight
 13374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpersons, with an universall deluge; And in these eight did consist the
 13375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen Kingdome Of God.
 13376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Originall Of The Kingdome Of God
 13381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter this, it pleased God to speak to Abraham, and (Gen. 17.7,8.) to
 13383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake a Covenant with him in these words, "I will establish my Covenant
 13384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetween me, and thee, and thy seed after thee in their generations,
 13385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor an everlasting Covenant, to be a God to thee, and to thy seed after
 13386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthee; And I will give unto thee, and to thy seed after thee, the land
 13387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twherein thou art a stranger, all the land of Canaan for an everlasting
 13388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossession." And for a memoriall, and a token of this Covenant, he
 13389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordaineth (verse 11.) the Sacrament of Circumcision. This is it which is
 13390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled the Old Covenant, or Testament; and containeth a Contract between
 13391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod and Abraham; by which Abraham obligeth himself, and his posterity,
 13392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin a peculiar manner to be subject to Gods positive Law; for to the Law
 13393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMorall he was obliged before, as by an Oath of Allegiance. And though
 13394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe name of King be not yet given to God, nor of Kingdome to Abraham and
 13395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this seed; yet the thing is the same; namely, an Institution by pact,
 13396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Gods peculiar Soveraignty over the seed of Abraham; which in the
 13397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trenewing of the same Covenant by Moses, at Mount Sinai, is expressely
 13398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled a peculiar Kingdome of God over the Jews: and it is of Abraham
 13399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(not of Moses) St. Paul saith (Rom. 4.11.) that he is the "Father of the
 13400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaithfull," that is, of those that are loyall, and doe not violate their
 13401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAllegiance sworn to God, then by Circumcision, and afterwards in the New
 13402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant by Baptisme.
 13403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat The Kingdome Of God Is Properly His Civill Soveraignty Over
 13408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Peculiar People By Pact
 13410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis Covenant, at the Foot of Mount Sinai, was renewed by Moses (Exod.
 13412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t19.5.) where the Lord commandeth Moses to speak to the people in this
 13413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner, "If you will obey my voice indeed, and keep my Covenant, then
 13414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyee shall be a peculiar people to me, for all the Earth is mine; and
 13415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyee shall be unto me a Sacerdotall Kingdome, and an holy Nation." For a
 13416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Peculiar people" the vulgar Latine hath, Peculium De Cunctis Populis:
 13417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe English translation made in the beginning of the Reign of King
 13418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJames, hath, a "Peculiar treasure unto me above all Nations;" and the
 13419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGeneva French, "the most precious Jewel of all Nations." But the truest
 13420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTranslation is the first, because it is confirmed by St. Paul himself
 13421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Tit. 2.14.) where he saith, alluding to that place, that our blessed
 13422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour "gave himself for us, that he might purifie us to himself, a
 13423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeculiar (that is, an extraordinary) people:" for the word is in the
 13424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGreek periousios, which is opposed commonly to the word epiousios: and
 13425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas this signifieth Ordinary, Quotidian, or (as in the Lords Prayer) Of
 13426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDaily Use; so the other signifieth that which is Overplus, and Stored
 13427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUp, and Enjoyed In A Speciall Manner; which the Latines call Peculium;
 13428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand this meaning of the place is confirmed by the reason God rendereth
 13429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof it, which followeth immediately, in that he addeth, "For all the
 13430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarth is mine," as if he should say, "All the Nations of the world are
 13431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmine;" but it is not so that you are mine, but in a Speciall Manner: For
 13432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are all mine, by reason of my Power; but you shall be mine, by your
 13433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town Consent, and Covenant; which is an addition to his ordinary title,
 13434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto all nations.
 13435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe same is again confirmed in expresse words in the same Text, "Yee
 13437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be to me a Sacerdotall Kingdome, and an holy Nation." The Vulgar
 13438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLatine hath it, Regnum Sacerdotale, to which agreeth the Translation of
 13439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat place (1 Pet. 2.9.) Sacerdotium Regale, A Regal Priesthood; as also
 13440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Institution it self, by which no man might enter into the Sanctum
 13441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSanctorum, that is to say, no man might enquire Gods will immediately of
 13442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod himselfe, but onely the High Priest. The English Translation before
 13443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmentioned, following that of Geneva, has, "a Kingdome of Priests;" which
 13444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis either meant of the succession of one High Priest after another, or
 13445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\telse it accordeth not with St. Peter, nor with the exercise of the High
 13446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriesthood; For there was never any but the High Priest onely, that was
 13447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto informe the People of Gods Will; nor any Convocation of Priests ever
 13448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallowed to enter into the Sanctum Sanctorum.
 13449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, the title of a Holy Nation confirmes the same: For Holy
 13451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifies, that which is Gods by speciall, not by generall Right. All
 13452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Earth (as is said in the text) is Gods; but all the Earth is
 13453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot called Holy, but that onely which is set apart for his especiall
 13454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tservice, as was the Nation of the Jews. It is therefore manifest enough
 13455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby this one place, that by the Kingdome of God, is properly meant a
 13456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, instituted (by the consent of those which were to be
 13457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject thereto) for their Civill Government, and the regulating of
 13458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir behaviour, not onely towards God their King, but also towards one
 13459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother in point of justice, and towards other Nations both in peace and
 13460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twarre; which properly was a Kingdome, wherein God was King, and the
 13461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHigh priest was to be (after the death of Moses) his sole Viceroy, or
 13462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLieutenant.
 13463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut there be many other places that clearly prove the same. As first (1
 13465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSam. 8.7.) when the Elders of Israel (grieved with the corruption of
 13466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Sons of Samuel) demanded a King, Samuel displeased therewith, prayed
 13467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunto the Lord; and the Lord answering said unto him, "Hearken unto the
 13468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvoice of the People, for they have not rejected thee, but they have
 13469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trejected me, that I should not reign over them." Out of which it is
 13470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevident, that God himself was then their King; and Samuel did not
 13471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommand the people, but only delivered to them that which God from time
 13472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto time appointed him.
 13473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, (1 Sam. 12.12.) where Samuel saith to the People, "When yee saw
 13475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Nahash King of the Children of Ammon came against you, ye said unto
 13476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tme, Nay, but a King shall reign over us, when the Lord your God was your
 13477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing:" It is manifest that God was their King, and governed the Civill
 13478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tState of their Common-wealth.
 13479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd after the Israelites had rejected God, the Prophets did foretell his
 13481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trestitution; as (Isaiah 24.23.) "Then the Moon shall be confounded, and
 13482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Sun ashamed when the Lord of Hosts shall reign in Mount Zion, and
 13483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Jerusalem;" where he speaketh expressely of his Reign in Zion, and
 13484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJerusalem; that is, on Earth. And (Micah 4.7.) "And the Lord shall
 13485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treign over them in Mount Zion:" This Mount Zion is in Jerusalem upon the
 13486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarth. And (Ezek. 20.33.) "As I live, saith the Lord God, surely with a
 13487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmighty hand, and a stretched out arme, and with fury powred out, I wil
 13488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trule over you; and (verse 37.) I will cause you to passe under the rod,
 13489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand I will bring you into the bond of the Covenant;" that is, I will
 13490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treign over you, and make you to stand to that Covenant which you made
 13491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith me by Moses, and brake in your rebellion against me in the days of
 13492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSamuel, and in your election of another King.
 13493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd in the New testament, the Angel Gabriel saith of our Saviour (Luke
 13495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t1.32,33) "He shall be great, and be called the Son of the Most High,
 13496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Lord shall give him the throne of his Father David; and he shall
 13497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treign over the house of Jacob for ever; and of his Kingdome there shall
 13498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe no end." This is also a Kingdome upon Earth; for the claim whereof,
 13499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas an enemy to Caesar, he was put to death; the title of his crosse,
 13500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas, Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews; hee was crowned in scorn with
 13501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta crown of Thornes; and for the proclaiming of him, it is said of
 13502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Disciples (Acts 17.7.) "That they did all of them contrary to
 13503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe decrees of Caesar, saying there was another King, one Jesus. The
 13504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome therefore of God, is a reall, not a metaphoricall Kingdome; and
 13505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso taken, not onely in the Old Testament, but the New; when we say, "For
 13506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthine is the Kingdome, the Power, and Glory," it is to be understood of
 13507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods Kingdome, by force of our Covenant, not by the Right of Gods Power;
 13508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor such a Kingdome God alwaies hath; so that it were superfluous to
 13509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay in our prayer, "Thy Kingdome come," unlesse it be meant of the
 13510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRestauration of that Kingdome of God by Christ, which by revolt of the
 13511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsraelites had been interrupted in the election of Saul. Nor had it been
 13512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproper to say, "The Kingdome of Heaven is at hand," or to pray, "Thy
 13513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome come," if it had still continued.
 13514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere be so many other places that confirm this interpretation, that it
 13516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere a wonder there is no greater notice taken of it, but that it gives
 13517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttoo much light to Christian Kings to see their right of Ecclesiastical
 13518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment. This they have observed, that in stead of a Sacerdotall
 13519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome, translate, a Kingdome of Priests: for they may as well
 13520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttranslate a Royall Priesthood, (as it is in St. Peter) into a Priesthood
 13521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Kings. And whereas, for a Peculiar People, they put a Pretious Jewel,
 13522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Treasure, a man might as well call the speciall Regiment, or Company
 13523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Generall, the Generalls pretious Jewel, or his Treasure.
 13524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn short, the Kingdome of God is a Civill Kingdome; which consisted,
 13526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst in the obligation of the people of Israel to those Laws, which
 13527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses should bring unto them from Mount Sinai; and which afterwards the
 13528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHigh Priest of the time being, should deliver to them from before the
 13529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCherubins in the Sanctum Sanctorum; and which kingdome having been cast
 13530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toff, in the election of Saul, the Prophets foretold, should be restored
 13531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Christ; and the Restauration whereof we daily pray for, when we
 13532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay in the Lords Prayer, "Thy Kingdome come;" and the Right whereof we
 13533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledge, when we adde, "For thine is the Kingdome, the Power, and
 13534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGlory, for ever and ever, Amen;" and the Proclaiming whereof, was
 13535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Preaching of the Apostles; and to which men are prepared, by the
 13536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTeachers of the Gospel; to embrace which Gospel, (that is to say, to
 13537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpromise obedience to Gods government) is, to bee in the Kingdome of
 13538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGrace, because God hath gratis given to such the power to bee the
 13539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubjects (that is, Children) of God hereafter, when Christ shall come
 13540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Majesty to judge the world, and actually to govern his owne people,
 13541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is called the Kingdome of Glory. If the Kingdome of God (called
 13542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso the Kingdome of Heaven, from the gloriousnesse, and admirable
 13543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theight of that throne) were not a Kingdome which God by his Lieutenant,
 13544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Vicars, who deliver his Commandements to the people, did exercise on
 13545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarth; there would not have been so much contention, and warre, about
 13546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho it is, by whom God speaketh to us; neither would many Priests have
 13547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttroubled themselves with Spirituall Jurisdiction, nor any King have
 13548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdenied it them.
 13549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOut of this literall interpretation of the Kingdome of God, ariseth also
 13551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe true interpretation of the word HOLY. For it is a word, which in
 13552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods Kingdome answereth to that, which men in their Kingdomes use to
 13553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcall Publique, or the Kings.
 13554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe King of any Countrey is the Publique Person, or Representative of
 13556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall his own Subjects. And God the King of Israel was the Holy One of
 13557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsrael. The Nation which is subject to one earthly Soveraign, is the
 13558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNation of that Soveraign, that is, of the Publique Person. So the Jews,
 13559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho were Gods Nation, were called (Exod. 19.6.) "a Holy Nation." For by
 13560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHoly, is alwaies understood, either God himselfe, or that which is Gods
 13561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin propriety; as by Publique is alwaies meant, either the Person of the
 13562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth it self, or something that is so the Common-wealths, as no
 13563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate person can claim any propriety therein.
 13564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore the Sabbath (Gods day) is a Holy Day; the Temple, (Gods house)
 13566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Holy House; Sacrifices, Tithes, and Offerings (Gods tribute) Holy
 13567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDuties; Priests, Prophets, and anointed Kings, under Christ (Gods
 13568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tministers) Holy Men; The Coelestiall ministring Spirits (Gods
 13569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMessengers) Holy Angels; and the like: and wheresoever the word Holy is
 13570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaken properly, there is still something signified of Propriety, gotten
 13571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby consent. In saying "Hallowed be thy name," we do but pray to God for
 13572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrace to keep the first Commandement, of "having no other Gods but
 13573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHim." Mankind is Gods Nation in propriety: but the Jews only were a Holy
 13574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNation. Why, but because they became his Propriety by covenant.
 13575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSacred What
 13580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd the word Profane, is usually taken in the Scripture for the same
 13582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith Common; and consequently their contraries, Holy, and Proper, in the
 13583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God must be the same also. But figuratively, those men also
 13584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare called Holy, that led such godly lives, as if they had forsaken all
 13585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworldly designes, and wholly devoted, and given themselves to God.
 13586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the proper sense, that which is made Holy by Gods appropriating or
 13587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseparating it to his own use, is said to be Sanctified by God, as the
 13588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeventh day in the fourth Commandement; and as the Elect in the New
 13589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestament were said to bee Sanctified, when they were endued with the
 13590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit of godlinesse. And that which is made Holy by the dedication of
 13591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, and given to God, so as to be used onely in his publique service,
 13592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis called also SACRED, and said to be consecrated, as Temples, and other
 13593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHouses of Publique Prayer, and their Utensils, Priests, and Ministers,
 13594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVictimes, Offerings, and the externall matter of Sacraments.
 13595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDegrees of Sanctity
 13600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Holinesse there be degrees: for of those things that are set apart
 13602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the service of God, there may bee some set apart again, for a neerer
 13603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand more especial service. The whole Nation of the Israelites were a
 13604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople Holy to God; yet the tribe of Levi was amongst the Israelites a
 13605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHoly tribe; and amongst the Levites, the Priests were yet more Holy; and
 13606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst the Priests, the High Priest was the most Holy. So the Land
 13607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Judea was the Holy Land; but the Holy City wherein God was to be
 13608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworshipped, was more Holy; and again, the Temples more Holy than the
 13609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCity; and the Sanctum Sanctorum more Holy than the rest of the Temple.
 13610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSacrament
 13615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA SACRAMENT, is a separation of some visible thing from common use;
 13617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand a consecration of it to Gods service, for a sign, either of our
 13618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadmission into the Kingdome of God, to be of the number of his peculiar
 13619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople, or for a Commemoration of the same. In the Old Testament, the
 13620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsign of Admission was Circumcision; in the New Testament, Baptisme. The
 13621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommemoration of it in the Old Testament, was the Eating (at a certain
 13622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, which was Anniversary) of the Paschall Lamb; by which they were
 13623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tput in mind of the night wherein they were delivered out of their
 13624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbondage in Egypt; and in the New Testament, the celebrating of the
 13625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLords Supper; by which, we are put in mind, of our deliverance from
 13626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe bondage of sin, by our Blessed Saviours death upon the crosse. The
 13627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSacraments of Admission, are but once to be used, because there needs
 13628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut one Admission; but because we have need of being often put in
 13629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmind of our deliverance, and of our Allegeance, The Sacraments of
 13630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommemoration have need to be reiterated. And these are the principall
 13631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSacraments, and as it were the solemne oathes we make of our
 13632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlleageance. There be also other Consecrations, that may be called
 13633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSacraments, as the word implyeth onely Consecration to Gods service; but
 13634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas it implies an oath, or promise of Alleageance to God, there were no
 13635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother in the Old Testament, but Circumcision, and the Passover; nor
 13636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare there any other in the New Testament, but Baptisme, and the Lords
 13637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSupper.
 13638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXXVI. OF THE WORD OF GOD, AND OF PROPHETS
 13642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWord What
 13647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen there is mention of the Word of God, or of Man, it doth not
 13649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifie a part of Speech, such as Grammarians call a Nown, or a Verb,
 13650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor any simple voice, without a contexture with other words to make it
 13651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignificative; but a perfect Speech or Discourse, whereby the speaker
 13652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAffirmeth, Denieth, Commandeth, Promiseth, Threateneth, Wisheth, or
 13653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterrogateth. In which sense it is not Vocabulum, that signifies a
 13654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWord; but Sermo, (in Greek Logos) that is some Speech, Discourse, or
 13655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaying.
 13656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Words Spoken By God And Concerning God, Both Are Called Gods Word
 13661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Scripture
 13663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, if we say the Word of God, or of Man, it may bee understood
 13665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes of the Speaker, (as the words that God hath spoken, or that
 13666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Man hath spoken): In which sense, when we say, the Gospel of St.
