 13667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMatthew, we understand St. Matthew to be the Writer of it: and sometimes
 13668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Subject: In which sense, when we read in the Bible, "The words
 13669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the days of the Kings of Israel, or Judah," 'tis meant, that the acts
 13670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat were done in those days, were the Subject of those Words; And in
 13671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Greek, which (in the Scripture) retaineth many Hebraismes, by the
 13672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWord of God is oftentimes meant, not that which is spoken by God, but
 13673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning God, and his government; that is to say, the Doctrine of
 13674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion: Insomuch, as it is all one, to say Logos Theou, and Theologia;
 13675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is, that Doctrine which wee usually call Divinity, as is manifest
 13676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the places following (Acts 13.46.) "Then Paul and Barnabas waxed
 13677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbold, and said, It was necessary that the Word of God should first
 13678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave been spoken to you, but seeing you put it from you, and judge your
 13679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tselves unworthy of everlasting life, loe, we turn to the Gentiles."
 13680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat which is here called the Word of god, was the Doctrine of Christian
 13681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion; as it appears evidently by that which goes before. And (Acts
 13682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t5.20.) where it is said to the Apostles by an Angel, "Go stand and speak
 13683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Temple, all the Words of this life;" by the Words of this life,
 13684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis meant, the Doctrine of the Gospel; as is evident by what they did in
 13685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Temple, and is expressed in the last verse of the same Chap. "Daily
 13686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Temple, and in every house they ceased not to teach and preach
 13687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist Jesus:" In which place it is manifest, that Jesus Christ was the
 13688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject of this Word of Life; or (which is all one) the subject of the
 13689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWords of this Life Eternall, that our saviour offered them. So (Acts
 13690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t15.7.) the Word of God, is called the Word of the Gospel, because it
 13691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontaineth the Doctrine of the Kingdome of Christ; and the same Word
 13692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Rom. 10.8,9.) is called the Word of Faith; that is, as is there
 13693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpressed, the Doctrine of Christ come, and raised from the dead. Also
 13694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Mat. 13. 19.) "When any one heareth the Word of the Kingdome;" that is,
 13695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Doctrine of the Kingdome taught by Christ. Again, the same Word, is
 13696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid (Acts 12. 24.) "to grow and to be multiplied;" which to understand
 13697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Evangelicall Doctrine is easie, but of the Voice, or Speech
 13698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God, hard and strange. In the same sense the Doctrine of Devils,
 13699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifieth not the Words of any Devill, but the Doctrine of Heathen men
 13700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning Daemons, and those Phantasms which they worshipped as Gods.
 13701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(1 Tim. 4.1.)
 13702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsidering these two significations of the WORD OF GOD, as it is taken
 13704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Scripture, it is manifest in this later sense (where it is taken for
 13705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Doctrine of the Christian Religion,) that the whole scripture is the
 13706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWord of God: but in the former sense not so. For example, though these
 13707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords, "I am the Lord thy God, &c." to the end of the Ten Commandements,
 13708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere spoken by God to Moses; yet the Preface, "God spake these words
 13709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand said," is to be understood for the Words of him that wrote the holy
 13710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHistory. The Word of God, as it is taken for that which he hath spoken,
 13711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis understood sometimes Properly, sometimes Metaphorically. Properly,
 13712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas the words, he hath spoken to his Prophets; Metaphorically, for his
 13713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWisdome, Power, and eternall Decree, in making the world; in which
 13714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense, those Fiats, "Let there be light," "Let there be a firmament,"
 13715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Let us make man," &c. (Gen. 1.) are the Word of God. And in the same
 13716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense it is said (John 1.3.) "All things were made by it, and without it
 13717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas nothing made that was made; And (Heb. 1.3.) "He upholdeth all things
 13718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the word of his Power;" that is, by the Power of his Word; that is,
 13719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby his Power; and (Heb. 11.3.) "The worlds were framed by the Word
 13720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God;" and many other places to the same sense: As also amongst the
 13721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLatines, the name of Fate, which signifieth properly The Word Spoken, is
 13722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaken in the same sense.
 13723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, For The Effect Of His Word
 13728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, for the effect of his Word; that is to say, for the thing it
 13730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tself, which by his Word is Affirmed, Commanded, Threatned, or Promised;
 13731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas (Psalm 105.19.) where Joseph is said to have been kept in prison,
 13732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"till his Word was come;" that is, till that was come to passe which
 13733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the had (Gen. 40.13.) foretold to Pharaohs Butler, concerning his being
 13734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trestored to his office: for there by His Word Was Come, is meant, the
 13735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing it self was come to passe. So also (1 King. 18.36.) Elijah saith
 13736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto God, "I have done all these thy Words," in stead of "I have done all
 13737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese things at thy Word," or commandement: and (Jer. 17.15.) "Where is
 13738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Word of the Lord," is put for, "Where is the Evill he threatened:"
 13739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd (Ezek. 12.28.) "There shall none of my Words be prolonged any
 13740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore:" by "Words" are understood those Things, which God promised to his
 13741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople. And in the New Testament (Mat. 24.35.) "heaven and earth shal
 13742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpass away, but my Words shall not pass away;" that is, there is nothing
 13743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat I have promised or foretold, that shall not come to passe. And in
 13744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis sense it is, that St. John the Evangelist, and, I think, St. John
 13745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely calleth our Saviour himself as in the flesh "the Word of God
 13746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as Joh. 1.14.) the Word was made Flesh;" that is to say, the Word, or
 13747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPromise that Christ should come into the world, "who in the beginning
 13748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas with God;" that is to say, it was in the purpose of God the Father,
 13749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto send God the Son into the world, to enlighten men in the way of
 13750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternall life, but it was not till then put in execution, and actually
 13751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tincarnate; So that our Saviour is there called "the Word," not because
 13752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the was the promise, but the thing promised. They that taking occasion
 13753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom this place, doe commonly call him the Verbe of God, do but render
 13754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe text more obscure. They might as well term him the Nown of God:
 13755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor as by Nown, so also by Verbe, men understand nothing but a part
 13756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof speech, a voice, a sound, that neither affirms, nor denies, nor
 13757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommands, nor promiseth, nor is any substance corporeall, or spirituall;
 13758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore it cannot be said to bee either God, or Man; whereas our
 13759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour is both. And this Word which St. John in his Gospel saith was
 13760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith God, is (in his 1 Epistle, verse 1.) called "the Word of Life;" and
 13761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(verse 2.) "The eternall life, which was with the Father:" so that he
 13762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan be in no other sense called the Word, then in that, wherein he is
 13763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Eternall life; that is, "he that hath procured us Eternall life,"
 13764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby his comming in the flesh. So also (Apocalypse 19.13.) the Apostle
 13765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeaking of Christ, clothed in a garment dipt in bloud, saith; his name
 13766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis "the Word of God;" which is to be understood, as if he had said his
 13767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname had been, "He that was come according to the purpose of God from
 13768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe beginning, and according to his Word and promises delivered by the
 13769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets." So that there is nothing here of the Incarnation of a Word,
 13770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut of the Incarnation of God the Son, therefore called the Word,
 13771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause his Incarnation was the Performance of the Promise; In like
 13772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner as the Holy Ghost is called The Promise. (Acts 1.4. Luke 24.49.)
 13773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, For The Words Of Reason And Equity
 13778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere are also places of the Scripture, where, by the Word of God, is
 13780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignified such Words as are consonant to reason, and equity, though
 13781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspoken sometimes neither by prophet, nor by a holy man. For Pharaoh
 13782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNecho was an Idolator; yet his Words to the good King Josiah, in which
 13783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the advised him by Messengers, not to oppose him in his march against
 13784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCarchemish, are said to have proceeded from the mouth of God; and that
 13785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJosiah not hearkning to them, was slain in the battle; as is to be read
 13786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2 Chron. 35. vers. 21,22,23. It is true, that as the same History is
 13787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trelated in the first book of Esdras, not Pharaoh, but Jeremiah spake
 13788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese words to Josiah, from the mouth of the Lord. But wee are to
 13789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive credit to the Canonicall Scripture, whatsoever be written in the
 13790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApocrypha.
 13791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Word of God, is then also to be taken for the Dictates of reason,
 13793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand equity, when the same is said in the Scriptures to bee written in
 13794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmans heart; as Psalm 36.31. Jerem. 31.33. Deut.30.11, 14. and many other
 13795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike places.
 13796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivers Acceptions Of The Word Prophet
 13801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe name of PROPHET, signifieth in Scripture sometimes Prolocutor; that
 13803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, he that speaketh from God to Man, or from man to God: And sometimes
 13804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPraedictor, or a foreteller of things to come; And sometimes one that
 13805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeaketh incoherently, as men that are distracted. It is most frequently
 13806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tused in the sense of speaking from God to the People. So Moses, Samuel,
 13807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tElijah, Isaiah, Jeremiah, and others were Prophets. And in this sense
 13808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe High Priest was a Prophet, for he only went into the Sanctum
 13809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSanctorum, to enquire of God; and was to declare his answer to the
 13810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople. And therefore when Caiphas said, it was expedient that one man
 13811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould die for the people, St. John saith (chap. 11.51.) that "He spake
 13812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot this of himselfe, but being High Priest that year, he prophesied
 13813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat one man should dye for the nation." Also they that in Christian
 13814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCongregations taught the people, (1 Cor. 14.3.) are said to Prophecy. In
 13815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe like sense it is, that God saith to Moses (Exod. 4.16.) concerning
 13816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAaron, "He shall be thy Spokes-man to the People; and he shall be to
 13817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthee a mouth, and thou shalt be to him in stead of God;" that which here
 13818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Spokesman, is (chap.7.1.) interpreted Prophet; "See (saith God)
 13819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI have made thee a God to Pharaoh, and Aaron thy Brother shall be thy
 13820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphet." In the sense of speaking from man to God, Abraham is called
 13821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Prophet (Genes. 20.7.) where God in a Dream speaketh to Abimelech
 13822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this manner, "Now therefore restore the man his wife, for he is a
 13823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphet, and shall pray for thee;" whereby may be also gathered,
 13824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat the name of Prophet may be given, not unproperly to them that
 13825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Christian Churches, have a Calling to say publique prayers for the
 13826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCongregation. In the same sense, the Prophets that came down from the
 13827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHigh place (or Hill of God) with a Psaltery, and a Tabret, and a Pipe,
 13828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand a Harp (1 Sam. 10.5,6.) and (vers. 10.) Saul amongst them, are said
 13829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Prophecy, in that they praised God, in that manner publiquely. In the
 13830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike sense, is Miriam (Exod. 15.20.) called a Prophetesse. So is it
 13831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso to be taken (1 Cor. 11.4,5.) where St. Paul saith, "Every man that
 13832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprayeth or prophecyeth with his head covered, &c. and every woman that
 13833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprayeth or prophecyeth with her head uncovered: For Prophecy in that
 13834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace, signifieth no more, but praising God in Psalmes, and Holy Songs;
 13835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich women might doe in the Church, though it were not lawfull for them
 13836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto speak to the Congregation. And in this signification it is, that the
 13837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPoets of the Heathen, that composed Hymnes and other sorts of Poems in
 13838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe honor of their Gods, were called Vates (Prophets) as is well enough
 13839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknown by all that are versed in the Books of the Gentiles, and as
 13840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis evident (Tit. 1.12.) where St. Paul saith of the Cretians, that a
 13841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphet of their owne said, they were Liars; not that St. Paul held
 13842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Poets for Prophets, but acknowledgeth that the word Prophet was
 13843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommonly used to signifie them that celebrated the honour of God in
 13844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVerse
 13845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPraediction Of Future Contingents, Not Alwaies Prophecy
 13850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen by Prophecy is meant Praediction, or foretelling of future
 13852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tContingents; not only they were Prophets, who were Gods Spokesmen, and
 13853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforetold those things to others, which God had foretold to them; but
 13854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso all those Imposters, that pretend by the helpe of familiar spirits,
 13855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor by superstitious divination of events past, from false causes, to
 13856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforetell the like events in time to come: of which (as I have declared
 13857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready in the 12. chapter of this Discourse) there be many kinds, who
 13858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgain in the opinion of the common sort of men, a greater reputation
 13859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Prophecy, by one casuall event that may bee but wrested to their
 13860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpurpose, than can be lost again by never so many failings. Prophecy is
 13861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot an art, nor (when it is taken for Praediction) a constant Vocation;
 13862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut an extraordinary, and temporary Employment from God, most often of
 13863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood men, but sometimes also of the Wicked. The woman of Endor, who
 13864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis said to have had a familiar spirit, and thereby to have raised a
 13865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhantasme of Samuel, and foretold Saul his death, was not therefore a
 13866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphetesse; for neither had she any science, whereby she could raise
 13867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch a Phantasme; nor does it appear that God commanded the raising of
 13868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit; but onely guided that Imposture to be a means of Sauls terror and
 13869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscouragement; and by consequent, of the discomfiture, by which he
 13870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfell. And for Incoherent Speech, it was amongst the Gentiles taken for
 13871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone sort of Prophecy, because the Prophets of their Oracles, intoxicated
 13872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith a spirit, or vapour from the cave of the Pythian Oracle at Delphi,
 13873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere for the time really mad, and spake like mad-men; of whose loose
 13874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords a sense might be made to fit any event, in such sort, as all
 13875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbodies are said to be made of Materia prima. In the Scripture I find
 13876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit also so taken (1 Sam. 18. 10.) in these words, "And the Evill spirit
 13877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcame upon Saul, and he Prophecyed in the midst of the house."
 13878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Manner How God Hath Spoken To The Prophets
 13883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd although there be so many significations in Scripture of the word
 13885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphet; yet is that the most frequent, in which it is taken for him,
 13886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto whom God speaketh immediately, that which the Prophet is to say from
 13887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, to some other man, or to the people. And hereupon a question may
 13888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe asked, in what manner God speaketh to such a Prophet. Can it (may some
 13889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay) be properly said, that God hath voice and language, when it cannot
 13890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe properly said, he hath a tongue, or other organs, as a man? The
 13891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphet David argueth thus, "Shall he that made the eye, not see? or he
 13892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat made the ear, not hear?" But this may be spoken, not (as usually) to
 13893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifie Gods nature, but to signifie our intention to honor him. For
 13894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto See, and Hear, are Honorable Attributes, and may be given to God, to
 13895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeclare (as far as our capacity can conceive) his Almighty power. But
 13896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif it were to be taken in the strict, and proper sense, one might argue
 13897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom his making of all parts of mans body, that he had also the same use
 13898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them which we have; which would be many of them so uncomely, as it
 13899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould be the greatest contumely in the world to ascribe them to him.
 13900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore we are to interpret Gods speaking to men immediately, for that
 13901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tway (whatsoever it be), by which God makes them understand his will: And
 13902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe wayes whereby he doth this, are many; and to be sought onely in the
 13903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHoly Scripture: where though many times it be said, that God spake to
 13904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis, and that person, without declaring in what manner; yet there be
 13905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain many places, that deliver also the signes by which they were
 13906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto acknowledge his presence, and commandement; and by these may be
 13907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood, how he spake to many of the rest.
 13908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo The Extraordinary Prophets Of The Old Testament He Spake
 13913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Dreams, Or Visions
 13915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn what manner God spake to Adam, and Eve, and Cain, and Noah, is not
 13917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpressed; nor how he spake to Abraham, till such time as he came out of
 13918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this own countrey to Sichem in the land of Canaan; and then (Gen. 12.7.)
 13919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod is said to have Appeared to him. So there is one way, whereby God
 13920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade his presence manifest; that is, by an Apparition, or Vision. And
 13921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain, (Gen. 15.1.) The Word of the Lord came to Abraham in a Vision;
 13922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, somewhat, as a sign of Gods presence, appeared as Gods
 13923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMessenger, to speak to him. Again, the Lord appeared to Abraham (Gen.
 13924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t18. 1.) by an apparition of three Angels; and to Abimelech (Gen. 20. 3.)
 13925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin a dream: To Lot (Gen. 19. 1.) by an apparition of Two Angels: And
 13926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Hagar (Gen. 21. 17.) by the apparition of one Angel: And to Abraham
 13927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain (Gen. 22. 11.) by the apparition of a voice from heaven: And (Gen.
 13928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t26. 24.) to Isaac in the night; (that is, in his sleep, or by dream):
 13929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd to Jacob (Gen. 18. 12.) in a dream; that is to say (as are the words
 13930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the text) "Jacob dreamed that he saw a ladder, &c." And (Gen. 32. 1.)
 13931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin a Vision of Angels: And to Moses (Exod. 3.2.) in the apparition of a
 13932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tflame of fire out of the midst of a bush: And after the time of Moses,
 13933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(where the manner how God spake immediately to man in the Old Testament,
 13934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis expressed) hee spake alwaies by a Vision, or by a Dream; as to
 13935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGideon, Samuel, Eliah, Elisha, Isaiah, Ezekiel, and the rest of the
 13936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets; and often in the New Testament, as to Joseph, to St. Peter, to
 13937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Paul, and to St. John the Evangelist in the Apocalypse.
 13938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOnely to Moses hee spake in a more extraordinary manner in Mount Sinai,
 13940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand in the Tabernacle; and to the High Priest in the Tabernacle, and in
 13941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Sanctum Sanctorum of the Temple. But Moses, and after him the
 13942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHigh Priests were Prophets of a more eminent place, and degree in
 13943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods favour; And God himself in express words declareth, that to other
 13944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets hee spake in Dreams and Visions, but to his servant Moses, in
 13945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch manner as a man speaketh to his friend. The words are these (Numb.
 13946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t12. 6,7,8.) "If there be a Prophet among you, I the Lord will make my
 13947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tself known to him in a Vision, and will speak unto him in a Dream. My
 13948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tservant Moses is not so, who is faithfull in all my house; with him I
 13949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill speak mouth to mouth, even apparently, not in dark speeches; and
 13950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe similitude of the Lord shall he behold." And (Exod. 33. 11.) "The
 13951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLord spake to Moses face to face, as a man speaketh to his friend."
 13952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd yet this speaking of God to Moses, was by mediation of an Angel, or
 13953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAngels, as appears expressely, Acts 7. ver. 35. and 53. and Gal. 3. 19.
 13954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand was therefore a Vision, though a more cleer Vision than was given to
 13955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Prophets. And conformable hereunto, where God saith (Deut. 13. 1.)
 13956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"If there arise amongst you a Prophet, or Dreamer of Dreams," the later
 13957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tword is but the interpretation of the former. And (Joel 2. 28.) "Your
 13958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsons and your daughters shall Prophecy; your old men shall dream Dreams,
 13959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand your young men shall see Visions:" where again, the word Prophecy is
 13960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpounded by Dream, and Vision. And in the same manner it was, that God
 13961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspake to Solomon, promising him Wisdome, Riches, and Honor; for the text
 13962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaith, (1 Kings 3. 15.) "And Solomon awoak, and behold it was a Dream:"
 13963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo that generally the Prophets extraordinary in the old Testament took
 13964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnotice of the Word of God no otherwise, than from their Dreams, or
 13965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVisions, that is to say, from the imaginations which they had in their
 13966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsleep, or in an Extasie; which imaginations in every true Prophet were
 13967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall; but in false Prophets were either naturall, or feigned.
 13968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe same Prophets were neverthelesse said to speak by the Spirit; as
 13970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Zach. 7. 12.) where the Prophet speaking of the Jewes, saith, "They
 13971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade their hearths hard as Adamant, lest they should hear the law, and
 13972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe words which the Lord of Hosts hath sent in his Spirit by the former
 13973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets." By which it is manifest, that speaking by the Spirit, or
 13974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInspiration, was not a particular manner of Gods speaking, different
 13975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom Vision, when they that were said to speak by the Spirit, were
 13976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textraordinary Prophets, such as for every new message, were to have a
 13977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular Commission, or (which is all one) a new Dream, or Vision.
 13978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 13979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Prophets Of Perpetuall Calling, And Supreme, God Spake In The
 13980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOld Testament From The Mercy Seat, In A Manner Not Expressed In The
 13981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture. Of Prophets, that were so by a perpetuall Calling in the Old
 13982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestament, some were Supreme, and some Subordinate: Supreme were first
 13983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses; and after him the High Priest, every one for his time, as long
 13984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas the Priesthood was Royall; and after the people of the Jews, had
 13985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trejected God, that he should no more reign over them, those Kings which
 13986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubmitted themselves to Gods government, were also his chief Prophets;
 13987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the High Priests office became Ministeriall. And when God was to be
 13988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsulted, they put on the holy vestments, and enquired of the Lord,
 13989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas the King commanded them, and were deprived of their office, when
 13990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe King thought fit. For King Saul (1 Sam. 13. 9.) commanded the burnt
 13991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toffering to be brought, and (1 Sam. 14. 18.) he commands the Priest to
 13992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbring the Ark neer him; and (ver. 19.) again to let it alone, because he
 13993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaw an advantage upon his enemies. And in the same chapter Saul asketh
 13994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcounsell of God. In like manner King David, after his being anointed,
 13995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough before he had possession of the Kingdome, is said to "enquire
 13996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Lord" (1 Sam. 23. 2.) whether he should fight against the
 13997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilistines at Keilah; and (verse 10.) David commandeth the Priest to
 13998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbring him the Ephod, to enquire whether he should stay in Keilah,
 13999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor not. And King Solomon (1 Kings 2. 27.) took the Priesthood from
 14000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbiathar, and gave it (verse 35.) to Zadoc. Therefore Moses, and
 14001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe High Priests, and the pious Kings, who enquired of God on all
 14002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textraordinary occasions, how they were to carry themselves, or what
 14003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevent they were to have, were all Soveraign Prophets. But in what manner
 14004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod spake unto them, is not manifest. To say that when Moses went up to
 14005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod in Mount Sinai, it was a Dream, or Vision, such as other Prophets
 14006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad, is contrary to that distinction which God made between Moses, and
 14007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Prophets, Numb. 12. 6,7,8. To say God spake or appeared as he
 14008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis in his own nature, is to deny his Infinitenesse, Invisibility,
 14009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIncomprehensibility. To say he spake by Inspiration, or Infusion of the
 14010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHoly Spirit, as the Holy Spirit signifieth the Deity, is to make Moses
 14011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequall with Christ, in whom onely the Godhead (as St. Paul speaketh Col.
 14012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2.9.) dwelleth bodily. And lastly, to say he spake by the Holy Spirit,
 14013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas it signifieth the graces, or gifts of the Holy Spirit, is to
 14014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tattribute nothing to him supernaturall. For God disposeth men to Piety,
 14015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice, Mercy, Truth, Faith, and all manner of Vertue, both Morall,
 14016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Intellectuall, by doctrine, example, and by severall occasions,
 14017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturall, and ordinary.
 14018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as these ways cannot be applyed to God, in his speaking to Moses, at
 14020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMount Sinai; so also, they cannot be applyed to him, in his speaking
 14021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the High Priests, from the Mercy-Seat. Therefore in what manner God
 14022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspake to those Soveraign Prophets of the Old Testament, whose office
 14023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit was to enquire of him, is not intelligible. In the time of the New
 14024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestament, there was no Soveraign Prophet, but our Saviour; who was both
 14025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod that spake, and the Prophet to whom he spake.
 14026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Prophets Of Perpetuall Calling, But Subordinate, God Spake By The
 14028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit. To subordinate Prophets of perpetuall Calling, I find not any
 14029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace that proveth God spake to them supernaturally; but onely in
 14030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch manner, as naturally he inclineth men to Piety, to Beleef, to
 14031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRighteousnesse, and to other vertues all other Christian Men. Which
 14032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tway, though it consist in Constitution, Instruction, Education, and the
 14033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toccasions and invitements men have to Christian vertues; yet it is truly
 14034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tattributed to the operation of the Spirit of God, or Holy Spirit
 14035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which we in our language call the Holy Ghost): For there is no good
 14036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinclination, that is not of the operation of God. But these operations
 14037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not alwaies supernaturall. When therefore a Prophet is said to speak
 14038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Spirit, or by the Spirit of God, we are to understand no more,
 14039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut that he speaks according to Gods will, declared by the supreme
 14040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphet. For the most common acceptation of the word Spirit, is in the
 14041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignification of a mans intention, mind, or disposition.
 14042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the time of Moses, there were seventy men besides himself, that
 14044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphecyed in the Campe of the Israelites. In what manner God spake to
 14045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, is declared in the 11 of Numbers, verse 25. "The Lord came down in
 14046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta cloud, and spake unto Moses, and took of the Spirit that was upon him,
 14047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand gave it to the seventy Elders. And it came to passe, when the Spirit
 14048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trested upon them, they Prophecyed, and did not cease," By which it is
 14049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest, first, that their Prophecying to the people, was subservient,
 14050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand subordinate to the Prophecying of Moses; for that God took of the
 14051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit of Moses, to put upon them; so that they Prophecyed as Moses
 14052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould have them: otherwise they had not been suffered to Prophecy at
 14053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall. For there was (verse 27.) a complaint made against them to Moses;
 14054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Joshua would have Moses to have forbidden them; which he did not,
 14055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut said to Joshua, Bee not jealous in my behalf. Secondly, that
 14056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Spirit of God in that place, signifieth nothing but the Mind and
 14057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDisposition to obey, and assist Moses in the administration of the
 14058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment. For if it were meant they had the substantial Spirit of God;
 14059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, the Divine nature, inspired into them, then they had it in no
 14060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlesse manner than Christ himself, in whom onely the Spirit of God dwelt
 14061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbodily. It is meant therefore of the Gift and Grace of God, that guided
 14062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem to co-operate with Moses; from whom their Spirit was derived. And
 14063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit appeareth (verse 16.) that, they were such as Moses himself should
 14064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappoint for Elders and Officers of the People: For the words are,
 14065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Gather unto me seventy men, whom thou knowest to be Elders and
 14066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOfficers of the people:" where, "thou knowest," is the same with "thou
 14067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappointest," or "hast appointed to be such." For we are told
 14068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore (Exod. 18.) that Moses following the counsell of Jethro his
 14069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFather-in-law, did appoint Judges, and Officers over the people, such as
 14070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfeared God; and of these, were those Seventy, whom God by putting upon
 14071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem Moses spirit, inclined to aid Moses in the Administration of the
 14072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome: and in this sense the Spirit of God is said (1 Sam. 16. 13,
 14073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t14.) presently upon the anointing of David, to have come upon David, and
 14074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleft Saul; God giving his graces to him he chose to govern his people,
 14075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand taking them away from him, he rejected. So that by the Spirit is
 14076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeant Inclination to Gods service; and not any supernaturall Revelation.
 14077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod Sometimes Also Spake By Lots
 14082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod spake also many times by the event of Lots; which were ordered by
 14084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as he had put in Authority over his people. So wee read that God
 14085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifested by the Lots which Saul caused to be drawn (1 Sam. 14. 43.)
 14086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe fault that Jonathan had committed, in eating a honey-comb, contrary
 14087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the oath taken by the people. And (Josh. 18. 10.) God divided the
 14088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tland of Canaan amongst the Israelite, by the "lots that Joshua did cast
 14089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore the Lord in Shiloh." In the same manner it seemeth to be, that
 14090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod discovered (Joshua 7.16., &c.) the crime of Achan. And these are the
 14091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twayes whereby God declared his Will in the Old Testament.
 14092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll which ways he used also in the New Testament. To the Virgin Mary, by
 14094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Vision of an Angel: To Joseph in a Dream: again to Paul in the way
 14095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Damascus in a Vision of our Saviour: and to Peter in the Vision of
 14096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta sheet let down from heaven, with divers sorts of flesh, of clean and
 14097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunclean, beasts; and in prison, by Vision of an Angel: And to all the
 14098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles, and Writers of the New Testament, by the graces of his Spirit;
 14099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to the Apostles again (at the choosing of Matthias in the place of
 14100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudas Iscariot) by lot.
 14101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvery Man Ought To Examine The Probability Of A Pretended Prophets
 14106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCalling
 14108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing then all Prophecy supposeth Vision, or Dream, (which two, when
 14110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey be naturall, are the same,) or some especiall gift of God, so
 14111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trarely observed in mankind, as to be admired where observed; and seeing
 14112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas well such gifts, as the most extraordinary Dreams, and Visions, may
 14113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceed from God, not onely by his supernaturall, and immediate, but
 14114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso by his naturall operation, and by mediation of second causes;
 14115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is need of Reason and Judgement to discern between naturall, and
 14116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall Gifts, and between naturall, and supernaturall Visions, or
 14117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDreams. And consequently men had need to be very circumspect, and wary,
 14118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin obeying the voice of man, that pretending himself to be a Prophet,
 14119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequires us to obey God in that way, which he in Gods name telleth us to
 14120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe the way to happinesse. For he that pretends to teach men the way of
 14121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso great felicity, pretends to govern them; that is to say, to rule, and
 14122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treign over them; which is a thing, that all men naturally desire, and
 14123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis therefore worthy to be suspected of Ambition and Imposture; and
 14124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently, ought to be examined, and tryed by every man, before hee
 14125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyeeld them obedience; unlesse he have yeelded it them already, in
 14126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe institution of a Common-wealth; as when the Prophet is the Civill
 14127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, or by the Civil Soveraign Authorized. And if this examination
 14128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Prophets, and Spirits, were not allowed to every one of the people,
 14129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit had been to no purpose, to set out the marks, by which every man
 14130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmight be able, to distinguish between those, whom they ought, and those
 14131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom they ought not to follow. Seeing therefore such marks are set out
 14132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Deut. 13. 1,&c.) to know a Prophet by; and (1 John 4.1.&C) to know a
 14133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit by: and seeing there is so much Prophecying in the Old Testament;
 14134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand so much Preaching in the New Testament against Prophets; and so much
 14135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreater a number ordinarily of false Prophets, then of true; every
 14136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone is to beware of obeying their directions, at their own perill. And
 14137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst, that there were many more false than true Prophets, appears by
 14138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis, that when Ahab (1 Kings 12.) consulted four hundred Prophets, they
 14139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere all false Imposters, but onely one Michaiah. And a little before
 14140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe time of the Captivity, the Prophets were generally lyars. "The
 14141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets" (saith the Lord by Jerem. cha. 14. verse 14.) "prophecy Lies
 14142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin my name. I sent them not, neither have I commanded them, nor spake
 14143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunto them, they prophecy to you a false Vision, a thing of naught; and
 14144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe deceit of their heart." In so much as God commanded the People by
 14145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe mouth of the Prophet Jeremiah (chap. 23. 16.) not to obey them.
 14146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Thus saith the Lord of Hosts, hearken not unto the words of the
 14147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets, that prophecy to you. They make you vain, they speak a Vision
 14148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their own heart, and not out of the mouth of the Lord."
 14149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll Prophecy But Of The Soveraign Prophet Is To Be Examined
 14154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Every Subject
 14156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing then there was in the time of the Old Testament, such quarrells
 14158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst the Visionary Prophets, one contesting with another, and asking
 14159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen departed the Spirit from me, to go to thee? as between Michaiah,
 14160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the rest of the four hundred; and such giving of the Lye to one
 14161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, (as in Jerem. 14.14.) and such controversies in the New
 14162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestament at this day, amongst the Spirituall Prophets: Every man then
 14163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas, and now is bound to make use of his Naturall Reason, to apply to
 14164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall Prophecy those Rules which God hath given us, to discern the
 14165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrue from the false. Of which rules, in the Old Testament, one was,
 14166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconformable doctrine to that which Moses the Soveraign Prophet had
 14167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaught them; and the other the miraculous power of foretelling what God
 14168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould bring to passe, as I have already shown out of Deut. 13. 1. &c.
 14169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand in the New Testament there was but one onely mark; and that was the
 14170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreaching of this Doctrine, That Jesus Is The Christ, that is, the
 14171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing of the Jews, promised in the Old Testament. Whosoever denyed that
 14172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArticle, he was a false Prophet, whatsoever miracles he might seem to
 14173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twork; and he that taught it was a true Prophet. For St. John (1 Epist,
 14174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t4. 2, &c) speaking expressely of the means to examine Spirits, whether
 14175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey be of God, or not; after he hath told them that there would arise
 14176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfalse Prophets, saith thus, "Hereby know ye the Spirit of God. Every
 14177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit that confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh, is of
 14178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod;" that is, is approved and allowed as a Prophet of God: not that
 14179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the is a godly man, or one of the Elect, for this, that he confesseth,
 14180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprofesseth, or preacheth Jesus to be the Christ; but for that he is a
 14181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphet avowed. For God sometimes speaketh by Prophets, whose persons he
 14182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath not accepted; as he did by Baalam; and as he foretold Saul of his
 14183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeath, by the Witch of Endor. Again in the next verse, "Every Spirit
 14184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat confesseth not that Jesus Christ is come in the Flesh, is not
 14185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Christ. And this is the Spirit of Antichrist." So that the rule is
 14186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperfect on both sides; that he is a true Prophet, which preacheth the
 14187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMessiah already come, in the person of Jesus; and he a false one that
 14188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdenyeth him come, and looketh for him in some future Imposter, that
 14189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall take upon him that honour falsely, whom the Apostle there properly
 14190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalleth Antichrist. Every man therefore ought to consider who is the
 14191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Prophet; that is to say, who it is, that is Gods Viceregent
 14192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton earth; and hath next under God, the Authority of Governing Christian
 14193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen; and to observe for a Rule, that Doctrine, which in the name of
 14194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, hee commanded to bee taught; and thereby to examine and try out
 14195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe truth of those Doctrines, which pretended Prophets with miracles, or
 14196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout, shall at any time advance: and if they find it contrary to that
 14197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRule, to doe as they did, that came to Moses, and complained that there
 14198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere some that Prophecyed in the Campe, whose Authority so to doe they
 14199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoubted of; and leave to the Soveraign, as they did to Moses to uphold,
 14200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor to forbid them, as hee should see cause; and if hee disavow them,
 14201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen no more to obey their voice; or if he approve them, then to obey
 14202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, as men to whom God hath given a part of the Spirit of their
 14203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne. For when Christian men, take not their Christian Soveraign,
 14204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Gods Prophet; they must either take their owne Dreams, for the
 14205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprophecy they mean to bee governed by, and the tumour of their own
 14206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thearts for the Spirit of God; or they must suffer themselves to bee lead
 14207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby some strange Prince; or by some of their fellow subjects, that can
 14208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbewitch them, by slander of the government, into rebellion, without
 14209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother miracle to confirm their calling, then sometimes an extraordinary
 14210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuccesse, and Impunity; and by this means destroying all laws, both
 14211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivine, and humane, reduce all Order, Government, and Society, to the
 14212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst Chaos of Violence, and Civill warre.
 14213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXXVII. OF MIRACLES, AND THEIR USE
 14217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Miracle Is A Work That Causeth Admiration
 14222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Miracles are signified the Admirable works of God: & therefore they
 14224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare also called Wonders. And because they are for the most part, done,
 14225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor a signification of his commandement, in such occasions, as
 14226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout them, men are apt to doubt, (following their private naturall
 14227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasoning,) what he hath commanded, and what not, they are commonly in
 14228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHoly Scripture, called Signes, in the same sense, as they are called by
 14229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Latines, Ostenta, and Portenta, from shewing, and fore-signifying
 14230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat, which the Almighty is about to bring to passe.
 14231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Must Therefore Be Rare, Whereof There Is No Naturall Cause Known
 14236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo understand therefore what is a Miracle, we must first understand what
 14238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworks they are, which men wonder at, and call Admirable. And there be
 14239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut two things which make men wonder at any event: The one is, if it
 14240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe strange, that is to say, such, as the like of it hath never, or very
 14241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trarely been produced: The other is, if when it is produced, we cannot
 14242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timagine it to have been done by naturall means, but onely by the
 14243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timmediate hand of God. But when wee see some possible, naturall cause of
 14244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, how rarely soever the like has been done; or if the like have been
 14245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toften done, how impossible soever it be to imagine a naturall means
 14246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof, we no more wonder, nor esteem it for a Miracle.
 14247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore, if a Horse, or Cow should speak, it were a Miracle; because
 14249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth the thing is strange, & the Naturall cause difficult to imagin: So
 14250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso were it, to see a strange deviation of nature, in the production
 14251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof some new shape of a living creature. But when a man, or other Animal,
 14252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tengenders his like, though we know no more how this is done, than the
 14253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother; yet because 'tis usuall, it is no Miracle. In like manner, if a
 14254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman be metamorphosed into a stone, or into a pillar, it is a Miracle;
 14255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause strange: but if a peece of wood be so changed; because we see it
 14256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toften, it is no Miracle: and yet we know no more, by what operation of
 14257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, the one is brought to passe, than the other.
 14258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe first Rainbow that was seen in the world, was a Miracle, because the
 14260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst; and consequently strange; and served for a sign from God, placed
 14261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin heaven, to assure his people, there should be no more an universall
 14262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdestruction of the world by Water. But at this day, because they
 14263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare frequent, they are not Miracles, neither to them that know their
 14264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturall causes, nor to them who know them not. Again, there be many
 14265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trare works produced by the Art of man: yet when we know they are done;
 14266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause thereby wee know also the means how they are done, we count them
 14267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot for Miracles, because not wrought by the immediate hand of God, but
 14268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby mediation of humane Industry.
 14269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat Which Seemeth A Miracle To One Man, May Seem Otherwise To Another
 14274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFurthermore, seeing Admiration and Wonder, is consequent to the
 14276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknowledge and experience, wherewith men are endued, some more, some
 14277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlesse; it followeth, that the same thing, may be a Miracle to one, and
 14278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot to another. And thence it is, that ignorant, and superstitious men
 14279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake great Wonders of those works, which other men, knowing to proceed
 14280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom Nature, (which is not the immediate, but the ordinary work of God,)
 14281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadmire not at all: As when Ecclipses of the Sun and Moon have been taken
 14282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor supernaturall works, by the common people; when neverthelesse, there
 14283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere others, could from their naturall causes, have foretold the very
 14284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thour they should arrive: Or, as when a man, by confederacy, and secret
 14285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tintelligence, getting knowledge of the private actions of an ignorant,
 14286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunwary man, thereby tells him, what he has done in former time; it seems
 14287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto him a Miraculous thing; but amongst wise, and cautelous men, such
 14288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles as those, cannot easily be done.
 14289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe End Of Miracles
 14294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, it belongeth to the nature of a Miracle, that it be wrought for
 14296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe procuring of credit to Gods Messengers, Ministers, and Prophets,
 14297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat thereby men may know, they are called, sent, and employed by God,
 14298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand thereby be the better inclined to obey them. And therefore, though
 14299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe creation of the world, and after that the destruction of all living
 14300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcreatures in the universall deluge, were admirable works; yet because
 14301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were not done to procure credit to any Prophet, or other Minister
 14302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God, they use not to be called Miracles. For how admirable soever any
 14303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twork be, the Admiration consisteth not in that it could be done, because
 14304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen naturally beleeve the Almighty can doe all things, but because he
 14305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoes it at the Prayer, or Word of a man. But the works of God in Egypt,
 14306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the hand of Moses, were properly Miracles; because they were done
 14307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith intention to make the people of Israel beleeve, that Moses came
 14308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunto them, not out of any design of his owne interest, but as sent from
 14309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod. Therefore after God had commanded him to deliver the Israelites
 14310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Egyptian bondage, when he said (Exod 4.1. &c.) "They will not
 14311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve me, but will say, the Lord hath not appeared unto me," God gave
 14312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim power, to turn the Rod he had in his hand into a Serpent, and again
 14313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto return it into a Rod; and by putting his hand into his bosome, to
 14314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake it leprous; and again by pulling it out to make it whole, to make
 14315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Children of Israel beleeve (as it is verse 5.) that the God of their
 14316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFathers had appeared unto him; And if that were not enough, he gave
 14317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim power to turn their waters into bloud. And when hee had done these
 14318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles before the people, it is said (verse 41.) that "they beleeved
 14319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim." Neverthelesse, for fear of Pharaoh, they durst not yet obey him.
 14320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore the other works which were done to plague Pharaoh and the
 14321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEgyptians, tended all to make the Israelites beleeve in Moses, and were
 14322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproperly Miracles. In like manner if we consider all the Miracles
 14323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdone by the hand of Moses, and all the rest of the Prophets, till the
 14324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCaptivity; and those of our Saviour, and his Apostles afterward; we
 14325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall find, their end was alwaies to beget, or confirm beleefe, that
 14326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey came not of their own motion, but were sent by God. Wee may further
 14327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserve in Scripture, that the end of Miracles, was to beget beleef,
 14328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot universally in all men, elect, and reprobate; but in the elect
 14329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonly; that is to say, is such as God had determined should become his
 14330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects. For those miraculous plagues of Egypt, had not for end, the
 14331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconversion of Pharaoh; For God had told Moses before, that he would
 14332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tharden the heart of Pharaoh, that he should not let the people goe: And
 14333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen he let them goe at last, not the Miracles perswaded him, but the
 14334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplagues forced him to it. So also of our Saviour, it is written, (Mat.
 14335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t13. 58.) that he wrought not many Miracles in his own countrey, because
 14336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their unbeleef; and (in Marke 6.5.) in stead of, "he wrought not
 14337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany," it is, "he could work none." It was not because he wanted power;
 14338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich to say, were blasphemy against God; nor that the end of Miracles
 14339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas not to convert incredulous men to Christ; for the end of all the
 14340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles of Moses, of Prophets, of our Saviour, and of his Apostles
 14341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas to adde men to the Church; but it was, because the end of their
 14342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles, was to adde to the Church (not all men, but) such as should
 14343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe saved; that is to say, such as God had elected. Seeing therefore
 14344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour sent from his Father, hee could not use his power in the
 14345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconversion of those, whom his Father had rejected. They that expounding
 14346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis place of St. Marke, say, that his word, "Hee could not," is put
 14347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor, "He would not," do it without example in the Greek tongue, (where
 14348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWould Not, is put sometimes for Could Not, in things inanimate, that
 14349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave no will; but Could Not, for Would Not, never,) and thereby lay
 14350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta stumbling block before weak Christians; as if Christ could doe no
 14351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles, but amongst the credulous.
 14352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Definition Of A Miracle
 14357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom that which I have here set down, of the nature, and use of a
 14359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracle, we may define it thus, "A MIRACLE, is a work of God, (besides
 14360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this operation by the way of Nature, ordained in the Creation,) done
 14361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the making manifest to his elect, the mission of an extraordinary
 14362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinister for their salvation."
 14363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd from this definition, we may inferre; First, that in all Miracles,
 14365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe work done, is not the effect of any vertue in the Prophet; because
 14366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is the effect of the immediate hand of God; that is to say God hath
 14367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdone it, without using the Prophet therein, as a subordinate cause.
 14368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, that no Devil, Angel, or other created Spirit, can do a
 14370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracle. For it must either be by vertue of some naturall science, or
 14371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Incantation, that is, vertue of words. For if the Inchanters do it
 14372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby their own power independent, there is some power that proceedeth not
 14373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom God; which all men deny: and if they doe it by power given them,
 14374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen is the work not from the immediate hand of God, but naturall, and
 14375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently no Miracle.
 14376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere be some texts of Scripture, that seem to attribute the power of
 14378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworking wonders (equall to some of those immediate Miracles, wrought
 14379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby God himself,) to certain Arts of Magick, and Incantation. As for
 14380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texample, when we read that after the Rod of Moses being cast on the
 14381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tground became a Serpent, (Exod. 7. 11.) "the Magicians of Egypt did the
 14382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike by their Enchantments;" and that after Moses had turned the waters
 14383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Egyptian Streams, Rivers, Ponds, and Pooles of water into blood,
 14384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Exod. 7. 22.) "the Magicians of Egypt did so likewise, with their
 14385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnchantments;" and that after Moses had by the power of God brought
 14386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrogs upon the land, (Exod. 8. 7.) "the Magicians also did so with their
 14387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnchantments, and brought up frogs upon the land of Egypt;" will not a
 14388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman be apt to attribute Miracles to Enchantments; that is to say, to the
 14389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tefficacy of the sound of Words; and think the same very well proved out
 14390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof this, and other such places? and yet there is no place of Scripture,
 14391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat telleth us what on Enchantment is. If therefore Enchantment be not,
 14392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas many think it, a working of strange effects by spells, and words;
 14393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut Imposture, and delusion, wrought by ordinary means; and so far
 14394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom supernaturall, as the Impostors need not the study so much as of
 14395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturall causes, but the ordinary ignorance, stupidity, and superstition
 14396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof mankind, to doe them; those texts that seem to countenance the power
 14397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Magick, Witchcraft, and Enchantment, must needs have another sense,
 14398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan at first sight they seem to bear.
 14399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat Men Are Apt To Be Deceived By False Miracles
 14404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor it is evident enough, that Words have no effect, but on those
 14406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat understand them; and then they have no other, but to signifie the
 14407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tintentions, or passions of them that speak; and thereby produce, hope,
 14408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfear, or other passions, or conceptions in the hearer. Therefore when a
 14409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRod seemeth a Serpent, or the Water Bloud, or any other Miracle seemeth
 14410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdone by Enchantment; if it be not to the edification of Gods people,
 14411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot the Rod, nor the Water, nor any other thing is enchanted; that is
 14412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, wrought upon by the Words, but the Spectator. So that all the
 14413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracle consisteth in this, that the Enchanter has deceived a man; which
 14414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis no Miracle, but a very easie matter to doe.
 14415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor such is the ignorance, and aptitude to error generally of all men,
 14417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut especially of them that have not much knowledge of naturall causes,
 14418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand of the nature, and interests of men; as by innumerable and easie
 14419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttricks to be abused. What opinion of miraculous power, before it was
 14420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknown there was a Science of the course of the Stars, might a man have
 14421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgained, that should have told the people, This hour, or day the Sun
 14422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould be darkned? A juggler by the handling of his goblets, and other
 14423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrinkets, if it were not now ordinarily practised, would be thought
 14424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto do his wonders by the power at least of the Devil. A man that hath
 14425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpractised to speak by drawing in of his breath, (which kind of men in
 14426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tantient time were called Ventriloqui,) and so make the weaknesse of
 14427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this voice seem to proceed, not from the weak impulsion of the organs
 14428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Speech, but from distance of place, is able to make very many men
 14429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve it is a voice from Heaven, whatsoever he please to tell them.
 14430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd for a crafty man, that hath enquired into the secrets, and familiar
 14431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconfessions that one man ordinarily maketh to another of his actions and
 14432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadventures past, to tell them him again is no hard matter; and yet there
 14433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe many, that by such means as that, obtain the reputation of being
 14434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConjurers. But it is too long a businesse, to reckon up the severall
 14435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsorts of those men, which the Greeks called Thaumaturgi, that is to say,
 14436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworkers of things wonderfull; and yet these do all they do, by their
 14437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town single dexterity. But if we looke upon the Impostures wrought by
 14438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConfederacy, there is nothing how impossible soever to be done, that is
 14439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpossible to bee beleeved. For two men conspiring, one to seem lame,
 14440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe other to cure him with a charme, will deceive many: but many
 14441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconspiring, one to seem lame, another so to cure him, and all the rest
 14442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto bear witnesse; will deceive many more.
 14443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCautions Against The Imposture Of Miracles
 14448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn this aptitude of mankind, to give too hasty beleefe to pretended
 14450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles, there can be no better, nor I think any other caution, than
 14451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which God hath prescribed, first by Moses, (as I have said before
 14452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the precedent chapter,) in the beginning of the 13. and end of the
 14453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t18. of Deuteronomy; That wee take not any for Prophets, that teach any
 14454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Religion, then that which Gods Lieutenant, (which at that time was
 14455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses,) hath established; nor any, (though he teach the same Religion,)
 14456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose Praediction we doe not see come to passe. Moses therefore in his
 14457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, and Aaron, and his successors in their times, and the Soveraign
 14458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernour of Gods people, next under God himself, that is to say, the
 14459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHead of the Church in all times, are to be consulted, what doctrine
 14460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the hath established, before wee give credit to a pretended Miracle, or
 14461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphet. And when that is done, the thing they pretend to be a Miracle,
 14462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe must both see it done, and use all means possible to consider,
 14463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhether it be really done; and not onely so, but whether it be such, as
 14464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno man can do the like by his naturall power, but that it requires the
 14465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timmediate hand of God. And in this also we must have recourse to Gods
 14466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLieutenant; to whom in all doubtfull cases, wee have submitted our
 14467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprivate judgments. For Example; if a man pretend, that after certain
 14468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords spoken over a peece of bread, that presently God hath made it not
 14469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbread, but a God, or a man, or both, and neverthelesse it looketh still
 14470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas like bread as ever it did; there is no reason for any man to think
 14471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit really done; nor consequently to fear him, till he enquire of God,
 14472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby his Vicar, or Lieutenant, whether it be done, or not. If he say not,
 14473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen followeth that which Moses saith, (Deut. 18. 22.) "he hath spoken
 14474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit presumptuously, thou shalt not fear him." If he say 'tis done, then
 14475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the is not to contradict it. So also if wee see not, but onely hear tell
 14476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Miracle, we are to consult the Lawful Church; that is to say, the
 14477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawful Head thereof, how far we are to give credit to the relators of
 14478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit. And this is chiefly the case of men, that in these days live under
 14479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Soveraigns. For in these times, I do not know one man, that
 14480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tever saw any such wondrous work, done by the charm, or at the word,
 14481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor prayer of a man, that a man endued but with a mediocrity of reason,
 14482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould think supernaturall: and the question is no more, whether what wee
 14483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsee done, be a Miracle; whether the Miracle we hear, or read of, were
 14484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta reall work, and not the Act of a tongue, or pen; but in plain terms,
 14485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhether the report be true, or a lye. In which question we are not every
 14486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone, to make our own private Reason, or Conscience, but the Publique
 14487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason, that is, the reason of Gods Supreme Lieutenant, Judge; and
 14488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tindeed we have made him Judge already, if wee have given him a Soveraign
 14489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower, to doe all that is necessary for our peace and defence. A private
 14490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman has alwaies the liberty, (because thought is free,) to beleeve,
