 14491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor not beleeve in his heart, those acts that have been given out for
 14492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles, according as he shall see, what benefit can accrew by
 14493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmens belief, to those that pretend, or countenance them, and thereby
 14494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconjecture, whether they be Miracles, or Lies. But when it comes
 14495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto confession of that faith, the Private Reason must submit to the
 14496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique; that is to say, to Gods Lieutenant. But who is this Lieutenant
 14497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God, and Head of the Church, shall be considered in its proper place
 14498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereafter.
 14499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXXVIII. OF THE SIGNIFICATION IN SCRIPTURE OF ETERNALL LIFE,
 14503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHELL, SALVATION, THE WORLD TO COME, AND REDEMPTION
 14505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe maintenance of Civill Society, depending on Justice; and Justice on
 14508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe power of Life and Death, and other lesse Rewards and Punishments,
 14509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tresiding in them that have the Soveraignty of the Common-wealth; It
 14510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis impossible a Common-wealth should stand, where any other than the
 14511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, hath a power of giving greater rewards than Life; and of
 14512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinflicting greater punishments than Death. Now seeing Eternall Life is
 14513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta greater reward, than the Life Present; and Eternall Torment a greater
 14514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunishment than the Death of Nature; It is a thing worthy to be well
 14515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsidered, of all men that desire (by obeying Authority) to avoid
 14516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe calamities of Confusion, and Civill war, what is meant in Holy
 14517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture, by Life Eternall, and Torment Eternall; and for what
 14518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toffences, against whom committed, men are to be Eternally Tormented; and
 14519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor what actions, they are to obtain Eternall Life.
 14520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPlace Of Adams Eternity If He Had Not Sinned, The Terrestrial Paradise
 14525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first we find, that Adam was created in such a condition of life,
 14527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas had he not broken the commandement of God, he had enjoyed it in the
 14528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tParadise of Eden Everlastingly. For there was the Tree of Life; whereof
 14529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the was so long allowed to eat, as he should forbear to eat of the tree
 14530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Knowledge of Good an Evill; which was not allowed him. And therefore
 14531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas soon as he had eaten of it, God thrust him out of Paradise, "lest he
 14532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould put forth his hand, and take also of the tree of life, and live
 14533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor ever." (Gen. 3. 22.) By which it seemeth to me, (with submission
 14534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse both in this, and in all questions, whereof the
 14535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdetermination dependeth on the Scriptures, to the interpretation of the
 14536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBible authorized by the Common-wealth, whose Subject I am,) that Adam if
 14537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the had not sinned, had had an Eternall Life on Earth: and that Mortality
 14538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tentred upon himself, and his posterity, by his first Sin. Not that
 14539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactuall Death then entred; for Adam then could never have had children;
 14540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereas he lived long after, and saw a numerous posterity ere he dyed.
 14541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut where it is said, "In the day that thou eatest thereof, thou shalt
 14542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsurely die," it must needs bee meant of his Mortality, and certitude
 14543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof death. Seeing then Eternall life was lost by Adams forfeiture, in
 14544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommitting sin, he that should cancell that forfeiture was to recover
 14545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereby, that Life again. Now Jesus Christ hath satisfied for the sins
 14546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof all that beleeve in him; and therefore recovered to all beleevers,
 14547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat ETERNALL LIFE, which was lost by the sin of Adam. And in this sense
 14548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is, that the comparison of St. Paul holdeth (Rom. 5.18, 19.) "As by
 14549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe offence of one, Judgment came upon all men to condemnation, even
 14550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso by the righteousnesse of one, the free gift came upon all men
 14551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Justification of Life." Which is again (1 Cor. 15.21,22) more
 14552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperspicuously delivered in these words, "For since by man came death, by
 14553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman came also the resurrection of the dead. For as in Adam all die, even
 14554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso in Christ shall all be made alive."
 14555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTexts Concerning The Place Of Life Eternall For Beleevers
 14560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConcerning the place wherein men shall enjoy that Eternall Life, which
 14562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist hath obtained for them, the texts next before alledged seem to
 14563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake it on Earth. For if as in Adam, all die, that is, have forfeited
 14564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tParadise, and Eternall Life on Earth; even so in Christ all shall be
 14565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade alive; then all men shall be made to live on Earth; for else
 14566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe comparison were not proper. Hereunto seemeth to agree that of the
 14567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPsalmist, (Psal. 133.3.) "Upon Zion God commanded the blessing, even
 14568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLife for evermore;" for Zion, is in Jerusalem, upon Earth: as also that
 14569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof S. Joh. (Rev. 2.7.) "To him that overcommeth I will give to eat of
 14570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe tree of life, which is in the midst of the Paradise of God." This
 14571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas the tree of Adams Eternall life; but his life was to have been on
 14572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarth. The same seemeth to be confirmed again by St. Joh. (Rev. 21.2.)
 14573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere he saith, "I John saw the Holy City, New Jerusalem, coming down
 14574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom God out of heaven, prepared as a Bride adorned for her husband:"
 14575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand again v. 10. to the same effect: As if he should say, the new
 14576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJerusalem, the Paradise of God, at the coming again of Christ, should
 14577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome down to Gods people from Heaven, and not they goe up to it from
 14578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarth. And this differs nothing from that, which the two men in white
 14579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tclothing (that is, the two Angels) said to the Apostles, that were
 14580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlooking upon Christ ascending (Acts 1.11.) "This same Jesus, who is
 14581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaken up from you into Heaven, shall so come, as you have seen him go up
 14582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto Heaven." Which soundeth as if they had said, he should come down
 14583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto govern them under his Father, Eternally here; and not take them up
 14584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto govern them in Heaven; and is conformable to the Restauration of the
 14585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdom of God, instituted under Moses; which was a Political government
 14586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Jews on Earth. Again, that saying of our Saviour (Mat. 22.30.)
 14587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"that in the Resurrection they neither marry, nor are given in marriage,
 14588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut are as the Angels of God in heaven," is a description of an Eternall
 14589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLife, resembling that which we lost in Adam in the point of Marriage.
 14590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor seeing Adam, and Eve, if they had not sinned, had lived on Earth
 14591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternally, in their individuall persons; it is manifest, they should
 14592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot continually have procreated their kind. For if Immortals should have
 14593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgenerated, as Mankind doth now; the Earth in a small time, would not
 14594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave been able to afford them a place to stand on. The Jews that asked
 14595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour the question, whose wife the woman that had married many
 14596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbrothers, should be, in the resurrection, knew not what were the
 14597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequences of Immortality; that there shal be no Generation, and
 14598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently no marriage, no more than there is Marriage, or generation
 14599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamong the Angels. The comparison between that Eternall life which Adam
 14600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlost, and our Saviour by his Victory over death hath recovered; holdeth
 14601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso in this, that as Adam lost Eternall Life by his sin, and yet lived
 14602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter it for a time; so the faithful Christian hath recovered Eternal
 14603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLife by Christs passion, though he die a natural death, and remaine dead
 14604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor a time; namely, till the Resurrection. For as Death is reckoned from
 14605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Condemnation of Adam, not from the Execution; so life is reckoned
 14606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Absolution, not from the Resurrection of them that are elected
 14607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Christ.
 14608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAscension Into Heaven
 14613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat the place wherein men are to live Eternally, after the
 14615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResurrection, is the Heavens, meaning by Heaven, those parts of the
 14616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld, which are the most remote from Earth, as where the stars are,
 14617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor above the stars, in another Higher Heaven, called Caelum Empyreum,
 14618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(whereof there is no mention in Scripture, nor ground in Reason) is not
 14619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teasily to be drawn from any text that I can find. By the Kingdome of
 14620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeaven, is meant the Kingdome of the King that dwelleth in Heaven; and
 14621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Kingdome was the people of Israel, whom he ruled by the Prophets
 14622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Lieutenants, first Moses, and after him Eleazar, and the Soveraign
 14623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriests, till in the days of Samuel they rebelled, and would have a
 14624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmortall man for their King, after the manner of other Nations. And
 14625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen our Saviour Christ, by the preaching of his Ministers, shall have
 14626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperswaded the Jews to return, and called the Gentiles to his obedience,
 14627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen shall there be a new Kingdome of Heaven, because our King shall
 14628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen be God, whose Throne is Heaven; without any necessity evident in
 14629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Scripture, that man shall ascend to his happinesse any higher than
 14630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods Footstool the Earth. On the contrary, we find written (Joh. 3.13.)
 14631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat "no man hath ascended into Heaven, but he that came down from
 14632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeaven, even the Son of man, that is in Heaven." Where I observe by the
 14633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tway, that these words are not, as those which go immediately before, the
 14634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords of our Saviour, but of St. John himself; for Christ was then not
 14635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Heaven, but upon the Earth. The like is said of David (Acts 2.34.)
 14636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere St. Peter, to prove the Ascension of Christ, using the words of
 14637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Psalmist, (Psal. 16.10.) "Thou wilt not leave my soule in Hell, nor
 14638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuffer thine Holy one to see corruption," saith, they were spoken (not
 14639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof David, but) of Christ; and to prove it, addeth this Reason, "For
 14640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDavid is not ascended into Heaven." But to this a man may easily answer,
 14641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand say, that though their bodies were not to ascend till the generall
 14642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tday of Judgment, yet their souls were in Heaven as soon as they were
 14643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeparted from their bodies; which also seemeth to be confirmed by the
 14644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords of our Saviour (Luke 20.37,38.) who proving the Resurrection out
 14645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the word of Moses, saith thus, "That the dead are raised, even Moses
 14646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshewed, at the bush, when he calleth the Lord, the God of Abraham, and
 14647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. For he is not a God of the Dead,
 14648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut of the Living; for they all live to him." But if these words be to
 14649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe understood only of the Immortality of the Soul, they prove not at all
 14650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which our Saviour intended to prove, which was the Resurrection
 14651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Body, that is to say, the Immortality of the Man. Therefore our
 14652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour meaneth, that those Patriarchs were Immortall; not by a property
 14653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequent to the essence, and nature of mankind, but by the will of
 14654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, that was pleased of his mere grace, to bestow Eternall Life upon
 14655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe faithfull. And though at that time the Patriarchs and many other
 14656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaithfull men were Dead, yet as it is in the text, they Lived To God;
 14657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, they were written in the Book of Life with them that were
 14658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsolved of their sinnes, and ordained to Life eternall at the
 14659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResurrection. That the Soul of man is in its own nature Eternall, and
 14660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta living Creature independent on the Body; or that any meer man is
 14661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImmortall, otherwise than by the Resurrection in the last day, (except
 14662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnos and Elias,) is a doctrine not apparent in Scripture. The whole 14.
 14663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChapter of Job, which is the speech not of his friends, but of himselfe,
 14664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a complaint of this Mortality of Nature; and yet no contradiction of
 14665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Immortality at the Resurrection. "There is hope of a tree," (saith
 14666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee verse 7.) "if it be cast down, Though the root thereof wax old, and
 14667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe stock thereof die in the ground, yet when it scenteth the water
 14668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit will bud, and bring forth boughes like a Plant. But man dyeth, and
 14669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twasteth away, yea, man giveth up the Ghost, and where is he?" and (verse
 14670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t12.) "man lyeth down, and riseth not, till the heavens be no more." But
 14671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen is it, that the heavens shall be no more? St. Peter tells us, that
 14672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is at the generall Resurrection. For in his 2. Epistle, 3. Chapter,
 14673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand 7. verse, he saith, that "the Heavens and the Earth that are now,
 14674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare reserved unto fire against the day of Judgment, and perdition of
 14675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tungodly men," and (verse 12.) "looking for, and hasting to the comming
 14676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God, wherein the Heavens shall be on fire, and shall be dissolved,
 14677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Elements shall melt with fervent heat. Neverthelesse, we
 14678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccording to the promise look for new Heavens, and a new Earth, wherein
 14679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdwelleth righteousnesse." Therefore where Job saith, man riseth not till
 14680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Heavens be no more; it is all one, as if he had said, the Immortall
 14681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLife (and Soule and Life in the Scripture, do usually signifie the same
 14682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing) beginneth not in man, till the Resurrection, and day of Judgment;
 14683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand hath for cause, not his specificall nature, and generation; but the
 14684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPromise. For St. Peter saies not, "Wee look for new heavens, and a new
 14685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tearth, (from Nature) but from Promise."
 14686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, seeing it hath been already proved out of divers evident places
 14688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Scripture, in the 35. chapter of this book, that the Kingdom of God
 14689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a Civil Common-wealth, where God himself is Soveraign, by vertue
 14690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst of the Old, and since of the New Covenant, wherein he reigneth by
 14691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Vicar, or Lieutenant; the same places do therefore also prove, that
 14692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter the comming again of our Saviour in his Majesty, and glory, to
 14693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treign actually, and Eternally; the Kingdom of God is to be on Earth. But
 14694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause this doctrine (though proved out of places of Scripture not few,
 14695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor obscure) will appear to most men a novelty; I doe but propound
 14696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit; maintaining nothing in this, or any other paradox of Religion;
 14697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut attending the end of that dispute of the sword, concerning the
 14698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority, (not yet amongst my Countrey-men decided,) by which all sorts
 14699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof doctrine are to bee approved, or rejected; and whose commands, both
 14700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin speech, and writing, (whatsoever be the opinions of private men) must
 14701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby all men, that mean to be protected by their Laws, be obeyed. For
 14702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe points of doctrine concerning the Kingdome (of) God, have so great
 14703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinfluence on the Kingdome of Man, as not to be determined, but by them,
 14704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat under God have the Soveraign Power.
 14705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Place After Judgment, Of Those Who Were Never In The Kingdome
 14710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf God, Or Having Been In, Are Cast Out
 14712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs the Kingdome of God, and Eternall Life, so also Gods Enemies, and
 14714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Torments after Judgment, appear by the Scripture, to have their
 14715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace on Earth. The name of the place, where all men remain till the
 14716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResurrection, that were either buryed, or swallowed up of the Earth, is
 14717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tusually called in Scripture, by words that signifie Under Ground; which
 14718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Latines read generally Infernus, and Inferni, and the Greeks Hades;
 14719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, a place where men cannot see; and containeth as well the
 14720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGrave, as any other deeper place. But for the place of the damned after
 14721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Resurrection, it is not determined, neither in the Old, nor New
 14722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestament, by any note of situation; but onely by the company: as that
 14723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit shall bee, where such wicked men were, as God in former times in
 14724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textraordinary, and miraculous manner, had destroyed from off the face of
 14725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Earth: As for Example, that they are in Inferno, in Tartarus, or in
 14726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe bottomelesse pit; because Corah, Dathan, and Abirom, were swallowed
 14727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tup alive into the earth. Not that the Writers of the Scripture would
 14728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave us beleeve, there could be in the globe of the Earth, which is
 14729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot only finite, but also (compared to the height of the Stars) of no
 14730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsiderable magnitude, a pit without a bottome; that is, a hole of
 14731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinfinite depth, such as the Greeks in their Daemonologie (that is to
 14732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, in their doctrine concerning Daemons,) and after them, the Romans
 14733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Tartarus; of which Virgill sayes,
 14734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t    Bis patet in praeceps, tantem tenditque sub umbras,
 14736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t    Quantus ad aethereum coeli suspectus Olympum:
 14737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor that is a thing the proportion of Earth to Heaven cannot bear: but
 14739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat wee should beleeve them there, indefinitely, where those men are,
 14740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton whom God inflicted that Exemplary punnishment.
 14741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Congregation Of Giants
 14746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, because those mighty men of the Earth, that lived in the time
 14748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Noah, before the floud, (which the Greeks called Heroes, and the
 14749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture Giants, and both say, were begotten, by copulation of the
 14750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchildren of God, with the children of men,) were for their wicked life
 14751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdestroyed by the generall deluge; the place of the Damned, is therefore
 14752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso sometimes marked out, by the company of those deceased Giants; as
 14753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProverbs 21.16. "The man that wandreth out of the way of understanding,
 14754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall remain in the congregation of the Giants," and Job 26.5. "Behold
 14755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Giants groan under water, and they that dwell with them." Here
 14756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe place of the Damned, is under the water. And Isaiah 14.9. "Hell is
 14757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttroubled how to meet thee," (that is, the King of Babylon) "and will
 14758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisplace the Giants for thee:" and here again the place of the Damned,
 14759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(if the sense be literall,) is to be under water.
 14760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLake Of Fire
 14765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, because the Cities of Sodom, and Gomorrah, by the extraordinary
 14767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twrath of God, were consumed for their wickednesse with Fire and
 14768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBrimstone, and together with them the countrey about made a stinking
 14769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbituminous Lake; the place of the Damned is sometimes expressed by
 14770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFire, and a Fiery Lake: as in the Apocalypse ch.21.8. "But the timorous,
 14771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tincredulous, and abominable, and Murderers, and Whoremongers, and
 14772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSorcerers, and Idolators, and all Lyars, shall have their part in the
 14773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLake that burneth with Fire, and Brimstone; which is the second Death."
 14774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo that it is manifest, that Hell Fire, which is here expressed by
 14775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMetaphor, from the reall Fire of Sodome, signifieth not any certain
 14776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkind, or place of Torment; but is to be taken indefinitely, for
 14777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDestruction, as it is in the 20. Chapter, at the 14. verse; where it is
 14778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid, that "Death and Hell were cast into the Lake of Fire;" that is
 14779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, were abolished, and destroyed; as if after the day of Judgment,
 14780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere shall be no more Dying, nor no more going into Hell; that is, no
 14781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore going to Hades (from which word perhaps our word Hell is derived,)
 14782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is the same with no more Dying.
 14783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUtter Darknesse
 14788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFourthly, from the Plague of Darknesse inflicted on the Egyptians, of
 14790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich it is written (Exod. 10.23.) "They saw not one another, neither
 14791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trose any man from his place for three days; but all the Children of
 14792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsrael had light in their dwellings;" the place of the wicked after
 14793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgment, is called Utter Darknesse, or (as it is in the originall)
 14794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDarknesse Without. And so it is expressed (Mat. 22.13.) where the King
 14795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommandeth his Servants, "to bind hand and foot the man that had not
 14796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton his Wedding garment, and to cast him out," Eis To Skotos To Exoteron,
 14797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExternall Darknesse, or Darknesse Without: which though translated Utter
 14798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDarknesse, does not signifie How Great, but Where that darknesse is to
 14799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe; namely, Without The Habitation of Gods Elect.
 14800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGehenna, And Tophet
 14805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, whereas there was a place neer Jerusalem, called the Valley of
 14807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Children of Hinnon; in a part whereof, called Tophet, the Jews had
 14808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommitted most grievous Idolatry, sacrificing their children to the
 14809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIdol Moloch; and wherein also God had afflicted his enemies with most
 14810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrievous punishments; and wherein Josias had burnt the Priests of Moloch
 14811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon their own Altars, as appeareth at large in the 2 of Kings chap. 23.
 14812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe place served afterwards, to receive the filth, and garbage which was
 14813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcarried thither, out of the City; and there used to be fires made, from
 14814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime to time, to purifie the aire, and take away the stench of Carrion.
 14815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom this abominable place, the Jews used ever after to call the place
 14816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Damned, by the name of Gehenna, or Valley of Hinnon. And this
 14817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGehenna, is that word, which is usually now translated HELL; and
 14818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the fires from time to time there burning, we have the notion of
 14819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEverlasting, and Unquenchable Fire.
 14820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Literall Sense Of The Scripture Concerning Hell
 14825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing now there is none, that so interprets the Scripture, as that
 14827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter the day of Judgment, the wicked are all Eternally to be punished
 14828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Valley of Hinnon; or that they shall so rise again, as to be ever
 14829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter under ground, or under water; or that after the Resurrection, they
 14830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall no more see one another; nor stir from one place to another; it
 14831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfolloweth, me thinks, very necessarily, that that which is thus said
 14832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning Hell Fire, is spoken metaphorically; and that therefore there
 14833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a proper sense to bee enquired after, (for of all Metaphors there is
 14834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome reall ground, that may be expressed in proper words) both of the
 14835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPlace of Hell, and the nature of Hellish Torment, and Tormenters.
 14836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSatan, Devill, Not Proper Names, But Appellatives
 14841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first for the Tormenters, wee have their nature, and properties,
 14843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texactly and properly delivered by the names of, The Enemy, or Satan;
 14844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Accuser, or Diabolus; The Destroyer, or Abbadon. Which significant
 14845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnames, Satan, Devill, Abbadon, set not forth to us any Individuall
 14846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperson, as proper names use to doe; but onely an office, or quality;
 14847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand are therefore Appellatives; which ought not to have been left
 14848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuntranslated, as they are, in the Latine, and Modern Bibles; because
 14849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereby they seem to be the proper names of Daemons; and men are the
 14850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore easily seduced to beleeve the doctrine of Devills; which at that
 14851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime was the Religion of the Gentiles, and contrary to that of Moses,
 14852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand of Christ.
 14853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because by the Enemy, the Accuser, and Destroyer, is meant, the
 14855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnemy of them that shall be in the Kingdome of God; therefore if the
 14856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God after the Resurrection, bee upon the Earth, (as in the
 14857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformer Chapter I have shewn by Scripture it seems to be,) The Enemy,
 14858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand his Kingdome must be on Earth also. For so also was it, in the time
 14859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore the Jews had deposed God. For Gods Kingdome was in Palestine;
 14860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Nations round about, were the Kingdomes of the Enemy; and
 14861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently by Satan, is meant any Earthly Enemy of the Church.
 14862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTorments Of Hell
 14867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Torments of Hell, are expressed sometimes, by "weeping, and gnashing
 14869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof teeth," as Mat. 8.12. Sometimes, by "the worm of Conscience;" as
 14870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsa.66.24. and Mark 9.44, 46, 48; sometimes, by Fire, as in the place
 14871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnow quoted, "where the worm dyeth not, and the fire is not quenched,"
 14872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand many places beside: sometimes by "Shame, and contempt," as Dan.
 14873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t12.2. "And many of them that sleep in the dust of the Earth, shall
 14874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tawake; some to Everlasting life; and some to shame, and everlasting
 14875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontempt." All which places design metaphorically a grief, and
 14876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscontent of mind, from the sight of that Eternall felicity in others,
 14877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich they themselves through their own incredulity, and disobedience
 14878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave lost. And because such felicity in others, is not sensible but by
 14879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomparison with their own actuall miseries; it followeth that they are
 14880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto suffer such bodily paines, and calamities, as are incident to those,
 14881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho not onely live under evill and cruell Governours, but have also for
 14882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnemy, the Eternall King of the Saints, God Almighty. And amongst these
 14883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbodily paines, is to be reckoned also to every one of the wicked a
 14884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsecond Death. For though the Scripture bee clear for an universall
 14885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResurrection; yet wee do not read, that to any of the Reprobate is
 14886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpromised an Eternall life. For whereas St. Paul (1 Cor. 15.42, 43.) to
 14887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe question concerning what bodies men shall rise with again, saith,
 14888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat "the body is sown in corruption, and is raised in incorruption; It
 14889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis sown in dishonour, it is raised in glory; it is sown in weaknesse, it
 14890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis raised in power;" Glory and Power cannot be applyed to the bodies of
 14891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe wicked: Nor can the name of Second Death, bee applyed to those
 14892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat can never die but once: And although in Metaphoricall speech, a
 14893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCalamitous life Everlasting, may bee called an Everlasting Death yet it
 14894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot well be understood of a Second Death. The fire prepared for the
 14895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twicked, is an Everlasting Fire: that is to say, the estate wherein
 14896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno man can be without torture, both of body and mind, after the
 14897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResurrection, shall endure for ever; and in that sense the Fire shall
 14898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe unquenchable, and the torments Everlasting: but it cannot thence be
 14899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinferred, that hee who shall be cast into that fire, or be tormented
 14900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith those torments, shall endure, and resist them so, as to be
 14901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teternally burnt, and tortured, and yet never be destroyed, nor die. And
 14902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough there be many places that affirm Everlasting Fire, and Torments
 14903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(into which men may be cast successively one after another for ever;)
 14904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet I find none that affirm there shall bee an Eternall Life therein of
 14905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany individuall person; but on the contrary, an Everlasting Death, which
 14906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the Second Death: (Apoc. 20. 13,14.) "For after Death, and the Grave
 14907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall have delivered up the dead which were in them, and every man be
 14908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudged according to his works; Death and the Grave shall also be cast
 14909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto the Lake of Fire. This is the Second Death." Whereby it is
 14910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevident, that there is to bee a Second Death of every one that shall bee
 14911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondemned at the day of Judgement, after which hee shall die no more.
 14912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Joyes Of Life Eternall, And Salvation The Same Thing,
 14917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation From Sin, And From Misery, All One
 14919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe joyes of Life Eternall, are in Scripture comprehended all under the
 14921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of SALVATION, or Being Saved. To be saved, is to be secured, either
 14922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trespectively, against speciall Evills, or absolutely against all Evill,
 14923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomprehending Want, Sicknesse, and Death it self. And because man
 14924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas created in a condition Immortall, not subject to corruption, and
 14925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently to nothing that tendeth to the dissolution of his nature;
 14926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand fell from that happinesse by the sin of Adam; it followeth, that
 14927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be Saved From Sin, is to be saved from all the Evill, and Calamities
 14928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Sinne hath brought upon us. And therefore in the Holy Scripture,
 14929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRemission of Sinne, and Salvation from Death and Misery, is the same
 14930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing, as it appears by the words of our Saviour, who having cured a man
 14931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsick of the Palsey, by saying, (Mat. 9.2.) "Son be of good cheer, thy
 14932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSins be forgiven thee;" and knowing that the Scribes took for blasphemy,
 14933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat a man should pretend to forgive Sins, asked them (v.5.) "whether
 14934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit were easier to say, Thy Sinnes be forgiven thee, or, Arise and walk;"
 14935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifying thereby, that it was all one, as to the saving of the sick,
 14936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, "Thy Sins are forgiven," and "Arise and walk;" and that he used
 14937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat form of speech, onely to shew he had power to forgive Sins. And
 14938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is besides evident in reason, that since Death and Misery, were the
 14939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunishments of Sin, the discharge of Sinne, must also be a discharge
 14940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Death and Misery; that is to say, Salvation absolute, such as the
 14941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaithfull are to enjoy after the day of Judgment, by the power, and
 14942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfavour of Jesus Christ, who for that cause is called our SAVIOUR.
 14943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConcerning Particular Salvations, such as are understood, 1 Sam. 14.39.
 14945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"as the Lord liveth that saveth Israel," that is, from their temporary
 14946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenemies, and 2 Sam. 22.4. "Thou art my Saviour, thou savest me from
 14947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tviolence;" and 2 Kings 13.5. "God gave the Israelites a Saviour, and
 14948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso they were delivered from the hand of the Assyrians," and the like,
 14949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI need say nothing; there being neither difficulty, nor interest, to
 14950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcorrupt the interpretation of texts of that kind.
 14951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Place Of Eternall Salvation
 14956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut concerning the Generall Salvation, because it must be in the
 14958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of Heaven, there is great difficulty concerning the Place.
 14959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOn one side, by Kingdome (which is an estate ordained by men for their
 14960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperpetuall security against enemies, and want) it seemeth that this
 14961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation should be on Earth. For by Salvation is set forth unto us,
 14962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta glorious Reign of our King, by Conquest; not a safety by Escape:
 14963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore there where we look for Salvation, we must look also
 14964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Triumph; and before Triumph, for Victory; and before Victory, for
 14965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBattell; which cannot well be supposed, shall be in Heaven. But how good
 14966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsoever this reason may be, I will not trust to it, without very evident
 14967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaces of Scripture. The state of Salvation is described at large,
 14968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsaiah, 33. ver. 20,21,22,23,24.
 14969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Look upon Zion, the City of our solemnities, thine eyes shall see
 14971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJerusalem a quiet habitation, a tabernacle that shall not be taken down;
 14972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot one of the stakes thereof shall ever be removed, neither shall any
 14973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the cords thereof be broken.
 14974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut there the glorious Lord will be unto us a place of broad rivers, and
 14976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstreams; wherein shall goe no Gally with oares; neither shall gallant
 14977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tship passe thereby.
 14978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the Lord is our Judge, the Lord is our Lawgiver, the Lord is our
 14980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing, he will save us.
 14981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThy tacklings are loosed; they could not well strengthen their mast;
 14983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey could not spread the sail: then is the prey of a great spoil
 14984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivided; the lame take the prey.
 14985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd the Inhabitant shall not say, I am sicke; the people that shall
 14987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdwell therein shall be forgiven their Iniquity."
 14988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 14989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn which words wee have the place from whence Salvation is to proceed,
 14990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Jerusalem, a quiet habitation;" the Eternity of it, "a tabernacle that
 14991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall not be taken down," &c. The Saviour of it, "the Lord, their Judge,
 14992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Lawgiver, their King, he will save us;" the Salvation, "the Lord
 14993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be to them as a broad mote of swift waters," &c. the condition of
 14994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Enemies, "their tacklings are loose, their masts weake, the
 14995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlame shal take the spoil of them." The condition of the Saved,
 14996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"The Inhabitants shall not say, I am sick:" And lastly, all this is
 14997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomprehended in Forgivenesse of sin, "The people that dwell therein
 14998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be forgiven their iniquity." By which it is evident, that
 14999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation shall be on Earth, then, when God shall reign, (at the coming
 15000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain of Christ) in Jerusalem; and from Jerusalem shall proceed the
 15001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation of the Gentiles that shall be received into Gods Kingdome; as
 15002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis also more expressely declared by the same Prophet, Chap. 66.20, 21.
 15003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"And they," (that is, the Gentiles who had any Jew in bondage) "shall
 15004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbring all your brethren, for an offering to the Lord, out of all
 15005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnations, upon horses, and in charets, and in litters, and upon mules,
 15006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand upon swift beasts, to my holy mountain, Jerusalem, saith the Lord,
 15007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas the Children of Israel bring an offering in a clean vessell into
 15008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe House of the Lord. And I will also take of them for Priests and for
 15009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLevites, saith the Lord:" Whereby it is manifest, that the chief seat of
 15010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGods Kingdome (which is the Place, from whence the Salvation of us that
 15011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere Gentiles, shall proceed) shall be Jerusalem; And the same is also
 15012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconfirmed by our Saviour, in his discourse with the woman of Samaria,
 15013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning the place of Gods worship; to whom he saith, John 4.22. that
 15014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Samaritans worshipped they know not what, but the Jews worship what
 15015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey knew, "For Salvation is of the Jews (Ex Judais, that is, begins at
 15016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Jews): as if he should say, you worship God, but know not by whom
 15017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the wil save you, as we doe, that know it shall be one of the tribe
 15018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Judah, a Jew, not a Samaritan. And therefore also the woman not
 15019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpertinently answered him again, "We know the Messias shall come." So
 15020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which our saviour saith, "Salvation is from the Jews," is the
 15021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame that Paul sayes (Rom. 1.16,17.) "The Gospel is the power of God to
 15022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation to every one that beleeveth; To the Jew first, and also to the
 15023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGreek. For therein is the righteousnesse of God revealed from faith to
 15024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaith;" from the faith of the Jew, to the faith of the Gentile. In
 15025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe like sense the Prophet Joel describing the day of Judgment, (chap.
 15026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2.30,31.) that God would "shew wonders in heaven, and in earth, bloud,
 15027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand fire, and pillars of smoak. The Sun should be turned to darknesse,
 15028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Moon into bloud, before the great and terrible day of the Lord
 15029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome," he addeth verse 32. "and it shall come to passe, that whosoever
 15030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall call upon the name of the Lord, shall be saved. For in Mount Zion,
 15031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand in Jerusalem shall be Salvation." And Obadiah verse 17 saith
 15032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same, "Upon Mount Zion shall be Deliverance; and there shall be
 15033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tholinesse, and the house of Jacob shall possesse their possessions,"
 15034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, the possessions of the Heathen, which possessions he expresseth
 15035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore particularly in the following verses, by the Mount of Esau, the
 15036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLand of the Philistines, the Fields of Ephraim, of Samaria, Gilead, and
 15037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Cities of the South, and concludes with these words, "the Kingdom
 15038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be the Lords." All these places are for Salvation, and the
 15039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God (after the day of Judgement) upon Earth. On the other
 15040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tside, I have not found any text that can probably be drawn, to prove
 15041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany Ascension of the Saints into Heaven; that is to say, into any Coelum
 15042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEmpyreum, or other aetheriall Region; saving that it is called the
 15043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of Heaven; which name it may have, because God, that was King
 15044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Jews, governed them by his commands, sent to Moses by Angels from
 15045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeaven, to reduce them to their obedience; and shall send him thence
 15046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain, to rule both them, and all other faithfull men, from the day of
 15047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgment, Everlastingly: or from that, that the Throne of this our Great
 15048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing is in Heaven; whereas the Earth is but his Footstoole. But that the
 15049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects of God should have any place as high as his throne, or higher
 15050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan his Footstoole, it seemeth not sutable to the dignity of a King,
 15051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor can I find any evident text for it in holy Scripture.
 15052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom this that hath been said of the Kingdom of God, and of Salvation,
 15054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is not hard to interpret, what is meant by the WORLD TO COME. There
 15055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare three worlds mentioned in Scripture, the Old World, the Present
 15056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorld, and the World to Come. Of the first, St. Peter speaks, (2 Pet.
 15057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2.5.) "If God spared not the Old World, but saved Noah the eighth
 15058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperson, a Preacher of righteousnesse, bringing the flood upon the world
 15059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the ungodly," &c. So the First World, was from Adam to the generall
 15060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFlood. Of the present World, our Saviour speaks (John 18.36.) "My
 15061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome is not of this World." For he came onely to teach men the way
 15062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Salvation, and to renew the Kingdome of his Father, by his doctrine.
 15063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf the World to come, St. Peter speaks, (2 Pet. 3. 13.) "Neverthelesse
 15064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe according to his promise look for new Heavens, and a new Earth." This
 15065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis that WORLD, wherein Christ coming down from Heaven, in the clouds,
 15066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith great power, and glory, shall send his Angels, and shall gather
 15067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttogether his elect, from the four winds, and from the uttermost parts
 15068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Earth, and thence forth reign over them, (under his Father)
 15069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEverlastingly.
 15070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRedemption
 15075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation of a sinner, supposeth a precedent REDEMPTION; for he that is
 15077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonce guilty of Sin, is obnoxious to the Penalty of the same; and must
 15078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpay (or some other for him) such Ransome, as he that is offended, and
 15079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thas him in his power, shall require. And seeing the person offended, is
 15080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlmighty God, in whose power are all things; such Ransome is to be paid
 15081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore Salvation can be acquired, as God hath been pleased to require.
 15082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy this Ransome, is not intended a satisfaction for Sin, equivalent to
 15083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Offence, which no sinner for himselfe, nor righteous man can ever be
 15084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\table to make for another; The dammage a man does to another, he may make
 15085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamends for by restitution, or recompence, but sin cannot be taken
 15086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taway by recompence; for that were to make the liberty to sin, a thing
 15087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvendible. But sins may bee pardoned to the repentant, either Gratis, or
 15088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon such penalty, as God is pleased to accept. That which God usually
 15089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccepted in the Old Testament, was some Sacrifice, or Oblation. To
 15090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforgive sin is not an act of Injustice, though the punishment have
 15091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen threatned. Even amongst men, though the promise of Good, bind the
 15092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpromiser; yet threats, that is to say, promises, of Evill, bind them
 15093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot; much lesse shall they bind God, who is infinitely more mercifull
 15094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen men. Our Saviour Christ therefore to Redeem us, did not in that
 15095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense satisfie for the Sins of men, as that his Death, of its own
 15096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvertue, could make it unjust in God to punish sinners with Eternall
 15097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeath; but did make that Sacrifice, and Oblation of himself, at his
 15098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst coming, which God was pleased to require, for the Salvation at his
 15099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsecond coming, of such as in the mean time should repent, and beleeve in
 15100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim. And though this act of our Redemption, be not alwaies in Scripture
 15101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled a Sacrifice, and Oblation, but sometimes a Price, yet by Price
 15102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe are not to understand any thing, by the value whereof, he could claim
 15103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tright to a pardon for us, from his offended Father, but that Price which
 15104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod the Father was pleased in mercy to demand.
 15105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XXXIX. OF THE SIGNIFICATION IN SCRIPTURE OF THE WORD CHURCH
 15109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch The Lords House
 15114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe word Church, (Ecclesia) signifieth in the Books of Holy Scripture
 15116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivers things. Sometimes (though not often) it is taken for Gods House,
 15117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, for a Temple, wherein Christians assemble to perform
 15118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tholy duties publiquely; as, 1 Cor. 14. ver. 34. "Let your women keep
 15119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsilence in the Churches:" but this is Metaphorically put, for the
 15120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCongregation there assembled; and hath been since used for the
 15121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEdifice it self, to distinguish between the Temples of Christians, and
 15122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIdolaters. The Temple of Jerusalem was Gods House, and the House of
 15123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrayer; and so is any Edifice dedicated by Christians to the worship of
 15124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, Christs House: and therefore the Greek Fathers call it Kuriake,
 15125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Lords House; and thence, in our language it came to be called Kyrke,
 15126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Church.
 15127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesia Properly What
 15132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch (when not taken for a House) signifieth the same that Ecclesia
 15134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignified in the Grecian Common-wealths; that is to say, a Congregation,
 15135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor an Assembly of Citizens, called forth, to hear the Magistrate speak
 15136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunto them; and which in the Common-wealth of Rome was called Concio, as
 15137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the that spake was called Ecclesiastes, and Concionator. And when they
 15138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere called forth by lawfull Authority, (Acts 19.39.) it was Ecclesia
 15139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLegitima, a Lawfull Church, Ennomos Ecclesia. But when they were excited
 15140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby tumultuous, and seditious clamor, then it was a confused Church,
 15141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesia Sugkechumene.
 15142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is taken also sometimes for the men that have right to be of the
 15144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCongregation, though not actually assembled; that is to say, for the
 15145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhole multitude of Christian men, how far soever they be dispersed: as
 15146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Act. 8.3.) where it is said, that "Saul made havock of the Church:" And
 15147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this sense is Christ said to be Head of the Church. And sometimes for
 15148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta certain part of Christians, as (Col. 4.15.) "Salute the Church that is
 15149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his house." Sometimes also for the Elect onely; as (Ephes. 5.27.) "A
 15150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGlorious Church, without spot, or wrinkle, holy, and without blemish;"
 15151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is meant of the Church Triumphant, or, Church To Come. Sometimes,
 15152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor a Congregation assembled, of professors of Christianity, whether
 15153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir profession be true, or counterfeit, as it is understood, Mat.
 15154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t18.17. where it is said, "Tell it to the Church, and if hee neglect to
 15155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thear the Church, let him be to thee as a Gentile, or Publican."
 15156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn What Sense The Church Is One Person Church Defined
 15161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd in this last sense only it is that the Church can be taken for one
 15163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson; that is to say, that it can be said to have power to will, to
 15164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpronounce, to command, to be obeyed, to make laws, or to doe any other
 15165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taction whatsoever; For without authority from a lawfull Congregation,
 15166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever act be done in a concourse of people, it is the particular
 15167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tact of every one of those that were present, and gave their aid to the
 15168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperformance of it; and not the act of them all in grosse, as of one
 15169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbody; much lesse that act of them that were absent, or that being
 15170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent, were not willing it should be done. According to this sense, I
 15171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdefine a CHURCH to be, "A company of men professing Christian Religion,
 15172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunited in the person of one Soveraign; at whose command they ought to
 15173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassemble, and without whose authority they ought not to assemble." And
 15174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause in all Common-wealths, that Assembly, which is without warrant
 15175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Civil Soveraign, is unlawful; that Church also, which is
 15176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassembled in any Common-wealth, that hath forbidden them to assemble, is
 15177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan unlawfull Assembly.
 15178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA Christian Common-wealth, And A Church All One
 15183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt followeth also, that there is on Earth, no such universall Church as
 15185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall Christians are bound to obey; because there is no power on Earth, to
 15186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich all other Common-wealths are subject: There are Christians, in
 15187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Dominions of severall Princes and States; but every one of them
 15188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis subject to that Common-wealth, whereof he is himself a member; and
 15189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently, cannot be subject to the commands of any other Person.
 15190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore a Church, such as one as is capable to Command, to Judge,
 15191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbsolve, Condemn, or do any other act, is the same thing with a Civil
 15192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, consisting of Christian men; and is called a Civill
 15193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tState, for that the subjects of it are Men; and a Church, for that the
 15194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubjects thereof are Christians. Temporall and Spirituall Government,
 15195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare but two words brought into the world, to make men see double, and
 15196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmistake their Lawfull Soveraign. It is true, that the bodies of the
 15197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaithfull, after the Resurrection shall be not onely Spirituall, but
 15198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternall; but in this life they are grosse, and corruptible. There
 15199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis therefore no other Government in this life, neither of State, nor
 15200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion, but Temporall; nor teaching of any doctrine, lawfull to any
 15201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubject, which the Governour both of the State, and of the Religion,
 15202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforbiddeth to be taught: And that Governor must be one; or else there
 15203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmust needs follow Faction, and Civil war in the Common-wealth, between
 15204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Church and State; between Spiritualists, and Temporalists; between
 15205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Sword Of Justice, and the Shield Of Faith; and (which is more) in
 15206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery Christian mans own brest, between the Christian, and the Man.
 15207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Doctors of the Church, are called Pastors; so also are Civill
 15208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignes: But if Pastors be not subordinate one to another, so
 15209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas that there may bee one chief Pastor, men will be taught contrary
 15210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrines, whereof both may be, and one must be false. Who that one
 15211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchief Pastor is, according to the law of Nature, hath been already
 15212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshewn; namely, that it is the Civill Soveraign; And to whom the
 15213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture hath assigned that Office, we shall see in the Chapters
 15214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollowing.
 15215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XL
 15219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOF THE RIGHTS OF THE KINGDOME OF GOD, IN ABRAHAM, MOSES, HIGH PRIESTS,
 15221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAND THE KINGS OF JUDAH
 15223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Soveraign Rights Of Abraham
 15228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Father of the Faithfull, and first in the Kingdome of God by
 15230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant, was Abraham. For with him was the Covenant first made; wherein
 15231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the obliged himself, and his seed after him, to acknowledge and obey the
 15232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommands of God; not onely such, as he could take notice of, (as Morall
 15233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaws,) by the light of Nature; but also such, as God should in speciall
 15234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner deliver to him by Dreams and Visions. For as to the Morall law,
 15235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were already obliged, and needed not have been contracted withall,
 15236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby promise of the Land of Canaan. Nor was there any Contract, that could
 15237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadde to, or strengthen the Obligation, by which both they, and all
 15238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen else were bound naturally to obey God Almighty: And therefore the
 15239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant which Abraham made with God, was to take for the Commandement
 15240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God, that which in the name of God was commanded him, in a Dream, or
 15241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVision, and to deliver it to his family, and cause them to observe the
 15242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame.
 15243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbraham Had The Sole Power Of Ordering The Religion Of His Own People
 15248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn this Contract of God with Abraham, wee may observe three points of
 15250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timportant consequence in the government of Gods people. First, that at
 15251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe making of this Covenant, God spake onely to Abraham; and therefore
 15252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontracted not with any of his family, or seed, otherwise then as their
 15253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twills (which make the essence of all Covenants) were before the Contract
 15254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinvolved in the will of Abraham; who was therefore supposed to have had
 15255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta lawfull power, to make them perform all that he covenanted for them.
 15256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAccording whereunto (Gen 18.18, 19.) God saith, "All the Nations of the
 15257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarth shall be blessed in him, For I know him that he will command his
 15258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchildren and his houshold after him, and they shall keep the way of the
 15259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLord." From whence may be concluded this first point, that they to
 15260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom God hath not spoken immediately, are to receive the positive
 15261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommandements of God, from their Soveraign; as the family and seed of
 15262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbraham did from Abraham their Father, and Lord, and Civill Soveraign.
 15263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Consequently in every Common-wealth, they who have no supernaturall
 15264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRevelation to the contrary, ought to obey the laws of their own
 15265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, in the externall acts and profession of Religion. As for the
 15266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinward Thought, and beleef of men, which humane Governours can take no
 15267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnotice of, (for God onely knoweth the heart) they are not voluntary, nor
 15268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe effect of the laws, but of the unrevealed will, and of the power of
 15269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod; and consequently fall not under obligation.
 15270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNo Pretence Of Private Spirit Against The Religion Of Abraham
 15275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom whence proceedeth another point, that it was not unlawfull for
 15277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbraham, when any of his Subjects should pretend Private Vision, or
 15278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit, or other Revelation from God, for the countenancing of any
 15279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoctrine which Abraham should forbid, or when they followed, or adhered
 15280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto any such pretender, to punish them; and consequently that it is
 15281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfull now for the Soveraign to punish any man that shall oppose his
 15282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivate Spirit against the Laws: For hee hath the same place in the
 15283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, that Abraham had in his own Family.
 15284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbraham Sole Judge, And Interpreter Of What God Spake
 15289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere ariseth also from the same, a third point; that as none but
 15291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbraham in his family, so none but the Soveraign in a Christian
 15292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, can take notice what is, or what is not the Word of God.
 15293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor God spake onely to Abraham; and it was he onely, that was able
 15294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto know what God said, and to interpret the same to his family: And
 15295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore also, they that have the place of Abraham in a Common-wealth,
 15296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare the onely Interpreters of what God hath spoken.
 15297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Authority Of Moses Whereon Grounded
 15302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe same Covenant was renewed with Isaac; and afterwards with Jacob; but
 15304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafterwards no more, till the Israelites were freed from the Egyptians,
 15305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand arrived at the Foot of Mount Sinai: and then it was renewed by Moses
 15306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as I have said before, chap. 35.) in such manner, as they became from
 15307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat time forward the Peculiar Kingdome of God; whose Lieutenant was
 15308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses, for his owne time; and the succession to that office was setled
 15309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon Aaron, and his heirs after him, to bee to God a Sacerdotall
 15310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome for ever.
 15311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy this constitution, a Kingdome is acquired to God. But seeing Moses
 15313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad no authority to govern the Israelites, as a successor to the right
 15314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Abraham, because he could not claim it by inheritance; it appeareth
 15315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot as yet, that the people were obliged to take him for Gods
 15316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLieutenant, longer than they beleeved that God spake unto him. And
 15317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore his authority (notwithstanding the Covenant they made with
 15318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod) depended yet merely upon the opinion they had of his Sanctity,
 15319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand of the reality of his Conferences with God, and the verity of his
 15320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles; which opinion coming to change, they were no more obliged to
 15321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake any thing for the law of God, which he propounded to them in Gods
 15322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname. We are therefore to consider, what other ground there was, of
 15323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir obligation to obey him. For it could not be the commandement of
 15324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod that could oblige them; because God spake not to them immediately,
 15325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut by the mediation of Moses Himself; And our Saviour saith of himself,
 15326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(John 5. 31.) "If I bear witnesse of my self, my witnesse is not true,"
 15327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmuch lesse if Moses bear witnesse of himselfe, (especially in a claim of
 15328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingly power over Gods people) ought his testimony to be received. His
 15329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority therefore, as the authority of all other Princes, must be
 15330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrounded on the Consent of the People, and their Promise to obey him.
 15331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd so it was: for "the people" (Exod. 20.18.) "when they saw the
 15332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThunderings, and the Lightnings, and the noyse of the Trumpet, and the
 15333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmountaine smoaking, removed, and stood a far off. And they said unto
 15334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses, speak thou with us, and we will hear, but let not God speak with
 15335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tus lest we die." Here was their promise of obedience; and by this it was
 15336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey obliged themselves to obey whatsoever he should deliver unto them
 15337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the Commandement of God.
 15338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses Was (Under God) Soveraign Of The Jews, All His Own Time,
 15343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThough Aaron Had The Priesthood
 15345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd notwithstanding the Covenant constituted a Sacerdotall Kingdome,
 15347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, a Kingdome hereditary to Aaron; yet that is to be
 15348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood of the succession, after Moses should bee dead. For
 15349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhosoever ordereth, and establisheth the Policy, as first founder of
 15350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Common-wealth (be it Monarchy, Aristocracy, or Democracy) must needs
 15351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave Soveraign Power over the people all the while he is doing of it.
 15352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd that Moses had that power all his own time, is evidently affirmed in
 15353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Scripture. First, in the text last before cited, because the people
 15354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpromised obedience, not to Aaron but to him. Secondly, (Exod. 24.1, 2.)
 15355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"And God said unto Moses, Come up unto the Lord, thou, and Aaron, Nadab
