 15356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Abihu, and seventy of the Elders of Israel. And Moses alone shall
 15357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome neer the Lord, but they shall not come nigh, neither shall the
 15358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople goe up with him." By which it is plain, that Moses who was alone
 15359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled up to God, (and not Aaron, nor the other Priests, nor the Seventy
 15360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tElders, nor the People who were forbidden to come up) was alone he, that
 15361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepresented to the Israelites the Person of God; that is to say, was
 15362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir sole Soveraign under God. And though afterwards it be said (verse
 15363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t9.) "Then went up Moses, and Aaron, Nadab, and Abihu, and seventy of the
 15364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tElders of Israel, and they saw the God of Israel, and there was under
 15365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this feet, as it were a paved work of a saphire stone," &c. yet this was
 15366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot till after Moses had been with God before, and had brought to
 15367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people the words which God had said to him. He onely went for the
 15368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbusinesse of the people; the others, as the Nobles of his retinue, were
 15369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadmitted for honour to that speciall grace, which was not allowed to
 15370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe people; which was, (as in the verse after appeareth) to see God and
 15371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlive. "God laid not his hand upon them, they saw God and did eat and
 15372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdrink" (that is, did live), but did not carry any commandement from
 15373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim to the people. Again, it is every where said, "The Lord spake unto
 15374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses," as in all other occasions of Government; so also in the ordering
 15375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Ceremonies of Religion, contained in the 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30,
 15376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand 31 Chapters of Exodus, and throughout Leviticus: to Aaron seldome.
 15377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Calfe that Aaron made, Moses threw into the fire. Lastly, the
 15378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestion of the Authority of Aaron, by occasion of his and Miriams
 15379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmutiny against Moses, was (Numbers 12.) judged by God himself for Moses.
 15380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo also in the question between Moses, and the People, when Corah,
 15381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDathan, and Abiram, and two hundred and fifty Princes of the Assembly
 15382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"gathered themselves together" (Numbers 16. 3) "against Moses, and
 15383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst Aaron, and said unto them, 'Ye take too much upon you, seeing
 15384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall the congregation are Holy, every one of them, and the Lord is
 15385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst them, why lift you up your selves above the congregation of the
 15386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLord?'" God caused the Earth to swallow Corah, Dathan, and Abiram with
 15387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir wives and children alive, and consumed those two hundred and fifty
 15388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrinces with fire. Therefore neither Aaron, nor the People, nor any
 15389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAristocracy of the chief Princes of the People, but Moses alone had next
 15390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder God the Soveraignty over the Israelites: And that not onely in
 15391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcauses of Civill Policy, but also of Religion; For Moses onely spake
 15392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith God, and therefore onely could tell the People, what it was that
 15393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod required at their hands. No man upon pain of death might be so
 15394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresumptuous as to approach the Mountain where God talked with Moses.
 15395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Thou shalt set bounds" (saith the Lord, Exod 19. 12.) "to the people
 15396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tround about, and say, Take heed to your selves that you goe not up into
 15397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Mount, or touch the border of it; whosoever toucheth the Mount shall
 15398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsurely be put to death." and again (verse 21.) "Get down, charge the
 15399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople, lest they break through unto the Lord to gaze." Out of which we
 15400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay conclude, that whosoever in a Christian Common-wealth holdeth the
 15401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace of Moses, is the sole Messenger of God, and Interpreter of
 15402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Commandements. And according hereunto, no man ought in the
 15403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterpretation of the Scripture to proceed further then the bounds which
 15404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare set by their severall Soveraigns. For the Scriptures since God now
 15405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeaketh in them, are the Mount Sinai; the bounds whereof are the Laws
 15406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them that represent Gods Person on Earth. To look upon them and
 15407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherein to behold the wondrous works of God, and learn to fear him is
 15408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallowed; but to interpret them; that is, to pry into what God saith to
 15409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim whom he appointeth to govern under him, and make themselves Judges
 15410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhether he govern as God commandeth him, or not, is to transgresse the
 15411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbounds God hath set us, and to gaze upon God irreverently.
 15412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll Spirits Were Subordinate To The Spirit Of Moses
 15417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere was no Prophet in the time of Moses, nor pretender to the Spirit
 15419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God, but such as Moses had approved, and Authorized. For there were
 15420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his time but Seventy men, that are said to Prophecy by the Spirit of
 15421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, and these were of all Moses his election; concerning whom God saith
 15422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Moses (Numb. 11.16.) "Gather to mee Seventy of the Elders of Israel,
 15423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom thou knowest to be the Elders of the People." To these God imparted
 15424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Spirit; but it was not a different Spirit from that of Moses; for
 15425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is said (verse 25.) "God came down in a cloud, and took of the Spirit
 15426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat was upon Moses, and gave it to the Seventy Elders." But as I have
 15427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshewn before (chap. 36.) by Spirit, is understood the Mind; so that the
 15428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense of the place is no other than this, that God endued them with
 15429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta mind conformable, and subordinate to that of Moses, that they might
 15430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphecy, that is to say, speak to the people in Gods name, in such
 15431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner, as to set forward (as Ministers of Moses, and by his authority)
 15432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch doctrine as was agreeable to Moses his doctrine. For they were but
 15433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters; and when two of them Prophecyed in the Camp, it was thought
 15434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta new and unlawfull thing; and as it is in the 27. and 28. verses of
 15435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same Chapter, they were accused of it, and Joshua advised Moses to
 15436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforbid them, as not knowing that it was by Moses his Spirit that they
 15437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphecyed. By which it is manifest, that no Subject ought to pretend to
 15438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphecy, or to the Spirit, in opposition to the doctrine established by
 15439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, whom God hath set in the place of Moses.
 15440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter Moses The Soveraignty Was In The High Priest
 15445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAaron being dead, and after him also Moses, the Kingdome, as being a
 15447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSacerdotall Kingdome, descended by vertue of the Covenant, to Aarons
 15448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSon, Eleazar the High Priest: And God declared him (next under himself)
 15449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Soveraign, at the same time that he appointed Joshua for the
 15450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGenerall of their Army. For thus God saith expressely (Numb. 27.21.)
 15451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning Joshua; "He shall stand before Eleazar the Priest, who shall
 15452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\task counsell for him, before the Lord, at his word shall they goe out,
 15453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand at his word they shall come in, both he, and all the Children of
 15454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsrael with him:" Therefore the Supreme Power of making War and Peace,
 15455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas in the Priest. The Supreme Power of Judicature belonged also to
 15456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe High Priest: For the Book of the Law was in their keeping; and the
 15457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriests and Levites onely were the subordinate Judges in causes Civill,
 15458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas appears in Deut. 17.8, 9, 10. And for the manner of Gods worship,
 15459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere was never doubt made, but that the High Priest till the time
 15460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Saul, had the Supreme Authority. Therefore the Civill and
 15461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticall Power were both joined together in one and the same
 15462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperson, the High Priest; and ought to bee so, in whosoever governeth by
 15463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivine Right; that is, by Authority immediate from God.
 15464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Soveraign Power Between The Time Of Joshua And Of Saul
 15469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter the death of Joshua, till the time of Saul, the time between is
 15471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnoted frequently in the Book of Judges, "that there was in those dayes
 15472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno King in Israel;" and sometimes with this addition, that "every
 15473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman did that which was right in his own eyes." By which is to bee
 15474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood, that where it is said, "there was no King," is meant, "there
 15475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas no Soveraign Power" in Israel. And so it was, if we consider the
 15476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAct, and Exercise of such power. For after the death of Joshua, &
 15477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEleazar, "there arose another generation" (Judges 2.10.) "that knew not
 15478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Lord, nor the works which he had done for Israel, but did evill in
 15479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe sight of the Lord, and served Baalim." And the Jews had that quality
 15480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich St. Paul noteth, "to look for a sign," not onely before they would
 15481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubmit themselves to the government of Moses, but also after they had
 15482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobliged themselves by their submission. Whereas Signs, and Miracles had
 15483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor End to procure Faith, not to keep men from violating it, when they
 15484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave once given it; for to that men are obliged by the law of Nature.
 15485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut if we consider not the Exercise, but the Right of governing, the
 15486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign power was still in the High Priest. Therefore whatsoever
 15487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobedience was yeelded to any of the Judges, (who were men chosen by God
 15488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textraordinarily, to save his rebellious subjects out of the hands of
 15489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe enemy,) it cannot bee drawn into argument against the Right the High
 15490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriest had to the Soveraign Power, in all matters, both of Policy and
 15491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion. And neither the Judges, nor Samuel himselfe had an ordinary,
 15492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut extraordinary calling to the Government; and were obeyed by the
 15493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsraelites, not out of duty, but out of reverence to their favour
 15494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith God, appearing in their wisdome, courage, or felicity. Hitherto
 15495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore the Right of Regulating both the Policy, and the Religion,
 15496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere inseparable.
 15497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Rights Of The Kings Of Israel
 15502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo the Judges, succeeded Kings; And whereas before, all authority, both
 15504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Religion, and Policy, was in the High Priest; so now it was all in
 15505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe King. For the Soveraignty over the people, which was before, not
 15506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely by vertue of the Divine Power, but also by a particular pact of
 15507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Israelites in God, and next under him, in the High Priest, as his
 15508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tViceregent on earth, was cast off by the People, with the consent of God
 15509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe. For when they said to Samuel (1 Sam. 8.5.) "make us a King to
 15510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudge us, like all the Nations," they signified that they would no
 15511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore bee governed by the commands that should bee laid upon them by the
 15512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriest, in the name of God; but by one that should command them in the
 15513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame manner that all other nations were commanded; and consequently in
 15514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeposing the High Priest of Royall authority, they deposed that peculiar
 15515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment of God. And yet God consented to it, saying to Samuel (verse
 15516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t7.) "Hearken unto the voice of the People, in all that they shall say
 15517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunto thee; for they have not rejected thee, but they have rejected mee,
 15518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat I should not reign over them." Having therefore rejected God, in
 15519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose Right the Priests governed, there was no authority left to the
 15520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriests, but such as the King was pleased to allow them; which was
 15521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore, or lesse, according as the Kings were good, or evill. And for the
 15522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment of Civill affaires, it is manifest, it was all in the hands
 15523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the King. For in the same Chapter, verse 20. They say they will be
 15524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike all the Nations; that their King shall be their Judge, and goe
 15525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore them, and fight their battells; that is, he shall have the
 15526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhole authority, both in Peace and War. In which is contained also the
 15527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordering of Religion; for there was no other Word of God in that time,
 15528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby which to regulate Religion, but the Law of Moses, which was their
 15529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Law. Besides, we read (1 Kings 2.27.) that Solomon "thrust out
 15530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbiathar from being Priest before the Lord:" He had therefore authority
 15531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover the High Priest, as over any other Subject; which is a great
 15532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmark of Supremacy in Religion. And we read also (1 Kings 8.) that hee
 15533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdedicated the Temple; that he blessed the People; and that he himselfe
 15534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin person made that excellent prayer, used in the Consecrations of all
 15535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurches, and houses of Prayer; which is another great mark of Supremacy
 15536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Religion. Again, we read (2 Kings 22.) that when there was question
 15537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning the Book of the Law found in the Temple, the same was not
 15538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdecided by the High Priest, but Josiah sent both him, and others to
 15539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenquire concerning it, of Hulda, the Prophetesse; which is another mark
 15540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Supremacy in Religion. Lastly, wee read (1 Chro. 26.30.) that
 15541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDavid made Hashabiah and his brethren, Hebronites, Officers of Israel
 15542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamong them Westward, "in all businesse of the Lord, and in the service
 15543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the King." Likewise (verse 32.) that hee made other Hebronites,
 15544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"rulers over the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the halfe tribe of
 15545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tManasseh" (these were the rest of Israel that dwelt beyond Jordan) "for
 15546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery matter pertaining to God, and affairs of the King." Is not this
 15547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfull Power, both Temporall and Spirituall, as they call it, that would
 15548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivide it? To conclude; from the first institution of Gods Kingdome, to
 15549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Captivity, the Supremacy of Religion, was in the same hand with that
 15550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Civill Soveraignty; and the Priests office after the election of
 15551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaul, was not Magisteriall, but Ministeriall.
 15552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Practice Of Supremacy In Religion, Was Not In The Time Of The Kings,
 15557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAccording To The Right Thereof
 15559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNotwithstanding the government both in Policy and Religion, were joined,
 15561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst in the High Priests, and afterwards in the Kings, so far forth as
 15562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerned the Right; yet it appeareth by the same Holy History, that the
 15563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople understood it not; but there being amongst them a great part, and
 15564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprobably the greatest part, that no longer than they saw great miracles,
 15565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor (which is equivalent to a miracle) great abilities, or great felicity
 15566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the enterprises of their Governours, gave sufficient credit, either
 15567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the fame of Moses, or to the Colloquies between God and the Priests;
 15568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey took occasion as oft as their Governours displeased them, by
 15569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tblaming sometimes the Policy, sometimes the Religion, to change the
 15570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment, or revolt from their Obedience at their pleasure: And from
 15571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthence proceeded from time to time the civill troubles, divisions, and
 15572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalamities of the Nation. As for example, after the death of Eleazar and
 15573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJoshua, the next generation which had not seen the wonders of God, but
 15574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere left to their own weak reason, not knowing themselves obliged
 15575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Covenant of a Sacerdotall Kingdome, regarded no more the
 15576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandement of the Priest, nor any law of Moses, but did every man that
 15577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich was right in his own eyes; and obeyed in Civill affairs, such
 15578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, as from time to time they thought able to deliver them from the
 15579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneighbour Nations that oppressed them; and consulted not with God (as
 15580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey ought to doe,) but with such men, or women, as they guessed to bee
 15581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets by their Praedictions of things to come; and thought they had
 15582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Idol in their Chappel, yet if they had a Levite for their Chaplain,
 15583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey made account they worshipped the God of Israel.
 15584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd afterwards when they demanded a King, after the manner of the
 15586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnations; yet it was not with a design to depart from the worship of God
 15587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir King; but despairing of the justice of the sons of Samuel, they
 15588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould have a King to judg them in Civill actions; but not that they
 15589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould allow their King to change the Religion which they thought was
 15590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trecommended to them by Moses. So that they alwaies kept in store a
 15591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretext, either of Justice, or Religion, to discharge themselves of
 15592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir obedience, whensoever they had hope to prevaile. Samuel was
 15593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdispleased with the people, for that they desired a King, (for God was
 15594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir King already, and Samuel had but an authority under him); yet did
 15595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSamuel, when Saul observed not his counsell, in destroying Agag as God
 15596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad commanded, anoint another King, namely David, to take the succession
 15597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom his heirs. Rehoboam was no Idolater; but when the people thought
 15598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim an Oppressor; that Civil pretence carried from him ten Tribes to
 15599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJeroboam an Idolater. And generally through the whole History of the
 15600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings, as well of Judah, as of Israel, there were Prophets that alwaies
 15601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrolled the Kings, for transgressing the Religion; and sometimes also
 15602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Errours of State; (2 Chro. 19. 2.) as Jehosaphat was reproved by
 15603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Prophet Jehu, for aiding the King of Israel against the Syrians;
 15604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Hezekiah, by Isaiah, for shewing his treasures to the Ambassadors of
 15605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBabylon. By all which it appeareth, that though the power both of State
 15606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Religion were in the Kings; yet none of them were uncontrolled
 15607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the use of it, but such as were gracious for their own naturall
 15608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabilities, or felicities. So that from the practise of those times,
 15609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere can no argument be drawn, that the right of Supremacy in Religion
 15610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas not in the Kings, unlesse we place it in the Prophets; and conclude,
 15611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat because Hezekiah praying to the Lord before the Cherubins, was not
 15612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanswered from thence, nor then, but afterwards by the Prophet Isaiah,
 15613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore Isaiah was supreme Head of the Church; or because Josiah
 15614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsulted Hulda the Prophetesse, concerning the Book of the Law, that
 15615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore neither he, nor the High Priest, but Hulda the Prophetesse had
 15616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Supreme authority in matter of Religion; which I thinke is not the
 15617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion of any Doctor.
 15618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter The Captivity The Jews Had No Setled Common-wealth
 15623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDuring the Captivity, the Jews had no Common-wealth at all
 15625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd after their return, though they renewed their Covenant with God, yet
 15627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere was no promise made of obedience, neither to Esdras, nor to any
 15628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother; And presently after they became subjects to the Greeks (from
 15629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose Customes, and Daemonology, and from the doctrine of the Cabalists,
 15630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Religion became much corrupted): In such sort as nothing can be
 15631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgathered from their confusion, both in State and Religion, concerning
 15632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Supremacy in either. And therefore so far forth as concerneth the
 15633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOld Testament, we may conclude, that whosoever had the Soveraignty
 15634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Common-wealth amongst the Jews, the same had also the Supreme
 15635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority in matter of Gods externall worship; and represented Gods
 15636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson; that is the person of God the Father; though he were not called
 15637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the name of Father, till such time as he sent into the world his Son
 15638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJesus Christ, to redeem mankind from their sins, and bring them into his
 15639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEverlasting Kingdome, to be saved for evermore. Of which we are to speak
 15640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Chapter following.
 15641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XLI. OF THE OFFICE OF OUR BLESSED SAVIOUR
 15645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThree Parts Of The Office Of Christ
 15650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWe find in Holy Scripture three parts of the Office of the Messiah: the
 15652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst of a Redeemer, or Saviour: The second of a Pastor, Counsellour,
 15653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Teacher, that is, of a Prophet sent from God, to convert such as God
 15654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath elected to Salvation; The third of a King, and Eternall King, but
 15655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder his Father, as Moses and the High Priests were in their severall
 15656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimes. And to these three parts are corespondent three times. For our
 15657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRedemption he wrought at his first coming, by the Sacrifice, wherein
 15658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the offered up himself for our sinnes upon the Crosse: our conversion
 15659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the wrought partly then in his own Person; and partly worketh now by his
 15660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters; and will continue to work till his coming again. And after
 15661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this coming again, shall begin that his glorious Reign over his elect,
 15662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is to last eternally.
 15663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHis Office As A Redeemer
 15668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo the Office of a Redeemer, that is, of one that payeth the Ransome of
 15670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSin, (which Ransome is Death,) it appertaineth, that he was Sacrificed,
 15671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand thereby bare upon his own head, and carryed away from us our
 15672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tiniquities, in such sort as God had required. Not that the death of one
 15673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, though without sinne, can satisfie for the offences of all men,
 15674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the rigour of Justice, but in the Mercy of God, that ordained such
 15675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSacrifices for sin, as he was pleased in his mercy to accept. In the old
 15676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw (as we may read, Leviticus the 16.) the Lord required, that there
 15677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould every year once, bee made an Atonement for the Sins of all
 15678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsrael, both Priests, and others; for the doing whereof, Aaron alone was
 15679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto sacrifice for himself and the Priests a young Bullock; and for the
 15680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trest of the people, he was to receive from them two young Goates, of
 15681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich he was to Sacrifice one; but as for the other, which was the Scape
 15682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGoat, he was to lay his hands on the head thereof, and by a confession
 15683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the iniquities of the people, to lay them all on that head, and then
 15684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby some opportune man, to cause the Goat to be led into the wildernesse,
 15685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand there to Escape, and carry away with him the iniquities of the
 15686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople. As the Sacrifice of the one Goat was a sufficient (because an
 15687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacceptable) price for the Ransome of all Israel; so the death of the
 15688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMessiah, is a sufficient price, for the Sins of all mankind, because
 15689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere was no more required. Our Saviour Christs sufferings seem to be
 15690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\there figured, as cleerly, as in the oblation of Isaac, or in any other
 15691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttype of him in the Old Testament: He was both the sacrificed Goat, and
 15692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Scape Goat; "Hee was oppressed, and he was afflicted (Isa. 53.7.);
 15693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the opened not his mouth; he brought as a lamb to the slaughter, and as a
 15694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsheep is dumbe before the shearer, so opened he not his mouth:" Here he
 15695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the Sacrificed Goat. "He hath born our Griefs, (ver.4.) and carried
 15696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour sorrows;" And again, (ver. 6.) "the Lord hath laid upon him the
 15697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tiniquities of us all:" And so he is the Scape Goat. "He was cut off from
 15698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe land of the living (ver. 8.) for the transgression of my People:"
 15699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere again he is the Sacrificed Goat. And again (ver. 11.) "he shall
 15700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbear their sins:" Hee is the Scape Goat. Thus is the Lamb of God
 15701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequivalent to both those Goates; sacrificed, in that he dyed; and
 15702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tescaping, in his Resurrection; being raised opportunely by his Father,
 15703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand removed from the habitation of men in his Ascension.
 15704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrists Kingdome Not Of This World
 15709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor as much therefore, as he that Redeemeth, hath no title to the Thing
 15711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRedeemed, before the Redemption, and Ransome paid; and this Ransome was
 15712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Death of the Redeemer; it is manifest, that our Saviour (as man) was
 15713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot King of those that he Redeemed, before hee suffered death; that is,
 15714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tduring that time hee conversed bodily on the Earth. I say, he was not
 15715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen King in present, by vertue of the Pact, which the faithfull make
 15716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith him in Baptisme; Neverthelesse, by the renewing of their Pact with
 15717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod in Baptisme, they were obliged to obey him for King, (under his
 15718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFather) whensoever he should be pleased to take the Kingdome upon him.
 15719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAccording whereunto, our Saviour himself expressely saith, (John 18.36.)
 15720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"My Kingdome is not of this world." Now seeing the Scripture maketh
 15721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmention but of two worlds; this that is now, and shall remain to the day
 15722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Judgment, (which is therefore also called, The Last Day;) and that
 15723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich shall bee a new Heaven, and a new Earth; the Kingdome of Christ
 15724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not to begin till the general Resurrection. And that is it which our
 15725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour saith, (Mat. 16.27.) "The Son of man shall come in the glory
 15726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his Father, with his Angels; and then he shall reward every man
 15727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccording to his works." To reward every man according to his works, is
 15728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto execute the Office of a King; and this is not to be till he come in
 15729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe glory of his Father, with his Angells. When our Saviour saith,
 15730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Mat. 23.2.) "The Scribes and Pharisees sit in Moses seat; All therefore
 15731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever they bid you doe, that observe and doe;" hee declareth
 15732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplainly, that hee ascribeth Kingly Power, for that time, not to
 15733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe, but to them. And so hee hath also, where he saith, (Luke
 15734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t12.14.) "Who made mee a Judge, or Divider over you?" And (John 12.47.)
 15735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"I came not to judge the world, but to save the world." And yet our
 15736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour came into this world that hee might bee a King, and a Judge in
 15737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe world to come: For hee was the Messiah, that is, the Christ, that
 15738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, the Anointed Priest, and the Soveraign Prophet of God; that is to
 15739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, he was to have all the power that was in Moses the Prophet, in the
 15740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHigh Priests that succeeded Moses, and in the Kings that succeeded the
 15741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriests. And St. John saies expressely (chap. 5. ver. 22.) "The Father
 15742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudgeth no man, but hath committed all judgment to the Son." And this is
 15743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot repugnant to that other place, "I came not to judge the world:" for
 15744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis is spoken of the world present, the other of the world to come; as
 15745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso where it is said, that at the second coming of Christ, (Mat. 19.
 15746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t28.) "Yee that have followed me in the Regeneration, when the Son of
 15747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman shall sit in the throne of his Glory, yee shall also sit on twelve
 15748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel."
 15749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe End Of Christs Comming Was To Renew The Covenant Of The Kingdome
 15754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf God, And To Perswade The Elect To Imbrace It, Which Was The Second
 15756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPart Of His Office
 15758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf then Christ while hee was on Earth, had no Kingdome in this World,
 15760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto what end was his first coming? It was to restore unto God, by a new
 15761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCovenant, the Kingdome, which being his by the Old Covenant, had been
 15762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcut off by the rebellion of the Israelites in the election of Saul.
 15763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhich to doe, he was to preach unto them, that he was the Messiah, that
 15764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, the King promised to them by the Prophets; and to offer himselfe in
 15765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsacrifice for the sinnes of them that should by faith submit themselves
 15766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereto; and in case the nation generally should refuse him, to call
 15767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto his obedience such as should beleeve in him amongst the Gentiles. So
 15768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat there are two parts of our Saviours Office during his aboad upon
 15769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Earth; One to Proclaim himself the Christ; and another by Teaching,
 15770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand by working of Miracles, to perswade, and prepare men to live so, as
 15771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be worthy of the Immortality Beleevers were to enjoy, at such time as
 15772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the should come in majesty, to take possession of his Fathers Kingdome.
 15773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore it is, that the time of his preaching, is often by himself
 15774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled the Regeneration; which is not properly a Kingdome, and thereby
 15775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta warrant to deny obedience to the Magistrates that then were, (for
 15776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee commanded to obey those that sate then in Moses chaire, and to pay
 15777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttribute to Caesar;) but onely an earnest of the Kingdome of God that was
 15778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto come, to those to whom God had given the grace to be his disciples,
 15779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to beleeve in him; For which cause the Godly are said to bee already
 15780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Kingdome of Grace, as naturalized in that heavenly Kingdome.
 15781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Preaching Of Christ Not Contrary To The Then Law Of The Jews,
 15786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor Of Caesar
 15788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHitherto therefore there is nothing done, or taught by Christ, that
 15790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttendeth to the diminution of the Civill Right of the Jewes, or of
 15791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCaesar. For as touching the Common-wealth which then was amongst
 15792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Jews, both they that bare rule amongst them, that they that were
 15793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgoverned, did all expect the Messiah, and Kingdome of God; which they
 15794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcould not have done if their Laws had forbidden him (when he came) to
 15795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest, and declare himself. Seeing therefore he did nothing, but by
 15796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPreaching, and Miracles go about to prove himselfe to be that Messiah,
 15797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee did therein nothing against their laws. The Kingdome hee claimed was
 15798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto bee in another world; He taught all men to obey in the mean time them
 15799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat sate in Moses seat: he allowed them to give Caesar his tribute, and
 15800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trefused to take upon himselfe to be a Judg. How then could his words,
 15801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor actions bee seditious, or tend to the overthrow of their then Civill
 15802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment? But God having determined his sacrifice, for the reduction
 15803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his elect to their former covenanted obedience, for the means,
 15804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereby he would bring the same to effect, made use of their malice,
 15805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand ingratitude. Nor was it contrary to the laws of Caesar. For though
 15806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPilate himself (to gratifie the Jews) delivered him to be crucified; yet
 15807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore he did so, he pronounced openly, that he found no fault in him:
 15808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd put for title of his condemnation, not as the Jews required, "that
 15809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the pretended to be King;" but simply, "That hee was King of the Jews;"
 15810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand notwithstanding their clamour, refused to alter it; saying, "What I
 15811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave written, I have written."
 15812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Third Part Of His Office Was To Be King (Under His Father)
 15817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Elect
 15819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for the third part of his Office, which was to be King, I have
 15821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready shewn that his Kingdome was not to begin till the Resurrection.
 15822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut then he shall be King, not onely as God, in which sense he is
 15823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing already, and ever shall be, of all the Earth, in vertue of his
 15824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tomnipotence; but also peculiarly of his own Elect, by vertue of the
 15825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpact they make with him in their Baptisme. And therefore it is, that
 15826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour saith (Mat. 19.28.) that his Apostles should sit upon twelve
 15827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel, "When the Son of man shall
 15828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsit in the throne of his glory;" whereby he signified that he should
 15829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treign then in his humane nature; and (Mat. 16.27.) "The Son of man shall
 15830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome in the glory of his Father, with his Angels, and then he shall
 15831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treward every man according to his works." The same we may read, Marke
 15832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t13..26. and 14.26. and more expressely for the time, Luke 22.29, 30. "I
 15833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappoint unto you a Kingdome, as my Father hath appointed to mee, that
 15834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyou may eat and drink at my table in my Kingdome, and sit on thrones
 15835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudging the twelve tribes of Israel." By which it is manifest that the
 15836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of Christ appointed to him by his Father, is not to be before
 15837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Son of Man shall come in Glory, and make his Apostles Judges of
 15838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe twelve tribes of Israel. But a man may here ask, seeing there is
 15839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno marriage in the Kingdome of Heaven, whether men shall then eat, and
 15840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdrink; what eating therefore is meant in this place? This is expounded
 15841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby our Saviour (John 6.27.) where he saith, "Labour not for the meat
 15842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich perisheth, but for that meat which endureth unto everlasting
 15843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife, which the Son of man shall give you." So that by eating at Christs
 15844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttable, is meant the eating of the Tree of Life; that is to say, the
 15845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenjoying of Immortality, in the Kingdome of the Son of Man. By which
 15846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaces, and many more, it is evident, that our Saviours Kingdome is to
 15847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee exercised by him in his humane nature.
 15848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrists Authority In The Kingdome Of God Subordinate To His Father
 15853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, he is to be King then, no otherwise than as subordinate, or
 15855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tViceregent of God the Father, as Moses was in the wildernesse; and as
 15856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe High Priests were before the reign of Saul; and as the Kings were
 15857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter it. For it is one of the Prophecies concerning Christ, that he
 15858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould be like (in Office) to Moses; "I will raise them up a Prophet
 15859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(saith the Lord, Deut. 18.18.) from amongst their Brethren like unto
 15860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthee, and will put my words into his mouth," and this similitude with
 15861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses, is also apparent in the actions of our Saviour himself, whilest
 15862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the was conversant on Earth. For as Moses chose twelve Princes of the
 15863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttribes, to govern under him; so did our Saviour choose twelve Apostles,
 15864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho shall sit on twelve thrones, and judge the twelve tribes of Israel;
 15865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as Moses authorized Seventy Elders, to receive the Spirit of God,
 15866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to Prophecy to the people, that is, (as I have said before,) to
 15867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeak unto them in the name of God; so our Saviour also ordained seventy
 15868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDisciples, to preach his Kingdome, and Salvation to all Nations. And as
 15869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen a complaint was made to Moses, against those of the Seventy that
 15870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprophecyed in the camp of Israel, he justified them in it, as being
 15871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubservient therein to his government; so also our Saviour, when St.
 15872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJohn complained to him of a certain man that cast out Devills in his
 15873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname, justified him therein, saying, (Luke 9.50.) "Forbid him not, for
 15874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee that is not against us, is on our part."
 15875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, our Saviour resembled Moses in the institution of Sacraments,
 15877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth of Admission into the Kingdome of God, and of Commemoration of his
 15878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeliverance of his Elect from their miserable condition. As the Children
 15879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Israel had for Sacrament of their Reception into the Kingdome of God,
 15880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore the time of Moses, the rite of Circumcision, which rite having
 15881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen omitted in the Wildernesse, was again restored as soon as they came
 15882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto the land of Promise; so also the Jews, before the coming of our
 15883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour, had a rite of Baptizing, that is, of washing with water all
 15884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that being Gentiles, embraced the God of Israel. This rite St.
 15885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJohn the Baptist used in the reception of all them that gave their names
 15886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Christ, whom hee preached to bee already come into the world; and
 15887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour instituted the same for a Sacrament to be taken by all that
 15888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeved in him. From what cause the rite of Baptisme first proceeded,
 15889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not expressed formally in the Scripture; but it may be probably
 15890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought to be an imitation of the law of Moses, concerning Leprousie;
 15891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twherein the Leprous man was commanded to be kept out of the campe of
 15892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsrael for a certain time; after which time being judged by the Priest
 15893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be clean, hee was admitted into the campe after a solemne Washing.
 15894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd this may therefore bee a type of the Washing in Baptisme; wherein
 15895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch men as are cleansed of the Leprousie of Sin by Faith, are received
 15896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto the Church with the solemnity of Baptisme. There is another
 15897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconjecture drawn from the Ceremonies of the Gentiles, in a certain case
 15898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat rarely happens; and that is, when a man that was thought dead,
 15899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchanced to recover, other men made scruple to converse with him, as they
 15900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould doe to converse with a Ghost, unlesse hee were received again into
 15901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe number of men, by Washing, as Children new born were washed from
 15902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe uncleannesse of their nativity, which was a kind of new birth. This
 15903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tceremony of the Greeks, in the time that Judaea was under the Dominion
 15904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Alexander, and the Greeks his successors, may probably enough have
 15905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcrept into the Religion of the Jews. But seeing it is not likely our
 15906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour would countenance a Heathen rite, it is most likely it proceeded
 15907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Legall Ceremony of Washing after Leprosie. And for the other
 15908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSacraments, of eating the Paschall Lambe, it is manifestly imitated in
 15909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Sacrament of the Lords Supper; in which the Breaking of the Bread,
 15910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the pouring out of the Wine, do keep in memory our deliverance from
 15911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Misery of Sin, by Christs Passion, as the eating of the Paschall
 15912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLambe, kept in memory the deliverance of the Jewes out of the Bondage of
 15913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEgypt. Seeing therefore the authority of Moses was but subordinate, and
 15914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee but a Lieutenant to God; it followeth, that Christ, whose authority,
 15915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas man, was to bee like that of Moses, was no more but subordinate to
 15916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe authority of his Father. The same is more expressely signified, by
 15917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat that hee teacheth us to pray, "Our Father, Let thy Kingdome come;"
 15918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand, "For thine is the Kingdome, the power and the Glory;" and by that
 15919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is said, that "Hee shall come in the Glory of his Father;" and by
 15920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which St. Paul saith, (1 Cor. 15.24.) "then commeth the end, when
 15921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee shall have delivered up the Kingdome to God, even the Father;" and
 15922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby many other most expresse places.
 15923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOne And The Same God Is The Person Represented By Moses, And By Christ
 15928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOur Saviour therefore, both in Teaching, and Reigning, representeth (as
 15930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses Did) the Person of God; which God from that time forward, but
 15931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot before, is called the Father; and being still one and the same
 15932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubstance, is one Person as represented by Moses, and another Person as
 15933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepresented by his Sonne the Christ. For Person being a relative to a
 15934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresenter, it is consequent to plurality of Representers, that there
 15935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee a plurality of Persons, though of one and the same Substance.
 15936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XLII. OF POWER ECCLESIASTICALL
 15940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the understanding of POWER ECCLESIASTICALL, what, and in whom it is,
 15943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe are to distinguish the time from the Ascension of our Saviour, into
 15944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttwo parts; one before the Conversion of Kings, and men endued with
 15945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Civill Power; the other after their Conversion. For it was
 15946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlong after the Ascension, before any King, or Civill Soveraign embraced,
 15947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand publiquely allowed the teaching of Christian Religion.
 15948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Holy Spirit That Fel On The Apostles
 15953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd for the time between, it is manifest, that the Power
 15955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticall, was in the Apostles; and after them in such as were by
 15956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem ordained to Preach the Gospell, and to convert men to Christianity,
 15957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to direct them that were converted in the way of Salvation; and
 15958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter these the Power was delivered again to others by these ordained,
 15959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand this was done by Imposition of hands upon such as were ordained; by
 15960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich was signified the giving of the Holy Spirit, or Spirit of God, to
 15961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose whom they ordained Ministers of God, to advance his Kingdome.
 15962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSo that Imposition of hands, was nothing else but the Seal of their
 15963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommission to Preach Christ, and teach his Doctrine; and the giving of
 15964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Holy Ghost by that ceremony of Imposition of hands, was an imitation
 15965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof that which Moses did. For Moses used the same ceremony to his
 15966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinister Joshua, as wee read Deuteronomy 34. ver. 9. "And Joshua the son
 15967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Nun was full of the Spirit of Wisdome; for Moses had laid his
 15968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thands upon him." Our Saviour therefore between his Resurrection, and
 15969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAscension, gave his Spirit to the Apostles; first, by "Breathing on
 15970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, and saying," (John 20.22.) "Receive yee the Holy Spirit;" and after
 15971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Ascension (Acts 2.2, 3.) by sending down upon them, a "mighty wind,
 15972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Cloven tongues of fire;" and not by Imposition of hands; as neither
 15973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdid God lay his hands on Moses; and his Apostles afterward, transmitted
 15974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same Spirit by Imposition of hands, as Moses did to Joshua. So that
 15975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is manifest hereby, in whom the Power Ecclesiasticall continually
 15976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tremained, in those first times, where there was not any Christian
 15977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; namely, in them that received the same from the Apostles,
 15978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby successive laying on of hands.
 15979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Trinity
 15984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 15985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHere wee have the Person of God born now the third time. For as Moses,
 15986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the High Priests, were Gods Representative in the Old Testament;
 15987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand our Saviour himselfe as Man, during his abode on earth: So the Holy
 15988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGhost, that is to say, the Apostles, and their successors, in the Office
 15989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Preaching, and Teaching, that had received the Holy Spirit, have
 15990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresented him ever since. But a Person, (as I have shewn before,
 15991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t[chapt. 16.].) is he that is Represented, as often as hee is
 15992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresented; and therefore God, who has been Represented (that is,
 15993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPersonated) thrice, may properly enough be said to be three Persons;
 15994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough neither the word Person, nor Trinity be ascribed to him in the
 15995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBible. St. John indeed (1 Epist. 5.7.) saith, "There be three that bear
 15996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twitnesse in heaven, the Father, the Word, and the Holy Spirit; and these
 15997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThree are One:" But this disagreeth not, but accordeth fitly with three
 15998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPersons in the proper signification of Persons; which is, that which is
 15999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresented by another. For so God the Father, as Represented by Moses,
 16000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis one Person; and as Represented by his Sonne, another Person, and as
 16001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresented by the Apostles, and by the Doctors that taught by authority
 16002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom them derived, is a third Person; and yet every Person here, is
 16003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Person of one and the same God. But a man may here ask, what it was
 16004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof these three bare witnesse. St. John therefore tells us (verse
 16005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t11.) that they bear witnesse, that "God hath given us eternall life
 16006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his Son." Again, if it should be asked, wherein that testimony
 16007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappeareth, the Answer is easie; for he hath testified the same by the
 16008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmiracles he wrought, first by Moses; secondly, by his Son himself; and
 16009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlastly by his Apostles, that had received the Holy Spirit; all which
 16010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin their times Represented the Person of God; and either prophecyed, or
 16011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreached Jesus Christ. And as for the Apostles, it was the character
 16012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Apostleship, in the twelve first and great Apostles, to bear
 16013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitnesse of his Resurrection; as appeareth expressely (Acts 1. ver.
 16014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t21,22.) where St Peter, when a new Apostle was to be chosen in the place
 16015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Judas Iscariot, useth these words, "Of these men which have companied
 16016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith us all the time that the Lord Jesus went in and out amongst us,
 16017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeginning at the Baptisme of John, unto that same day that hee was
 16018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaken up from us, must one bee ordained to be a Witnesse with us of his
 16019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResurrection:" which words interpret the Bearing of Witnesse, mentioned
 16020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby St. John. There is in the same place mentioned another Trinity of
 16021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitnesses in Earth. For (ver. 8.) he saith, "there are three that bear
 16022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitnesse in Earth, the Spirit, and the Water, and the Bloud; and these
 16023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthree agree in one:" that is to say, the graces of Gods Spirit, and the
 16024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttwo Sacraments, Baptisme, and the Lords Supper, which all agree in one
 16025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestimony, to assure the consciences of beleevers, of eternall life; of
 16026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich Testimony he saith (verse 10.) "He that beleeveth on the Son of
 16027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman hath the Witnesse in himselfe." In this Trinity on Earth the Unity
 16028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not of the thing; for the Spirit, the Water, and the Bloud, are not
 16029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same substance, though they give the same testimony: But in the
 16030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTrinity of Heaven, the Persons are the persons of one and the same God,
 16031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough Represented in three different times and occasions. To conclude,
 16032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe doctrine of the Trinity, as far as can be gathered directly from
 16033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Scripture, is in substance this; that God who is alwaies One and the
 16034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame, was the Person Represented by Moses; the Person Represented by
 16035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Son Incarnate; and the Person Represented by the Apostles. As
 16036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresented by the Apostles, the Holy Spirit by which they spake, is
 16037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod; As Represented by his Son (that was God and Man), the Son is that
 16038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod; As represented by Moses, and the High Priests, the Father, that is
 16039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, is that God: From whence
 16040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe may gather the reason why those names Father, Son, and Holy Spirit in
 16041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe signification of the Godhead, are never used in the Old Testament:
 16042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor they are Persons, that is, they have their names from Representing;
 16043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich could not be, till divers men had Represented Gods Person in
 16044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\truling, or in directing under him.
 16045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThus wee see how the Power Ecclesiasticall was left by our Saviour
 16047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Apostles; and how they were (to the end they might the better
 16048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texercise that Power,) endued with the Holy Spirit, which is therefore
 16049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled sometime in the New Testament Paracletus which signifieth an
 16050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssister, or one called to for helpe, though it bee commonly translated
 16051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Comforter. Let us now consider the Power it selfe, what it was, and
 16052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover whom.
 16053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Power Ecclesiasticall Is But The Power To Teach
 16058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCardinall Bellarmine in his third generall Controversie, hath handled a
 16060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat many questions concerning the Ecclesiasticall Power of the Pope
 16061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Rome; and begins with this, Whether it ought to be Monarchicall,
 16062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAristocraticall, or Democraticall. All which sorts of Power, are
 16063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, and Coercive. If now it should appear, that there is no
 16064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCoercive Power left them by our Saviour; but onely a Power to proclaim
 16065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Kingdom of Christ, and to perswade men to submit themselves
 16066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereunto; and by precepts and good counsell, to teach them that have
 16067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubmitted, what they are to do, that they may be received into the
 16068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdom of God when it comes; and that the Apostles, and other Ministers
 16069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Gospel, are our Schoolemasters, and not our Commanders, and their
 16070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrecepts not Laws, but wholesome Counsells then were all that dispute in
 16071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvain.
 16072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAn Argument Thereof, The Power Of Christ Himself
 16077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI have shewn already (in the last Chapter,) that the Kingdome of Christ
 16079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not of this world: therefore neither can his Ministers (unlesse they
 16080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Kings,) require obedience in his name. For if the Supreme King, have
 16081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot his Regall Power in this world; by what authority can obedience be
 16082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequired to his Officers? As my Father sent me, (so saith our Saviour)
 16083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI send you. But our Saviour was sent to perswade the Jews to return to,
 16084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to invite the Gentiles, to receive the Kingdome of his Father, and
 16085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot to reign in Majesty, no not, as his Fathers Lieutenant, till the day
 16086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Judgment.
 16087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom The Name Of Regeneration
 16092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe time between the Ascension, and the generall Resurrection, is
 16094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled, not a Reigning, but a Regeneration; that is, a Preparation
 16095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men for the second and glorious coming of Christ, at the day of
 16096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgment; as appeareth by the words of our Saviour, Mat. 19.28. "You
 16097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat have followed me in the Regeneration, when the Son of man shall sit
 16098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the throne of his glory, you shall also sit upon twelve Thrones;" And
 16099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof St. Paul (Ephes. 6.15.) "Having your feet shod with the Preparation
 16100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Gospell of Peace."
 16101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom The Comparison Of It, With Fishing, Leaven, Seed
 16106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd is compared by our Saviour, to Fishing; that is, to winning men
 16108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obedience, not by Coercion, and Punishing; but by Perswasion: and
 16109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore he said not to his Apostles, hee would make them so many
 16110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNimrods, Hunters Of Men; But Fishers Of Men. It is compared also to
 16111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLeaven; to Sowing of Seed, and to the Multiplication of a grain of
 16112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMustard-seed; by all which Compulsion is excluded; and consequently
 16113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere can in that time be no actual Reigning. The work of Christs
 16114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters, is Evangelization; that is, a Proclamation of Christ, and
 16115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta preparation for his second comming; as the Evangelization of John
 16116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBaptist, was a preparation to his first coming.
 16117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom The Nature Of Faith:
 16122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, the Office of Christs Ministers in this world, is to make men
 16124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBeleeve, and have Faith in Christ: But Faith hath no relation to, nor
 16125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdependence at all upon Compulsion, or Commandement; but onely upon
 16126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcertainty, or probability of Arguments drawn from Reason, or from
 16127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsomething men beleeve already. Therefore the Ministers of Christ in this
 16128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld, have no Power by that title, to Punish any man for not Beleeving,
 16129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor for Contradicting what they say; they have I say no Power by that
 16130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttitle of Christs Ministers, to Punish such: but if they have Soveraign
 16131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Power, by politick institution, then they may indeed lawfully
 16132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunish any Contradiction to their laws whatsoever: And St. Paul, of
 16133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe and other then Preachers of the Gospell saith in expresse
 16134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords, (2 Cor. 1.24.) "Wee have no Dominion over your Faith, but are
 16135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHelpers of your Joy."
 16136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom The Authority Christ Hath Left To Civill Princes
 16141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother Argument, that the Ministers of Christ in this present world
 16143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave no right of Commanding, may be drawn from the lawfull Authority
 16144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich Christ hath left to all Princes, as well Christians, as Infidels.
 16145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Paul saith (Col. 3.20.) "Children obey your Parents in all things;
 16146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor this is well pleasing to the Lord." And ver. 22. "Servants obey in
 16147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall things your Masters according to the flesh, not with eye-service, as
 16148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen-pleasers, but in singlenesse of heart, as fearing the Lord;" This is
 16149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspoken to them whose Masters were Infidells; and yet they are bidden
 16150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey them In All Things. And again, concerning obedience to Princes.
 16151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Rom. 13. the first 6. verses) exhorting to "be subject to the Higher
 16152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPowers," he saith, "that all Power is ordained of God;" and "that we
 16153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought to be subject to them, not onely for" fear of incurring their
 16154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"wrath, but also for conscience sake." And St. Peter, (1 Epist. chap. 2e
 16155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tver. 13, 14, 15.) "Submit your selves to every Ordinance of Man, for the
 16156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLords sake, whether it bee to the King, as Supreme, or unto Governours,
 16157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas to them that be sent by him for the punishment of evill doers, and
 16158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the praise of them that doe well; for so is the will of God."
 16159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd again St. Paul (Tit. 3.1.) "Put men in mind to be subject to
 16160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrincipalities, and Powers, and to obey Magistrates." These Princes, and
 16161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPowers, whereof St. Peter, and St. Paul here speak, were all Infidels;
 16162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmuch more therefore we are to obey those Christians, whom God hath
 16163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordained to have Soveraign Power over us. How then can wee be obliged
 16164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto doe any thing contrary to the Command of the King, or other Soveraign
 16165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentant of the Common-wealth, whereof we are members, and by whom
 16166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe look to be protected? It is therefore manifest, that Christ hath not
 16167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleft to his Ministers in this world, unlesse they be also endued with
 16168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Authority, any authority to Command other men.
 16169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat Christians May Do To Avoid Persecution
 16174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut what (may some object) if a King, or a Senate, or other Soveraign
 16176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson forbid us to beleeve in Christ? To this I answer, that such
 16177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforbidding is of no effect, because Beleef, and Unbeleef never follow
 16178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmens Commands. Faith is a gift of God, which Man can neither give, nor
 16179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake away by promise of rewards, or menaces of torture. And if it be
 16180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfurther asked, What if wee bee commanded by our lawfull Prince, to say
 16181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith our tongue, wee beleeve not; must we obey such command? Profession
 16182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the tongue is but an externall thing, and no more then any other
 16183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgesture whereby we signifie our obedience; and wherein a Christian,
 16184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tholding firmely in his heart the Faith of Christ, hath the same liberty
 16185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Prophet Elisha allowed to Naaman the Syrian. Naaman was
 16186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconverted in his heart to the God of Israel; For hee saith (2 Kings
 16187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t5.17.) "Thy servant will henceforth offer neither burnt offering, nor
 16188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsacrifice unto other Gods but unto the Lord. In this thing the Lord
 16189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpardon thy servant, that when my Master goeth into the house of Rimmon
 16190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto worship there, and he leaneth on my hand, and I bow my selfe in the
 16191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thouse of Rimmon; when I bow my selfe in the house of Rimmon, the Lord
 16192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpardon thy servant in this thing." This the Prophet approved, and bid
 16193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim "Goe in peace." Here Naaman beleeved in his heart; but by bowing
 16194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore the Idol Rimmon, he denyed the true God in effect, as much as
 16195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif he had done it with his lips. But then what shall we answer to our
 16196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviours saying, "Whosoever denyeth me before men, I will deny him
 16197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore my Father which is in Heaven?" This we may say, that whatsoever
 16198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Subject, as Naaman was, is compelled to in obedience to his Soveraign,
 16199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand doth it not in order to his own mind, but in order to the laws of
 16200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this country, that action is not his, but his Soveraigns; nor is it he
 16201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat in this case denyeth Christ before men, but his Governour, and the
