 16202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlaw of his countrey. If any man shall accuse this doctrine, as repugnant
 16203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto true, and unfeigned Christianity; I ask him, in case there should be
 16204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta subject in any Christian Common-wealth, that should be inwardly in his
 16205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theart of the Mahometan Religion, whether if his Soveraign Command him to
 16206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee present at the divine service of the Christian Church, and that on
 16207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpain of death, he think that Mamometan obliged in conscience to suffer
 16208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeath for that cause, rather than to obey that command of his lawful
 16209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrince. If he say, he ought rather to suffer death, then he authorizeth
 16210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall private men, to disobey their Princes, in maintenance of their
 16211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion, true, or false; if he say, he ought to bee obedient, then he
 16212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talloweth to himself, that which hee denyeth to another, contrary to the
 16213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords of our Saviour, "Whatsoever you would that men should doe unto
 16214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyou, that doe yee unto them;" and contrary to the Law of Nature, (which
 16215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the indubitable everlasting Law of God) "Do not to another, that
 16216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich thou wouldest not he should doe unto thee."
 16217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Martyrs
 16222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut what then shall we say of all those Martyrs we read of in the
 16224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHistory of the Church, that they have needlessely cast away their lives?
 16225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor answer hereunto, we are to distinguish the persons that have been
 16226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor that cause put to death; whereof some have received a Calling to
 16227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreach, and professe the Kingdome of Christ openly; others have had no
 16228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch Calling, nor more has been required of them than their owne faith.
 16229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe former sort, if they have been put to death, for bearing witnesse to
 16230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis point, that Jesus Christ is risen from the dead, were true Martyrs;
 16231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor a Martyr is, (to give the true definition of the word) a Witnesse of
 16232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Resurrection of Jesus the Messiah; which none can be but those
 16233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat conversed with him on earth, and saw him after he was risen: For a
 16234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitnesse must have seen what he testifieth, or else his testimony is not
 16235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood. And that none but such, can properly be called Martyrs of Christ,
 16236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis manifest out of the words of St. Peter, Act. 1.21, 22. "Wherefore of
 16237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese men which have companyed with us all the time that the Lord Jesus
 16238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twent in and out amongst us, beginning from the Baptisme of John unto
 16239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat same day hee was taken up from us, must one be ordained to be a
 16240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMartyr (that is a Witnesse) with us of his Resurrection:" Where we
 16241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay observe, that he which is to bee a Witnesse of the truth of
 16242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Resurrection of Christ, that is to say, of the truth of this
 16243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfundamentall article of Christian Religion, that Jesus was the Christ,
 16244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmust be some Disciple that conversed with him, and saw him before, and
 16245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter his Resurrection; and consequently must be one of his originall
 16246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDisciples: whereas they which were not so, can Witnesse no more, but
 16247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat their antecessors said it, and are therefore but Witnesses of
 16248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother mens testimony; and are but second Martyrs, or Martyrs of Christs
 16249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitnesses.
 16250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHe, that to maintain every doctrine which he himself draweth out of
 16252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe History of our Saviours life, and of the Acts, or Epistles of the
 16253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles; or which he beleeveth upon the authority of a private man,
 16254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twil oppose the Laws and Authority of the Civill State, is very far from
 16255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing a Martyr of Christ, or a Martyr of his Martyrs. 'Tis one Article
 16256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely, which to die for, meriteth so honorable a name; and that Article
 16257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis this, that Jesus Is The Christ; that is to say, He that hath redeemed
 16258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tus, and shall come again to give us salvation, and eternall life in his
 16259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tglorious Kingdome. To die for every tenet that serveth the ambition,
 16260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor profit of the Clergy, is not required; nor is it the Death of the
 16261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitnesse, but the Testimony it self that makes the Martyr: for the word
 16262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifieth nothing else, but the man that beareth Witnesse, whether he
 16263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe put to death for his testimony, or not.
 16264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAlso he that is not sent to preach this fundamentall article, but taketh
 16266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit upon him of his private authority, though he be a Witnesse, and
 16267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently a Martyr, either primary of Christ, or secondary of his
 16268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles, Disciples, or their Successors; yet is he not obliged to
 16269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuffer death for that cause; because being not called thereto, tis
 16270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot required at his hands; nor ought hee to complain, if he loseth
 16271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe reward he expecteth from those that never set him on work. None
 16272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore can be a Martyr, neither of the first, nor second degree, that
 16273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave not a warrant to preach Christ come in the flesh; that is to say,
 16274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone, but such as are sent to the conversion of Infidels. For no man
 16275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis a Witnesse to him that already beleeveth, and therefore needs no
 16276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWitnesse; but to them that deny, or doubt, or have not heard it. Christ
 16277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsent his Apostles, and his Seventy Disciples, with authority to preach;
 16278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the sent not all that beleeved: And he sent them to unbeleevers; "I send
 16279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyou (saith he) as sheep amongst wolves;" not as sheep to other sheep.
 16280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArgument From The Points Of Their Commission
 16285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly the points of their Commission, as they are expressely set down
 16287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Gospel, contain none of them any authority over the Congregation.
 16288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Preach
 16293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWe have first (Mat. 10.) that the twelve Apostles were sent "to the
 16295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlost sheep of the house of Israel," and commanded to Preach, "that the
 16296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God was at hand." Now Preaching in the originall, is that
 16297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tact, which a Crier, Herald, or other Officer useth to doe publiquely in
 16298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProclaiming of a King. But a Crier hath not right to Command any man.
 16299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd (Luke 10.2.) the seventy Disciples are sent out, "as Labourers,
 16300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot as Lords of the Harvest;" and are bidden (verse 9.) to say, "The
 16301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God is come nigh unto you;" and by Kingdome here is meant,
 16302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot the Kingdome of Grace, but the Kingdome of Glory; for they are
 16303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbidden to denounce it (ver. 11.) to those Cities which shall not receive
 16304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, as a threatning, that it shall be more tolerable in that day for
 16305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSodome, than for such a City. And (Mat. 20.28.) our Saviour telleth his
 16306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDisciples, that sought Priority of place, their Office was to minister,
 16307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teven as the Son of man came, not to be ministred unto, but to minister.
 16308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPreachers therefore have not Magisteriall, but Ministeriall power: "Bee
 16309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot called Masters, (saith our Saviour, Mat. 23.10) for one is your
 16310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMaster, even Christ."
 16311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd Teach
 16316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother point of their Commission, is, to Teach All Nations; as it is in
 16318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMat. 28.19. or as in St. Mark 16.15 "Goe into all the world, and Preach
 16319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Gospel to every creature." Teaching therefore, and Preaching is the
 16320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame thing. For they that Proclaim the comming of a King, must withall
 16321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake known by what right he commeth, if they mean men shall submit
 16322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves unto him: As St. Paul did to the Jews of Thessalonica,
 16323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen "three Sabbath days he reasoned with them out of the Scriptures,
 16324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topening, and alledging that Christ must needs have suffered, and risen
 16325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain from the dead, and that this Jesus is Christ." But to teach out
 16326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Old Testament that Jesus was Christ, (that is to say, King,)
 16327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand risen from the dead, is not to say, that men are bound after they
 16328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve it, to obey those that tell them so, against the laws, and
 16329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommands of their Soveraigns; but that they shall doe wisely, to expect
 16330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe coming of Christ hereafter, in Patience, and Faith, with Obedience
 16331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto their present Magistrates.
 16332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Baptize;
 16337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother point of their Commission, is to Baptize, "in the name of
 16339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost." What is Baptisme?
 16340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDipping into water. But what is it to Dip a man into the water in the
 16341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of any thing? The meaning of these words of Baptisme is this. He
 16342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is Baptized, is Dipped or Washed, as a sign of becomming a new man,
 16343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand a loyall subject to that God, whose Person was represented in old
 16344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime by Moses, and the High Priests, when he reigned over the Jews; and
 16345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Jesus Christ, his Sonne, God, and Man, that hath redeemed us, and
 16346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall in his humane nature Represent his Fathers Person in his eternall
 16347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome after the Resurrection; and to acknowledge the Doctrine of the
 16348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles, who assisted by the Spirit of the Father, and of the Son, were
 16349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleft for guides to bring us into that Kingdome, to be the onely, and
 16350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassured way thereunto. This, being our promise in Baptisme; and the
 16351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority of Earthly Soveraigns being not to be put down till the day of
 16352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgment; (for that is expressely affirmed by S. Paul 1 Cor. 15. 22, 23,
 16353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t24. where he saith, "As in Adam all die, so in Christ all shall be
 16354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade alive. But every man in his owne order, Christ the first fruits,
 16355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafterward they that are Christs, at his comming; Then Commeth the end,
 16356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen he shall have delivered up the Kingdome of God, even the Father,
 16357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen he shall have put down all Rule, and all Authority and Power")
 16358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is manifest, that we do not in Baptisme constitute over us another
 16359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority, by which our externall actions are to be governed in this
 16360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife; but promise to take the doctrine of the Apostles for our direction
 16361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the way to life eternall.
 16362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd To Forgive, And Retain Sinnes
 16367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Power of Remission, And Retention Of Sinnes, called also the Power
 16369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Loosing, and Binding, and sometimes the Keyes Of The Kingdome Of
 16370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeaven, is a consequence of the Authority to Baptize, or refuse to
 16371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBaptize. For Baptisme is the Sacrament of Allegeance, of them that are
 16372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be received into the Kingdome of God; that is to say, into Eternall
 16373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife; that is to say, to Remission of Sin: For as Eternall life was lost
 16374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Committing, so it is recovered by the Remitting of mens Sins. The
 16375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tend of Baptisme is Remission of Sins: and therefore St. Peter, when they
 16376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat were converted by his Sermon on the day of Pentecost, asked what
 16377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were to doe, advised them to "repent, and be Baptized in the name
 16378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Jesus, for the Remission of Sins." And therefore seeing to Baptize
 16379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to declare the Reception of men into Gods Kingdome; and to refuse to
 16380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBaptize is to declare their Exclusion; it followeth, that the Power
 16381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto declare them Cast out, or Retained in it, was given to the same
 16382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles, and their Substitutes, and Successors. And therefore after our
 16383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour had breathed upon them, saying, (John 20.22.) "Receive the Holy
 16384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGhost," hee addeth in the next verse, "Whose soever Sins ye Remit,
 16385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are Remitted unto them; and whose soever Sins ye Retain, they are
 16386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRetained." By which words, is not granted an Authority to Forgive, or
 16387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRetain Sins, simply and absolutely, as God Forgiveth or Retaineth them,
 16388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho knoweth the Heart of man, and truth of his Penitence and Conversion;
 16389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut conditionally, to the Penitent: And this Forgivenesse, or
 16390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbsolution, in case the absolved have but a feigned Repentance, is
 16391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereby without other act, or sentence of the Absolvent, made void,
 16392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand hath no effect at all to Salvation, but on the contrary, to the
 16393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAggravation of his Sin. Therefore the Apostles, and their Successors,
 16394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare to follow but the outward marks of Repentance; which appearing, they
 16395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave no Authority to deny Absolution; and if they appeare not, they have
 16396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno authority to Absolve. The same also is to be observed in Baptisme:
 16397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor to a converted Jew, or Gentile, the Apostles had not the Power to
 16398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeny Baptisme; nor to grant it to the Un-penitent. But seeing no man is
 16399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\table to discern the truth of another mans Repentance, further than by
 16400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texternall marks, taken from his words, and actions, which are subject to
 16401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thypocrisie; another question will arise, Who it is that is constituted
 16402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudge of those marks. And this question is decided by our Saviour
 16403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself; (Mat. 18. 15, 16, 17.) "If thy Brother (saith he) shall
 16404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrespasse against thee, go and tell him his fault between thee, and him
 16405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talone; if he shall hear thee, thou hast gained thy Brother. But if he
 16406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill not hear thee, then take with thee one, or two more. And if he
 16407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall neglect to hear them, tell it unto the Church, let him be unto
 16408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthee as an Heathen man, and a Publican." By which it is manifest, that
 16409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Judgment concerning the truth of Repentance, belonged not to any one
 16410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMan, but to the Church, that is, to the Assembly of the Faithfull, or
 16411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto them that have authority to bee their Representant. But besides the
 16412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgment, there is necessary also the pronouncing of Sentence: And
 16413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis belonged alwaies to the Apostle, or some Pastor of the Church,
 16414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas Prolocutor; and of this our Saviour speaketh in the 18 verse,
 16415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Whatsoever ye shall bind on earth, shall be bound in heaven; and
 16416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever ye shall loose on earth, shall be loosed in heaven." And
 16417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomformable hereunto was the practise of St. Paul (1 Cor. 5.3, 4, & 5.)
 16418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere he saith, "For I verily, as absent in body, but present in spirit,
 16419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave determined already, as though I were present, concerning him that
 16420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath so done this deed; In the name of our Lord Jesus Christ when ye
 16421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare gathered together, and my spirit, with the power of our Lord Jesus
 16422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, To deliver such a one to Satan;" that is to say, to cast him
 16423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of the Church, as a man whose Sins are not Forgiven. Paul here
 16424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpronounceth the Sentence; but the Assembly was first to hear the Cause,
 16425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(for St. Paul was absent;) and by consequence to condemn him. But in
 16426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same chapter (ver. 11, 12.) the Judgment in such a case is more
 16427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpressely attributed to the Assembly: "But now I have written unto
 16428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyou, not to keep company, if any man that is called a Brother be a
 16429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFornicator, &c. with such a one no not to eat. For what have I to do to
 16430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudg them that are without? Do not ye judg them that are within?"
 16431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Sentence therefore by which a man was put out of the Church, was
 16432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpronounced by the Apostle, or Pastor; but the Judgment concerning the
 16433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmerit of the cause, was in the Church; that is to say, (as the times
 16434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere before the conversion of Kings, and men that had Soveraign
 16435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority in the Common-wealth,) the Assembly of the Christians dwelling
 16436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the same City; as in Corinth, in the Assembly of the Christians of
 16437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCorinth.
 16438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Excommunication
 16443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis part of the Power of the Keyes, by which men were thrust out from
 16445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Kingdome of God, is that which is called Excommunication; and to
 16446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texcommunicate, is in the Originall, Aposunagogon Poiein, To Cast Out Of
 16447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Synagogue; that is, out of the place of Divine service; a word drawn
 16448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the custom of the Jews, to cast out of their Synagogues, such as
 16449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey thought in manners, or doctrine, contagious, as Lepers were by the
 16450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw of Moses separated from the congregation of Israel, till such time
 16451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they should be by the Priest pronounced clean.
 16452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Use Of Excommunication Without Civill Power.
 16457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Use and Effect of Excommunication, whilest it was not yet
 16459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstrengthened with the Civill Power, was no more, than that they, who
 16460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere not Excommunicate, were to avoid the company of them that were.
 16461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt was not enough to repute them as Heathen, that never had been
 16462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristians; for with such they might eate, and drink; which with
 16463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcommunicate persons they might not do; as appeareth by the words of
 16464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Paul, (1 Cor. 5. ver. 9, 10, &c.) where he telleth them, he had
 16465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformerly forbidden them to "company with Fornicators;" but (because that
 16466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcould not bee without going out of the world,) he restraineth it to such
 16467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFornicators, and otherwise vicious persons, as were of the brethren;
 16468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"with such a one" (he saith) they ought not to keep company, "no, not to
 16469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teat." And this is no more than our Saviour saith (Mat. 18.17.) "Let
 16470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim be to thee as a Heathen, and as a Publican." For Publicans (which
 16471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifieth Farmers, and Receivers of the revenue of the Common-wealth)
 16472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere so hated, and detested by the Jews that were to pay for it, as
 16473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Publican and Sinner were taken amongst them for the same thing:
 16474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInsomuch, as when our Saviour accepted the invitation of Zacchaeus a
 16475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublican; though it were to Convert him, yet it was objected to him as
 16476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Crime. And therefore, when our Saviour, to Heathen, added Publican, he
 16477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdid forbid them to eat with a man Excommunicate.
 16478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for keeping them out of their Synagogues, or places of Assembly, they
 16480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad no Power to do it, but that of the owner of the place, whether he
 16481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere Christian, or Heathen. And because all places are by right, in the
 16482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominion of the Common-wealth; as well hee that was Excommunicated, as
 16483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee that never was Baptized, might enter into them by Commission from
 16484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Civill Magistrate; as Paul before his conversion entred into their
 16485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSynagogues at Damascus, (Acts 9.2.) to apprehend Christians, men and
 16486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twomen, and to carry them bound to Jerusalem, by Commission from the High
 16487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriest.
 16488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf No Effect Upon An Apostate
 16493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy which it appears, that upon a Christian, that should become an
 16495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostate, in a place where the Civill Power did persecute, or not assist
 16496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Church, the effect of Excommunication had nothing in it, neither of
 16497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdammage in this world, nor of terrour: Not of terrour, because of their
 16498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunbeleef; nor of dammage, because they returned thereby into the favour
 16499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the world; and in the world to come, were to be in no worse estate,
 16500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen they which never had beleeved. The dammage redounded rather to the
 16501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, by provocation of them they cast out, to a freer execution of
 16502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir malice.
 16503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut Upon The Faithfull Only
 16508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcommunication therefore had its effect onely upon those, that beleeved
 16510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Jesus Christ was to come again in Glory, to reign over, and to
 16511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudge both the quick, and the dead, and should therefore refuse entrance
 16512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto his Kingdom, to those whose Sins were Retained; that is, to those
 16513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat were Excommunicated by the Church. And thence it is that St. Paul
 16514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalleth Excommunication, a delivery of the Excommunicate person to
 16515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSatan. For without the Kingdom of Christ, all other Kingdomes after
 16516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgment, are comprehended in the Kingdome of Satan. This is it that the
 16517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaithfull stood in fear of, as long as they stood Excommunicate, that is
 16518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, in an estate wherein their sins were not Forgiven. Whereby wee
 16519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay understand, that Excommunication in the time that Christian Religion
 16520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas not authorized by the Civill Power, was used onely for a correction
 16521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof manners, not of errours in opinion: for it is a punishment, whereof
 16522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone could be sensible but such as beleeved, and expected the coming
 16523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain of our Saviour to judge the world; and they who so beleeved,
 16524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneeded no other opinion, but onely uprightnesse of life, to be saved.
 16525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor What Fault Lyeth Excommunication
 16530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere Lyeth Excommunication for Injustice; as (Mat. 18.) If thy Brother
 16532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toffend thee, tell it him privately; then with Witnesses; lastly, tell
 16533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Church; and then if he obey not, "Let him be to thee as an Heathen
 16534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, and a Publican." And there lyeth Excommunication for a Scandalous
 16535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLife, as (1 Cor. 5. 11.) "If any man that is called a Brother, be
 16536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Fornicator, or Covetous, or an Idolater, or a Drunkard, or an
 16537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExtortioner, with such a one yee are not to eat." But to Excommunicate a
 16538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman that held this foundation, that Jesus Was The Christ, for difference
 16539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof opinion in other points, by which that Foundation was not destroyed,
 16540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere appeareth no authority in the Scripture, nor example in the
 16541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles. There is indeed in St. Paul (Titus 3.10.) a text that seemeth
 16542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be to the contrary. "A man that is an Haeretique, after the first
 16543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand second admonition, reject." For an Haeretique, is he, that being a
 16544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmember of the Church, teacheth neverthelesse some private opinion, which
 16545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Church has forbidden: and such a one, S. Paul adviseth Titus, after
 16546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe first, and second admonition, to Reject. But to Reject (in this
 16547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace) is not to Excommunicate the Man; But to Give Over Admonishing
 16548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHim, To Let Him Alone, To Set By Disputing With Him, as one that is to
 16549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe convinced onely by himselfe. The same Apostle saith (2 Tim. 2.23.)
 16550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Foolish and unlearned questions avoid;" The word Avoid in this place,
 16551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Reject in the former, is the same in the Originall, paraitou: but
 16552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFoolish questions may bee set by without Excommunication. And again,
 16553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Tit. 3.93) "Avoid Foolish questions," where the Originall, periistaso,
 16554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(set them by) is equivalent to the former word Reject. There is no
 16555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother place that can so much as colourably be drawn, to countenance
 16556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Casting out of the Church faithfull men, such as beleeved the
 16557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfoundation, onely for a singular superstructure of their own, proceeding
 16558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperhaps from a good & pious conscience. But on the contrary, all such
 16559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaces as command avoiding such disputes, are written for a Lesson to
 16560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors, (such as Timothy and Titus were) not to make new Articles of
 16561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith, by determining every small controversie, which oblige men to a
 16562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneedlesse burthen of Conscience, or provoke them to break the union of
 16563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Church. Which Lesson the Apostles themselves observed well. S. Peter
 16564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand S. Paul, though their controversie were great, (as we may read
 16565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Gal. 2.11.) yet they did not cast one another out of the Church.
 16566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse, during the Apostles time, there were other Pastors that
 16567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserved it not; As Diotrephes (3 John 9. &c.) who cast out of the
 16568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, such as S. John himself thought fit to be received into it, out
 16569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a pride he took in Praeeminence; so early it was, that Vainglory, and
 16570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAmbition had found entrance into the Church of Christ.
 16571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Persons Liable To Excommunication
 16576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat a man be liable to Excommunication, there be many conditions
 16578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequisite; as First, that he be a member of some Commonalty, that is to
 16579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, of some lawfull Assembly, that is to say, of some Christian
 16580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, that hath power to judge of the cause for which hee is to
 16581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee Excommunicated. For where there is no community, there can bee no
 16582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcommunication; nor where there is no power to Judge, can there bee any
 16583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower to give Sentence. From hence it followeth, that one Church cannot
 16584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Excommunicated by another: For either they have equall power
 16585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Excommunicate each other, in which case Excommunication is not
 16586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDiscipline, nor an act of Authority, but Schisme, and Dissolution of
 16587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcharity; or one is so subordinate to the other, as that they both
 16588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave but one voice, and then they be but one Church; and the part
 16589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcommunicated, is no more a Church, but a dissolute number of
 16590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tindividuall persons.
 16591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because the sentence of Excommunication, importeth an advice, not to
 16593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkeep company, nor so much as to eat with him that is Excommunicate, if
 16594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Soveraign Prince, or Assembly bee Excommunicate, the sentence is of no
 16595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teffect. For all Subjects are bound to be in the company and presence of
 16596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own Soveraign (when he requireth it) by the law of Nature; nor
 16597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan they lawfully either expell him from any place of his own Dominion,
 16598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhether profane or holy; nor go out of his Dominion, without his leave;
 16599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmuch lesse (if he call them to that honour,) refuse to eat with him. And
 16600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas to other Princes and States, because they are not parts of one and
 16601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same congregation, they need not any other sentence to keep
 16602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem from keeping company with the State Excommunicate: for the
 16603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery Institution, as it uniteth many men into one Community; so it
 16604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdissociateth one Community from another: so that Excommunication is
 16605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot needfull for keeping Kings and States asunder; nor has any further
 16606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teffect then is in the nature of Policy it selfe; unlesse it be to
 16607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinstigate Princes to warre upon one another.
 16608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor is the Excommunication of a Christian Subject, that obeyeth the laws
 16610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his own Soveraign, whether Christian, or Heathen, of any effect. For
 16611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif he beleeve that "Jesus is the Christ, he hath the Spirit of God" (1
 16612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJoh. 4.1.) "and God dwelleth in him, and he in God," (1 Joh. 4.15.) But
 16613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee that hath the Spirit of God; hee that dwelleth in God; hee in
 16614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom God dwelleth, can receive no harm by the Excommunication of men.
 16615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore, he that beleeveth Jesus to be the Christ, is free from all
 16616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe dangers threatned to persons Excommunicate. He that beleeveth it
 16617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot, is no Christian. Therefore a true and unfeigned Christian is not
 16618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tliable to Excommunication; Nor he also that is a professed Christian,
 16619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttill his Hypocrisy appear in his Manners, that is, till his behaviour
 16620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee contrary to the law of his Soveraign, which is the rule of Manners,
 16621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand which Christ and his Apostles have commanded us to be subject to.
 16622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the Church cannot judge of Manners but by externall Actions, which
 16623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActions can never bee unlawfull, but when they are against the Law of
 16624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Common-wealth.
 16625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a mans Father, or Mother, or Master bee Excommunicate, yet are not
 16627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Children forbidden to keep them Company, nor to Eat with them; for
 16628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat were (for the most part) to oblige them not to eat at all, for want
 16629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof means to get food; and to authorise them to disobey their Parents,
 16630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Masters, contrary to the Precept of the Apostles.
 16631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn summe, the Power of Excommunication cannot be extended further than
 16633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the end for which the Apostles and Pastors of the Church have
 16634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Commission from our Saviour; which is not to rule by Command and
 16635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCoaction, but by Teaching and Direction of men in the way of Salvation
 16636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the world to come. And as a Master in any Science, may abandon his
 16637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScholar, when hee obstinately neglecteth the practise of his rules; but
 16638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot accuse him of Injustice, because he was never bound to obey him:
 16639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso a Teacher of Christian doctrine may abandon his Disciples that
 16640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobstinately continue in an unchristian life; but he cannot say, they doe
 16641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim wrong, because they are not obliged to obey him: For to a Teacher
 16642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat shall so complain, may be applyed the Answer of God to Samuel in
 16643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe like place, (1 Sam. 8.) "They have not rejected thee, but mee."
 16644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcommunication therefore when it wanteth the assistance of the Civill
 16645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower, as it doth, when a Christian State, or Prince is Excommunicate
 16646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby a forain Authority, is without effect; and consequently ought to
 16647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe without terrour. The name of Fulmen Excommunicationis (that is, the
 16648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThunderbolt Of Excommunication) proceeded from an imagination of the
 16649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBishop of Rome, which first used it, that he was King of Kings, as the
 16650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeathen made Jupiter King of the Gods; and assigned him in their Poems,
 16651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Pictures, a Thunderbolt, wherewith to subdue, and punish the Giants,
 16652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat should dare to deny his power: Which imagination was grounded on
 16653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttwo errours; one, that the Kingdome of Christ is of this world, contrary
 16654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto our Saviours owne words, "My Kingdome is not of this world;" the
 16655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother, that hee is Christs Vicar, not onely over his owne Subjects,
 16656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut over all the Christians of the World; whereof there is no ground in
 16657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture, and the contrary shall bee proved in its due place.
 16658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Interpreter Of The Scriptures Before Civill Soveraigns
 16663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBecame Christians
 16665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Paul coming to Thessalonica, where was a Synagogue of the Jews,
 16667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Acts 17.2, 3.) "As his manner was, went in unto them, and three Sabbath
 16668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdayes reasoned with them out of the Scriptures, Opening and alledging,
 16669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Christ must needs have suffered and risen again from the dead; and
 16670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat this Jesus whom he preached was the Christ." The Scriptures here
 16671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmentioned were the Scriptures of the Jews, that is, the Old Testament.
 16672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe men, to whom he was to prove that Jesus was the Christ, and risen
 16673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain from the dead, were also Jews, and did beleeve already, that
 16674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were the Word of God. Hereupon (as it is verse 4.) some of them
 16675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeved, and (as it is in the 5. ver.) some beleeved not. What was
 16676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe reason, when they all beleeved the Scripture, that they did not
 16677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall beleeve alike; but that some approved, others disapproved the
 16678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpretation of St. Paul that cited them; and every one Interpreted
 16679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem to himself? It was this; S. Paul came to them without any Legall
 16680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommission, and in the manner of one that would not Command, but
 16681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerswade; which he must needs do, either by Miracles, as Moses did
 16682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Israelites in Egypt, that they might see his Authority in Gods
 16683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworks; or by Reasoning from the already received Scripture, that
 16684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey might see the truth of his doctrine in Gods Word. But whosoever
 16685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperswadeth by reasoning from principles written, maketh him to whom hee
 16686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeaketh Judge, both of the meaning of those principles, and also of the
 16687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforce of his inferences upon them. If these Jews of Thessalonica were
 16688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot, who else was the Judge of what S. Paul alledged out of Scripture?
 16689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf S. Paul, what needed he to quote any places to prove his doctrine? It
 16690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad been enough to have said, I find it so in Scripture, that is to
 16691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, in your Laws, of which I am Interpreter, as sent by Christ. The
 16692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpreter therefore of the Scripture, to whose Interpretation the
 16693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJews of Thessalonica were bound to stand, could be none: every one might
 16694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve, or not beleeve, according as the Allegations seemed to himselfe
 16695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be agreeable, or not agreeable to the meaning of the places alledged.
 16696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd generally in all cases of the world, hee that pretendeth any proofe,
 16697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmaketh Judge of his proofe him to whom he addresseth his speech. And as
 16698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the case of the Jews in particular, they were bound by expresse words
 16699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Deut. 17.) to receive the determination of all hard questions, from
 16700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Priests and Judges of Israel for the time being. But this is to bee
 16701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood of the Jews that were yet unconverted.
 16702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the Conversion of the Gentiles, there was no use of alledging the
 16704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScriptures, which they beleeved not. The Apostles therefore laboured by
 16705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason to confute their Idolatry; and that done, to perswade them to the
 16706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaith of Christ, by their testimony of his Life, and Resurrection. So
 16707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat there could not yet bee any controversie concerning the authority
 16708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Interpret Scripture; seeing no man was obliged during his infidelity,
 16709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto follow any mans Interpretation of any Scripture, except his
 16710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns Interpretation of the Laws of his countrey.
 16711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLet us now consider the Conversion it self, and see what there was
 16713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherein, that could be cause of such an obligation. Men were converted
 16714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto no other thing then to the Beleef of that which the Apostles
 16715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreached: And the Apostles preached nothing, but that Jesus was the
 16716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, that is to say, the King that was to save them, and reign over
 16717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem eternally in the world to come; and consequently that hee was not
 16718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdead, but risen again from the dead, and gone up into Heaven, and should
 16719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome again one day to judg the world, (which also should rise again to
 16720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe judged,) and reward every man according to his works. None of them
 16721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreached that himselfe, or any other Apostle was such an Interpreter
 16722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Scripture, as all that became Christians, ought to take their
 16723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpretation for Law. For to Interpret the Laws, is part of the
 16724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdministration of a present Kingdome; which the Apostles had not. They
 16725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprayed then, and all other Pastors ever since, "Let thy Kingdome come;"
 16726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand exhorted their Converts to obey their then Ethnique Princes. The New
 16727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestament was not yet published in one Body. Every of the Evangelists
 16728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas Interpreter of his own Gospel; and every Apostle of his own Epistle;
 16729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd of the Old Testament, our Saviour himselfe saith to the Jews (John
 16730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t5. 39.) "Search the Scriptures; for in them yee thinke to have eternall
 16731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife, and they are they that testifie of me." If hee had not meant they
 16732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould Interpret them, hee would not have bidden them take thence the
 16733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproof of his being the Christ; he would either have Interpreted them
 16734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe, or referred them to the Interpretation of the Priests.
 16735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen a difficulty arose, the Apostles and Elders of the Church assembled
 16737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves together, and determined what should bee preached, and
 16738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaught, and how they should Interpret the Scriptures to the People;
 16739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut took not from the People the liberty to read, and Interpret them to
 16740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves. The Apostles sent divers Letters to the Churches, and other
 16741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWritings for their instruction; which had been in vain, if they had not
 16742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallowed them to Interpret, that is, to consider the meaning of them.
 16743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as it was in the Apostles time, it must be till such time as
 16744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere should be Pastors, that could authorise an Interpreter, whose
 16745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpretation should generally be stood to: But that could not be till
 16746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings were Pastors, or Pastors Kings.
 16747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Power To Make Scripture Law
 16752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere be two senses, wherein a Writing may be said to be Canonicall;
 16754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Canon, signifieth a Rule; and a Rule is a Precept, by which a man
 16755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis guided, and directed in any action whatsoever. Such Precepts, though
 16756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiven by a Teacher to his Disciple, or a Counsellor to his friend,
 16757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout power to Compell him to observe them, are neverthelesse Canons;
 16758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause they are Rules: But when they are given by one, whom he that
 16759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceiveth them is bound to obey, then are those Canons, not onely Rules,
 16760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut Laws: The question therefore here, is of the Power to make the
 16761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScriptures (which are the Rules of Christian Faith) Laws.
 16762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Ten Commandements
 16767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat part of the Scripture, which was first Law, was the Ten
 16769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandements, written in two Tables of Stone, and delivered by God
 16770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe to Moses; and by Moses made known to the people. Before that
 16771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime there was no written Law of God, who as yet having not chosen any
 16772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople to bee his peculiar Kingdome, had given no Law to men, but the
 16773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw of Nature, that is to say, the Precepts of Naturall Reason, written
 16774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin every mans own heart. Of these two Tables, the first containeth the
 16775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlaw of Soveraignty; 1. That they should not obey, nor honour the Gods of
 16776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Nations, in these words, "Non habebis Deos alienos coram me," that
 16777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, "Thou shalt not have for Gods, the Gods that other Nations worship;
 16778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut onely me:" whereby they were forbidden to obey, or honor, as their
 16779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing and Governour, any other God, than him that spake unto them then by
 16780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses, and afterwards by the High Priest. 2. That they "should not make
 16781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany Image to represent him;" that is to say, they were not to choose to
 16782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, neither in heaven, nor in earth, any Representative of their
 16783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town fancying, but obey Moses and Aaron, whom he had appointed to that
 16784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toffice. 3. That "they should not take the Name of God in vain;" that is,
 16785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey should not speak rashly of their King, nor dispute his Right,
 16786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor the commissions of Moses and Aaron, his Lieutenants. 4. That "they
 16787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould every Seventh day abstain from their ordinary labour," and employ
 16788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat time in doing him Publique Honor. The second Table containeth the
 16789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDuty of one man towards another, as "To honor Parents; Not to kill;
 16790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNot to Commit Adultery; Not to steale; Not to corrupt Judgment by false
 16791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twitnesse;" and finally, "Not so much as to designe in their heart the
 16792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoing of any injury one to another." The question now is, Who it was
 16793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat gave to these written Tables the obligatory force of Lawes. There
 16794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis no doubt but that they were made Laws by God himselfe: But because a
 16795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw obliges not, nor is Law to any, but to them that acknowledge it to
 16796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe the act of the Soveraign, how could the people of Israel that were
 16797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforbidden to approach the Mountain to hear what God said to Moses, be
 16798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobliged to obedience to all those laws which Moses propounded to them?
 16799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSome of them were indeed the Laws of Nature, as all the Second Table;
 16800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore to be acknowledged for Gods Laws; not to the Israelites
 16801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talone, but to all people: But of those that were peculiar to the
 16802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsraelites, as those of the first Table, the question remains; saving
 16803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat they had obliged themselves, presently after the propounding of
 16804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, to obey Moses, in these words (Exod. 20.19.) "Speak them thou to
 16805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tus, and we will hear thee; but let not God speak to us, lest we die." It
 16806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas therefore onely Moses then, and after him the High Priest, whom (by
 16807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses) God declared should administer this his peculiar Kingdome, that
 16808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad on Earth, the power to make this short Scripture of the Decalogue
 16809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto bee Law in the Common-wealth of Israel. But Moses, and Aaron, and the
 16810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsucceeding High Priests were the Civill Soveraigns. Therefore hitherto,
 16811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Canonizing, or making of the Scripture Law, belonged to the Civill
 16812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne.
 16813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Judicial, And Leviticall Law
 16818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Judiciall Law, that is to say, the Laws that God prescribed to the
 16820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMagistrates of Israel, for the rule of their administration of Justice,
 16821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand of the Sentences, or Judgments they should pronounce, in Pleas
 16822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetween man and man; and the Leviticall Law, that is to say, the rule
 16823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat God prescribed touching the Rites and Ceremonies of the Priests and
 16824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLevites, were all delivered to them by Moses onely; and therefore also
 16825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecame Lawes, by vertue of the same promise of obedience to Moses.
 16826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhether these laws were then written, or not written, but dictated to
 16827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe People by Moses (after his forty dayes being with God in the Mount)
 16828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby word of mouth, is not expressed in the Text; but they were all
 16829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpositive Laws, and equivalent to holy Scripture, and made Canonicall by
 16830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses the Civill Soveraign.
 16831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Second Law
 16836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter the Israelites were come into the Plains of Moab over against
 16838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJericho, and ready to enter into the land of Promise, Moses to the
 16839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformer Laws added divers others; which therefore are called Deuteronomy:
 16840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, Second Laws. And are (as it is written, Deut. 29.1.) "The words
 16841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Covenant which the Lord commanded Moses to make with the Children
 16842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Israel, besides the Covenant which he made with them in Horeb." For
 16843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thaving explained those former Laws, in the beginning of the Book of
 16844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeuteronomy, he addeth others, that begin at the 12. Cha. and continue
 16845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the end of the 26. of the same Book. This Law (Deut. 27.1.) they were
 16846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommanded to write upon great stones playstered over, at their passing
 16847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover Jordan: This Law also was written by Moses himself in a Book; and
 16848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdelivered into the hands of the "Priests, and to the Elders of Israel,"
 16849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Deut. 31.9.) and commanded (ve. 26.) "to be put in the side of the
 16850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArke;" for in the Ark it selfe was nothing but the Ten Commandements.
 16851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis was the Law, which Moses (Deuteronomy 17.18.) commanded the Kings
 16852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Israel should keep a copie of: And this is the Law, which having been
 16853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlong time lost, was found again in the Temple in the time of Josiah,
 16854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand by his authority received for the Law of God. But both Moses at the
 16855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twriting, and Josiah at the recovery thereof, had both of them the
 16856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Soveraignty. Hitherto therefore the Power of making Scripture
 16857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCanonicall, was in the Civill Soveraign.
 16858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBesides this Book of the Law, there was no other Book, from the time of
 16860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMoses, till after the Captivity, received amongst the Jews for the
 16861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw of God. For the Prophets (except a few) lived in the time of the
 16862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCaptivity it selfe; and the rest lived but a little before it; and were
 16863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso far from having their Prophecies generally received for Laws, as that
 16864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir persons were persecuted, partly by false Prophets, and partly by
 16865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Kings which were seduced by them. And this Book it self, which was
 16866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconfirmed by Josiah for the Law of God, and with it all the History of
 16867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Works of God, was lost in the Captivity, and sack of the City of
 16868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJerusalem, as appears by that of 2 Esdras 14.21. "Thy Law is burnt;
 16869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefor no man knoweth the things that are done of thee, of the works
 16870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat shall begin." And before the Captivity, between the time when the
 16871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw was lost, (which is not mentioned in the Scripture, but may probably
 16872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe thought to be the time of Rehoboam, when Shishak King of Egypt took
 16873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe spoils of the Temple,(1 Kings 14.26.)) and the time of Josiah,
 16874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen it was found againe, they had no written Word of God, but ruled
 16875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccording to their own discretion, or by the direction of such, as each
 16876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them esteemed Prophets.
 16877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Old Testament, When Made Canonicall
 16882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom whence we may inferre, that the Scriptures of the Old Testament,
 16884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich we have at this day, were not Canonicall, nor a Law unto the Jews,
 16885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttill the renovation of their Covenant with God at their return from the
 16886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCaptivity, and restauration of their Common-wealth under Esdras. But
 16887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom that time forward they were accounted the Law of the Jews, and for
 16888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch translated into Greek by Seventy Elders of Judaea, and put into the
 16889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLibrary of Ptolemy at Alexandria, and approved for the Word of God. Now
 16890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseeing Esdras was the High Priest, and the High Priest was their Civill
 16891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigne, it is manifest, that the Scriptures were never made Laws,
 16892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut by the Soveraign Civill Power.
 16893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe New Testament Began To Be Canonicall Under Christian Soveraigns By
 16895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Writings of the Fathers that lived in the time before that Christian
 16896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion was received, and authorised by Constantine the Emperour, we
 16897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay find, that the Books wee now have of the New Testament, were held by
 16898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Christians of that time (except a few, in respect of whose paucity
 16899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe rest were called the Catholique Church, and others Haeretiques) for
 16900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe dictates of the Holy Ghost; and consequently for the Canon, or Rule
 16901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Faith: such was the reverence and opinion they had of their Teachers;
 16902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas generally the reverence that the Disciples bear to their first
 16903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMasters, in all manner of doctrine they receive from them, is not small.
 16904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore there is no doubt, but when S. Paul wrote to the Churches he
 16905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad converted; or any other Apostle, or Disciple of Christ, to those
 16906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich had then embraced Christ, they received those their Writings for
 16907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe true Christian Doctrine. But in that time, when not the Power and
 16908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority of the Teacher, but the Faith of the Hearer caused them
 16909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto receive it, it was not the Apostles that made their own Writings
 16910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCanonicall, but every Convert made them so to himself.
 16911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the question here, is not what any Christian made a Law, or Canon
 16913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto himself, (which he might again reject, by the same right he received
 16914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit;) but what was so made a Canon to them, as without injustice they
 16915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcould not doe any thing contrary thereunto. That the New Testament
 16916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould in this sense be Canonicall, that is to say, a Law in any place
 16917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere the Law of the Common-wealth had not made it so, is contrary to
 16918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe nature of a Law. For a Law, (as hath been already shewn) is the
 16919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandement of that Man, or Assembly, to whom we have given Soveraign
 16920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority, to make such Rules for the direction of our actions, as hee
 16921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall think fit; and to punish us, when we doe any thing contrary to the
 16922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame. When therefore any other man shall offer unto us any other Rules,
 16923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich the Soveraign Ruler hath not prescribed, they are but Counsell,
 16924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Advice; which, whether good, or bad, hee that is counselled, may
 16925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout injustice refuse to observe, and when contrary to the Laws
 16926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready established, without injustice cannot observe, how good soever
 16927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the conceiveth it to be. I say, he cannot in this case observe the same
 16928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his actions, nor in his discourse with other men; though he may
 16929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout blame beleeve the his private Teachers, and wish he had the
 16930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tliberty to practise their advice; and that it were publiquely received
 16931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Law. For internall faith is in its own nature invisible, and
 16932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently exempted from all humane jurisdiction; whereas the words,
 16933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand actions that proceed from it, as breaches of our Civil obedience,
 16934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare injustice both before God and Man. Seeing then our Saviour hath
 16935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdenyed his Kingdome to be in this world, seeing he hath said, he came
 16936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot to judge, but to save the world, he hath not subjected us to other
 16937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaws than those of the Common-wealth; that is, the Jews to the Law
 16938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Moses, (which he saith (Mat. 5.) he came not to destroy, but to
 16939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfulfill,) and other Nations to the Laws of their severall Soveraigns,
 16940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand all men to the Laws of Nature; the observing whereof, both he
 16941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe, and his Apostles have in their teaching recommended to us, as
 16942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta necessary condition of being admitted by him in the last day into his
 16943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teternall Kingdome, wherein shall be Protection, and Life everlasting.
 16944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing then our Saviour, and his Apostles, left not new Laws to oblige
 16945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tus in this world, but new Doctrine to prepare us for the next; the Books
 16946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the New Testament, which containe that Doctrine, untill obedience to
 16947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem was commanded, by them that God hath given power to on earth to be
 16948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLegislators, were not obligatory Canons, that is, Laws, but onely good,
 16949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand safe advice, for the direction of sinners in the way to salvation,
 16950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich every man might take, and refuse at his owne perill, without
 16951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinjustice.
 16952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, our Saviour Christs Commission to his Apostles, and Disciples,
 16954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas to Proclaim his Kingdome (not present, but) to come; and to Teach
 16955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall Nations; and to Baptize them that should beleeve; and to enter into
 16956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe houses of them that should receive them; and where they were not
 16957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceived, to shake off the dust of their feet against them; but not
 16958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto call for fire from heaven to destroy them, nor to compell them to
 16959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobedience by the Sword. In all which there is nothing of Power, but of
 16960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerswasion. He sent them out as Sheep unto Wolves, not as Kings to their
 16961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects. They had not in Commission to make Laws; but to obey, and
 16962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tteach obedience to Laws made; and consequently they could not make their
 16963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWritings obligatory Canons, without the help of the Soveraign Civill
 16964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower. And therefore the Scripture of the New Testament is there only
 16965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, where the lawfull Civill Power hath made it so. And there also the
 16966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing, or Soveraign, maketh it a Law to himself; by which he subjecteth
 16967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe, not to the Doctor, or Apostle, that converted him, but to God
 16968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself, and his Son Jesus Christ, as immediately as did the Apostles
 16969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves.
 16970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Power Of Councells To Make The Scripture Law
 16975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 16976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat which may seem to give the New Testament, in respect of those that
 16977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave embraced Christian Doctrine, the force of Laws, in the times, and
 16978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaces of persecution, is the decrees they made amongst themselves in
 16979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Synods. For we read (Acts 15.28.) the stile of the Councell of the
 16980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles, the Elders, and the whole Church, in this manner, "It seemed
 16981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood to the Holy Ghost, and to us, to lay upon you no greater burthen
 16982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan these necessary things, &C." which is a stile that signifieth a
 16983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower to lay a burthen on them that had received their Doctrine. Now
 16984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"to lay a burthen on another," seemeth the same that "to oblige;" and
 16985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore the Acts of that Councell were Laws to the then Christians.
 16986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse, they were no more Laws than are these other Precepts,
 16987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Repent, Be Baptized; Keep the Commandements; Beleeve the Gospel; Come
 16988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunto me; Sell all that thou hast; Give it to the poor;" and "Follow
 16989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tme;" which are not Commands, but Invitations, and Callings of men to
 16990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristianity, like that of Esay 55.1. "Ho, every man that thirsteth,
 16991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome yee to the waters, come, and buy wine and milke without money."
 16992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor first, the Apostles power was no other than that of our Saviour,
 16993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto invite men to embrace the Kingdome of God; which they themselves
 16994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledged for a Kingdome (not present, but) to come; and they that
 16995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave no Kingdome, can make no Laws. And secondly, if their Acts of
 16996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCouncell, were Laws, they could not without sin be disobeyed. But we
 16997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tread not any where, that they who received not the Doctrine of Christ,
 16998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdid therein sin; but that they died in their sins; that is, that their
 16999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsins against the Laws to which they owed obedience, were not pardoned.
 17000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd those Laws were the Laws of Nature, and the Civill Laws of the
 17001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tState, whereto every Christian man had by pact submitted himself. And
 17002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore by the Burthen, which the Apostles might lay on such as they
 17003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad converted, are not to be understood Laws, but Conditions, proposed
 17004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto those that sought Salvation; which they might accept, or refuse at
 17005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own perill, without a new sin, though not without the hazard of
 17006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing condemned, and excluded out of the Kingdome of God for their sins
 17007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpast. And therefore of Infidels, S. John saith not, the wrath of God
 17008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall "come" upon them, but "the wrath of God remaineth upon them;"
 17009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand not that they shall be condemned; but that "they are condemned
 17010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready."(John 3.36, 3.18) Nor can it be conceived, that the benefit
 17011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Faith, "is Remission of sins" unlesse we conceive withall, that the
 17012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdammage of Infidelity, is "the Retention of the same sins."
 17013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut to what end is it (may some man aske), that the Apostles, and other
 17015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors of the Church, after their time, should meet together, to agree
 17016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon what Doctrine should be taught, both for Faith and Manners, if no
 17017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman were obliged to observe their Decrees? To this may be answered, that
 17018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Apostles, and Elders of that Councell, were obliged even by their
 17019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tentrance into it, to teach the Doctrine therein concluded, and decreed
 17020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be taught, so far forth, as no precedent Law, to which they were
 17021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobliged to yeeld obedience, was to the contrary; but not that all other
 17022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristians should be obliged to observe, what they taught. For though
 17023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey might deliberate what each of them should teach; yet they could
 17024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot deliberate what others should do, unless their Assembly had had
 17025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Legislative Power; which none could have but Civill Soveraigns. For
 17026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough God be the Soveraign of all the world, we are not bound to take
 17027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor his Law, whatsoever is propounded by every man in his name; nor any
 17028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing contrary to the Civill Law, which God hath expressely commanded us
 17029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey.
 17030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing then the Acts of Councell of the Apostles, were then no Laws,
 17032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut Councells; much lesse are Laws the Acts of any other Doctors,
 17033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Councells since, if assembled without the Authority of the Civill
 17034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign. And consequently, the Books of the New Testament, though most
 17035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperfect Rules of Christian Doctrine, could not be made Laws by any other
 17036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority then that of Kings, or Soveraign Assemblies.
 17037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe first Councell, that made the Scriptures we now have, Canon, is not
