 17039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textant: For that Collection the first Bishop of Rome after S. Peter, is
 17040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject to question: For though the Canonicall books bee there reckoned
 17041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tup; yet these words, "Sint vobis omnibus Clericis & Laicis Libris
 17042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvenerandi, &c." containe a distinction of Clergy, and Laity, that was
 17043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot in use so neer St. Peters time. The first Councell for setling the
 17044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCanonicall Scripture, that is extant, is that of Laodicea, Can. 59.
 17045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich forbids the reading of other Books then those in the Churches;
 17046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is a Mandate that is not addressed to every Christian, but to
 17047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose onely that had authority to read any publiquely in the Church;
 17048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, to Ecclesiastiques onely.
 17049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Right Of Constituting Ecclesiasticall Officers In The Time
 17054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Apostles
 17056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Ecclesiastical Officers in the time of the Apostles, some were
 17058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMagisteriall, some Ministeriall. Magisteriall were the Offices
 17059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof preaching of the Gospel of the Kingdom of God to Infidels; of
 17060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadministring the Sacraments, and Divine Service; and of teaching the
 17061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRules of Faith and Manners to those that were converted. Ministeriall
 17062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas the Office of Deacons, that is, of them that were appointed to the
 17063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadministration of the secular necessities of the Church, at such time
 17064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they lived upon a common stock of mony, raised out of the voluntary
 17065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontributions of the faithfull.
 17066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAmongst the Officers Magisteriall, the first, and principall were the
 17068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles; whereof there were at first but twelve; and these were chosen
 17069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand constituted by our Saviour himselfe; and their Office was not onely
 17070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Preach, Teach, and Baptize, but also to be Martyrs, (Witnesses of
 17071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviours Resurrection.) This Testimony, was the specificall, and
 17072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tessentiall mark; whereby the Apostleship was distinguished from other
 17073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMagistracy Ecclesiasticall; as being necessary for an Apostle, either to
 17074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave seen our Saviour after his Resurrection, or to have conversed with
 17075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim before, and seen his works, and other arguments of his Divinity,
 17076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereby they might be taken for sufficient Witnesses. And therefore at
 17077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe election of a new Apostle in the place of Judas Iscariot, S. Peter
 17078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaith (Acts 1.21,22.) "Of these men that have companyed with us, all the
 17079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime that the Lord Jesus went in and out among us, beginning from the
 17080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBaptisme of John unto that same day that he was taken up from us, must
 17081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone be ordained to be a Witnesse with us of his Resurrection:" where, by
 17082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis word Must, is implyed a necessary property of an Apostle, to have
 17083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcompanyed with the first and prime Apostles in the time that our Saviour
 17084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifested himself in the flesh.
 17085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMatthias Made Apostle By The Congregation.
 17090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe first Apostle, of those which were not constituted by Christ in the
 17092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime he was upon the Earth, was Matthias, chosen in this manner: There
 17093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere assembled together in Jerusalem about 120 Christians (Acts 1.15.)
 17094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese appointed two, Joseph the Just, and Matthias (ver. 23.) and caused
 17095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlots to be drawn; "and (ver. 26.) the Lot fell on Matthias and he was
 17096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnumbred with the Apostles." So that here we see the ordination of this
 17097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostle, was the act of the Congregation, and not of St. Peter, nor of
 17098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe eleven, otherwise then as Members of the Assembly.
 17099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPaul And Barnabas Made Apostles By The Church Of Antioch
 17104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter him there was never any other Apostle ordained, but Paul and
 17106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBarnabas, which was done (as we read Acts 13.1,2,3.) in this manner.
 17107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"There were in the Church that was at Antioch, certaine Prophets, and
 17108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTeachers; as Barnabas, and Simeon that was called Niger, and Lucius of
 17109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCyrene, and Manaen; which had been brought up with Herod the Tetrarch,
 17110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Saul. As they ministred unto the Lord, and fasted, the Holy Ghost
 17111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid, 'Separate mee Barnabas, and Saul for the worke whereunto I have
 17112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled them.' And when they had fasted, and prayed, and laid their hands
 17113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton them, they sent them away."
 17114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy which it is manifest, that though they were called by the Holy Ghost,
 17116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Calling was declared unto them, and their Mission authorized by
 17117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe particular Church of Antioch. And that this their calling was to
 17118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Apostleship, is apparent by that, that they are both called (Acts
 17119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t14.14.) Apostles: And that it was by vertue of this act of the Church of
 17120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAntioch, that they were Apostles, S. Paul declareth plainly (Rom. 1.1.)
 17121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin that hee useth the word, which the Holy Ghost used at his calling:
 17122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor he stileth himself, "An Apostle separated unto the Gospel of God;"
 17123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talluding to the words of the Holy Ghost, "Separate me Barnabas and Saul,
 17124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t&c." But seeing the work of an Apostle, was to be a Witnesse of
 17125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Resurrection of Christ, and man may here aske, how S. Paul that
 17126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconversed not with our Saviour before his passion, could know he was
 17127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trisen. To which it is easily answered, that our Saviour himself appeared
 17128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto him in the way to Damascus, from Heaven, after his Ascension; "and
 17129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchose him for a vessell to bear his name before the Gentiles, and Kings,
 17130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Children of Israel;" and consequently (having seen the Lord after
 17131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this passion) was a competent Witnesse of his Resurrection: And as for
 17132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBarnabas, he was a Disciple before the Passion. It is therefore evident
 17133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Paul, and Barnabas were Apostles; and yet chosen, and authorized
 17134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(not by the first Apostles alone, but) by the Church of Antioch; as
 17135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMatthias was chosen, and authorized by the Church of Jerusalem.
 17136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat Offices In The Church Are Magisteriall
 17141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBishop, a word formed in our language, out of the Greek Episcopus,
 17143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifieth an overseer, or Superintendent of any businesse, and
 17144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticularly a Pastor or Shepherd; and thence by metaphor was taken, not
 17145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonly amongst the Jews that were originally Shepherds, but also amongst
 17146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Heathen, to signifie the Office of a King, or any other Ruler,
 17147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Guide of People, whether he ruled by Laws, or Doctrine. And so
 17148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Apostles were the first Christian Bishops, instituted by Christ
 17149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe: in which sense the Apostleship of Judas is called (Acts 1.20.)
 17150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Bishoprick. And afterwards, when there were constituted Elders in
 17151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Christian Churches, with charge to guide Christs flock by their
 17152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoctrine, and advice; these Elders were also called Bishops. Timothy was
 17153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Elder (which word Elder, in the New Testament is a name of Office, as
 17154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twell as of Age;) yet he was also a Bishop. And Bishops were then content
 17155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the Title of Elders. Nay S. John himselfe, the Apostle beloved of
 17156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Lord, beginneth his Second Epistle with these words, "The Elder to
 17157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Elect Lady." By which it is evident, that Bishop, Pastor, Elder,
 17158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctor, that is to say, Teacher, were but so many divers names of
 17159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same Office in the time of the Apostles. For there was then no
 17160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgovernment by Coercion, but only by Doctrine, and Perswading. The
 17161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God was yet to come, in a new world; so that there could
 17162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe no authority to compell in any Church, till the Common-wealth
 17163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad embraced the Christian Faith; and consequently no diversity of
 17164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority, though there were diversity of Employments.
 17165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBesides these Magisteriall employments in the Church, namely Apostles,
 17167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBishops, Elders, Pastors, and Doctors, whose calling was to proclaim
 17168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist to the Jews, and Infidels, and to direct, and teach those that
 17169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeved we read in the New Testament of no other. For by the names
 17170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Evangelists and Prophets, is not signified any Office, but severall
 17171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGifts, by which severall men were profitable to the Church: as
 17172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvangelists, by writing the life and acts of our Saviour; such as were
 17173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tS. Matthew and S. John Apostles, and S. Marke and S. Luke Disciples, and
 17174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhosoever else wrote of that subject, (as S. Thomas, and S. Barnabas are
 17175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid to have done, though the Church have not received the Books
 17176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat have gone under their names:) and as Prophets, by the gift of
 17177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterpreting the Old Testament; and sometimes by declaring their
 17178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeciall Revelations to the Church. For neither these gifts, nor the
 17179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgifts of Languages, nor the gift of Casting out Devils, or of Curing
 17180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother diseases, nor any thing else did make an Officer in the Church,
 17181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsave onely the due calling and election to the charge of Teaching.
 17182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOrdination Of Teachers
 17187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs the Apostles, Matthias, Paul, and Barnabas, were not made by our
 17189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour himself, but were elected by the Church, that is, by the
 17190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly of Christians; namely, Matthias by the Church of Jerusalem,
 17191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Paul, and Barnabas by the Church of Antioch; so were also the
 17192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresbyters, and Pastors in other Cities, elected by the Churches of
 17193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Cities. For proof whereof, let us consider, first, how S. Paul
 17194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceeded in the Ordination of Presbyters, in the Cities where he had
 17195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconverted men to the Christian Faith, immediately after he and Barnabas
 17196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad received their Apostleship. We read (Acts 14.23.) that "they
 17197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordained Elders in every Church;" which at first sight may be taken for
 17198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Argument, that they themselves chose, and gave them their authority:
 17199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut if we consider the Originall text, it will be manifest, that they
 17200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere authorized, and chosen by the Assembly of the Christians of each
 17201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCity. For the words there are, "cheirotonesantes autoispresbuterous kat
 17202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tekklesian," that is, "When they had Ordained them Elders by the Holding
 17203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tup of Hands in every Congregation." Now it is well enough known, that in
 17204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall those Cities, the manner of choosing Magistrates, and Officers,
 17205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas by plurality of suffrages; and (because the ordinary way of
 17206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdistinguishing the Affirmative Votes from the Negatives, was by Holding
 17207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tup of Hands) to ordain an Officer in any of the Cities, was no more
 17208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut to bring the people together, to elect them by plurality of Votes,
 17209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhether it were by plurality of elevated hands, or by plurality of
 17210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvoices, or plurality of balls, or beans, or small stones, of which every
 17211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman cast in one, into a vessell marked for the Affirmative, or Negative;
 17212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor divers Cities had divers customes in that point. It was therefore
 17213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Assembly that elected their own Elders: the Apostles were onely
 17214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresidents of the Assembly to call them together for such Election, and
 17215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto pronounce them Elected, and to give them the benediction, which now
 17216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis called Consecration. And for this cause they that were Presidents
 17217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Assemblies, as (in the absence of the Apostles) the Elders were,
 17218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere called proestotes, and in Latin Antistities; which words signifie
 17219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Principall Person of the Assembly, whose office was to number the
 17220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVotes, and to declare thereby who was chosen; and where the Votes were
 17221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequall, to decide the matter in question, by adding his own; which is
 17222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Office of a President in Councell. And (because all the Churches
 17223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad their Presbyters ordained in the same manner,) where the word is
 17224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConstitute, (as Titus 1.5.) "ina katasteses kata polin presbuterous,"
 17225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"For this cause left I thee in Crete, that thou shouldest constitute
 17226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tElders in every City," we are to understand the same thing; namely, that
 17227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee should call the faithfull together, and ordain them Presbyters by
 17228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplurality of suffrages. It had been a strange thing, if in a Town, where
 17229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen perhaps had never seen any Magistrate otherwise chosen then by an
 17230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly, those of the Town becomming Christians, should so much as have
 17231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought on any other way of Election of their Teachers, and Guides, that
 17232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, of their Presbyters, (otherwise called Bishops,) then this of
 17233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplurality of suffrages, intimated by S. Paul (Acts 14.23.) in the word
 17234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCheirotonesantes: Nor was there ever any choosing of Bishops, (before
 17235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Emperors found it necessary to regulate them in order to the keeping
 17236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the peace amongst them,) but by the Assemblies of the Christians in
 17237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery severall Town.
 17238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe same is also confirmed by the continuall practise even to this day,
 17240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Election of the Bishops of Rome. For if the Bishop of any place,
 17241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad the right of choosing another, to the succession of the Pastorall
 17242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOffice, in any City, at such time as he went from thence, to plant the
 17243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame in another place; much more had he had the Right, to appoint his
 17244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuccessour in that place, in which he last resided and dyed: And we find
 17245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot, that ever any Bishop of Rome appointed his successor. For they were
 17246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta long time chosen by the People, as we may see by the sedition raised
 17247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabout the Election, between Damascus, and Ursinicus; which Ammianus
 17248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMarcellinus saith was so great, that Juventius the Praefect, unable to
 17249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkeep the peace between them, was forced to goe out of the City; and that
 17250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere were above an hundred men found dead upon that occasion in the
 17251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch it self. And though they afterwards were chosen, first, by the
 17252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhole Clergy of Rome, and afterwards by the Cardinalls; yet never any
 17253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas appointed to the succession by his predecessor. If therefore they
 17254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretended no right to appoint their successors, I think I may reasonably
 17255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconclude, they had no right to appoint the new power; which none could
 17256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake from the Church to bestow on them, but such as had a lawfull
 17257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority, not onely to Teach, but to Command the Church; which none
 17258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcould doe, but the Civill Soveraign.
 17259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters Of The Church What
 17264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe word Minister in the Originall Diakonos signifieth one that
 17266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvoluntarily doth the businesse of another man; and differeth from a
 17267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tServant onely in this, that Servants are obliged by their condition,
 17268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto what is commanded them; whereas Ministers are obliged onely by
 17269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir undertaking, and bound therefore to no more than that they have
 17270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tundertaken: So that both they that teach the Word of God, and they that
 17271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadminister the secular affairs of the Church, are both Ministers, but
 17272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are Ministers of different Persons. For the Pastors of the Church,
 17273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled (Acts 6.4.) "The Ministers of the Word," are Ministers of Christ,
 17274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose Word it is: But the Ministery of a Deacon, which is called (verse
 17275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2. of the same Chapter) "Serving of Tables," is a service done to the
 17276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, or Congregation: So that neither any one man, nor the whole
 17277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, could ever of their Pastor say, he was their Minister; but of
 17278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Deacon, whether the charge he undertook were to serve tables, or
 17279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdistribute maintenance to the Christians, when they lived in each City
 17280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton a common stock, or upon collections, as in the first times, or to
 17281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttake a care of the House of Prayer, or of the Revenue, or other worldly
 17282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbusinesse of the Church, the whole Congregation might properly call him
 17283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Minister.
 17284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor their employment, as Deacons, was to serve the Congregation; though
 17286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon occasion they omitted not to preach the Gospel, and maintain the
 17287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine of Christ, every one according to his gifts, as S. Steven did;
 17288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand both to Preach, and Baptize, as Philip did: For that Philip, which
 17289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Act. 8. 5.) Preached the Gospel at Samaria, and (verse 38.) Baptized
 17290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Eunuch, was Philip the Deacon, not Philip the Apostle. For it is
 17291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest (verse 1.) that when Philip preached in Samaria, the Apostles
 17292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere at Jerusalem, and (verse 14.) "When they heard that Samaria had
 17293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceived the Word of God, sent Peter and John to them;" by imposition of
 17294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose hands, they that were Baptized (verse 15.) received (which before
 17295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Baptisme of Philip they had not received) the Holy Ghost. For it
 17296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas necessary for the conferring of the Holy Ghost, that their Baptisme
 17297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould be administred, or confirmed by a Minister of the Word, not by a
 17298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinister of the Church. And therefore to confirm the Baptisme of those
 17299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Philip the Deacon had Baptized, the Apostles sent out of their own
 17300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnumber from Jerusalem to Samaria, Peter, and John; who conferred on them
 17301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat before were but Baptized, those graces that were signs of the Holy
 17302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit, which at that time did accompany all true Beleevers; which what
 17303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were may be understood by that which S. Marke saith (chap. 16.17.)
 17304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"These signs follow them that beleeve in my Name; they shall cast out
 17305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDevills; they shall speak with new tongues; They shall take up Serpents,
 17306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand if they drink any deadly thing, it shall not hurt them; They shall
 17307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlay hands on the sick, and they shall recover." This to doe, was it that
 17308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilip could not give; but the Apostles could, and (as appears by this
 17309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace) effectually did to every man that truly beleeved, and was by
 17310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Minister of Christ himself Baptized: which power either Christs
 17311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters in this age cannot conferre, or else there are very few true
 17312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBeleevers, or Christ hath very few Ministers.
 17313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd How Chosen What
 17318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat the first Deacons were chosen, not by the Apostles, but by a
 17320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCongregation of the Disciples; that is, of Christian men of all sorts,
 17321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis manifest out of Acts 6. where we read that the Twelve, after the
 17322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnumber of Disciples was multiplyed, called them together, and having
 17323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttold them, that it was not fit that the Apostles should leave the Word
 17324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God, and serve tables, said unto them (verse 3.) "Brethren looke you
 17325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout among you seven men of honest report, full of the Holy Ghost, and of
 17326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWisdome, whom we may appoint over this businesse." Here it is manifest,
 17327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat though the Apostles declared them elected; yet the Congregation
 17328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchose them; which also, (verse the fift) is more expressely said, where
 17329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is written, that "the saying pleased the multitude, and they chose
 17330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseven, &c."
 17331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf Ecclesiasticall Revenue, Under The Law Of Moses
 17336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUnder the Old Testament, the Tribe of Levi were onely capable of the
 17338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriesthood, and other inferiour Offices of the Church. The land
 17339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas divided amongst the other Tribes (Levi excepted,) which by the
 17340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubdivision of the Tribe of Joseph, into Ephraim and Manasses, were
 17341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstill twelve. To the Tribe of Levi were assigned certain Cities for
 17342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir habitation, with the suburbs for their cattell: but for their
 17343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tportion, they were to have the tenth of the fruits of the land of their
 17344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBrethren. Again, the Priests for their maintenance had the tenth of that
 17345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttenth, together with part of the oblations, and sacrifices. For God had
 17346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid to Aaron (Numb. 18. 20.) "Thou shalt have no inheritance in their
 17347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tland, neither shalt thou have any part amongst them, I am thy part, and
 17348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthine inheritance amongst the Children of Israel." For God being then
 17349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing, and having constituted the Tribe of Levi to be his Publique
 17350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters, he allowed them for their maintenance, the Publique revenue,
 17351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, the part that God had reserved to himself; which were
 17352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTythes, and Offerings: and that it is which is meant, where God saith, I
 17353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tam thine inheritance. And therefore to the Levites might not unfitly
 17354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe attributed the name of Clergy from Kleros, which signifieth Lot, or
 17355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInheritance; not that they were heirs of the Kingdome of God, more than
 17356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother; but that Gods inheritance, was their maintenance. Now seeing
 17357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this time God himself was their King, and Moses, Aaron, and the
 17358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsucceeding High Priests were his Lieutenants; it is manifest, that the
 17359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight of Tythes, and Offerings was constituted by the Civill Power.
 17360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter their rejection of God in the demand of a King, they enjoyed still
 17362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same revenue; but the Right thereof was derived from that, that the
 17363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings did never take it from them: for the Publique Revenue was at
 17364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe disposing of him that was the Publique Person; and that (till the
 17365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCaptivity) was the King. And again, after the return from the Captivity,
 17366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey paid their Tythes as before to the Priest. Hitherto therefore
 17367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch Livings were determined by the Civill Soveraign.
 17368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn Our Saviours Time, And After
 17373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf the maintenance of our Saviour, and his Apostles, we read onely they
 17375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad a Purse, (which was carried by Judas Iscariot;) and, that of the
 17376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles, such as were Fisher-men, did sometimes use their trade; and
 17377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat when our Saviour sent the Twelve Apostles to Preach, he forbad them
 17378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"to carry Gold, and Silver, and Brasse in their purses, for that
 17379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe workman is worthy of his hire:" (Mat. 10. 9,10.) By which it
 17380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis probable, their ordinary maintenance was not unsuitable to their
 17381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\temployment; for their employment was (ver. 8.) "freely to give, because
 17382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey had freely received;" and their maintenance was the Free Gift of
 17383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that beleeved the good tyding they carryed about of the coming
 17384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Messiah their Saviour. To which we may adde, that which was
 17385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontributed out of gratitude, by such as our Saviour had healed of
 17386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiseases; of which are mentioned "Certain women (Luke 8. 2,3.) which had
 17387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen healed of evill spirits and infirmities; Mary Magdalen, out of whom
 17388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twent seven Devills; and Joanna the wife of Chuza, Herods Steward; and
 17389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSusanna, and many others, which ministred unto him of their substance.
 17390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter our Saviours Ascension, the Christians of every City lived in
 17392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon, (Acts 4. 34.) upon the mony which was made of the sale of their
 17393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlands and possessions, and laid down at the feet of the Apostles, of
 17394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood will, not of duty; for "whilest the Land remained (saith S. Peter
 17395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Ananias Acts 5.4.) was it not thine? and after it was sold, was it
 17396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot in thy power?" which sheweth he needed not to have saved his land,
 17397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor his money by lying, as not being bound to contribute any thing at
 17398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall, unlesse he had pleased. And as in the time of the Apostles, so also
 17399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall the time downward, till after Constantine the Great, we shall
 17400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfind, that the maintenance of the Bishops, and Pastors of the Christian
 17401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, was nothing but the voluntary contribution of them that had
 17402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tembraced their Doctrine. There was yet no mention of Tythes: but
 17403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch was in the time of Constantine, and his Sons, the affection of
 17404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristians to their Pastors, as Ammianus Marcellinus saith (describing
 17405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe sedition of Damasus and Ursinicus about the Bishopricke,) that it
 17406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas worth their contention, in that the Bishops of those times by the
 17407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tliberality of their flock, and especially of Matrons, lived splendidly,
 17408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere carryed in Coaches, and sumptuous in their fare and apparell.
 17409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Ministers Of The Gospel Lived On The Benevolence Of Their Flocks
 17411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut here may some ask, whether the Pastor were then bound to live upon
 17412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvoluntary contribution, as upon almes, "For who (saith S. Paul 1 Cor. 9.
 17413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t7.) goeth to war at his own charges? or who feedeth a flock, and eatheth
 17414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot of the milke of the flock?" And again, (1 Cor. 9. 13.) "Doe ye not
 17415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow that they which minister about holy things, live of the things of
 17416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Temple; and they which wait at the Altar, partake with the Altar;"
 17417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, have part of that which is offered at the Altar for
 17418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir maintenance? And then he concludeth, "Even so hath the Lord
 17419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappointed, that they which preach the Gospel should live of the Gospel.
 17420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom which place may be inferred indeed, that the Pastors of the Church
 17421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought to be maintained by their flocks; but not that the Pastors were to
 17422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdetermine, either the quantity, or the kind of their own allowance, and
 17423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe (as it were) their own Carvers. Their allowance must needs therefore
 17424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe determined, either by the gratitude, and liberality of every
 17425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparticular man of their flock, or by the whole Congregation. By the
 17426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhole Congregation it could not be, because their Acts were then no
 17427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaws: Therefore the maintenance of Pastors, before Emperours and Civill
 17428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns had made Laws to settle it, was nothing but Benevolence. They
 17429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat served at the Altar lived on what was offered. In what court should
 17430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey sue for it, who had no Tribunalls? Or if they had Arbitrators
 17431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst themselves, who should execute their Judgments, when they had no
 17432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower to arme their Officers? It remaineth therefore, that there could
 17433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe no certaine maintenance assigned to any Pastors of the Church, but by
 17434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe whole Congregation; and then onely, when their Decrees should have
 17435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe force (not onely of Canons, but also) of Laws; which Laws could not
 17436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe made, but by Emperours, Kings, or other Civill Soveraignes. The Right
 17437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Tythes in Moses Law, could not be applyed to the then Ministers
 17438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Gospell; because Moses and the High Priests were the Civill
 17439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns of the people under God, whose Kingdom amongst the Jews was
 17440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent; whereas the Kingdome of God by Christ is yet to come.
 17441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHitherto hath been shewn what the Pastors of the Church are; what are
 17443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe points of their Commission (as that they were to Preach, to Teach,
 17444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Baptize, to be Presidents in their severall Congregations;) what is
 17445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticall Censure, viz. Excommunication, that is to say, in those
 17446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaces where Christianity was forbidden by the Civill Laws, a putting
 17447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof themselves out of the company of the Excommunicate, and where
 17448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristianity was by the Civill Law commanded, a putting the
 17449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcommunicate out of the Congregations of Christians; who elected the
 17450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors and Ministers of the Church, (that it was, the Congregation);
 17451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho consecrated and blessed them, (that it was the Pastor); what was
 17452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir due revenue, (that it was none but their own possessions,
 17453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand their own labour, and the voluntary contributions of devout and
 17454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgratefull Christians). We are to consider now, what Office those persons
 17455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave, who being Civill Soveraignes, have embraced also the Christian
 17456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith.
 17457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Civill Soveraign Being A Christian Hath The Right Of Appointing
 17462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors
 17464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first, we are to remember, that the Right of Judging what
 17466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrines are fit for Peace, and to be taught the Subjects, is in all
 17467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths inseparably annexed (as hath been already proved cha.
 17468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t18.) to the Soveraign Power Civill, whether it be in one Man, or in one
 17469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly of men. For it is evident to the meanest capacity, that mens
 17470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions are derived from the opinions they have of the Good, or Evill,
 17471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich from those actions redound unto themselves; and consequently,
 17472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen that are once possessed of an opinion, that their obedience to
 17473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign Power, will bee more hurtfull to them, than their
 17474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisobedience, will disobey the Laws, and thereby overthrow the
 17475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, and introduce confusion, and Civill war; for the avoiding
 17476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof, all Civill Government was ordained. And therefore in all
 17477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths of the Heathen, the Soveraigns have had the name of
 17478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors of the People, because there was no Subject that could lawfully
 17479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTeach the people, but by their permission and authority.
 17480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis Right of the Heathen Kings, cannot bee thought taken from them by
 17482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir conversion to the Faith of Christ; who never ordained, that Kings
 17483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor beleeving in him, should be deposed, that is, subjected to any but
 17484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself, or (which is all one) be deprived of the power necessary for
 17485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe conservation of Peace amongst their Subjects, and for their defence
 17486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst foraign Enemies. And therefore Christian Kings are still the
 17487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSupreme Pastors of their people, and have power to ordain what Pastors
 17488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey please, to teach the Church, that is, to teach the People committed
 17489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto their charge.
 17490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, let the right of choosing them be (as before the conversion
 17492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Kings) in the Church, for so it was in the time of the Apostles
 17493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves (as hath been shewn already in this chapter); even so also
 17494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Right will be in the Civill Soveraign, Christian. For in that he is
 17495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Christian, he allowes the Teaching; and in that he is the Soveraign
 17496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which is as much as to say, the Church by Representation,) the
 17497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTeachers hee elects, are elected by the Church. And when an Assembly of
 17498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristians choose their Pastor in a Christian Common-wealth, it is the
 17499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign that electeth him, because tis done by his Authority; In the
 17500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame manner, as when a Town choose their Maior, it is the act of him
 17501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat hath the Soveraign Power: For every act done, is the act of him,
 17502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout whose consent it is invalid. And therefore whatsoever examples
 17503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay be drawn out of History, concerning the Election of Pastors, by the
 17504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeople, or by the Clergy, they are no arguments against the Right of
 17505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany Civill Soveraign, because they that elected them did it by his
 17506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority.
 17507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing then in every Christian Common-wealth, the Civill Soveraign is
 17509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Supreme Pastor, to whose charge the whole flock of his Subjects is
 17510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommitted, and consequently that it is by his authority, that all
 17511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Pastors are made, and have power to teach, and performe all
 17512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Pastorall offices; it followeth also, that it is from the Civill
 17513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, that all other Pastors derive their right of Teaching,
 17514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPreaching, and other functions pertaining to that Office; and that they
 17515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare but his Ministers; in the same manner as the Magistrates of Towns,
 17516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudges in Courts of Justice, and Commanders of Armies, are all but
 17517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters of him that is the Magistrate of the whole Common-wealth,
 17518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudge of all Causes, and Commander of the whole Militia, which is
 17519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talwayes the Civill Soveraign. And the reason hereof, is not because they
 17520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Teach, but because they that are to Learn, are his Subjects.
 17521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor let it be supposed, that a Christian King commit the Authority of
 17522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOrdaining Pastors in his Dominions to another King, (as divers Christian
 17523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings allow that power to the Pope;) he doth not thereby constitute a
 17524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastor over himself, nor a Soveraign Pastor over his People; for that
 17525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere to deprive himself of the Civill Power; which depending on the
 17526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion men have of their Duty to him, and the fear they have of
 17527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishment in another world, would depend also on the skill, and loyalty
 17528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Doctors, who are no lesse subject, not only to Ambition, but also
 17529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Ignorance, than any other sort of men. So that where a stranger hath
 17530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthority to appoint Teachers, it is given him by the Soveraign in
 17531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose Dominions he teacheth. Christian Doctors are our Schoolmasters
 17532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Christianity; But Kings are Fathers of Families, and may receive
 17533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSchoolmasters for their Subjects from the recommendation of a stranger,
 17534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut not from the command; especially when the ill teaching them shall
 17535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tredound to the great and manifest profit of him that recommends them:
 17536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor can they be obliged to retain them, longer than it is for the
 17537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique good; the care of which they stand so long charged withall, as
 17538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey retain any other essentiall Right of the Soveraignty.
 17539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Pastorall Authority Of Soveraigns Only Is De Jure Divino,
 17544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat Of Other Pastors Is Jure Civili
 17546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf a man therefore should ask a Pastor, in the execution of his Office,
 17548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas the chief Priests and Elders of the people (Mat. 21.23.) asked our
 17549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour, "By what authority dost thou these things, and who gave thee
 17550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis authority:" he can make no other just Answer, but that he doth
 17551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit by the Authority of the Common-wealth, given him by the King, or
 17552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly that representeth it. All Pastors, except the Supreme, execute
 17553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir charges in the Right, that is by the Authority of the Civill
 17554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, that is, Jure Civili. But the King, and every other Soveraign
 17555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texecuteth his Office of Supreme Pastor, by immediate Authority from God,
 17556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, In Gods Right, or Jure Divino. And therefore none but
 17557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings can put into their Titles (a mark of their submission to God onely
 17558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t) Dei Gratia Rex, &c. Bishops ought to say in the beginning of their
 17559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMandates, "By the favour of the Kings Majesty, Bishop of such a
 17560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDiocesse;" or as Civill Ministers, "In his Majesties Name." For in
 17561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaying, Divina Providentia, which is the same with Dei Gratia, though
 17562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisguised, they deny to have received their authority from the Civill
 17563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tState; and sliely slip off the Collar of their Civill Subjection,
 17564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary to the unity and defence of the Common-wealth.
 17565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Kings Have Power To Execute All Manner Of Pastoral Function
 17570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut if every Christian Soveraign be the Supreme Pastor of his own
 17572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects, it seemeth that he hath also the Authority, not only to Preach
 17573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which perhaps no man will deny;) but also to Baptize, and to Administer
 17574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Sacrament of the Lords Supper; and to Consecrate both Temples, and
 17575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors to Gods service; which most men deny; partly because they use
 17576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot to do it; and partly because the Administration of Sacraments,
 17577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Consecration of Persons, and Places to holy uses, requireth the
 17578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImposition of such mens hands, as by the like Imposition successively
 17579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the time of the Apostles have been ordained to the like Ministery.
 17580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor proof therefore that Christian Kings have power to Baptize, and to
 17581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsecrate, I am to render a reason, both why they use not to doe it,
 17582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand how, without the ordinary ceremony of Imposition of hands, they are
 17583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade capable of doing it, when they will.
 17584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere is no doubt but any King, in case he were skilfull in the
 17586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSciences, might by the same Right of his Office, read Lectures of
 17587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem himself, by which he authorizeth others to read them in the
 17588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUniversities. Neverthelesse, because the care of the summe of the
 17589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbusinesse of the Common-wealth taketh up his whole time, it were not
 17590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconvenient for him to apply himself in Person to that particular. A King
 17591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay also if he please, sit in Judgment, to hear and determine all manner
 17592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Causes, as well as give others authority to doe it in his name; but
 17593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat the charge that lyeth upon him of Command and Government, constrain
 17594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim to bee continually at the Helm, and to commit the Ministeriall
 17595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOffices to others under him. In the like manner our Saviour (who surely
 17596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad power to Baptize) Baptized none himselfe, but sent his Apostles and
 17597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDisciples to Baptize. (John 4.2.) So also S. Paul, by the necessity of
 17598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPreaching in divers and far distant places, Baptized few: Amongst all
 17599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Corinthians he Baptized only Crispus, Cajus, and Stephanus; (1
 17600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCor.1.14,16.) and the reason was, because his principall Charge was to
 17601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPreach. (1 Cor. 1.17.) Whereby it is manifest, that the greater Charge,
 17602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(such as is the Government of the Church,) is a dispensation for the
 17603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlesse. The reason therefore why Christian Kings use not to Baptize, is
 17604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevident, and the same, for which at this day there are few Baptized by
 17605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBishops, and by the Pope fewer.
 17606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as concerning Imposition of Hands, whether it be needfull, for the
 17608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthorizing of a King to Baptize, and Consecrate, we may consider thus.
 17609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImposition of Hands, was a most ancient publique ceremony amongst the
 17611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJews, by which was designed, and made certain, the person, or other
 17612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing intended in a mans prayer, blessing, sacrifice, consecration,
 17613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcondemnation, or other speech. So Jacob in blessing the children of
 17614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJoseph (Gen. 48.14.) "Laid his right Hand on Ephraim the younger, and
 17615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this left Hand on Manasseh the first born;" and this he did Wittingly
 17616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(though they were so presented to him by Joseph, as he was forced in
 17617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoing it to stretch out his arms acrosse) to design to whom he intended
 17618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe greater blessing. So also in the sacrificing of the Burnt offering,
 17619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAaron is commanded (Exod. 29.10.) "to Lay his Hands on the head of the
 17620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbullock;" and (ver. 15.) "to Lay his Hand on the head of the ramme."
 17621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe same is also said again, Levit. 1.4. & 8.14. Likewise Moses when he
 17622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordained Joshua to be Captain of the Israelites, that is, consecrated
 17623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim to Gods service, (Numb. 27.23.) "Laid his hands upon him, and gave
 17624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim his Charge," designing and rendring certain, who it was they were
 17625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey in war. And in the consecration of the Levites (Numb. 8.10.) God
 17626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommanded that "the Children of Israel should Put their Hands upon the
 17627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLevites." And in the condemnation of him that had blasphemed the Lord
 17628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Levit. 24.14.) God commanded that "all that heard him should Lay their
 17629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHands on his head, and that all the Congregation should stone him." And
 17630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhy should they only that heard him, Lay their Hands upon him, and not
 17631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trather a Priest, Levite, or other Minister of Justice, but that
 17632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone else were able to design, and demonstrate to the eyes of the
 17633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCongregation, who it was that had blasphemed, and ought to die? And
 17634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto design a man, or any other thing, by the Hand to the Eye is lesse
 17635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject to mistake, than when it is done to the Eare by a Name.
 17636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd so much was this ceremony observed, that in blessing the whole
 17638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCongregation at once, which cannot be done by Laying on of Hands, yet
 17639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Aaron (Levit. 9.22.) did lift up his Hand towards the people when he
 17640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tblessed them." And we read also of the like ceremony of Consecration of
 17641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTemples amongst the Heathen, as that the Priest laid his Hands on
 17642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome post of the Temple, all the while he was uttering the words of
 17643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsecration. So naturall it is to design any individuall thing, rather
 17644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Hand, to assure the Eyes, than by Words to inform the Eare in
 17645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmatters of Gods Publique service.
 17646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis ceremony was not therefore new in our Saviours time. For Jairus
 17648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Mark 5.23.) whose daughter was sick, besought our Saviour (not to heal
 17649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ther, but) "to Lay his Hands upon her, that shee might bee healed." And
 17650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Matth. 19.13.) "they brought unto him little children, that hee should
 17651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPut his Hands on them, and Pray."
 17652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAccording to this ancient Rite, the Apostles, and Presbyters, and the
 17654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresbytery it self, Laid Hands on them whom they ordained Pastors, and
 17655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithall prayed for them that they might receive the Holy Ghost; and that
 17656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot only once, but sometimes oftner, when a new occasion was presented:
 17657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the end was still the same, namely a punctuall, and religious
 17658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesignation of the person, ordained either to the Pastorall Charge
 17659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin general, or to a particular Mission: so (Act. 6.6.) "The Apostles
 17660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrayed, and Laid their Hands" on the seven Deacons; which was done,
 17661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot to give them the Holy Ghost, (for they were full of the Holy Ghost
 17662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore thy were chosen, as appeareth immediately before, verse 3.) but
 17663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto design them to that Office. And after Philip the Deacon had converted
 17664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcertain persons in Samaria, Peter and John went down (Act. 8.17.)" and
 17665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlaid their Hands on them, and they received the Holy Ghost." And not
 17666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonly an Apostle, but a Presbyter had this power: For S. Paul adviseth
 17667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTimothy (1 Tim. 5.22.) "Lay Hands suddenly on no man;" that is, designe
 17668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno man rashly to the Office of a Pastor. The whole Presbytery Laid their
 17669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHands on Timothy, as we read 1 Tim. 4.14. but this is to be understood,
 17670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas that some did it by the appointment of the Presbytery, and most
 17671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlikely their Proestos, or Prolocutor, which it may be was St. Paul
 17672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself. For in his 2 Epist. to Tim. ver. 6. he saith to him, "Stirre up
 17673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe gift of God which is in thee, by the Laying on of my Hands:" where
 17674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnote by the way, that by the Holy ghost, is not meant the third Person
 17675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Trinity, but the Gifts necessary to the Pastorall Office. We read
 17676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso, that St. Paul had Imposition of Hands twice; once from Ananias at
 17677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDamascus (Acts 9.17,18.) at the time of his Baptisme; and again (Acts
 17678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t13.3.) at Antioch, when he was first sent out to Preach. The use then of
 17679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis ceremony considered in the Ordination of Pastors, was to design
 17680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Person to whom they gave such Power. But if there had been then any
 17681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian, that had had the Power of Teaching before; the Baptizing of
 17682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, that is the making of him a Christian, had given him no new Power,
 17683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut had onely caused him to preach true Doctrine, that is, to use
 17684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Power aright; and therefore the Imposition of Hands had been
 17685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunnecessary; Baptisme it selfe had been sufficient. But every Soveraign,
 17686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore Christianity, had the power of Teaching, and Ordaining Teachers;
 17687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore Christianity gave them no new Right, but only directed
 17688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem in the way of teaching truth; and consequently they needed
 17689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno Imposition of Hands (besides that which is done in Baptisme) to
 17690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tauthorize them to exercise any part of the Pastorall Function, as
 17691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnamely, to Baptize, and Consecrate. And in the Old Testament, though
 17692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Priest only had right to Consecrate, during the time that the
 17693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty was in the High Priest; yet it was not so when the
 17694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty was in the King: For we read (1 Kings 8.) That Solomon
 17695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBlessed the People, Consecrated the Temple, and pronounced that Publique
 17696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrayer, which is the pattern now for Consecration of all Christian
 17697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurches, and Chappels: whereby it appears, he had not only the right
 17698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Ecclesiasticall Government; but also of exercising Ecclesiasticall
 17699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFunctions.
 17700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Civill Soveraigne If A Christian, Is Head Of The Church
 17705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn His Own Dominions
 17707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom this consolidation of the Right Politique, and Ecclesiastique in
 17709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Soveraigns, it is evident, they have all manner of Power over
 17710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Subjects, that can be given to man, for the government of mens
 17711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texternall actions, both in Policy, and Religion; and may make such
 17712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaws, as themselves shall judge fittest, for the government of their
 17713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town Subjects, both as they are the Common-wealth, and as they are the
 17714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch: for both State, and Church are the same men.
 17715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf they please therefore, they may (as many Christian Kings now doe)
 17717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommit the government of their Subjects in matters of Religion to
 17718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Pope; but then the Pope is in that point Subordinate to them, and
 17719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texerciseth that Charge in anothers Dominion Jure Civili, in the Right of
 17720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Civill Soveraign; not Jure Divino, in Gods Right; and may therefore
 17721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe discharged of that Office, when the Soveraign for the good of his
 17722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects shall think it necessary. They may also if they please,
 17723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommit the care of Religion to one Supreme Pastor, or to an Assembly of
 17724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors; and give them what power over the Church, or one over another,
 17725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey think most convenient; and what titles of honor, as of Bishops,
 17726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArchbishops, Priests, or Presbyters, they will; and make such Laws for
 17727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir maintenance, either by Tithes, or otherwise, as they please,
 17728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso they doe it out of a sincere conscience, of which God onely is
 17729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Judge. It is the Civill Soveraign, that is to appoint Judges, and
 17730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpreters of the Canonicall Scriptures; for it is he that maketh them
 17731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaws. It is he also that giveth strength to Excommunications; which but
 17732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor such Laws and Punishments, as may humble obstinate Libertines, and
 17733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treduce them to union with the rest of the Church, would bee
 17734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontemned. In summe, he hath the Supreme Power in all causes, as well
 17735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticall, as Civill, as far as concerneth actions, and words, for
 17736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese onely are known, and may be accused; and of that which cannot be
 17737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccused, there is no Judg at all, but God, that knoweth the heart.
 17738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd these Rights are incident to all Soveraigns, whether Monarchs, or
 17739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssemblies: for they that are the Representants of a Christian People,
 17740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Representants of the Church: for a Church, and a Common-wealth of
 17741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian People, are the same thing.
 17742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCardinal Bellarmines Books De Summo Pontifice Considered
 17747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThough this that I have here said, and in other places of this Book,
 17749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseem cleer enough for the asserting of the Supreme Ecclesiasticall Power
 17750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Christian Soveraigns; yet because the Pope of Romes challenge to that
 17751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower universally, hath been maintained chiefly, and I think as strongly
 17752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas is possible, by Cardinall Bellarmine, in his Controversie De Summo
 17753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPontifice; I have thought it necessary, as briefly as I can, to examine
 17754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe grounds, and strength of his Discourse.
 17755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe First Book
 17760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf five Books he hath written of this subject, the first containeth
 17762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthree Questions: One, Which is simply the best government, Monarchy,
 17763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAristocracy, or Democracy; and concludeth for neither, but for a
 17764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgovernment mixt of all there: Another, which of these is the best
 17765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment of the Church; and concludeth for the mixt, but which should
 17766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost participate of Monarchy: the third, whether in this mixt Monarchy,
 17767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Peter had the place of Monarch. Concerning his first Conclusion, I
 17768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave already sufficiently proved (chapt. 18.) that all Governments which
 17769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen are bound to obey, are Simple, and Absolute. In Monarchy there is
 17770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut One Man Supreme; and all other men that have any kind of Power in
 17771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe State, have it by his Commission, during his pleasure; and execute
 17772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit in his name: And in Aristocracy, and Democracy, but One Supreme
 17773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly, with the same Power that in Monarchy belongeth to the Monarch,
 17774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is not a Mixt, but an Absolute Soveraignty. And of the three
 17775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsorts, which is the best, is not to be disputed, where any one of them
 17776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis already established; but the present ought alwaies to be preferred,
 17777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmaintained, and accounted best; because it is against both the Law of
 17778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature, and the Divine positive Law, to doe any thing tending to the
 17779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubversion thereof. Besides, it maketh nothing to the Power of
 17780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany Pastor, (unlesse he have the Civill Soveraignty,) what kind of
 17781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment is the best; because their Calling is not to govern men by
 17782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandement, but to teach them, and perswade them by Arguments, and
 17783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleave it to them to consider, whether they shall embrace, or reject the
 17784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine taught. For Monarchy, Aristocracy, and Democracy, do mark out
 17785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunto us three sorts of Soveraigns, not of Pastors; or, as we may say,
 17786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthree sorts of Masters of Families, not three sorts of Schoolmasters for
 17787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir children.
 17788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore the second Conclusion, concerning the best form of
 17790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment of the Church, is nothing to the question of the Popes Power
 17791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout his own Dominions: For in all other Common-wealths his Power (if
 17792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee have any at all) is that of the Schoolmaster onely, and not of the
 17793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMaster of the Family.
 17794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the third Conclusion, which is, that St. Peter was Monarch of the
 17796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, he bringeth for his chiefe argument the place of S. Matth.
 17797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(chap. 16.18, 19.) "Thou art Peter, And upon this rock I will build my
 17798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, &c. And I will give thee the keyes of Heaven; whatsoever thou
 17799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshalt bind on Earth, shall be bound in Heaven, and whatsoever thou shalt
 17800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tloose on Earth, shall be loosed in Heaven." Which place well considered,
 17801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproveth no more, but that the Church of Christ hath for foundation one
 17802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely Article; namely, that which Peter in the name of all the Apostles
 17803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprofessing, gave occasion to our Saviour to speak the words here cited;
 17804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich that wee may cleerly understand, we are to consider, that our
 17805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour preached by himself, by John Baptist, and by his Apostles,
 17806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnothing but this Article of Faith, "that he was the Christ;" all other
 17807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArticles requiring faith no otherwise, than as founded on that. John
 17808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbegan first, (Mat. 3.2.) preaching only this, "The Kingdome of God is at
 17809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thand." Then our Saviour himself (Mat. 4.17.) preached the same: And to
 17810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Twelve Apostles, when he gave them their Commission (Mat. 10.7.)
 17811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is no mention of preaching any other Article but that. This was
 17812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe fundamentall Article, that is the Foundation of the Churches Faith.
 17813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfterwards the Apostles being returned to him, he asketh them all, (Mat.
 17814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t16.13) not Peter onely, "Who men said he was;" and they answered, that
 17815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"some said he was John the Baptist, some Elias, and others Jeremias,
 17816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor one of the Prophets:" Then (ver. 15.) he asked them all again, (not
 17817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeter onely) "Whom say yee that I am?" Therefore Peter answered (for
 17818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem all) "Thou art Christ, the Son of the Living God;" which I said is
 17819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Foundation of the Faith of the whole Church; from which our Saviour
 17820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttakes the occasion of saying, "Upon this stone I will build my Church;"
 17821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy which it is manifest, that by the Foundation-Stone of the Church, was
 17822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeant the Fundamentall Article of the Churches Faith. But why then (will
 17823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome object) doth our Saviour interpose these words, "Thou art Peter"?
 17824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf the originall of this text had been rigidly translated, the reason
 17825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould easily have appeared: We are therefore to consider, that the
 17826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostle Simon, was surnamed Stone, (which is the signification of
 17827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Syriacke word Cephas, and of the Greek word Petrus). Our Saviour
 17828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore after the confession of that Fundamentall Article, alluding
 17829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto his name, said (as if it were in English) thus, Thou art "Stone," and
 17830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon this Stone I will build my Church: which is as much as to say, this
 17831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArticle, that "I am the Christ," is the Foundation of all the Faith I
 17832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trequire in those that are to bee members of my Church: Neither is this
 17833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallusion to a name, an unusuall thing in common speech: But it had been
 17834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta strange, and obscure speech, if our Saviour intending to build his
 17835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch on the Person of St. Peter, had said, "thou art a Stone, and
 17836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon this Stone I will build my Church," when it was so obvious without
 17837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tambiguity to have said, "I will build my Church on thee; and yet there
 17838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad been still the same allusion to his name.
 17839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd for the following words, "I will give thee the Keyes of Heaven, &c."
 17841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is no more than what our Saviour gave also to all the rest of his
 17842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDisciples (Matth. 18.18.) "Whatsoever yee shall bind on Earth, shall be
 17843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbound in Heaven. And whatsoever ye shall loose on Earth, shall be loosed
 17844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Heaven." But howsoever this be interpreted, there is no doubt but
 17845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Power here granted belongs to all Supreme Pastors; such as are all
 17846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Civill Soveraignes in their own Dominions. In so much, as if
 17847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Peter, or our Saviour himself had converted any of them to beleeve
 17848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, and to acknowledge his Kingdome; yet because his Kingdome is not of
 17849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis world, he had left the supreme care of converting his subjects to
 17850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone but him; or else hee must have deprived him of the Soveraignty,
 17851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto which the Right of Teaching is inseparably annexed. And thus much in
 17852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trefutation of his first Book, wherein hee would prove St. Peter to have
 17853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen the Monarch Universall of the Church, that is to say, of all the
 17854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristians in the world.
 17855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Second Book
 17860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe second Book hath two Conclusions: One, that S. Peter was Bishop
 17862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Rome, and there dyed: The other, that the Popes of Rome are his
 17863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuccessors. Both which have been disputed by others. But supposing them
 17864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be true; yet if by Bishop of Rome bee understood either the
 17865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarch of the Church, or the Supreme Pastor of it; not Silvester, but
 17866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConstantine (who was the first Christian Emperour) was that Bishop; and
 17867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas Constantine, so all other Christian Emperors were of Right supreme
 17868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBishops of the Roman Empire; I say of the Roman Empire, not of all
 17869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristendome: For other Christian Soveraigns had the same Right in their
 17870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseverall Territories, as to an Office essentially adhaerent to their
