 17871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty. Which shall serve for answer to his second Book.
 17872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Third Book
 17877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the third Book, he handleth the question whether the Pope be
 17879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAntichrist. For my part, I see no argument that proves he is so, in that
 17880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense that Scripture useth the name: nor will I take any argument from
 17881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe quality of Antichrist, to contradict the Authority he exerciseth,
 17882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor hath heretofore exercised in the Dominions of any other Prince, or
 17883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tState.
 17884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is evident that the Prophets of the Old Testament foretold, and the
 17886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJews expected a Messiah, that is, a Christ, that should re-establish
 17887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst them the kingdom of God, which had been rejected by them in
 17888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe time of Samuel, when they required a King after the manner of
 17889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Nations. This expectation of theirs, made them obnoxious to the
 17890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImposture of all such, as had both the ambition to attempt the attaining
 17891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Kingdome, and the art to deceive the People by counterfeit
 17892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmiracles, by hypocriticall life, or by orations and doctrine plausible.
 17893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOur Saviour therefore, and his Apostles forewarned men of False
 17894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets, and of False Christs. False Christs, are such as pretend to
 17895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe the Christ, but are not, and are called properly Antichrists, in such
 17896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense, as when there happeneth a Schisme in the Church by the election
 17897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof two Popes, the one calleth the other Antipapa, or the false Pope.
 17898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore Antichrist in the proper signification hath two essentiall
 17899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmarks; One, that he denyeth Jesus to be Christ; and another that he
 17900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprofesseth himselfe to bee Christ. The first Mark is set down by S. John
 17901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his 1 Epist. 4. ch. 3. ver. "Every Spirit that confesseth not that
 17902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJesus Christ is come in the flesh, is not of God; And this is the Spirit
 17903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Antichrist." The other Mark is expressed in the words of our Saviour,
 17904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Mat. 24.5.) "Many shall come in my name, saying, I am Christ;" and
 17905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain, "If any man shall say unto you, Loe, here is Christ, there is
 17906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist beleeve it not." And therefore Antichrist must be a False Christ,
 17907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, some one of them that shall pretend themselves to be Christ.
 17908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd out of these two Marks, "to deny Jesus to be the Christ," and to
 17909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"affirm himselfe to be the Christ," it followeth, that he must also be
 17910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan "Adversary of the true Christ," which is another usuall signification
 17911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the word Antichrist. But of these many Antichrists, there is one
 17912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeciall one, O Antichristos, The Antichrist, or Antichrist definitely,
 17913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas one certaine person; not indefinitely An Antichrist. Now seeing the
 17914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPope of Rome, neither pretendeth himself, nor denyeth Jesus to be the
 17915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, I perceive not how he can be called Antichrist; by which word
 17916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not meant, one that falsely pretendeth to be His Lieutenant, or Vicar
 17917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGenerall, but to be Hee. There is also some Mark of the time of this
 17918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeciall Antichrist, as (Mat. 24.15.) when that abominable Destroyer,
 17919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspoken of by Daniel, (Dan. 9. 27.) shall stand in the Holy place, and
 17920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch tribulation as was not since the beginning of the world, nor ever
 17921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be again, insomuch as if it were to last long, (ver. 22.) "no
 17922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tflesh could be saved; but for the elects sake those days shall be
 17923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshortened" (made fewer). But that tribulation is not yet come; for it
 17924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to be followed immediately (ver. 29.) by a darkening of the Sun
 17925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Moon, a falling of the Stars, a concussion of the Heavens, and the
 17926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tglorious coming again of our Saviour, in the cloudes. And therefore The
 17927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAntichrist is not yet come; whereas, many Popes are both come and gone.
 17928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is true, the Pope in taking upon him to give Laws to all Christian
 17929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings, and Nations, usurpeth a Kingdome in this world, which Christ took
 17930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot on him: but he doth it not As Christ, but as For Christ, wherein
 17931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is nothing of the Antichrist.
 17932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Fourth Book
 17937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the fourth Book, to prove the Pope to be the supreme Judg in all
 17939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestions of Faith and Manners, (which is as much as to be the absolute
 17940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarch of all Christians in the world,) be bringeth three Propositions:
 17941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe first, that his Judgments are Infallible: The second, that he can
 17942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake very Laws, and punish those that observe them not: The third, that
 17943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour conferred all Jurisdiction Ecclesiasticall on the Pope of
 17944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRome.
 17945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTexts For The Infallibility Of The Popes Judgement In Points Of Faith
 17950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the Infallibility of his Judgments, he alledgeth the Scriptures: and
 17952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst, that of Luke 22.31. "Simon, Simon, Satan hath desired you that
 17953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee may sift you as wheat; but I have prayed for thee, that thy faith
 17954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaile not; and when thou art converted, strengthen thy Brethren." This,
 17955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccording to Bellarmines exposition, is, that Christ gave here to Simon
 17956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeter two priviledges: one, that neither his Faith should fail, neither
 17957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the, nor any of his successors should ever define any point concerning
 17958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith, or Manners erroneously, or contrary to the definition of a former
 17959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPope: Which is a strange, and very much strained interpretation. But he
 17960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat with attention readeth that chapter, shall find there is no place
 17961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the whole Scripture, that maketh more against the Popes Authority,
 17962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan this very place. The Priests and Scribes seeking to kill our
 17963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour at the Passeover, and Judas possessed with a resolution to
 17964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetray him, and the day of killing the Passeover being come, our Saviour
 17965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcelebrated the same with his Apostles, which he said, till the Kingdome
 17966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God was come hee would doe no more; and withall told them, that one
 17967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them was to betray him: Hereupon they questioned, which of them it
 17968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould be; and withall (seeing the next Passeover their Master would
 17969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcelebrate should be when he was King) entred into a contention, who
 17970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould then be the greater man. Our Saviour therefore told them, that
 17971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Kings of the Nations had Dominion over their Subjects, and are
 17972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled by a name (in Hebrew) that signifies Bountifull; but I cannot
 17973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe so to you, you must endeavour to serve one another; I ordain you a
 17974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome, but it is such as my Father hath ordained mee; a Kingdome that
 17975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI am now to purchase with my blood, and not to possesse till my second
 17976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcoming; then yee shall eat and drink at my Table, and sit on Thrones,
 17977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjudging the twelve Tribes of Israel: And then addressing himself to
 17978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Peter, he saith, Simon, Simon, Satan seeks by suggesting a present
 17979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdomination, to weaken your faith of the future; but I have prayed for
 17980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthee, that thy faith shall not fail; Thou therefore (Note this,) being
 17981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconverted, and understanding my Kingdome as of another world, confirm
 17982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same faith in thy Brethren: To which S. Peter answered (as one that
 17983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno more expected any authority in this world) "Lord I am ready to goe
 17984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith thee, not onely to Prison, but to Death." Whereby it is manifest,
 17985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tS. Peter had not onely no jurisdiction given him in this world, but a
 17986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcharge to teach all the other Apostles, that they also should have none.
 17987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd for the Infallibility of St. Peters sentence definitive in matter
 17988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Faith, there is no more to be attributed to it out of this Text, than
 17989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Peter should continue in the beleef of this point, namely, that
 17990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist should come again, and possesse the Kingdome at the day of
 17991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgement; which was not given by the Text to all his Successors; for
 17992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twee see they claim it in the World that now is.
 17993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 17994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe second place is that of Matth. 16. "Thou art Peter, and upon this
 17995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trocke I will build my Church, and the gates of Hell shall not prevail
 17996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst it." By which (as I have already shewn in this chapter) is
 17997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproved no more, than that the gates of Hell shall not prevail against
 17998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe confession of Peter, which gave occasion to that speech; namely
 17999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis, That Jesus Is Christ The Sonne Of God.
 18000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe third text is John 21. ver. 16,17. "Feed my sheep;" which contains
 18002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno more but a Commission of Teaching: And if we grant the rest of the
 18003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles to be contained in that name of Sheep; then it is the supreme
 18004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower of Teaching: but it was onely for the time that there were no
 18005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Soveraigns already possessed of that Supremacy. But I have
 18006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready proved, that Christian Soveraignes are in their owne Dominions
 18007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe supreme Pastors, and instituted thereto, by vertue of their being
 18008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBaptized, though without other Imposition of Hands. For such imposition
 18009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing a Ceremony of designing the person, is needlesse, when hee is
 18010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready designed to the Power of Teaching what Doctrine he will, by his
 18011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinstitution to an Absolute Power over his Subjects. For as I have proved
 18012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore, Soveraigns are supreme Teachers (in generall) by their Office
 18013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore oblige themselves (by their Baptisme) to teach the
 18014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine of Christ: And when they suffer others to teach their people,
 18015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey doe it at the perill of their own souls; for it is at the hands
 18016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Heads of Families that God will require the account of the
 18017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinstruction of his Children and Servants. It is of Abraham himself,
 18018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot of a hireling, that God saith (Gen. 18.19) "I know him that he will
 18019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommand his Children, and his houshold after him, that they keep the way
 18020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Lord, and do justice and judgement.
 18021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fourth place is that of Exod. 28.30. "Thou shalt put in the
 18023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBreastplate of Judgment, the Urim and the Thummin:" which hee saith is
 18024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterpreted by the Septuagint, delosin kai aletheian, that is, Evidence
 18025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Truth: And thence concludeth, God had given Evidence, and Truth,
 18026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which is almost infallibility,) to the High Priest. But be it Evidence
 18027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Truth it selfe that was given; or be it but Admonition to the Priest
 18028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto endeavour to inform himself cleerly, and give judgment uprightly;
 18029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet in that it was given to the High Priest, it was given to the Civill
 18030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign: For next under God was the High Priest in the Common-wealth
 18031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Israel; and is an argument for Evidence and Truth, that is, for the
 18032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticall Supremacy of Civill Soveraigns over their own Subjects,
 18033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the pretended Power of the Pope. These are all the Texts hee
 18034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbringeth for the Infallibility of the Judgement of the Pope, in point of
 18035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith.
 18036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTexts For The Same In Point Of Manners
 18041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the Infallibility of his Judgment concerning Manners, hee bringeth
 18043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone Text, which is that of John 16.13. "When the Spirit of truth is
 18044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome, hee will lead you into all truth" where (saith he) by All Truth,
 18045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis meant, at least, All Truth Necessary To Salvation. But with this
 18046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmitigation, he attributeth no more Infallibility to the Pope, than to
 18047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany man that professeth Christianity, and is not to be damned: For
 18048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif any man erre in any point, wherein not to erre is necessary to
 18049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation, it is impossible he should be saved; for that onely is
 18050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessary to Salvation, without which to be saved is impossible. What
 18051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpoints these are, I shall declare out of the Scripture in the Chapter
 18052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollowing. In this place I say no more, but that though it were granted,
 18053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Pope could not possibly teach any error at all, yet doth not this
 18054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tentitle him to any Jurisdiction in the Dominions of another Prince,
 18055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunlesse we shall also say, a man is obliged in conscience to set on
 18056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twork upon all occasions the best workman, even then also when he hath
 18057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformerly promised his work to another.
 18058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBesides the Text, he argueth from Reason, thus, If the Pope could erre
 18060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin necessaries, then Christ hath not sufficiently provided for the
 18061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurches Salvation; because he hath commanded her to follow the Popes
 18062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdirections. But this Reason is invalid, unlesse he shew when, and where
 18063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist commanded that, or took at all any notice of a Pope: Nay granting
 18064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever was given to S. Peter was given to the Pope; yet seeing there
 18065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis in the Scripture no command to any man to obey St. Peter, no man can
 18066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee just, that obeyeth him, when his commands are contrary to those of
 18067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this lawfull Soveraign.
 18068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, it hath not been declared by the Church, nor by the Pope
 18070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe, that he is the Civill Soveraign of all the Christians in the
 18071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld; and therefore all Christians are not bound to acknowledge his
 18072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJurisdiction in point of Manners. For the Civill Soveraignty, and
 18073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupreme Judicature in controversies of Manners, are the same thing: And
 18074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Makers of Civill Laws, are not onely Declarers, but also Makers
 18075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the justice, and injustice of actions; there being nothing in mens
 18076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tManners that makes them righteous, or unrighteous, but their conformity
 18077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the Law of the Soveraign. And therefore when the Pope challengeth
 18078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSupremacy in controversies of Manners, hee teacheth men to disobey the
 18079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Soveraign; which is an erroneous Doctrine, contrary to the
 18080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany precepts of our Saviour and his Apostles, delivered to us in the
 18081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture.
 18082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo prove the Pope has Power to make Laws, he alledgeth many places; as
 18084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst, Deut. 17.12. "The man that will doe presumptuously, and will not
 18085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thearken unto the Priest, (that standeth to Minister there before the
 18086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLord thy God, or unto the Judge,) even that man shall die, and thou
 18087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshalt put away the evill from Israel." For answer whereunto, we are to
 18088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tremember that the High Priest (next and immediately under God) was the
 18089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Soveraign; and all Judges were to be constituted by him. The
 18090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords alledged sound therefore thus. "The man that will presume to
 18091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisobey the Civill Soveraign for the time being, or any of his Officers
 18092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the execution of their places, that man shall die, &c." which is
 18093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcleerly for the Civill Soveraignty, against the Universall power of the
 18094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPope.
 18095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecondly, he alledgeth that of Matth. 16. "Whatsoever yee shall bind,
 18097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t&c." and interpreteth it for such Binding as is attributed (Matth.
 18098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t23.4.) to the Scribes and Pharisees, "They bind heavy burthens, and
 18099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrievous to be born, and lay them on mens shoulders;" by which is meant
 18100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(he sayes) Making of Laws; and concludes thence, the Pope can make
 18101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaws. But this also maketh onely for the Legislative power of Civill
 18102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns: For the Scribes, and Pharisees sat in Moses Chaire,
 18103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut Moses next under God was Soveraign of the People of Israel: and
 18104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore our Saviour commanded them to doe all that they should say,
 18105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut not all that they should do. That is, to obey their Laws, but not
 18106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollow their Example.
 18107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe third place, is John 21.16. "Feed my sheep;" which is not a Power
 18109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto make Laws, but a command to Teach. Making Laws belongs to the Lord of
 18110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Family; who by his owne discretion chooseth his Chaplain, as also a
 18111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSchoolmaster to Teach his children.
 18112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fourth place John 20.21. is against him. The words are, "As my
 18114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFather sent me, so send I you." But our Saviour was sent to Redeem (by
 18115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Death) such as should Beleeve; and by his own, and his Apostles
 18116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreaching to prepare them for their entrance into his Kingdome; which he
 18117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself saith, is not of this world, and hath taught us to pray for the
 18118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcoming of it hereafter, though hee refused (Acts 1.6,7.) to tell his
 18119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles when it should come; and in which, when it comes, the twelve
 18120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles shall sit on twelve Thrones (every one perhaps as high as that
 18121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof St. Peter) to judge the twelve tribes of Israel. Seeing then God the
 18122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFather sent not our Saviour to make Laws in this present world, wee may
 18123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconclude from the Text, that neither did our Saviour send S. Peter to
 18124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake Laws here, but to perswade men to expect his second comming with
 18125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta stedfast faith; and in the mean time, if Subjects, to obey their
 18126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrinces; and if Princes, both to beleeve it themselves, and to do their
 18127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbest to make their Subjects doe the same; which is the Office of a
 18128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBishop. Therefore this place maketh most strongly for the joining of the
 18129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticall Supremacy to the Civill Soveraignty, contrary to that
 18130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich Cardinall Bellarmine alledgeth it for.
 18131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fift place is Acts 15.28. "It hath seemed good to the Holy Spirit,
 18133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to us, to lay upon you no greater burden, than these necessary
 18134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings, that yee abstaine from meats offered to Idols, and from bloud,
 18135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand from things strangled, and from fornication." Here hee notes the
 18136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tword Laying Of Burdens for the Legislative Power. But who is there,
 18137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat reading this Text, can say, this stile of the Apostles may not as
 18138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproperly be used in giving Counsell, as in making Laws? The stile of a
 18139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw is, We Command: But, We Think Good, is the ordinary stile of them,
 18140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat but give Advice; and they lay a Burthen that give Advice, though
 18141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit bee conditionall, that is, if they to whom they give it, will
 18142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tattain their ends: And such is the Burthen, of abstaining from things
 18143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstrangled, and from bloud; not absolute, but in case they will not
 18144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\terre. I have shewn before (chap. 25.) that Law, is distinguished from
 18145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell, in this, that the reason of a Law, is taken from the designe,
 18146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand benefit of him that prescribeth it; but the reason of a Counsell,
 18147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the designe, and benefit of him, to whom the Counsell is given. But
 18148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\there, the Apostles aime onely at the benefit of the converted Gentiles,
 18149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnamely their Salvation; not at their own benefit; for having done their
 18150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tendeavour, they shall have their reward, whether they be obeyed, or not.
 18151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore the Acts of this Councell, were not Laws, but Counsells.
 18152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe sixt place is that of Rom. 13. "Let every Soul be subject to the
 18154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHigher Powers, for there is no Power but of God;" which is meant, he
 18155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaith not onely of Secular, but also of Ecclesiasticall Princes. To
 18156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich I answer, first, that there are no Ecclesiasticall Princes but
 18157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that are also Civill Soveraignes; and their Principalities exceed
 18158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot the compasse of their Civill Soveraignty; without those bounds
 18159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough they may be received for Doctors, they cannot be acknowledged for
 18160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrinces. For if the Apostle had meant, we should be subject both to our
 18161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town Princes, and also to the Pope, he had taught us a doctrine, which
 18162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist himself hath told us is impossible, namely, "to serve two
 18163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMasters." And though the Apostle say in another place, "I write these
 18164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings being absent, lest being present I should use sharpnesse,
 18165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccording to the Power which the Lord hath given me;" it is not, that
 18166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the challenged a Power either to put to death, imprison, banish, whip,
 18167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor fine any of them, which are Punishments; but onely to Excommunicate,
 18168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich (without the Civill Power) is no more but a leaving of their
 18169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcompany, and having no more to doe with them, than with a Heathen man,
 18170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor a Publican; which in many occasions might be a greater pain to the
 18171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcommunicant, than to the Excommunicate.
 18172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe seventh place is 1 Cor. 4.21. "Shall I come unto you with a Rod, or
 18174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin love, and the spirit of lenity?" But here again, it is not the Power
 18175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Magistrate to punish offenders, that is meant by a Rod; but
 18176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely the Power of Excommunication, which is not in its owne nature
 18177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Punishment, but onely a Denouncing of punishment, that Christ shall
 18178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinflict, when he shall be in possession of his Kingdome, at the day of
 18179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgment. Nor then also shall it bee properly a Punishment, as upon a
 18180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubject that hath broken the Law; but a Revenge, as upon an Enemy, or
 18181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRevolter, that denyeth the Right of our Saviour to the Kingdome: And
 18182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore this proveth not the Legislative Power of any Bishop, that has
 18183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot also the Civill Power.
 18184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe eighth place is, Timothy 3.2. "A Bishop must be the husband but of
 18186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone wife, vigilant, sober, &c." which he saith was a Law. I thought that
 18187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone could make a Law in the Church, but the Monarch of the Church, St.
 18188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeter. But suppose this Precept made by the authority of St. Peter;
 18189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet I see no reason why to call it a Law, rather than an Advice, seeing
 18190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTimothy was not a Subject, but a Disciple of St. Paul; nor the flock
 18191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder the charge of Timothy, his Subjects in the Kingdome, but his
 18192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScholars in the Schoole of Christ: If all the Precepts he giveth
 18193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTimothy, be Laws, why is not this also a Law, "Drink no longer water,
 18194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut use a little wine for thy healths sake"? And why are not also
 18195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Precepts of good Physitians, so many Laws? but that it is not the
 18196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImperative manner of speaking, but an absolute Subjection to a Person,
 18197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat maketh his Precept Laws.
 18198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn like manner, the ninth place, 1 Tim. 5. 19. "Against an Elder
 18200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceive not an accusation, but before two or three Witnesses," is a wise
 18201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrecept, but not a Law.
 18202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe tenth place is, Luke 10.16. "He that heareth you, heareth mee; and
 18204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the that despiseth you, despiseth me." And there is no doubt, but he that
 18205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdespiseth the Counsell of those that are sent by Christ, despiseth
 18206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Counsell of Christ himself. But who are those now that are sent by
 18207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, but such as are ordained Pastors by lawfull Authority? and who
 18208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare lawfully ordained, that are not ordained by the Soveraign
 18209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastor? and who is ordained by the Soveraign Pastor in a Christian
 18210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, that is not ordained by the authority of the Soveraign
 18211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof? Out of this place therefore it followeth, that he which heareth
 18212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Soveraign being a Christian, heareth Christ; and hee that despiseth
 18213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Doctrine which his King being a Christian, authorizeth, despiseth
 18214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Doctrine of Christ (which is not that which Bellarmine intendeth
 18215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\there to prove, but the contrary). But all this is nothing to a Law. Nay
 18216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore, a Christian King, as a Pastor, and Teacher of his Subjects, makes
 18217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot thereby his Doctrines Laws. He cannot oblige men to beleeve; though
 18218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas a Civill Soveraign he may make Laws suitable to his Doctrine, which
 18219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay oblige men to certain actions, and sometimes to such as they would
 18220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot otherwise do, and which he ought not to command; and yet when
 18221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are commanded, they are Laws; and the externall actions done in
 18222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobedience to them, without the inward approbation, are the actions of
 18223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign, and not of the Subject, which is in that case but as
 18224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan instrument, without any motion of his owne at all; because God hath
 18225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommanded to obey them.
 18226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe eleventh, is every place, where the Apostle for Counsell, putteth
 18228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome word, by which men use to signifie Command; or calleth the
 18229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollowing of his Counsell, by the name of Obedience. And therefore they
 18230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare alledged out of 1 Cor. 11.2. "I commend you for keeping my Precepts
 18231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas I delivered them to you." The Greek is, "I commend you for keeping
 18232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose things I delivered to you, as I delivered them." Which is far from
 18233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifying that they were Laws, or any thing else, but good Counsell.
 18234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd that of 1 Thess. 4.2. "You know what commandements we gave you:"
 18235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere the Greek word is paraggelias edokamen, equivalent to paredokamen,
 18236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat wee delivered to you, as in the place next before alledged, which
 18237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoes not prove the Traditions of the Apostles, to be any more than
 18238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsells; though as is said in the 8th verse, "he that despiseth them,
 18239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdespiseth not man, but God": For our Saviour himself came not to Judge,
 18240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, to be King in this world; but to Sacrifice himself for Sinners,
 18241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand leave Doctors in his Church, to lead, not to drive men to Christ,
 18242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho never accepteth forced actions, (which is all the Law produceth,)
 18243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the inward conversion of the heart; which is not the work of Laws,
 18244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut of Counsell, and Doctrine.
 18245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd that of 2 Thess. 3.14. "If any man Obey not our word by this
 18247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEpistle, note that man, and have no company with him, that he may bee
 18248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tashamed": where from the word Obey, he would inferre, that this Epistle
 18249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas a Law to the Thessalonians. The Epistles of the Emperours were
 18250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tindeed Laws. If therefore the Epistle of S. Paul were also a Law, they
 18251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere to obey two Masters. But the word Obey, as it is in the Greek
 18252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupakouei, signifieth Hearkening To, or Putting In Practice, not onely
 18253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which is Commanded by him that has right to punish, but also that
 18254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is delivered in a way of Counsell for our good; and therefore St.
 18255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPaul does not bid kill him that disobeys, nor beat, nor imprison, nor
 18256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamerce him, which Legislators may all do; but avoid his company, that
 18257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the may bee ashamed: whereby it is evident, it was not the Empire of an
 18258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostle, but his Reputation amongst the Faithfull, which the Christians
 18259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstood in awe of.
 18260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe last place is that of Heb. 13.17. "Obey your Leaders, and submit
 18262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyour selves to them, for they watch for your souls, as they that must
 18263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive account:" And here also is intended by Obedience, a following of
 18264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Counsell: For the reason of our Obedience, is not drawn from the
 18265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill and command of our Pastors, but from our own benefit, as being the
 18266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation of our Souls they watch for, and not for the Exaltation of
 18267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own Power, and Authority. If it were meant here, that all they
 18268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tteach were Laws, then not onely the Pope, but every Pastor in his Parish
 18269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould have Legislative Power. Again, they that are bound to obey, their
 18270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors, have no power to examine their commands. What then shall wee
 18271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay to St. John who bids us (1 Epist. chap. 4. ver. 1.) "Not to beleeve
 18272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery Spirit, but to try the Spirits whether they are of God, because
 18273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmany false Prophets are gone out into the world"? It is therefore
 18274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest, that wee may dispute the Doctrine of our Pastors; but no man
 18275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan dispute a Law. The Commands of Civill Soveraigns are on all sides
 18276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgranted to be Laws: if any else can make a Law besides himselfe, all
 18277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth, and consequently all Peace, and Justice must cease; which
 18278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis contrary to all Laws, both Divine and Humane. Nothing therefore can
 18279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe drawn from these, or any other places of Scripture, to prove the
 18280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDecrees of the Pope, where he has not also the Civill Soveraignty, to be
 18281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaws.
 18282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Question Of Superiority Between The Pope And Other Bishops The last
 18284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpoint hee would prove, is this, "That our Saviour Christ has committed
 18285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticall Jurisdiction immediately to none but the Pope." Wherein
 18286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the handleth not the Question of Supremacy between the Pope and Christian
 18287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings, but between the Pope and other Bishops. And first, he sayes it is
 18288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagreed, that the Jurisdiction of Bishops, is at least in the generall
 18289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDe Jure Divino, that is, in the Right of God; for which he alledges S.
 18290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPaul, Ephes. 4.11. where hee sayes, that Christ after his Ascension
 18291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto heaven, "gave gifts to men, some Apostles, some Prophets, and some
 18292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvangelists, and some Pastors, and some Teachers:" And thence inferres,
 18293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey have indeed their Jurisdiction in Gods Right; but will not grant
 18294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey have it immediately from God, but derived through the Pope. But if
 18295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man may be said to have his Jurisdiction De Jure Divino, and yet not
 18296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timmediately; what lawfull Jurisdiction, though but Civill, is there in a
 18297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Common-wealth, that is not also De Jure Divino? For Christian
 18298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKings have their Civill Power from God immediately; and the Magistrates
 18299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder him exercise their severall charges in vertue of his Commission;
 18300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twherein that which they doe, is no lesse De Jure Divino Mediato, than
 18301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which the Bishops doe, in vertue of the Popes Ordination. All
 18302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfull Power is of God, immediately in the Supreme Governour, and
 18303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmediately in those that have Authority under him: So that either hee
 18304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmust grant every Constable in the State, to hold his Office in the Right
 18305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God; or he must not hold that any Bishop holds his so, besides the
 18306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPope himselfe.
 18307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut this whole Dispute, whether Christ left the Jurisdiction to the Pope
 18309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely, or to other Bishops also, if considered out of these places where
 18310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Pope has the Civill Soveraignty, is a contention De Lana Caprina:
 18311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor none of them (where they are not Soveraigns) has any Jurisdiction
 18312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat all. For Jurisdiction is the Power of hearing and determining Causes
 18313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetween man and man; and can belong to none, but him that hath the Power
 18314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto prescribe the Rules of Right and Wrong; that is, to make Laws;
 18315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand with the Sword of Justice to compell men to obey his Decisions,
 18316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpronounced either by himself, or by the Judges he ordaineth thereunto;
 18317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich none can lawfully do, but the Civill Soveraign.
 18318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore when he alledgeth out of the 6 of Luke, that our Saviour
 18320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled his Disciples together, and chose twelve of them which he named
 18321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles, he proveth that he Elected them (all, except Matthias, Paul
 18322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Barnabas,) and gave them Power and Command to Preach, but not
 18323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Judge of Causes between man and man: for that is a Power which
 18324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the refused to take upon himselfe, saying, "Who made me a Judge, or a
 18325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivider, amongst you?" and in another place, "My Kingdome is not of this
 18326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld." But hee that hath not the Power to hear, and determine Causes
 18327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetween man and man, cannot be said to have any Jurisdiction at all. And
 18328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet this hinders not, but that our Saviour gave them Power to Preach and
 18329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBaptize in all parts of the world, supposing they were not by their own
 18330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfull Soveraign forbidden: For to our own Soveraigns Christ himself,
 18331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand his Apostles have in sundry places expressely commanded us in all
 18332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings to be obedient.
 18333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe arguments by which he would prove, that Bishops receive their
 18335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJurisdiction from the Pope (seeing the Pope in the Dominions of other
 18336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrinces hath no Jurisdiction himself,) are all in vain. Yet because they
 18337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprove, on the contrary, that all Bishops receive Jurisdiction when they
 18338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave it from their Civill Soveraigns, I will not omit the recitall of
 18339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem.
 18340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe first, is from Numbers 11. where Moses not being able alone to
 18342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tundergoe the whole burthen of administring the affairs of the People of
 18343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsrael, God commanded him to choose Seventy Elders, and took part of
 18344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe spirit of Moses, to put it upon those Seventy Elders: by which it is
 18345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood, not that God weakened the spirit of Moses, for that had not
 18346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teased him at all; but that they had all of them their authority from
 18347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim; wherein he doth truly, and ingenuously interpret that place. But
 18348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseeing Moses had the entire Soveraignty in the Common-wealth of the
 18349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJews, it is manifest, that it is thereby signified, that they had their
 18350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority from the Civill Soveraign: and therefore that place proveth,
 18351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Bishops in every Christian Common-wealth have their Authority from
 18352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Civill Soveraign; and from the Pope in his own Territories only, and
 18353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot in the Territories of any other State.
 18354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe second argument, is from the nature of Monarchy; wherein all
 18356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority is in one Man, and in others by derivation from him: But the
 18357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment of the Church, he says, is Monarchicall. This also makes for
 18358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Monarchs. For they are really Monarchs of their own people;
 18359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, of their own Church (for the Church is the same thing with a
 18360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian people;) whereas the Power of the Pope, though hee were
 18361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tS. Peter, is neither Monarchy, nor hath any thing of Archicall, nor
 18362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCraticall, but onely of Didacticall; For God accepteth not a forced, but
 18363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta willing obedience.
 18364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe third, is, from that the Sea of S. Peter is called by S. Cyprian,
 18366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Head, the Source, the Roote, the Sun, from whence the Authority
 18367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Bishops is derived. But by the Law of Nature (which is a better
 18368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrinciple of Right and Wrong, than the word of any Doctor that is but
 18369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man) the Civill Soveraign in every Common-wealth, is the Head, the
 18370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSource, the Root, and the Sun, from which all Jurisdiction is derived.
 18371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore, the Jurisdiction of Bishops, is derived from the Civill
 18372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign.
 18373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fourth, is taken from the Inequality of their Jurisdictions: For
 18375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif God (saith he) had given it them immediately, he had given aswell
 18376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEquality of Jurisdiction, as of Order: But wee see, some are Bishops but
 18377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof own Town, some of a hundred Towns, and some of many whole Provinces;
 18378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich differences were not determined by the command of God; their
 18379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJurisdiction therefore is not of God, but of Man; and one has a
 18380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreater, another a lesse, as it pleaseth the Prince of the Church. Which
 18381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\targument, if he had proved before, that the Pope had had an Universall
 18382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJurisdiction over all Christians, had been for his purpose. But seeing
 18383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat hath not been proved, and that it is notoriously known, the large
 18384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJurisdiction of the Pope was given him by those that had it, that is,
 18385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Emperours of Rome, (for the Patriarch of Constantinople, upon the
 18386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame title, namely, of being Bishop of the Capitall City of the Empire,
 18387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Seat of the Emperour, claimed to be equal to him,) it followeth,
 18388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat all other Bishops have their Jurisdiction from the Soveraigns of
 18389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe place wherein they exercise the same: And as for that cause they
 18390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave not their Authority De Jure Divino; so neither hath the Pope his De
 18391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJure Divino, except onely where hee is also the Civill Soveraign.
 18392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHis fift argument is this, "If Bishops have their Jurisdiction
 18394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timmediately from God, the Pope could not take it from them, for he can
 18395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoe nothing contrary to Gods ordination;" And this consequence is good,
 18396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand well proved. "But, (saith he) the Pope can do this, and has done
 18397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit." This also is granted, so he doe it in his own Dominions, or in the
 18398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominions of any other Prince that hath given him that Power; but not
 18399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuniversally, in Right of the Popedome: For that power belongeth to
 18400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery Christian Soveraign, within the bounds of his owne Empire, and is
 18401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinseparable from the Soveraignty. Before the People of Israel had (by
 18402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe commandment of God to Samuel) set over themselves a King, after the
 18403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner of other Nations, the High Priest had the Civill Government; and
 18404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone but he could make, nor depose an inferiour Priest: But that Power
 18405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas afterwards in the King, as may be proved by this same argument of
 18406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBellarmine; For if the Priest (be he the High Priest or any other) had
 18407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Jurisdiction immediately from God, then the King could not take it
 18408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom him; "for he could do nothing contrary to Gods ordinance: But it
 18409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis certain, that King Solomon (1 Kings 2.26.) deprived Abiathar the High
 18410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriest of his office, and placed Zadok (verse 35.) in his room. Kings
 18411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore may in the like manner Ordaine, and Deprive Bishops, as they
 18412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall thinke fit, for the well governing of their Subjects.
 18413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHis sixth argument is this, If Bishops have their Jurisdiction De Jure
 18415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivino (that is, immediately from God,) they that maintaine it, should
 18416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbring some Word of God to prove it: But they can bring none. The
 18417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\targument is good; I have therefore nothing to say against it. But it
 18418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis an argument no lesse good, to prove the Pope himself to have no
 18419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJurisdiction in the Dominion of any other Prince.
 18420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, hee bringeth for argument, the testimony of two Popes, Innocent,
 18422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Leo; and I doubt not but hee might have alledged, with as good
 18423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treason, the testimonies of all the Popes almost since S. Peter: For
 18424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsidering the love of Power naturally implanted in mankind, whosoever
 18425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere made Pope, he would be tempted to uphold the same opinion.
 18426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse, they should therein but doe, as Innocent, and Leo did,
 18427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbear witnesse of themselves, and therefore their witness should not be
 18428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood.
 18429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Popes Temporall Power
 18434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the fift Book he hath four Conclusions. The first is, "That the Pope
 18436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin not Lord of all the world:" the second, "that the Pope is not Lord
 18437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof all the Christian world:" The third, "That the Pope (without his owne
 18438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTerritory) has not any Temporall Jurisdiction DIRECTLY:" These three
 18439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConclusions are easily granted. The fourth is, "That the Pope has (in
 18440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Dominions of other Princes) the Supreme Temporall Power INDIRECTLY:"
 18441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is denyed; unlesse he mean by Indirectly, that he has gotten it by
 18442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIndirect means; then is that also granted. But I understand, that
 18443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen he saith he hath it Indirectly, he means, that such Temporall
 18444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJurisdiction belongeth to him of Right, but that this Right is but a
 18445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsequence of his Pastorall Authority, the which he could not exercise,
 18446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunlesse he have the other with it: And therefore to the Pastorall Power
 18447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(which he calls Spirituall) the Supreme Power Civill is necessarily
 18448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tannexed; and that thereby hee hath a Right to change Kingdomes, giving
 18449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem to one, and taking them from another, when he shall think it
 18450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconduces to the Salvation of Souls.
 18451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBefore I come to consider the Arguments by which hee would prove this
 18453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoctrine, it will not bee amisse to lay open the Consequences of it;
 18454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Princes, and States, that have the Civill Soveraignty in their
 18455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseverall Common-wealths, may bethink themselves, whether it bee
 18456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconvenient for them, and conducing to the good of their Subjects, of
 18457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom they are to give an account at the day of Judgment, to admit the
 18458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame.
 18459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen it is said, the Pope hath not (in the Territories of other States)
 18461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Supreme Civill Power Directly; we are to understand, he doth
 18462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot challenge it, as other Civill Soveraigns doe, from the originall
 18463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubmission thereto of those that are to be governed. For it is evident,
 18464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand has already been sufficiently in this Treatise demonstrated, that
 18465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Right of all Soveraigns, is derived originally from the consent of
 18466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one of those that are to bee governed; whether they that choose
 18467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, doe it for their common defence against an Enemy, as when they
 18468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagree amongst themselves to appoint a Man, or an Assembly of men to
 18469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprotect them; or whether they doe it, to save their lives, by submission
 18470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto a conquering Enemy. The Pope therefore, when he disclaimeth the
 18471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSupreme Civill Power over other States Directly, denyeth no more, but
 18472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat his Right cometh to him by that way; He ceaseth not for all that,
 18473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto claime it another way; and that is, (without the consent of them
 18474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat are to be governed) by a Right given him by God, (which hee calleth
 18475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIndirectly,) in his Assumption to the Papacy. But by what way soever he
 18476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretend, the Power is the same; and he may (if it bee granted to be his
 18477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight) depose Princes and States, as often as it is for the Salvation
 18478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Soules, that is, as often as he will; for he claimeth also the Sole
 18479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower to Judge, whether it be to the salvation of mens Souls, or not.
 18480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd this is the Doctrine, not onely that Bellarmine here, and many other
 18481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctors teach in their Sermons and Books, but also that some
 18482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCouncells have decreed, and the Popes have decreed, and the Popes have
 18483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccordingly, when the occasion hath served them, put in practise. For
 18484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe fourth Councell of Lateran held under Pope Innocent the third, (in
 18485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe third Chap. De Haereticis,) hath this Canon. "If a King at the
 18486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPopes admonition, doe not purge his Kingdome of Haeretiques, and being
 18487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcommunicate for the same, make not satisfaction within a year, his
 18488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubjects are absolved of their Obedience." And the practise hereof hath
 18489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen seen on divers occasions; as in the Deposing of Chilperique, King
 18490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof France; in the Translation of the Roman Empire to Charlemaine; in
 18491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Oppression of John King of England; in Transferring the Kingdome
 18492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Navarre; and of late years, in the League against Henry the third of
 18493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrance, and in many more occurrences. I think there be few Princes that
 18494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsider not this as Injust, and Inconvenient; but I wish they would
 18495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall resolve to be Kings, or Subjects. Men cannot serve two Masters: They
 18496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought therefore to ease them, either by holding the Reins of Government
 18497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twholly in their own hands; or by wholly delivering them into the
 18498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thands of the Pope; that such men as are willing to be obedient, may be
 18499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprotected in their obedience. For this distinction of Temporall, and
 18500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirituall Power is but words. Power is as really divided, and as
 18501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdangerously to all purposes, by sharing with another Indirect Power, as
 18502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith a Direct one. But to come now to his Arguments.
 18503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe first is this, "The Civill Power is subject to the Spirituall:
 18505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore he that hath the Supreme Power Spirituall, hath right to
 18506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommand Temporall Princes, and dispose of their Temporalls in order to
 18507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Spirituall. As for the distinction of Temporall, and Spirituall,
 18508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlet us consider in what sense it may be said intelligibly, that the
 18509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTemporall, or Civill Power is subject to the Spirituall. There be but
 18510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttwo ways that those words can be made sense. For when wee say, one Power
 18511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis subject to another Power, the meaning either is, that he which hath
 18512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe one, is subject to him that hath the other; or that the one Power is
 18513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the other, as the means to the end. For wee cannot understand, that
 18514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone Power hath Power over another Power; and that one Power can have
 18515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight or Command over another: For Subjection, Command, Right, and
 18516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower are accidents, not of Powers, but of Persons: One Power may be
 18517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubordinate to another, as the art of a Sadler, to the art of a Rider.
 18518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf then it be granted, that the Civill Government be ordained as a means
 18519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto bring us to a Spirituall felicity; yet it does not follow, that if a
 18520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing have the Civill Power, and the Pope the Spirituall, that therefore
 18521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe King is bound to obey the Pope, more then every Sadler is bound to
 18522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobey every Rider. Therefore as from Subordination of an Art, cannot be
 18523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinferred the Subjection of the Professor; so from the Subordination of
 18524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Government, cannot be inferred the Subjection of the Governor. When
 18525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore he saith, the Civill Power is Subject to the Spirituall, his
 18526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeaning is, that the Civill Soveraign, is Subject to the Spirituall
 18527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign. And the Argument stands thus, "The Civil Soveraign, is
 18528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject to the Spirituall; Therefore the Spirituall Prince may
 18529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommand Temporall Princes." Where the conclusion is the same, with the
 18530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAntecedent he should have proved. But to prove it, he alledgeth
 18531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst, this reason, "Kings and Popes, Clergy and Laity make but one
 18532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; that is to say, but one Church: And in all Bodies the
 18533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMembers depend one upon another: But things Spirituall depend not
 18534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof things Temporall: Therefore, Temporall depend on Spirituall. And
 18535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore are Subject to them." In which Argumentation there be two
 18536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrosse errours: one is, that all Christian Kings, Popes, Clergy, and all
 18537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Christian men, make but one Common-wealth: For it is evident that
 18538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrance is one Common-wealth, Spain another, and Venice a third, &c. And
 18539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese consist of Christians; and therefore also are severall Bodies
 18540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Christians; that is to say, severall Churches: And their severall
 18541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns Represent them, whereby they are capable of commanding and
 18542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobeying, of doing and suffering, as a natural man; which no Generall or
 18543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUniversall Church is, till it have a Representant; which it hath not on
 18544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarth: for if it had, there is no doubt but that all Christendome were
 18545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone Common-wealth, whose Soveraign were that Representant, both in
 18546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings Spirituall and Temporall: And the Pope, to make himself this
 18547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentant, wanteth three things that our Saviour hath not given
 18548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, to Command, and to Judge, and to Punish, otherwise than (by
 18549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcommunication) to run from those that will not Learn of him: For
 18550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough the Pope were Christs onely Vicar, yet he cannot exercise his
 18551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgovernment, till our Saviours second coming: And then also it is not the
 18552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPope, but St. Peter himselfe, with the other Apostles, that are to be
 18553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudges of the world.
 18554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe other errour in this his first Argument is, that he sayes, the
 18556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMembers of every Common-wealth, as of a naturall Body, depend one of
 18557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother: It is true, they cohaere together; but they depend onely on the
 18558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, which is the Soul of the Common-wealth; which failing, the
 18559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth is dissolved into a Civill war, no one man so much
 18560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas cohaering to another, for want of a common Dependance on a known
 18561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign; Just as the Members of the naturall Body dissolve into Earth,
 18562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor want of a Soul to hold them together. Therefore there is nothing in
 18563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis similitude, from whence to inferre a dependance of the Laity on the
 18564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tClergy, or of the Temporall Officers on the Spirituall; but of both on
 18565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Civill Soveraign; which ought indeed to direct his Civill commands
 18566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Salvation of Souls; but is not therefore subject to any but God
 18567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimselfe. And thus you see the laboured fallacy of the first Argument,
 18568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto deceive such men as distinguish not between the Subordination of
 18569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActions in the way to the End; and the Subjection of Persons one to
 18570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother in the administration of the Means. For to every End, the Means
 18571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare determined by Nature, or by God himselfe supernaturally: but the
 18572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower to make men use the Means, is in every nation resigned (by the
 18573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw of Nature, which forbiddeth men to violate their Faith given) to the
 18574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Soveraign.
 18575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHis second Argument is this, "Every Common-wealth, (because it is
 18577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupposed to be perfect and sufficient in it self,) may command any
 18578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Common-wealth, not subject to it, and force it to change the
 18579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadministration of the Government, nay depose the Prince, and set another
 18580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his room, if it cannot otherwise defend it selfe against the injuries
 18581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the goes about to doe them: much more may a Spirituall Common-wealth
 18582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommand a Temporall one to change the administration of their
 18583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernment, and may depose Princes, and institute others, when they
 18584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot otherwise defend the Spirituall Good."
 18585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat a Common-wealth, to defend it selfe against injuries, may lawfully
 18587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoe all that he hath here said, is very true; and hath already in that
 18588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich hath gone before been sufficiently demonstrated. And if it were
 18589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso true, that there is now in this world a Spirituall Common-wealth,
 18590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdistinct from a Civill Common-wealth, then might the Prince thereof,
 18591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon injury done him, or upon want of caution that injury be not done
 18592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim in time to come, repaire, and secure himself by Warre; which is in
 18593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsumme, deposing, killing, or subduing, or doing any act of Hostility.
 18594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut by the same reason, it would be no lesse lawfull for a Civill
 18595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, upon the like injuries done, or feared, to make warre
 18596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon the Spirituall Soveraign; which I beleeve is more than Cardinall
 18597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBellarmine would have inferred from his own proposition.
 18598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut Spirituall Common-wealth there is none in this world: for it is the
 18600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame thing with the Kingdome of Christ; which he himselfe saith, is not
 18601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof this world; but shall be in the next world, at the Resurrection, when
 18602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey that have lived justly, and beleeved that he was the Christ, shall
 18603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(though they died Naturall bodies) rise Spirituall bodies; and then it
 18604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, that our Saviour shall judge the world, and conquer his Adversaries,
 18605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand make a Spirituall Common-wealth. In the mean time, seeing there are
 18606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno men on earth, whose bodies are Spirituall; there can be no Spirituall
 18607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth amongst men that are yet in the flesh; unlesse wee call
 18608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPreachers, that have Commission to Teach, and prepare men for
 18609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir reception into the Kingdome of Christ at the Resurrection, a
 18610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealth; which I have proved to bee none.
 18611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe third Argument is this; "It is not lawfull for Christians to
 18613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttolerate an Infidel, or Haereticall King, in case he endeavour to draw
 18614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem to his Haeresie, or Infidelity. But to judge whether a King draw
 18615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this subjects to Haeresie, or not, belongeth to the Pope. Therefore hath
 18616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Pope Right, to determine whether the Prince be to be deposed, or not
 18617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeposed."
 18618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo this I answer, that both these assertions are false. For Christians,
 18620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(or men of what Religion soever,) if they tolerate not their King,
 18621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhatsoever law hee maketh, though it bee concerning Religion, doe
 18622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tviolate their faith, contrary to the Divine Law, both Naturall and
 18623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPositive: Nor is there any Judge of Haeresie amongst Subjects, but
 18624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own Civill Soveraign; for "Haeresie is nothing else, but a private
 18625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion, obstinately maintained, contrary to the opinion which the
 18626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Person (that is to say, the Representant of the Common-wealth)
 18627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath commanded to bee taught." By which it is manifest, that an
 18628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\topinion publiquely appointed to bee taught, cannot be Haeresie; nor the
 18629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Princes that authorize them, Haeretiques. For Haeretiques are
 18630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone but private men, that stubbornly defend some Doctrine, prohibited
 18631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby their lawful Soveraigns.
 18632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut to prove that Christians are not to tolerate Infidell, or
 18634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHaereticall Kings, he alledgeth a place in Deut. 17. where God
 18635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforbiddeth the Jews, when they shall set a King over themselves, to
 18636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchoose a stranger; And from thence inferreth, that it is unlawfull for
 18637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Christian, to choose a King, that is not a Christian. And 'tis true,
 18638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat he that is a Christian, that is, hee that hath already obliged
 18639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself to receive our Saviour when he shall come, for his King, shal
 18640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttempt God too much in choosing for King in this world, one that hee
 18641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknoweth will endeavour, both by terrour, and perswasion to make him
 18642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tviolate his faith. But, it is (saith hee) the same danger, to choose one
 18643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is not a Christian, for King, and not to depose him, when hee
 18644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis chosen. To this I say, the question is not of the danger of not
 18645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeposing; but of the Justice of deposing him. To choose him, may in some
 18646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcases bee unjust; but to depose him, when he is chosen, is in no case
 18647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJust. For it is alwaies violation of faith, and consequently against the
 18648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw of Nature, which is the eternal Law of God. Nor doe wee read, that
 18649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany such Doctrine was accounted Christian in the time of the Apostles;
 18650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor in the time of the Romane Emperours, till the Popes had the Civill
 18651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty of Rome. But to this he hath replyed, that the Christians of
 18652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\told, deposed not Nero, nor Diocletian, nor Julian, nor Valens an Arrian,
 18653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor this cause onely, that they wanted Temporall forces. Perhaps so. But
 18654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdid our Saviour, who for calling for, might have had twelve Legions
 18655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof immortall, invulnerable Angels to assist him, want forces to depose
 18656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCaesar, or at least Pilate, that unjustly, without finding fault in him,
 18657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdelivered him to the Jews to bee crucified? Or if the Apostles wanted
 18658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTemporall forces to depose Nero, was it therefore necessary for them in
 18659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Epistles to the new made Christians, to teach them, (as they did)
 18660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey the Powers constituted over them, (whereof Nero in that time was
 18661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone,) and that they ought to obey them, not for fear of their wrath,
 18662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut for conscience sake? Shall we say they did not onely obey, but also
 18663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tteach what they meant not, for want of strength? It is not therefore
 18664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor want of strength, but for conscience sake, that Christians are to
 18665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttolerate their Heathen Princes, or Princes (for I cannot call any one
 18666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose Doctrine is the Publique Doctrine, an Haeretique) that authorize
 18667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe teaching of an Errour. And whereas for the Temporall Power of the
 18668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPope, he alledgeth further, that St. Paul (1 Cor. 6.) appointed Judges
 18669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder the Heathen Princes of those times, such as were not ordained by
 18670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Princes; it is not true. For St. Paul does but advise them,
 18671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto take some of their Brethren to compound their differences, as
 18672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArbitrators, rather than to goe to law one with another before the
 18673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeathen Judges; which is a wholsome Precept, and full of Charity, fit
 18674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto bee practised also in the Best Christian Common-wealths. And for
 18675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe danger that may arise to Religion, by the Subjects tolerating of an
 18676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeathen, or an Erring Prince, it is a point, of which a Subject is no
 18677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcompetent Judge; or if hee bee, the Popes Temporall Subjects may judge
 18678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso of the Popes Doctrine. For every Christian Prince, as I have
