 18679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tformerly proved, is no lesse Supreme Pastor of his own Subjects, than
 18680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Pope of his.
 18681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fourth Argument, is taken from the Baptisme of Kings; wherein, that
 18683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey may be made Christians they submit their Scepters to Christ; and
 18684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpromise to keep, and defend the Christian Faith. This is true; for
 18685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Kings are no more but Christs Subjects: but they may, for all
 18686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat, bee the Popes Fellowes; for they are Supreme Pastors of their own
 18687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects; and the Pope is no more but King, and Pastor, even in Rome it
 18688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tselfe.
 18689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fifth Argument, is drawn from the words spoken by our Saviour, Feed
 18691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMy Sheep; by which was give all Power necessary for a Pastor; as the
 18692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower to chase away Wolves, such as are Haeretiques; the Power to shut
 18693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tup Rammes, if they be mad, or push at the other Sheep with their Hornes,
 18694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as are Evill (though Christian) Kings; and Power to give the Flock
 18695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconvenient food: From whence hee inferreth, that St. Peter had these
 18696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthree Powers given him by Christ. To which I answer, that the last of
 18697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese Powers, is no more than the Power, or rather Command to Teach.
 18698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the first, which is to chase away Wolves, that is, Haeretiques, the
 18699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace hee quoteth is (Matth. 7.15.) "Beware of false Prophets which
 18700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome to you in Sheeps clothing, but inwardly are ravening Wolves."
 18701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut neither are Haeretiques false Prophets, or at all Prophets: nor
 18702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(admitting Haeretiques for the Wolves there meant,) were the Apostles
 18703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommanded to kill them, or if they were Kings, to depose them; but to
 18704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeware of, fly, and avoid them: nor was it to St. Peter, nor to any of
 18705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Apostles, but to the multitude of the Jews that followed him into
 18706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe mountain, men for the most part not yet converted, that hee gave
 18707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Counsell, to Beware of false Prophets: which therefore if it
 18708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconferre a Power of chasing away Kings, was given, not onely to private
 18709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen; but to men that were not at all Christians. And as to the Power
 18710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Separating, and Shutting up of furious Rammes, (by which hee meaneth
 18711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Kings that refuse to submit themselves to the Roman Pastor,)
 18712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour refused to take upon him that Power in this world himself,
 18713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut advised to let the Corn and Tares grow up together till the day of
 18714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudgment: much lesse did hee give it to St. Peter, or can S. Peter give
 18715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit to the Popes. St. Peter, and all other Pastors, are bidden to esteem
 18716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Christians that disobey the Church, that is, (that disobey the
 18717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Soveraigne) as Heathen men, and as Publicans. Seeing then men
 18718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchallenge to the Pope no authority over Heathen Princes, they ought to
 18719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchallenge none over those that are to bee esteemed as Heathen.
 18720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut from the Power to Teach onely, hee inferreth also a Coercive Power
 18722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Pope, over Kings. The Pastor (saith he) must give his flock
 18723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconvenient food: Therefore the Pope may, and ought to compell Kings to
 18724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoe their duty. Out of which it followeth, that the Pope, as Pastor of
 18725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian men, is King of Kings: which all Christian Kings ought indeed
 18726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither to Confesse, or else they ought to take upon themselves the
 18727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSupreme Pastorall Charge, every one in his own Dominion.
 18728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHis sixth, and last Argument, is from Examples. To which I answer,
 18730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst, that Examples prove nothing; Secondly, that the Examples he
 18731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talledgeth make not so much as a probability of Right. The fact of
 18732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJehoiada, in Killing Athaliah (2 Kings 11.) was either by the Authority
 18733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof King Joash, or it was a horrible Crime in the High Priest, which
 18734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(ever after the election of King Saul) was a mere Subject. The fact of
 18735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Ambrose, in Excommunicating Theodosius the Emperour, (if it were
 18736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrue hee did so,) was a Capitall Crime. And for the Popes, Gregory 1.
 18737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGreg. 2. Zachary, and Leo 3. their Judgments are void, as given in their
 18738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town Cause; and the Acts done by them conformably to this Doctrine, are
 18739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe greatest Crimes (especially that of Zachary) that are incident to
 18740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHumane Nature. And thus much of Power Ecclesiasticall; wherein I had
 18741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen more briefe, forbearing to examine these Arguments of Bellarmine,
 18742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif they had been his, as a Private man, and not as the Champion of the
 18743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPapacy, against all other Christian Princes, and States.
 18744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XLIII. OF WHAT IS NECESSARY FOR A MANS RECEPTION INTO THE
 18748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKINGDOME OF HEAVEN.
 18749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Difficulty Of Obeying God And Man Both At Once
 18754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe most frequent praetext of Sedition, and Civill Warre, in Christian
 18756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths hath a long time proceeded from a difficulty, not yet
 18757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsufficiently resolved, of obeying at once, both God, and Man, then
 18758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen their Commandements are one contrary to the other. It is manifest
 18759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenough, that when a man receiveth two contrary Commands, and knows that
 18760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone of them is Gods, he ought to obey that, and not the other, though
 18761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit be the command even of his lawfull Soveraign (whether a Monarch, or
 18762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Soveraign Assembly,) or the command of his Father. The difficulty
 18763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore consisteth in this, that men when they are commanded in the
 18764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of God, know not in divers Cases, whether the command be from God,
 18765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor whether he that commandeth, doe but abuse Gods name for some private
 18766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tends of his own. For as there ware in the Church of the Jews, many false
 18767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets, that sought reputation with the people, by feigned Dreams, and
 18768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVisions; so there have been in all times in the Church of Christ, false
 18769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTeachers, that seek reputation with the people, by phantasticall and
 18770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfalse Doctrines; and by such reputation (as is the nature of Ambition,)
 18771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto govern them for their private benefit.
 18772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIs None To Them That Distinguish Between What Is, And What Is Not
 18777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNecessary To Salvation
 18779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut this difficulty of obeying both God, and the Civill Soveraign on
 18781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tearth, to those that can distinguish between what is Necessary, and what
 18782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not Necessary for their Reception into the Kingdome of God, is of no
 18783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmoment. For if the command of the Civill Soveraign bee such, as that it
 18784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay be obeyed, without the forfeiture of life Eternall; not to obey it
 18785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis unjust; and the precept of the Apostle takes place; "Servants obey
 18786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyour Masters in all things;" and, "Children obey your Parents in all
 18787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings;" and the precept of our Saviour, "The Scribes and Pharisees sit
 18788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Moses Chaire, All therefore they shall say, that observe, and doe."
 18789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut if the command be such, as cannot be obeyed, without being damned
 18790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Eternall Death, then it were madnesse to obey it, and the Counsell
 18791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof our Saviour takes place, (Mat. 10. 28.) "Fear not those that kill the
 18792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbody, but cannot kill the soule." All men therefore that would avoid,
 18793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth the punishments that are to be in this world inflicted, for
 18794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisobedience to their earthly Soveraign, and those that shall be
 18795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinflicted in the world to come for disobedience to God, have need be
 18796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaught to distinguish well between what is, and what is not Necessary to
 18797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternall Salvation.
 18798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll That Is Necessary To Salvation Is Contained In Faith And Obedience
 18803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll that is NECESSARY to Salvation, is contained in two Vertues, Faith
 18805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Christ, and Obedience to Laws. The latter of these, if it were
 18806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperfect, were enough to us. But because wee are all guilty of
 18807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisobedience to Gods Law, not onely originally in Adam, but also
 18808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactually by our own transgressions, there is required at our hands now,
 18809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot onely Obedience for the rest of our time, but also a Remission of
 18810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsins for the time past; which Remission is the reward of our Faith
 18811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Christ. That nothing else is Necessarily required to Salvation, is
 18812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest from this, that the Kingdome of Heaven, is shut to none but
 18813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Sinners; that is to say, to the disobedient, or transgressors of the
 18814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw; nor to them, in case they Repent, and Beleeve all the Articles of
 18815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Faith, Necessary to Salvation.
 18816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat Obedience Is Necessary;
 18821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Obedience required at our hands by God, that accepteth in all our
 18823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions the Will for the Deed, is a serious Endeavour to Obey him;
 18824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand is called also by all such names as signifie that Endeavour. And
 18825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore Obedience, is sometimes called by the names of Charity, and
 18826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLove, because they imply a Will to Obey; and our Saviour himself maketh
 18827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Love to God, and to one another, a Fulfilling of the whole Law: and
 18828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes by the name of Righteousnesse; for Righteousnesse is but the
 18829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill to give to every one his owne, that is to say, the will to obey
 18830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Laws: and sometimes by the name of Repentance; because to Repent,
 18831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timplyeth a turning away from sinne, which is the same, with the return
 18832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the will to Obedience. Whosoever therefore unfeignedly desireth
 18833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto fulfill the Commandements of God, or repenteth him truely of his
 18834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransgressions, or that loveth God with all his heart, and his neighbor
 18835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas himself, hath all the Obedience Necessary to his Reception into the
 18836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God: For if God should require perfect Innocence, there
 18837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcould no flesh be saved.
 18838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd To What Laws
 18843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut what Commandements are those that God hath given us? Are all
 18845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Laws which were given to the Jews by the hand of Moses, the
 18846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandements of God? If they bee, why are not Christians taught to obey
 18847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem? If they be not, what others are so, besides the Law of Nature? For
 18848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour Christ hath not given us new Laws, but Counsell to observe
 18849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose wee are subject to; that is to say, the Laws of Nature, and the
 18850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaws of our severall Soveraigns: Nor did he make any new Law to the Jews
 18851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his Sermon on the Mount, but onely expounded the Laws of Moses, to
 18852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich they were subject before. The Laws of God therefore are none
 18853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut the Laws of Nature, whereof the principall is, that we should
 18854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot violate our Faith, that is, a commandement to obey our Civill
 18855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns, which wee constituted over us, by mutuall pact one with
 18856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother. And this Law of God, that commandeth Obedience to the Law
 18857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill, commandeth by consequence Obedience to all the Precepts of the
 18858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBible, which (as I have proved in the precedent Chapter) is there onely
 18859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw, where the Civill Soveraign hath made it so; and in other places but
 18860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCounsell; which a man at his own perill, may without injustice refuse to
 18861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobey.
 18862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn The Faith Of A Christian, Who Is The Person Beleeved
 18867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKnowing now what is the Obedience Necessary to Salvation, and to whom
 18869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is due; we are to consider next concerning Faith, whom, and why we
 18870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve; and what are the Articles, or Points necessarily to be beleeved
 18871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby them that shall be saved. And first, for the Person whom we beleeve,
 18872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause it is impossible to beleeve any Person, before we know what he
 18873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaith, it is necessary he be one that wee have heard speak. The Person
 18874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore, whom Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Moses and the Prophets beleeved,
 18875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas God himself, that spake unto them supernaturally: And the Person,
 18876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom the Apostles and Disciples that conversed with Christ beleeved, was
 18877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour himself. But of them, to whom neither God the Father, nor
 18878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour ever spake, it cannot be said, that the Person whom they
 18879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeved, was God. They beleeved the Apostles, and after them the
 18880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors and Doctors of the Church, that recommended to their faith the
 18881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHistory of the Old and New Testament: so that the Faith of Christians
 18882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tever since our Saviours time, hath had for foundation, first, the
 18883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treputation of their Pastors, and afterward, the authority of those that
 18884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmade the Old and New Testament to be received for the Rule of Faith;
 18885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich none could do but Christian Soveraignes; who are therefore the
 18886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSupreme Pastors, and the onely Persons, whom Christians now hear speak
 18887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom God; except such as God speaketh to, in these days supernaturally.
 18888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut because there be many false Prophets "gone out into the world,"
 18889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother men are to examine such Spirits (as St. John advised us, 1
 18890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEpistle, Chap. 4. ver.1.) "whether they be of God, or not." And
 18891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore, seeing the Examination of Doctrines belongeth to the Supreme
 18892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastor, the Person which all they that have no speciall revelation are
 18893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto beleeve, is (in every Common-wealth) the Supreme Pastor, that is to
 18894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, the Civill Soveraigne.
 18895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Causes Of Christian Faith
 18900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe causes why men beleeve any Christian Doctrine, are various; For
 18902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith is the gift of God; and he worketh it in each severall man, by
 18903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch wayes, as it seemeth good unto himself. The most ordinary immediate
 18904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcause of our beleef, concerning any point of Christian Faith, is, that
 18905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twee beleeve the Bible to be the Word of God. But why wee beleeve the
 18906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBible to be the Word of God, is much disputed, as all questions must
 18907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneeds bee, that are not well stated. For they make not the question
 18908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be, "Why we Beleeve it," but "How wee Know it;" as if Beleeving and
 18909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKnowing were all one. And thence while one side ground their Knowledge
 18910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon the Infallibility of the Church, and the other side, on the
 18911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestimony of the Private Spirit, neither side concludeth what it
 18912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretends. For how shall a man know the Infallibility of the Church, but
 18913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby knowing first the Infallibility of the Scripture? Or how shall a man
 18914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow his own Private spirit to be other than a beleef, grounded upon the
 18915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority, and Arguments of his Teachers; or upon a Presumption of his
 18916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town Gifts? Besides, there is nothing in the Scripture, from which can be
 18917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinferred the Infallibility of the Church; much lesse, of any particular
 18918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch; and least of all, the Infallibility of any particular man.
 18919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith Comes By Hearing
 18924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is manifest, therefore, that Christian men doe not know, but onely
 18926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve the Scripture to be the Word of God; and that the means of
 18927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmaking them beleeve which God is pleased to afford men ordinarily, is
 18928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccording to the way of Nature, that is to say, from their Teachers.
 18929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is the Doctrine of St. Paul concerning Christian Faith in generall,
 18930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Rom. 10.17.) "Faith cometh by Hearing," that is, by Hearing our lawfull
 18931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPastors. He saith also (ver. 14,15. of the same Chapter) "How shall
 18932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey beleeve in him of whom they have not heard? and how shall they hear
 18933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout a Preacher? and how shall they Preach, except they be sent?"
 18934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhereby it is evident, that the ordinary cause of beleeving that the
 18935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScriptures are the Word of God, is the same with the cause of the
 18936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeving of all other Articles of our Faith, namely, the Hearing of
 18937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that are by the Law allowed and appointed to Teach us, as our
 18938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tParents in their Houses, and our Pastors in the Churches: Which also
 18939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis made more manifest by experience. For what other cause can there bee
 18940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassigned, why in Christian Common-wealths all men either beleeve, or
 18941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat least professe the Scripture to bee the Word of God, and in other
 18942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths scarce any; but that in Christian Common-wealths they
 18943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare taught it from their infancy; and in other places they are taught
 18944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\totherwise?
 18945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut if Teaching be the cause of Faith, why doe not all beleeve? It is
 18947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcertain therefore that Faith is the gift of God, and hee giveth it to
 18948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom he will. Neverthelesse, because of them to whom he giveth it, he
 18949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiveth it by the means of Teachers, the immediate cause of Faith is
 18950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHearing. In a School where many are taught, and some profit, others
 18951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprofit not, the cause of learning in them that profit, is the Master;
 18952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet it cannot be thence inferred, that learning is not the gift of God.
 18953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll good things proceed from God; yet cannot all that have them, say
 18954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are Inspired; for that implies a gift supernaturall, and the
 18955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timmediate hand of God; which he that pretends to, pretends to be a
 18956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphet, and is subject to the examination of the Church.
 18957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut whether men Know, or Beleeve, or Grant the Scriptures to be the Word
 18959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God; if out of such places of them, as are without obscurity, I
 18960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall shew what Articles of Faith are necessary, and onely necessary for
 18961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation, those men must needs Know, Beleeve, or Grant the same.
 18962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Onely Necessary Article Of Christian Faith, The (Unum Necessarium)
 18964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOnely Article of Faith, which the Scripture maketh simply Necessary to
 18965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation, is this, that JESUS IS THE CHRIST. By the name of Christ, is
 18966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood the King, which God had before promised by the Prophets of
 18967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Old Testament, to send into the world, to reign (over the Jews,
 18968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand over such of other nations as should beleeve in him) under himself
 18969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teternally; and to give them that eternall life, which was lost by the
 18970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsin of Adam. Which when I have proved out of Scripture, I will further
 18971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshew when, and in what sense some other Articles may bee also called
 18972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNecessary.
 18973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProved From The Scope Of The Evangelists
 18978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 18979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor Proof that the Beleef of this Article, Jesus Is The Christ, is all
 18980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Faith required to Salvation, my first Argument shall bee from the
 18981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScope of the Evangelists; which was by the description of the life of
 18982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour, to establish that one Article, Jesus Is The Christ. The
 18983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsumme of St. Matthews Gospell is this, That Jesus was of the stock of
 18984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDavid; Born of a Virgin; which are the Marks of the true Christ: That
 18985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Magi came to worship him as King of the Jews: That Herod for the
 18986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame cause sought to kill him: That John Baptist proclaimed him: That
 18987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the preached by himselfe, and his Apostles that he was that King; That
 18988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the taught the Law, not as a Scribe, but as a man of Authority: That he
 18989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcured diseases by his Word onely, and did many other Miracles, which
 18990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere foretold the Christ should doe: That he was saluted King when he
 18991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tentered into Jerusalem: That he fore-warned them to beware of all others
 18992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat should pretend to be Christ: That he was taken, accused, and put
 18993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto death, for saying, hee was King: That the cause of his condemnation
 18994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten on the Crosse, was JESUS OF NAZARETH, THE KING OF THE JEWES.
 18995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll which tend to no other end than this, that men should beleeve,
 18996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Jesus Is The Christ. Such therefore was the Scope of St. Matthews
 18997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGospel. But the Scope of all the Evangelists (as may appear by reading
 18998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem) was the same. Therefore the Scope of the whole Gospell, was the
 18999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\testablishing of that onely Article. And St. John expressely makes it his
 19000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconclusion, John 20. 31. "These things are written, that you may know
 19001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Jesus is the Christ, the Son of the living God."
 19002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom The Sermons Of The Apostles:
 19007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMy second Argument is taken from the Subject of the Sermons of the
 19009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles, both whilest our Saviour lived on earth, and after his
 19010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAscension. The Apostles in our Saviours time were sent, Luke 9.2. to
 19011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPreach the Kingdome of God: For neither there, nor Mat. 10.7. giveth he
 19012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany Commission to them, other than this, "As ye go, Preach, saying, the
 19013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of Heaven is at hand;" that is, that Jesus is the Messiah, the
 19014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, the King which was to come. That their Preaching also after his
 19015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tascension was the same, is manifest out of Acts 17.6. "They drew (saith
 19016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Luke) Jason and certain Brethren unto the Rulers of the City,
 19017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcrying, These that have turned the world upside down are come hither
 19018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso, whom Jason hath received. And these all do contrary to the Decrees
 19019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Caesar, saying, that there is another King, one Jesus:" And out of
 19020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe 2.&3. verses of the same Chapter, where it is said, that St. Paul
 19021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"as his manner was, went in unto them; and three Sabbath dayes reasoned
 19022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith them out of the Scriptures; opening and alledging, that Christ must
 19023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneeds have suffered, and risen againe from the dead, and that this Jesus
 19024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(whom he preached) is Christ."
 19025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom The Easinesse Of The Doctrine:
 19030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe third Argument is, from those places of Scripture, by which all the
 19032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaith required to Salvation is declared to be Easie. For if an inward
 19033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassent of the mind to all the Doctrines concerning Christian Faith now
 19034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaught, (whereof the greatest part are disputed,) were necessary to
 19035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation, there would be nothing in the world so hard, as to be a
 19036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian. The Thief upon the Crosse though repenting, could not have
 19037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen saved for saying, "Lord remember me when thou commest into thy
 19038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome;" by which he testified no beleefe of any other Article, but
 19039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis, That Jesus Was The King. Nor could it bee said (as it is Mat.
 19040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t11. 30.) that "Christs yoke is Easy, and his burthen Light:" Nor that
 19041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Little Children beleeve in him," as it is Matth. 18.6. Nor could St.
 19042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPaul have said (1 Cor. 1. 21.) "It pleased God by the Foolishnesse of
 19043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreaching, to save them that beleeve:" Nor could St. Paul himself have
 19044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen saved, much lesse have been so great a Doctor of the Church
 19045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso suddenly, that never perhaps thought of Transsubstantiation, nor
 19046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPurgatory, nor many other Articles now obtruded.
 19047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom Formall And Cleer Texts
 19052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fourth Argument is taken from places expresse, and such as receive
 19054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno controversie of Interpretation; as first, John 5. 39. "Search the
 19055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScriptures, for in them yee thinke yee have eternall life; and they are
 19056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey that testifie of mee." Our Saviour here speaketh of the Scriptures
 19057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely of the Old Testament; for the Jews at that time could not search
 19058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Scriptures of the New Testament, which were not written. But the Old
 19059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestament hath nothing of Christ, but the Markes by which men might
 19060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknow him when hee came; as that he should descend from David, be born at
 19061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBethlehem, and of a Virgin; doe great Miracles, and the like. Therefore
 19062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto beleeve that this Jesus was He, was sufficient to eternall life: but
 19063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmore than sufficient is not Necessary; and consequently no other Article
 19064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis required. Again, (John 11. 26.) "Whosoever liveth and beleeveth in
 19065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmee, shall not die eternally," Therefore to beleeve in Christ, is faith
 19066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsufficient to eternall life; and consequently no more faith than that
 19067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Necessary, But to beleeve in Jesus, and to beleeve that Jesus is the
 19068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, is all one, as appeareth in the verses immediately following.
 19069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor when our Saviour (verse 26.) had said to Martha, "Beleevest thou
 19070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis?" she answereth (verse 27.) "Yea Lord, I beleeve that thou art the
 19071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, the Son of God, which should come into the world;" Therefore
 19072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Article alone is faith sufficient to life eternall; and more than
 19073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsufficient is not Necessary. Thirdly, John 20. 31. "These things are
 19074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten that yee might beleeve, that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of
 19075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, and that beleeving yee might have life through his name." There, to
 19076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve that Jesus Is The Christ, is faith sufficient to the obtaining
 19077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof life; and therefore no other Article is Necessary. Fourthly, 1 John
 19078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t4. 2. "Every Spirit that confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the
 19079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tflesh, is of God." And 1 Joh. 5. 1. "whosoever beleeveth that Jesus is
 19080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Christ, is born of God." And verse 5. "Who is hee that overcommeth
 19081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe world, but he that beleeveth that Jesus is the Son of God?" Fiftly,
 19082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAct. 8. ver. 36, 37. "See (saith the Eunuch) here is water, what doth
 19083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thinder me to be baptized? And Philip said, If thou beleevest with all
 19084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthy heart thou mayst. And hee answered and said, I beleeve that Jesus
 19085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist is the Son of God." Therefore this Article beleeved, Jesus Is The
 19086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, is sufficient to Baptisme, that is to say, to our Reception into
 19087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Kingdome of God, and by consequence, onely Necessary. And generally
 19088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin all places where our Saviour saith to any man, "Thy faith hath saved
 19089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthee," the cause he saith it, is some Confession, which directly, or by
 19090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequence, implyeth a beleef, that Jesus Is The Christ.
 19091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom That It Is The Foundation Of All Other Articles
 19096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe last Argument is from the places, where this Article is made the
 19098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFoundation of Faith: For he that holdeth the Foundation shall bee saved.
 19099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhich places are first, Mat. 24.23. "If any man shall say unto you, Loe,
 19100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\there is Christ, or there, beleeve it not, for there shall arise false
 19101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrists, and false Prophets, and shall shew great signes and wonders,
 19102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t&c." Here wee see, this Article Jesus Is The Christ, must bee held,
 19103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough hee that shall teach the contrary should doe great miracles. The
 19104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsecond place is Gal. 1. 8. "Though we, or an Angell from Heaven preach
 19105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany other Gospell unto you, than that wee have preached unto you, let
 19106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim bee accursed." But the Gospell which Paul, and the other Apostles,
 19107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreached, was onely this Article, that Jesus Is The Christ; Therefore
 19108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the Beleef of this Article, we are to reject the Authority of
 19109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Angell from heaven; much more of any mortall man, if he teach the
 19110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary. This is therefore the Fundamentall Article of Christian Faith.
 19111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA third place is, 1 Joh. 4.1. "Beloved, beleeve not every spirit. Hereby
 19112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyee shall know the Spirit of God; every spirit that confesseth that
 19113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJesus Christ is come in the flesh, is of God." By which it is evident,
 19114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat this Article, is the measure, and rule, by which to estimate,
 19115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand examine all other Articles; and is therefore onely Fundamentall.
 19116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA fourth is, Matt. 16.18. where after St. Peter had professed this
 19117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArticle, saying to our Saviour, "Thou art Christ the Son of the living
 19118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod," Our Saviour answered, "Thou art Peter, and upon this Rock I will
 19119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbuild my Church:" from whence I inferre, that this Article is that,
 19120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton which all other Doctrines of the Church are built, as on their
 19121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFoundation. A fift is (1 Cor. 3. ver. 11, 12, &c.) "Other Foundation can
 19122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno man lay, than that which is laid, Jesus is the Christ. Now if any man
 19123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbuild upon this Foundation, Gold, Silver, pretious Stones, Wood, Hay,
 19124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tStubble; Every mans work shall be made manifest; For the Day shall
 19125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeclare it, because it shall be revealed by fire, and the fire shall try
 19126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery mans work, of what sort it is. If any mans work abide, which he
 19127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath built thereupon, he shall receive a reward: If any mans work shall
 19128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee burnt, he shall suffer losse; but he himself shall be saved, yet so
 19129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas by fire." Which words, being partly plain and easie to understand,
 19130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand partly allegoricall and difficult; out of that which is plain, may
 19131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe inferred, that Pastors that teach this Foundation, that Jesus Is The
 19132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, though they draw from it false consequences, (which all men are
 19133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes subject to,) they may neverthelesse bee saved; much more that
 19134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey may bee saved, who being no Pastors, but Hearers, beleeve that
 19135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is by their lawfull Pastors taught them. Therefore the beleef of
 19136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Article is sufficient; and by consequence there is no other Article
 19137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Faith Necessarily required to Salvation.
 19138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNow for the part which is Allegoricall, as "That the fire shall try
 19140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery mans work," and that "They shall be saved, but so as by fire,"
 19141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor "through fire," (for the originall is dia puros,) it maketh nothing
 19142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst this conclusion which I have drawn from the other words, that
 19143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare plain. Neverthelesse, because upon this place there hath been an
 19144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\targument taken, to prove the fire of Purgatory, I will also here offer
 19145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyou my conjecture concerning the meaning of this triall of Doctrines,
 19146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand saving of men as by Fire. The Apostle here seemeth to allude to
 19147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe words of the Prophet Zachary, Ch. 13. 8,9. who speaking of the
 19148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRestauration of the Kingdome of God, saith thus, "Two parts therein
 19149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be cut off, and die, but the third shall be left therein; and
 19150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI will bring the third part through the Fire, and will refine them as
 19151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSilver is refined, and will try them as Gold is tryed; they shall call
 19152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton the name of the Lord, and I will hear them." The day of Judgment, is
 19153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe day of the Restauration of the Kingdome of God; and at that day
 19154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is, that St. Peter tells us (2 Pet. 3. v.7, 10, 12.) shall be the
 19155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConflagration of the world, wherein the wicked shall perish; but the
 19156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tremnant which God will save, shall passe through that Fire, unhurt,
 19157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand be therein (as Silver and Gold are refined by the fire from their
 19158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdrosse) tryed, and refined from their Idolatry, and be made to call upon
 19159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe name of the true God. Alluding whereto St. Paul here saith, that The
 19160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDay (that is, the Day of Judgment, the Great Day of our Saviours comming
 19161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto restore the Kingdome of God in Israel) shall try every mans doctrine,
 19162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Judging, which are Gold, Silver, Pretious Stones, Wood, Hay, Stubble;
 19163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd then they that have built false Consequences on the true Foundation,
 19164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall see their Doctrines condemned; neverthelesse they themselves
 19165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be saved, and passe unhurt through this universall Fire, and live
 19166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teternally, to call upon the name of the true and onely God. In which
 19167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense there is nothing that accordeth not with the rest of Holy
 19168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture, or any glimpse of the fire of Purgatory.
 19169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn What Sense Other Articles May Be Called Necessary
 19174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut a man may here aske, whether it bee not as necessary to Salvation,
 19176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto beleeve, that God is Omnipotent; Creator of the world; that Jesus
 19177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist is risen; and that all men else shall rise again from the dead
 19178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat the last day; as to beleeve, that Jesus Is The Christ. To which I
 19179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanswer, they are; and so are many more Articles: but they are such, as
 19180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare contained in this one, and may be deduced from it, with more, or
 19181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlesse difficulty. For who is there that does not see, that they
 19182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho beleeve Jesus to be the Son of the God of Israel, and that the
 19183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsraelites had for God the Omnipotent Creator of all things, doe therein
 19184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso beleeve, that God is the Omnipotent Creator of all things? Or how
 19185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan a man beleeve, that Jesus is the King that shall reign eternally,
 19186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunlesse hee beleeve him also risen again from the dead? For a dead man
 19187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot exercise the Office of a King. In summe, he that holdeth this
 19188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFoundation, Jesus Is The Christ, holdeth Expressely all that hee
 19189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseeth rightly deduced from it, and Implicitely all that is consequent
 19190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereunto, though he have not skill enough to discern the consequence.
 19191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore it holdeth still good, that the beleef of this one Article
 19192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis sufficient faith to obtaine remission of sinnes to the Penitent, and
 19193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequently to bring them into the Kingdome of Heaven.
 19194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat Faith, And Obedience Are Both Of Them Necessary To Salvation
 19199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNow that I have shewn, that all the Obedience required to Salvation,
 19201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsisteth in the will to obey the Law of God, that is to say, in
 19202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepentance; and all the Faith required to the same, is comprehended in
 19203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe beleef of this Article, Jesus Is The Christ; I will further alledge
 19204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose places of the Gospell, that prove, that all that is Necessary to
 19205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation is contained in both these joined together. The men to whom
 19206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Peter preached on the day of Pentecost, next after the Ascension
 19207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof our Saviour, asked him, and the rest of the Apostles, saying, (Act.
 19208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2.37.) "Men and Brethren what shall we doe?" to whom St. Peter answered
 19209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(in the next verse) "Repent, and be Baptized every one of you, for the
 19210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tremission of sins, and ye shall receive the gift of the Holy Ghost."
 19211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore Repentance, and Baptisme, that is, beleeving that Jesus Is The
 19212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, is all that is Necessary to Salvation. Again, our Saviour being
 19213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tasked by a certain Ruler, (Luke 18.18.) "What shall I doe to inherit
 19214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teternall life?" Answered (verse 20) "Thou knowest the Commandements,
 19215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoe not commit Adultery, Doe not Kill, Doe not Steal, Doe not bear false
 19216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twitnesse, Honor thy Father, and thy Mother;" which when he said he had
 19217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserved, our Saviour added, "Sell all thou hast, give it to the Poor,
 19218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand come and follow me:" which was as much as to say, Relye on me that
 19219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tam the King: Therefore to fulfill the Law, and to beleeve that Jesus
 19220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the King, is all that is required to bring a man to eternall life.
 19221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThirdly, St. Paul saith (Rom. 1.17.) "The Just shall live by Faith;" not
 19222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one, but the Just; therefore Faith and Justice (that is, the Will
 19223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo Be Just, or Repentance) are all that is Necessary to life eternall.
 19224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd (Mark 1.15.) our Saviour preached, saying, "The time is fulfilled,
 19225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Kingdom of God is at hand, Repent and Beleeve the Evangile,"
 19226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, the Good news that the Christ was come. Therefore to Repent,
 19227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to Beleeve that Jesus is the Christ, is all that is required to
 19228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation.
 19229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat Each Of Them Contributes Thereunto
 19234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing then it is Necessary that Faith, and Obedience (implyed in the
 19236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tword Repentance) do both concurre to our Salvation; the question
 19237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby which of the two we are Justified, is impertinently disputed.
 19238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse, it will not be impertinent, to make manifest in what
 19239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner each of them contributes thereunto; and in what sense it is said,
 19240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat we are to be Justified by the one, and by the other. And first,
 19241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif by Righteousnesse be understood the Justice of the Works themselves,
 19242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is no man that can be saved; for there is none that hath not
 19243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransgressed the Law of God. And therefore when wee are said to be
 19244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustified by Works, it is to be understood of the Will, which God doth
 19245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talwaies accept for the Work it selfe, as well in good, as in evill men.
 19246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd in this sense onely it is, that a man is called Just, or Unjust; and
 19247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat his Justice Justifies him, that is, gives him the title, in Gods
 19248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacceptation, of Just; and renders him capable of Living By His Faith,
 19249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich before he was not. So that Justice Justifies in that that sense,
 19250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin which to Justifie, is the same that to Denominate A Man Just; and not
 19251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the signification of discharging the Law; whereby the punishment of
 19252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this sins should be unjust.
 19253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut a man is then also said to be Justified, when his Plea, though in
 19255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit selfe unsufficient, is accepted; as when we Plead our Will, our
 19256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEndeavour to fulfill the Law, and Repent us of our failings, and God
 19257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccepteth it for the Performance it selfe: And because God accepteth not
 19258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Will for the Deed, but onely in the Faithfull; it is therefore Faith
 19259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat makes good our Plea; and in this sense it is, that Faith onely
 19260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustifies: So that Faith and Obedience are both Necessary to Salvation;
 19261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet in severall senses each of them is said to Justifie.
 19262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tObedience To God And To The Civill Soveraign Not Inconsistent
 19267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhether Christian, Having thus shewn what is Necessary to Salvation; it
 19269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not hard to reconcile our Obedience to the Civill Soveraign; who is
 19270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither Christian, or Infidel. If he bee a Christian, he alloweth the
 19271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleefe of this Article, that Jesus Is The Christ; and of all the
 19272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArticles that are contained in, or are evident consequence deduced from
 19273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit: which is all the Faith Necessary to Salvation. And because he is a
 19274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, he requireth Obedience to all his owne, that is, to all the
 19275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Laws; in which also are contained all the Laws of Nature, that
 19276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, all the Laws of God: for besides the Laws of Nature, and the Laws of
 19277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Church, which are part of the Civill Law, (for the Church that
 19278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan make Laws is the Common-wealth,) there bee no other Laws Divine.
 19279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhosoever therefore obeyeth his Christian Soveraign, is not thereby
 19280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thindred, neither from beleeving, nor from obeying God. But suppose that
 19281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Christian King should from this Foundation, Jesus Is The Christ, draw
 19282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome false consequences, that is to say, make some superstructions of
 19283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHay, or Stubble, and command the teaching of the same; yet seeing St.
 19284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPaul says, he shal be saved; much more shall he be saved, that teacheth
 19285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem by his command; and much more yet, he that teaches not, but onely
 19286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeves his lawfull Teacher. And in case a Subject be forbidden by
 19287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Civill Soveraign to professe some of those his opinions, upon
 19288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat grounds can he disobey? Christian Kings may erre in deducing a
 19289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsequence, but who shall Judge? Shall a private man Judge, when the
 19290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestion is of his own obedience? or shall any man Judg but he that is
 19291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappointed thereto by the Church, that is, by the Civill Soveraign that
 19292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepresenteth it? or if the Pope, or an Apostle Judge, may he not erre
 19293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin deducing of a consequence? did not one of the two, St. Peter, or St.
 19294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPaul erre in a superstructure, when St. Paul withstood St. Peter to his
 19295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tface? There can therefore be no contradiction between the Laws of God,
 19296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Laws of a Christian Common-wealth.
 19297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOr Infidel
 19302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd when the Civill Soveraign is an Infidel, every one of his own
 19304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects that resisteth him, sinneth against the Laws of God (for such
 19305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas are the Laws of Nature,) and rejecteth the counsell of the Apostles,
 19306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat admonisheth all Christians to obey their Princes, and all Children
 19307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Servants to obey they Parents, and Masters, in all things. And for
 19308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Faith, it is internall, and invisible; They have the licence that
 19309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNaaman had, and need not put themselves into danger for it. But if they
 19310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo, they ought to expect their reward in Heaven, and not complain of
 19311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Lawfull Soveraign; much lesse make warre upon him. For he that
 19312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not glad of any just occasion of Martyrdome, has not the faith be
 19313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprofesseth, but pretends it onely, to set some colour upon his own
 19314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontumacy. But what Infidel King is so unreasonable, as knowing he has
 19315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Subject, that waiteth for the second comming of Christ, after the
 19316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent world shall be burnt, and intendeth then to obey him (which is
 19317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe intent of beleeving that Jesus is the Christ,) and in the mean time
 19318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthinketh himself bound to obey the Laws of that Infidel King, (which
 19319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall Christians are obliged in conscience to doe,) to put to death, or to
 19320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpersecute such a Subject?
 19321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd thus much shall suffice, concerning the Kingdome of God, and Policy
 19323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticall. Wherein I pretend not to advance any Position of
 19324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmy own, but onely to shew what are the Consequences that seem to me
 19325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeducible from the Principles of Christian Politiques, (which are the
 19326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tholy Scriptures,) in confirmation of the Power of Civill Soveraigns, and
 19327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Duty of their Subjects. And in the allegation of Scripture, I have
 19328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tendeavoured to avoid such Texts as are of obscure, or controverted
 19329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInterpretation; and to alledge none, but is such sense as is most plain,
 19330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand agreeable to the harmony and scope of the whole Bible; which was
 19331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twritten for the re-establishment of the Kingdome of God in Christ. For
 19332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is not the bare Words, but the Scope of the writer that giveth the
 19333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrue light, by which any writing is to bee interpreted; and they that
 19334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinsist upon single Texts, without considering the main Designe, can
 19335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tderive no thing from them cleerly; but rather by casting atomes of
 19336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture, as dust before mens eyes, make every thing more obscure than
 19337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is; an ordinary artifice of those that seek not the truth, but their
 19338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town advantage.
 19339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XLIV. OF SPIRITUALL DARKNESSE FROM MISINTERPRETATION OF
 19343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSCRIPTURE
 19344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Kingdome Of Darknesse What
 19349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBesides these Soveraign Powers, Divine, and Humane, of which I have
 19351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thitherto discoursed, there is mention in Scripture of another Power,
 19352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnamely, (Eph. 6. 12.), that of "the Rulers of the Darknesse of this
 19353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld," (Mat. 12. 26.), "the Kingdome of Satan," and, (Mat. 9. 34.), "the
 19354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrincipality of Beelzebub over Daemons," that is to say, over Phantasmes
 19355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat appear in the Air: For which cause Satan is also called (Eph. 2.
 19356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t2.) "the Prince of the Power of the Air;" and (because he ruleth in the
 19357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdarknesse of this world) (Joh. 16. 11.) "The Prince of this world;" And
 19358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin consequence hereunto, they who are under his Dominion, in opposition
 19359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the faithfull (who are the Children Of The Light) are called the
 19360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChildren Of Darknesse. For seeing Beelzebub is Prince of Phantasmes,
 19361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInhabitants of his Dominion of Air and Darknesse, the Children of
 19362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDarknesse, and these Daemons, Phantasmes, or Spirits of Illusion,
 19363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifie allegorically the same thing. This considered, the Kingdome
 19364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Darknesse, as it is set forth in these, and other places of the
 19365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture, is nothing else but a "Confederacy of Deceivers, that to
 19366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobtain dominion over men in this present world, endeavour by dark, and
 19367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\terroneous Doctrines, to extinguish in them the Light, both of Nature,
 19368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand of the Gospell; and so to dis-prepare them for the Kingdome of God
 19369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto come."
 19370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Church Not Yet Fully Freed Of Darknesse
 19375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs men that are utterly deprived from their Nativity, of the light
 19377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the bodily Eye, have no Idea at all, of any such light; and no man
 19378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconceives in his imagination any greater light, than he hath at some
 19379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, or other perceived by his outward Senses: so also is it of the
 19380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlight of the Gospel, and of the light of the Understanding, that no man
 19381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan conceive there is any greater degree of it, than that which he hath
 19382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready attained unto. And from hence it comes to passe, that men
 19383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave no other means to acknowledge their owne Darknesse, but onely by
 19384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasoning from the un-forseen mischances, that befall them in their
 19385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tways; The Darkest part of the Kingdome of Satan, is that which is
 19386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout the Church of God; that is to say, amongst them that beleeve not
 19387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Jesus Christ. But we cannot say, that therefore the Church enjoyeth
 19388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as the land of Goshen) all the light, which to the performance of
 19389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe work enjoined us by God, is necessary. Whence comes it, that in
 19390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristendome there has been, almost from the time of the Apostles,
 19391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch justling of one another out of their places, both by forraign,
 19392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Civill war? such stumbling at every little asperity of their own
 19393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfortune, and every little eminence of that of other men? and such
 19394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiversity of ways in running to the same mark, Felicity, if it be not
 19395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNight amongst us, or at least a Mist? wee are therefore yet in the Dark.
 19396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFour Causes Of Spirituall Darknesse
 19401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Enemy has been here in the Night of our naturall Ignorance, and sown
 19403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe tares of Spirituall Errors; and that, First, by abusing, and
 19404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tputting out the light of the Scriptures: For we erre, not knowing the
 19405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScriptures. Secondly, by introducing the Daemonology of the Heathen
 19406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPoets, that is to say, their fabulous Doctrine concerning Daemons, which
 19407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare but Idols, or Phantasms of the braine, without any reall nature of
 19408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own, distinct from humane fancy; such as are dead mens Ghosts, and
 19409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFairies, and other matter of old Wives tales. Thirdly, by mixing with
 19410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Scripture divers reliques of the Religion, and much of the vain and
 19411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\terroneous Philosophy of the Greeks, especially of Aristotle. Fourthly,
 19412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby mingling with both these, false, or uncertain Traditions, and
 19413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfained, or uncertain History. And so we come to erre, by "giving heed
 19414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto seducing Spirits," and the Daemonology of such "as speak lies in
 19415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHypocrisie," (or as it is in the Originall, 1 Tim. 4.1,2. "of those that
 19416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplay the part of lyars") "with a seared conscience," that is, contrary
 19417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto their own knowledge. Concerning the first of these, which is the
 19418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeducing of men by abuse of Scripture, I intend to speak briefly in this
 19419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChapter.
 19420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tErrors From Misinterpreting The Scriptures, Concerning The Kingdome
 19425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf God
 19427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe greatest, and main abuse of Scripture, and to which almost all the
 19429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trest are either consequent, or subservient, is the wresting of it, to
 19430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprove that the Kingdome of God, mentioned so often in the Scripture, is
 19431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe present Church, or multitude of Christian men now living, or that
 19432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing dead, are to rise again at the last day: whereas the Kingdome of
 19433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod was first instituted by the Ministery of Moses, over the Jews onely;
 19434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho were therefore called his Peculiar People; and ceased afterward, in
 19435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe election of Saul, when they refused to be governed by God any more,
 19436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand demanded a King after the manner of the nations; which God himself
 19437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsented unto, as I have more at large proved before, in the 35.
 19438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChapter. After that time, there was no other Kingdome of God in the
 19439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld, by any Pact, or otherwise, than he ever was, is, and shall be
 19440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing, of all men, and of all creatures, as governing according to his
 19441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWill, by his infinite Power. Neverthelesse, he promised by his Prophets
 19442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto restore this his Government to them again, when the time he hath in
 19443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this secret counsell appointed for it shall bee fully come, and when they
 19444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall turn unto him by repentance, and amendment of life; and not
 19445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely so, but he invited also the Gentiles to come in, and enjoy the
 19446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thappinesse of his Reign, on the same conditions of conversion and
 19447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepentance; and hee promised also to send his Son into the world, to
 19448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpiate the sins of them all by his death, and to prepare them by his
 19449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine, to receive him at his second coming: Which second coming not
 19450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet being, the Kingdome of God is not yet come, and wee are not now
 19451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder any other Kings by Pact, but our Civill Soveraigns; saving onely,
 19452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Christian men are already in the Kingdome of Grace, in as much as
 19453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey have already the Promise of being received at his comming againe.
 19454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs That The Kingdome Of God Is The Present Church
 19459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsequent to this Errour, that the present Church is Christs Kingdome,
 19461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere ought to be some one Man, or Assembly, by whose mouth our Saviour
 19462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(now in heaven) speaketh, giveth law, and which representeth his person
 19463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto all Christians, or divers Men, or divers Assemblies that doe the same
 19464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto divers parts of Christendome. This power Regal under Christ, being
 19465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchallenged, universally by that Pope, and in particular Common-wealths
 19466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Assemblies of the Pastors of the place, (when the Scripture gives it
 19467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto none but to Civill Soveraigns,) comes to be so passionately disputed,
 19468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat it putteth out the Light of Nature, and causeth so great a
 19469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDarknesse in mens understanding, that they see not who it is to whom
 19470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey have engaged their obedience.
 19471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd That The Pope Is His Vicar Generall
 19476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsequent to this claim of the Pope to Vicar Generall of Christ in the
 19478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent Church, (supposed to be that Kingdom of his, to which we are
 19479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taddressed in the Gospel,) is the Doctrine, that it is necessary for a
 19480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian King, to receive his Crown by a Bishop; as if it were from
 19481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Ceremony, that he derives the clause of Dei Gratia in his title;
 19482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand that then onely he is made King by the favour of God, when he is
 19483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcrowned by the authority of Gods universall Viceregent on earth; and
 19484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat every Bishop whosoever be his Soveraign, taketh at his Consecration
 19485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan oath of absolute Obedience to the Pope, Consequent to the same, is
 19486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Doctrine of the fourth Councell of Lateran, held under Pope Innocent
 19487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe third, (Chap. 3. De Haereticis.) "That if a King at the Popes
 19488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadmonition, doe not purge his Kingdome of Haeresies, and being
 19489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texcommunicate for the same, doe not give satisfaction within a year,
 19490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Subjects are absolved of the bond of their obedience." Where, by
 19491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHaeresies are understood all opinions which the Church of Rome hath
 19492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforbidden to be maintained. And by this means, as often as there is
 19493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany repugnancy between the Politicall designes of the Pope, and other
 19494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian Princes, as there is very often, there ariseth such a Mist
 19495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst their Subjects, that they know not a stranger that thrusteth
 19496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thimself into the throne of their lawfull Prince, from him whom they
 19497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad themselves placed there; and in this Darknesse of mind, are made to
 19498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfight one against another, without discerning their enemies from their
 19499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfriends, under the conduct of another mans ambition.
 19500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd That The Pastors Are The Clergy
 19505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom the same opinion, that the present Church is the Kingdome of God,
 19507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit proceeds that Pastours, Deacons, and all other Ministers of the
 19508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, take the name to themselves of the Clergy, giving to other
 19509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristians the name of Laity, that is, simply People. For Clergy
 19510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifies those, whose maintenance is that Revenue, which God having
 19511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treserved to himselfe during his Reigne over the Israelites, assigned
 19512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the tribe of Levi (who were to be his publique Ministers, and had no
 19513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tportion of land set them out to live on, as their brethren) to be their
 19514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinheritance. The Pope therefore, (pretending the present Church to be,
 19515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas the Realme of Israel, the Kingdome of God) challenging to himselfe
 19516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand his subordinate Ministers, the like revenue, as the Inheritance of
 19517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, the name of Clergy was sutable to that claime. And thence it is,
 19518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Tithes, or other tributes paid to the Levites, as Gods Right,
 19519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst the Israelites, have a long time been demanded, and taken of
 19520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristians, by Ecclesiastiques, Jure Divino, that is, in Gods Right. By
 19521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich meanes, the people every where were obliged to a double tribute;
 19522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone to the State, another to the Clergy; whereof, that to the Clergy,
 19523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing the tenth of their revenue, is double to that which a King of
 19524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAthens (and esteemed a Tyrant) exacted of his subjects for the defraying
 19525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof all publique charges: For he demanded no more but the twentieth part;
 19526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand yet abundantly maintained therewith the Commonwealth. And in the
 19527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of the Jewes, during the Sacerdotall Reigne of God, the Tithes
 19528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Offerings were the whole Publique Revenue.
 19529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom the same mistaking of the present Church for the Kingdom of God,
 19531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcame in the distinction betweene the Civill and the Canon Laws: The
 19532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcivil Law being the acts of Soveraigns in their own Dominions, and
 19533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Canon Law being the Acts of the Pope in the same Dominions. Which
 19534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCanons, though they were but Canons, that is, Rules Propounded, and but
 19535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvoluntarily received by Christian Princes, till the translation of
 19536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Empire to Charlemain; yet afterwards, as the power of the Pope
 19537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tencreased, became Rules Commanded, and the Emperours themselves (to
