 19538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tavoyd greater mischiefes, which the people blinded might be led into)
 19539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere forced to let them passe for Laws.
 19540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom hence it is, that in all Dominions, where the Popes Ecclesiasticall
 19542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower is entirely received, Jewes, Turkes, and Gentiles, are in the
 19543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRoman Church tolerated in their Religion, as farre forth, as in the
 19544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texercise and profession thereof they offend not against the civill
 19545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpower: whereas in a Christian, though a stranger, not to be of the Roman
 19546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion, is Capitall; because the Pope pretendeth that all Christians
 19547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare his Subjects. For otherwise it were as much against the law of
 19548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNations, to persecute a Christian stranger, for professing the Religion
 19549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his owne country, as an Infidell; or rather more, in as much as they
 19550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat are not against Christ, are with him.
 19551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom the same it is, that in every Christian State there are certaine
 19553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, that are exempt, by Ecclesiasticall liberty, from the tributes, and
 19554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the tribunals of the Civil State; for so are the secular Clergy,
 19555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbesides Monks and Friars, which in many places, bear so great a
 19556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproportion to the common people, as if need were, there might be raised
 19557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tout of them alone, an Army, sufficient for any warre the Church militant
 19558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshould imploy them in, against their owne, or other Princes.

 19562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tError From Mistaking Consecration For Conjuration
 19564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA second generall abuse of Scripture, is the turning of Consecration
 19566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto Conjuration, or Enchantment. To Consecrate, is in Scripture, to
 19567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOffer, Give, or Dedicate, in pious and decent language and gesture, a
 19568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, or any other thing to God, by separating of it from common use;
 19569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, to Sanctifie, or make it Gods, and to be used only by
 19570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose, whom God hath appointed to be his Publike Ministers, (as I have
 19571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready proved at large in the 35. Chapter;) and thereby to change, not
 19572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe thing Consecrated, but onely the use of it, from being Profane
 19573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand common, to be Holy, and peculiar to Gods service. But when by such
 19574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords, the nature of qualitie of the thing it selfe, is pretended to be
 19575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchanged, it is not Consecration, but either an extraordinary worke of
 19576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, or a vaine and impious Conjuration. But seeing (for the frequency
 19577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof pretending the change of Nature in their Consecrations,) it cannot
 19578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe esteemed a work extraordinary, it is no other than a Conjuration or
 19579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIncantation, whereby they would have men to beleeve an alteration of
 19580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature that is not, contrary to the testimony of mans Sight, and of all
 19581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe rest of his Senses. As for example, when the Priest, in stead of
 19582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsecrating Bread and Wine to Gods peculiar service in the Sacrament of
 19583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Lords Supper, (which is but a separation of it from the common use,
 19584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto signifie, that is, to put men in mind of their Redemption, by the
 19585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassion of Christ, whose body was broken, and blood shed upon the Crosse
 19586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor our transgressions,) pretends, that by saying of the words of our
 19587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour, "This is my Body," and "This is my Blood," the nature of Bread
 19588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis no more there, but his very Body; notwithstanding there appeared not
 19589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Sight, or other Sense of the Receiver, any thing that appeareth
 19590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot before the Consecration. The Egyptian Conjurers, that are said
 19591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto have turned their Rods to Serpents, and the Water into Bloud, are
 19592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought but to have deluded the senses of the Spectators by a false shew
 19593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof things, yet are esteemed Enchanters: But what should wee have thought
 19594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them, if there had appeared in their Rods nothing like a Serpent, and
 19595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Water enchanted, nothing like Bloud, nor like any thing else but
 19596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWater, but that they had faced down the King, that they were Serpents
 19597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat looked like Rods, and that it was Bloud that seemed Water? That
 19598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad been both Enchantment, and Lying. And yet in this daily act of
 19599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Priest, they doe the very same, by turning the holy words into the
 19600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner of a Charme, which produceth nothing now to the Sense; but they
 19601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tface us down, that it hath turned the Bread into a Man; nay more, into
 19602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta God; and require men to worship it, as if it were our Saviour himself
 19603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent God and Man, and thereby to commit most grosse Idolatry. For if
 19604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit bee enough to excuse it of Idolatry, to say it is no more Bread, but
 19605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod; why should not the same excuse serve the Egyptians, in case they
 19606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad the faces to say, the Leeks, and Onyons they worshipped, were
 19607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot very Leeks, and Onyons, but a Divinity under their Species, or
 19608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlikenesse. The words, "This is my Body," are aequivalent to these,
 19609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"This signifies, or represents my Body;" and it is an ordinary figure of
 19610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpeech: but to take it literally, is an abuse; nor though so taken, can
 19611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit extend any further, than to the Bread which Christ himself with his
 19612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town hands Consecrated. For hee never said, that of what Bread soever,
 19613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany Priest whatsoever, should say, "This is my Body," or, "This is
 19614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrists Body," the same should presently be transubstantiated. Nor did
 19615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Church of Rome ever establish this Transubstantiation, till the time
 19616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Innocent the third; which was not above 500. years agoe, when the
 19617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower of Popes was at the Highest, and the Darknesse of the time grown
 19618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso great, as men discerned not the Bread that was given them to eat,
 19619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tespecially when it was stamped with the figure of Christ upon the
 19620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrosse, as if they would have men beleeve it were Transubstantiated, not
 19621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely into the Body of Christ, but also into the Wood of his Crosse, and
 19622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat they did eat both together in the Sacrament.
 19623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

 19627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIncantation In The Ceremonies Of Baptisme
 19628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe like incantation, in stead of Consecration, is used also in the
 19630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSacrament of Baptisme: Where the abuse of Gods name in each severall
 19631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson, and in the whole Trinity, with the sign of the Crosse at each
 19632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname, maketh up the Charm: As first, when they make the Holy water, the
 19633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriest saith, "I Conjure thee, thou Creature of Water, in the name of
 19634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod the Father Almighty, and in the name of Jesus Christ his onely Son
 19635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Lord, and in vertue of the Holy Ghost, that thou become Conjured
 19636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twater, to drive away all the Powers of the Enemy, and to eradicate, and
 19637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupplant the Enemy, &c." And the same in the Benediction of the Salt
 19638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be mingled with it; "That thou become Conjured Salt, that all
 19639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhantasmes, and Knavery of the Devills fraud may fly and depart from the
 19640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace wherein thou art sprinkled; and every unclean Spirit bee Conjured
 19641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Him that shall come to judge the quicke and the dead." The same in
 19642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Benediction of the Oyle. "That all the Power of the Enemy, all the
 19643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHost of the Devill, all Assaults and Phantasmes of Satan, may be
 19644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdriven away by this Creature of Oyle." And for the Infant that is to be
 19645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBaptized, he is subject to many Charms; First, at the Church dore the
 19646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPriest blows thrice in the Childs face, and sayes, "Goe out of him
 19647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunclean Spirit, and give place to the Holy Ghost the Comforter." As
 19648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif all Children, till blown on by the Priest were Daemoniaques: Again,
 19649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore his entrance into the Church, he saith as before, "I Conjure
 19650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthee, &c. to goe out, and depart from this Servant of God:" And again
 19651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same Exorcisme is repeated once more before he be Baptized. These,
 19652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand some other Incantations, and Consecrations, in administration of the
 19653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSacraments of Baptisme, and the Lords Supper; wherein every thing that
 19654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tserveth to those holy men (except the unhallowed Spittle of the Priest)
 19655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath some set form of Exorcisme.

 19672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tErrors From Mistaking Eternall Life, And Everlasting Death
 19673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother generall Error, is from the Misinterpretation of the words
 19675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternall Life, Everlasting Death, and the Second Death. For though we
 19676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tread plainly in Holy Scripture, that God created Adam in an estate of
 19677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiving for Ever, which was conditionall, that is to say, if he disobeyed
 19678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot his Commandement; which was not essentiall to Humane Nature, but
 19679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsequent to the vertue of the Tree of Life; whereof hee had liberty
 19680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto eat, as long as hee had not sinned; and that hee was thrust out of
 19681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tParadise after he had sinned, lest hee should eate thereof, and live for
 19682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tever; and that Christs Passion is a Discharge of sin to all that beleeve
 19683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton him; and by consequence, a restitution of Eternall Life, to all the
 19684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFaithfull, and to them onely: yet the Doctrine is now, and hath been a
 19685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlong time far otherwise; namely, that every man hath Eternity of Life by
 19686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature, in as much as his Soul is Immortall: So that the flaming Sword
 19687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat the entrance of Paradise, though it hinder a man from coming to the
 19688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTree of Life, hinders him not from the Immortality which God took from
 19689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim for his Sin; nor makes him to need the sacrificing of Christ, for
 19690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe recovering of the same; and consequently, not onely the faithfull
 19691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand righteous, but also the wicked, and the Heathen, shall enjoy
 19692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternall Life, without any Death at all; much lesse a Second, and
 19693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEverlasting Death. To salve this, it is said, that by Second, and
 19694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEverlasting Death, is meant a Second, and Everlasting Life, but in
 19695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTorments; a Figure never used, but in this very Case.
 19696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAll which Doctrine is founded onely on some of the obscurer places of
 19698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe New Testament; which neverthelesse, the whole scope of the Scripture
 19699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsidered, are cleer enough in a different sense, and unnecessary to
 19700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Christian Faith. For supposing that when a man dies, there remaineth
 19701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnothing of him but his carkasse; cannot God that raised inanimated dust
 19702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand clay into a living creature by his Word, as easily raise a dead
 19703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcarkasse to life again, and continue him alive for Ever, or make him
 19704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdie again, by another Word? The Soule in Scripture, signifieth alwaies,
 19705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither the Life, or the Living Creature; and the Body and Soule jointly,
 19706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Body Alive. In the fift day of the Creation, God said, Let the water
 19707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproduce Reptile Animae Viventis, the creeping thing that hath in it a
 19708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiving Soule; the English translate it, "that hath Life:" And again,
 19709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod created Whales, "& omnem animam viventem;" which in the English is,
 19710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"every living Creature:" And likewise of Man, God made him of the dust
 19711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the earth, and breathed in his face the breath of Life, "& factus est
 19712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHomo in animam viventem," that is, "and Man was made a Living Creature;"
 19713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd after Noah came out of the Arke, God saith, hee will no more smite
 19714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"omnem animam viventem," that is "every Living Creature;" And Deut.
 19715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t12.23. "Eate not the Bloud, for the Bloud is the Soule;" that is
 19716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"the Life." From which places, if by Soule were meant a Substance
 19717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIncorporeall, with an existence separated from the Body, it might as
 19718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twell be inferred of any other living Creature, as of Man. But that
 19719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Souls of the Faithfull, are not of their own Nature, but by Gods
 19720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeciall Grace, to remaine in their bodies, from the Resurrection to
 19721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall Eternity, I have already I think sufficiently proved out of the
 19722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScriptures, in the 38. Chapter. And for the places of the New Testament,
 19723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere it is said that any man shall be cast Body and Soul into Hell
 19724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfire, it is no more than Body and Life; that is to say, they shall be
 19725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcast alive into the perpetuall fire of Gehenna.
 19726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs The Doctrine Of Purgatory, And Exorcismes, And Invocation Of Saints
 19731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis window it is, that gives entrance to the Dark Doctrine, first, of
 19733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternall Torments; and afterwards of Purgatory, and consequently of the
 19734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twalking abroad, especially in places Consecrated, Solitary, or Dark, of
 19735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Ghosts of men deceased; and thereby to the pretences of Exorcisme
 19736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Conjuration of Phantasmes; as also of Invocation of men dead; and to
 19737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Doctrine of Indulgences; that is to say, of exemption for a time,
 19738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor for ever, from the fire of Purgatory, wherein these Incorporeall
 19739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubstances are pretended by burning to be cleansed, and made fit
 19740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Heaven. For men being generally possessed before the time of our
 19741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour, by contagion of the Daemonology of the Greeks, of an opinion,
 19742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat the Souls of men were substances distinct from their Bodies, and
 19743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore that when the Body was dead, the Soule of every man, whether
 19744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgodly, or wicked, must subsist somewhere by vertue of its own nature,
 19745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout acknowledging therein any supernaturall gift of Gods; the
 19746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctors of the Church doubted a long time, what was the place, which
 19747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were to abide in, till they should be re-united to their Bodies in
 19748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Resurrection; supposing for a while, they lay under the Altars: but
 19749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafterward the Church of Rome found it more profitable, to build for them
 19750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis place of Purgatory; which by some other Churches in this later age,
 19751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thas been demolished.
 19752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

 19755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Texts Alledged For The Doctrines Aforementioned Have Been Answered
 19757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBefore
 19759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLet us now consider, what texts of Scripture seem most to confirm these
 19761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthree generall Errors, I have here touched. As for those which Cardinall
 19762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBellarmine hath alledged, for the present Kingdome of God administred by
 19763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Pope, (than which there are none that make a better show of proof,)
 19764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI have already answered them; and made it evident, that the Kingdome
 19765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God, instituted by Moses, ended in the election of Saul: After which
 19766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime the Priest of his own authority never deposed any King. That which
 19767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe High Priest did to Athaliah, was not done in his own right, but in
 19768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe right of the young King Joash her Son: But Solomon in his own right
 19769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeposed the High Priest Abiathar, and set up another in his place. The
 19770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost difficult place to answer, of all those than can be brought,
 19771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto prove the Kingdome of God by Christ is already in this world, is
 19772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talledged, not by Bellarmine, nor any other of the Church of Rome; but
 19773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Beza; that will have it to begin from the Resurrection of Christ.
 19774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut whether hee intend thereby, to entitle the Presbytery to the Supreme
 19775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower Ecclesiasticall in the Common-wealth of Geneva, (and consequently
 19776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto every Presbytery in every other Common-wealth,) or to Princes,
 19777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand other Civill Soveraignes, I doe not know. For the Presbytery hath
 19778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchallenged the power to Excommunicate their owne Kings, and to bee the
 19779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSupreme Moderators in Religion, in the places where they have that form
 19780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Church government, no lesse then the Pope challengeth it universally.

 19785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnswer To The Text On Which Beza Infereth
 19786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat The Kingdome Of Christ Began At The Resurrection The words are
 19788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(Marke 9.1.) "Verily, I say unto you, that there be some of them that
 19789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstand here, which shall not tast of death, till they have seene the
 19790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God come with power." Which words, if taken grammatically,
 19791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake it certaine, that either some of those men that stood by Christ at
 19792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat time, are yet alive; or else, that the Kingdome of God must be now
 19793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this present world. And then there is another place more difficult:
 19794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor when the Apostles after our Saviours Resurrection, and immediately
 19795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore his Ascension, asked our Saviour, saying, (Acts.1.6.) "Wilt thou
 19796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat this time restore again the Kingdome to Israel," he answered them,
 19797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"It is not for you to know the times and the seasons, which the Father
 19798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath put in his own power; But ye shall receive power by the comming of
 19799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Holy Ghost upon you, and yee shall be my (Martyrs) witnesses both in
 19800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJerusalem, & in all Judaea, and in Samaria, and unto the uttermost part
 19801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Earth:" Which is as much as to say, My Kingdome is not yet come,
 19802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor shall you foreknow when it shall come, for it shall come as a theefe
 19803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the night; But I will send you the Holy Ghost, and by him you shall
 19804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave power to beare witnesse to all the world (by your preaching) of
 19805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmy Resurrection, and the workes I have done, and the doctrine I have
 19806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttaught, that they may beleeve in me, and expect eternall life, at my
 19807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomming againe: How does this agree with the comming of Christs Kingdome
 19808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat the Resurrection? And that which St. Paul saies (1 Thessal. 1.9, 10.)
 19809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"That they turned from Idols, to serve the living and true God, and
 19810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto waite for his Sonne from Heaven:" Where to waite for his Sonne from
 19811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeaven, is to wait for his comming to be King in power; which were
 19812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot necessary, if this Kingdome had beene then present. Againe, if the
 19813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome of God began (as Beza on that place (Mark 9.1.) would have it)
 19814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat the Resurrection; what reason is there for Christians ever since the
 19815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResurrection to say in their prayers, "Let thy Kingdome Come"? It
 19816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis therefore manifest, that the words of St. Mark are not so to be
 19817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterpreted. There be some of them that stand here (saith our Saviour)
 19818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat shall not tast of death till they have seen the Kingdome of God
 19819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcome in power. If then this Kingdome were to come at the Resurrection
 19820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Christ, why is it said, "some of them" rather than all? For they all
 19821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlived till after Christ was risen.

 19826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExplication Of The Place In Mark 9.1
 19827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut they that require an exact interpretation of this text, let them
 19829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterpret first the like words of our Saviour to St. Peter concerning
 19830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. John, (chap. 21.22.) "If I will that he tarry till I come, what is
 19831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat to thee?" upon which was grounded a report that hee should not dye:
 19832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse the truth of that report was neither confirmed, as well
 19833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrounded; nor refuted, as ill grounded on those words; but left as a
 19834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaying not understood. The same difficulty is also in the place of St.
 19835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMarke. And if it be lawfull to conjecture at their meaning, by that
 19836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich immediately followes, both here, and in St. Luke, where the same
 19837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis againe repeated, it is not unprobable, to say they have relation
 19838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Transfiguration, which is described in the verses immediately
 19839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollowing; where it is said, that "After six dayes Jesus taketh with
 19840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim Peter, and James, and John (not all, but some of his Disciples)
 19841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand leadeth them up into an high mountaine apart by themselves, and
 19842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas transfigured before them. And his rayment became shining, exceeding
 19843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhite as snow; so as no Fuller on earth can white them. And there
 19844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappeared unto them Elias with Moses, and they were talking with Jesus,
 19845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t&c." So that they saw Christ in Glory and Majestie, as he is to come;
 19846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinsomuch as "They were sore afraid." And thus the promise of our Saviour
 19847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas accomplished by way of Vision: For it was a Vision, as may probably
 19848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee inferred out of St. Luke, that reciteth the same story (ch. 9. ve.
 19849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t28.) and saith, that Peter and they that were with him, were heavy with
 19850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsleep; But most certainly out of Matth. 17.9. (where the same is again
 19851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trelated;) for our Saviour charged them, saying, "Tell no man the Vision
 19852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuntill the Son of man be Risen from the dead." Howsoever it be, yet
 19853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere can from thence be taken no argument, to prove that the Kingdome
 19854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God taketh beginning till the day of Judgement.

 19859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbuse Of Some Other Texts In Defence Of The Power Of The Pope
 19860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for some other texts, to prove the Popes Power over civill
 19862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignes (besides those of Bellarmine;) as that the two Swords that
 19863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist and his Apostles had amongst them, were the Spirituall and the
 19864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTemporall Sword, which they say St. Peter had given him by Christ: And,
 19865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat of the two Luminaries, the greater signifies the Pope, and the
 19866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlesser the King; One might as well inferre out of the first verse of the
 19867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBible, that by Heaven is meant the Pope, and by Earth the King: Which
 19868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not arguing from Scripture, but a wanton insulting over Princes, that
 19869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcame in fashion after the time the Popes were growne so secure of their
 19870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreatnesse, as to contemne all Christian Kings; and Treading on the
 19871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecks of Emperours, to mocke both them, and the Scripture, in the words
 19872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the 91. Psalm, "Thou shalt Tread upon the Lion and the Adder, the
 19873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyoung Lion and the Dragon thou shalt Trample under thy feet."

 19878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Manner Of Consecrations In The Scripture, Was Without Exorcisms
 19879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for the rites of Consecration, though they depend for the most part
 19881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon the discretion and judgement of the governors of the Church,
 19882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand not upon the Scriptures; yet those governors are obliged to such
 19883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdirection, as the nature of the action it selfe requireth; as that the
 19884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tceremonies, words, and gestures, be both decent, and significant, or at
 19885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tleast conformable to the action. When Moses consecrated the Tabernacle,
 19886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Altar, and the Vessels belonging to them (Exod. 40.) he anointed
 19887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem with the Oyle which God had commanded to bee made for that
 19888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpurpose; and they were holy; There was nothing Exorcised, to drive away
 19889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhantasmes. The same Moses (the civill Soveraigne of Israel) when he
 19890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsecrated Aaron (the High Priest,) and his Sons, did wash them with
 19891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWater, (not Exorcised water,) put their Garments upon them, and anointed
 19892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem with Oyle; and they were sanctified, to minister unto the Lord
 19893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the Priests office; which was a simple and decent cleansing, and
 19894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadorning them, before hee presented them to God, to be his servants.
 19895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen King Solomon, (the civill Soveraigne of Israel) consecrated the
 19896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTemple hee had built, (2 Kings 8.) he stood before all the Congregation
 19897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Israel; and having blessed them, he gave thanks to God, for putting
 19898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto the heart of his father, to build it; and for giving to himselfe
 19899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe grace to accomplish the same; and then prayed unto him, first,
 19900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto accept that House, though it were not sutable to his infinite
 19901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGreatnesse; and to hear the prayers of his Servants that should pray
 19902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherein, or (if they were absent) towards it; and lastly, he offered a
 19903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsacrifice of Peace-offering, and the House was dedicated. Here was no
 19904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProcession; the King stood still in his first place; no Exorcised Water;
 19905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno Asperges Me, nor other impertinent application of words spoken upon
 19906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother occasion; but a decent, and rationall speech, and such as in
 19907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmaking to God a present of his new built House, was most conformable
 19908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the occasion. We read not that St. John did Exorcise the Water
 19909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Jordan; nor Philip the Water of the river wherein he baptized the
 19910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEunuch; nor that any Pastor in the time of the Apostles, did take his
 19911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspittle, and put it to the nose of the person to be Baptized, and say,
 19912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"In odorem suavitatis," that is, "for a sweet savour unto the Lord;"
 19913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twherein neither the Ceremony of Spittle, for the uncleannesse; nor the
 19914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapplication of that Scripture for the levity, can by any authority of
 19915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman be justified.

 19919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Immortality Of Mans Soule, Not Proved By Scripture To Be Of Nature,
 19921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut Of Grace
 19923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo prove that the Soule separated from the Body liveth eternally, not
 19925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely the Soules of the Elect, by especiall grace, and restauration of
 19926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Eternall Life which Adam lost by Sinne, and our Saviour restored
 19927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Sacrifice of himself, to the Faithfull, but also the Soules
 19928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Reprobates, as a property naturally consequent to the essence of
 19929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmankind, without other grace of God, but that which is universally given
 19930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto all mankind; there are divers places, which at the first sight seem
 19931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsufficiently to serve the turn: but such, as when I compare them with
 19932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which I have before (Chapter 38.) alledged out of the 14 of Job,
 19933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseem to mee much more subject to a divers interpretation, than the words
 19934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Job.
 19935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first there are the words of Solomon (Ecclesiastes 12.7.) "Then
 19937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall the Dust return to Dust, as it was, and the Spirit shall return to
 19938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod that gave it." Which may bear well enough (if there be no other text
 19939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdirectly against it) this interpretation, that God onely knows, (but
 19940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMan not,) what becomes of a mans spirit, when he expireth; and the same
 19941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSolomon, in the same Book, (Chap. 3. ver. 20,21.) delivereth in the same
 19942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsentence in the sense I have given it: His words are, "All goe, (man
 19943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand beast) to the same place; all are of the dust, and all turn to dust
 19944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagain; who knoweth that the spirit of Man goeth upward, and the spirit
 19945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Beast goeth downward to the earth?" That is, none knows but God;
 19946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor is it an unusuall phrase to say of things we understand not, "God
 19947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknows what," and "God knows where." That of Gen. 5.24. "Enoch walked
 19948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith God, and he was not; for God took him;" which is expounded Heb.
 19949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t13.5. "He was translated, that he should not die; and was not found,
 19950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause God had translated him. For before his Translation, he had this
 19951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttestimony, that he pleased God," making as much for the Immortality
 19952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Body, as of the Soule, proveth, that this his translation was
 19953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeculiar to them that please God; not common to them with the wicked;
 19954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand depending on Grace, not on Nature. But on the contrary, what
 19955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterpretation shall we give, besides the literall sense of the words of
 19956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSolomon (Eccles. 3.19.) "That which befalleth the Sons of Men, befalleth
 19957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBeasts, even one thing befalleth them; as the one dyeth, so doth the
 19958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother; yea, they have all one breath (one spirit;) so that a Man hath no
 19959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpraeeminence above a Beast, for all is vanity." By the literall sense,
 19960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\there is no Naturall Immortality of the Soule; nor yet any repugnancy
 19961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the Life Eternall, which the Elect shall enjoy by Grace. And (chap.
 19962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t4. ver.3.) "Better is he that hath not yet been, than both they;" that
 19963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, than they that live, or have lived; which, if the Soule of all them
 19964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat have lived, were Immortall, were a hard saying; for then to have
 19965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Immortall Soule, were worse than to have no Soule at all. And
 19966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagaine,(Chapt. 9.5.) "The living know they shall die, but the dead know
 19967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot any thing;" that is, Naturally, and before the resurrection of the
 19968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbody.
 19969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother place which seems to make for a Naturall Immortality of the
 19971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoule, is that, where our Saviour saith, that Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob
 19972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare living: but this is spoken of the promise of God, and of their
 19973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcertitude to rise again, not of a Life then actuall; and in the same
 19974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsense that God said to Adam, that on the day hee should eate of the
 19975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforbidden fruit, he should certainly die; from that time forward he was
 19976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta dead man by sentence; but not by execution, till almost a thousand
 19977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyears after. So Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob were alive by promise, then,
 19978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen Christ spake; but are not actually till the Resurrection. And the
 19979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHistory of Dives and Lazarus, make nothing against this, if wee take it
 19980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as it is) for a Parable.
 19981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut there be other places of the New Testament, where an Immortality
 19983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseemeth to be directly attributed to the wicked. For it is evident, that
 19984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey shall all rise to Judgement. And it is said besides in many places,
 19985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat they shall goe into "Everlasting fire, Everlasting torments,
 19986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEverlasting punishments; and that the worm of conscience never dyeth;"
 19987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand all this is comprehended in the word Everlasting Death, which is
 19988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordinarily interpreted Everlasting Life In Torments: And yet I can find
 19989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno where that any man shall live in torments Everlastingly. Also, it
 19990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseemeth hard, to say, that God who is the Father of Mercies, that doth
 19991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Heaven and Earth all that hee will; that hath the hearts of all men
 19992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his disposing; that worketh in men both to doe, and to will; and
 19993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout whose free gift a man hath neither inclination to good, nor
 19994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepentance of evill, should punish mens transgressions without any end
 19995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof time, and with all the extremity of torture, that men can imagine,
 19996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand more. We are therefore to consider, what the meaning is, of
 19997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEverlasting Fire, and other the like phrases of Scripture.
 19998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 19999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI have shewed already, that the Kingdome of God by Christ beginneth at
 20000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe day of Judgment: That in that day, the Faithfull shall rise again,
 20001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith glorious, and spirituall Bodies, and bee his Subjects in that his
 20002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome, which shall be Eternall; That they shall neither marry, nor
 20003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe given in marriage, nor eate and drink, as they did in their naturall
 20004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbodies; but live for ever in their individuall persons, without the
 20005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspecificall eternity of generation: And that the Reprobates also shall
 20006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trise again, to receive punishments for their sins: As also, that those
 20007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Elect, which shall be alive in their earthly bodies at that
 20008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tday, shall have their bodies suddenly changed, and made spirituall, and
 20009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImmortall. But that the bodies of the Reprobate, who make the Kingdome
 20010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Satan, shall also be glorious, or spirituall bodies, or that they
 20011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall bee as the Angels of God, neither eating, nor drinking, nor
 20012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tengendring; or that their life shall be Eternall in their individuall
 20013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpersons, as the life of every faithfull man is, or as the life of Adam
 20014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad been if hee had not sinned, there is no place of Scripture to prove
 20015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit; save onely these places concerning Eternall Torments; which may
 20016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\totherwise be interpreted.
 20017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom whence may be inferred, that as the Elect after the Resurrection
 20019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall be restored to the estate, wherein Adam was before he had sinned;
 20020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso the Reprobate shall be in the estate, that Adam, and his posterity
 20021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere in after the sin committed; saving that God promised a Redeemer to
 20022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdam, and such of his seed as should trust in him, and repent; but not
 20023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto them that should die in their sins, as do the Reprobate.

 20028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEternall Torments What
 20029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThese things considered, the texts that mention Eternall Fire, Eternal
 20031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTorments, or the Word That Never Dieth, contradict not the Doctrine of
 20032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Second, and Everlasting Death, in the proper and naturall sense of the
 20033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tword Death. The Fire, or Torments prepared for the wicked in Gehenna,
 20034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTophet, or in what place soever, may continue for ever; and there may
 20035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnever want wicked men to be tormented in them; though not every, nor
 20036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany one Eternally. For the wicked being left in the estate they were in
 20037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tafter Adams sin, may at the Resurrection live as they did, marry, and
 20038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive in marriage, and have grosse and corruptible bodies, as all
 20039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmankind now have; and consequently may engender perpetually, after the
 20040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResurrection, as they did before: For there is no place of Scripture to
 20041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe contrary. For St. Paul, speaking of the Resurrection (1 Cor. 15.)
 20042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstandeth it onely of the Resurrection to Life Eternall; and not the
 20043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResurrection to Punishment. And of the first, he saith that the Body is
 20044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Sown in Corruption, raised in Incorruption; sown in Dishonour, raised
 20045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Honour; sown in Weaknesse, raised in Power; sown a Naturall body,
 20046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\traised a Spirituall body:" There is no such thing can be said of the
 20047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbodies of them that rise to Punishment. The text is Luke 20. Verses
 20048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t34,35,36. a fertile text. "The Children of this world marry, and are
 20049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiven in marriage; but they that shall be counted worthy to obtaine that
 20050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld, and the Resurrection from the dead, neither marry, nor are given
 20051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin marriage: Neither can they die any more; for they are equall to
 20052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Angells, and are the Children of God, being the Children of the
 20053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResurrection:" The Children of this world, that are in the estate
 20054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich Adam left them in, shall marry, and be given in marriage; that is
 20055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcorrupt, and generate successively; which is an Immortality of the Kind,
 20056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut not of the Persons of men: They are not worthy to be counted amongst
 20057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem that shall obtain the next world, and an absolute Resurrection from
 20058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe dead; but onely a short time, as inmates of that world; and to the
 20059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tend onely to receive condign punishment for their contumacy. The Elect
 20060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare the onely children of the Resurrection; that is to say the sole
 20061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theirs of Eternall Life: they only can die no more; it is they that are
 20062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequall to the Angels, and that are the children of God; and not the
 20063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReprobate. To the Reprobate there remaineth after the Resurrection,
 20064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Second, and Eternall Death: between which Resurrection, and their
 20065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecond, and Eternall death, is but a time of Punishment and Torment; and
 20066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto last by succession of sinners thereunto, as long as the kind of Man
 20067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby propagation shall endure, which is Eternally.

 20069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnswer Of The Texts Alledged For Purgatory
 20073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUpon this Doctrine of the Naturall Eternity of separated Soules, is
 20075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfounded (as I said) the Doctrine of Purgatory. For supposing Eternall
 20076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLife by Grace onely, there is no Life, but the Life of the Body; and no
 20077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImmortality till the Resurrection. The texts for Purgatory alledged by
 20078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBellarmine out of the Canonicall Scripture of the old Testament, are
 20079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst, the Fasting of David for Saul and Jonathan, mentioned (2 Kings,
 20080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t1. 12.); and againe, (2 Sam. 3. 35.) for the death of Abner. This
 20081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFasting of David, he saith, was for the obtaining of something for them
 20082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat Gods hands, after their death; because after he had Fasted to procure
 20083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe recovery of his owne child, assoone as he know it was dead, he
 20084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled for meate. Seeing then the Soule hath an existence separate from
 20085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Body, and nothing can be obtained by mens Fasting for the Soules
 20086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat are already either in Heaven, or Hell, it followeth that there be
 20087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome Soules of dead men, what are neither in Heaven, nor in Hell; and
 20088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore they must bee in some third place, which must be Purgatory.
 20089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd thus with hard straining, hee has wrested those places to the proofe
 20090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Purgatory; whereas it is manifest, that the ceremonies of Mourning,
 20091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Fasting, when they are used for the death of men, whose life was
 20092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot profitable to the Mourners, they are used for honours sake to their
 20093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpersons; and when tis done for the death of them by whose life the
 20094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMourners had benefit, it proceeds from their particular dammage: And so
 20095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDavid honoured Saul, and Abner, with his Fasting; and in the death of
 20096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this owne child, recomforted himselfe, by receiving his ordinary food.
 20097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the other places, which he alledgeth out of the old Testament, there
 20099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not so much as any shew, or colour of proofe. He brings in every text
 20100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twherein there is the word Anger, or Fire, or Burning, or Purging, or
 20101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tClensing, in case any of the Fathers have but in a Sermon rhetorically
 20102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapplied it to the Doctrine of Purgatory, already beleeved. The first
 20103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tverse of Psalme, 37. "O Lord rebuke me not in thy wrath, nor chasten me
 20104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin thy hot displeasure:" What were this to Purgatory, if Augustine had
 20105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot applied the Wrath to the fire of Hell, and the Displeasure, to that
 20106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Purgatory? And what is it to Purgatory, that of Psalme, 66. 12. "Wee
 20107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twent through fire and water, and thou broughtest us to a moist place;"
 20108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand other the like texts, (with which the Doctors of those times
 20109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tentended to adorne, or extend their Sermons, or Commentaries) haled to
 20110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir purposes by force of wit?
 20111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPlaces Of The New Testament For Purgatory Answered
 20116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut he alledgeth other places of the New Testament, that are not
 20118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso easie to be answered: And first that of Matth. 12.32. "Whosoever
 20119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeaketh a word against the Sonne of man, it shall be forgiven him; but
 20120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhosoever speaketh against the Holy Ghost, it shall not bee forgiven
 20121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim neither in this world, nor in the world to come:" Where he will have
 20122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPurgatory to be the World to come, wherein some sinnes may be forgiven,
 20123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich in this World were not forgiven: notwithstanding that it is
 20124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest, there are but three Worlds; one from the Creation to the
 20125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFlood, which was destroyed by Water, and is called in Scripture the
 20126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOld World; another from the Flood to the day of Judgement, which is the
 20127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresent World, and shall bee destroyed by Fire; and the third, which
 20128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall bee from the day of Judgement forward, everlasting, which is
 20129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled the World To Come; and in which it is agreed by all, there shall
 20130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe no Purgatory; And therefore the World to come, and Purgatory, are
 20131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinconsistent. But what then can bee the meaning of those our Saviours
 20132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords? I confesse they are very hardly to bee reconciled with all the
 20133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrines now unanimously received: Nor is it any shame, to confesse the
 20134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprofoundnesse of the Scripture, to bee too great to be sounded by the
 20135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshortnesse of humane understanding. Neverthelesse, I may propound such
 20136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings to the consideration of more learned Divines, as the text it
 20137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tselfe suggesteth. And first, seeing to speake against the Holy Ghost, as
 20138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing the third Person of the Trinity, is to speake against the Church,
 20139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin which the Holy Ghost resideth; it seemeth the comparison is made,
 20140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetweene the Easinesse of our Saviour, in bearing with offences done to
 20141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim while he was on earth, and the Severity of the Pastors after him,
 20142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst those which should deny their authority, which was from the Holy
 20143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGhost: As if he should say, You that deny my Power; nay you that shall
 20144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcrucifie me, shall be pardoned by mee, as often as you turne unto mee by
 20145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepentance: But if you deny the Power of them that teach you hereafter,
 20146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby vertue of the Holy Ghost, they shall be inexorable, and shall not
 20147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforgive you, but persecute you in this World, and leave you without
 20148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabsolution, (though you turn to me, unlesse you turn also to them,) to
 20149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe punishments (as much as lies in them) of the World to come: And
 20150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso the words may be taken as a Prophecy, or Praediction concerning the
 20151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttimes, as they have along been in the Christian Church: Or if this be
 20152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot the meaning, (for I am not peremptory in such difficult places,)
 20153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperhaps there may be place left after the Resurrection for the
 20154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepentance of some sinners: And there is also another place, that
 20155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseemeth to agree therewith. For considering the words of St. Paul (1
 20156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCor. 15. 29.) "What shall they doe which are Baptized for the dead, if
 20157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe dead rise not at all? why also are they Baptized for the dead?" a
 20158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman may probably inferre, as some have done, that in St. Pauls time,
 20159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere was a custome by receiving Baptisme for the dead, (as men that now
 20160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve, are Sureties and Undertakers for the Faith of Infants, that
 20161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not capable of beleeving,) to undertake for the persons of their
 20162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeceased friends, that they should be ready to obey, and receive our
 20163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour for their King, at his coming again; and then the forgivenesse
 20164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof sins in the world to come, has no need of a Purgatory. But in both
 20165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese interpretations, there is so much of paradox, that I trust not
 20166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto them; but propound them to those that are throughly versed in the
 20167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture, to inquire if there be no clearer place that contradicts
 20168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem. Onely of thus much, I see evident Scripture, to perswade men, that
 20169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is neither the word, nor the thing of Purgatory, neither in this,
 20170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor any other text; nor any thing that can prove a necessity of a place
 20171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the Soule without the Body; neither for the Soule of Lazarus during
 20172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe four days he was dead; nor for the Soules of them which the Romane
 20173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch pretend to be tormented now in Purgatory. For God, that could
 20174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgive a life to a peece of clay, hath the same power to give life again
 20175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto a dead man, and renew his inanimate, and rotten Carkasse, into a
 20176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tglorious, spirituall, and immortall Body.
 20177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother place is that of 1 Cor. 3. where it is said that they which
 20179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbuilt Stubble, Hay, &c. on the true Foundation, their work shall perish;
 20180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut "they themselves shall be saved; but as through Fire:" This Fire, he
 20181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill have to be the Fire of Purgatory. The words, as I have said before,
 20182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare an allusion to those of Zach. 13. 9. where he saith, "I will bring
 20183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe third part through the Fire, and refine them as Silver is refined,
 20184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand will try them as Gold is tryed;" Which is spoken of the comming of
 20185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Messiah in Power and Glory; that is, at the day of Judgment, and
 20186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConflagration of the present world; wherein the Elect shall not be
 20187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsumed, but be refined; that is, depose their erroneous Doctrines, and
 20188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTraditions, and have them as it were sindged off; and shall afterwards
 20189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcall upon the name of the true God. In like manner, the Apostle saith
 20190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them, that holding this Foundation Jesus Is The Christ, shall build
 20191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereon some other Doctrines that be erroneous, that they shall not be
 20192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsumed in that fire which reneweth the world, but shall passe through
 20193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit to Salvation; but so, as to see, and relinquish their former Errours.
 20194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Builders, are the Pastors; the Foundation, that Jesus Is The Christ;
 20195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Stubble and Hay, False Consequences Drawn From It Through Ignorance,
 20196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOr Frailty; the Gold, Silver, and pretious Stones, are their True
 20197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrines; and their Refining or Purging, the Relinquishing Of Their
 20198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tErrors. In all which there is no colour at all for the burning of
 20199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIncorporeall, that is to say, Impatible Souls.

 20202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBaptisme For The Dead, How Understood
 20205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA third place is that of 1 Cor. 15. before mentioned, concerning
 20207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBaptisme for the Dead: out of which he concludeth, first, that Prayers
 20208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor the Dead are not unprofitable; and out of that, that there is a Fire
 20209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Purgatory: But neither of them rightly. For of many interpretations
 20210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the word Baptisme, he approveth this in the first place, that by
 20211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBaptisme is meant (metaphorically) a Baptisme of Penance; and that men
 20212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare in this sense Baptized, when they Fast, and Pray, and give Almes:
 20213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd so Baptisme for the Dead, and Prayer of the Dead, is the same thing.
 20214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut this is a Metaphor, of which there is no example, neither in
 20215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Scripture, nor in any other use of language; and which is also
 20216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscordant to the harmony, and scope of the Scripture. The word Baptisme
 20217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis used (Mar. 10. 38. & Luk. 12. 59.) for being Dipped in ones own
 20218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbloud, as Christ was upon the Cross, and as most of the Apostles
 20219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere, for giving testimony of him. But it is hard to say, that Prayer,
 20220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFasting, and Almes, have any similitude with Dipping. The same is used
 20221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talso Mat. 3. 11. (which seemeth to make somewhat for Purgatory) for
 20222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Purging with Fire. But it is evident the Fire and Purging here
 20223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmentioned, is the same whereof the Prophet Zachary speaketh (chap. 13.
 20224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tv. 9.) "I will bring the third part through the Fire, and will Refine
 20225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, &c." And St. Peter after him (1 Epist. 1. 7.) "That the triall
 20226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof your Faith, which is much more precious than of Gold that perisheth,
 20227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough it be tryed with fire, might be found unto praise, and honour,
 20228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand glory at the Appearing of Jesus Christ;" And St. Paul (1 Cor. 3.
 20229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t13.) The Fire shall trie every mans work of what sort it is." But
 20230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Peter, and St. Paul speak of the Fire that shall be at the Second
 20231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAppearing of Christ; and the Prophet Zachary of the Day of Judgment: And
 20232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore this place of S. Mat. may be interpreted of the same; and then
 20233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere will be no necessity of the Fire of Purgatory.
 20234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother interpretation of Baptisme for the Dead, is that which I
 20236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave before mentioned, which he preferreth to the second place of
 20237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprobability; And thence also he inferreth the utility of Prayer for the
 20238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDead. For if after the Resurrection, such as have not heard of Christ,
 20239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor not beleeved in him, may be received into Christs Kingdome; it is
 20240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot in vain, after their death, that their friends should pray for them,
 20241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttill they should be risen. But granting that God, at the prayers of the
 20242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfaithfull, may convert unto him some of those that have not heard Christ
 20243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreached, and consequently cannot have rejected Christ, and that the
 20244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcharity of men in that point, cannot be blamed; yet this concludeth
 20245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnothing for Purgatory, because to rise from Death to Life, is one thing;
 20246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto rise from Purgatory to Life is another; and being a rising from Life
 20247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Life, from a Life in torments to a Life in joy.
 20248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA fourth place is that of Mat. 5. 25. "Agree with thine Adversary
 20250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquickly, whilest thou art in the way with him, lest at any time the
 20251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdversary deliver thee to the Officer, and thou be cast into prison.
 20252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVerily I say unto thee, thou shalt by no means come out thence, till
 20253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthou has paid the uttermost farthing." In which Allegory, the Offender
 20254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the Sinner; both the Adversary and the Judge is God; the Way is
 20255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis Life; the Prison is the Grave; the Officer, Death; from which, the
 20256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsinner shall not rise again to life eternall, but to a second Death,
 20257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttill he have paid the utmost farthing, or Christ pay it for him by his
 20258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassion, which is a full Ransome for all manner of sin, as well lesser
 20259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsins, as greater crimes; both being made by the passion of Christ
 20260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tequally veniall.
 20261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fift place, is that of Matth. 5. 22. "Whosoever is angry with his
 20263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBrother without a cause, shall be guilty in Judgment. And whosoever
 20264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall say to his Brother, RACHA, shall be guilty in the Councel. But
 20265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhosoever shall say, Thou Foole, shall be guilty to hell fire." From
 20266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich words he inferreth three sorts of Sins, and three sorts of
 20267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPunishments; and that none of those sins, but the last, shall be
 20268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunished with hell fire; and consequently, that after this life, there
 20269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis punishment of lesser sins in Purgatory. Of which inference, there is
 20270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno colour in any interpretation that hath yet been given to them: Shall
 20271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere be a distinction after this life of Courts of Justice, as there
 20272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas amongst the Jews in our Saviours time, to hear, and determine
 20273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivers sorts of Crimes; as the Judges, and the Councell? Shall not
 20274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall Judicature appertain to Christ, and his Apostles? To understand
 20275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore this text, we are not to consider it solitarily, but jointly
 20276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the words precedent, and subsequent. Our Saviour in this Chapter
 20277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinterpreteth the Law of Moses; which the Jews thought was then
 20278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfulfilled, when they had not transgressed the Grammaticall sense
 20279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof, howsoever they had transgressed against the sentence, or
 20280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeaning of the Legislator. Therefore whereas they thought the Sixth
 20281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandement was not broken, but by Killing a man; nor the Seventh, but
 20282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen a man lay with a woman, not his wife; our Saviour tells them, the
 20283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinward Anger of a man against his brother, if it be without just cause,
 20284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Homicide: You have heard (saith hee) the Law of Moses, "Thou shalt
 20285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot Kill," and that "Whosoever shall Kill, shall be condemned before the
 20286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudges," or before the Session of the Seventy: But I say unto you, to
 20287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Angry with ones Brother without cause; or to say unto him Racha, or
 20288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFoole, is Homicide, and shall be punished at the day of Judgment, and
 20289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSession of Christ, and his Apostles, with Hell fire: so that those words
 20290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere not used to distinguish between divers Crimes, and divers Courts
 20291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Justice, and divers Punishments; but to taxe the distinction between
 20292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsin, and sin, which the Jews drew not from the difference of the Will
 20293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Obeying God, but from the difference of their Temporall Courts of
 20294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustice; and to shew them that he that had the Will to hurt his Brother,
 20295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough the effect appear but in Reviling, or not at all, shall be cast
 20296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto hell fire, by the Judges, and by the Session, which shall be the
 20297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame, not different Courts at the day of Judgment. This Considered, what
 20298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan be drawn from this text, to maintain Purgatory, I cannot imagine.
 20299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe sixth place is Luke 16. 9. "Make yee friends of the unrighteous
 20301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMammon, that when yee faile, they may receive you into Everlasting
 20302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTabernacles." This he alledges to prove Invocation of Saints departed.
 20303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the sense is plain, That we should make friends with our Riches, of
 20304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Poore, and thereby obtain their Prayers whilest they live. "He that
 20305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiveth to the Poore, lendeth to the Lord. "The seventh is Luke 23. 42.
 20306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"Lord remember me when thou commest into thy Kingdome:" Therefore, saith
 20307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee, there is Remission of sins after this life. But the consequence
 20308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not good. Our Saviour then forgave him; and at his comming againe in
 20309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGlory, will remember to raise him againe to Life Eternall.
 20310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Eight is Acts 2. 24. where St. Peter saith of Christ, "that God
 20312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad raised him up, and loosed the Paines of Death, because it was not
 20313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossible he should be holden of it;" Which hee interprets to bee a
 20314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdescent of Christ into Purgatory, to loose some Soules there from their
 20315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttorments; whereas it is manifest, that it was Christ that was loosed;
 20316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit was hee that could not bee holden of Death, or the Grave; and not the
 20317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSouls in Purgatory. But if that which Beza sayes in his notes on this
 20318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace be well observed, there is none that will not see, that in stead
 20319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Paynes, it should be Bands; and then there is no further cause to
 20320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseek for Purgatory in this Text.
 20321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XLV. OF DAEMONOLOGY, AND OTHER RELIQUES OF THE RELIGION OF THE
 20325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGENTILES
 20326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Originall Of Daemonology
 20331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe impression made on the organs of Sight, by lucide Bodies, either in
 20333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone direct line, or in many lines, reflected from Opaque, or refracted
 20334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the passage through Diaphanous Bodies, produceth in living Creatures,
 20335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin whom God hath placed such Organs, an Imagination of the Object, from
 20336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhence the Impression proceedeth; which Imagination is called Sight; and
 20337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseemeth not to bee a meer Imagination, but the Body it selfe without
 20338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tus; in the same manner, as when a man violently presseth his eye, there
 20339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappears to him a light without, and before him, which no man perceiveth
 20340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut himselfe; because there is indeed no such thing without him, but
 20341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely a motion in the interiour organs, pressing by resistance
 20342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toutward, that makes him think so. And the motion made by this pressure,
 20343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontinuing after the object which caused it is removed, is that we call
 20344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImagination, and Memory, and (in sleep, and sometimes in great distemper
 20345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the organs by Sicknesse, or Violence) a Dream: of which things I have
 20346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready spoken briefly, in the second and third Chapters.
 20347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis nature of Sight having never been discovered by the ancient
 20349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretenders to Naturall Knowledge; much lesse by those that consider not
 20350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings so remote (as that Knowledge is) from their present use; it was
 20351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thard for men to conceive of those Images in the Fancy, and in the Sense,
 20352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\totherwise, than of things really without us: Which some (because they
 20353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvanish away, they know not whither, nor how,) will have to be absolutely
 20354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIncorporeall, that is to say Immateriall, of Formes without Matter;
 20355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tColour and Figure, without any coloured or figured Body; and that they
 20356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan put on Aiery bodies (as a garment) to make them Visible when
 20357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey will to our bodily Eyes; and others say, are Bodies, and living
 20358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCreatures, but made of Air, or other more subtile and aethereall Matter,
 20359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is, then, when they will be seen, condensed. But Both of them
 20360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagree on one generall appellation of them, DAEMONS. As if the Dead of
 20361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom they Dreamed, were not Inhabitants of their own Brain, but of the
 20362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAir, or of Heaven, or Hell; not Phantasmes, but Ghosts; with just
 20363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas much reason, as if one should say, he saw his own Ghost in a
 20364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLooking-Glasse, or the Ghosts of the Stars in a River; or call the
 20365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tordinary apparition of the Sun, of the quantity of about a foot, the
 20366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDaemon, or Ghost of that great Sun that enlighteneth the whole visible
 20367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld: And by that means have feared them, as things of an unknown, that
 20368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, of an unlimited power to doe them good, or harme; and consequently,
 20369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiven occasion to the Governours of the Heathen Common-wealths to
 20370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tregulate this their fear, by establishing that DAEMONOLOGY (in which
 20371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Poets, as Principal Priests of the Heathen Religion, were specially
 20372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\temployed, or reverenced) to the Publique Peace, and to the Obedience of
 20373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubjects necessary thereunto; and to make some of them Good Daemons,
 20374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand others Evill; the one as a Spurre to the Observance, the other, as
 20375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReines to withhold them from Violation of the Laws.
 20376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat Were The Daemons Of The Ancients
 20381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat kind of things they were, to whom they attributed the name of
 20383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDaemons, appeareth partly in the Genealogie of their Gods, written by
 20384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHesiod, one of the most ancient Poets of the Graecians; and partly in
 20385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Histories; of which I have observed some few before, in the 12.
 20386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChapter of this discourse.
 20387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
