 20389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHow That Doctrine Was Spread
 20392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Graecians, by their Colonies and Conquests, communicated their
 20394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLanguage and Writings into Asia, Egypt, and Italy; and therein, by
 20395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessary consequence their Daemonology, or (as St. Paul calles it)
 20396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"their Doctrines of Devils;" And by that meanes, the contagion was
 20397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tderived also to the Jewes, both of Judaea, and Alexandria, and other
 20398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tparts, whereinto they were dispersed. But the name of Daemon they did
 20399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot (as the Graecians) attribute to Spirits both Good, and Evill; but
 20400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Evill onely: And to the Good Daemons they gave the name of the
 20401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit of God; and esteemed those into whose bodies they entred to be
 20402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets. In summe, all singularity if Good, they attributed to the
 20403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit of God; and if Evill, to some Daemon, but a kakodaimen, an Evill
 20404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDaemon, that is, a Devill. And therefore, they called Daemoniaques, that
 20405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis, possessed by the Devill, such as we call Madmen or Lunatiques; or
 20406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch as had the Falling Sicknesse; or that spoke any thing, which they
 20407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor want of understanding, thought absurd: As also of an Unclean person
 20408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin a notorious degree, they used to say he had an Unclean Spirit; of a
 20409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDumbe man, that he had a Dumbe Devill; and of John Baptist (Math. 11.
 20410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t18.) for the singularity of his fasting, that he had a Devill; and of
 20411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour, because he said, hee that keepeth his sayings should not
 20412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsee Death In Aeternum, (John 8. 52.) "Now we know thou hast a Devill;
 20413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbraham is dead, and the Prophets are dead:" And again, because he said
 20414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(John 7. 20.) "They went about to kill him," the people answered, "Thou
 20415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thast a Devill, who goeth about to kill thee?" Whereby it is manifest,
 20416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat the Jewes had the same opinions concerning Phantasmes, namely, that
 20417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey were not Phantasmes that is, Idols of the braine, but things reall,
 20418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand independent on the Fancy.
 20419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhy Our Saviour Controlled It Not
 20424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhich doctrine if it be not true, why (may some say) did not our Saviour
 20426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontradict it, and teach the Contrary? nay why does he use on diverse
 20427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toccasions, such forms of speech as seem to confirm it? To this I answer,
 20428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat first, where Christ saith, "A Spirit hath not flesh and bone,"
 20429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough hee shew that there be Spirits, yet he denies not that they are
 20430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBodies: And where St. Paul sais, "We shall rise Spirituall Bodies," he
 20431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledgeth the nature of Spirits, but that they are Bodily Spirits;
 20432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is not difficult to understand. For Air and many other things
 20433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Bodies, though not Flesh and Bone, or any other grosse body, to bee
 20434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdiscerned by the eye. But when our Saviour speaketh to the Devill, and
 20435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommandeth him to go out of a man, if by the Devill, be meant a Disease,
 20436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas Phrenesy, or Lunacy, or a corporeal Spirit, is not the speech
 20437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timproper? can Diseases heare? or can there be a corporeall Spirit in a
 20438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBody of Flesh and Bone, full already of vitall and animall Spirits?
 20439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAre there not therefore Spirits, that neither have Bodies, nor are meer
 20440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImaginations? To the first I answer, that the addressing of our Saviours
 20441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommand to the Madnesse, or Lunacy he cureth, is no more improper, then
 20442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas his rebuking of the Fever, or of the Wind, and Sea; for neither
 20443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo these hear: Or than was the command of God, to the Light, to the
 20444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFirmament, to the Sunne, and Starres, when he commanded them to bee; for
 20445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey could not heare before they had a beeing. But those speeches are
 20446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot improper, because they signifie the power of Gods Word: no more
 20447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore is it improper, to command Madnesse, or Lunacy (under the
 20448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappellation of Devils, by which they were then commonly understood,)
 20449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto depart out of a mans body. To the second, concerning their being
 20450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIncorporeall, I have not yet observed any place of Scripture, from
 20451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhence it can be gathered, that any man was ever possessed with any
 20452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Corporeal Spirit, but that of his owne, by which his body is
 20453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturally moved.
 20454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Scriptures Doe Not Teach That Spirits Are Incorporeall
 20459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOur Saviour, immediately after the Holy Ghost descended upon him in the
 20461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tform of a Dove, is said by St. Matthew (Chapt. 4. 1.) to have been "led
 20462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tup by the Spirit into the Wildernesse;" and the same is recited (Luke 4.
 20463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t1.) in these words, "Jesus being full of the Holy Ghost, was led in
 20464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Spirit into the Wildernesse;" Whereby it is evident, that by
 20465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirit there, is meant the Holy Ghost. This cannot be interpreted for
 20466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Possession: For Christ, and the Holy Ghost, are but one and the same
 20467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubstance; which is no possession of one substance, or body, by another.
 20468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whereas in the verses following, he is said "to have been taken
 20469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tup by the Devill into the Holy City, and set upon a pinnacle of the
 20470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTemple," shall we conclude thence that hee was possessed of the Devill,
 20471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor carryed thither by violence? And again, "carryed thence by the Devill
 20472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto an exceeding high mountain, who shewed him them thence all the
 20473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdomes of the world:" herein, wee are not to beleeve he was either
 20474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpossessed, or forced by the Devill; nor that any Mountaine is high
 20475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenough, (according to the literall sense,) to shew him one whole
 20476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHemisphere. What then can be the meaning of this place, other than that
 20477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the went of himself into the Wildernesse; and that this carrying of him
 20478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tup and down, from the Wildernesse to the City, and from thence into a
 20479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMountain, was a Vision? Conformable whereunto, is also the phrase of St.
 20480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLuke, that hee was led into the Wildernesse, not By, but In the Spirit:
 20481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereas concerning His being Taken up into the Mountaine, and unto the
 20482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPinnacle of the Temple, hee speaketh as St. Matthew doth. Which suiteth
 20483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith the nature of a Vision.
 20484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, where St. Luke sayes of Judas Iscariot, that "Satan entred into
 20486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, and thereupon that he went and communed with the Chief Priests, and
 20487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCaptaines, how he might betray Christ unto them:" it may be answered,
 20488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat by the Entring of Satan (that is the Enemy) into him, is meant, the
 20489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thostile and traiterous intention of selling his Lord and Master. For as
 20490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Holy Ghost, is frequently in Scripture understood, the Graces and
 20491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood Inclinations given by the Holy Ghost; so by the Entring of
 20492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSatan, may bee understood the wicked Cogitations, and Designes of the
 20493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAdversaries of Christ, and his Disciples. For as it is hard to say,
 20494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat the Devill was entred into Judas, before he had any such hostile
 20495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesigne; so it is impertinent to say, he was first Christs Enemy in his
 20496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theart, and that the Devill entred into him afterwards. Therefore the
 20497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEntring of Satan, and his Wicked Purpose, was one and the same thing.
 20498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut if there be no Immateriall Spirit, nor any Possession of mens bodies
 20500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby any Spirit Corporeall, it may again be asked, why our Saviour and his
 20501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles did not teach the People so; and in such cleer words, as they
 20502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmight no more doubt thereof. But such questions as these, are more
 20503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcurious, than necessary for a Christian mans Salvation. Men may as well
 20504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taske, why Christ that could have given to all men Faith, Piety, and all
 20505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner of morall Vertues, gave it to some onely, and not to all: and
 20506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhy he left the search of naturall Causes, and Sciences, to the naturall
 20507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason and Industry of men, and did not reveal it to all, or any man
 20508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturally; and many other such questions: Of which neverthelesse
 20509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere may be alledged probable and pious reasons. For as God, when he
 20510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbrought the Israelites into the Land of Promise, did not secure them
 20511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherein, by subduing all the Nations round about them; but left many of
 20512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, as thornes in their sides, to awaken from time to time their
 20513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPiety and Industry: so our Saviour, in conducting us toward his heavenly
 20514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKingdome, did not destroy all the difficulties of Naturall Questions;
 20515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut left them to exercise our Industry, and Reason; the Scope of
 20516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this preaching, being onely to shew us this plain and direct way to
 20517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSalvation, namely, the beleef of this Article, "that he was the Christ,
 20518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Son of the living God, sent into the world to sacrifice himselfe for
 20519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Sins, and at his comming again, gloriously to reign over his Elect,
 20520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand to save them from their Enemies eternally:" To which, the opinion
 20521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Possession by Spirits, or Phantasmes, are no impediment in the way;
 20522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough it be to some an occasion of going out of the way, and to follow
 20523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir own Inventions. If wee require of the Scripture an account of all
 20524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tquestions, which may be raised to trouble us in the performance of Gods
 20525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommands; we may as well complaine of Moses for not having set downe the
 20526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime of the creation of such Spirits, as well as of the Creation of the
 20527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarth, and Sea, and of Men, and Beasts. To conclude, I find in Scripture
 20528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat there be Angels, and Spirits, good and evill; but not that they are
 20529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIncorporeall, as are the Apparitions men see in the Dark, or in a Dream,
 20530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Vision; which the Latines call Spectra, and took for Daemons. And I
 20531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfind that there are Spirits Corporeal, (though subtile and Invisible;)
 20532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut not that any mans body was possessed, or inhabited by them; And that
 20533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Bodies of the Saints shall be such, namely, Spirituall Bodies, as
 20534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSt. Paul calls them.
 20535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Power Of Casting Out Devills, Not The Same It Was In The Primitive
 20540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch
 20542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse, the contrary Doctrine, namely, that there be Incorporeall
 20544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirits, hath hitherto so prevailed in the Church, that the use of
 20545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExorcisme, (that is to say, of ejection of Devills by Conjuration) is
 20546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereupon built; and (though rarely and faintly practised) is not yet
 20547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttotally given over. That there were many Daemoniaques in the Primitive
 20548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, and few Mad-men, and other such singular diseases; whereas in
 20549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese times we hear of, and see many Mad-men, and few Daemoniaques,
 20550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceeds not from the change of Nature; but of Names. But how it comes
 20551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto passe, that whereas heretofore the Apostles, and after them for a
 20552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, the Pastors of the Church, did cure those singular Diseases, which
 20553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnow they are not seen to doe; as likewise, why it is not in the power of
 20554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery true Beleever now, to doe all that the Faithfull did then, that is
 20555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, as we read (Mark 16. 17.) "In Christs name to cast out Devills,
 20556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto speak with new Tongues, to take up Serpents, to drink deadly Poison
 20557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout harm taking, and to cure the Sick by the laying on of their
 20558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thands," and all this without other words, but "in the Name of Jesus,"
 20559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis another question. And it is probable, that those extraordinary gifts
 20560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere given to the Church, for no longer a time, than men trusted wholly
 20561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Christ, and looked for their felicity onely in his Kingdome to come;
 20562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand consequently, that when they sought Authority, and Riches, and
 20563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrusted to their own Subtilty for a Kingdome of this world, these
 20564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall gifts of God were again taken from them.
 20565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother Relique Of Gentilisme, Worshipping Images, Left In The Church
 20570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNot Brought Into It
 20572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnother relique of Gentilisme, is the Worship of Images, neither
 20574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinstituted by Moses in the Old, nor by Christ in the New Testament; nor
 20575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet brought in from the Gentiles; but left amongst them, after they had
 20576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiven their names to Christ. Before our Saviour preached, it was the
 20577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgenerall Religion of the Gentiles, to worship for Gods, those Apparences
 20578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat remain in the Brain from the impression of externall Bodies upon
 20579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe organs of their Senses, which are commonly called Ideas, Idols,
 20580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhantasmes, Conceits, as being Representations of those externall
 20581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBodies, which cause them, and have nothing in them of reality, no more
 20582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan there is in the things that seem to stand before us in a Dream:
 20583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd this is the reason why St. Paul says, "Wee know that an Idol is
 20584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNothing:" Not that he thought that an Image of Metall, Stone, or Wood,
 20585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas nothing; but that the thing which they honored, or feared in
 20586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Image, and held for a God, was a meer Figment, without place,
 20587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thabitation, motion, or existence, but in the motions of the Brain.
 20588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd the worship of these with Divine Honour, is that which is in the
 20589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture called Idolatry, and Rebellion against God. For God being King
 20590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Jews, and his Lieutenant being first Moses, and afterward the
 20591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHigh Priest; if the people had been permitted to worship, and pray to
 20592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImages, (which are Representations of their own Fancies,) they had
 20593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad no farther dependence on the true God, of whom there can be no
 20594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsimilitude; nor on his prime Ministers, Moses, and the High Priests;
 20595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut every man had governed himself according to his own appetite, to the
 20596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tutter eversion of the Common-wealth, and their own destruction for want
 20597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Union. And therefore the first Law of God was, "They should not take
 20598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor Gods, ALIENOS DEOS, that is, the Gods of other nations, but that
 20599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely true God, who vouchsafed to commune with Moses, and by him to give
 20600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem laws and directions, for their peace, and for their salvation
 20601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom their enemies." And the second was, that "they should not make to
 20602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves any Image to Worship, of their own Invention." For it is the
 20603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame deposing of a King, to submit to another King, whether he be set up
 20604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby a neighbour nation, or by our selves.
 20605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnswer To Certain Seeming Texts For Images
 20610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe places of Scripture pretended to countenance the setting up of
 20612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImages, to worship them; or to set them up at all in the places where
 20613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod is worshipped, are First, two Examples; one of the Cherubins over
 20614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Ark of God; the other of the Brazen Serpent: Secondly, some texts
 20615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereby we are commanded to worship certain Creatures for their relation
 20616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto God; as to worship his Footstool: And lastly, some other texts, by
 20617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich is authorized, a religious honoring of Holy things. But before I
 20618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texamine the force of those places, to prove that which is pretended, I
 20619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmust first explain what is to be understood by Worshipping, and what by
 20620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImages, and Idols.
 20621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat Is Worship
 20626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI have already shewn in the 20 Chapter of this Discourse, that to Honor,
 20628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to value highly the Power of any person: and that such value is
 20629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeasured, by our comparing him with others. But because there is nothing
 20630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be compared with God in Power; we Honor him not but Dishonour him
 20631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby any Value lesse than Infinite. And thus Honor is properly of its own
 20632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnature, secret, and internall in the heart. But the inward thoughts of
 20633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, which appeare outwardly in their words and actions, are the signes
 20634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof our Honoring, and these goe by the name of WORSHIP, in Latine,
 20635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCULTUS. Therefore, to Pray to, to Swear by, to Obey, to bee Diligent,
 20636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Officious in Serving: in summe, all words and actions that betoken
 20637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFear to Offend, or Desire to Please, is Worship, whether those words
 20638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand actions be sincere, or feigned: and because they appear as signes of
 20639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHonoring, are ordinarily also called Honor.
 20640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDistinction Between Divine And Civill Worship
 20645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Worship we exhibite to those we esteem to be but men, as to Kings,
 20647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand men in Authority, is Civill Worship: But the worship we exhibite
 20648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto that which we think to bee God, whatsoever the words, ceremonies,
 20649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgestures, or other actions be, is Divine Worship. To fall prostrate
 20650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore a King, in him that thinks him but a Man, is but Civill Worship:
 20651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd he that but putteth off his hat in the Church, for this cause, that
 20652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the thinketh it the House of God, worshippeth with Divine Worship. They
 20653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat seek the distinction of Divine and Civill Worship, not in the
 20654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tintention of the Worshipper, but in the Words douleia, and latreia,
 20655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeceive themselves. For whereas there be two sorts of Servants; that
 20656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsort, which is of those that are absolutely in the power of their
 20657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMasters, as Slaves taken in war, and their Issue, whose bodies are not
 20658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin their own power, (their lives depending on the Will of their Masters,
 20659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin such manner as to forfeit them upon the least disobedience,) and that
 20660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare bought and sold as Beasts, were called Douloi, that is properly,
 20661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSlaves, and their Service, Douleia: The other, which is of those that
 20662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tserve (for hire, or in hope of benefit from their Masters) voluntarily;
 20663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare called Thetes; that is, Domestique Servants; to whose service the
 20664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMasters have no further right, than is contained in the Covenants made
 20665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetwixt them. These two kinds of Servants have thus much common to them
 20666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth, that their labour is appointed them by another, whether, as a
 20667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSlave, or a voluntary Servant: And the word Latris, is the general name
 20668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof both, signifying him that worketh for another, whether, as a Slave,
 20669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor a voluntary Servant: So that Latreia signifieth generally all
 20670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tService; but Douleia the service of Bondmen onely, and the condition of
 20671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSlavery: And both are used in Scripture (to signifie our Service of God)
 20672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpromiscuously. Douleia, because we are Gods Slaves; Latreia, because
 20673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twee Serve him: and in all kinds of Service is contained, not onely
 20674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tObedience, but also Worship, that is, such actions, gestures, and words,
 20675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas signifie Honor.
 20676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAn Image What Phantasmes
 20681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAn IMAGE (in the most strict signification of the word) is the
 20683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResemblance of some thing visible: In which sense the Phantasticall
 20684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFormes, Apparitions, or Seemings of Visible Bodies to the Sight, are
 20685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely Images; such as are the Shew of a man, or other thing in the
 20686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWater, by Reflexion, or Refraction; or of the Sun, or Stars by Direct
 20687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVision in the Air; which are nothing reall in the things seen, nor in
 20688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe place where thy seem to bee; nor are their magnitudes and figures
 20689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same with that of the object; but changeable, by the variation of
 20690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe organs of Sight, or by glasses; and are present oftentimes in our
 20691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImagination, and in our Dreams, when the object is absent; or changed
 20692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto other colours, and shapes, as things that depend onely upon the
 20693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFancy. And these are the Images which are originally and most properly
 20694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Ideas, and IDOLS, and derived from the language of the Graecians,
 20695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith whom the word Eido signifieth to See. They are also called
 20696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPHANTASMES, which is in the same language, Apparitions. And from these
 20697	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImages it is that one of the faculties of mans Nature, is called the
 20698	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImagination. And from hence it is manifest, that there neither is, nor
 20699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan bee any Image made of a thing Invisible.
 20700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is also evident, that there can be no Image of a thing Infinite: for
 20702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall the Images, and Phantasmes that are made by the Impression of things
 20703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvisible, are figured: but Figure is a quantity every way determined: And
 20704	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore there can bee no Image of God: nor of the Soule of Man; nor of
 20705	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirits, but onely of Bodies Visible, that is, Bodies that have light in
 20706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, or are by such enlightened.
 20707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFictions; Materiall Images
 20712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whereas a man can fancy Shapes he never saw; making up a Figure out
 20714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the parts of divers creatures; as the Poets make their Centaures,
 20715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChimaeras, and other Monsters never seen: So can he also give Matter to
 20716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Shapes, and make them in Wood, Clay or Metall. And these are also
 20717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Images, not for the resemblance of any corporeall thing, but for
 20718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe resemblance of some Phantasticall Inhabitants of the Brain of the
 20719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMaker. But in these Idols, as they are originally in the Brain, and
 20720	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they are painted, carved, moulded, or moulten in matter, there is a
 20721	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsimilitude of the one to the other, for which the Materiall Body made
 20722	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Art, may be said to be the Image of the Phantasticall Idoll made by
 20723	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNature.
 20724	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20725	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut in a larger use of the word Image, is contained also, any
 20726	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentation of one thing by another. So an earthly Soveraign may be
 20727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled the Image of God: And an inferiour Magistrate the Image of an
 20728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tearthly Soveraign. And many times in the Idolatry of the Gentiles there
 20729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas little regard to the similitude of their Materiall Idoll to the
 20730	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIdol in their fancy, and yet it was called the Image of it. For a
 20731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tStone unhewn has been set up for Neptune, and divers other shapes far
 20732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifferent from the shapes they conceived of their Gods. And at this
 20733	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tday we see many Images of the Virgin Mary, and other Saints, unlike one
 20734	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, and without correspondence to any one mans Fancy; and yet serve
 20735	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twell enough for the purpose they were erected for; which was no more but
 20736	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby the Names onely, to represent the Persons mentioned in the History;
 20737	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto which every man applyeth a Mentall Image of his owne making, or
 20738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnone at all. And thus an Image in the largest sense, is either the
 20739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tResemblance, or the Representation of some thing Visible; or both
 20740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttogether, as it happeneth for the most part.
 20741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the name of Idoll is extended yet further in Scripture, to
 20743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifie also the Sunne, or a Starre, or any other Creature, visible or
 20744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinvisible, when they are worshipped for Gods.
 20745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIdolatry What
 20750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHaving shewn what is Worship, and what an Image; I will now put them
 20752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttogether, and examine what that IDOLATRY is, which is forbidden in the
 20753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSecond Commandement, and other places of the Scripture.
 20754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo worship an Image, is voluntarily to doe those externall acts, which
 20756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare signes of honoring either the matter of the Image, which is Wood,
 20757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tStone, or Metall, or some other visible creature; or the Phantasme of
 20758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe brain, for the resemblance, or representation whereof, the matter
 20759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas formed and figured; or both together, as one animate Body, composed
 20760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Matter and the Phantasme, as of a Body and Soule.
 20761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo be uncovered, before a man of Power and Authority, or before the
 20763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThrone of a Prince, or in such other places as hee ordaineth to that
 20764	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpurpose in his absence, is to Worship that man, or Prince with Civill
 20765	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship; as being a signe, not of honoring the stoole, or place, but the
 20766	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPerson; and is not Idolatry. But if hee that doth it, should suppose the
 20767	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoule of the Prince to be in the Stool, or should present a Petition to
 20768	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Stool, it were Divine Worship, and Idolatry.
 20769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo pray to a King for such things, as hee is able to doe for us, though
 20771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe prostrate our selves before him, is but Civill Worship; because we
 20772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledge no other power in him, but humane: But voluntarily to pray
 20773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunto him for fair weather, or for any thing which God onely can doe
 20774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor us, is Divine Worship, and Idolatry. On the other side, if a King
 20775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcompell a man to it by the terrour of Death, or other great corporall
 20776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunishment, it is not Idolatry: For the Worship which the Soveraign
 20777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommandeth to bee done unto himself by the terrour of his Laws, is not
 20778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta sign that he that obeyeth him, does inwardly honour him as a God, but
 20779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat he is desirous to save himselfe from death, or from a miserable
 20780	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlife; and that which is not a sign of internall honor, is no Worship;
 20781	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand therefore no Idolatry. Neither can it bee said, that hee that does
 20782	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, scandalizeth, or layeth any stumbling block before his Brother;
 20783	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause how wise, or learned soever he be that worshippeth in that
 20784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner, another man cannot from thence argue, that he approveth it; but
 20785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat he doth it for fear; and that it is not his act, but the act of the
 20786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign.
 20787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo worship God, in some peculiar Place, or turning a mans face towards
 20789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Image, or determinate Place, is not to worship, or honor the Place,
 20790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Image; but to acknowledge it Holy, that is to say, to acknowledge
 20791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Image, or the Place to be set apart from common use: for that is the
 20792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeaning of the word Holy; which implies no new quality in the Place, or
 20793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImage; but onely a new Relation by Appropriation to God; and therefore
 20794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not Idolatry; no more than it was Idolatry to worship God before
 20795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Brazen Serpent; or for the Jews when they were out of their owne
 20796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcountrey, to turn their faces (when they prayed) toward the Temple of
 20797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJerusalem; or for Moses to put off his Shoes when he was before the
 20798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFlaming Bush, the ground appertaining to Mount Sinai; which place God
 20799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad chosen to appear in, and to give his Laws to the People of Israel,
 20800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand was therefore Holy ground, not by inhaerent sanctity, but by
 20801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseparation to Gods use; or for Christians to worship in the Churches,
 20802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich are once solemnly dedicated to God for that purpose, by the
 20803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority of the King, or other true Representant of the Church. But to
 20804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworship God, is inanimating, or inhibiting, such Image, or place; that
 20805	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, an infinite substance in a finite place, is Idolatry: for
 20806	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch finite Gods, are but Idols of the brain, nothing reall; and are
 20807	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommonly called in the Scripture by the names of Vanity, and Lyes, and
 20808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNothing. Also to worship God, not as inanimating, or present in the
 20809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplace, or Image; but to the end to be put in mind of him, or of some
 20810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworks of his, in case the Place, or Image be dedicated, or set up
 20811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby private authority, and not by the authority of them that are our
 20812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign Pastors, is Idolatry. For the Commandement is, "Thou shalt not
 20813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake to thy selfe any graven image." God commanded Moses to set up the
 20814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBrazen Serpent; hee did not make it to himselfe; it was not therefore
 20815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the Commandement. But the making of the Golden Calfe by Aaron,
 20816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the People, as being done without authority from God, was Idolatry;
 20817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot onely because they held it for God, but also because they made it
 20818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor a Religious use, without warrant either from God their Soveraign, or
 20819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom Moses, that was his Lieutenant.
 20820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Gentiles worshipped for Gods, Jupiter, and others; that living, were
 20822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen perhaps that had done great and glorious Acts; and for the Children
 20823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God, divers men and women, supposing them gotten between an Immortall
 20824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeity, and a mortall man. This was Idolatry, because they made them so
 20825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto themselves, having no authority from God, neither in his eternall Law
 20826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Reason, nor in his positive and revealed Will. But though our Saviour
 20827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas a man, whom wee also beleeve to bee God Immortall, and the Son of
 20828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod; yet this is no Idolatry; because wee build not that beleef upon
 20829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour own fancy, or judgment, but upon the Word of God revealed in the
 20830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScriptures. And for the adoration of the Eucharist, if the words of
 20831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, "This is my Body," signifie, "that he himselfe, and the seeming
 20832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbread in his hand; and not onely so, but that all the seeming morsells
 20833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof bread that have ever since been, and any time hereafter shall bee
 20834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsecrated by Priests, bee so many Christs bodies, and yet all of them
 20835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut one body," then is that no Idolatry, because it is authorized by our
 20836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSaviour: but if that text doe not signifie that, (for there is no other
 20837	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat can be alledged for it,) then, because it is a worship of humane
 20838	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinstitution, it is Idolatry. For it is not enough to say, God can
 20839	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttransubstantiate the Bread into Christs Body: For the Gentiles also held
 20840	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod to be Omnipotent; and might upon that ground no lesse excuse their
 20841	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIdolatry, by pretending, as well as others, as transubstantiation of
 20842	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Wood, and Stone into God Almighty.
 20843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhereas there be, that pretend Divine Inspiration, to be a supernaturall
 20845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tentring of the Holy Ghost into a man, and not an acquisition of Gods
 20846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrace, by doctrine, and study; I think they are in a very dangerous
 20847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDilemma. For if they worship not the men whom they beleeve to be so
 20848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinspired, they fall into Impiety; as not adoring Gods supernaturall
 20849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresence. And again, if they worship them, they commit Idolatry; for the
 20850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tApostles would never permit themselves to be so worshipped. Therefore
 20851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe safest way is to beleeve, that by the Descending of the Dove upon
 20852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Apostles; and by Christs Breathing on them, when hee gave them
 20853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Holy Ghost; and by the giving of it by Imposition of Hands, are
 20854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood the signes which God hath been pleased to use, or ordain to
 20855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe used, of his promise to assist those persons in their study to
 20856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPreach his Kingdome, and in their Conversation, that it might not be
 20857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScandalous, but Edifying to others.
 20858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20859	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20860	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScandalous Worship Of Images
 20863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBesides the Idolatrous Worship of Images, there is also a Scandalous
 20865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship of them; which is also a sin; but not Idolatry. For Idolatry is
 20866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto worship by signes of an internall, and reall honour: but Scandalous
 20867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship, is but Seeming Worship; and may sometimes bee joined with
 20868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan inward, and hearty detestation, both of the Image, and of the
 20869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhantasticall Daemon, or Idol, to which it is dedicated; and proceed
 20870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely from the fear of death, or other grievous punishment; and is
 20871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneverthelesse a sin in them that so worship, in case they be men whose
 20872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions are looked at by others, as lights to guide them by; because
 20873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfollowing their ways, they cannot but stumble, and fall in the way of
 20874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion: Whereas the example of those we regard not, works not on us
 20875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat all, but leaves us to our own diligence and caution; and consequently
 20876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare no causes of our falling.
 20877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf therefore a Pastor lawfully called to teach and direct others, or any
 20879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother, of whose knowledge there is a great opinion, doe externall honor
 20880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto an Idol for fear; unlesse he make his feare, and unwillingnesse to
 20881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, as evident as the worship; he Scandalizeth his Brother, by seeming
 20882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto approve Idolatry. For his Brother, arguing from the action of his
 20883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tteacher, or of him whose knowledge he esteemeth great, concludes it
 20884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto bee lawfull in it selfe. And this Scandall, is Sin, and a Scandall
 20885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiven. But if one being no Pastor, nor of eminent reputation for
 20886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknowledge in Christian Doctrine, doe the same, and another follow him;
 20887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis is no Scandall given; for he had no cause to follow such example:
 20888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut is a pretence of Scandall which hee taketh of himselfe for an excuse
 20889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore men: For an unlearned man, that is in the power of an idolatrous
 20890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing, or State, if commanded on pain of death to worship before an
 20891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIdoll, hee detesteth the Idoll in his heart, hee doth well; though if he
 20892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad the fortitude to suffer death, rather than worship it, he should
 20893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoe better. But if a Pastor, who as Christs Messenger, has undertaken to
 20894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tteach Christs Doctrine to all nations, should doe the same, it were
 20895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot onely a sinfull Scandall, in respect of other Christian mens
 20896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsciences, but a perfidious forsaking of his charge.
 20897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe summe of that which I have said hitherto, concerning the Worship of
 20899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImages, is that, that he that worshippeth in an Image, or any Creature,
 20900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teither the Matter thereof, or any Fancy of his own, which he thinketh
 20901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto dwell in it; or both together; or beleeveth that such things hear
 20902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Prayers, or see his Devotions, without Ears, or Eyes, committeth
 20903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIdolatry: and he that counterfeiteth such Worship for fear of
 20904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunishment, if he bee a man whose example hath power amongst his
 20905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBrethren, committeth a sin: But he that worshippeth the Creator of the
 20906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworld before such an Image, or in such a place as he hath not made, or
 20907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchosen of himselfe, but taken from the commandement of Gods Word, as the
 20908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJewes did in worshipping God before the Cherubins, and before the Brazen
 20909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSerpent for a time, and in, or towards the Temple of Jerusalem, which
 20910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas also but for a time, committeth not Idolatry.
 20911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNow for the Worship of Saints, and Images, and Reliques, and other
 20913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthings at this day practised in the Church of Rome, I say they are not
 20914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tallowed by the Word of God, not brought into the Church of Rome, from
 20915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Doctrine there taught; but partly left in it at the first conversion
 20916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Gentiles; and afterwards countenanced, and confirmed, and
 20917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taugmented by the Bishops of Rome.
 20918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnswer To The Argument From The Cherubins, And Brazen Serpent
 20923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs for the proofs alledged out of Scripture, namely, those examples
 20925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Images appointed by God to bee set up; They were not set up for the
 20926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople, or any man to worship; but that they should worship God himselfe
 20927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore them: as before the Cherubins over the Ark, and the Brazen
 20928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSerpent. For we read not, that the Priest, or any other did worship the
 20929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCherubins; but contrarily wee read (2 Kings 18.4.) that Hezekiah brake
 20930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin pieces the Brazen Serpent which Moses had set up, because the
 20931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeople burnt incense to it. Besides, those examples are not put for
 20932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Imitation, that we also should set up Images, under pretence
 20933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof worshipping God before them; because the words of the second
 20934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandement, "Thou shalt not make to thy selfe any graven Image, &c."
 20935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdistinguish between the Images that God commanded to be set up, and
 20936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose which wee set up to our selves. And therefore from the Cherubins,
 20937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Brazen Serpent, to the Images of mans devising; and from the Worship
 20938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommanded by God, to the Will-Worship of men, the argument is not good.
 20939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThis also is to bee considered, that as Hezekiah brake in pieces the
 20940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBrazen Serpent, because the Jews did worship it, to the end they should
 20941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoe so no more; so also Christian Soveraigns ought to break down the
 20942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImages which their Subjects have been accustomed to worship; that there
 20943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe no more occasion of such Idolatry. For at this day, the ignorant
 20944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeople, where Images are worshipped, doe really beleeve there is a
 20945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDivine Power in the Images; and are told by their Pastors, that some
 20946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them have spoken; and have bled; and that miracles have been done by
 20947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem; which they apprehend as done by the Saint, which they think either
 20948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the Image it self, or in it. The Israelites, when they worshipped the
 20949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCalfe, did think they worshipped the God that brought them out of Egypt;
 20950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand yet it was Idolatry, because they thought the Calfe either was
 20951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat God, or had him in his belly. And though some man may think it
 20952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpossible for people to be so stupid, as to think the Image to be
 20953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod, or a Saint; or to worship it in that notion; yet it is manifest
 20954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Scripture to the contrary; where when the Golden Calfe was made, the
 20955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople said, (Exod. 32. 2.) "These are thy Gods O Israel;" and where the
 20956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImages of Laban (Gen. 31.30.) are called his Gods. And wee see daily by
 20957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texperience in all sorts of People, that such men as study nothing but
 20958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir food and ease, are content to beleeve any absurdity, rather than
 20959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto trouble themselves to examine it; holding their faith as it were by
 20960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tentaile unalienable, except by an expresse and new Law.
 20961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPainting Of Fancies No Idolatry: Abusing Them To Religious Worship Is
 20966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut they inferre from some other places, that it is lawfull to paint
 20968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAngels, and also God himselfe: as from Gods walking in the Garden; from
 20969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJacobs seeing God at the top of the ladder; and from other Visions, and
 20970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDreams. But Visions, and Dreams whether naturall, or supernaturall, are
 20971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut Phantasmes: and he that painteth an Image of any of them, maketh not
 20972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan Image of God, but of his own Phantasm, which is, making of an Idol. I
 20973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay not, that to draw a Picture after a fancy, is a Sin; but when it
 20974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis drawn, to hold it for a Representation of God, is against the second
 20975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommandement; and can be of no use, but to worship. And the same may be
 20976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsaid of the Images of Angels, and of men dead; unlesse as Monuments of
 20977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfriends, or of men worthy remembrance: For such use of an Image, is not
 20978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship of the Image; but a civill honoring of the Person, not that is,
 20979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut that was: But when it is done to the Image which we make of a Saint,
 20980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor no other reason, but that we think he heareth our prayers, and is
 20981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpleased with the honour wee doe him, when dead, and without sense, wee
 20982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tattribute to him more than humane power; and therefore it is Idolatry.
 20983	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20984	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeeing therefore there is no authority, neither in the Law of Moses,
 20985	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor in the Gospel, for the religious Worship of Images, or other
 20986	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepresentations of God, which men set up to themselves; or for the
 20987	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship of the Image of any Creature in Heaven, or Earth, or under the
 20988	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEarth: And whereas Christian Kings, who are living Representants of God,
 20989	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not to be worshipped by their Subjects, by any act, that signifieth
 20990	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta greater esteem of his power, than the nature of mortall man is capable
 20991	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof; It cannot be imagined, that the Religious Worship now in use,
 20992	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas brought into the Church, by misunderstanding of the Scripture. It
 20993	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tresteth therefore, that it was left in it, by not destroying the Images
 20994	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, in the conversion of the Gentiles that worshipped them.
 20995	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 20999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHow Idolatry Was Left In The Church
 21000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe cause whereof, was the immoderate esteem, and prices set upon the
 21002	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworkmanship of them, which made the owners (though converted, from
 21003	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworshipping them as they had done Religiously for Daemons) to retain
 21004	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem still in their houses, upon pretence of doing it in the honor of
 21005	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChrist, of the Virgin Mary, and of the Apostles, and other the Pastors
 21006	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Primitive Church; as being easie, by giving them new names, to
 21007	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake that an Image of the Virgin Mary, and of her Sonne our Saviour,
 21008	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich before perhaps was called the Image of Venus, and Cupid; and so of
 21009	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Jupiter to make a Barnabas, and of Mercury a Paul, and the like. And
 21010	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas worldly ambition creeping by degrees into the Pastors, drew them to
 21011	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan endeavour of pleasing the new made Christians; and also to a liking
 21012	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof this kind of honour, which they also might hope for after their
 21013	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdecease, as well as those that had already gained it: so the worshipping
 21014	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Images of Christ and his Apostles, grow more and more Idolatrous;
 21015	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsave that somewhat after the time of Constantine, divers Emperors, and
 21016	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBishops, and generall Councells observed, and opposed the unlawfulnesse
 21017	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof; but too late, or too weakly.
 21018	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21019	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21020	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21021	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21022	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCanonizing Of Saints
 21023	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21024	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Canonizing of Saints, is another Relique of Gentilisme: It is
 21025	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneither a misunderstanding of Scripture, nor a new invention of the
 21026	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRoman Church, but a custome as ancient as the Common-wealth of Rome it
 21027	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tself. The first that ever was canonized at Rome, was Romulus, and that
 21028	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon the narration of Julius Proculus, that swore before the Senate,
 21029	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the spake with him after his death, and was assured by him, he dwelt in
 21030	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeaven, and was there called Quirinius, and would be propitious to
 21031	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe State of their new City: And thereupon the Senate gave Publique
 21032	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTestimony of his Sanctity. Julius Caesar, and other Emperors after him,
 21033	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad the like Testimony; that is, were Canonized for Saints; now defined;
 21034	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand is the same with the Apotheosis of the Heathen.
 21035	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21036	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21037	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21038	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21039	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Name Of Pontifex
 21040	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21041	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is also from the Roman Heathen, that the Popes have received the
 21042	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname, and power of PONTIFEX MAXIMUS. This was the name of him that in
 21043	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe ancient Common-wealth of Rome, had the Supreme Authority under
 21044	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Senate and People, of regulating all Ceremonies, and Doctrines
 21045	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning their Religion: And when Augustus Caesar changed the State
 21046	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto a Monarchy, he took to himselfe no more but this office, and that
 21047	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Tribune of the People, (than is to say, the Supreme Power both in
 21048	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tState, and Religion;) and the succeeding Emperors enjoyed the same. But
 21049	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen the Emperour Constantine lived, who was the first that professed
 21050	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand authorized Christian Religion, it was consonant to his profession,
 21051	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto cause Religion to be regulated (under his authority) by the Bishop
 21052	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Rome: Though it doe not appear they had so soon the name of Pontifex;
 21053	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut rather, that the succeeding Bishops took it of themselves, to
 21054	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcountenance the power they exercised over the Bishops of the Roman
 21055	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProvinces. For it is not any Priviledge of St. Peter, but the Priviledge
 21056	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the City of Rome, which the Emperors were alwaies willing to uphold;
 21057	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat gave them such authority over other Bishops; as may be evidently
 21058	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseen by that, that the Bishop of Constantinople, when the Emperour made
 21059	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat City the Seat of the Empire, pretended to bee equall to the Bishop
 21060	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Rome; though at last, not without contention, the Pope carryed it,
 21061	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand became the Pontifex Maximus; but in right onely of the Emperour; and
 21062	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot without the bounds of the Empire; nor any where, after the Emperour
 21063	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad lost his power in Rome; though it were the Pope himself that took
 21064	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this power from him. From whence wee may by the way observe, that there
 21065	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis no place for the superiority of the Pope over other Bishops, except
 21066	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the territories whereof he is himself the Civill Soveraign; and where
 21067	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Emperour having Soveraign Power Civill, hath expressely chosen the
 21068	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPope for the chief Pastor under himselfe, of his Christian Subjects.
 21069	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21070	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21071	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21072	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21073	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProcession Of Images
 21074	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21075	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe carrying about of Images in Procession, is another Relique of the
 21076	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReligion of the Greeks, and Romans: For they also carried their
 21077	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIdols from place to place, in a kind of Chariot, which was peculiarly
 21078	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdedicated to that use, which the Latines called Thensa, and Vehiculum
 21079	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDeorum; and the Image was placed in a frame, or Shrine, which they
 21080	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Ferculum: And that which they called Pompa, is the same that
 21081	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnow is named Procession: According whereunto, amongst the Divine Honors
 21082	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich were given to Julius Caesar by the Senate, this was one, that in
 21083	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Pompe (or Procession) at the Circaean games, he should have Thensam
 21084	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t& Ferculum, a sacred Chariot, and a Shrine; which was as much, as to be
 21085	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcarried up and down as a God: Just as at this day the Popes are carried
 21086	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Switzers under a Canopie.
 21087	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21088	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21089	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21090	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21091	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWax Candles, And Torches Lighted
 21092	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21093	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo these Processions also belonged the bearing of burning Torches, and
 21094	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCandles, before the Images of the Gods, both amongst the Greeks, and
 21095	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRomans. For afterwards the Emperors of Rome received the same honor; as
 21096	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe read of Caligula, that at his reception to the Empire, he was carried
 21097	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom Misenum to Rome, in the midst of a throng of People, the wayes
 21098	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeset with Altars, and Beasts for Sacrifice, and burning Torches: And
 21099	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Caracalla that was received into Alexandria with Incense, and with
 21100	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcasting of Flowers, and Dadouchiais, that is, with Torches; for Dadochoi
 21101	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere they that amongst the Greeks carried Torches lighted in the
 21102	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProcessions of their Gods: And in processe of time, the devout, but
 21103	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tignorant People, did many times honor their Bishops with the like
 21104	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpompe of Wax Candles, and the Images of our Saviour, and the Saints,
 21105	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconstantly, in the Church it self. And thus came in the use of Wax
 21106	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCandles; and was also established by some of the ancient Councells.
 21107	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21108	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Heathens had also their Aqua Lustralis, that is to say, Holy Water.
 21109	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Church of Rome imitates them also in their Holy Dayes. They had
 21110	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Bacchanalia; and we have our Wakes, answering to them: They
 21111	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Saturnalia, and we our Carnevalls, and Shrove-tuesdays liberty
 21112	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Servants: They their Procession of Priapus; wee our fetching in,
 21113	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\terection, and dancing about May-poles; and Dancing is one kind of
 21114	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWorship: They had their Procession called Ambarvalia; and we our
 21115	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProcession about the fields in the Rogation Week. Nor do I think that
 21116	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese are all the Ceremonies that have been left in the Church, from the
 21117	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst conversion of the Gentiles: but they are all that I can for the
 21118	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresent call to mind; and if a man would wel observe that which is
 21119	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdelivered in the Histories, concerning the Religious Rites of the Greeks
 21120	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Romanes, I doubt not but he might find many more of these old empty
 21121	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBottles of Gentilisme, which the Doctors of the Romane Church, either
 21122	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Negligence, or Ambition, have filled up again with the new Wine of
 21123	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristianity, that will not faile in time to break them.
 21124	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21125	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21126	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21127	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XLVI. OF DARKNESSE FROM VAIN PHILOSOPHY, AND FABULOUS TRADITIONS
 21128	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21129	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21130	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21131	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21132	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat Philosophy Is
 21133	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21134	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy Philosophy is understood "the Knowledge acquired by Reasoning, from
 21135	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Manner of the Generation of any thing, to the Properties; or from
 21136	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Properties, to some possible Way of Generation of the same; to the
 21137	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tend to bee able to produce, as far as matter, and humane force permit,
 21138	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch Effects, as humane life requireth." So the Geometrician, from the
 21139	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConstruction of Figures, findeth out many Properties thereof; and from
 21140	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Properties, new Ways of their Construction, by Reasoning; to the end
 21141	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be able to measure Land and Water; and for infinite other uses. So
 21142	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Astronomer, from the Rising, Setting, and Moving of the Sun, and
 21143	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tStarres, in divers parts of the Heavens, findeth out the Causes of Day,
 21144	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Night, and of the different Seasons of the Year; whereby he keepeth
 21145	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan account of Time: And the like of other Sciences.
 21146	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21147	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21148	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21149	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21150	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrudence No Part Of Philosophy
 21151	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21152	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy which Definition it is evident, that we are not to account as any
 21153	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart thereof, that originall knowledge called Experience, in which
 21154	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsisteth Prudence: Because it is not attained by Reasoning, but found
 21155	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas well in Brute Beasts, as in Man; and is but a Memory of successions
 21156	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof events in times past, wherein the omission of every little
 21157	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcircumstance altering the effect, frustrateth the expectation of the
 21158	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmost Prudent: whereas nothing is produced by Reasoning aright, but
 21159	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgenerall, eternall, and immutable Truth.
 21160	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21161	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21162	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21164	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNo False Doctrine Is Part Of Philosophy
 21165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor are we therefore to give that name to any false Conclusions: For he
 21167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Reasoneth aright in words he understandeth, can never conclude an
 21168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tError:
 21169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNo More Is Revelation Supernaturall
 21173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor to that which any man knows by supernaturall Revelation; because it
 21175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis not acquired by Reasoning:
 21176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor Learning Taken Upon Credit Of Authors
 21181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNor that which is gotten by Reasoning from the Authority of Books;
 21183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause it is not by Reasoning from the Cause to the Effect, nor from
 21184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Effect to the Cause; and is not Knowledge, but Faith.
 21185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Beginnings And Progresse Of Philosophy
 21190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe faculty of Reasoning being consequent to the use of Speech, it was
 21192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot possible, but that there should have been some generall Truthes
 21193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfound out by Reasoning, as ancient almost as Language it selfe. The
 21194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSavages of America, are not without some good Morall Sentences; also
 21195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey have a little Arithmetick, to adde, and divide in Numbers not too
 21196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat: but they are not therefore Philosophers. For as there were Plants
 21197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Corn and Wine in small quantity dispersed in the Fields and Woods,
 21198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore men knew their vertue, or made use of them for their nourishment,
 21199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor planted them apart in Fields, and Vineyards; in which time they
 21200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfed on Akorns, and drank Water: so also there have been divers true,
 21201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgenerall, and profitable Speculations from the beginning; as being the
 21202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturall plants of humane Reason: But they were at first but few in
 21203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnumber; men lived upon grosse Experience; there was no Method; that is
 21204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, no Sowing, nor Planting of Knowledge by it self, apart from the
 21205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWeeds, and common Plants of Errour and Conjecture: And the cause of it
 21206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing the want of leasure from procuring the necessities of life, and
 21207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdefending themselves against their neighbours, it was impossible, till
 21208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe erecting of great Common-wealths, it should be otherwise. Leasure
 21209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the mother of Philosophy; and Common-wealth, the mother of Peace, and
 21210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLeasure: Where first were great and flourishing Cities, there was first
 21211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe study of Philosophy. The Gymnosophists of India, the Magi of Persia,
 21212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Priests of Chaldea and Egypt, are counted the most ancient
 21213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophers; and those Countreys were the most ancient of Kingdomes.
 21214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophy was not risen to the Graecians, and other people of the West,
 21215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose Common-wealths (no greater perhaps then Lucca, or Geneva) had
 21216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnever Peace, but when their fears of one another were equall; nor the
 21217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLeasure to observe any thing but one another. At length, when Warre had
 21218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunited many of these Graecian lesser Cities, into fewer, and greater;
 21219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen began Seven Men, of severall parts of Greece, to get the reputation
 21220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof being Wise; some of them for Morall and Politique Sentences; and
 21221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tothers for the learning of the Chaldeans and Egyptians, which was
 21222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAstronomy, and Geometry. But we hear not yet of any Schools of
 21223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophy.
 21224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Schools Of Philosophy Amongst The Athenians
 21229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter the Athenians by the overthrow of the Persian Armies, had gotten
 21231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Dominion of the Sea; and thereby, of all the Islands, and Maritime
 21232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCities of the Archipelago, as well of Asia as Europe; and were grown
 21233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twealthy; they that had no employment, neither at home, nor abroad, had
 21234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlittle else to employ themselves in, but either (as St. Luke says, Acts
 21235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t17.21.) "in telling and hearing news," or in discoursing of Philosophy
 21236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpubliquely to the youth of the City. Every Master took some place for
 21237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat purpose. Plato in certaine publique Walks called Academia, from one
 21238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAcademus: Aristotle in the Walk of the Temple of Pan, called Lycaeum:
 21239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tothers in the Stoa, or covered Walk, wherein the Merchants Goods were
 21240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbrought to land: others in other places; where they spent the time of
 21241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Leasure, in teaching or in disputing of their Opinions: and some
 21242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin any place, where they could get the youth of the City together to
 21243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thear them talk. And this was it which Carneades also did at Rome, when
 21244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the was Ambassadour: which caused Cato to advise the Senate to dispatch
 21245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim quickly, for feare of corrupting the manners of the young men that
 21246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdelighted to hear him speak (as they thought) fine things.
 21247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom this it was, that the place where any of them taught, and disputed,
 21249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas called Schola, which in their Tongue signifieth Leasure; and their
 21250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDisputations, Diatribae, that is to say, Passing of The Time. Also the
