 21251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophers themselves had the name of their Sects, some of them from
 21252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese their Schools: For they that followed Plato's Doctrine, were
 21253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Academiques; The followers of Aristotle, Peripatetiques, from the
 21254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWalk hee taught in; and those that Zeno taught, Stoiques, from the Stoa:
 21255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas if we should denominate men from More-fields, from Pauls-Church, and
 21256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the Exchange, because they meet there often, to prate and loyter.
 21257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse, men were so much taken with this custome, that in time
 21259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit spread it selfe over all Europe, and the best part of Afrique; so as
 21260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere were Schools publiquely erected, and maintained for Lectures, and
 21261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDisputations, almost in every Common-wealth.
 21262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf The Schools Of The Jews
 21267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere were also Schools, anciently, both before, and after the time of
 21269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour, amongst the Jews: but they were Schools of their Law. For
 21270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough they were called Synagogues, that is to say, Congregations of the
 21271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeople; yet in as much as the Law was every Sabbath day read, expounded,
 21272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand disputed in them, they differed not in nature, but in name onely
 21273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom Publique Schools; and were not onely in Jerusalem, but in every
 21274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCity of the Gentiles, where the Jews inhabited. There was such a Schoole
 21275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat Damascus, whereinto Paul entred, to persecute. There were others at
 21276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAntioch, Iconium and Thessalonica, whereinto he entred, to dispute:
 21277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd such was the Synagogue of the Libertines, Cyrenians, Alexandrians,
 21278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCilicians, and those of Asia; that is to say, the Schoole of Libertines,
 21279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand of Jewes, that were strangers in Jerusalem: And of this Schoole they
 21280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere that disputed with Saint Steven.
 21281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Schoole Of Graecians Unprofitable
 21286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut what has been the Utility of those Schools? what Science is there
 21288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat this day acquired by their Readings and Disputings? That wee have
 21289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Geometry, which is the Mother of all Naturall Science, wee are not
 21290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tindebted for it to the Schools. Plato that was the best Philosopher
 21291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Greeks, forbad entrance into his Schoole, to all that were not
 21292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready in some measure Geometricians. There were many that studied that
 21293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScience to the great advantage of mankind: but there is no mention of
 21294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Schools; nor was there any Sect of Geometricians; nor did they
 21295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen passe under the name of Philosophers. The naturall Philosophy
 21296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof those Schools, was rather a Dream than Science, and set forth in
 21297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsenselesse and insignificant Language; which cannot be avoided by
 21298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose that will teach Philosophy, without having first attained great
 21299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknowledge in Geometry: For Nature worketh by Motion; the Wayes,
 21300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Degrees whereof cannot be known, without the knowledge of the
 21301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProportions and Properties of Lines, and Figures. Their Morall
 21302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophy is but a description of their own Passions. For the rule of
 21303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tManners, without Civill Government, is the Law of Nature; and in it,
 21304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law Civill; that determineth what is Honest, and Dishonest; what is
 21305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJust, and Unjust; and generally what is Good, and Evill: whereas they
 21306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmake the Rules of Good, and Bad, by their own Liking, and Disliking: By
 21307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich means, in so great diversity of taste, there is nothing generally
 21308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagreed on; but every one doth (as far as he dares) whatsoever seemeth
 21309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgood in his own eyes, to the subversion of Common-wealth. Their Logique
 21310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich should bee the Method of Reasoning, is nothing else but Captions
 21311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Words, and Inventions how to puzzle such as should goe about to pose
 21312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem. To conclude there is nothing so absurd, that the old Philosophers
 21313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as Cicero saith, who was one of them) have not some of them maintained.
 21314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd I beleeve that scarce any thing can be more absurdly said
 21315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin naturall Philosophy, than that which now is called Aristotles
 21316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMetaphysiques, nor more repugnant to Government, than much of that hee
 21317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath said in his Politiques; nor more ignorantly, than a great part of
 21318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Ethiques.
 21319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Schools Of The Jews Unprofitable
 21324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Schoole of the Jews, was originally a Schoole of the Law of Moses;
 21326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho commanded (Deut. 31.10.) that at the end of every seventh year, at
 21327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Feast of the Tabernacles, it should be read to all the people, that
 21328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey might hear, and learn it: Therefore the reading of the Law (which
 21329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas in use after the Captivity) every Sabbath day, ought to have had
 21330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno other end, but the acquainting of the people with the Commandements
 21331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich they were to obey, and to expound unto them the writings of the
 21332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets. But it is manifest, by the many reprehensions of them by
 21333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tour Saviour, that they corrupted the Text of the Law with their
 21334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfalse Commentaries, and vain Traditions; and so little understood the
 21335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProphets, that they did neither acknowledge Christ, nor the works he
 21336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdid; for which the Prophets prophecyed. So that by their Lectures and
 21337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDisputations in their Synagogues, they turned the Doctrine of their Law
 21338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto a Phantasticall kind of Philosophy, concerning the incomprehensible
 21339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnature of God, and of Spirits; which they compounded of the Vain
 21340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophy and Theology of the Graecians, mingled with their own
 21341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfancies, drawn from the obscurer places of the Scripture, and which
 21342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmight most easily bee wrested to their purpose; and from the Fabulous
 21343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTraditions of their Ancestors.
 21344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUniversity What It Is
 21349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat which is now called an University, is a Joyning together, and an
 21351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIncorporation under one Government of many Publique Schools, in one and
 21352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe same Town or City. In which, the principal Schools were ordained for
 21353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe three Professions, that is to say, of the Romane Religion, of the
 21354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRomane Law, and of the Art of Medicine. And for the study of Philosophy
 21355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit hath no otherwise place, then as a handmaid to the Romane Religion:
 21356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd since the Authority of Aristotle is onely current there, that
 21357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstudy is not properly Philosophy, (the nature whereof dependeth not on
 21358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthors,) but Aristotelity. And for Geometry, till of very late times it
 21359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad no place at all; as being subservient to nothing but rigide Truth.
 21360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd if any man by the ingenuity of his owne nature, had attained to any
 21361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdegree of perfection therein, hee was commonly thought a Magician, and
 21362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Art Diabolicall.
 21363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tErrors Brought Into Religion From Aristotles Metaphysiques
 21368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNow to descend to the particular Tenets of Vain Philosophy, derived to
 21370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Universities, and thence into the Church, partly from Aristotle,
 21371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpartly from Blindnesse of understanding; I shall first consider their
 21372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrinciples. There is a certain Philosophia Prima, on which all other
 21373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophy ought to depend; and consisteth principally, in right
 21374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlimiting of the significations of such Appellations, or Names, as are
 21375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof all others the most Universall: Which Limitations serve to avoid
 21376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tambiguity, and aequivocation in Reasoning; and are commonly called
 21377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDefinitions; such as are the Definitions of Body, Time, Place, Matter,
 21378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tForme, Essence, Subject, Substance, Accident, Power, Act, Finite,
 21379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInfinite, Quantity, Quality, Motion, Action, Passion, and divers others,
 21380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessary to the explaining of a mans Conceptions concerning the Nature
 21381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Generation of Bodies. The Explication (that is, the setling of the
 21382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeaning) of which, and the like Terms, is commonly in the Schools called
 21383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMetaphysiques; as being a part of the Philosophy of Aristotle, which
 21384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath that for title: but it is in another sense; for there it signifieth
 21385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas much, as "Books written, or placed after his naturall Philosophy:"
 21386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the Schools take them for Books Of Supernaturall Philosophy: for the
 21387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tword Metaphysiques will bear both these senses. And indeed that which is
 21388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere written, is for the most part so far from the possibility of being
 21389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood, and so repugnant to naturall Reason, that whosoever
 21390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthinketh there is any thing to bee understood by it, must needs think it
 21391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsupernaturall.
 21392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tErrors Concerning Abstract Essences
 21397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom these Metaphysiques, which are mingled with the Scripture to make
 21399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSchoole Divinity, wee are told, there be in the world certaine
 21400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEssences separated from Bodies, which they call Abstract Essences, and
 21401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubstantiall Formes: For the Interpreting of which Jargon, there is
 21402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tneed of somewhat more than ordinary attention in this place. Also I
 21403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\task pardon of those that are not used to this kind of Discourse, for
 21404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapplying my selfe to those that are. The World, (I mean not the Earth
 21405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely, that denominates the Lovers of it Worldly Men, but the Universe,
 21406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, the whole masse of all things that are) is Corporeall, that
 21407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis to say, Body; and hath the dimensions of Magnitude, namely, Length,
 21408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBredth, and Depth: also every part of Body, is likewise Body, and hath
 21409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe like dimensions; and consequently every part of the Universe,
 21410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Body, and that which is not Body, is no part of the Universe: And
 21411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause the Universe is all, that which is no part of it, is Nothing;
 21412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand consequently No Where. Nor does it follow from hence, that Spirits
 21413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Nothing: for they have dimensions, and are therefore really Bodies;
 21414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough that name in common Speech be given to such Bodies onely, as are
 21415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvisible, or palpable; that is, that have some degree of Opacity: But for
 21416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpirits, they call them Incorporeall; which is a name of more honour,
 21417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand may therefore with more piety bee attributed to God himselfe; in
 21418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom wee consider not what Attribute expresseth best his Nature, which
 21419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Incomprehensible; but what best expresseth our desire to honour him.
 21420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo know now upon what grounds they say there be Essences Abstract, or
 21422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubstantiall Formes, wee are to consider what those words do properly
 21423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsignifie. The use of Words, is to register to our selves, and make
 21424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest to others the Thoughts and Conceptions of our Minds. Of which
 21425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWords, some are the names of the Things conceived; as the names of all
 21426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsorts of Bodies, that work upon the Senses, and leave an Impression in
 21427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Imagination: Others are the names of the Imaginations themselves;
 21428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is to say, of those Ideas, or mentall Images we have of all things
 21429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twee see, or remember: And others againe are names of Names; or of
 21430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdifferent sorts of Speech: As Universall, Plurall, Singular, Negation,
 21431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTrue, False, Syllogisme, Interrogation, Promise, Covenant, are the names
 21432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof certain Forms of Speech. Others serve to shew the Consequence, or
 21433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRepugnance of one name to another; as when one saith, "A Man is a Body,"
 21434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thee intendeth that the name of Body is necessarily consequent to the
 21435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tname of Man; as being but severall names of the same thing, Man; which
 21436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsequence is signified by coupling them together with the word Is.
 21437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as wee use the Verbe Is; so the Latines use their Verbe Est, and
 21438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Greeks their Esti through all its Declinations. Whether all other
 21439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNations of the world have in their severall languages a word that
 21440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanswereth to it, or not, I cannot tell; but I am sure they have not need
 21441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof it: For the placing of two names in order may serve to signifie their
 21442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsequence, if it were the custome, (for Custome is it, that give words
 21443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir force,) as well as the words Is, or Bee, or Are, and the like.
 21444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd if it were so, that there were a Language without any Verb
 21446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanswerable to Est, or Is, or Bee; yet the men that used it would bee
 21447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot a jot the lesse capable of Inferring, Concluding, and of all kind of
 21448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReasoning, than were the Greeks, and Latines. But what then would become
 21449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof these Terms, of Entity, Essence, Essentiall, Essentially, that are
 21450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tderived from it, and of many more that depend on these, applyed as most
 21451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcommonly they are? They are therefore no Names of Things; but Signes, by
 21452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich wee make known, that wee conceive the Consequence of one name or
 21453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAttribute to another: as when we say, "a Man, is, a living Body," wee
 21454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmean not that the Man is one thing, the Living Body another, and the Is,
 21455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Beeing a third: but that the Man, and the Living Body, is the same
 21456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthing: because the Consequence, "If hee bee a Man, hee is a living
 21457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBody," is a true Consequence, signified by that word Is. Therefore, to
 21458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee a Body, to Walke, to bee Speaking, to Live, to See, and the like
 21459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInfinitives; also Corporeity, Walking, Speaking, Life, Sight, and the
 21460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike, that signifie just the same, are the names of Nothing; as I have
 21461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\telsewhere more amply expressed.
 21462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut to what purpose (may some man say) is such subtilty in a work of
 21464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis nature, where I pretend to nothing but what is necessary to the
 21465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoctrine of Government and Obedience? It is to this purpose, that men
 21466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay no longer suffer themselves to be abused, by them, that by this
 21467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoctrine of Separated Essences, built on the Vain Philosophy of
 21468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAristotle, would fright them from Obeying the Laws of their Countrey,
 21469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith empty names; as men fright Birds from the Corn with an empty
 21470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoublet, a hat, and a crooked stick. For it is upon this ground, that
 21471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen a Man is dead and buried, they say his Soule (that is his Life) can
 21472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twalk separated from his Body, and is seen by night amongst the graves.
 21473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tUpon the same ground they say, that the Figure, and Colour, and Tast of
 21474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta peece of Bread, has a being, there, where they say there is no Bread:
 21475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd upon the same ground they say, that Faith, and Wisdome, and other
 21476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tVertues are sometimes powred into a man, sometimes blown into him from
 21477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHeaven; as if the Vertuous, and their Vertues could be asunder; and a
 21478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat many other things that serve to lessen the dependance of Subjects
 21479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton the Soveraign Power of their Countrey. For who will endeavour to obey
 21480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Laws, if he expect Obedience to be Powred or Blown into him? Or who
 21481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill not obey a Priest, that can make God, rather than his Soveraign;
 21482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnay than God himselfe? Or who, that is in fear of Ghosts, will not bear
 21483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat respect to those that can make the Holy Water, that drives them
 21484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom him? And this shall suffice for an example of the Errors, which are
 21485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbrought into the Church, from the Entities, and Essences of Aristotle:
 21486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich it may be he knew to be false Philosophy; but writ it as a thing
 21487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsonant to, and corroborative of their Religion; and fearing the fate
 21488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Socrates.
 21489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBeing once fallen into this Error of Separated Essences, they are
 21491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereby necessarily involved in many other absurdities that follow it.
 21492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor seeing they will have these Forms to be reall, they are obliged to
 21493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassign them some place. But because they hold them Incorporeall, without
 21494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall dimension of Quantity, and all men know that Place is Dimension, and
 21495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot to be filled, but by that which is Corporeall; they are driven to
 21496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tuphold their credit with a distinction, that they are not indeed any
 21497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhere Circumscriptive, but Definitive: Which Terms being meer Words, and
 21498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this occasion insignificant, passe onely in Latine, that the vanity
 21499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them may bee concealed. For the Circumscription of a thing, is
 21500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnothing else but the Determination, or Defining of its Place; and so
 21501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth the Terms of the Distinction are the same. And in particular, of
 21502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Essence of a Man, which (they say) is his Soule, they affirm it,
 21503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be All of it in his little Finger, and All of it in every other Part
 21504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(how small soever) of his Body; and yet no more Soule in the Whole Body,
 21505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan in any one of those Parts. Can any man think that God is served
 21506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twith such absurdities? And yet all this is necessary to beleeve,
 21507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto those that will beleeve the Existence of an Incorporeall Soule,
 21508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeparated from the Body.
 21509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd when they come to give account, how an Incorporeall Substance can
 21511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe capable of Pain, and be tormented in the fire of Hell, or Purgatory,
 21512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey have nothing at all to answer, but that it cannot be known how fire
 21513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcan burn Soules.
 21514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, whereas Motion is change of Place, and Incorporeall Substances
 21516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not capable of Place, they are troubled to make it seem possible,
 21517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thow a Soule can goe hence, without the Body to Heaven, Hell, or
 21518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPurgatory; and how the Ghosts of men (and I may adde of their clothes
 21519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich they appear in) can walk by night in Churches, Church-yards, and
 21520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother places of Sepulture. To which I know not what they can answer,
 21521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunlesse they will say, they walke Definitive, not Circumscriptive, or
 21522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSpiritually, not Temporally: for such egregious distinctions are equally
 21523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tapplicable to any difficulty whatsoever.
 21524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNunc-stans
 21529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor the meaning of Eternity, they will not have it to be an Endlesse
 21531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuccession of Time; for then they should not be able to render a reason
 21532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thow Gods Will, and Praeordaining of things to come, should not be before
 21533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Praescience of the same, as the Efficient Cause before the Effect,
 21534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Agent before the Action; nor of many other their bold opinions
 21535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning the Incomprehensible Nature of God. But they will teach us,
 21536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat Eternity is the Standing still of the Present Time, a Nunc-stans
 21537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(as the Schools call it;) which neither they, nor any else understand,
 21538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno more than they would a Hic-stans for an Infinite greatnesse of Place.
 21539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOne Body In Many Places, And Many Bodies In One Place At Once
 21544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd whereas men divide a Body in their thought, by numbring parts of
 21546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit, and in numbring those parts, number also the parts of the Place
 21547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit filled; it cannot be, but in making many parts, wee make also many
 21548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tplaces of those parts; whereby there cannot bee conceived in the mind of
 21549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany man, more, or fewer parts, than there are places for: yet they will
 21550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave us beleeve, that by the Almighty power of God, one body may be at
 21551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone and the same time in many places; and many bodies at one and the
 21552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame time in one place; as if it were an acknowledgment of the Divine
 21553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower, to say, that which is, is not; or that which has been, has not
 21554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeen. And these are but a small part of the Incongruities they are
 21555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tforced to, from their disputing Philosophically, in stead of admiring,
 21556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand adoring of the Divine and Incomprehensible Nature; whose Attributes
 21557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcannot signifie what he is, but ought to signifie our desire to honour
 21558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, with the best Appellations we can think on. But they that venture
 21559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto reason of his Nature, from these Attributes of Honour, losing their
 21560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstanding in the very first attempt, fall from one Inconvenience
 21561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto another, without end, and without number; in the same manner,
 21562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas when a man ignorant of the Ceremonies of Court, comming into the
 21563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpresence of a greater Person than he is used to speak to, and stumbling
 21564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat his entrance, to save himselfe from falling, lets slip his Cloake;
 21565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto recover his Cloake, lets fall his Hat; and with one disorder after
 21566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, discovers his astonishment and rusticity.
 21567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbsurdities In Naturall Philosophy, As Gravity The Cause Of Heavinesse
 21572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThen for Physiques, that is, the knowledge of the subordinate, and
 21574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsecundary causes of naturall events; they render none at all, but empty
 21575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twords. If you desire to know why some kind of bodies sink naturally
 21576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdownwards toward the Earth, and others goe naturally from it; The
 21577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSchools will tell you out of Aristotle, that the bodies that sink
 21578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdownwards, are Heavy; and that this Heavinesse is it that causes them to
 21579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdescend: But if you ask what they mean by Heavinesse, they will define
 21580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit to bee an endeavour to goe to the center of the Earth: so that the
 21581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcause why things sink downward, is an Endeavour to be below: which is
 21582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas much as to say, that bodies descend, or ascend, because they doe.
 21583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOr they will tell you the center of the Earth is the place of Rest, and
 21584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConservation for Heavy things; and therefore they endeavour to be there:
 21585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAs if Stones, and Metalls had a desire, or could discern the place they
 21586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould bee at, as Man does; or loved Rest, as Man does not; or that a
 21587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeece of Glasse were lesse safe in the Window, than falling into the
 21588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tStreet.
 21589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tQuantity Put Into Body Already Made
 21594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf we would know why the same Body seems greater (without adding to it)
 21596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone time, than another; they say, when it seems lesse, it is Condensed;
 21597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen greater, Rarefied. What is that Condensed, and Rarefied? Condensed,
 21598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis when there is in the very same Matter, lesse Quantity than before;
 21599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Rarefied, when more. As if there could be Matter, that had not some
 21600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdetermined Quantity; when Quantity is nothing else but the Determination
 21601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Matter; that is to say of Body, by which we say one Body is greater,
 21602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor lesser than another, by thus, or thus much. Or as if a Body were made
 21603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout any Quantity at all, and that afterwards more, or lesse were put
 21604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinto it, according as it is intended the Body should be more, or lesse
 21605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDense.

 21622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Apparitions of objects; which when they be Apparitions to the Eye, is
 21623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSight; when to the Eare, Hearing; to the Palate, Tast; to the Nostrill,

 21631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor cause of the Will, to doe any particular action, which is called

 21644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIgnorance, but disguised in other words: As when they say, Fortune is
 21645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe cause of things contingent; that is, of things whereof they know no

 21649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tQualities, and other like Termes, which signifie neither the Agent that
 21650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproduceth them, nor the Operation by which they are produced.

 21653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere was never any; nor needed St. Paul to give us warning to avoid it.

 21658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOne Makes The Things Incongruent, Another The Incongruity
 21659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd for their Morall, and Civill Philosophy, it hath the same, or
 21661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreater absurdities. If a man doe an action of Injustice, that is to
 21662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, an action contrary to the Law, God they say is the prime cause of

 21665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto the Law. This is Vain Philosophy. A man might as well say, that one
 21666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman maketh both a streight line, and a crooked, and another maketh their
 21667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIncongruity. And such is the Philosophy of all men that resolve of their
 21668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConclusions, before they know their Premises; pretending to comprehend,
 21669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat which is Incomprehensible; and of Attributes of Honour to make
 21670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAttributes of Nature; as this distinction was made to maintain the
 21671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine of Free-Will, that is, of a Will of man, not subject to the
 21672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWill of God.

 21676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivate Appetite The Rule Of Publique Good:
 21678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAristotle, and other Heathen Philosophers define Good, and Evill, by the
 21680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAppetite of men; and well enough, as long as we consider them governed
 21681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tevery one by his own Law: For in the condition of men that have no other
 21682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw but their own Appetites, there can be no generall Rule of Good, and
 21683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEvill Actions. But in a Common-wealth this measure is false: Not the
 21684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAppetite of Private men, but the Law, which is the Will and Appetite of
 21685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe State is the measure. And yet is this Doctrine still practised; and
 21686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen judge the Goodnesse, or Wickednesse of their own, and of other mens
 21687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tactions, and of the actions of the Common-wealth it selfe, by their own
 21688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPassions; and no man calleth Good or Evill, but that which is so in his
 21689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town eyes, without any regard at all to the Publique Laws; except onely
 21690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonks, and Friers, that are bound by Vow to that simple obedience to
 21691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Superiour, to which every Subject ought to think himself bound by
 21692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law of Nature to the Civill Soveraign. And this private measure of
 21693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGood, is a Doctrine, not onely Vain, but also Pernicious to the Publique
 21694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tState.

 21699	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd That Lawfull Marriage Is Unchastity
 21700	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21701	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt is also Vain and false Philosophy, to say the work of Marriage is
 21702	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepugnant to Chastity, or Continence, and by consequence to make them
 21703	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMorall Vices; as they doe, that pretend Chastity, and Continence, for

 21706	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOrders that continually attend the Altar, and administration of the
 21707	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEucharist, a continuall Abstinence from women, under the name of
 21708	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontinuall Chastity, Continence, and Purity. Therefore they call the
 21709	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfull use of Wives, want of Chastity, and Continence; and so make
 21710	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMarriage a Sin, or at least a thing so impure, and unclean, as to render
 21711	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta man unfit for the Altar. If the Law were made because the use of Wives
 21712	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Incontinence, and contrary to Chastity, then all marriage is vice; If
 21713	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause it is a thing too impure, and unclean for a man consecrated to
 21714	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGod; much more should other naturall, necessary, and daily works which
 21715	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall men doe, render men unworthy to bee Priests, because they are more
 21716	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunclean.
 21717	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21718	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut the secret foundation of this prohibition of Marriage of Priests, is
 21719	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot likely to have been laid so slightly, as upon such errours in Morall

 21727	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this world; to which it was necessary to take from them the use of
 21728	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMarriage, because our Saviour saith, that at the coming of his Kingdome
 21729	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Children of God shall "neither Marry, nor bee given in Marriage, but

 21731	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen they had taken on them the name of Spirituall, to have allowed
 21732	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves (when there was no need) the propriety of Wives, had been an

 21738	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd That All Government But Popular, Is Tyranny
 21739	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21740	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom Aristotles Civill Philosophy, they have learned, to call all manner
 21741	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Common-wealths but the Popular, (such as was at that time the state
 21742	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Athens,) Tyranny. All Kings they called Tyrants; and the Aristocracy
 21743	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the thirty Governours set up there by the Lacedemonians that subdued
 21744	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, the thirty Tyrants: As also to call the condition of the people
 21745	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder the Democracy, Liberty. A Tyrant originally signified no more
 21746	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsimply, but a Monarch: But when afterwards in most parts of Greece that
 21747	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkind of government was abolished, the name began to signifie, not onely
 21748	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe thing it did before, but with it, the hatred which the Popular
 21749	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tStates bare towards it: As also the name of King became odious after the
 21750	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdeposing of the Kings in Rome, as being a thing naturall to all men,
 21751	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto conceive some great Fault to be signified in any Attribute, that is
 21752	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiven in despight, and to a great Enemy. And when the same men shall be
 21753	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdispleased with those that have the administration of the Democracy,
 21754	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor Aristocracy, they are not to seek for disgraceful names to expresse
 21755	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir anger in; but call readily the one Anarchy, and the other
 21756	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOligarchy, or the Tyranny Of A Few. And that which offendeth the People,
 21757	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis no other thing, but that they are governed, not as every one of them
 21758	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould himselfe, but as the Publique Representant, be it one Man, or an
 21759	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAssembly of men thinks fit; that is, by an Arbitrary government: for
 21760	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich they give evill names to their Superiors; never knowing (till
 21761	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperhaps a little after a Civill warre) that without such Arbitrary
 21762	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgovernment, such Warre must be perpetuall; and that it is Men, and Arms,
 21763	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot Words, and Promises, that make the Force and Power of the Laws.

 21769	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21770	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore this is another Errour of Aristotles Politiques, that in
 21771	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta wel ordered Common-wealth, not Men should govern, but the Laws. What
 21772	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, that has his naturall Senses, though he can neither write nor read,
 21773	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdoes not find himself governed by them he fears, and beleeves can kill
 21774	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor hurt him when he obeyeth not? or that beleeves the Law can hurt him;
 21775	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, Words, and Paper, without the Hands, and Swords of men? And
 21776	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis is of the number of pernicious Errors: for they induce men, as oft
 21777	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they like not their Governours, to adhaere to those that call them
 21778	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTyrants, and to think it lawfull to raise warre against them: And yet
 21779	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey are many times cherished from the Pulpit, by the Clergy.

 21784	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaws Over The Conscience
 21785	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21786	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere is another Errour in their Civill Philosophy (which they never
 21787	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlearned of Aristotle, nor Cicero, nor any other of the Heathen,) to
 21788	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\textend the power of the Law, which is the Rule of Actions onely, to the
 21789	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery Thoughts, and Consciences of men, by Examination, and Inquisition
 21790	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof what they Hold, notwithstanding the Conformity of their Speech and
 21791	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tActions: By which, men are either punished for answering the truth
 21792	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their thoughts, or constrained to answer an untruth for fear of
 21793	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpunishment. It is true, that the Civill Magistrate, intending to employ
 21794	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta Minister in the charge of Teaching, may enquire of him, if hee bee
 21795	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontent to Preach such, and such Doctrines; and in case of refusall,
 21796	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmay deny him the employment: But to force him to accuse himselfe of
 21797	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOpinions, when his Actions are not by Law forbidden, is against the
 21798	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaw of Nature; and especially in them, who teach, that a man shall bee
 21799	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdamned to Eternall and extream torments, if he die in a false opinion
 21800	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning an Article of the Christian Faith. For who is there, that
 21801	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknowing there is so great danger in an error, when the naturall care
 21802	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof himself, compelleth not to hazard his Soule upon his own judgement,
 21803	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trather than that of any other man that is unconcerned in his damnation?
 21804	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

 21808	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrivate Interpretation Of Law
 21809	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21810	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor a Private man, without the Authority of the Common-wealth, that is
 21811	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, without permission from the Representant thereof, to Interpret
 21812	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Law by his own Spirit, is another Error in the Politiques; but not
 21813	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdrawn from Aristotle, nor from any other of the Heathen Philosophers.
 21814	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor none of them deny, but that in the Power of making Laws, is
 21815	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcomprehended also the Power of Explaining them when there is need. And
 21816	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not the Scriptures, in all places where they are Law, made Law by
 21817	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Authority of the Common-wealth, and consequently, a part of the
 21818	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Law?
 21819	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21820	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOf the same kind it is also, when any but the Soveraign restraineth in
 21821	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany man that power which the Common-wealth hath not restrained: as they
 21822	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo, that impropriate the Preaching of the Gospell to one certain Order
 21823	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men, where the Laws have left it free. If the State give me leave to
 21824	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreach, or teach; that is, if it forbid me not, no man can forbid me.
 21825	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIf I find my selfe amongst the Idolaters of America, shall I that am a
 21826	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChristian, though not in Orders, think it a sin to preach Jesus Christ,
 21827	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttill I have received Orders from Rome? or when I have preached, shall
 21828	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnot I answer their doubts, and expound the Scriptures to them; that is
 21829	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall I not Teach? But for this may some say, as also for administring
 21830	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto them the Sacraments, the necessity shall be esteemed for a sufficient
 21831	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMission; which is true: But this is true also, that for whatsoever,
 21832	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta dispensation is due for the necessity, for the same there needs no
 21833	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdispensation, when there is no Law that forbids it. Therefore to deny
 21834	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthese Functions to those, to whom the Civill Soveraigne hath not denyed
 21835	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthem, is a taking away of a lawfull Liberty, which is contrary to the
 21836	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine of Civill Government.

 21843	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMore examples of Vain Philosophy, brought into Religion by the Doctors
 21844	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Schoole-Divinity, might be produced; but other men may if they please
 21845	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobserve them of themselves. I shall onely adde this, that the
 21846	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWritings of Schoole-Divines, are nothing else for the most part, but
 21847	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinsignificant Traines of strange and barbarous words, or words otherwise
 21848	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tused, then in the common use of the Latine tongue; such as would pose
 21849	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCicero, and Varro, and all the Grammarians of ancient Rome. Which if any
 21850	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman would see proved, let him (as I have said once before) see whether
 21851	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the can translate any Schoole-Divine into any of the Modern tongues, as
 21852	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrench, English, or any other copious language: for that which cannot
 21853	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin most of these be made Intelligible, is no Intelligible in the Latine.
 21854	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhich Insignificancy of language, though I cannot note it for false
 21855	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophy; yet it hath a quality, not onely to hide the Truth, but also
 21856	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto make men think they have it, and desist from further search.
 21857	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21858	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t

 21861	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tErrors From Tradition
 21862	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21863	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLastly, for the errors brought in from false, or uncertain History, what
 21864	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis all the Legend of fictitious Miracles, in the lives of the Saints;
 21865	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand all the Histories of Apparitions, and Ghosts, alledged by the
 21866	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctors of the Romane Church, to make good their Doctrines of Hell, and
 21867	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpurgatory, the power of Exorcisme, and other Doctrines which have no
 21868	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twarrant, neither in Reason, nor Scripture; as also all those Traditions
 21869	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich they call the unwritten Word of God; but old Wives Fables?
 21870	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhereof, though they find dispersed somewhat in the Writings of the
 21871	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tancient Fathers; yet those Fathers were men, that might too easily
 21872	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve false reports; and the producing of their opinions for testimony
 21873	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the truth of what they beleeved, hath no other force with them that
 21874	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(according to the Counsell of St. John 1 Epist. chap. 4. verse 1.)
 21875	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texamine Spirits, than in all things that concern the power of the Romane
 21876	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChurch, (the abuse whereof either they suspected not, or had benefit
 21877	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby it,) to discredit their testimony, in respect of too rash beleef of
 21878	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treports; which the most sincere men, without great knowledge of naturall
 21879	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcauses, (such as the Fathers were) are commonly the most subject to: For
 21880	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnaturally, the best men are the least suspicious of fraudulent purposes.
 21881	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGregory the Pope, and S. Bernard have somewhat of Apparitions of Ghosts,
 21882	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat said they were in Purgatory; and so has our Beda: but no where, I
 21883	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeleeve, but by report from others. But if they, or any other, relate
 21884	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tany such stories of their own knowledge, they shall not thereby confirm
 21885	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe more such vain reports; but discover their own Infirmity, or Fraud.
 21886	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21887	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21888	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21889	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21890	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuppression Of Reason
 21891	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21892	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWith the Introduction of False, we may joyn also the suppression of True
 21893	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPhilosophy, by such men, as neither by lawfull authority, nor sufficient
 21894	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstudy, are competent Judges of the truth. Our own Navigations make
 21895	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanifest, and all men learned in humane Sciences, now acknowledge there
 21896	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare Antipodes: And every day it appeareth more and more, that Years, and
 21897	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDayes are determined by Motions of the Earth. Neverthelesse, men that
 21898	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave in their Writings but supposed such Doctrine, as an occasion to
 21899	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlay open the reasons for, and against it, have been punished for it
 21900	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby Authority Ecclesiasticall. But what reason is there for it? Is it
 21901	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbecause such opinions are contrary to true Religion? that cannot be,
 21902	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif they be true. Let therefore the truth be first examined by competent
 21903	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJudges, or confuted by them that pretend to know the contrary. Is
 21904	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit because they be contrary to the Religion established? Let them be
 21905	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsilenced by the Laws of those, to whom the Teachers of them are subject;
 21906	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat is, by the Laws Civill: For disobedience may lawfully be punished
 21907	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin them, that against the Laws teach even true Philosophy. Is it because
 21908	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey tend to disorder in Government, as countenancing Rebellion, or
 21909	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSedition? then let them be silenced, and the Teachers punished by vertue
 21910	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof his power to whom the care of the Publique quiet is committed; which
 21911	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis the Authority Civill. For whatsoever Power Ecclesiastiques take upon
 21912	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves (in any place where they are subject to the State) in their
 21913	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\town Right, though they call it Gods Right, is but Usurpation.
 21914	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21915	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21916	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21917	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCHAPTER XLVII. OF THE BENEFIT THAT PROCEEDETH FROM SUCH DARKNESSE,
 21918	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21919	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAND TO WHOM IT ACCREWETH
 21920	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21921	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21922	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21923	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21924	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHe That Receiveth Benefit By A Fact, Is Presumed To Be The Author
 21925	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21926	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCicero maketh honorable mention of one of the Cassii, a severe Judge
 21927	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tamongst the Romans, for a custome he had, in Criminal causes, (when the
 21928	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttestimony of the witnesses was not sufficient,) to ask the Accusers,
 21929	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCui Bono; that is to say, what Profit, Honor, or other Contentment, the
 21930	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\taccused obtained, or expected by the Fact. For amongst Praesumptions,
 21931	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthere is none that so evidently declareth the Author, as doth the
 21932	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBENEFIT of the Action. By the same rule I intend in this place to
 21933	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texamine, who they may be, that have possessed the People so long in this
 21934	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart of Christendome, with these Doctrines, contrary to the Peaceable
 21935	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSocieties of Mankind.
 21936	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21937	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21938	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21939	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21940	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat The Church Militant Is The Kingdome Of God, Was First Taught By
 21941	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21942	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Church Of Rome
 21943	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21944	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd first, to this Error, That The Present Church Now Militant On Earth,
 21945	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIs The Kingdome Of God, (that is, the Kingdome of Glory, or the Land of
 21946	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPromise; not the Kingdome of Grace, which is but a Promise of the
 21947	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLand,) are annexed these worldly Benefits, First, that the Pastors,
 21948	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Teachers of the Church, are entitled thereby, as Gods Publique
 21949	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinisters, to a Right of Governing the Church; and consequently (because
 21950	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Church, and Common-wealth are the same Persons) to be Rectors, and
 21951	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tGovernours of the Common-wealth. By this title it is, that the Pope
 21952	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprevailed with the subjects of all Christian Princes, to beleeve, that
 21953	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto disobey him, was to disobey Christ himselfe; and in all differences
 21954	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetween him and other Princes, (charmed with the word Power Spirituall,)
 21955	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto abandon their lawfull Soveraigns; which is in effect an universall
 21956	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMonarchy over all Christendome. For though they were first invested in
 21957	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe right of being Supreme Teachers of Christian Doctrine, by, and
 21958	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunder Christian Emperors, within the limits of the Romane Empire (as is
 21959	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tacknowledged by themselves) by the title of Pontifex Maximus, who was an
 21960	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOfficer subject to the Civill State; yet after the Empire was divided,
 21961	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand dissolved, it was not hard to obtrude upon the people already
 21962	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubject to them, another Title, namely, the Right of St. Peter; not
 21963	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tonely to save entire their pretended Power; but also to extend the same
 21964	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tover the same Christian Provinces, though no more united in the Empire
 21965	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Rome. This Benefit of an Universall Monarchy, (considering the desire
 21966	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof men to bear Rule) is a sufficient Presumption, that the popes that
 21967	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpretended to it, and for a long time enjoyed it, were the Authors of
 21968	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Doctrine, by which it was obtained; namely, that the Church now
 21969	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ton Earth, is the Kingdome of Christ. For that granted, it must be
 21970	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunderstood, that Christ hath some Lieutenant amongst us, by whom we are
 21971	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be told what are his Commandements.
 21972	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 21973	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAfter that certain Churches had renounced this universall Power of the
 21974	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPope, one would expect in reason, that the Civill Soveraigns in all
 21975	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthose Churches, should have recovered so much of it, as (before they had
 21976	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunadvisedly let it goe) was their own Right, and in their own hands.
 21977	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd in England it was so in effect; saving that they, by whom the Kings
 21978	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadministred the Government of Religion, by maintaining their imployment
 21979	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto be in Gods Right, seemed to usurp, if not a Supremacy, yet an
 21980	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIndependency on the Civill Power: and they but seemed to usurp it, in
 21981	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas much as they acknowledged a Right in the King, to deprive them of the
 21982	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExercise of their Functions at his pleasure.

 21996	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Gods publique Service in his own Kingdom? and with force to resist
 21997	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim, when he with force endeavoureth to correct them? Or what is it,
 21998	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twithout Authority from the Civill Soveraign, to excommunicate any
 21999	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperson, but to take from him his Lawfull Liberty, that is, to usurpe
 22000	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan unlawfull Power over their Brethren? The Authors therefore of this
 22001	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDarknesse in Religion, are the Romane, and the Presbyterian Clergy.

 22163	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, there was no humane remedy to be applyed, that any man could
