 22165	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin his good time to destroy all the Machinations of men against the
 22166	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTruth, wee are to attend his good pleasure, that suffereth many times
 22167	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe prosperity of his enemies, together with their ambition, to grow
 22168	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto such a height, as the violence thereof openeth the eyes, which the
 22169	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twarinesse of their predecessours had before sealed up, and makes men
 22170	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tby too much grasping let goe all, as Peters net was broken, by the
 22171	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstruggling of too great a multitude of Fishes; whereas the Impatience
 22172	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof those, that strive to resist such encroachment, before their Subjects
 22173	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\teyes were opened, did but encrease the power they resisted. I doe not
 22174	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore blame the Emperour Frederick for holding the stirrop to our
 22175	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcountryman Pope Adrian; for such was the disposition of his subjects
 22176	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen, as if hee had not doe it, hee was not likely to have succeeded in
 22177	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Empire: But I blame those, that in the beginning, when their power
 22178	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas entire, by suffering such Doctrines to be forged in the Universities
 22179	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof their own Dominions, have holden the Stirrop to all the succeeding
 22180	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPopes, whilest they mounted into the Thrones of all Christian
 22181	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraigns, to ride, and tire, both them, and their people, at their
 22182	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpleasure.
 22183	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22184	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut as the Inventions of men are woven, so also are they ravelled out;
 22185	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe way is the same, but the order is inverted: The web begins at the
 22186	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst Elements of Power, which are Wisdom, Humility, Sincerity, and
 22187	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother vertues of the Apostles, whom the people converted, obeyed, out
 22188	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Reverence, not by Obligation: Their Consciences were free, and their
 22189	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWords and Actions subject to none but the Civill Power. Afterwards the
 22190	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresbyters (as the Flocks of Christ encreased) assembling to consider
 22191	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat they should teach, and thereby obliging themselves to teach nothing
 22192	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the Decrees of their Assemblies, made it to be thought the
 22193	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople were thereby obliged to follow their Doctrine, and when
 22194	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey refused, refused to keep them company, (that was then called
 22195	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExcommunication,) not as being Infidels, but as being disobedient: And
 22196	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis was the first knot upon their Liberty. And the number of Presbyters
 22197	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tencreasing, the Presbyters of the chief City or Province, got themselves
 22198	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tan authority over the parochiall Presbyters, and appropriated to
 22199	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves the names of Bishops: And this was a second knot on Christian
 22200	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLiberty. Lastly, the Bishop of Rome, in regard of the Imperiall City,
 22201	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttook upon him an Authority (partly by the wills of the Emperours
 22202	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthemselves, and by the title of Pontifex Maximus, and at last when the
 22203	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEmperours were grown weak, by the priviledges of St. Peter) over all
 22204	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tother Bishops of the Empire: Which was the third and last knot, and the
 22205	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhole Synthesis and Construction of the Pontificall Power.
 22206	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22207	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd therefore the Analysis, or Resolution is by the same way; but
 22208	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeginning with the knot that was last tyed; as wee may see in the
 22209	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdissolution of the praeterpoliticall Church Government in England.
 22210	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22211	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFirst, the Power of the Popes was dissolved totally by Queen Elizabeth;
 22212	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand the Bishops, who before exercised their Functions in Right of the
 22213	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPope, did afterwards exercise the same in Right of the Queen and her
 22214	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuccessours; though by retaining the phrase of Jure Divino, they were
 22215	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought to demand it by immediate Right from God: And so was untyed the
 22216	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfirst knot. After this, the Presbyterians lately in England obtained the
 22217	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tputting down of Episcopacy: And so was the second knot dissolved:
 22218	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd almost at the same time, the Power was taken also from the
 22219	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPresbyterians: And so we are reduced to the Independency of the
 22220	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPrimitive Christians to follow Paul, or Cephas, or Apollos, every man
 22221	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas he liketh best: Which, if it be without contention, and without
 22222	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeasuring the Doctrine of Christ, by our affection to the Person of his
 22223	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMinister, (the fault which the Apostle reprehended in the Corinthians,)
 22224	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis perhaps the best: First, because there ought to be no Power over the
 22225	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConsciences of men, but of the Word it selfe, working Faith in every
 22226	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tone, not alwayes according to the purpose of them that Plant and Water,
 22227	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut of God himself, that giveth the Increase: and secondly, because it
 22228	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis unreasonable in them, who teach there is such danger in every little
 22229	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tErrour, to require of a man endued with Reason of his own, to follow the
 22230	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReason of any other man, or of the most voices of many other men; Which
 22231	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis little better, then to venture his Salvation at crosse and pile. Nor
 22232	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tought those Teachers to be displeased with this losse of their antient
 22233	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority: For there is none should know better then they, that power is
 22234	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpreserved by the same Vertues by which it is acquired; that is to
 22235	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsay, by Wisdome, Humility, Clearnesse of Doctrine, and sincerity of
 22236	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConversation; and not by suppression of the Naturall Sciences, and
 22237	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Morality of Naturall Reason; nor by obscure Language; nor by
 22238	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArrogating to themselves more Knowledge than they make appear; nor by
 22239	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPious Frauds; nor by such other faults, as in the Pastors of Gods Church
 22240	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare not only Faults, but also scandalls, apt to make men stumble one
 22241	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime or other upon the suppression of their Authority.
 22242	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22243	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22244	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22245	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22246	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tComparison Of The Papacy With The Kingdome Of Fayries
 22247	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22248	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBut after this Doctrine, "that the Church now Militant, is the Kingdome
 22249	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof God spoken of in the Old and New Testament," was received in
 22250	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe World; the ambition, and canvasing for the Offices that belong
 22251	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereunto, and especially for that great Office of being Christs
 22252	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLieutenant, and the Pompe of them that obtained therein the principal
 22253	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Charges, became by degrees so evident, that they lost the
 22254	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinward Reverence due to the Pastorall Function: in so much as the Wisest
 22255	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, of them that had any power in the Civill State, needed nothing but
 22256	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe authority of their Princes, to deny them any further Obedience. For,
 22257	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom the time that the Bishop of Rome had gotten to be acknowledged for
 22258	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBishop Universall, by pretence of Succession to St. Peter, their whole
 22259	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tHierarchy, or Kingdome of Darknesse, may be compared not unfitly to
 22260	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Kingdome of Fairies; that is, to the old wives Fables in England,
 22261	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconcerning Ghosts and Spirits, and the feats they play in the night. And
 22262	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tif a man consider the originall of this great Ecclesiasticall Dominion,
 22263	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\the will easily perceive, that the Papacy, is no other, than the Ghost of
 22264	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe deceased Romane Empire, sitting crowned upon the grave thereof: For
 22265	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tso did the Papacy start up on a Sudden out of the Ruines of that Heathen
 22266	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPower.
 22267	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22268	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Language also, which they use, both in the Churches, and in their
 22269	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPublique Acts, being Latine, which is not commonly used by any Nation
 22270	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnow in the world, what is it but the Ghost of the Old Romane Language.
 22271	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22272	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Fairies in what Nation soever they converse, have but one Universall
 22273	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tKing, which some Poets of ours call King Oberon; but the Scripture calls
 22274	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBeelzebub, Prince of Daemons. The Ecclesiastiques likewise, in whose
 22275	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDominions soever they be found, acknowledge but one Universall King, the
 22276	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPope.
 22277	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22278	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Ecclesiastiques are Spirituall men, and Ghostly Fathers. The
 22279	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFairies are Spirits, and Ghosts. Fairies and Ghosts inhabite Darknesse,
 22280	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSolitudes, and Graves. The Ecclesiastiques walke in Obscurity of
 22281	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine, in Monasteries, Churches, and Churchyards.
 22282	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22283	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Ecclesiastiques have their Cathedral Churches; which, in what Towne
 22284	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsoever they be erected, by vertue of Holy Water, and certain Charmes
 22285	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcalled Exorcismes, have the power to make those Townes, cities, that is
 22286	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto say, Seats of Empire. The Fairies also have their enchanted Castles,
 22287	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand certain Gigantique Ghosts, that domineer over the Regions round
 22288	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabout them.
 22289	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22290	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe fairies are not to be seized on; and brought to answer for the hurt
 22291	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey do. So also the Ecclesiastiques vanish away from the Tribunals of
 22292	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Justice.
 22293	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22294	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Ecclesiastiques take from young men, the use of Reason, by certain
 22295	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCharms compounded of Metaphysiques, and Miracles, and Traditions, and
 22296	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbused Scripture, whereby they are good for nothing else, but to execute
 22297	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat they command them. The Fairies likewise are said to take young
 22298	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tChildren out of their Cradles, and to change them into Naturall Fools,
 22299	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich Common people do therefore call Elves, and are apt to mischief.
 22300	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22301	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn what Shop, or Operatory the Fairies make their Enchantment, the old
 22302	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWives have not determined. But the Operatories of the Clergy, are well
 22303	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tenough known to be the Universities, that received their Discipline from
 22304	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAuthority Pontificall.
 22305	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22306	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhen the Fairies are displeased with any body, they are said to
 22307	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsend their Elves, to pinch them. The Ecclesiastiques, when they are
 22308	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdispleased with any Civill State, make also their Elves, that is,
 22309	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSuperstitious, Enchanted Subjects, to pinch their Princes, by preaching
 22310	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSedition; or one Prince enchanted with promises, to pinch another.
 22311	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22312	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Fairies marry not; but there be amongst them Incubi, that have
 22313	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcopulation with flesh and bloud. The Priests also marry not.
 22314	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22315	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThe Ecclesiastiques take the Cream of the Land, by Donations of ignorant
 22316	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen, that stand in aw of them, and by Tythes: So also it is in the Fable
 22317	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Fairies, that they enter into the Dairies, and Feast upon the Cream,
 22318	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich they skim from the Milk.
 22319	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22320	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWhat kind of Money is currant in the Kingdome of Fairies, is not
 22321	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trecorded in the Story. But the Ecclesiastiques in their Receipts accept
 22322	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the same Money that we doe; though when they are to make any Payment,
 22323	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit is in Canonizations, Indulgences, and Masses.
 22324	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22325	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo this, and such like resemblances between the Papacy, and the Kingdome
 22326	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Fairies, may be added this, that as the Fairies have no existence,
 22327	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbut in the Fancies of ignorant people, rising from the Traditions of old
 22328	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWives, or old Poets: so the Spirituall Power of the Pope (without the
 22329	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbounds of his own Civill Dominion) consisteth onely in the Fear that
 22330	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeduced people stand in, of their Excommunication; upon hearing of false
 22331	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMiracles, false Traditions, and false Interpretations of the Scripture.
 22332	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22333	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIt was not therefore a very difficult matter, for Henry 8. by his
 22334	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tExorcisme; nor for Qu. Elizabeth by hers, to cast them out. But who
 22335	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tknows that this Spirit of Rome, now gone out, and walking by Missions
 22336	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthrough the dry places of China, Japan, and the Indies, that yeeld him
 22337	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlittle fruit, may not return, or rather an Assembly of Spirits worse
 22338	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan he, enter, and inhabite this clean swept house, and make the End
 22339	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthereof worse than the beginning? For it is not the Romane Clergy onely,
 22340	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat pretends the Kingdome of God to be of this World, and thereby to
 22341	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave a Power therein, distinct from that of the Civill State. And
 22342	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthis is all I had a designe to say, concerning the Doctrine of the
 22343	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPOLITIQUES. Which when I have reviewed, I shall willingly expose it to
 22344	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe censure of my Countrey.
 22345	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22346	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22347	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22348	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22349	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tA REVIEW, AND CONCLUSION
 22350	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22351	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22352	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFrom the contrariety of some of the Naturall Faculties of the Mind, one
 22353	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto another, as also of one Passion to another, and from their reference
 22354	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Conversation, there has been an argument taken, to inferre an
 22355	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\timpossibility that any one man should be sufficiently disposed to all
 22356	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsorts of Civill duty. The Severity of Judgment, they say, makes men
 22357	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCensorious, and unapt to pardon the Errours and Infirmities of other
 22358	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmen: and on the other side, Celerity of Fancy, makes the thoughts lesse
 22359	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsteddy than is necessary, to discern exactly between Right and Wrong.
 22360	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAgain, in all Deliberations, and in all Pleadings, the faculty of solid
 22361	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tReasoning, is necessary: for without it, the Resolutions of men are
 22362	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trash, and their Sentences unjust: and yet if there be not powerfull
 22363	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEloquence, which procureth attention and Consent, the effect of Reason
 22364	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twill be little. But these are contrary Faculties; the former being
 22365	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgrounded upon principles of Truth; the other upon Opinions already
 22366	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treceived, true, or false; and upon the Passions and Interests of men,
 22367	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhich are different, and mutable.
 22368	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22369	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd amongst the Passions, Courage, (by which I mean the Contempt of
 22370	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWounds, and violent Death) enclineth men to private Revenges, and
 22371	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes to endeavour the unsetling of the Publique Peace; And
 22372	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTimorousnesse, many times disposeth to the desertion of the Publique
 22373	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDefence. Both these they say cannot stand together in the same person.
 22374	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22375	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd to consider the contrariety of mens Opinions, and Manners in
 22376	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgenerall, It is they say, impossible to entertain a constant Civill
 22377	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAmity with all those, with whom the Businesse of the world constrains
 22378	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tus to converse: Which Businesse consisteth almost in nothing else but a
 22379	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tperpetuall contention for Honor, Riches, and Authority.
 22380	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22381	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo which I answer, that these are indeed great difficulties, but not
 22382	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tImpossibilities: For by Education, and Discipline, they may bee, and
 22383	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare sometimes reconciled. Judgment, and Fancy may have place in the
 22384	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsame man; but by turnes; as the end which he aimeth at requireth. As the
 22385	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsraelites in Egypt, were sometimes fastened to their labour of making
 22386	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBricks, and other times were ranging abroad to gather Straw: So also may
 22387	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Judgment sometimes be fixed upon one certain Consideration, and
 22388	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Fancy at another time wandring about the world. So also Reason,
 22389	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Eloquence, (though not perhaps in the Naturall Sciences, yet in the
 22390	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMorall) may stand very well together. For wheresoever there is place for
 22391	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadorning and preferring of Errour, there is much more place for adorning
 22392	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand preferring of Truth, if they have it to adorn. Nor is there any
 22393	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trepugnancy between fearing the Laws, and not fearing a publique Enemy;
 22394	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnor between abstaining from Injury, and pardoning it in others. There is
 22395	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore no such Inconsistence of Humane Nature, with Civill Duties,
 22396	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas some think. I have known cleernesse of Judgment, and largenesse of
 22397	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFancy; strength of Reason, and gracefull Elocution; a Courage for the
 22398	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWarre, and a Fear for the Laws, and all eminently in one man; and that
 22399	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas my most noble and honored friend Mr. Sidney Godolphin; who hating no
 22400	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tman, nor hated of any, was unfortunately slain in the beginning of the
 22401	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlate Civill warre, in the Publique quarrel, by an indiscerned, and an
 22402	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tundiscerning hand.
 22403	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22404	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo the Laws of Nature, declared in the 15. Chapter, I would have this
 22405	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tadded, "That every man is bound by Nature, as much as in him lieth, to
 22406	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprotect in Warre, the Authority, by which he is himself protected in
 22407	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime of Peace." For he that pretendeth a Right of Nature to preserve
 22408	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this owne body, cannot pretend a Right of Nature to destroy him, by whose
 22409	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tstrength he is preserved: It is a manifest contradiction of himselfe.
 22410	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd though this Law may bee drawn by consequence, from some of those
 22411	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat are there already mentioned; yet the Times require to have it
 22412	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinculcated, and remembred.
 22413	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22414	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because I find by divers English Books lately printed, that the
 22415	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill warres have not yet sufficiently taught men, in what point of
 22416	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime it is, that a Subject becomes obliged to the Conquerour; nor what
 22417	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis Conquest; nor how it comes about, that it obliges men to obey his
 22418	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLaws: Therefore for farther satisfaction of men therein, I say, the
 22419	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpoint of time, wherein a man becomes subject of a Conquerour, is that
 22420	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpoint, wherein having liberty to submit to him, he consenteth, either by
 22421	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpresse words, or by other sufficient sign, to be his Subject. When it
 22422	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tis that a man hath the liberty to submit, I have showed before in the
 22423	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tend of the 21. Chapter; namely, that for him that hath no obligation to
 22424	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this former Soveraign but that of an ordinary Subject, it is then, when
 22425	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe means of his life is within the Guards and Garrisons of the Enemy;
 22426	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor it is then, that he hath no longer Protection from him, but is
 22427	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprotected by the adverse party for his Contribution. Seeing
 22428	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttherefore such contribution is every where, as a thing inevitable,
 22429	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(notwithstanding it be an assistance to the Enemy,) esteemed lawfull;
 22430	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas totall Submission, which is but an assistance to the Enemy, cannot
 22431	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe esteemed unlawfull. Besides, if a man consider that they who submit,
 22432	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tassist the Enemy but with part of their estates, whereas they that
 22433	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\trefuse, assist him with the whole, there is no reason to call their
 22434	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubmission, or Composition an Assistance; but rather a Detriment to the
 22435	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEnemy. But if a man, besides the obligation of a Subject, hath taken
 22436	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon him a new obligation of a Souldier, then he hath not the liberty
 22437	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto submit to a new Power, as long as the old one keeps the field, and
 22438	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgiveth him means of subsistence, either in his Armies, or Garrisons:
 22439	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor in this case, he cannot complain of want of Protection, and means to
 22440	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlive as a Souldier: But when that also failes, a Souldier also may seek
 22441	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\this Protection wheresoever he has most hope to have it; and may lawfully
 22442	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubmit himself to his new Master. And so much for the Time when he may
 22443	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdo it lawfully, if hee will. If therefore he doe it, he is undoubtedly
 22444	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbound to be a true Subject: For a Contract lawfully made, cannot
 22445	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlawfully be broken.
 22446	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22447	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tBy this also a man may understand, when it is, that men may be said to
 22448	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe Conquered; and in what the nature of Conquest, and the Right of a
 22449	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConquerour consisteth: For this Submission is it implyeth them all.
 22450	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tConquest, is not the Victory it self; but the Acquisition by Victory,
 22451	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof a Right, over the persons of men. He therefore that is slain, is
 22452	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tOvercome, but not Conquered; He that is taken, and put into prison, or
 22453	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tchaines, is not Conquered, though Overcome; for he is still an Enemy,
 22454	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand may save himself if hee can: But he that upon promise of Obedience,
 22455	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath his Life and Liberty allowed him, is then Conquered, and a Subject;
 22456	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand not before. The Romanes used to say, that their Generall had
 22457	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPacified such a Province, that is to say, in English, Conquered it; and
 22458	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat the Countrey was Pacified by Victory, when the people of it
 22459	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad promised Imperata Facere, that is, To Doe What The Romane People
 22460	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommanded Them: this was to be Conquered. But this promise may be either
 22461	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\texpresse, or tacite: Expresse, by Promise: Tacite, by other signes. As
 22462	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor example, a man that hath not been called to make such an expresse
 22463	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPromise, (because he is one whose power perhaps is not considerable;)
 22464	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tyet if he live under their Protection openly, hee is understood to
 22465	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsubmit himselfe to the Government: But if he live there secretly, he is
 22466	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlyable to any thing that may bee done to a Spie, and Enemy of the State.
 22467	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI say not, hee does any Injustice, (for acts of open Hostility bear not
 22468	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat name); but that he may be justly put to death. Likewise, if a man,
 22469	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhen his Country is conquered, be out of it, he is not Conquered, nor
 22470	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSubject: but if at his return, he submit to the Government, he is bound
 22471	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto obey it. So that Conquest (to define it) is the Acquiring of the
 22472	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRight of Soveraignty by Victory. Which Right, is acquired, in the
 22473	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeoples Submission, by which they contract with the Victor, promising
 22474	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tObedience, for Life and Liberty.
 22475	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22476	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the 29th Chapter I have set down for one of the causes of the
 22477	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDissolutions of Common-wealths, their Imperfect Generation, consisting
 22478	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin the want of an Absolute and Arbitrary Legislative Power; for want
 22479	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof, the Civill Soveraign is fain to handle the Sword of Justice
 22480	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tunconstantly, and as if it were too hot for him to hold: One reason
 22481	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhereof (which I have not there mentioned) is this, That they will all
 22482	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof them justifie the War, by which their Power was at first gotten,
 22483	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand whereon (as they think) their Right dependeth, and not on the
 22484	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPossession. As if, for example, the Right of the Kings of England did
 22485	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdepend on the goodnesse of the cause of William the Conquerour, and upon
 22486	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir lineall, and directest Descent from him; by which means, there
 22487	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twould perhaps be no tie of the Subjects obedience to their Soveraign
 22488	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tat this day in all the world: wherein whilest they needlessely think to
 22489	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tjustifie themselves, they justifie all the successefull Rebellions that
 22490	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAmbition shall at any time raise against them, and their Successors.
 22491	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTherefore I put down for one of the most effectuall seeds of the Death
 22492	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof any State, that the Conquerours require not onely a Submission of
 22493	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmens actions to them for the future, but also an Approbation of all
 22494	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir actions past; when there is scarce a Common-wealth in the world,
 22495	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhose beginnings can in conscience be justified.
 22496	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22497	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd because the name of Tyranny, signifieth nothing more, nor lesse,
 22498	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthan the name of Soveraignty, be it in one, or many men, saving that
 22499	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey that use the former word, are understood to bee angry with them
 22500	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey call Tyrants; I think the toleration of a professed hatred of
 22501	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTyranny, is a Toleration of hatred to Common-wealth in general, and
 22502	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother evill seed, not differing much from the former. For to the
 22503	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tJustification of the Cause of a Conqueror, the Reproach of the Cause
 22504	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Conquered, is for the most part necessary: but neither of them
 22505	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessary for the Obligation of the Conquered. And thus much I have
 22506	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthought fit to say upon the Review of the first and second part of this
 22507	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDiscourse.
 22508	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22509	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the 35th Chapter, I have sufficiently declared out of the Scripture,
 22510	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat in the Common-wealth of the Jewes, God himselfe was made the
 22511	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraign, by Pact with the People; who were therefore called his
 22512	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeculiar People, to distinguish them from the rest of the world, over
 22513	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhom God reigned not by their Consent, but by his own Power: And that
 22514	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this Kingdome Moses was Gods Lieutenant on Earth; and that it was he
 22515	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat told them what Laws God appointed to doe Execution; especially
 22516	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin Capitall Punishments; not then thinking it a matter of so necessary
 22517	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tconsideration, as I find it since. Wee know that generally in all
 22518	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCommon-wealths, the Execution of Corporeall Punishments, was either put
 22519	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon the Guards, or other Souldiers of the Soveraign Power; or given
 22520	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto those, in whom want of means, contempt of honour, and hardnesse of
 22521	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\theart, concurred, to make them sue for such an Office. But amongst the
 22522	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIsraelites it was a Positive Law of God their Soveraign, that he that
 22523	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas convicted of a capitall Crime, should be stoned to death by the
 22524	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPeople; and that the Witnesses should cast the first Stone, and after
 22525	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Witnesses, then the rest of the People. This was a Law that designed
 22526	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twho were to be the Executioners; but not that any one should throw a
 22527	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tStone at him before Conviction and Sentence, where the Congregation
 22528	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twas Judge. The Witnesses were neverthelesse to be heard before they
 22529	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tproceeded to Execution, unlesse the Fact were committed in the presence
 22530	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Congregation it self, or in sight of the lawfull Judges; for
 22531	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthen there needed no other Witnesses but the Judges themselves.
 22532	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNeverthelesse, this manner of proceeding being not throughly understood,
 22533	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thath given occasion to a dangerous opinion, that any man may kill
 22534	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tanother, is some cases, by a Right of Zeal; as if the Executions done
 22535	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon Offenders in the Kingdome of God in old time, proceeded not from
 22536	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Soveraign Command, but from the Authority of Private Zeal: which, if
 22537	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twe consider the texts that seem to favour it, is quite contrary.
 22538	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22539	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFirst, where the Levites fell upon the People, that had made and
 22540	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tworshipped the Golden Calfe, and slew three thousand of them; it was by
 22541	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Commandement of Moses, from the mouth of God; as is manifest, Exod.
 22542	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t32.27. And when the Son of a woman of Israel had blasphemed God, they
 22543	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat heard it, did not kill him, but brought him before Moses, who
 22544	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tput him under custody, till God should give Sentence against him; as
 22545	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tappears, Levit. 25.11, 12. Again, (Numbers 25.6, 7.) when Phinehas
 22546	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tkilled Zimri and Cosbi, it was not by right of Private Zeale: Their
 22547	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCrime was committed in the sight of the Assembly; there needed
 22548	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno Witnesse; the Law was known, and he the heir apparent to the
 22549	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSoveraignty; and which is the principall point, the Lawfulnesse of his
 22550	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAct depended wholly upon a subsequent Ratification by Moses, whereof he
 22551	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thad no cause to doubt. And this Presumption of a future Ratification, is
 22552	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes necessary to the safety [of] a Common-wealth; as in a sudden
 22553	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRebellion, any man that can suppresse it by his own Power in the
 22554	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCountrey where it begins, may lawfully doe it, and provide to have it
 22555	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tRatified, or Pardoned, whilest it is in doing, or after it is done. Also
 22556	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tNumb. 35.30. it is expressely said, "Whosoever shall kill the Murtherer,
 22557	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tshall kill him upon the word of Witnesses:" but Witnesses suppose
 22558	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta formall Judicature, and consequently condemn that pretence of Jus
 22559	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tZelotarum. The Law of Moses concerning him that enticeth to Idolatry,
 22560	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(that is to say, in the Kingdome of God to a renouncing of his
 22561	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAllegiance) (Deut. 13.8.) forbids to conceal him, and commands the
 22562	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAccuser to cause him to be put to death, and to cast the first stone at
 22563	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thim; but not to kill him before he be Condemned. And (Deut. 17. ver.4,
 22564	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t5, 6.) the Processe against Idolatry is exactly set down: For God there
 22565	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tspeaketh to the People, as Judge, and commandeth them, when a man is
 22566	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAccused of Idolatry, to Enquire diligently of the Fact, and finding it
 22567	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttrue, then to Stone him; but still the hand of the Witnesse throweth
 22568	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe first stone. This is not Private Zeal, but Publique Condemnation. In
 22569	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlike manner when a Father hath a rebellious Son, the Law is (Deut. 21.
 22570	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t18.) that he shall bring him before the Judges of the Town, and all the
 22571	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpeople of the Town shall Stone him. Lastly, by pretence of these Laws
 22572	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit was, that St. Steven was Stoned, and not by pretence of Private Zeal:
 22573	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor before hee was carried away to Execution, he had Pleaded his Cause
 22574	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore the High Priest. There is nothing in all this, nor in any other
 22575	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpart of the Bible, to countenance Executions by Private Zeal; which
 22576	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbeing oftentimes but a conjunction of Ignorance and Passion, is against
 22577	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tboth the Justice and Peace of a Common-wealth.
 22578	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22579	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn the 36th Chapter I have said, that it is not declared in what
 22580	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmanner God spake supernaturally to Moses: Not that he spake not to him
 22581	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsometimes by Dreams and Visions, and by a supernaturall Voice, as
 22582	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto other Prophets: For the manner how he spake unto him from the
 22583	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tMercy-seat, is expressely set down (Numbers 7.89.) in these words,
 22584	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t"From that time forward, when Moses entred into the Tabernacle of the
 22585	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCongregation to speak with God, he heard a Voice which spake unto him
 22586	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom over the Mercy-Seate, which is over the Arke of the Testimony, from
 22587	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbetween the Cherubins he spake unto him." But it is not declared in
 22588	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twhat consisted the praeeminence of the manner of Gods speaking to Moses,
 22589	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tabove that of his speaking to other Prophets, as to Samuel, and to
 22590	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAbraham, to whom he also spake by a Voice, (that is, by Vision) Unlesse
 22591	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe difference consist in the cleernesse of the Vision. For Face
 22592	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto Face, and Mouth to Mouth, cannot be literally understood of the
 22593	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInfinitenesse, and Incomprehensibility of the Divine Nature.
 22594	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22595	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd as to the whole Doctrine, I see not yet, but the principles of
 22596	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit are true and proper; and the Ratiocination solid. For I ground the
 22597	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tCivill Right of Soveraigns, and both the Duty and Liberty of Subjects,
 22598	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tupon the known naturall Inclinations of Mankind, and upon the Articles
 22599	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof the Law of Nature; of which no man, that pretends but reason enough
 22600	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tto govern his private family, ought to be ignorant. And for the Power
 22601	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticall of the same Soveraigns, I ground it on such Texts, as
 22602	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tare both evident in themselves, and consonant to the Scope of the whole
 22603	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tScripture. And therefore am perswaded, that he that shall read it with
 22604	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ta purpose onely to be informed, shall be informed by it. But for those
 22605	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthat by Writing, or Publique Discourse, or by their eminent actions,
 22606	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave already engaged themselves to the maintaining of contrary opinions,
 22607	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthey will not bee so easily satisfied. For in such cases, it is naturall
 22608	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfor men, at one and the same time, both to proceed in reading, and to
 22609	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tlose their attention, in the search of objections to that they had read
 22610	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore: Of which, in a time wherein the interests of men are changed
 22611	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t(seeing much of that Doctrine, which serveth to the establishing of a
 22612	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnew Government, must needs be contrary to that which conduced to the
 22613	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdissolution of the old,) there cannot choose but be very many.
 22614	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22615	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tIn that part which treateth of a Christian Common-wealth, there are
 22616	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsome new Doctrines, which, it may be, in a State where the contrary were
 22617	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\talready fully determined, were a fault for a Subject without leave to
 22618	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdivulge, as being an usurpation of the place of a Teacher. But in this
 22619	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, that men call not onely for Peace, but also for Truth, to offer
 22620	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch Doctrines as I think True, and that manifestly tend to Peace and
 22621	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tLoyalty, to the consideration of those that are yet in deliberation, is
 22622	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno more, but to offer New Wine, to bee put into New Cask, that bothe may
 22623	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbe preserved together. And I suppose, that then, when Novelty can breed
 22624	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tno trouble, nor disorder in a State, men are not generally so much
 22625	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tinclined to the reverence of Antiquity, as to preferre Ancient Errors,
 22626	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbefore New and well proved Truth.
 22627	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22628	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThere is nothing I distrust more than my Elocution; which neverthelesse
 22629	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tI am confident (excepting the Mischances of the Presse) is not obscure.
 22630	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tThat I have neglected the Ornament of quoting ancient Poets, Orators,
 22631	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand Philosophers, contrary to the custome of late time, (whether I have
 22632	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdone well or ill in it,) proceedeth from my judgment, grounded on many
 22633	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treasons. For first, all Truth of Doctrine dependeth either upon Reason,
 22634	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tor upon Scripture; both which give credit to many, but never receive it
 22635	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfrom any Writer. Secondly, the matters in question are not of Fact, but
 22636	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof Right, wherein there is no place for Witnesses. There is scarce any
 22637	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof those old Writers, that contradicteth not sometimes both himself,
 22638	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tand others; which makes their Testimonies insufficient. Fourthly,
 22639	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tsuch Opinions as are taken onely upon Credit of Antiquity, are not
 22640	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tintrinsically the Judgment of those that cite them, but Words that
 22641	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tpasse (like gaping) from mouth to mouth. Fiftly, it is many times with a
 22642	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tfraudulent Designe that men stick their corrupt Doctrine with the Cloves
 22643	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tof other mens Wit. Sixtly, I find not that the Ancients they cite, took
 22644	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit for an Ornament, to doe the like with those that wrote before them.
 22645	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSeventhly, it is an argument of Indigestion, when Greek and Latine
 22646	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tSentences unchewed come up again, as they use to doe, unchanged. Lastly,
 22647	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthough I reverence those men of Ancient time, that either have written
 22648	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTruth perspicuously, or set us in a better way to find it out our
 22649	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tselves; yet to the Antiquity it self I think nothing due: For if we will
 22650	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\treverence the Age, the Present is the Oldest. If the Antiquity of the
 22651	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tWriter, I am not sure, that generally they to whom such honor is given,
 22652	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twere more Ancient when they wrote, than I am that am Writing: But if it
 22653	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tbee well considered, the praise of Ancient Authors, proceeds not from
 22654	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe reverence of the Dead, but from the competition, and mutuall envy of
 22655	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Living.
 22656	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22657	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tTo conclude, there is nothing in this whole Discourse, nor in that I
 22658	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twrit before of the same Subject in Latine, as far as I can perceive,
 22659	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcontrary either to the Word of God, or to good Manners; or to the
 22660	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdisturbance of the Publique Tranquillity. Therefore I think it may be
 22661	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tprofitably printed, and more profitably taught in the Universities, in
 22662	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tcase they also think so, to whom the judgment of the same belongeth.
 22663	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tFor seeing the Universities are the Fountains of Civill, and Morall
 22664	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine, from whence the Preachers, and the Gentry, drawing such water
 22665	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas they find, use to sprinkle the same (both from the Pulpit, and in
 22666	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttheir Conversation) upon the People, there ought certainly to be
 22667	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tgreat care taken, to have it pure, both from the Venime of Heathen
 22668	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tPoliticians, and from the Incantation of Deceiving Spirits. And by that
 22669	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tmeans the most men, knowing their Duties, will be the less subject to
 22670	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tserve the Ambition of a few discontented persons, in their purposes
 22671	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tagainst the State; and be the lesse grieved with the Contributions
 22672	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tnecessary for their Peace, and Defence; and the Governours themselves
 22673	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thave the lesse cause, to maintain at the Common charge any greater
 22674	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tArmy, than is necessary to make good the Publique Liberty, against the
 22675	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tInvasions and Encroachments of forraign Enemies.
 22676	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22677	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tAnd thus I have brought to an end my Discourse of Civill and
 22678	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tEcclesiasticall Government, occasioned by the disorders of the present
 22679	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\ttime, without partiality, without application, and without other
 22680	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tdesigne, than to set before mens eyes the mutuall Relation between
 22681	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tProtection and Obedience; of which the condition of Humane Nature, and
 22682	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tthe Laws Divine, (both Naturall and Positive) require an inviolable
 22683	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tobservation. And though in the revolution of States, there can be no
 22684	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tvery good Constellation for Truths of this nature to be born under, (as
 22685	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\thaving an angry aspect from the dissolvers of an old Government, and
 22686	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tseeing but the backs of them that erect a new;) yet I cannot think
 22687	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tit will be condemned at this time, either by the Publique Judge of
 22688	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tDoctrine, or by any that desires the continuance of Publique Peace. And
 22689	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tin this hope I return to my interrupted Speculation of Bodies Naturall;
 22690	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\twherein, (if God give me health to finish it,) I hope the Novelty will
 22691	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tas much please, as in the Doctrine of this Artificiall Body it useth to
 22692	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\toffend. For such Truth, as opposeth no man profit, nor pleasure, is to
 22693	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\tall men welcome.
 22694	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22695	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
 22696	LeviathanbyThomasHobbes.txt\t
